bibl.et: Phytosociology of woody vegetation under different management regimes in Garhwal Himalaya.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, Ecology Laboratory, H.N.B. Garhwal University, Srinagar 246 174, Garhwal (U.P.), India.

ab.p: Species composition, distribution pattern, diversity, concentration of dominance, community coefficient, beta diversity and equitability were investigated in forest grazing land at Pauri (Garhwal), Uttar Pradesh (submontane to alpine climate), under 4 management regimes at the end of a study period of 2 yr. The regimes were: burnt protected (BP), burnt grazed (BG), unburnt protected (UP) and unburnt grazed (UG); the prescribed burning was carried out in February 1986. On the burnt sites, tree, sapling and seedling strata were dominated by Pinus roxburghii, except in the BG site where the seedling stratum was codominated by Quercus leucotrichophora. In the shrub stratum, Berberis asiatica (BP) and Rhus parviflora (BG) dominated. On the UP and UG sites all 3 strata were dominated by Cupressus torulosa, and within the shrubs Berberis asiatica was dominant. On the majority of the sites, most of the trees, saplings, seedlings and shrubs were widely distributed, but only the UG site showed regular distribution in the sapling stratum. The diversity index for the tree stratum was higher on the burnt sites than the unburnt sites. The sapling stratum followed the opposite trend to the tree stratum. The diversity index for the seedling stratum ranged from 1.141 in the UG site to 1.876 in the BG site. The shrub stratum recorded maximum index on BP (2.291) and minimum on UP (1.811). The values of dominance of concentration in general followed an opposite trend to that of the diversity index for each stratum on all the study sites. The maximum similarity in the tree, sapling and shrub strata was recorded between the UP and UG sites. Beta diversity and equitability did not show any proper trend among sites and strata.

index.de: botanical composition\controlled burning\forest management\forest trees\forests\grasslands\grazing\layer structure\seedlings\shrubs\spatial distribution\species diversity\stand structure\synecology\trees\vegetation\woodland grasslands\woody plants

bibl.et: Effect of growth regulators on seedling attributes of Acacia mellifera.
bibl.aa: Department of Seed Technology, Tamil Nadu Agricultural University, Coimbatore 641 003, Tamil Nadu, India.

ab.p: Seeds of Acacia mellifera were collected from a natural stand [in Tamil Nadu], sulfuric acid scarified for 10 min, washed and dried in the shade for 12 h. They were then soaked in individual solutions of 100 or 200 ppm CCC [chlormequat], GA, IAA, kinetin and riboflavin, or combinations of 100 ppm each of GA + CCC, GA + kinetin or GA + riboflavin, for 24 h. The treated seeds were sown in sand medium and germination and seedling growth and vigour recorded after 21 days. Best germination (98%) and seedling growth and vigour were obtained in the 200 ppm GA treatment, followed by kinetin at 100 and 200 ppm. The other treatments all gave better germination and seedling growth than the control water soaking treatment (which gave 74% germination) although the CCC treatments gave only marginally better results than the control.

bibl.et: Conversion fellings and the principles of management in post-fire birch forests of the middle Volga region.
bibl.aa: MarGTU, Russia.

ab.p: Two methods of conversion fellings have been developed for post-fire stands of birch (Betula pendula, B. pubescens), viz. (1) alternate-strip integrated fellings in mature birch stands with an understorey of spruce [Picea abies], and (2) heavy corridor-strip thinnings for middle-aged and maturing stands with medium and large spruce regeneration. Details of the purpose and execution of these two types of fellings are discussed, and experience with them in the Marii E&dotover;l republic is outlined.

index.de: felling\forest fires\forests\silvicultural conversion

bibl.et: The use of growth stimulators.
bibl.aa: OLKh 'Russkii˘ Les', Russia.

ab.p: Studies were made on the pre-treatment of seeds of spruce [Picea abies] with various concentrations of three growth stimulants, viz. Fumar, Cresacin, and Ambiol, and also on the effect of these growth stimulants when sprayed on to the aerial parts of spruce seedlings. For growing plants in the open on sandy nursery soils the seed should be pre-treated with Fumar [dehydroamino acid] or Ambiol [auxin] at concentrations of 1×10-5 and 1×10-4%, or Cresacin [5-hydroxy benzimidazole] at 1×10-4 or 1×10-3%. If necessary, seedlings can be sprayed in the first or second year with Fumar or Cresacin at 1×10-4 or 1×10-3%, or with ambiol at 1×10-5 to 1×10-3%. Recommendations are also made on pre-treatment rates when the plants are to be grown in plastic greenhouses.

bibl.et: Improvement of uniform shelterwood fellings in spruce/birch stands.
bibl.aa: Institut Lesa UrO RAN, Russia.

ab.p: A detailed analysis was made of stand structure and the amount and composition of natural regeneration in various spruce/birch [Picea obovata/Betula alba] stands in the Sverdlovsk region of the Urals. Conditions were best for spruce natural regeneration and advance growth in stands of birch/spruce (9/1) and density 0.5-0.7. Data are presented on the height growth of the spruce regeneration on clear-felled areas and on areas after a first shelterwood felling (removing only spruce). The second (final) shelterwood felling should be carried out in accordance with the particular aims and circumstances, and taking into account the ability of the young spruce to compete with the birch regrowth after the felling; the second shelterwood cut may be as early as 3 years or up to 6-9 years after the first.

bibl.et: Determining the age of maturity for single-resource and multi-resource forest management.
bibl.aa: VNIILM, Russia.

ab.p: Various concepts and definitions of forest maturity are discussed, and two methods of determining economic maturity are compared, viz. financial maturity and financial return. For illustration, these approaches are applied to the long-living Pinus sibirica forests of Siberia, which may be managed for a single resource (i.e. wood) or for two (wood and edible 'nuts'). Tables are presented showing the value of the wood and of the edible 'nuts' at ages 60, 80...240 years, and also the discounted revenues for rates of 3% and 5%. It is argued that the concept of financial maturity is inappropriate for application to these Pinus sibirica forests, which should be managed in perpetuity on the basis of sustainable utilization.

bibl.et: A phytosociological survey of the boreal forest (Vaccinio-Piceetea) in North America.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Biología Vegetal, Universidad de Alcalá, E-28871 Alcalá de Henares, Madrid, Spain.

ab.p: A survey of syntaxa of vegetation of North American boreal forests (class Vaccinio-Piceetea) is presented. This phytosociological survey, carried out combining the Braun-Blanquet method with numerical syntaxonomical analyses (cluster and correspondence analysis), describes the associations of the North American boreal forests, which have several species, varieties or vicariant species in common with their Eurasian counterparts, and can be placed in the class Vaccinio-Piceetea. By means of tabular and multivariate analyses, 2084 North American relevés were compared with 3273 relevés from European, Japanese and Korean boreal forest, to describe and typify 4 orders, 10 alliances and 37 associations. Diagnostic tables, ordination, clustering, and climatic, edaphic and biogeographical data were used to show floristic affinities among these syntaxa and interpret their distribution areas. Syntaxa were briefly characterized by their floristic composition, physiognomy, succession, zonation, and biogeographical distribution.

bibl.et: Wildlife and nature in Turkey.

ab.p: A brief report, including graphical representations, is presented on the distribution and growth of protected, wildlife and conservation areas, the number of game species, wildlife, national parks, hunting tourism, and the growth of rest areas in forests. A list of 13 non-governmental organizations concerned with environmental and forestry activities in Turkey is presented.

bibl.et: A model for predicting forest fire spreading using cellular automata.
bibl.aa: Democritus University of Thrace, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, GR-671 00 Xanthi, Greece.

ab.p: A model is presented which predicts the spread of fire in both homogeneous and inhomogeneous forests and which incorporates both weather conditions and land topography. An algorithm was constructed based on the proposed model and was used for the determination of fire fronts in a number of hypothetical forests, which were found to be in good agreement with the experience of fire spreading in real forests. Application to forest management is discussed.

bibl.et: Applicability of the forest stand growth simulator PROGNAUS for the Austrian part of the Bohemian Massif.
bibl.aa: Institut für Waldwachstumsforschung, Universität für Bodenkultur, Peter Jordan Str. 82, A-1190 Vienna, Austria.

ab.p: The applicability of the basal area increment model in the PROGNAUS forest stand growth simulator was assessed using independent permanent plot data. The simulator was designed to forecast the development of both pure even-aged and mixed-species uneven-aged stands in Austria using distance-independent individual tree methodology. The primary model relates to the basal area increment (BAI), which is predicted from size (diameter, crown ratio etc), competition (basal area of larger trees, crown competition factor), and site descriptors. Because the model must be able to simulate the development of both uneven- and even-aged stands, site index and age were not used as predictors. An independent data set of 22 permanent plots in mixed Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris)-Norway spruce (Picea abies) stand in the Austrian part of the Bohemian Massif, northeastern Austria, was analysed. Validation plots were remeasured for three 5-year periods between 1977 and 1992. The prediction interval (95% confidence) for the basal area increment over the full 15-year period was 62 to 157%, with a mean of 99% of the observed increment. A plot-specific adjustment of the model's intercept using past increment did not improve predictions for P. abies, but did improve predictions for P. sylvestris. It is suggested that important site-specific variation not captured by the P. sylvestris model could be accounted for by using increment calibration. A time trend towards increasing underestimation of the increment was detected in the later growth periods of the validation data. This trend agreed with a frequently reported increase in the site potential of central European stands, possibly caused by changing weather conditions, N deposition and abandoning of litter raking. It is concluded that in future model development, as many growth periods as possible should be used to parameterize increment models, although even this may not account for a long term change in the site potential.

bibl.et: Designing the urban forest of tomorrow: pre-commercial thinning adapted for use in urban areas in Sweden.
bibl.aa: Department of Silviculture, SLU, S-901 83 Umeá, Sweden.

ab.p: The area of semi-natural young growth in urban green areas of Sweden is growing. These young urban forests are often in urgent need of management. The aim of this study is to show some possibilities for creating a multifunctional urban forest using pre-commercial thinning, by means of which the variation in naturally regenerated mixed young forest can be enhanced. A demonstration forest was created on a 2.1-hectare large piece of land forested with trees about 20 yr old, in Umeå, northern Sweden; the area was formerly part of the rural landscape. A very early thinning created 12 small and different forest compartments, each servicing a specific function. The 12 compartments are: the rowan forest (Sorbus aucuparia), the children's forest, the glade, the high forest-like pine forest (Pinus sylvestris), the untended forest, the mixed forest, the 'walk the dog' forest, the birch forest (Betula pendula/B. pubescens), the ever juvenile forest, the willow forest (Salix phylicifolia), the multilayered spruce forest (Picea abies) and the aspen forest (Populus tremula). Other species present in the forest were sallow (Salix caprea), juniper (Juniperus communis), bird cherry (Prunus padus) and larch (Larix decidua). Future silvicultural measures are proposed for each compartment.

bibl.et: Allometric equations for two South American conifers: test of a non-destructive method.
bibl.aa: Department of Geology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA 19104, USA.

ab.p: Non-destructive biomass estimation for protected tree species is necessary to understand their population dynamics and the ecological factors affecting species scarcity. A method is presented for estimating above-ground biomass of stem, branches and foliage, using data obtained by climbing live trees to collect limited samples and measurements. This method was applied to 26 individuals of Fitzroya cupressoides, a protected Chilean conifer, and to 12 individuals of a second, morphologically similar but unprotected species, Pilgerodendron uviferum. Trees were climbed, the basal diameter of all branches >1 cm were recorded and 4 branches per tree were removed for further measurement. The sampled branches were used to develop allometric equations predicting branch, twig and foliar biomass from branch basal diameter. These equations were used to generate whole tree canopy biomass estimates based on the climber's measurements of branch basal diameter. Bole biomass was estimated from serial measurements of height, diameter and wood density. Whole tree canopy and bole biomass estimates were then used to develop allometric equations predicting wood and foliar biomass from diameter at breast height. Five of the P. uviferum trees were felled and weighed by conventional methods, and the data used to evaluate error in the non-destructive technique. Although the technique was labour intensive, it was found to yield mean estimates for canopy components that are expected to be within 10% of the true mean for large populations of trees (watershed level studies). Accurate estimation of individual trees may be less reliable, as the amount of dispersion about some of the regressions was quite high.

index.de: allometry\biomass\endangered species\equations\estimation\measurement\nondestructive testing\plant morphology\protected species\regression analysis

bibl.et: Soil dynamics in an age sequence of Prosopis juliflora planted for sodic soil restoration in India.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Forestry, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario M5S 3B3, Canada.

ab.p: A field study was conducted to study long-term soil dynamics in Prosopis juliflora stands planted to rehabilitate degraded sodic soils in Haryana, India. Soil samples were collected from an age sequence of 0-, 5-, 7- and 30-yr-old plantations to assess the effects of the trees on the physical, chemical and biological properties of soil. Tree growth altered microclimate, improved soil moisture status, organic C, total N, extractable P, exchangeable Ca, Mg and K, and decreased pH, electrical conductivity and exchangeable Na levels. These changes contributed to the reclamation of the sodic sites. The dynamics reflected a 3-phase restoration sequence, characterized by nominal soil changes during tree establishment (0-5 yr), marked and rapid changes associated with canopy closure (5-7 yr), and gradual stabilization of soil properties in the fallow enrichment phase (7-30 yr). The ameliorative mechanisms operating in the chronosequence were categorized into 2 parallel sets of major processes, viz. sodicity alleviation that dominated in the transitional phase, and fertility restoration that characterized the fallow enrichment phase. The bioremediation mechanisms driving the reclamation processes in the reforestation of degraded sites were examined in relation to hypotheses accounting for these changes.

bibl.et: Sources of temporal variation in sap sugar content in a mature sugar maple (Acer saccharum) plantation.
bibl.aa: Centre de Recherche en Biologie Forestière, Faculté de Foresterie et de Géomatique, Université Laval, Sainte-Foy, Québec GIK 7P4, Canada.

ab.p: Temporal factors affecting sap sugar content (SSC) were assessed in a 65-yr-old plantation of sugar maple (Acer saccharum) in Quebec. A total of 694 maples were measured and the variation in SSC was assessed between 2 sampling years (1994-95), among 3 days within each sugar season (in March and April), and among hours within each sampling day (09.30-17.30). Average individual tree variation in SSC was extensive, ranging from 1.3 to 5.5% for spring 1994, and from 1.4 to 4.8% for spring 1995. The correlation between DBH (diameter at breast height) and SSC was weak for both sampling years. SSC did not vary extensively between sampling hours within days, but it varied significantly among sampling days for both years analysed. However, the largest source of variation in SSC was between the 2 sampling years. Tree relative performances in SSC were moderately conserved among days within years and to a lesser degree, between sampling years. The relative magnitude of the differences between statistical treatments and the stability analysis of tree relative performances indicated that for adequate estimation of the SSC of an individual tree, sampling over years was superior to sampling over several days within a single sugar season. Also, sampling towards the end of the sugar season or during days with lower SSC appeared to be less reliable for mass selection.

bibl.et: Effects of site preparation on timber and non-timber values of loblolly pine plantations.
bibl.aa: Department of Agricultural Sciences, Tuskegee University, Tuskegee, AL 36088, USA.

ab.p: This study evaluated the timber and non-timber values of loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) stands generated by 4 site preparation methods tested in the Tuskegee National Forest, SE Alabama, 15 yr earlier. The timber values of the forest stands were assessed using yields predicted by the SE TWIGS model. Non-timber benefits were evaluated through the Contingent Valuation Method; these included aesthetic value, pinicking, hiking/walking/cycling, camping, hunting, birdwatching, wildlife habitat, water protection, biodiversity and mushrooms/berries. Two hundred residents randomly selected from 3 counties surrounding or near the National Forest were interviewed. The survey results indicate that the majority (62%) of the respondents felt that the National Forest should be managed for both timber and non-timber products. Of the 4 site preparation methods, the soil-active herbicide method was projected to produce the highest timber value. For non-timber benefits, the respondents preferred the forest stand without site preparation to those generated using chainsaw felling, soil-active herbicide, and tree injection methods. When both timber and non-timber values were considered, no site preparation method was a best alternative that seemed to meet the desires of the various groups of citizens with different or even conflicting preferences over timber and non-timber products.

bibl.et: Effect of NaCl on growth, photosynthesis, ion and water relations of four poplar genotypes.
bibl.aa: Experimental Centre of Forest Biology, Beijing Forestry University, P.O. Box 162, Beijing 100083, China.

ab.p: Cuttings of 4 poplar clones, Populus deltoides × P. nigra [P. canadensis] cv. I-214 (P. 'I-214'), P. canadensis f. robusta (P. 'Robusta'), P. berolinensis and P. simonii × (P. pyramidalis × Salix matsudana) cv. Popularis 35-44 (P. 'Popularis') were treated with 3 salt levels (0, 0.5 or 1.0% w/v NaCl) in sand culture for 21 days. Growth, photosynthesis, stomatal resistance, leaf water potential, and Na+ and K+ concentrations were all significantly affected by salinity. For all clones, leaf and height growth were significantly reduced after 3 and 5 days, respectively, following exposure to salinity. Physiological parameters (photosynthesis, stomatal resistance and pre-dawn leaf water potential) also showed rapid responses to salinity, but clonal differences were not significant. Growth, biomass partitioning and Na+ and K+ concentrations were also significantly affected by salinity. Reductions in leaf area growth were maintained throughout the experiment. Height and diameter growth were less sensitive but still showed significant differences between the 3 NaCl treatments. Proportionately less above-ground biomass was produced than below-ground (root) biomass, P. 'I-214' was more vigorous than other clones and had significantly lower leaf and root Na+ concentrations than P. 'Popularis'. Young leaf tissue had higher Na+ and K+ concentrations and Na:K ratios than older leaf or root tissue.

bibl.et: Effects of two short rotation prescribed fires in autumn on surface-active arthropods in dry sclerophyll eucalypt forest of west-central Victoria.
bibl.aa: Centre for Forest Tree Technology, 123 Brown Street, Heidelberg, Victoria, 3084, Australia.

ab.p: The effects of 2 prescribed low intensity fires (from 73 to 123 kW m-1) within 5 yr on invertebrates in litter/upper soil were assessed at adjacent sites in eucalypt dry sclerophyll forest (dominant species Eucalyptus obliqua and E. radiata) in Victoria, Australia. The 7.8-yr study was based on 98&thin;159 arthropod specimens representing 34 ordinal or lower level taxa contained in 3200 pitfall trap samples from a twice burnt site and an unburnt control site within a 29.9 ha area. The 2 fires had no discernible effect on total insects. Araneae (spiders), Coleoptera (beetles) and Diptera (flies), although the activity of total arthropods and total non-arthropods decreased significantly after the first fire due largely to Collembola (springtails); however, within 5 yr, the activity of these groups had recovered to prefire levels. There was no change in activity in these 3 groups following the second fire, leaving the question open as to whether fire was the cause for the change following the first fire. The activity of Formicidae (ants) increased and that of Dermaptera (earwigs) decreased following the second fire, although effects other than fire are believed to be the cause. As the increase in Formicidae and decrease in Collembola and Dermaptera activity were confined to a single postfire period only, it is not possible to determine whether or not these changes were fire-related. The results indicate that 2 consecutive fires in autumn appear to have a minimal effect on activity of major arthropod groups in the forest litter layer. It is recommended that the interval of prescribed fires in autumn should be not less than 5 yr. Further research is required on families and species comprising the major arthropod groups before precise prescriptions on fire frequency can be formulated. In forest where protracted drought has supervened, a second burn should be delayed until the drought has broken.

bibl.et: Observations on red cedar and the tip moth.
bibl.aa: 17 Third Avenue, Epping, NSW 2121, Australia.

ab.p: An account is given of work done earlier (mainly during the 1950s and 1960s) by the author on the Australian red cedar (Toona ciliata) and its relationship with the tip moth (Hypsipyla robusta). A record of some of the impacts of European settlement on the tree is presented, noting that its disastrous over-exploitation has resulted in its timber becoming a rare commodity. Past attempts to regenerate the tree are discussed and more recent investigations into the inter-relationships of the tree and the tip moth presented. The insect pest remains one of the major difficulties in regenerating the species. A silvicultural method, based on the results of these investigations, which minimizes the effect of the insect's attack, is postulated for consideration.

bibl.et: Development of freezing tolerance in roots and shoots of Scots pine seedlings at nonfreezing temperatures.
bibl.aa: Finnish Forest Research Institute, Suonenjoki Research Station, Juntintie 40, FIN-77600 Suonenjoki, Finland.

ab.p: The hardening of hydroponically cultured Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris) seedlings and their recovery after freezing was studied at the end of the second growing season (LD), after 3 weeks of short day treatment (SD), after a gradual decrease in temperature to 5°C over 4 weeks (H1), and after 4 weeks at 5°C (H2) at Suonenjoki Research Station, Finland. Frost hardiness was determined by several methods and the recovery as survival of the seedlings. The highest frost hardiness was achieved in the distal parts of needles (-21 to -27°C) and in the proximal parts of needles (-18 to -25°C), followed by woody roots (-7 to -9°C), the 1-year-old and current stem (-8°C), and the fine roots (-5°C), all at the end of H2. Hardening of needles was induced by SD, but the stem and woody roots started to harden later, as a response to low temperature. As a result of frost treatment during LD and SD, potential plasma membrane H+-ATPase activity of roots decreased as electrolyte leakage increased and extracellular resistance decreased, but this relationship was lost during H1 and H2. The present study demonstrates the lack of hardening capacity in the fine roots of Scots pine seedlings at non-freezing temperatures and the increased mortality of the young seedlings having frost damage on roots.

bibl.do: Nafanua: saving the Samoan rain forest.
bibl.et: Nafanua: saving the Samoan rain forest.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany & Range Science, Brigham Young University, Provo, UT 84602, USA.

ab.p: Based upon the memoirs of the author, an informative narrative is presented on a Samoan village, the legends of Nafanua (a Samoan goddess who freed people from oppression in ancient times and taught them to protect the rainforest), the preservation of the Falealupo Rain Forest through international campaigns, the protection of Samoa's endangered flying foxes (Pteropus poliocephalus), and of scientific discoveries.

bibl.av: Chen, C. X.\Wang, J. L.\Zhi, X.
bibl.et: Research state of the dormancy and pregermination of Pinus koraiensis seed in China and abroad.
bibl.aa: Beijing Forestry University, 100083 Beijing, China.

ab.p: This review examines seed dormancy in P. koraiensis, emphasizing its causes and mechanisms, and pregermination methods. The main theories on the cause of seed dormancy in P. koraiensis are: (1) the resistance of the seed coat to mechanical force and poor air permeability; (2) endogenous inhibitors, especially abscisic acid; and (3) post-maturation physiology of the embryo. Most research on the mechanisms of seed dormancy has concentrated on aspects of the control of endogenous growth regulators and other metabolic substances, as well as the effects of peroxidase. Stratification is the main pregermination seed treatment.

bibl.et: Testing models of unthinned red pine plantation dynamics using a modified Bakuzis matrix of stand properties.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, North Central Forest Experiment Station, 1992 Folwell Avenue, St. Paul, MN 55108, USA.

ab.p: The comprehensive graphical matrix of even-aged stand property inter-dependence first developed by E.V. Bakuzis, which facilitates identification and understanding of the relationship among stand properties, is discussed. The original matrix of 8 stand properties, contained 64 cells, was symmetric, but only about 11 of the 64 relationships had shown enough regularity among species to have been named. The Bakuzis matrix was simplified by reordering the rows and columns to make a more compact, lower, triangular arrangement of 8 rules or law-like relationships. Matrix use is demonstrated by looking for structural flaws in 2 models of unthinned red pine (Pinus resinosa) plantation dynamics in the Lake States (Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan) (STEMS and REDPINE), and one from Ontario (yield tables from Petawawa). Flaws were found in each source of projections. REDPINE violated the Sukachev effect, predicted trees to have larger diameters on poor sites than on good sites, and that site has a significant effect on the mean height-stem frequency relation. All bi-variate relations for the Petawawa data were identical, which violated several rules. The STEM program was the worst of the 3 prediction methods for unthinned red pine plantation stand development, primarily because site index had very little effect on any of the stand variables.

bibl.et: Grindstone production using local materials and basic technology.
bibl.aa: Wondo Genet College of Forestry, P.O. Box 128, Shashemene, Ethiopia.

ab.p: Flat-bladed cutting tools are among the most important forestry production implements in Ethiopia, and most are currently maintained using flat sandstone rocks. This technology is unsuitable and inefficient. Thirty-six circular grindstones that could be manually operated were produced using local materials and basic technology. All sharpened an iron bar of uniform thickness adequately and efficiently. Comparisons were made of material quality, maintenance efficiency and rate of wear. The best of the locally made grindstones were compared further with imported ones, and they were found to be equally good in most respects. The cost of local production is, moreover, a small fraction of the purchasing and delivery costs of imported stones. Local grindstone production technology is simple, cheap and appropriate for developing countries and can be readily taught.

bibl.et: Research on sustainability of plantation forestry: volume estimation of Pinus patula trees in two different rotations.
bibl.aa: Correspondence address: Imperial College Centre for Environmental Technology, 48 Prince's Gardens, London SW7 2PE, UK.

ab.p: Productivity research in the Usutu Forest, Swaziland, indicates that over 3 rotations growth rate of successive plantations of Pinus patula is being maintained. This important result for the 'narrow-sense' sustainability of plantation forestry was further investigated to discover whether the single tree volume function used for one rotation remained valid for the next. Procedures for obtaining the original function in 1977 were repeated in 1997 under identical conditions, except that trees were third rather than second rotation. Analysis showed that functions did differ between rotations in a small but statistically significant way. Several explanations are suggested, but the scale of the difference did not affect the overall conclusion about sustainability of plantation productivity. However, the result poses the general question of whether mensurational relationships and models derived in the past may need revisiting owing to large-scale changes affecting trees and forests such as climatic change or genetic improvement, which may invalidate current use of functions based on data from an earlier generation.

bibl.et: Modelling interactions between trees by means of field observations.
bibl.aa: University of Gothenburg, 411 80 Gothenburg, Sweden.

ab.p: The Gibbs model and the pseudo-likelihood estimation method are applied to study interactions between trees of pine [Pinus sylvestris] and spruce [Picea abies] forests in the southern half of Finland, which result in various distribution patterns. The coordinates of trees were measured on small sample plots in the original data, which were from the INKA permanent sample plots established by the Finnish Forest Research Institute for growth study purposes. Only some trees from the plots were needed for parameter estimation through field measurements. Spatial distribution patterns at various ages are shown for both species. In pine, regular distribution patterns were demonstrated, resulting from the trees inhibiting each other up to a distance of about 1 m; this is related to the light requirement of pine. In spruce, trees formed clusters (although older forests had a more regular pattern, probably due to thinning); this pattern is related the the lower light requirement of spruce.

bibl.et: Identifying climatically suitable areas for growing particular trees in Latin America.
bibl.aa: CSIRO Division of Forestry and Forest Products, PO Box E4008, Kingston, Canberra ACT 2604, Australia.

ab.p: Six climatic factors important for tree species selection were calculated from monthly mean values of maximum temperature, minimum temperature and precipitation estimated for 66&thin;688 locations in a 10-min (18.5 km approx.) grid across Latin America. These included measures such as mean annual temperature, mean maximum temperature of the hottest month, mean annual precipitation and rainfall regime. Three microcomputer programs were written to enable the database to be interrogated for Latin America as a whole (LATIN), and also for the northern (CEN, Central America and northern South America) and southern (SOUTH) regions. The use of the programs is demonstrated with data on the climatic requirements of Acacia mearnsii, Eucalyptus camaldulensis (northern provenances) and Pinus radiata. The species climatic data are fed into the programs, and used to produce maps of areas suitable for growing the species. It is concluded that the programs can assist both in identifying climatically suitable areas for these trees and in developing improved descriptions of climatic requirements for other species and provenances.

bibl.et: Control of bilberry vegetation by steam treatment - effects on seeded Scots pine and associated mycorrhizal fungi.
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Vegetation Ecology, Faculty of Forestry, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, S-901 83 Umeå, Sweden.

ab.p: In boreal forest, ground vegetation of bilberry (Vaccinium myrtillus) and feather mosses strongly suppress seed regeneration of Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris). A site preparation technique by steam treatment to control bilberry and moss vegetation after clear felling was investigated on a clear felled area in northern Sweden. Sowing experiments were performed between 1993 and 1995 with Scots pine in 4 treatments: (1) untreated vegetation, (2) activated carbon added to the soil surface of otherwise intact ground vegetation, (3) steam treated vegetation, and (4) activated carbon added to the soil surface of steam treated vegetation. Activated carbon was added to adsorb possible phenolic compounds released from bilberry leaves and litter. Steam killed ground vegetation effectively and recolonization by vascular plants and mosses was slow. Scots pine seedling establishment was improved by steam treatment, especially when activated carbon was added to the soil surface. The action of activated carbon was interpreted as adsorbing and reducing the levels of phenolics from bilberry litter and humus, which otherwise may have inhibited seed germination. Dry weight of 4-yr-old seedlings was 3 times higher in steam treated plots than in untreated plots. Seedling nutrient content was also strongly improved by steam treatment. The increased growth of seedlings in steam treated plots is interpreted mainly as an effect of reduced resource competition from ground vegetation. Irrespective of treatment, almost all fine roots were colonized by ectomycorrhizal fungi. Using PCR (polymerase chain reaction)-based molecular methods, 28 taxa forming mycorrhizas were identified on the seedlings. Steam treatment did not affect species richness and abundance of ectomycorrhizal inoculum. It is concluded that steam treatment has the potential to be an efficient and environmentally acceptable method to reduce negative influence of bilberry vegetation on Scots pine seedling establishment and early growth. The experiment also provides a better understanding of factors blocking natural regeneration at boreal forest sites.

bibl.et: Effect of defoliation on the growth of teak.
bibl.aa: Forest Protection Division, Bangladesh Forest Research Institute, GPO Box 273, Chittagong 4000, Bangladesh.

ab.p: In a 1-yr-old teak (Tectona grandis) plantation at Kaptai, Bangladesh, manual defoliation (25, 50, 75 and 100%) was carried out in June, simulating the damage caused by the larvae of teak defoliator, Hyblaea puera. Control plants (0% defoliation) were either sprayed or not with phosphamidon + malathion (applied when an infestation by herbivores was present or imminent). Four years of manual defoliation caused significant losses of about 14-49% in height, 19-51% in basal area and 23-62% in volume increments depending on the intensity of defoliation compared with the unsprayed control. However, the losses were about 28-57%, 53-72% and 58-79%, respectively, compared with the sprayed control. The sprayed control, which afforded about 16% in height, 42% in basal area and 45% in volume increments against those of the unsprayed control. Loss of volume increment is a serious impact of defoliation. Protection during the early years would be advantageous because of the higher absolute increment of teak at this stage. None of the trees defoliated showed mortality or leading shoot dieback.

bibl.et: The role of forests in stabilizing the beds of rivers, and the prospects of growing forests in the river floodplains of Ukraine.

ab.p: Studies were made of the effect of the percentage of forest cover on each bank on the course of the river bed in floodplains in Ukraine. Morphometric indices of the river beds (characterizing the bends and meanders) are related to the absence of forest and to the percentage of forest cover on one bank or on both banks, for three case-studies, viz. the rivers Vorskla, Psel, and Severskii Donets. A simple formula is derived for calculating the width of the bank-protecting strips of forest from the width of the meandering zone and is the mean width of the river bed. On this basis the mean width of the bank-protecting strips should be 150 m for the Vorskla, 200 m for the Severskii Donets, and 250 m for the Psel. The amount of floodplain planting required to stabilize the rivers is discussed.

bibl.et: The dimensional stability of coated wood-based materials.
bibl.ft: Zur Formstabilität beschichteter Holzwerkstoffe.
bibl.aa: Institut für Holztechnologie, Dresden, Germany.

ab.p: A diffusion test in a special two-climate chamber was used to investigate the effect of various lacquer and melamine resin film coatings in protecting commercial board products against moisture uptake. The boards tested were FPO particleboard, MDF (medium density fibreboard) 0, and walnut-veneered MDF M. With lacquer coating there was a direct correlation between moisture uptake and dimensional stability. Coating with melamine resin film gave a high protective effect. The temperature effect (gradient 20°:40°C) was of little importance on uncoated materials, but with coated materials the temperature difference caused a shift in the moisture profile, and this resulted in dimensional changes.

ab.p: Six Weinmannia species are recognized in this region, all belonging to section Leiospermum. W. rapensis is confined to Rapa in the Austral Islands and its reported occurrence in Pitcairn is discussed. W. parviflora occurs on most of the large islands of the Societies except Raiatea and its leaf shape and indumentum vary with its ecology. W. vescoi and W. raiateensis are both confined to Raiatea. In the Marquesas, W. marquesana is represented by two varieties and a distinctive, new species, W. tremuloides, is described and illustrated from Fatu Hiva.

bibl.et: Vegetative propagation of Calliandra calothyrsus (Meissner).
bibl.ct: Special section: Agroforestry research and development in the humid lowlands of West and Central Africa. Selected papers from the regional symposium on agroforestry research and development, 4-8 December 1995, Yaounde, Cameroon.
bibl.aa: Ministry of the Environment and Forestry, Provincial Delegate of Centre Province, P.O. Box 2067, Yaoundé, Cameroon.

ab.p: The effects of propagation medium and the type of auxin on root and shoot development of stem cuttings of Calliandra calothyrsus were investigated in 2 experiments. Cuttings were taken from 4-wk-old coppice shoots from a cleared C. calothyrsus plantation. In the first experiment, the effects of 5 propagation media were compared. These were fine sand (FS, 3 mm), sawdust (SD), fine gravel (FG, 6 mm) and 50:50 mixtures of FS:SD and FG:SD. In the second experiment, 2 commercial brands of auxin rooting powder ('Seradix 3' (IBA), and 'Bouture CF' (NAA, IBA and methyl-NAA)) were evaluated. The experiments were done in a low-cost, non-mist propagator system in Cameroon. Propagation medium had a significant effect on mean rooting percentages, which ranged from 43% in FS to 93% in FS:SD; the 2 best rooting media were FS:SD and SD alone (88%). The effect of the medium on shoot growth of the cuttings (height, basal diameter and shoot biomass) were also significant, with the best results again from FS:SD and SD alone. The application of both the commercial auxins significantly enhanced rooting (84% overall for untreated cuttings and 91% for IBA-treated cuttings). Bouture CF promoted shoot development from the cuttings, while Seradix 3 inhibited shoot development. The results indicate that in the humid lowlands of Cameroon, where seed productivity of C. calothyrsus is known to be very poor, large-scale production of young plants using these vegetative techniques is possible.

bibl.et: Effect of changing light availability on nutrient foraging in tropical deciduous tree-seedlings.
bibl.aa: Dept of Integrative Biology, Univ. of California, Berkeley, CA 94720-3140, USA.

ab.p: The relationship between the capacity to respond to changes in light and the ability to search and exploit nutrient-rich soil patches (foraging) was evaluated in deciduous tree species. Seedlings of four tropical tree species (Caesalpinia platyloba, Celaenodendron mexicanum, Cordia alliodora and Heliocarpus pallidus) were exposed to a factorial combination of high (H) and low (L) photon flux density with fertilized (+ Fp) and unfertilized nutrient patches (- Fp) for 42 days. After this initial growth period, half of the plants from H were transferred to L (HL treatment), and half of the plants from L were transferred to H (LH) for another 42 days. When plants were transferred from high light to low light (HL), their productivity and RGR (relative growth rate) were lower than plants under high light, but when plants were transferred from low light to high light (LH), they reached similar or higher RGR (and sometimes biomass) compared to plants under continuously high light. The study species differed in their ability to explore and to benefit from the fertilized patch, depending on characteristics such as root length and root density in the fertilized patch and the potential relative growth rate of the species. The slow-growing species C. mexicanum showed no response to nutrient patches because it was unable to locate and produce roots in the patch. This species responded only to light, with slightly higher plant dry biomass and growth rate under HH and HL than under LH and LL, with thinner leaves (higher specific leaf area) under LL and LH. Fast-growing species had a higher ability than slow-growing species to forage for patchily distributed soil nutrients. This ability was maintained when plants experienced light increases (LH plants) but not when plants were growing under shaded conditions. In addition, the lack of the fertilized patch caused a strong reduction in RGR in the most productive light conditions (HH), so that HH plants had as low an RGR as LL and HL plants when grown without a fertilized patch. This response indicates a strong interaction between light capture and soil foraging behaviour.

bibl.aa: 5400 Grosvenor Lane, Bethesda, MD 20814-2198, USA.

ab.p: Two general initial sessions of the convention considered: populations and demographics, forestry and the new demographic ball-game; emerging information technologies; conservation of the environment, responsibilities of natural resource professionals; forests - supply and demand, global fibre supply; global issues - local solutions, foresters and civic stewardship; and a summary on selected reflections on how to address global concerns and develop local solutions. The working group technical sessions discussed: biometrics (data needs for forest management, and modelling); remote sensing and photogrammetry; urban forestry (perspectives and influences, and measurements and utilization); international forestry, and economics, policy and law; agroforestry (forest ecology, soils, range ecology, wildlife and fish ecology, physiology, technology assessment and future analysis, wilderness, recreation, education and communication, human resources, philosophy); SAF ethics committee (ecotourism and workshops); silviculture; fire; economics, policy and law; land use and planning design, and forest land organization and management; management science and operations research (wildlife as an objective in forest management, and dealing with risk in forest management); and wilderness management and recreation. A total of 36 posters are presented.

bibl.do: Malesian seed plants. Volume 1: spot-characters, an aid for identification of families and genera.
bibl.et: Malesian seed plants. Volume 1: spot-characters, an aid for identification of families and genera.

ab.p: Volume 1 of this series contains lists of spot characters which can be easily observed in plant material of Malesian seed plants, illustrated by line drawings (Malesia includes Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines and Singapore). The book provides a user-friendly identification tool for professional and amateur use in the herbarium and the field. The 105 characters used are arranged in a logical manner, in 13 main categories: habit; stem or branch; exudate; smell; indument; leaves with glands; stipules; petiole/rachis; lamina; inflorescence; flower; fruit; and seed. The list of characters also includes examples from a few non-Malesian taxa. An index to taxa is included.

ab.p: Some 11 families of Malesian (including Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines and Singapore) seed plants are treated in this volume 2 of this series. All the families contain at least one tree species with diameter at breast height of >10 cm or height of >10 m. For each family the portrait describes the characteristics found, with brief details of distribution and ecology, and spot characters of selected genera for easy identification. A guide to use of the book, a glossary, a list of spot characters (as described in detail in volume 1), and an index to taxa are included.

bibl.et: The evolution of shrimp culture and its impact on mangroves.
bibl.aa: Aquatic Resources Research Institute, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok, Thailand.

ab.p: The development of shrimp culture from extensive systems within mangrove forests which formed an integral part of the fishing practices of coastal communities, to more recent semi-intensive and intensive systems in Asia is described. It is concluded that the intensive systems, able to make use of land behind the mangroves beyond the tidal range due to the development of high volume water pumps, are better for the conservation of the mangrove forests. These systems allow more intensive shrimp farming due to the better environmental conditions (worldwide intensively farmed shrimp account for 36% of shrimp produced and 5% of the shrimp culture area).

bibl.et: Use of statistical and neural network techniques to detect how stomatal conductance responds to changes in the local environment.
bibl.aa: Institute of Hydrology, Wallingford, OX10 8BB, UK.

ab.p: The bulk stomatal conductance term, gs, in the Penman-Monteith equation was modelled as a function of local environmental variables. Stomatal dependencies are frequently described as a product of individual functions, fj, each depending on only one variable Xj, where the functional forms have been estimated through laboratory experiments. Other descriptions for gs are being developed (notably through photosynthesis models) and so methods of comparing model performance are needed. A notion of the best possible fit of gs to the Xj is required, thereby providing a benchmark for any model. Regression and neural network methods are presented to analyse the stomatal conductance of pine forest, although the techniques are applicable to any vegetation type. The importance of a strong nonlinear dependence of gs on the Xj is illustrated and in addition, the frequently used Jarvis type nonlinear functions, fj, are shown to be nearly optimal.

bibl.et: Protecting sowings of Pinus [koraiensis] from birds in nurseries in the Russian Far East.
bibl.aa: Dal'NIILKh, Russia.

ab.p: An account is given of the damage done by birds to sowings of Pinus koraiensis in nurseries in the Russian Far East. The main bird pests are identified (crows, magpies, turtle doves, hawfinches), and various ways of scaring them away are discussed. Dangling mirrors and spheres with raptors' eyes have proved effective, as have rotating scarecrows holding strips of aluminium foil, wind-driven propellers, or rattles. These are also effective in scaring off rodents, especially Siberian chipmunks.

bibl.et: Evaluating the risk of large forest fires occurring.
bibl.aa: VNIITslesresurs, Russia.

ab.p: In Russia, forest fires are classed as large if they affect ≥200 ha in regions where fire fighting is mainly by air, and ≥25 ha in areas where fire fighting is done from the ground. An analysis is made of the areas of crown and ground fires by regions, the number of large fires as a function of the total number of fires, and the effect of the time since rainfall and its amount on the risk of large forest fires. A scale is drawn up showing fire risk (ranging from I = no danger, to V = extreme danger), based on the combustibility index which is calculated from the air temperature and dew point at noon and the number of days without rain, including the last day with at least 3 mm of rain.

bibl.et: Estimation of leaf area index with the Li-Cor LAI 2000 in deciduous forests.
bibl.aa: Istituto Sperimentale per la Selvicoltura, Viale S. Margherita, 80, I-52100, Arezzo, Italy.

ab.p: Sample thinned and unthinned stands of the most widespread deciduous species in Italy (Quercus cerris, 6.3% of the total area; Castanea sativa, 8.5%; and Fagus sylvatica 12.6%) were selected from 15 permanent plots. Leaf area index (LAI) data were collected over 3 yr (1993-95), using both direct (litter traps) and indirect methods (the LAI-2000 Plant Canopy Analyzer, PCA, Li-Cor, Lincoln, NE, USA). LAI estimation by litter collection (LAILT, 3.2-7.6 m² m-2) was in the range of values reported for deciduous forest, while the PCA method generally underestimated LAI (LAIPCA, 1.8-5.8 m² m-2). Average underestimation was 26.5%, and was similar to that in other reports. The underestimation was higher in thinned (29.1±14.7%) than in unthinned (22.2±12.2%) stands and in stands characterized by a LAILT >5 m² m-2. On the contrary, in stands with LAILT <5 m² m-2, PCA estimates were closer to litter trap values (-11±9.6%). On average, LAILT was 4.51±0.92 m² m-2 and 5.86±0.11 m² m-2, for thinned and unthinned stands, respectively. PCA was also able to estimate this difference, giving 3.14±0.70 m² m-2 for thinned stands and 4.47±0.61 m² m-2 for unthinned stands. With both methods, the difference between the 2 stand types was strongly significant. Although LAIPCA values were always below LAILT, the correlation between the 2 data sets was linear and significant. When recalculated omitting the reading of the external PCA ring, the correlation between LAILT and LAIPCA improved, and the underestimation of LAIPCA was within 12%. Woody area index (WAI) was evaluated with the PCA during the leafless period. The instrument was able to show the difference between thinned (0.55±0.09) and unthinned stands (0.80±0.19). As in other studies, the subtraction of WAI from LAIPCA values increased the underestimation of LAILT. The agreement between the 2 methods for LAI estimation was satisfactory. Nevertheless, the underestimation by the PCA method must be taken into account. Over different years and stands, the variability of underestimation was not marked, pointing to a reliable use of PCA in different conditions, as, for example, the comparison of thinned and unthinned stands and in measuring temporal and spatial variations of LAI. The overlapping of leaves, the presence of gaps within the canopy and light at the horizon level seem to be some of the important variables that influence LAI estimation by the PCA. Further corrections of the data can substantially improve the performance of the PCA and produce reliable LAI estimates even though the collection of direct reference measurements is strongly recommended for exact estimation of LAI, in order to assess instrument performance at a given site.

bibl.et: Physiological and environmental control of transpiration by trees in windbreaks.
bibl.aa: Institute of Ecology and Resource Management, University of Edinburgh, Mayfield Road, Edinburgh EH9 3JU, UK.

ab.p: Knowledge of the environmental and physiological variables controlling water use by trees in windbreaks should assist efforts to manage competition for water between trees and crops in agroforestry. Coupling between windbreak trees and the atmosphere was therefore assessed by determining values of the decoupling coefficient (ω) for windbreaks during 4 periods of the year, using experimentally-derived aerodynamic and surface conductances for trees of Azadirachta indica in windbreaks at Sadoré, Niger. Aerodynamic conductances were determined by scaling-up measurements of leaf boundary layer conductances made using leaf replicas. Surface conductances for the trees were derived from measurements of whole-tree transpiration made using the heat-pulse technique. Values of ω for the windbreaks were ~0.3 at moderate wind speeds in the more humid seasons of the year, but fell to 0.1 during the driest period of the year. Thus, windbreaks are generally well-coupled to the atmosphere, so that transpiration is predominantly driven by the ambient vapour pressure deficit at leaf surfaces and the trees are able to exert close physiological control over water use. Management strategies to reduce the surface conductances of windbreak canopies should, consequently, effectively reduce demand for water by windbreaks and help to control competition for water between trees and crops.

bibl.et: Browsing damage by roe deer on Norway spruce seedlings planted on clearcuts of different ages. 1. Effect of slash removal, vegetation development, and roe deer density.
bibl.aa: Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, Department of Animal Ecology, Asa Forest Research Station, S-360 30 Lammhult, Sweden.

ab.p: A 2-year-long field experiment was established in May 1993, on clearcuts ranging in age from fresh to 4 years old at 4 sites in southern Sweden. The aim of the experiment was to study the effect of clearcut age and removal of slash (twigs, branches, and tops of harvested trees) on browsing damage by roe deer (Capreolus capreolus) on planted Norway spruce (Picea abies) seedlings. The cover and height of the vegetation, as well as the number of plant species, increased rapidly during the first 2 years after cutting, and afterwards continued to increase, although more slowly. Hairy grass (Deschampsia flexuosa) made up about 90% of the vegetation cover. The nitrogen concentration of hairy grass was highest in 2- and 3-year-old clearcuts. The height of the slash was lower on older clearcuts. Roe deer density increased with clearcut age. Browsing occurred during winter and the frequency of browsed seedlings was 31.2% in the 1993-94 period and 24.8% in the 1994-95 period. During both years the browsing damage tended to be highest on the 1-year-old clearcuts, but the effect was not statistically significant. The level of damage was about equal on the clearcuts of other ages. The level of browsing damage was not correlated with the quantity or quality of associated vegetation, slash quantity, or roe deer density on the clearcuts.

bibl.et: Study on flavonoid content in mulberry leaves.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Basic Course, Zhejiang Agricultural University, Hangzhou 310029, China.

ab.p: Flavonoid content in mulberry [Morus sp.] leaves from 20 species was determined by spectrophotometric method using rutin as standard sample. Flavonoid content in spring leaves varies from 11.71 to 26.61 mg/g according to species and from 9.84 to 29.60 mg/g in autumn leaves. The flavonoid extract rate with three different sample pretreatments was studied. Fresh leaves had the highest flavonoid content. Flavonoid constituents were distinguished and determined with HPLC. The results showed that mulberry leaves contain four flavonoids, two of which are rutin and quercetin.

bibl.et: Factors involved during in vitro culture of Calamus rotang.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, Bose Institute, 93/1, A.P.C. Road, Calcutta 700 009, India.

ab.p: Plants of Calamus rotang 4-5 yr old were selected from Higuli Forest, Krishnanagar Forest Division, West Bengal, and plantlets developing from the rhizomes excised and washed. The leaf bases were removed acropetally and the length of the plantlets reduced to 6-7 cm. The white parts (with 4-5 leaf bases) were treated with antioxidant solution, and the explants were sterilized with various combinations of chemicals. Sodium hypochlorite (5.0% v/v) in combination with mercuric chloride (0.5% w/v) gave the best results. Explants of various lengths were established in Eeuwens Y3 basal medium supplemented with 2,4-D (5 mg/litre), BAP ([benzyladenine] 1.2 mg/litre), 5% v/v sucrose and activated charcoal (0.3% v/v). Establishment was dependent on explant length as well as the plantlet origin. Explants of length 1.5-2.0 cm derived from plantlets of length 10-20 cm performed better. Bud proliferation of the explant was achieved in the establishment medium supplemented with benzyladenine at 5-10 mg/litre.

bibl.et: Reduction of fire hazard through thinning/residue disposal in the urban interface.
bibl.aa: Forest Fire Laboratory, Forest Research Institute, GR-57006 Vasilika-Thessaloniki, Greece.

ab.p: Alternative fire hazard reduction techniques are needed for managing fuel profiles in forest ecosystems located within the so-called wildland-urban interface. The present study includes experimental fuel manipulations initiated along the Rocky Mountain National Park interface with residential areas in Colorado, USA. Three thinning/slash disposal treatments were applied on two lodgepole pine (Pinus contoria) stands: thinning with whole-tree removal; thinning with stem removal - lopping and scattering; and thinning with stem removal - hand piling and burning. Results indicate that treatments reduced surface fire behaviour parameters, bringing flame size down and closer to the limits of direct attack fire fighting methods. Crown fire potential was decreased not only because of canopy removal, but also as a result of the potential reduction in heat generated by surface fuels. Projected fire behaviour for the thinning-without-slash-removal scenario indicates the possibility of serious control problems with major fire runs and crown fires given an outbreak.

ab.p: Eight papers are presented in this journal issue on the wildfire that occurred in September 1989 on Mt. Carmel, Israel. Over 100 ha of natural E. Mediterranean Aleppo pine (Pinus halepensis) forest was burnt in an area highly valued for recreation. A special study was set up to examine the possibilities for ecosystem restoration and future management. Topics considered included the repercussions of the fire on nature conservation, soil erosion and forestry management after wildfire, regeneration, spatial and temporal heterogeneity of species diversity after fire, arthropod species diversity, Aleppo pine seedling mortality and attack by Matsucoccus josephi, effects of management after fire on bird community succession, and the management implications of the project.

bibl.do: Journal of the Torrey Botanical Society
bibl.et: Forest response to the introduced hemlock woolly adelgid in southern New England, USA.
bibl.aa: Harvard University, Harvard Forest, Petersham, Massachusetts 01366, USA.

ab.p: Hemlock woolly adelgid (HWA), Adelges tsugae, an introduced aphid-like insect from Asia, is expanding its range across the northeastern United States through the range of Tsuga canadensis (eastern hemlock) and can severely reduce or eliminate this species. Initial community response to HWA of eight T. canadensis stands in south-central Connecticut was investigated. Tsuga canadensis damage varied broadly across the study area ranging from near zero to greater than 95% mortality. All size and age classes sampled were attacked by HWA, although smaller trees exhibited higher mortality rates than larger trees. All remaining T. canadensis sampled in seven of the eight stands were infested with HWA and over 90% suffered at least 50% foliar loss. Substantial accumulations of downed woody debris have developed in stands with severe HWA damage. Canopy gaps created by HWA damage significantly increased the amount of light reaching the forest floor and resulted in rapid understorey vegetation responses. Prolific Betula lenta (black birch) establishment occurred in stands with moderate to severe T. canadensis mortality. In addition, opportunistic herbaceous species (Erechtites hieracifolia, Phytolacca americana) and exotic species (Ailanthus altissima, Microstegium vimineum) have recently invaded these stands. Due to mortality from HWA, T. canadensis seedlings were scarce in sampled stands, suggesting that advance regeneration and seed banks will not be important mechanisms for T. canadensis reestablishment. Tsuga canadensis cannot sprout following defoliation and has no apparent resistance to HWA. Therefore, dramatic reductions in T. canadensis across broad geographical areas appear imminent if HWA dispersal continues unimpeded and no effective natural enemies of HWA are found.

bibl.et: Neighborhood approach for quantifying interspecific competition in coastal Oregon forests.
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Science, Oregon State University, Corvallis, Oregon 97331, USA.

ab.p: The neighbourhood approach (where plant competition is examined at the individual-plant-level) was assessed for use in quantifying interspecific competition around Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) seedlings that were planted in early-successional forest vegetation dominated by the perennial shrub salmonberry (Rubus spectabilis). Woody and herbaceous vegetation in the neighbourhoods of >685 trees was manipulated on four sites in the Oregon Coast Range for five years. The best neighbourhood expression of interspecific competition was investigated by systematically examining the influence of various measures of woody-neighbour abundance, height, distance, and spatial arrangement in regression models that predict the annual basal area and height growth of Douglas-fir. The optimum neighbourhood height and radius was determined for each year. Visual estimates of shrub species cover provided the best assessment of neighbour abundance. Stratifying the neighbourhood by the height of shrubs relative to the height of the Douglas-fir improved regression models and quantified patterns of competitive asymmetry. Differences in the response of Douglas-fir height and basal area to neighbourhood height suggested that neighbour influences on height growth were asymmetric, while effects on basal area growth were symmetric. Shrub neighbours whose crowns intermingled with that of the Douglas-fir had the greatest influence on Douglas-fir growth and defined the optimum neighbourhood radius. The competitive influence of neighbouring shrubs decreased rapidly as their distance increased beyond the optimum neighbourhood radius. Accounting for neighbour spatial arrangement using two measures of angular dispersion did not improve the models. The best neighbourhood dimensions for Douglas-fir seedlings changed with time, apparently with the dynamics of vertical structure in the plant community. The neighbourhood approach was effective for (1) evaluating various approaches forest managers might use to quantify competing vegetation, (2) examining the dynamics of competitive effects, (3) quantifying asymmetric competition, (4) determining the relative competitive effects of woody and herbaceous vegetation, and (5) documenting the differing response of tree height and basal area growth to neighbouring plants.

bibl.do: Ecology : a bridge between science and society.
bibl.et: Ecology : a bridge between science and society.
bibl.aa: Institute of Ecology, The University of Georgia, Athens, Georgia, USA.

ab.p: The emphasis throughout this book is placed upon the causes and long-term solutions to environmental problems, rather than the usual 'quick-fix' treatment of symptoms. It is considered to be a citizens guide to the principles of modern ecology related to human affairs, and as a textbook for students. There are 8 chapters, a Prologue and an Epilogue: The life support environment (the developed, cultivated and natural environments of the earth); Levels of organization (geographical and political, biological, and ecological hierarchies); The ecosystem (management, Gaia and models); Energetics (laws, food webs, energy partitioning, primary production, solar radiation, and energy flow); Material cycles and physical conditions of existence (the hydrological cycle, salinization, biogeochemical cycles, climatic change, atmospheric gases, recycling, fire, soil resources, and tillage); Population and community ecology (population growth, optimizing energy use, and interactions between species); Development and evolution (succession, models of ecosystem development, and the mechanisms of evolution); Major ecosystem types of the world (the ocean, estuaries and seashores, mangroves and reefs, freshwater marshes and rivers, forested wetlands, deserts, tundra, grasslands, forests, and urban-industrial techno-ecosystems). There is a detailed keyword index.

ab.p: Characteristic features and effects of shifting cultivation, as practiced by tribal peoples in NE India, are outlined, and it is suggested that this form of agriculture causes environmental and forest degradation. The damage to forests caused by fires is then discussed, causes and effects of forest fires are listed, and recommendations for control of forest fires are made.

bibl.et: Pellets made of wood ash and other wastes as nutrient sources for silver birch seedlings.
bibl.ft: Puutuhkasta ja muista jäteaineista valmistetut pelletit rauduskoivun taimien ravinnelähteenä.
bibl.aa: The Finnish Forest Research Institute, Kannus Research Statioh, P.O. Box 44, FIN-69101 Kannus, Finland.

ab.p: The effects of pellets made of wood ash and of ash mixed with other wastes (composted mink dung, composted municipal sewage sludge, or dung from stomachs of slaughtered animals) on the growth and nutrition of silver birch (Betula pendula) seedlings was studied in a greenhouse experiment. Seedlings were grown in peat soil originating from a drained dwarf-shrub pine bog, peat soil from an afforested field, and in mineral soil. The pellets were applied in varying rates (0, 6, 12, 24, 48 t ha-1). When applied at 24 t ha-1, the effect of pelleting was also studied. The pellets promoted seedling growth depending on the waste used, growing medium, and the application rate. The pellets containing the highest amounts of nitrogen increased growth most. As compared with the unpelleted-waste treatment, the use of pelleted waste material decreased seedling growth. This was probably due to the reduced solubility of the nutrients contained by the waste material when presented in pelleted form. Pellets increased the foliar nutrient concentrations of many elements depending on the waste used, the growing medium, and the application rate.

ab.p: Proceedings of the 1995 conference are presented. Papers are divided between five sections entitled: integrating the human dimension - applications in ecosystem management (nine papers); institutional challenges in integrating the sciences (four papers); deep meaning, sense of place, spatial scale and environmental modelling (six papers); knowledge, values, and attitudes towards ecosystem management (nine papers); and economic values, development, and impact of ecosystem management (five papers). Case studies cover a range of different ecosystems types including wetland, forestry and highland. Particular reference is made to the USA.

bibl.et: Mapping riparian vegetation along rivers: old concepts and new methods.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Geographic information systems and remote sensing in aquatic botany.
bibl.aa: Centre d'Ecologie des Systèmes Aquatiques Continentaux (C.E.S.A.C.), UMR C5576 (Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique/Université Paul Sabatier) 29, rue Jeanne Marvig, 31055 Toulouse Cedex 4, France.

ab.p: This paper presents a discussion about the historical trends in vegetation mapping concepts with the aim of identifying useful aspects for improving the GIS approach to studying vegetation dynamics. In the first part, a summary of the debates in the scientific community is presented and includes summaries of the opposing arguments put forward by taxonomists and physiognomists and the repercussions derived from the development of concepts of ecosystem and landscape. The second part of the paper focuses on two specific requirements for remote sensing (RS) of riparian vegetation, namely high spatial resolution and spatially-oriented classification algorithms. The author considers recent improvements in satellite data as possibly stimulating studies on riparian vegetation, although, aerial photographs are still considered the best medium for analysing riparian vegetation in detail. The third part of the paper presents a discussion which focuses on the use of GIS for riparian vegetation studies. Mapping vegetation is considered a driving element in research, a means to moderate the subjectivity of conceptual statements and to validate ecological theories. On floodplains the major problem is a lack of useful data and the high cost for obtaining such data: the main challenge is therefore identified as the mapping flood disturbances and the vegetation dynamic.

index.de: classification\ecosystems\floodplains\geographical information systems\mapping\monitoring\remote sensing\riparian vegetation\rivers\satellite imagery

bibl.et: Modeling impacts of forest roads on recreation opportunities.
bibl.aa: School of Forestry, University of Montana, Missoula, MT 59802, USA.

ab.p: Transportation systems are one of the key components of forest recreation activities, yet they are often overlooked and seldom adequately considered in the planning process. This paper presents a road impact model (RIM) used to analyse transportation networks to determine their impact on recreation opportunities in an area. Four categories of opportunities are considered in this analysis: experiential recreation, physical recreation, transportation network, and aesthetics. The RIM model is demonstrated on a test area within the Chippewa National Forest, Minnesota, utilizing a geographic information system (GIS) to aid in spatial data handling. The case study presents and demonstrates an assessment framework based on simplified interpretations of the four identified opportunity classes. This spatially explicit approach will aid recreation planning through providing information on current recreation opportunities and on potential recreation opportunities driven by changes to the road or trail systems in an area.

bibl.et: Decaying logs as germination sites in northern hardwood forests.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Environmental and Forest Biology, State University of New York, College of Environmental Science and Forestry, 1 Forestry Drive, Syracuse, New York, 13210, USA.

ab.p: Densities of small seedlings (≤ 5 cm high) of seven tree species were sampled on and directly adjacent to logs in two northern hardwood stands in the Adirondack mountains of New York. Polar ordination of 42 microsite plots revealed distinctly different small seedling communities on logs vs. forest floor. Yellow birch [Betula alleghaniensis] and red spruce [Picea rubens] densities were 24 times and 5 times greater on logs than forest floor, while those of sugar maple [Acer saccharum] and striped maple [A. pensylvanicum] were 8 times and 4 times greater on the forest floor. Red maple [A. rubrum], American beech [Fagus grandifolia] and eastern hemlock [Tsuga canadensis] were the least abundant species and densities did not differ between logs and forest floor, although hemlock only occurred on one log. Maintaining a natural level (~5% ground cover) of well distributed logs can supplement site preparation techniques such as soil scarification to provide regeneration sites for yellow birch and red spruce, particularly in heavily stocked northern hardwood stands.

bibl.et: Porcupine feeding damage in precommercially thinned conifer stands of central southeast Alaska.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Deschutes National Forest, 1645 Highway 20 East, Bend OR 97701, USA.

ab.p: This study describes feeding damage by porcupines (Erethizon dorsatum) in precommercially thinned young-growth stands of Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) and western hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla) on Mitkof Island in central southeast Alaska. A total of 641 trees were examined from 54 sampling plots along transect lines in three stands, 12 to 20 years old. Porcupine feeding was monitored each spring and autumn from 1985 to 1987. Four categories of feeding damage are described: complete girdling of the bole, partial girdling (bole scars), branch clipping, and 'tasting wounds' (small basal bole scars). Sitka spruce, the primary crop tree in these thinned stands, sustained significantly higher damage (52% of trees affected) than western hemlock (26% of trees affected). Porcupine feeding was greater on taller than shorter Sitka spruce. Although only 8 of 59 trees initially girdled in 1985 were killed, many later sustained additional feeding damage. Following the 1987 season 3 years after thinning, nearly 30% of the spruce and 14% of the western hemlock crop trees had been partially or completely girdled.

bibl.et: Conjoint analysis: a preference-based approach for the accounting of multiple benefits in southern forest management.
bibl.aa: Daniel B. Warnell School of Forest Resources, University of Georgia, Athens, Georgia 30602-2152, USA.

ab.p: Conjoint analysis, which enables a manager to measure the relative importance of the multidimensional attributes of a forest, is critically reviewed and assessed. Special attention is given to the feasibility of using conjoint analysis for measuring the utility of market and nonmarket outputs from southern US forests. Also, an application to a case of designing a nature and recreational park within a longleaf pine (Pinus palustris) forest of North Carolina is presented. It is concluded that there are promising applications for conjoint analysis; however, traditional validity testing, especially of southern nonindustrial private forest owners, is needed.

bibl.et: The influence of thinning on tree height and diameter relationships in loblolly pine plantations.
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, VA 24061-0324, USA.

ab.p: Loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) data from thinned and unthinned plantations in its native range in the southern USA were used to evaluate the effects of thinning on tree height-diameter relationships. Results showed that thinning positively influences both tree height and diameter growth in loblolly pine plantations. The intensity of the thinning and the time since thinning, along with the inherent site quality, will determine the magnitude and duration of the thinning response. An equation for predicting total tree height from diameter at breast and certain stand characteristics is developed from the data and can be used for predicting tree height in thinned and unthinned plantations.

bibl.et: Distribution and characterization of forested wetlands in the Carolinas and Virginia.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Forest Inventory and Analysis, Southern Research Station, Asheville, NC 28802, USA.

ab.p: Recent forest inventories of North Carolina, South Carolina and Virginia included sampling for hydric vegetation, hydric soils, and wetland hydrology. Forest samples that met all 3 of these criteria were classified as forested wetland. This study characterizes wetland forests by extent, owner, age, forest type, physiography, volume, growth, and removals, and evaluates its contribution to the timber supply. Wetland stands comprise 8.1 million acres, or 17% of the forests in the 3 States. They are over 90% privately owned, they vary widely by type and physiography, and they contribute 21% of all removals. Classification of wetland area based simply on broad management class and physiography will result in inaccurate estimates.
