bibl.et: Financial performance of maple-birch stands in Wisconsin: value growth rate versus equivalent annual income.
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 1630 Linden Drive, Madison, WI 53705, USA.

ab.p: The value growth rate and equivalent annual income per acre were computed for the maple-birch [Acer-Betula] plots measured at the last two Wisconsin forest inventories. The computations reflected stand growth as well as real price changes between the two inventories. The equivalent annual income averaged $13/acre on industrial forests, and $8.50/acre on public and other private lands. Stand value growth rates, in percent per year, suggested much higher returns, but they are misleading because many of the stands that grew fast were understocked and gave low returns per acre. At the other extreme, some of the best stocked stands (highest basal area) also were poor financial performers. A regression equation showed that the stands of highest equivalent annual income were on better sites, had a basal area of about 80 ft²/acre, a large number of smaller poles ready to become sawtimber, large proportions of oak [Quercus], elm [Ulmus americana], ash [Fraxinus], and cherry [Prunus serotina] trees, and few aspen [Populus] or conifers. No single variable had a major effect by itself, but within the range of the data, by changing all of them together, the annual income on land of average site index could double.

ab.p: The New Forestry Act (1993) divided Slovenian forestry into the Public Forest Service and forest enterprises. A questionnaire was used to determine the conditions, course of development and market orientation of 6 forest enterprises. The enterprises are distinguished from each other primarily by different priorities give to the various activities. Felling and skidding are the most important activities related to income in all enterprises, while wood sales and transport are the most profitable.

bibl.et: Loblolly pine: the ecology and culture of loblolly pine (Pinus taeda L.).
bibl.ms: ref. at ends of each chapter
bibl.aa: Southern Forest Experiment Station, USDA Forest Service, New Orleans, LA, USA.

ab.p: This book summarizes the results of an exhaustive search and review of literature on loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) published between 1960 and 1990, with the addition of noteworthy references and technical innovations since then. There are 12 chapters, each paginated separately. Part 1, Ecology of loblolly pine, includes an introduction, and chapters covering botanical and silvical characteristics, and habitat. Part 2, Management of loblolly pine, includes 9 chapters: Site preparation; Natural regeneration; Artificial regeneration; Genetics (and tree improvement); Stand management; Multiple-use management of loblolly pine forest resources; Protection (including damage by diseases, insect pests and climate, and its control); Growth and yield; and International importance of loblolly pine. There is a subject and species index.

bibl.do: Technical Note - Technical Development Branch, Forest Research
bibl.et: Foam concentrates for forest fire fighting.
bibl.aa: Forestry Commission, Technical Development Branch, Ae Village, Dumfries, UK.

ab.p: This note details the types of foam concentrates available and the environmental effects that should be considered when foam is used. The UK National Rivers Authority (NRA) suggests that protein and synthetic Aqueous Film Forming Foam (AFFF) foams would be less damaging to aquatic life. Forest Enterprise currently uses synthetic detergent foams for aerial and ground based fire fighting. Previous work by the Forestry Commission suggested that a synthetic detergent foam was superior to a protein foam but further tests should be carried out to confirm performance. Synthetic foam concentrates currently in Forest Enterprise stores should be used following the guidelines in this report. A trial of protein concentrates is recommended including a comparison with synthetic material.

bibl.et: Forestry, soil rent and taxation.
bibl.ft: Skogbruk, grunnrente og skatt.
bibl.pb: Norsk Institutt for Skogforskning (Norwegian Forest Research Institute)
bibl.aa: Institutt for skogfag, NLH, N-1432 Ås, Norway.

ab.p: A Norwegian governmental committee studying tax reforms related to the effects on employment and environment has pointed to the possibility of taxing the rents of exploiting scarce natural resources. In this article the concept of rent related to forestry is discussed. The current forest taxation is based on net harvest income in which forest rent as a matter of principle is included. However, the methods of calculating income brings about significant deviations. An alternative system implying taxing annual value increment is discussed. The effects of different systems depend on what environmental or other factors are emphasized.

ab.p: The case-study describes an agricultural/forestry property which has been developed for cabin rental for tourism. In this case the profit is the result of (i) good timing; (ii) development of a unique product; (iii) goal-oriented marketing; (iv) acquiring competence; (v) network building; (vi) an opportune combination-enterprise which transfers forestry assets to equity; and (vii) an enterprise which exploits the advantages of a large concern in both operation and marketing.

bibl.et: Factors influencing male mating success in bur oak, Quercus macrocarpa.
bibl.aa: Department of Biological Science, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL 60607, USA.

ab.p: Pollen donors of acorns and saplings in a stand of mature bur oaks in Illinois were identified by paternity exclusion using microsatellite genotype analysis, and an examination made of the influence of several factors likely to affect reproductive success of males with wind-dispersed pollen. The factors included distance of pollen donor from maternal tree, genetic relatedness of pollen donor to maternal tree, direction of pollen donor relative to maternal tree, and size of pollen donor (crown volume and stem diameter). None of these factors were strongly correlated with fertilization success, although weak but significant correlations with crown volume and distance were found. The slight influence of distance was overestimated because the analysis necessarily excluded a large proportion of pollinations that were effected by trees outside the stand. The pollen donors outside the stand were not identified, but were more than 150 m distant. Pollination patterns in the stand were quite complicated. Seed parents were fertilized by multiple pollen donors within the stand from all directions and as far as 200 m away. These results caution against the use of models of pollination that are based on simple distance or directional parameters because they will not adequately predict gene flow or male reproductive success. The results further emphasize the importance of genetically identifying successful pollen donors rather than relying on patterns of physical movement of pollen.

ab.p: Needle, seed and cone characteristics of Abies guatemalensis were studied for 3 populations in Chiapas, Mexico. Statistical analysis showed that 12 of the 20 characteristics were significantly different between populations, and all except seed width were significantly different within populations. Two populations had similar morphology and were closely related to A. guatemalensis var. tacanensis, while the other location related to A. guatemalensis.

bibl.et: Protostelids from tropical forests of Costa Rica.
bibl.aa: Department of Biology, Fairmont State College, Fairmont, West Virginia 26554, USA.

ab.p: Samples for isolation of protostelids were collected in November 1995 and March 1997 from two microhabitats, forest floor litter and aerial litter (dead but still attached plant parts), in tropical forests at four different localities in Costa Rica. Seventeen species of protostelids were recovered from these samples. In general, numbers of species recorded for samples of forest floor litter were rather comparable to those recorded for samples of aerial litter. Schizoplasmodiopsis pseudoendospora, Nematostelium gracile, and N. ovatum appear to be the most widely distributed and abundant species associated with the litter microhabitat in the forests sampled.

bibl.et: The rise, decline and extinction of spring wood management in south-west Yorkshire.
bibl.ct: European woods and forests: studies in cultural history, based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996.
bibl.aa: Sheffield Hallam University, City Campus, Sheffield S1 1WB, UK.

ab.p: Evidence is presented on changes in woodland management in SW Yorkshire (the present metropolitan districts of Sheffield and Rotherham), northern England, over the last 1000 yr. Four distinct phases are distinguished, during which coppice management gradually became dominant, reached a high degree of sophistication, exploited a succession of markets, and then gradually went into almost terminal decline. The phases are described as: the wood pasture tradition; the retreat of wood pasture and emergence of coppice management as the dominant management form, in which phase fuelwood and charcoal were produced for smeltering; the decline and extinction of spring wood management and the rise of high forest; and lastly, coniferization, neglect, amenity and the revival of woodmanship.

ab.p: The 'Schlagwaldwirtschaft' is a forest management system based on growing and felling trees section by section in an evenly divided woodland, so that overall the woodland is sustainable, and the property and annual rates of return from it are protected. The historical motives for implementation of the system are discussed, and the measures and their ecological and social consequences described.

bibl.et: Performance of Prosopis cineraria and associated crops under varying spacing regimes in the arid zone of India.
bibl.aa: Division of Forest Ecology and Desert Development, Arid Forest Research Institute, New Pali Road, Jodhpur-342005, India.

ab.p: A field experiment with Prosopis cineraria (khejri, an important agroforestry tree species in arid India) was conducted in 1990-94 at the Arid Forest Research Institute at Jodhpur, Rajasthan, to evaluate tree-crop interactions as affected by varying tree density (1666, 833 and 417 stems ha-1) and different intercrops (Vigna mungo, Cyamopsis tetragonoloba, Vigna aconitifolia and Pennisetum glaucum). The trees were established as seedlings in July 1990, and intercropping started in 1991. During the tree establishment phase (1991-92), Prosopis cineraria did not compete with the associated crops at the 2 lower tree densities, nor was its growth affected by them at any density. Data on soil water content in cropped and uncropped plots confirmed this lack of competition, but also showed differences between crops in their effect on soil water. However, when the trees were older, and at higher tree densities, crop yield was reduced, and there was a decrease in soil water in the upper 75 cm layer, indicating competition between trees and crops for water. At 4 yr old, 417 stems ha-1 (4×6 m spacing) was the optimum density for both tree growth and crop yield, with higher stem densities adversely affected both tree growth and crop yield. The pulses were better suited than Pennisetum glaucum as intercrops.

bibl.et: Structure and function in two tropical gallery forest communities: implications for forest conservation in fragmented systems.
bibl.aa: Department of Geography, York University, Toronto, Ontario, M3J 1P3, Canada.

ab.p: Composition, growth and turnover of trees were examined in 2 species-rich tropical gallery forests in the Mountain Pine Ridge Savanna of Belize during 1996, to evaluate what community reorganization is needed to transform recently created tropical forest fragments into stable refugia for regional forest biotas. Rates of tree growth and turnover over a 5-year interval were comparable to those recorded in continuous forests and in both communities some tree species turnover was observed in the measured stem size classes. The more abundant tree species in both communities formed 3 functional groups along gradients between streams and forest edges (edge-concentrators, core-concentrators and generalists). Soil fertility did not increase close to streams and neither tree growth nor recruitment rates were increased in this zone. In contrast, forest edge zones exhibited increased rates of tree growth and recruitment indicating that growth processes in these forests were light-limited rather than soil-limited. Both communities showed signs of past fire incursions, and the tendency of a subset of tree species to concentrate in the more growth-limited core habitats was attributed to their fire sensitivity. It is concluded that rapid development of an edge zone of fire-insensitive tree species is essential to the survival of forest community fragments in the fire-prone landscapes of the tropics, and that the edges of gallery forests are recommended as potential sources of species with which to fashion these protective ecotones. It is suggested that the preservation of a diverse forest biota in the fire-protected interiors of forest fragments may require natural or artificially enhanced immigration rates that are sufficient to offset local extinctions.

bibl.et: The interaction of thorns and symbiotic ants as an effective defence mechanism of swollen-thorn acacias.
bibl.aa: Department of Zoology, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EJ, UK.

ab.p: Evidence is provided for the interaction of ants (Crematogaster spp.) and thorns as a defence mechanism against browsing mammals for the African myrmecophyte Acacia drepanolobium. Two experiments were conducted during 1996 in the Mkomazi Game Reserve, northern Tanzania, using goats as representative mammalian browsers, the swollen thorns of A. drepanolobium being inhabited by colonies of ants which are able to bite and rub acid into the wound. In the first experiment, the defences of individual branches were manipulated in order to assess the effectiveness of ants and thorns both on their own and together as anti-herbivore defences. Ants on their own were more effective for a single branch compared with the plant possessing neither ants nor thorns, but ants from a single branch did not add significantly to the effectiveness of thorns as an anti-herbivore defence. It was also observed that ants from a whole tree did significantly add to the effectiveness of thorns as an anti-herbivore defence. In all cases, the goats refused to go back to and feed from a tree whose ants had attacked it. Thorns on their own, however, do not act as total browsing deterrents. Thorns slowed down the rate of feeding but animals often compensated for this by feeding for longer periods of time. It is suggested that the ant-A. drepanolobium association evolved at least partly because of pressure from browsing mammals.

bibl.et: Density variation in Bayur (Pterospermum sp.), Randagong (Trema orientalis) and Magas (Duabanga moluccana) from Sabah, Malaysia.
bibl.ct: Die Variabilität der Rohdichte in Bayur (Pterospermum sp.), Randagong (Trema orientalis) and Magas (Duabanga moluccana) aus Sabah, Malaysia.
bibl.aa: Forest Research Centre, Forestry Department P.O. Box 1407, 90715 Sandakan, Sabah, Malaysia.

ab.p: The lesser utilised timbers bayur (Pterospermum sp.), randagong (Trema orientalis) and magas (Duabanga moluccana) were analysed with regard to the variation of the wood density (ovendry and at 14% moisture content). The average ovendry density of the different individuals varied from 0.36-0.43 g/cm³ in bayur, from 0.24-0.38 g/cm³ in randagong and from 0.26-0.35 g/cm³ in magas. The corresponding values for the density at 14% moisture content were 0.38-0.49 g/cm³ in bayur, 0.29-0.41 g/cm³ in randagong and 0.27-0.35 g/cm³ in magas. All trees showed an increase in density from the centre of the stem to the periphery. The differences between height levels were not significant.

bibl.do: New Zealand Journal of Forestry Science
bibl.et: Realised genetic gain in Pinus radiata from "850" seed-orchard seedlots grown commercially in the central North Island, New Zealand. Part 1: growth.
bibl.aa: New Zealand Forest Research Institute Limited, Private Bag 3020, Rotorua, New Zealand.

ab.p: Analysis of covariance models of diameter and height of 13-yr-old Pinus radiata grown in commercial forests in the central North Island formed the basis for comparing average stand tree diameter (d¯on;) and mean top height (MTH) of non-seed-orchard (non-improved) and '850' seed-orchard seedlots (the '850' denotes a series of clones, the first digit signifying the regional origin, in this case New Zealand Forest Research Institute collections, not necessarily from one region, and the second 2 digits the year of selection, here 1950). Both the d¯on; and MTH models used several groupings of seedlots to determine the impact of these first tree selections on d¯on; and MTH. The models included several variables to remove other growth-affecting factors. For the modelling of d¯on;, altitude and crop stocking were used, and the MTH model used site index. The analyses of covariance for both d¯on; and MTH show no significant improvement overall of '850' seed-orchard seedlots compared with non-improved Kaingaroa climbing select (seeds collected by climbing selected trees in Kaingaroa forest) or Kaingaroa (bulk) seedlots at age 13. The Gwavas '850' seed-orchard 25-clone seedlots did show a significant improvement in d¯on; over Kaingaroa bulk, but not over Kaingaroa climbing select. The results of this study differed from those of large-plot genetic gain and progeny trials. This may be for several reasons. The first 8-10 years of seed production from the '850' seed orchards contained seed of poorer quality than later seed production. Also, the assessment of P. radiata at age 13 may be too early for the detection of divergence of '850' seed-orchard material from non-seed-orchard material to be noticeable in commercial stands. Superior '850' seed-orchard seedlots may have been better than those planted in commercial stands.

bibl.et: Silviculture for people. Close-to-nature forestry in the Bavarian State Forest Administration.
bibl.ft: Waldbau für Menschen. Naturnahe Forstwirtschaft in der Bayerischen Staatsforstverwaltung.
bibl.aa: Staatsministerium für ELF, München, Germany.

ab.p: The legal basis of the work of the Bavarian State Forest Administration is outlined, and the policy of sustainability for the benefit of people is explained. These forest functions include protection forests\the production of wood and other foret products in a sustainable way and the unrestricted use of forest for recreation. With the development of close-to-nature forestry, the standing volume has increased from 222 m³/ha in 1975 to 273 m³/ha in 1995, and the overall ratio of conifers to broadleaves has changed from 77:23 to 73:27 (but in age-class I from 75:25 in 1975 to 60:40 in 1995).

bibl.et: Dendroclimatological reconstructions in Galicia (Spain) since the last years of the XVIII century.
bibl.ft: Reconstrucciones dendroclimatologicas de Galicia (España) desde finales del siglo XVIII.
bibl.aa: Sección de Paleoecolocía, Museo de Arqueoloxía e Prehistoria de Vilalba, Praza de Suso Gayoso, 1, 27800 Vilalba, Lugo, Spain.

ab.p: Three monthly total rainfall and six monthly mean temperatures. The data were reconstructed using Four chronologies for Quercus and Castanea sativa created for the provinces of Lugo, Pontevedra and La Coruña, Spain, were used to analyse 3 monthly totals of precipitation and six monthly mean temperatures at the Santiago de Compostela (University), Lugo and La Coruña meteorological stations. Reconstruction of the variables and information about mean deviations are presented. Similar results were obtained when the reconstructions were compared with each other and with climatic information. During the last two centuries, temperature and rainfall variables have been characterized by a gradual heating, with some cold periods, and progressive irregular rainfall. Both temperature and rainfall appear to have been rising at the reconstructed stations for the two last decades.

bibl.et: The economics of shelter provision on farms.
bibl.ct: Special issue on shelterbelts and shelter trees.
bibl.aa: Institute of Ecology and Resource Management, University of Edinburgh, Darwin Building, Mayfield Road, Edinburgh EH9 3JU, UK.

ab.p: The economic benefit of tree shelter (for crops and livestock) on British farms is generally perceived as not proven. Early 20th century research in North America and Russia indicated substantial benefits but examples of systematic shelter provision in Britain established in that period are now often neglected. An economic assessment of 4 contrasting farm types (hill sheep; upland; lowland, arable or livestock; and lowland, raspberries) suggests that tree shelter can be a viable proposition, particularly on better land. Reasons for the current lack of interest include poorly focused management objectives and a cultural heritage which still divides farming and forestry interests. Further investigation is recommended with regard to productivity, design, grant aid, amenity/conservation value and area coordination aspects.

bibl.et: Efficiency of neem and groundnut oils in protecting leguminous tree seeds against seed beetles in the Sahel.
bibl.aa: ISRA-D.R.P.F./CIRAD-Forêt, BP 2312, Dakar, Senegal.

ab.p: The comparative efficiency was tested of neem (Azadirachta indica) kernel oil, groundnut oil and a synthetic insecticide (K-Othrine [deltamethrin]) in protecting stocks of leguminous tree seeds against seed beetles under Sahelian conditions (in Senegal). The following insect/seed combinations were used as models: Caryedon acaciae [C. serratus]/Acacia nilotica, C. longispinosus/A. raddiana and C. serratus/Tamarindus indica. Neem oil, when used at concentrations of 5-20 ml/kg of seeds, had pronounced adulticidal and ovicidal effects which were maintained for 5 months. No significant fall in seed viability was observed except in the case of C. acaciae/A. nilotica. Groundnut oil, when used at concentrations of 5-20 ml/kg of seeds, had pronounced adulticidal and ovicidal effects which were relatively short-lived. A significant fall in seed viability was observed over 5 months. Deltamethrin when used at concentrations of 25-100 mg/kg, had high adulticidal effects which were maintained for 5 months; however, it had no ovicidal properties. No significant fall in seed viability was observed. This study concluded that it is possible to use neem oil, a product that can be obtained locally at low cost, to protect tree seed stocks efficiently in the Sahel.

bibl.et: Selection criteria for thinning on ancient woodland sites.
bibl.aa: Bradleys Cottage, Broaks Wood, Halstead, Essex CO9 1UL, UK.

ab.p: Manifold criteria are employed when choosing one stem in favour of another during the thinning selection. Those currently in use on ancient woodland sites in southern East Anglia are explained. They include consideration of spacing (for growth promotion), stem form, access for harvesting machinery, species diversity, timber value, hygiene, safety, amenity, wind firmness, recreation, landscape, fecundity (retention of seed trees), light penetration, archaeology, and effects on soil. It is suggested that these criteria are also appropriate for other areas and site types.

bibl.do: New Zealand Journal of Forestry Science
bibl.et: Brushtail possum damage and abundance in a New Zealand Pinus radiata plantation.
bibl.aa: Ecology and Entomology Group, P.O. Box 84, Lincoln University, Canterbury, New Zealand.

ab.p: During summer 1996-97, a Pinus radiata plantation (9000 ha) near Whangamata, North Island, New Zealand, was sampled to assess how intensity and distribution of brushtail possum (Trichosurus vulpecula) damage were related to stand maturity. Based on a review of previous surveys, a new damage-scoring system was developed. Using this system, the overall proportion of pine trees >3 years old with possum damage was found to be very low (3.6% of 1244 trees surveyed) despite possums being present in substantial numbers (mean catch of 28.1 possums per 100 trapnights; range 12.0-54.9). Damage levels varied markedly (0-30%) between 36 plantation blocks. The majority of possum damage involved needle clipping and damage to lateral branches. All damage types showed negative correlations with tree maturity. Given the low damage levels recorded, the cost-effectiveness of current possum-control efforts in pine plantations of this type is uncertain and would benefit from further economic analysis.

bibl.et: Tropical forests under the climates of the last 30,000 years.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Potential impacts of climate change on tropical forest ecosystems. Papers from an international workshop held at San Juan, Puerto Rico, 24-28 April 1995.
bibl.aa: Department of Geography, Massey University, Palmerston North, New Zealand.

ab.p: Vegetational history can help in the prediction of future environments by providing data for testing AGCMs (atmospheric general circulation models), for indicating the vegetational response to rapid warming and changing CO2 concentrations, and for mathematical modelling of vegetation. Most of the data available are palynological, and there are well over 100 pollen diagrams from tropical regions. Maps are presented showing summarized pollen diagrams from the lowlands of South-East Asia and the West Pacific, Tropical Latin America and Tropical Africa. In all these regions there is some evidence suggesting that at the LGM (Last Glacial Maximum) lowland forests were somewhat restricted in area and included montane elements. This is consistent with cooler and drier climate in the LGM. From the montane and lowland areas of these three regions, the pollen evidence is summarized in altitudinal diagrams. These suggest considerable depression of altitudinal zones in the LGM, suggesting temperatures c.&thin;5-10°C cooler than now. These results conflict with earlier oxygen isotope data from marine foraminifera, but do not conflict with more recent oxygen isotope measurements from tropical corals. It is also suggested that altitudinal movements may be partly controlled by CO2 concentration and ultraviolet light.

index.de: altitude\climate\climatic change\forests\global warming\history\lowland areas\maps\mountain forests\palaeoecology\palynology\pollen analysis\tropical forests\tropics\vegetation

bibl.et: Possible effects of climate change on plant/herbivore interactions in moist tropical forests.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Potential impacts of climate change on tropical forest ecosystems. Papers from an international workshop held at San Juan, Puerto Rico, 24-28 April 1995.
bibl.aa: Department of Biology, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA.

ab.p: Interactions between plants and herbivores (the discussion relates mostly insect herbivores) are key determinants of community structure worldwide, and their role is particularly important in lowland tropical rain forests where rates of herbivory are higher, plants are better defended chemically and physically, and herbivores have specialized diets. In contrast to the temperate zone, most of the herbivory in the tropics occurs on ephemeral young leaves (>70%), which requires herbivores to have finely tuned host-finding abilities. As a consequence of these tight ecological and evolutionary linkages, the interplay between plants and herbivores in the tropics may be more susceptible to perturbations of climate change. Increases in global temperature, atmospheric CO2, and the length of the dry season are all likely to have ramifications for plant/herbivore interactions in the tropics - this paper presents a scenario for possible trends under a changing climate. Although increased CO2 tends to enhance plant growth rates, the larger effects of increased drought stress will probably result in lower growth. In atmospheres experimentally enriched in CO2, the nutritional quality of leaves declines substantially due to a dilution of nitrogen by 10-30%. This response is buffered in plant species associated with nitrogen fixers. Increased CO2 should also cause a slight decrease in nitrogen-based defences (e.g. alkaloids) and a slight increase in carbon-based defences (e.g. tannins). The most dramatic and robust predicted effect of climate change is on rates of herbivory. Lower foliar nitrogen due to CO2 fertilizing of plants causes an increase in consumption per herbivore by as much as 40%, and unusually severe drought appears to cause herbivore populations to explode. In areas where increased CO2 is combined with drying, rates of herbivory may rise 2-4 fold. The frequency of insect outbreaks is also expected to increase. Higher herbivory should further reduce plant growth rates, perhaps favouring plant species that are well-defended or fix nitrogen. The predicted increase in the number of herbivores is primarily due to relaxed pressure from predators (possibly by increased temperature causing increased herbivore developmental times, affording partial protection from natural enemies) and parasitoids (whose populations appear to be decimated by drought, although decline may also be due to the relative scarcity of herbivores during drought). The relative abundance of species will, therefore, change, and overall biodiversity should decline.

bibl.et: Fractionation of woody biomass with boiling aqueous acetic acid containing a small amount of mineral acid at atmospheric pressure: Reactivity of arylglycerol-β-aryl ethers in lignins with aqueous acetic acid containing H2SO4.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Agriculture, Hokkaido University, Sapporo 060-0809, Japan.

ab.p: To characterize the mechanism of the reaction of lignin with aqueous acetic acid (AW) containing a small amount of H2SO4, guaiacylglycerol-β-guaiacyl ether (GOG), and guaiacylglycerol-β-syringyl ether (GOS) were refluxed in 90% AW with 0.28% H2SO4 for 0-120 min. Reaction products and their silylated derivatives were characterized by analytical methods such as gas chromatography-mass spectrometry and nuclear magnetic resonance. When the model compounds were allowed to react at boiling temperature for 0 min (heat-up time 30 min), most of their primary alcohol groups and some of their secondary alcohol groups were acetylated, but their phenolic groups were not. About 90% of GOG was degraded, polymerized, or both during boiling for at least 15 min, yielding guaiacol and isocoumaran compounds (GOG-e and GOG-f) in addition to homovanillin (II) as guaiacylvinyl alcohol (I) and other minor products. GOS yielded syringol, homovanillin (II), and a novel compound (V) together with unknown products but not the corresponding isocoumaran compounds.

bibl.et: Tree productivity and successional status in Québec northern hardwoods.
bibl.aa: Institut de Recherche en Biologie Végétale, Université de Montréal et Jardin botanique de Montréal, 4101, rue Sherbrooke Est, Montréal, Québec, H1X 2B2, Canada.

ab.p: The age, production and biomass of 3273 stems were estimated in 34 stands distributed along a stand age gradient in south-western Québec. The successional status of a species was determined by comparing its abundance with stand age in a contingency table. Linear regressions of the logarithm of the age of trees with the logarithm of the aerial biomass (log [B]), the logarithm of the net primary production (log[NPP]) and the relative biomass increment (NNP/B) were established for each species. An analysis of covariance allowed the separation of statistically different species regression curves. Sugar maple (Acer saccharum), American beech (Fagus grandifolia) and eastern hemlock (Tsuga canadensis) are indicator species of old stands; bitternut hickory (Carya cordiformis), white ash (Fraxinus americana), butternut (Juglans cinerea), black cherry (Prunus serotina), white elm (Ulmus americana) and red elm (Ulmus rubra) are mostly found in young stands. Ironwood (Ostrya virginiana) is a ubiquitous species, found in stands of all ages. Analysis of the relationships between tree age and B, NPP and NPP/B revealed that the more a species is capable of rapidly increasing its biomass at a young age, the less it is able to sustain this growth with increasing age. This growth trade-off relationships ordered species along a gradient of productivity patterns closely linked to the observed stand age gradient.

bibl.ft: Propriété privée et politique de reboisement le cas des Groupements Forestiers.
bibl.aa: Université Lumière, Lyon 2, France.

ab.p: The conflict between private forest owners and those demanding public access to forests in France led to the establishment by law in 1954 of 'Groupements Forestiers', groups of private forests with responsibility for regional afforestation and forest management. At the start of the 1980's there were some 3000 groupements covering 480&thin;000 ha in France. These were of great importance in the area to the south of the Massif Central and in particular in Tarn and l'Aveyron. Five types of groupements operating in l'Aveyron are identified and discussed in detail. The most numerous type brings together small farmers, with each groupement covering an average of 56 ha. Less numerous but having a greater area (average 130 ha each) are groupements of small farmers in association with the area forest administration society whose consolidated support is large but temporary. It is concluded that the groupements were set up at a time when modern agricultural systems were changing the lives and land ownership patterns of small farmers and it has been argued that the new categories of ownership and the creation of forests as technico-industrial units thus established suppressed indigenous knowledge of the means of living off the forest on the margins of the market economy. The groupements did establish a hybrid private/public forest system which is considered of great importance to the wider debate on public ownership and access.

index.de: forest management\forests\land ownership\peasant farming\peasantry\private forestry\small farms

bibl.et: Phytosociological studies of the ground flora in different types of vegetation on Tiger Hill, Darjeeling District, West Bengal.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Botany, North Bengal University, Siliguri (West Bengal), India.

ab.p: A large part of Tiger Hill Forest in West Bengal was clear felled in the first decade of this century and a part of it was planted with Cryptomeria japonica in 1921. There are now 3 types of vegetation in the area: (i) natural forest, (ii) plantation forest and (iii) grassland. Phytosociological studies were undertaken to determine the differences in the ground vegetation within these vegetational types and the the relative density, relative frequency and importance value of its elements. Altogether 85 species and 3672 individuals were recorded from fifteen 1 m² quadrats. While 33.33% of species were the same in natural forest and plantation forest, only 7.25% were the same in natural forest and grassland, and 13.84% were the same in plantation forest and grassland. Therophytes (40%) appeared to be the most successful life form, but chamaephytes (24.7%) were also well represented along with 14.12% cryptophytes, 12.94% hemicryptophytes and 8.23% phanerophytes. Most of the 31 species of angiosperms recorded from the plantation forest were sparsely distributed, weak and produced only few or no flowers. A more spaced plantation of Cryptomeria japonica mixed with selected broadleaved non-resinous trees has been suggested as suitable for improving the ground vegetation. However, all ground species recorded from natural forest (37 species) and grassland (43 species) were normal in their development and reproduction although they were much affected with grazing.

index.de: botanical composition\forest plantations\forests\grasslands\grazing\ground vegetation\life form\species diversity\synecology\tropical forests

bibl.et: Spoil characteristics and vegetation development in different aged flyash dykes of Chachai (M.P.) thermal power plants.
bibl.aa: Forest Ecology and Rehabilitation Division, Tropical Forest Research Institute, Mandla Road, Jabalpur, India.

ab.p: The successional development and spoil characteristics were studied in 6-60 month old fly ash dykes and adjacent natural forest in Chachai, Madhya Pradesh. The number of species increased steadily as a function of the age of the dyke: there were only 3 species in the 6 months old dyke but this had increased to 33 species in the 60 months old dyke. Species found at each site are listed, and phytosociological indexes and relative biomass, and similarity indexes between pairs of sites given. Tree species started to appear in the 24-36 month old communities, and as the plant communities aged there was increasing similarity with natural forest. With the progress of weathering, the spoil characteristics improved gradually in organic matter and nutrient content facilitating the recruitment of new species.

bibl.et: Physiological basis for the ecological preference of Eucalyptus globulus Labill (blue gum) III: nutritional status, growth performance and oil production.
bibl.aa: Tamil Nadu Agricultural University Coimbatore (Tamil Nadu), India.

ab.p: The nutrient status was investigated (by means of foliar diagnosis) of 4- and 8-yr-old plantations of Eucalyptus globulus grown at 2 altitudes (2300 and 2067 m, designated high and low) in Tamil Nadu, and related to growth performance and (essential) oil production. Nutrients determined were total and soluble nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, calcium and magnesium. The results of correlation analysis indicated the significance of foliar nutrient status for the development of diameter growth and also for oil production. Total nitrogen and phosphorus status had a direct and significant effect on diameter growth (r 0.43 and 0.48, respectively). Potassium played a dual role in promoting better production of oil and growth performance; it had a direct influence on oil production (r 0.40) and also an indirect effect on growth performance by increasing the foliar status of total and soluble nitrogen.

bibl.et: Regeneration of tree legume - Albizia procera (Roxb.) Benth. through tissue culture.
bibl.aa: Division of Genetics and Tree Propagation, Forest Research Institute, Dehra Dun, India.

ab.p: Plantlets were produced in vitro from hypocotyl and nodal bud explants of Albizia procera. Explants were reared for 8 wk on MS medium + 0.1-2.0 mg/litre of IAA, IBA, NAA, 2,4-D, BAP [benzyladenine] or KN [kinetin], or combinations of these growth regulators . Multiple shoots differentiated directly on the explants and from callus of explants; detailed data are tabulated for shoot production from each single treatment and from benzyladenine + NAA or IBA treatments. A combination of MS + 1.0 mg/litre BAP + 0.5 mg/litre NAA gave best differentiation and proliferation of shoots. This combination enhanced shoot proliferation rate 13-16 fold in 180 days upon serial transfer of cultures. Nodal segments yielded more shoots than hypocotyl explants. Rooting was achieved in 1/2 MS + 1.5 mg/litre IBA + 1.0% activated charcoal. The plantlets were acclimatized stepwise and successfully transferred to soil.

bibl.et: Nodulation and seedling growth in some nitrogen fixing tree species.
bibl.aa: High Altitude Plant Physiology Research Centre, H.N.B. Garhwal University, Srinagar Garhwal, 246 174, U.P., India.

ab.p: Seedlings of 5 nitrogen fixing tree (NFT) species (Albizia lebbeck, Albizia stipulata, Dalbergia sericea, Dalbergia sissoo, Ougeinia dalbergioides) growing in the Indian Himalayan region were assessed for their nodulation behaviour in the nursery. In terms of nodule number, nodulation was highest in D. sericea and D. sissoo, but quantitatively A. stipulata had the highest nodule weight per plant. On the basis of nodule nitrogen, although A. stipulata had highest nitrogen turnover per plant, the rhizobial strain associated with D. sericea seemed to be highly efficient than other species.

bibl.et: Analysis of variability in morphological traits in Populus ciliata Wall. ex Royle provenances.
bibl.aa: Dr. Y.S. Parmar University of Horticulture and Forestry, Solan, 173 230, India.

ab.p: Thirty provenances of Populus ciliata Wall ex Royle sampled from Himachal Pradesh in India were evaluated for various morphological traits. Significant differences among provenances were observed for all the traits studied except leaf index. Large amount of variability was observed for height, collar diameter and internodal length. The other two traits viz., bark thickness and leaf index exhibited low amount of variability between provenances. Provenances from Shimla and Chamba region were promising for growth parameters and thus provides an opportunity for further selection of superior genotypes for use in future breeding programme. Correlation studies revealed that significant correlations were observed between plant height and collar diameter, internodal length and bark thickness. However, none of the growth parameters were found correlated with survival per cent which suggests independent control of these parameters.

bibl.et: Performance of fourteen provenances of Gliricidia sepium.
bibl.aa: State Forest Research Institute, Polipathar, Jabalpur (M.P.), India.

ab.p: Nine-year data on survival, height and diameter growth, and fuelwood production are reported for 14 Latin American provenances of G. sepium in trials started at the Forest Research Institute, Jabalpur, Madhya Pradesh in 1988, on a sandy well drained site. Germination data are also given. Survival ranged from 57 to 98%. Superior provenances are recommended for use for fuelwood production and cover on poor sites (where the species is particularly useful).

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Species-richness of African grazer assemblages: towards a functional explanation.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Department of Terrestrial Ecology and Nature Conservation, Wageningen Agricultural University, Bornesteeg 69, 6708 PD Wageningen, Netherlands.

ab.p: A theoretical analysis was made on the underlying causes of variation in the species-richness of herbivore assemblages in Africa at different spatial scales. The study was restricted to grazers. The fact that many species of grazers are unable to co-occur in the same area was explored. An attempt is made to explain the species composition and species-richness of grazer assemblages by resource competition and facilitation interactions. Simple theoretical arguments are presented regarding the dependence of gross and net daily food intake on body mass, and the consequences of body mass for numerical response patterns on an annual basis. Experimental data are reviewed for the interdependence of primary production and quality of primary production, and for the functional response patterns of differently sized herbivores. It is concluded that forage quality may decrease with increasing plant standing crop, imposing an important constraint on net nutrient and energy intake by grazers. Both theoretical arguments and experimental evidence support the conclusion that large grazers are better suited to handling high biomass/low quality forage than smaller species. It is suggested therefore that the presence of large herbivores may decrease the standing crop and improve forage quality, leading to facilitation for smaller grazers. However, when the body mass difference is too large, the smaller species is not expected to benefit from the presence of the larger species. When 2 species in a herbivore assemblage have very similar body mass, then resource competition is expected to prevail over facilitation interactions. Some optimum difference between body weights of subsequent species in assemblages is expected. Experimental data on grazer assemblages on different spatial scales (whole of Africa, whole ecosystems, parts of ecosystems) indicate that body masses show a certain regularity. Each species in an assemblage is, on average, a constant proportion larger than the next smaller one (i.e. the species show a constant weight ratio), and it is concluded that these data provide evidence that the body mass of different species in herbivore assemblages do not represent a random selection from a uniform distribution, but rather have a certain regularity, which might be related to the balance between competition and facilitation interactions. Observational evidence on the effect of the removal and addition of grazers in African national parks is reviewed. The scarce evidence available suggests that grazers more similar in body mass are more likely to compete, and that large grazers may facilitate for smaller ones. A map of potential species-richness of African grazer assemblages is compiled through a GIS overlay of the distribution maps of 96 species. This map indicates that the highest potential species-richness of grazers is found in East Africa and in the border area of Zimbabwe and Mozambique. Furthermore, weight ratios and species-richness patterns are described for a large number of ecosystems. The causes of regional and local variation are discussed in terms of area size, primary productivity, habitat isolation, fragmentation and competition and facilitation interactions.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Niche specificity among tropical trees: a question of scales.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: The Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University, 22 Divinity Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA.

ab.p: A review is presented concerning the stochastic processes and events which play an important part in determining the structure (including floristic composition), of plant communities and the way patterns observed in nature are determined. Area vs. habitat as determinant of species richness, rank order of abundance, ecological plasticity, rare species, population genetics and mobile links are discussed in depth. Of particular relevance is the renewed interest in the striking structural similarities that exist in forests on different continents that share a common habitat. It is suggested that with appropriate sampling design, such global comparisons of forest dynamics may yield a general theory which will be of importance to foresters and conservation biologists as much as to theoreticians.

index.de: botanical composition\evolution\extinction\forest ecology\forest trees\forests\genetic drift\habitats\immigration\nature conservation\plant communities\population dynamics\population genetics\reviews\selection\species diversity\trees\tropical forests\tropics\woody plants

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Disturbance and succession on the Krakatau Islands, Indonesia.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: School of Geography, Oxford University, Mansfield Road, Oxford OX1 3TB, UK.

ab.p: A review of studies concerning the development of Krakatau's forest ecosystems since apparent sterilization in 1883 is presented highlighting; (i) the development of successional pathways; (ii) the role of dispersal systems and vectors; (iii) the influence of volcanism on diversification and community development; and (iv) the differing status of Rakata island (undisturbed by volcanism since 1883) compared with the other, volcanically disturbed islands. A number of different lines of evidence are presented which suggest a re-appraisal of parts of this pre-existing framework of ideas. An alternative successional model for Krakatau is presented in diagrammatic form. A study was conducted on the Krakatau islands to quantify disturbance frequency during 1994 using transects aligned in 2 ways (i) 6 were cross-country and ran form a chosen starting point along a compass bearing and (ii) 9 were gully transects. Total length surveyed was 5850 m on Rakata, 3480 m on Panjang and 3000 m on Sertung. All canopy disturbances of an area ≥10 m² within 10 m of the transects were recorded and classified into 4 age classes to enable assessment of recent patterns of gap creation within and between islands. Six permanent plots established in 1989 were resurveyed in 1992 when 2 others were set up, and all were examined for mortality in 1994-95. All islands were found to have a more active disturbance regime during the most recent phase of volcanic activity than in the preceding inactive phase. Although Rakata does not receive ashfall and blast damage, it may experience more disturbances in the form of landslides, lightning strikes and windthrows, from increased numbers of earth tremors and local thunderstorms during volcanic activity. Local and regional dispersal constraints were a major factor influencing successional development, and species performance was in general negatively affected by ashfall, although this may vary according to interspecific differences in tolerance to this form of pollution. Dysoxylum gaudichaudianum saplings were shown to be relatively tolerant both of ashfall and drought conditions. Alongside the volcanic influences, particular attention has been drawn to the importance of extreme climatic events in influencing successional processes, particularly at the regeneration stage. It is suggested that human impacts should also be included in the evaluation of successional processes on the islands. A hierarchical model of succession, following that proposed by Pickett et al. (1987) is advocated as a means of clarifying the complex interrelationships between the different causes and mechanisms of succession.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Major disturbances in tropical rainforests.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Geography Department, University of Cambridge, Cambridge CB2 3EN, UK.

ab.p: A review of disturbances of various kinds and the way they influence the species composition of tropical rain forest is presented. Large scale disturbances (community-wide) to the forest canopy are highlighted while differentiating between those that are followed by primary succession (landslides, volcanic activity and mobile rivers) and those followed by secondary succession or recovery (wind, lightening, drought, epidemic herbivory and fire). Human impact on forest ecosystems and natural regeneration are also discussed.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: The impact of traditional and modern cultivation practices, including forestry, on lepidoptera diversity in Malaysia and Indonesia.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Department of Entomology, The Natural History Museum, Cromwell Road, London SW7 5BD, UK.

ab.p: Results already published or in press on the effects of logging and conversion to softwood plantation on moth diversity in Malaysia are reviewed. New analyses are presented, in particular those of transects across the interface between natural forest systems and 2 types of cultivation (traditional swidden in Seram and modern field crops and plantation systems in Sulawesi). It is concluded that whilst conversion to modern cropping systems resulted in a major reduction in the level of moth diversity and its quality in terms of faunistic composition, endemism, etc., the cyclic nature of sustainable swidden operated within the natural regeneration cycle of the forest type where it occurs, permitting diversity to recover to near its original level from an initial drop after clearance for cultivation.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Tropical forests: spatial pattern and change with time, as assessed by remote sensing.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Sciences, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge CB2 3EA, UK.

ab.p: A review of what remote sensing (RS) has contributed to answering questions in tropical ecology, what it can and cannot do now, and what it may do in the future is presented. Vegetation disturbance, both anthropogenic and natural, has been measured by RS, estimates of deforestation being routinely conducted for Brazil. Natural disturbance such as blowdowns in the Amazon were first detected by RS, and hurricane damage has also been measured. Spectral mixture modelling has proved to be useful for studying land use and land cover change on a 200 km² ranch in central Brazil. Some very distinct vegetation types can been distinguished by RS, for example bamboo forest and deciduous forest, but in general it has not proved possible to separate forests differing in more subtle ways, such as terra firma forests on different types of soils, which have very different species compositions. Phenological changes are measurable by RS, and these may soon help to detect interannual vegetation responses to climate fluctuations such as El Niño effects. It is suggested that in future such information could help to measure the effects of climate change, and that in the near future it should be possible to detect effects such as selective logging due to changes in canopy structure and crown size. In the more distant future it may be possible to map the distributions of distinct emergent trees.

bibl.et: Opposite, linear and non-linear effects of plant stress on a galling aphid.
bibl.aa: Department of Entomology, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, P. O. Box 7044, S-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: The impact of plant stress on the occurrence and performance of the gall-making aphid Sacchiphantes abietis was investigated by estimating the density and size of galls on experimentally stressed Norway spruce (Picea abies) trees in a forest plantation in southwest Sweden. Plots with 25-yr-old spruce trees were treated so as to create a range of stress. Trees were exposed to an untreated control or one of the following five treatments: drought, irrigation, ammonium sulfate addition, nitrogen-free fertilizer application and optimum fertilizer application with irrigation. The occurrence of galls was higher on drought-stressed trees than on trees in other treatments. Gall size varied continuously among treatments, with the largest galls being found on trees treated with notrogen-free fertilizer and the smallest on drought-stressed trees. Mechanisms that might explain the inconsistent effects of stress on aphids are discussed. It is concluded that plant stress has opposite effects on different life-stages of this galling insect and possibly on other species of gall-makers as well.

bibl.et: Amino acid sequence, glycan structure, and proteolytic processing of the lectin of Vatairea macrocarpa seeds.
bibl.aa: Institut für Reproduktionsmedizin, Tierärztliche Hochschule Hannover, Bünteweg 15, 30559 Hannover-Kirchrode, Germany.

ab.p: Analyses of VML, a galactose-binding lectin isolated from Vatairea macrocarpa seeds, indicated that it is a pH-independent homotetrameric protein and that a small proportion of the alpha-subunits are cleaved into non-covalently associated N- and C-terminal fragments. Mass spectrometric analysis suggested a mechanism for the proteolytic processing of VML.

bibl.et: Effect of seed freezing and storage conditions on plasma membrane properties of Norway spruce (Picea abies Karst.) seedlings.
bibl.aa: Department of Genetics and Forest Trees Physiology, Forest Research Institute, Bitwy Warszawskiej 1920 R-3, 00-973 Warsaw, Poland.

ab.p: Norway spruce (Picea abies) seeds were frozen and stored for 15 months at +3, -25, -75 or -196°C. After storage, seeds were germinated for 9-14 days to determine viability and plasma membrane protein composition, H+-ATPase activity and fluidity. The results indicate no significant differences in viability of seed 14 days after germination. Biochemical analyses revealed increased plasma membrane fluidity in 9-day-old Norway spruce seedlings raised from seeds pretreated at -75°C, and changes in the temperature profile of membrane fluidity in seedlings after pre-treatment of seeds at -25°C. On the other hand, the same treatments did not result in changes in plasma membrane protein content, protein composition or ATPase activity. There was also no difference in plasma membrane H+-ATPase activity assayed in the presence of different ATP hydrolysis inhibitors. It is suggested that during early seedling growth, adaptation of seeds to -25 and -75°C freezing and/or storage temperature results in stability of the plasma membrane protein function and composition and increased fluidity or changes in the temperature-dependent fluidity profile of these membranes.

bibl.et: Efficacy test of the herbicide Glidamin to control weeds in Acacia mangium plantations.
bibl.ft: Uji efikasi herbisida Glidamin untuk mengendalikan gulma di bawah tegakan Acacia mangium.

ab.p: Research on the use of the herbicide Glidamin was carried out in PT. Wirakarya Sakti, Jambi, Sumatra. Dominant weed species in the 1-yr-old test Acacia mangium plantation, included Eupatorium palescens, Melastoma malabathricum, Mikania sp. and Imperata cylindrica, which had respective importance values of 186.24, 28.81, 25.23 and 22.69%. Manual weed control, and 4 Glidamin treatments were applied (2, 4, 6 and 8 litres/ha in 500 litres of solution). Glidamin at 4-8 litre/ha significantly suppressed weed growth and increased height and diameter growth of the trees. The effect of the manual control treatment was transitory.

bibl.et: Rapid soil redistribution within alleys: why simple extension models for contour hedgerows may not be appropriate.
bibl.ct: Special issue on the control of soil erosion and fertility on sloping land.
bibl.aa: South East Regional Research Program, ICRAF, Box 161, Bogor 16001, Indonesia.

ab.p: Rapid redistribution of soil often occurs within the alley ways of contour hedgerow cropping systems, resulting in quite dramatic yield reductions in the upper zones. Recent work suggests that while this is a threat to sustainability on strongly acidic soils, it ought to be a manageable threat. Farmers in a number of on-farm trials in Claveria, Philippines, who have encountered scouring, have developed practical ways of coping, which are currently being validated experimentally. Robust management solutions will depend on a more fundamental understanding of the processes governing fertility resilience in contour hedgerow systems. Conventional crop and agroforestry simulation models have not yet been developed that adequately incorporate the key landscape issues that need to be addressed in this analysis, although one model (WANULCAS, Water, Nutrient, and Light Capture in Agroforestry Systems) is being adapted to these spatially zoned systems.

index.de: agroforestry systems\agrosilvicultural systems\constraints\contour cultivation\erosion\hedges\models\sloping land\soil\soil conservation\soil fertility\sustainability

bibl.et: Comparative seedling growth of five endemic New Zealand podocarp species under different light regimes.
bibl.aa: School of Forestry, University of Canterbury, Private Bag 4800 Christchurch, New Zealand.

ab.p: The comparative growth of seedlings of Dacrycarpus dacrydioides, Podocarpus totara, Dacrydium cupressinum, Prumnopitys ferruginea and P. taxifolia was investigated at different light levels. Five light regimes were achieved using shade cloth for glasshouse seedlings (2-25% of full sunlight) and under different canopy vegetation types (5-30% of full sunlight) in dense lowland podocarp forest at Whirinaki Forest Sanctuary, Central North Island, New Zealand. Height growth, stem diameter growth, and dry weight increase were measured for a 15 month period over 2 spring seasons in both glasshouse and forest environments. The 5 podocarp species exhibited significant differences in height growth, stem diameter growth and dry weight increase under the different light regimes in both glasshouse and forest environments. Seasonal height growth rates were examined in the forest, and species exhibited different responses to the climatic parameters of rainfall, humidity, temperature and solar radiation. Comparative growth rates are used to infer the natural regeneration strategies of the 5 species, particularly in response to elevated light levels. P. totara and D. dacrydioides were observed to be light demanding and have the ability to respond to increased light levels, while both D. cupressinum and P. taxifolia did not have the ability to respond to elevated light levels. It is suggested that it may be more appropriate to consider these latter 2 species as consistently slow growers. P. ferruginea is often considered the most shade tolerant of these species and in the present study it exhibited an increased growth response to elevated light levels, especially in the forest environment.

bibl.et: Tree growth form in the establishment phase of a silvopastoral system in NE Scotland.
bibl.aa: Macaulay Land Use Research Institute (MLURI), Craigiebuckler, Aberdeen AB15 8QH, UK.

ab.p: Some results are presented from an ongoing silvopastoral research project at an upland site of the UK Silvopastoral Research Network Experiment, at the Glensaugh Research Station of MLURI. This paper reports on growth form (subjectively assessed by professional foresters) of hybrid larch (Larix eurolepis) at 3 spacings (100, 200 and 400 trees/ha) and sycamore (Acer pseudoplatanus) at 2 spacings (100 and 400 trees/ha) in the establishment phase (the 8th year after planting) of these silvopastoral systems. Assessments were also made in a sycamore woodland control (2500 trees/ha); the larch woodland control was not assessed because it had developed beyond the canopy closure stage. Growth and survival of trees in these silvopastoral systems has previously been shown to be positively correlated with planting density. The results given here show that good growth form (which will also contribute to the value of the output from these systems), is also associated with higher planting densities, although growth form of sycamore was less influenced by the site conditions than that of hybrid larch. Some conclusions about productivity are drawn.

bibl.et: Endemic butterflies on Grande Comore: habitat preferences and conservation priorities.
bibl.aa: Department of Biology, University of Leeds, Leeds LS2 9JT, UK.

ab.p: The island of Grande Comore (Comore Islands, western Indian Ocean) has an endemic butterfly fauna threatened by rapid habitat change. Transect counts were used to assess the abundance and species richness of butterflies in different habitats, and along an altitude gradient. Species richness of non-endemic butterflies was highest in low altitude, man-modified habitats. In contrast, most endemic butterflies were confined to forest habitats, which only remain above 500 m. Richness and abundance of endemic butterflies were highest at the lower altitude limits of the remaining forest. Taking altitude into account, the species richness of endemic butterflies was highest in mature forest where the gross structure of the forest remained intact, lower in scrubby secondary forest, and lowest in pioneer forest on old lava flows. It is suggested that the survival of the majority of the endemic butterflies may depend on forest conservation measures in the rapidly diminishing areas of mature forest at mid altitudes.

bibl.et: Effects of nature trails on ground vegetation and understory colonization of a patchy remnant forest in an urban domain.
bibl.aa: Laboratory of Ecology, Faculty of Science, Chiba University 1-33, Yayoicho, Inageku, Chiba 263, Japan.

ab.p: Effects of nature trails on understorey vegetation was studied in a self-recovering patchy secondary forest remnant with Cryptomeria japonica, Chamaecyparis obtusa and Quercus myrsinaefolia in the urban sprawl of central Japan. An adverse impact of soil compaction at surface level, originating basically from human trampling, was found on root development and stem growth of understorey colonizers impeding plant succession. Ground cover (such as Pleioblastus chino, lianas and ferns) was reduced by a proliferation of paths in trampled sites and few species exhibited site preferences. Management options such as demarcation of paths and restriction of trampling may revitalize plant succession.

bibl.et: Distribution pattern of microflora in different forest areas.
bibl.aa: State Forest Research Institute, Sal Research Centre, Bilaspur, Madhya Pradesh, India.

ab.p: A survey of microflora carried out in different forest areas indicated that greatest number of microorganisms was obtained in soils under bamboo and sal plantations, whereas the least was found in soils under grassland. The population of microflora decreased with increasing soil depth. The differences in the distribution of microflora in different habitats was also been discussed.

bibl.et: The thermal regime of urban parks in two cities with different summer climates.
bibl.aa: Department of Geography, University of Canterbury, Private Bag 4800, Christchurch, New Zealand.

ab.p: Differences between the temperature of vegetated urban parks and that of their surrounding built environment are reported. The study is based on observations of surface and air temperature in Vancouver, British Columbia, during July and August 1992, and Sacramento, California during August 1993. Park types included grass, grass with tree borders, savanna (grass with trees scattered throughout), golf course, garden, multi-use and forest. A combination of remotely sensed surface temperature and air temperature from fixed station and mobile (car and bicycle) traverses is used to characterize the magnitude of park-induced coolness - the 'park cool island' (PCI) effect. Relatively large surface PCI are present by day and at night, although for different reasons. Air temperature effects are smaller. In Vancouver, parks are typically 1-2°C, but in ideal conditions can be almost 5°C, cooler than their surroundings. Larger PCI are possible in Sacramento where irrigated green-space can be 5-7°C cooler. Park type, especially the extent of irrigation and the presence of trees, is important in PCI development. During the day trees may play an important role in establishing a cool park effect, perhaps through a combination of shade and evaporative cooling. At night it appears that the surface geometry and moisture status of the park are important controls on surface cooling. Open parks (with higher sky view factors) that have dry soils (and hence lower thermal admittance) cool the most, while tree coverage resulted in warmer surfaces. Nocturnal cooling in open grass parks is often similar to that at rural sites. The influence of parks on air temperatures appears to be restricted to a distance of about one park width.

bibl.et: Orang Asli, forest and development.

ab.p: This book is the result of 7 years' research on the socioeconomic development of the Orang Asli, a forest dwelling community in Peninsular Malaysia, who are among the poorest ethnic groups in the country. The majority of these people still depend to varying degrees on forests for their livelihood, but over the years the community has gradually been affected by external changes - primarily the trading of forest and agricultural products in the market economy, and the subsequent income generation which forms an important economic activity over the traditional subsistence farming. Government efforts in developing the Orang Asli (through the provision of basic facilities, and regroupment and resettlement) have also gradually transformed the population. The book also examines the responses of the Orang Asli community to regroupment and resettlement, which has resulted in improvement of living standards for some, but continued socioeconomic insecurity for others. There are 8 chapters, 6 of which are revised and updated versions of papers presented or published elsewhere in local and international seminars/conferences and in books, between 1990 and 1993. The chapters are: Introduction; The Orang Asli and the forest: a historical perspective - the pre- and post-colonial eras, and details of important forest produce traded today; Orang Asli today - socioeconomics, culture and government interventions; Decreasing forest resources for local communities: a case study; Farming practices - socioeconomics, land and tree tenure, and types; The use of traditional and modern medicines; Changes and responses; and Issues and recommendations. Appendices provide details of the distribution of the Orang Asli and their land use by state, and lists of medicinal forest plants/preparations used in Bukit Tapah Forest Reserve.

bibl.et: North American Landscape Characterization dataset development and data fusion issues.
bibl.aa: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, National Exposure Research Laboratory, Research Triangle Park, NC 27711, USA.

ab.p: With the launch of Landsat 1 on 23 July 1972, the United States initiated the capability for land resource monitoring from space. Over a 20-year period, the Landsat Multi-Spectral Scanner (MSS) sensor collected data documenting land-cover conditions over the majority of the globe. The global change research community has prioritized reducing the uncertainty associated with land cover-change as a major constituent of importance to balancing the global carbon cycle. The MSS archive currently represents the best available, continuous public source of relatively high resolution imagery for the monitoring of land cover over the 1972-92 period. The North American Landscape Characterization project was designed to exploit this archive by providing standardized satellite data sets to support land-cover change analysis. Land-cover categorization products derived from MSS data alone provide only a general characterization of land-cover condition and change. A data fusion approach using a post-classification technique is presented as a cost-effective method for delineating land cover at appropriate thematic and spatial resolutions to support a quantitative inventory of forest carbon stocks. Issues related to assessing the accuracy of carbon inventory datasets is presented, and a two-step model is proposed for accuracy assessment.

bibl.do: Technical Bulletin - Maine Agricultural and Forest Experiment Station
bibl.et: Time series analysis of Maine stumpage prices.
bibl.aa: Department of Resource Economics and Policy, University of Maine, Orono, ME 04469, USA.

ab.p: In this analysis of price series for stumpage in Maine, for each available species and product group (sawlogs, pulpwood), a test is done for stationarity and fit autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA) models to the data based on preliminary diagnostics. In-sample and out-of-sample price forecasts are then performed. The central objective of this work is to characterize the processes for Maine stumpage prices in order to identify opportunities for using reservation price policies to increase timber and land values. These results are of particular value to nonindustrial timber growers for use in scheduling harvests. The price forecasts are also of interest to stumpage buyers and industrial timber growers, though as with any forecasts they are subject to qualifications and must be interpreted carefully.

bibl.do: Staff Paper Series - Department of Forest Resources, University of Minnesota
bibl.et: Tourism and forest products: twin resource sectors for effective community development in the Lake States.
bibl.pb: Department of Forest Resources, University of Minnesota
bibl.aa: College of Natural Resources and the Agricultural Experiment Station, University of Minnesota, St. Paul, MN 55108, USA.

ab.p: Communities with major activities in both tourism and forest products are substantially better off with lower unemployment than communities with only one activity in the Lake States of the USA. This paper examines the sequences by which combined development centres came about and similarities between these centres in Rhinelander and northeastern Wisconsin, Grand Rapids and north central Minnesota, and the area around and including Gaylord and Grayling in northern Lower Peninsula Michigan. The similarities relate to natural, cultural and infrastructural assets that appear to have contributed to these communities becoming combined development centres. The final section discusses ways in which other communities could appraise their own prospects for becoming combined development centres.

bibl.et: Alkylated dibenzothiophenes in pine needles from pulp and paper mill environment.
bibl.aa: Department of Chemistry, University of Jyväskylä, PO Box 35, FIN-40351 Jyväskylä, Finland.

ab.p: Concentrations of alkylated dibenzothiophenes (CnDBTs) in pine [Pinus spp.] needles in a recipient area of the emissions from a pulp and paper mill were measured, where waste combustion was also carried out. The concentrations (ng/g dry weight) of C1DBTs were in the range of < 0.7 ng/g to 73.0 ng/g, those of C2DBTs in the range of < 0.7 to 273.3 ng/g and those of C3DBTs in the range of <0.7 to 393.0 ng/g. The concentrations increased with the number of alkyl carbons so that [C3DBTs]> [C2DBTs]> [C1DBTs]. The pulp mill could not be shown to be the source of C1-C3DBTs in the pine needles. Other possible sources are situated in the vicinity of the pulp and paper mill. Long-range transport cannot be excluded as a possible source.

bibl.et: Results of a dry zone species evaluation trial.
bibl.ft: Resultados de un ensayo de evaluación de especies de zona seca.
bibl.pb: Proyecto Conservacion y Mejoramiento de los Recursos Forestales de Honduras (COHDEFOR)
bibl.aa: Proyecto Conservación y Mejoramiento de los Recursos Forestales de Honduras, Apartado Postal No. 45, Siguatepeque, Honduras.

ab.p: This report summarises the method and results of a species evaluation trial of 19 native and 1 exotic dry zone species, conducted over three years on a single site in the Valle de Comayagua, Honduras. Assessments were made at 10, 23 and 36 months after establishment. Prior to the 36 month assessment, species were labelled according to end-use class: either 'multipurpose' (MPT) and/or 'timber'. Standard forestry mensuration techniques as well as specialised MPT assessment techniques were employed in the final assessment. Three MPT species, Leucaena leucocephala, Moringa oleifera and Gliricidia sepium, emerge as promising, both in terms of the standard measure of height and the alternative MPT measure of length. However a different pattern emerges when MPT species are ranked by cross-sectional area: Guazuma ulmifolia, Senna atomaria and Enterolobium cyclocarpum emerge as the best performers. Albizia saman [Samanea saman] ranks top in the timber species in terms of both height and diameter at breast height.

ab.p: A collection of papers presented at a Symposium, and including an appreciation of the work of H. D. Löffler, and a list of 120 publications by him. The Symposium papers deal with: modern organization and execution of forest work; physical and mechanical soil protection; choice of logging methods and access; output and performance in forestry work; computer tomography in the study of forest soils; the use of the Eco-Mate hydraulic system in harvesters; cost-benefit analysis of access in montane forests; the Internet and WWW; GPS in forestry; formal concept analysis for describing forms of forest management; BPR (Business Process Re-engineering) in forestry; current status and future developments in information technology in forestry; and draining of landslides in the flysch region of Switzerland.

bibl.et: Establishing forest tree species on peatland in a reflooded area of the Huleh Valley, Israel.
bibl.aa: Institute of Field and Garden Crops, Agricultural Research Organization, Volcani Center, Ber Dagan, PO Box 6, 50250 Israel.

ab.p: The performance was evaluated of 4 tree species (Ficus carica, Fraxinus syriaca, Salix acmophylla and Platanus orientalis) 3 yr after planting (in February 1994) as shade sites on 2 reclaimed peatland islands in the Huleh Valley, Israel. Planting stock of Fraxinus syriaca was grown in 3-litre containers for 2 yr; that of the other 3 species was grown in 1-litre plastic bags for 1 yr. To develop good tree establishment and avoid uprooting, two types of soils were tested as alternatives for the rhizosphere. For each tree 6 m³ of soil (2×2×1.5 m) were replaced with river bed alluvium or terra-rossa, in which the tree was planted. Control trees were planted directly in the peat. The trees were planted as shade sites, each with 36 trees, 27 of one species, and 9 of a secondary species. Trees were irrigated in the first growing season. Changing the rhizosphere soil type to river bed alluvium significantly improved the establishment and performance of Salix acmophylla and Fraxinus syriaca (survival, height, diameter and canopy shade area). Ficus carica was not affected by changing the soil in the rhizosphere, while Platanus orientalis was affected mainly in the canopy shade area. Terra-rossa improved establishment only of Salix acmophylla.
