bibl.et: Direct seeding of native trees and shrubs in low rainfall areas and on non-wetting sands in South Australia.
bibl.aa: Revegetation Centre, P.O. Box 752, Murray Bridge, South Australia 5253, Australia.

ab.p: Seeds of common endemic species of Acacia, Callitris, Eucalyptus and Melaleuca were direct sown in single-row plots 10 m long at 12 sites in South Australia in 1994 and 1995 to determine the role of various treatments in improving the reliability of direct sowing in Mediterranean type climate with low rainfall. The treatments were: (1) soil stabilizers (mulches of kerosene or water based bitumen or polyvinyl alcohol (PVA, Curak)), (2) fertilizers (NPS 8:19:4 + 2% Zn), (3) time of sowing, (4) herbicides (2,4-DB dimethylamine (Trifolamine), Fusilade [fluazifop-P] and glyphosate), (5) ripping to improve water penetration and break up hard layers, and (6) soil preparation with a V-blade or a disc to remove any non-wetting topsoil, harvest water and provide a weed-free seedbed. Not all treatments were tested at all sites. Soil types at the 12 sites included clayey sand, loamy sand, water repellent loamy sand, water repellent sand, and clayey sand over limestone. Rainfall in 1994 was below average with 140 mm at the northern sites (55% of the average) and 300 mm at the southern sites (74% of the average); only Acacia was successful with at least 3 plants/10 m present at the end of spring at 8 sites and a survival rate after the first summer of 43%. In 1995, at least 3 plants/10 m of Acacia and Eucalyptus spp. were present at the end of spring at 8 sites, with at least 3 plants/10 m of Melaleuca at 6 sites and at least 3 plants/10 m of Callitris at only 3 sites. Melaleuca had the highest overall survival rate at the end of summer with 52% compared with Acacia 42%, Eucalyptus 41% and Callitris 29%. Sowing 2-3 wk after the opening rains (May at most sites) with good weed control gave the best results. Plant survival over the summer was reduced by 40% where weeds were not controlled by a herbicide. Ripping or fertilizer did not improve success. Ground preparation with an 80 cm wide V-blade generally produced better results than using a 25 cm wide disc except for Melaleuca. The effect of bitumen was variable in the trials, but appeared to be beneficial on wind eroded sites. The results indicate the potential of direct sowing of trees and shrubs in Mediterranean type climates with 250 to 425 mm average annual rainfall, including on soils that are water repellent.

bibl.do: The ecological history of European forests.
bibl.et: The ecological history of European forests.
bibl.ct: The ecological history of European forests.
bibl.ms: (refs also included at ends of chapters)
bibl.aa: Department of Geography, University of Nottingham, University Park, Nottingham NG7 2RD, UK.

ab.p: Most of the 26 chapters in this book are based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996, and supported by the Forest Ecology Group of the British Ecological Society and IUFRO. Wide ranging case studies are provided on specific aspects of the ecological history of European forests - although the majority of semi-natural woodland in this region has been destroyed by human activity over the centuries, a considerable amount remains, which has been managed to varying degrees and for a wide variety of reasons. This has resulted in a large number of natural and semi-natural landscapes and habitat types and a high diversity of plant and animal communities adapted to them. Aspects covered in the chapters are grazing/woodland pastures, management practices, habitat changes/plant succession/synecology and biodiversity and conservation, as well as overviews from recognized authorities on the latest research. Contributions cover forest ecological history in the UK, Scandinavia, the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, Spain, Italy, Switzerland, Poland, Hungary and Turkey, with 1 paper from West Africa, and illustrative data on temperate forests from the Irish Republic, Poland and Australia (Tasmania). An introduction by the editors on historical ecology and European woodland, and a subject index, are included. A second book (European woods and forests: studies in cultural history, edited by Watkins, C., published by CAB INTERNATIONAL in 1998) also draws on papers from the conference.

bibl.do: European woods and forests: studies in cultural history.
bibl.et: European woods and forests: studies in cultural history.
bibl.ct: European woods and forests: studies in cultural history.
bibl.ms: 12 pp. of refs (refs also included at ends of chapters)
bibl.aa: Department of Geography, University of Nottingham, University Park, Nottingham NG7 2RD, UK.

ab.p: Most of the 15 chapters in this book are based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996, and supported by the Forest Ecology Group of the British Ecological Society and IUFRO. The chapters constitute case studies which explore recent developments in the study of the cultural history of European forests. In this region, woods and forests were the principal source of fuel for many hundreds of years, and in addition were crucially important as a source of construction material for a wide range of domestic, agricultural, industrial and military artefacts. Also, the woods and forests were used for grazing, cultivation and hunting. Consequently the varied landscapes of today are often a result of past management policies which were closely linked to important events and cultural developments in human history. The contributions cover cultural forest history in Western Europe, England, Scotland, Germany, Austria, Italy, Palestine (Israel), and Spain. The last chapter is a theoretical consideration of the concept of ancient woodland in Britain. An introduction by the editor on themes in the history of European woods and forests, and a subject index, are included. A second book (The ecological history of European forests, edited by Kirby, K. J. & Watkins, C., published by CAB INTERNATIONAL in 1998) also draws on papers from the conference.

bibl.do: Economic models of tropical deforestation: a review.
bibl.et: Economic models of tropical deforestation: a review.

ab.p: As international concern over tropical deforestation has grown over the last 10 yr, researchers have sought to understand the causes of deforestation and possible solutions by using quantitative economic models. This book reviews the results and methodology of >150 of these models and synthesizes the main lessons that can be learned from them. It is arranged in 7 sections: Introduction; Types of economic deforestation models; Household and firm-level models; Regional-level models; National and macro-level models; Summary: what drives deforestation?; and Priority areas for future research. Two appendices summarize the variables included in economic deforestation models, and give details of models for specific countries. Higher agricultural prices, lower wages, less off-farm employment, and more roads generally lead to more deforestation. Major doubts remain on the impact of technological change, agricultural input prices, household incomes and tenure security. The role of macro-level factors such as population growth, poverty reduction, national income levels, economic growth and foreign debt is still largely uncertain. It is concluded that while the modelling exercises have revealed new insights into deforestation, many model results should be regarded with caution because of poor data quality and methodological weaknesses. In particular, most multi-country regression models are found to be of limited value, and a shift in future research towards household and regional level studies is recommended, instead of the current emphasis on national and multi-country studies.

bibl.do: Tree heritage of Britain and Ireland: a guide to the famous trees of Britain and Ireland.
bibl.et: Tree heritage of Britain and Ireland: a guide to the famous trees of Britain and Ireland.

ab.p: This guide book starts with an introductory chapter which discusses woodland history and mythology in Britain. Topics covered in this are introduced species, fear of the forest, tree worship, trees in art, trees and fertility and tree recording. The rest of the book constitutes the guide proper, and is divided in to 7 main geographical sections (West Country, South-east England, Wales, Central Shires of England, Eastern England, North Country, Scottish Lowlands, Scottish Highlands, and Ireland -7 counties from the Republic and 1 from Northern Ireland). Each section is divided into counties, and famous tree in each are described, accompanied by colour photographs and historical drawings. The last section describes some record trees (broadleaves and conifers). An index lists names of trees/gardens/parks alphabetically, with details of schemes/organizations to which they belong (open to public, National Trust, Royal Horticultural Society, National Nature Reserve, National Gardens Scheme) or situations in which they are found (churchyards, private, etc.).

bibl.do: Urban nature conservation: landscape management in the urban countryside.
bibl.et: Urban nature conservation: landscape management in the urban countryside.
bibl.aa: Department of Horticulture and Landscape, University of Reading, UK.

ab.p: This book attempts a synthesis of principles which will guide urban landscape management and policy formulation at a strategic level which allows the integration of conservation into a wider management or urban planning framework. This a complex technical area which requires professional management understanding of ecological, traditional horticultural and arboricultural approaches to green space development. The resulting text is a comprehensive overview aimed at the working professional and students. After a preface, there are 9 chapters: The urban estate and the 'urban countryside'; The urban environment and urban species; The history and development of ecological landscape styles (with Cooper, D.) - with particular reference to the UK, but including discussion of Germany, the Netherlands and the USA; The objectives of urban nature conservation; Biogeography and conservation planning in the urban countryside; Ecological restoration and habitat creation; Restoration and creation of the main biome types - grassland, heath, annuals, wetland, trees, woodland; Strategic management issues in the urban countryside - including vegetation management and weed control; and Nature for people. A subject index is included.

bibl.do: Forest politics: the evolution of international cooperation.
bibl.et: Forest politics: the evolution of international cooperation.

ab.p: The evolution of international cooperation on forests is traced from the inception of the controversial International Tropical Timber Organization (ITTO) and the failed Tropical Forestry Action Programme in the mid-1980s, to the creation of the Intergovernmental Panel on Forests in the mid-1990s. The book also provides a detailed analysis of the negotiating stances of the parties involved in the diverse negotiations that took place prior to the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, and the equally factious negotiations for the International Tropical Timber Agreement of 1994. The insights given illustrate the difficulties that arise when concepts such as the global commons come into conflict with national sovereignty. The book is arranged in 7 chapters: Deforestation as a global issue; The Tropical Forestry Action Programme; The International Tropical Timber Organization; The forest negotiations of the UNCED process; The negotiation of the International Tropical Timber Agreement, 1994; The global politics of forest conservation since the UNCED; and Conclusions. Various notes and annexes, and a subject index, are included.

index.de: deforestation\forest policy\forests\international cooperation\nature conservation\protection of forests\timber trade\tropical forests\tropics

bibl.do: Forests of hope: stories of regeneration.
bibl.et: Forests of hope: stories of regeneration.

ab.p: The experiences are described of forest dwellers and concerned groups in forest management and conservation projects in 12 different countries (Switzerland, India, Nepal, Tanzania, Kenya, Costa Rica, Indonesia, Brazil, Thailand, China, USA and Germany), based on personal investigations made by the author, who adopts a sociological and cross-cultural approach to document the place of trees and forests in a variety of cultural and physical landscapes. The many accounts given are illustrated by a large number of colour photographs. Although the causes of forest degradation were found to be complex, a basic pattern was identified in which national governments or market forces deny local people the chance to control their own resources, resulting in profound changes in land use. However, wherever social and institutional conflicts have been resolved, forests have regenerated.

bibl.do: Tree seed suppliers directory: sources of seeds and microsymbionts.
bibl.et: Tree seed suppliers directory: sources of seeds and microsymbionts.
bibl.pb: International Centre for Research in Agroforestry (ICRAF)
bibl.ms: Produced in technical collaboration with FAO, DFSC and IUFRO, with funding from DFID, BMZ and VVOB

ab.p: This directory is an updated version of one published in 1991 by ICRAF (Multipurpose trees and shrubs: sources of seeds and inoculants, Carlowitz, P. G. von). It includes many more tree species (primarily agroforestry or multipurpose species) and suppliers of seeds and microsymbionts (mycorrhizal fungi and bacteria). The data are based on questionnaires sent to suppliers. After introductory information, instructions on use of the directory, and guidelines for seed ordering, the main information in the directory is presented in 7 tables: Taxa; Synonyms; Seed- and supplier-specific information; microsymbiont- and supplier-specific information; Seed suppliers; Microsymbiont suppliers; and Seed information. Other suppliers not included in the tables, and copies of the questionnaire are included at the end of the directory. Information from the directory is also available on the Internet at the ICRAF website.

bibl.et: Moriculture: science of mulberry cultivation.

ab.p: The first edition of this book was published in Japanese in 1984 as Science of mulberry cultivation: fundamentals and practice (Tokyo, Japan; Meiho-Sha, Japan Science Press). This edition was published with the assistance of the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC), and the translation undertaken by Alamelu Gopal. Moriculture is addressed in relation to sericulture, and the need to increase the production and productivity of mulberry [Morus] for this purpose. The book is based on research experience and collection of research data. There are 12 chapters. The first, Introduction, discusses the significance, importance and history of mulberry cultivation, trends in Japan, and plant physiology and the principles of cultivation. The other chapters are: Morphological, physiological and ecological features of mulberry; Mulberry varieties; Improvement of mulberry varieties; Preparation of mulberry seedlings - including vegetative propagation; Establishment of mulberry field[s]; Training and harvesting of mulberry; Quality of mulberry leaf [leaves]; Tillage, manuring and weeding of mulberry field[s]; Damages of [to] mulberry field[s] - abiotic injuries; Diseases of mulberry; and Damage to mulberry caused by insects and small animals - rodents.

bibl.do: Base-line training needs assessment for community forestry in South Africa.
bibl.et: Base-line training needs assessment for community forestry in South Africa.
bibl.aa: Community Environmental Development Services, PO Box 464, Hilton, South Africa.

ab.p: This report was prepared for the South African Department of Water Affairs & Forestry, Pretoria, and funded by the Danish Cooperation for Environmental Development (DANCED). The Basic Needs Assessment (BNA) provided gives an overview of the current status of Community Forestry Training (CFT) in South Africa - training was considered for the purposes of the survey as those activities which would improve the performance of extensionists and communities already working with trees and tree products. No formal capacity was identified to undertake CFT, although there were many local initiatives. As a result of this, both communities and extensionists depend heavily on experience. This lack of training facilities/capacity is a major constraint in developing effective initiatives. The report outlines a training programme for both service providers and partner interest groups, based on a modular approach. It is recommended that each module is linked to the next with a monitored intervening community forestry project, so that the whole training process takes place over 5 yr. Recommendations are also made on the need to identify trainers for establishing the proposed Community Forestry Training Programme, and it is proposed that formal forestry institutions use NGOs (non-governmental organizations) and CBOs (community based organizations) to facilitate training and help build partnerships with community interest groups. In addition, proposals are made for the development of Community Forestry Media, and initiatives on education and research to link in with the training BNA.

bibl.et: The National Forest: from vision to reality. A special issue of the East Midland Geographer.
bibl.ms: Available from ICOLE, Loughborough University, Loughborough, Leics., LE11 3TU, UK
bibl.ad: Evans, S.\Hooke, D.\Westerhuis, M.\Kerr, G.\Wait, C. P.\Britt, C. P.\Cohn, E. V. J.\King, A.\Ferris, C.\Rosier, P.\Infield, D. G.\Beaverstock, J. V.\Evans, D. M.\Jackson, G. A. M.\Sidaway, R.

ab.p: The 16 papers presented derive from a conference organized by and held in the Department of Geography at Loughborough University, UK, near the eastern boundary of the new flagship UK National Forest. This forest was created following the Countryside Commission's policy statement of December 1987 (Forestry in the countryside), which incorporated a vision of the National Forest, together with a number of what have become known as Community Forests. The National Forest encompasses the countryside and towns in and between ancient Charnwood and Needwood, and includes parts of Leicestershire, Derbyshire and Staffordshire. It will transform some 320 km², with a blend of wooded areas, open country, farmland and settlements, and create a multipurpose resource for the nation. Both the idea and implementation have been embraced with widespread enthusiasm at national, local and administrative levels. The papers included are: (1) A forest for the nation (Evans, S.; 7-11; 6 ref.); (2) The National Forest: an historical context (Sheail, J.; 12-22; 18 ref.); (3) The historical landscape regions of the National Forest (Hooke, D.; 23-30; 23 ref.); (4) Landscape enhancement and the difficulties of stimulating change (Westerhuis, M.; 31-34; 7 ref.); (5) Establishing new woodlands: research and demonstration in the National Forest (Kerr, G.; 35-42; 16 ref.); (6) The National Forest - financial implications of afforestation (Wait, C. P.; 43-48; 4 ref.); (7) The cost of farm woodland establishment (Britt, C. P.; 49-53; 8 ref.); (8) Woodland enhancement and forest integrity (Cohn, E. V. J.; 54-61; 21 ref.); (9) National Forest, national trees? (King, A.; Ferris, C.; 62-66; 9 ref.); (10) The hydrological importance of broad-leaved woodlands (Rosier, P.; 67-70; 7 ref.); (11) Hydrological impacts of the National Forest (Wilby, R. L.; 71-77; 17 ref.); (12) The future of the useful recycling of sewage sludge with reference to afforestation (Wheatley, A. D.; 78-84; 20 ref.); (13) Wind energy in the context of the National Forest - two case studies (Infield, D. G.; 85-91; 13 ref.)l (14) Economic regeneration in the Midland Coalfield area of the National Forest (Beaverstock, J. V.; 92-97; 21 ref.); (15) Sustainable recreation and tourism in the National Forest (Evans, D. M.; Jackson, G. A. M.; 98-104; 18 ref.); and (16) Reflections on the developing vision of a National Forest (Sidaway, R.; 105-107; 8 ref.).

ab.p: Two white spruce (Picea glauca) plantations (12- and 14-year-old) on loam soils in Quebec, Canada, were fertilized in 1983 and 1984. Results showed that fertilizer stimulated white spruce growth. The best results were obtained with NPK at 75+75+75 and 100+0+100 kg/ha. After 10 years, those treatments showed superior total volume increments of more than 34 (37%) and 10 (8%) m³/ha, respectively, compared with control trees.

bibl.et: The horsechesnut leafmining moth (Cameraria ohridella): a new pest in central Europe.
bibl.aa: Institute of Forest Protection, Federal Forest Research Institute, A-1131 Vienna, Austria.

ab.p: The leafminer Cameraria ohridella, a monophagous pest of horse chestnut (Aesculus hippocastanum), was first recorded in Macedonia in 1984. It has now spread throughout Austria, where at least 20&thin;000 horse chestnuts grow as shade and street trees in Vienna, and to other areas of central Europe. The origin, biology, damage, population dynamics, natural limitation factors (intraspecific competition and parasitism), economic impact, management options, and control (mainly chemical) of C. ohridella are discussed.

bibl.et: Mechanical characterization of structural timber from Scots pine from Central and Iberian stands.
bibl.ft: Caracterización mecánica del la madera aserrada de pino silvestre do los sistemas central e ibérico mediante probetas de tamaño estructural.
bibl.aa: Laboratorio de Estructuras, CIFOR-INIa, Ctra. de La Coruña, km 7, 28040 Madrid, Spain.

ab.p: A mechanical characterization of structural timber (150 × 50 × 3000 mm) of Pinus sylvestris from different Spanish provenances was carried out. Characteristic values and strength classes corresponding to the quality classes considered in the UNE 56544 visual grading standard were considered. A criticism of the cited UNE 56544 standard is also included, and suggestions are made for improvement. A mechanical characterization of young timber logs with small diameters is also considered and the influence of thinning intensity on mechanical properties and quality of timber is discussed. Results are compared with those from studies on P. pinaster and P. radiata.

bibl.et: Response of treatments on germination and early seedling growth with regard to seed weight/size of Celtis australis Linn. (nettle tree).
bibl.aa: Division of Forestry, S.K. University of Agricultural Sciences and Technology, Shalimar Campus, Srinagar (J & K), India.

ab.p: Nine presowing treatments were tested for improving the germination and subsequent seedling growth of Celtis australis in experiments in Jammu and Kashmir. The best germination was observed in the stratification (1 month at 5±1°C) + gibberellin (200 ppm GA3 for 48 h) treatment, followed by the stratification alone treatment. The best early growth and vigour was in the 200 ppm GA3 alone treatment, followed by stratification + 200 ppm GA3. The other treatments tested were hot water for 48 h, stratification + 100 ppm GA3, 100 or 200 ppm GA3, and nitric acid for 15 or 30 min. All treatments increased germination and seedling growth over control (untreated seeds) values. When seeds were graded into 2 size groups (100-seed weight 5.99-6.01 and 7.97-8.72 g), the larger seeds gave the best germination and seedling growth. There were interactions between some seedling growth parameters and seed size.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Architecture and development of rainforest trees: responses to light variation.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry, Agricultural University, P.O. Box 342, 6700 AH Wageningen, Netherlands.

ab.p: A review is presented which investigates architectural changes during tree development. These architectural changes were studied in relation to tree height and light availability for 2 canopy tree species (Dicorynia guianensis and Vouacapoua americana) in a lowland tropical rain forest at the Les Nouragues Field Station, French Guiana, during 1992-94. Light environments, architectural tree models, trunk and crown allometry, mechanical design and crown development were investigated, and the results discussed as a section within this review. It is concluded that; (i) although light levels are highly variable among trees of the same height, in general they increase with height. Trees of shade-intolerant species receive higher light levels than trees of shade-tolerant species but they are sometimes found at low light levels in the forest understorey as well; (ii) height is linearly related with stem diameter when trees are young, but in later development stages height growth ceases while diameter growth still continues. Slenderness (height/stem diameter ratio) decreases with tree height. Juvenile trees of understorey species tend to be more slender than overstorey species of the same height, and this may be related to their wood properties. Later, trees of understorey species become less slender than trees of overstorey species because their height growth ceases at a smaller diameter while diameter growth continues; (iii) trees produce deep and narrow crowns (relative to their height) when they grow. For one of the 2 selected species, trees also produced deeper and narrower crowns when they received more light; (iv) on their way to the canopy, trees take large risks with respect to mechanical stability. The study species exhibited the smallest margins in mechanical safety at a height of 20 m. For one species, the safety margins increased with light availability. Trees of shade-intolerant species tended to have lower safety margins than trees of shade-tolerant species; (v) crown development (in terms of leaf area) refers to the demography, spatial arrangement, and structure of plant components at different levels within the crown hierarchy, from meristem to whole crown. At each of these levels crown development is affected by tree height and light level. Using path analysis, the influence of tree height and light availability on different components, and the consequences of these influences for one whole crown trait, total leaf area was analysed. Leaf area increased with both tree height and light availability, mainly because trees had produced more apical meristems; (vi) although light is a major factor influencing the architecture of a tree, studies taking this factor into account are scarce and mostly confined to seedlings. This is due to the difficulty in estimating light levels of trees larger than small saplings, and because the taller trees have a longer life history and their architecture is the result of a long process.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Limits to tree species distributions in lowland tropical rainforest.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant and Soil Science, University of Aberdeen, Cruickshank Building, St Machar Drive, Aberdeen AB24 3UU, UK.

ab.p: The factors believed to determine the natural limits to species distribution in tropical forest are reviewed, while highlighting the effects of changing climate. The distributions of tropical forest tree species in West Africa were examined in relation to environmental conditions. The main forest types in Ghana were defined using floristic data. Seasonal drought and soil fertility covaried along a pronounced rainfall gradient and were the strongest candidates for determining the limits of species distributions. Shadehouse experiments to test the growth responses of a number of different tree species (e.g. Celtis mildbraedii, Cynometra ananta, Heritiera utilis, Lophira alata, Mansonia altissima, Pericopsis elata, Pterygota macrocarpa, Pycnanthus angolensis and Terminalia ivorensis) seedlings to seasonal drought and soil type (acid, infertile soil taken from high rainfall forest and near-neutral, more fertile soil from moderate rainfall forest) were conducted. The results of these studies were compared with seedling transplant experiments between wet and moist forest. In the drought experiment, a species with a wide range of natural distributions was subjected to a droughting regime in which soil matric potentials fell to values similar to those that occur annually in moist semi-deciduous forest. Seedling mortality varied greatly among species, exceeding 80% in species native to wet forest, and less than 5% for species whose distributions extend to lower rainfall areas. In the soil-type experiment, a wide range of species were tested including several expected from their natural distribution to show poor growth on infertile soil. Of 15 species tested, only 3 responded significantly to soil type. Triplochiton scleroxylon and Mansonia altissima, both deciduous Sterculiaceae absent from wet forest, exhibited significantly poorer growth on the infertile soil than on fertile soil at irradiances greater than about 10%. The drought-sensitive pioneer of wet forests, Lophira alata, showed the opposite response, growing better in the low fertility soil than in the more fertile. Seedling transplants between wet and moist forest supported the differences in species drought responses recorded in the shadehouse experiments and indicated that growth was faster for all species in the wet forest where seasonal drought is rare. The apparent sensitivity of Mansonia altissima to infertile soil was not evident in wet forest transplants, at least during the first 4 years. Some preliminary results on ecophysiological differences among species are reported in a discussion of the factors likely to determine species distribution in these West African trees.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Community structure and the demography of primary species in tropical rainforest.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, University of Utrecht, PO Box 80.084, 3508 TB Utrecht, Netherlands.

ab.p: A review is presented of equilibrium and non-equilibrium theories proposed to explain the high species richness in tropical rain forests. Equilibrium theories suggest that species differ in their regeneration requirements and partition the available space over resource gradients. Non-equilibrium theories propose that most species have similar resource requirements and emphasize chance as the major factor determining the species composition of tropical rain forests. A study of the literature revealed that support for non-equilibrium theories comes from studies on large (diameter > 10 cm) or at least well-established trees, whereas support for equilibrium theories comes from studies on seedlings. It is suggested that in interspecific comparisons, large trees are more likely than seedlings to be classified as generalists that do not show habitat specificity. This is because their growth and mortality responses are too slow and insensitive, the methods of measuring growth are too inaccurate, current methods are capable of measuring only part of the spectrum from very negative to very positive plant responses, and the abiotic environment cannot be quantified with sufficient precision as to detect small but significant differences between species. The growth and survival of seedlings are easier to quantify with accuracy, however, large-scale seedling studies are scarce and often only quantify seedling numbers but not size. The contributions of chance and determinism to successful regeneration are discussed and it is concluded that they are not constant during different stages of the regeneration cycle. Processes occurring before gap formation partly determine the result of interspecific competition after a gap has formed. Even though the spatially and temporally stochastic availability of seedlings, and stochastic seedling mortality may dominate seedling dynamics in the understorey, interspecific differences in growth and mortality and variation in resource availability may affect the size and condition of the seedlings at the onset of the gap phase. It is suggested therefore, that seedling studies should not limit themselves to gaps, but also address the understorey. Owing to a higher availability of resources, species-specific differences in growth are more pronounced in the gap phase than in the understorey, and the contribution of chance factors to regeneration is less. Among generalist tree species, species that differ in competitive ability and in the abundance of seedlings and their spatial distribution may maintain themselves in the community at different population size distributions, which represent different pathways towards successful regeneration. Species that are weak competitors in gaps may locally recruit through chance by being common as seedlings. It is concluded that to resolve the issue of species maintenance in rain forests, seedlings should be included in large-scale, long-term demographic studies, and that the full variability of their biotic and abiotic environment should be addressed.

bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Department of Biological and Molecular Sciences, University of Stirling, Stirling FK9 4LA, Scotland, UK.

ab.p: Studies were conducted in groves of ectomycorrhizal caesalpinaccous legumes in Korup, Cameroon, during 1990-91, to investigate the phenology and seedling demography of 3 caesalps (Microberlinia bisulcata, Tetraberlinia bifoliolata and T. moreliana). The most abundant of the 3 co-dominant tree species, Microberlinia bisulcata, has had, and continues to show, very low recruitment, replacement tending to favour the 2 other guild members, Tetraberlinia bifoliolata and T. moreliana. All 3 species produced large sufficient seedling banks. Microberlinia bisulcata attained the greatest tree sizes and had the most pronounced mast fruiting pattern (a 3-year cycle). Masting was associated with peaks in the previous dry-season radiation, suggesting a requirement to accumulate carbon reserves before fruiting. More circumstantial evidence pointed to phosphorus supply as a co-controlling factor. The dominance of M. bisulcata was due to a recently unique, natural historical event, an epoch of unusually dry years, which allowed its shade-intolerant ectomycorrhizal seedlings to outcompete other species. The putative fungal connections to parents were of no advantage (possibly a disadvantage) to the seedlings under such mature adults. The composition of Korup is neither constant nor cycling, but a fragment of change which might be reset by climatic fluctuations coincident with potential regeneration of a species also adapted to the low-K soils and strongly seasonal conditions of the site. It is concluded that understanding the dynamics of such an African forest requires a stochastic view over several centuries.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Primates, phenology and frugivory: present, past and future patterns in the Lopé Reserve, Gabon.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Centre International de Recherches Médicales de Franceville, Gabon.

ab.p: Climate change in central Africa over the past 75 000 years has had a profound impact on vegetation of the Lopé Reserve in central Gabon, Africa. Present-day vegetation is dominated by closed-canopy tropical rain forest but a zone of savanna persists where forest recolonization has been blocked by regular burning. Eight species of diurnal primate share the forest habitats of the 50 km² study area where research has been in progress for 12 years. The diets of the primates are dominated by fruit flesh and seeds, which account for between 55 and 77% of dietary items. Since 1986, the phenology of 63 species of tree which produce fruit eaten by primates has been monitired monthly. Analysis of these data indicated that the year may be divided into 3 periods with respect to fruit availability. During the 3-month dry season few ripe fruit were present, for 4 months after the onset of rains fruit availability was consistently high, while for the remaining 5 months of the year there were large interannual variations in the amount of fruit produced. Flowering in some species with irregular production patterns was triggered by low temperatures which occur normally only in the dry season. Climate influenced phenological patterns in other ways, for example one species of tree required a combination of 2 climatic features (dry weather and sunshine) for flowering, and the absence of sunshine during the dry season inhibited fruit ripening. It is suggested that as fruit production is influenced by climate, both the colder weather of the past and the likely warmer weather of the future may have a large and immediate impact on populations of frugivorous primates. It is concluded that climate change has in the past reduced, and is likely again in the future to reduce, the extent of closed-canopy forest at Lopé, but that the chances of recovery of primates from future population reductions are slim as both they and their tropical forest habitats are already under intense pressure from human activities such as selective logging, hunting and deforestation for agriculture.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: A spatial model of savanna function and dynamics: model description and preliminary results.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Laboratoire d'Écologie, Ecole Normale Supérieure, 46 Rue d'Ulm, 75230 Paris Cedex 05, France.

ab.p: MUSE, a modular modelling environment which enables the simulation of linkages between structure, function and dynamics in savannas, is presented and discussed. MUSE is spatially explicit and flexible in time and space scales in order to deal with the various processes involved. It contains an extendable library of models allowing both to incorporate in MUSE new processes and compare results from models using different approaches to vegetation and soil simulations. It provides scenarios of ecosystem changes in response to intrinsic dynamic properties and to climatic or anthropogenic disturbances. Results are presented which focus on tree dynamics and spatial pattern, and on grass primary production in relation to water stress. Trees are treated as individuals (growth, reproduction, seed dispersal, recruitment) which interact with neighbours and grasses. Grass is treated as a homogeneous layer locally affected by trees. Disturbances are also spatially explicit, and affect (or are affected by) tree and grass coenoses. Impacts on (and feedback effects from) soil functioning (water, organic matter and nutrient dynamics) are incorporated. MUSE is parameterized and validated on data collected during 30 years from a variety of sites at the Lamto Research Station (Côte d'Ivoire, West Africa), and is being adapted to other savanna types (drier West African and Australian savannas).

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Evolution and diversity in Amazonian floodplain communities.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Animal Behaviour Research Group, Department of Zoology, University of Oxford, South Parks Road, Oxford OXI 3PS, UK.

ab.p: The evolutionary and ecological characteristics of the plants and fish of the particularly broad alluvial plain of the Rio Solimões (Amazon) that surrounds its junction with a large ex-Andean tributary (the Rio Japurá), western Brazil, is discussed based on evidence from a 6 year study at the Estaçäo Ecológica Mamirauá nature reserve. The physical environment of the Rio Solimões and Rio Japurá floodplain confluence was shown to be highly variable both spatially and temporally at scales ranging from 0.01 to 10 000 m and 1 hour to 100 years. The floodplain held >300 species of fish, however almost all of these species were found in other local habitats such as main river channels, black-water lakes or forest streams. For both plants and fish it is argued that factors positive for gene flow and negative for patch persistence make speciation in the floodplain uncommon. Speciation was much more common under the isolation afforded by side streams and peripheral areas; floodplain species and clades were probably usually derived from these areas. A lack of speciation combined with the high rate of temporal change led to demand plastic adaptability in most floodplain inhabitants. Low speciation is not low macro-evolution, indeed much remarkable floodplain adaptation was present. Genetically assimilable plasticity often precedes radical novelty. Examples are given of past important macroevolutionary developments that may have originated in tropical floodplains, including the likely origins of angiosperms (Taylor & Hickey 1995), and of tetrapods (Ahlberg & Milner 1994). Radical innovations of the present and recent past in the Amazon floodplain are illustrated.

bibl.et: Melastomataceae in the flora and vegetation of the Venezuelan Guayana: some ecological and phytogeographical considerations.
bibl.ct: A Festschrift in honor of John J. Wurdack.
bibl.pb: BioCentro de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora
bibl.aa: Fundación Instituto Botánico de Venezuela (FIBV), Caracas, Venezuela.

ab.p: Fifty genera and 436 species of Melastomataceae are known from the Venezuelan Guayana, of which more than 100 species are endemics. Species diversity decreases, but endemism increases, from the lowlands to the highlands. Ecological differentiation in forests, shrublands, and savannas and meadows is discussed, as is the phytogeography of Guayana generic endemics and Guayana-centred genera.

bibl.do: Subsurface hydrological responses to land cover and land use changes.
bibl.et: Using heat pulse and deuterium tracing techniques to estimate tree water use.
bibl.aa: Resource Sciences Centre, Department of Natural Resources, Meiers Rd. Indooroopilly, Qld. 4068, Australia.

ab.p: The use of heat pulse and deuterium tracing techniques for estimating sap flux in a stand of 5-year-old Eucalyptus grandis trees in south east Queensland, Australia, were compared. Comparisons of sap flux from 10 trees, representing the range of tree sizes in the stand, identified some substantial differences between the methods at the scale of the individual tree (between 12 and 43%). Using tree diameter as a scaling parameter, water use of the stand was also calculated, and a variety of scaling scenarios investigated. This included the potential of combining the heat pulse and deuterium tracing techniques in order to increase sample size, and hence confidence in scaling estimates. Despite differences at the scale of the individual tree, it is concluded that there is potential to combine the two methods and still maintain an adequate level of precision.

bibl.et: The boom in forest owners - a bust for forestry?
bibl.aa: DeCoster Group, 11322 French Horn Lane, Reston, VA 20191-4402, USA.

ab.p: Private forests in the USA are breaking into smaller ownerships. The largest parcels remain intact for now, but the acreage in mid-size woodlots is shrinking and the smallest size class is growing. As the size of their ownerships decreases, owners are less likely to see the relevance of forestry. Without significant investments in public relations and marketing, forestry will become less and less relevant to more and more people, and vital forests that can produce both environmental and economic benefits will be lost. The need for new approaches and technologies designed for small parcels is discussed.

bibl.et: A review of conceptual landscape planning models for multiobjective forestry in Sweden.
bibl.aa: Department of Silviculture, SLU, SE-901 87 Umeå, Sweden.

ab.p: This paper reviews the approaches to multiple objective landscape planning that have developed in Swedish forestry in the 1990s. The objectives of such planning include primarily timber production and maintenance of biodiversity, but also aspects such as aesthetics and recreation. The variety of approaches and models that have emerged is caused by regional differences in land-use history, forest conditions, recreation pressure, and ownership. Three approaches are distinguished. The species approach and the naturalness approach integrate conservation aspects, while the multiple aspects approach integrates several aspects (biological, social, economic, spiritual, etc.) into commercial timber-producing forestry. The species approach is exemplified by the key habitat-corridor model in which key habitats and corridors are preserved to support certain species. The natural landscape model illustrates an example of the naturalness approach, as it integrates natural forest features from a fire-disturbed landscape and gives examples of management implications at the landscape as well as at the stand level. The multiple aspects approach combines several objectives and defines important structures rather loosely. This approach was developed in areas where private nonindustrial forestry dominates. Non-timber and non-conservation aspects therefore become relevant to forest management. The supportive feature model exemplifies an application of that approach.

bibl.et: Biomass partitioning and nitrogen retranslocation in black spruce seedlings on competitive mixedwood sites: a bioassay study.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Forestry, University of Toronto, 33 Willcocks Street, Toronto, ON M5S 3B3, Canada.

ab.p: Black spruce (Picea mariana) seedlings were exponentially nutrient loaded by applying 3 or 6 times more fertilizer than recommended for conventional seedling production in the nursery in northern Ontario. Loaded seedlings were similar in height and biomass to non-loaded seedlings after nursery culture, but their tissue N, P, and K content was almost twice as much as that of non-loaded seedlings. The 1-year-old seedlings were transplanted on intact potted substrates (bioassays) retrieved with natural vegetation from two boreal mixedwood sites in Ontario and grown for one season in a greenhouse to study early- and late-season growth and nutrient dynamics, and nutrient loading and herbicide effects (spraying with glyphosate to create weed-free plots) on N retranslocation processes. After transplanting, height and biomass growth of loaded seedlings were, respectively, 9-14% and 24-49% more than non-loaded seedlings in herbicide-treated plots, and 14-32% and 42-85% more in untreated plots. The more competitive loaded seedlings resulted in 32-39% greater biomass reduction in natural vegetation than under non-loaded trees. The effect of nutrient loading on growth was attributed to earlier and greater biomass and N partitioning to current needles and roots that promoted N uptake (up to 20.9±1.7 mg) compared with non-loaded seedlings (up to 11.8±1.2 mg). Although both loading and herbicide treatments stimulated seedling growth and N uptake, N retranslocation from older to actively growing tissues was promoted by loading but reduced by herbicide treatment. The results demonstrate the high dependence of seedlings on internal nutrient reserves when planted in competitive environments, and that nutrient retranslocation is mainly driven by current growth, nutrient uptake, and internal nutrient reserves.

bibl.et: Differences in composition and release rate of volatiles emitted by black spruce seed cones sampled in situ versus ex situ.
bibl.aa: Canadian Forest Service, Great Lakes Forestry Centre, P.O. Box 90, Sault Ste. Marie, ON P6A 5M7, Canada.

ab.p: The volatile emissions of black spruce (Picea mariana) seed cones still attached to a live 7 m tall tree (in situ) were compared with those of cones that had been severed (ex situ) from the same tree at Moonbeam, Ontario, in the morning and afternoon of 15 June 1994. Volatiles were collected simultaneously from several cones with a manifold headspace sampling system, adsorbed on Porapak Q, and analysed by capillary gas chromatography (GC) and GC/mass spectrometry. The cones emitted tricyclene, α- and β-pinene, camphene, sabinene, β-myrcene, 3-carene, p-cymene, β-phellandrene, limonene, γ-terpinene, α-terpinolene, camphor, borneol, and bornyl acetate. There were consistent quantitative differences between the volatile constituents of in situ and ex situ samples. Qualitative differences were also found: camphene and bornyl acetate represented ~7 and 12% of total emissions, respectively, of the volatiles from in situ cones and 0.9 and <0.2%, respectively, of the volatiles from ex situ cones. β-Phellandrene and β-pinene were consistently less abundant in extracts of in situ collections (4.5 and 22%, respectively) than in those of ex situ collections (6 and 32%, respectively). The release rate of total monoterpenes from in situ seed cones was approximately twice as high as that from ex situ cones. These results indicate that ex situ sampling does not accurately depict the composition of volatile emissions by seed cones and suggest that tests for biological activity based on such compositions could lead to erroneous conclusions.

bibl.et: Limitation of plant water use by rhizosphere and xylem conductance: results from a model.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, Box 90338, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, USA.

ab.p: Hydraulic conductivity (K) in the soil and xylem declines as water potential (Ψ) declines. This results in a maximum rate of steady-state transpiration (Ecrit) and corresponding minimum leaf Ψ (Ψcrit) at which K has approached zero somewhere in the soil-leaf continuum. Exceeding these limits causes water transport to cease. A model determined whether the point of hydraulic failure (where K = 0) occurred in the rhizosphere or xylem components of the continuum. Below a threshold of root:leaf area (AR:AL), the loss of rhizosphere K limited Ecrit and Ψcrit. Above the threshold, loss of xylem K from cavitation was limiting. The AR:AL threshold ranged from >40 for coarse soils and/or cavitation-resistant xylem to <0.20 in fine soils and/or cavitation-susceptible xylem. Comparison of model results with drought experiments in sunflowers (Helianthus annuus) and water birch (Betula occidentalis) indicated that stomatal regulation of E reflected the species' hydraulic potential for extracting soil water, and that the more sensitive stomatal response of water birch to drought was necessary to avoid hydraulic failure. The results suggest that plants should be xylem-limited and near their AR:AL threshold. Corollary predictions are that within a soil type the AR:AL should increase with increasing cavitation resistance and drought tolerance, and that across soil types from fine to coarse the AR:AL should increase and maximum cavitation resistance should decrease.

bibl.av: Chang, S. T.\Wu, C. L.\Wang, S. Y.\Chang, H. T.
bibl.et: Influence of concentration and particle size on the DRIFT spectroscopy of wood.
bibl.ms: English figures and tables.
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry, National Taiwan University, 1 Sec. 4, Roosevelt Rd, Taipei, Taiwan.

ab.p: This study evaluates the effects of the concentration and particle size of wood powder in KBr on the diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy of China fir (Cunninghamia lanceolata). The DRIFT spectra of wood powder in KBr were measured over a concentration range of 1 to 100 weight percent with particle size over a diameter range of 61 µm to 3 mm. It was demonstrated that the characteristics of the DRIFT spectra of China fir were very much influenced by the concentration of wood powder in KBr. By comparing with the absorbance spectrum obtained using the traditional transmission technique in KBr pellets, spectral distortions occurred as a function of the concentration and particle size of wood powder in KBr. Results clearly reveal that an anomalous effect caused by the specular reflection was observed mainly between the 950 cm-1 and 1200 cm-1 regions with a shift to higher wavenumber and a significant variation in the relative intensities at 1735 cm-1, 1645 cm-1, 1158 cm-1, 1106 cm-1, 898 cm-1, and 810 cm-1. The spectral distortions can be suppressed by decreasing the concentration and particle size of wood powders in KBr. It was possible to obtain a high quality DRIFT spectrum, similar to the absorbance spectrum obtained using KBr pellets, from diluting wood powders, with diameters smaller than 200 µm, in KBr at concentrations not exceeding 10%.

bibl.et: The role of mycorrhizae, site preparation, and organic amendment in the afforestation of a semi-arid Mediterranean site with Pinus halepensis.
bibl.aa: Centro de Edafología y Biología Aplicada del Segura-CSIC, Apdo. 4195, 30080 Murcia, Spain.

ab.p: A factorial field experiment was established in November 1992 in a degraded semi-arid site of southeastern Spain to test the effectiveness of mycorrhization and several soil preparation techniques on afforestation with Pinus halepensis. The mycorrhizal treatments were nursery inoculation with Pisolithus arhizus [P. tinctorius] and forest soil addition to the planting holes. The soil preparation treatments were terracing (mechanical and manual) and the addition of an organic amendment (urban solid refuse). One year after planting, there were significant differences in mycorrhization levels, frequency of mycorrhizal species, fine root production and growth between the inoculated seedlings and the uninoculated controls. Inoculation with P. tinctorius gave better pine growth and mycorrhization rates than the addition of forest soil. Both mycorrhization treatments were particularly effective in combination with mechanical terracing. The organic amendment had no apparent negative influence on the mycorrhization level of the seedlings and significantly improved pine growth. The beneficial effects of mycorrhization treatments on Pinus halepensis growth persisted 2 years after planting. The increase in growth of the seedlings due to the treatments could be attributed to the change in soil conditions (increased fertility and soil aeration) and probably to a mycorrhization effect on water relations, although it has not been clearly demonstrated.

bibl.et: Influence of intensive culture on leaf net photosynthesis and growth of sweetgum and loblolly pine seedlings.
bibl.aa: School of Forestry, Auburn University, AL 36849-5418, USA.

ab.p: The influence of (1) complete weed control only, (2) weed control and irrigation, (3) weed control and irrigation with a fertilizer solution (fertigation), and (4) weed control and fertigation plus pest suppression (pine only) on midday light-saturated leaf net photosynthesis (Pn) of sweetgum (Liquidambar styraciflua) and loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) was examined monthly, two growing seasons after plantation establishment. The plantation near Bainbridge, Georgia, USA, was established in January 1995 after intensive site preparation. Weed control was maintained with broadcast applications of sulfometuron and direct applications of glyphosate. Irrigation was applied from March to October 1995 and 1996, and fertigation involved addition of NH4NO3, urea, H3PO4 and K2O from May. For the pine, fusiform rust (Cronartium quercuum f.sp. fusiforme [C. fusiforme]) was controlled with triadimefon and Nantucket pine tip moth (Rhyacionia frustrana) with permethrin or acephate. Irrigation but not fertigation increased Pn on all dates and more than doubled height and diameter of sweetgum after the first growing season. Greater Pn in sweetgum in response to irrigation was, in part, a result of reductions in stomatal limitation to Pn and decreased stomatal sensitivity to vapour pressure deficit. In loblolly pine, Pn was increased only by irrigation and only on one date during the first growing season. No effect of treatment on Pn of either species was observed for the second season. After two growing seasons, an eight-fold increase in aboveground biomass and six-fold increase in leaf area were observed in sweetgum in response to fertigation relative to the control treatment. Fertigation plus pest control treatment eliminated tip moth damage to shoots of loblolly pine during the first growing season and resulted in a doubling of total biomass and tripling of leaf area. Maximum biomass accumulation in sweetgum and loblolly pine after two seasons of intensive culture was mainly a function of leaf area rather than Pn.

bibl.et: TROPIS: Tree Growth and Permanent Plot Information System.
bibl.aa: Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR), PO Box 6596 JKPWB, Jakarta 10065, Indonesia.

ab.p: TROPIS (Tree Growth and Permanent Plot Information System) is sponsored by the Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR), to promote more effective use of existing data and knowledge on tree growth. It contains 5 elements: (1) a network of people willing to share permanent plot data and tree growth information, serviced by newsletters and information sources, and hosted at http://www.cgnet.org/cifor/research/tropis.html (or available from CIFOR), (2) an index of people and institutions holding permanent plot data, (3) a database management system, (4) a system to facilitate site matching by identifying comparable sites and allowing foreign data to be used when no local growth information exists, and (5) an inference system to allow growth estimates to be made in the absence of empirical data. The index or metadatabase contains references to 12&thin;000 plots with 3000 species provided by 100 contributors, and is growing at about 1000 plots per month. Searches of the database are welcomed, and may be directed to the author.

bibl.av: Zhao, W.\Wu, Y. B.\Liu, J. X.
bibl.et: Exploring the theory of light energy distribution on the canopy surface of Picea koraiensis Nakai.
bibl.aa: Northeast Forestry University, Harbin 150040, China.

ab.p: The distribution of scattered light and light energy on the canopy surface of Picea koraiensis [P. koyamai] was investigated theoretically by making a simple electric dipole model. The distribution of branches and leaves on the canopy surface was described by introducing the concept of surface gap degree. Theoretical results showed that the influence of scattered light intensity was very weak, approximating to 5% of incident light intensity. Therefore, light distribution was approximately even on every flank of canopy surface of a tree, but the light distribution of every flank was different, and the distribution of light on the flank which was vertical to the direction of incident light was the strongest.

bibl.do: Resource Bulletin - Southern Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.et: South Carolina's timber industry - an assessment of timber product output and use, 1995.
bibl.pb: Southern Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Southern Research Station, PO Box 2680, Asheville, NC 28802, USA.

ab.p: In 1995, roundwood output from South Carolina's forests totalled 622 million cubic feet, 5% less than in 1994. Mill byproducts generated from primary manufacturers declined 4% to 203 million cubic feet. Almost all plant residues were used primarily for fuel and fibre products. Pulpwood was the leading roundwood product at 320 million cubic feet; saw logs ranked second at 247 million cubic feet; veneer logs were third at 50 million cubic feet. The number of primary processing plants declined from 105 in 1994 to 99 in 1995. Total receipts declined 5% to about 619 million cubic feet.

bibl.et: The influence of fruit and bud volumes on eucalypt flowering- an exploratory analysis.
bibl.aa: School of Forestry and Resource Conservation, University of Melbourne, Creswick, Vic. 3363, Australia.

ab.p: The appearance of buds and development of fruits in 51 species of Eucalyptus were examined to determine whether bud and fruit volume had an influence on flowering. These variables exerted an influence on eucalypt flowering as individuals and as members within an umbel. Flowering earlier in the growing season was characteristic of species with large, individual bud and fruit volume and those that have a large umbel volume. The number of buds and fruits in an umbel is influenced by volume of the individuals. Development time of buds was longer in umbels which had a larger total volume. Bud and fruit umbel volume was positively correlated with the timing of bud appearance as was seed maturity with individual fruit and fruit umbel volume. A threshold of bud and fruit volume was indicated below which seed maturity and time of flowering was not reflected by volume. Discriminant analysis used nine predictors to assign 80% (overall) of section members of Adnataria (91%), Bisectaria (60%), Maidenaria (67%) and Renantheria (87%) to their true groups. Across groups examination adduced the possibility of each group having a distinct bud development period and a discernible cessation of flowering. Five clusters were revealed whose members were significantly differentiated on seed maturity, section, individual fruit volumes, bud and fruit umbel volumes. Factor analysis outlined four factors (buds, fruits, timing and development) which accounted for 78.9% of the variance.

bibl.et: In vitro culture of rudimentary embryos of Ilex paraguariensis: responses to exogenous cytokinins.
bibl.aa: Facultad de Ciencias Agrarias, IBONE, C.C. 209 (3.400), Corrientes, Argentina.

ab.p: The effects of benzyladenine (BAP), kinetin (KIN), zeatin (ZEA), isopentenyladenine (2iP), and thidiazuron (TDZ) on in vitro growth of rudimentary embryos of Ilex paraguariensis were examined. Heart stage zygotic embryos were removed from seeds of immature, light green fruits and cultured aseptically on quarter-strength Murashige and Skoog medium containing 3% sucrose, 0.65% agar, and supplemented with or without three concentrations of BAP, KIN, ZEA, 2iP, or TDZ. Cultures were incubated in darkness at 27 ± 2°C. Media containing 4.4 × 10-6 &smallcap;M BAP, 4.6 × 10-6 &smallcap;M KIN, or 4.9 × 10-6 &smallcap;M 2iP were totally ineffective in inducing embryo growth after culture for 28 days. However, lower concentrations of these compounds (4.4 × 10-8 &smallcap;M BAP, 4.6 × 10-8 &smallcap;M KIN, 4.5 × 10-8 &smallcap;M ZEA, or 4.9 × 10-8 &smallcap;M 2iP) promoted embryo growth. TDZ at 9.9 × 10-9 &smallcap;M, 9.9 × 10-8 &smallcap;M, or 9.9 × 10-7 &smallcap;M induced embryo growth at similar rates. The maximum percentage of embryos converted to seedlings was achieved when the medium was supplemented with 4.5 × 10-7 &smallcap;M ZEA.

bibl.et: Feruloyl esters of ω-hydroxyacids in cork suberin.
bibl.aa: Instituto Superior de Agronomia, Departamento de Engenharia Florestal, P-1399 Lisboa Codex, Portugal.

ab.p: Feruloyl esters of ω-hydroxyacids were found in the alcoholysis products of suberin from Quercus suber cork. Their identification was made from mass spectra and by comparison with synthetic model compounds. The ω-hydroxyls of suberinic hydroxyacids are thought to be the ester-bonding points between suberin aliphatics and associated aromatics.

bibl.et: Temperate silvoarable agroforestry with poplar.
bibl.aa: Department of Biology, University of Leeds, Leeds LS2 9JT, UK.

ab.p: 1995-97 results are reported from an ongoing project set up in 1992 at 3 sites with differing soils and climate in England (Leeds, West Yorkshire; Silsoe, Bedfordshire; and Cirencester, Gloucestershire), in which the effect of widely spaced poplar hybrids (Populus × trichocarpa, P. deltoides × P. nigra [P. canadensis] 'Robusta' and 'Gibecq' and P. deltoides × P. trichocarpa [P. interamericana] 'Beaupré') on crop yield, the effects of the crops on tree growth, and establishment, management and economic aspects were investigated. Treatments included continuous cropping of the alleys between tree rows on both sides, cropping on alternate sides each year (with the other side a fallow), and continuous fallow in the alleys. Arable rotations included winter or spring cereals with winter or spring beans or suitable break crops. The trees are 6.4 m apart within rows and 10 m apart between rows, with uncultivated areas at the base of trees and cropped areas 2 and 8 m wide, respectively. Earlier results have been reported in earlier issues of this journal. Populus 'Beaupré' was the best growing species at all sites and in all treatments. The effects of treatment on tree height growth varied with site, with no significant difference at Silsoe, and significantly least growth in the continuously cropped treatment at Cirencester and Leeds (but significant differences between the 2 other treatments only at Leeds). Rank orders of crop yield by treatment were not consistent across sites, but results at Cirencester and Leeds suggested that the trees were reducing crop yield, and this was confirmed by demonstration of differences in yield with distance from tree rows. Populus 'Beaupré' reduced crop yield most at Silsoe, but there were no differences between tree species at the other sites. Management measures are discussed, and included ploughing and plastic mulching at the base of the tree rows.

bibl.et: The use of SEM/EDX for studying the distribution of air pollutants in the surroundings of the emission source.
bibl.aa: Department of Limnology and Environmental Protection, PO Box 27, Viikki A-Building, FIN-00014 University of Helsinki, Helsinki, Finland.

ab.p: A new application of SEM/EDX-methods to study the distribution of air pollutants in the surroundings of an emission source is described. An energy dispersive X-ray microanalyzer (EDX) connected to a scanning electron microscope (SEM) was used to measure the amount of several elements on the surface of Scots pine bark. To test this method, bark samples were collected near a limestone quarry and plant. The results indicated that the pollutant gradient in the surroundings of the emission source was clearest, when this new method was used. The coefficient of determination (R²) for calcium on pine bark was 0.99, whereas in the same study line, measurements of total Ca content of pine needles and soil humus yielded R² values of 0.46 and 0.74, respectively.

bibl.et: Geodiversity and biodiversity in the Wielkopolska National Park - identification and protection, selected problems.
bibl.ft: Georóz&dotover;norodnośc´ i bioróz&dotover;norodnośc´ Wielkopolskiego Parku Narodowego - rozpoznanie i ochrona, wybrane problemy.

ab.p: Twenty papers/articles by various authors are included in this volume from the Wielkopolska National Park in Poland. They are arranged in 4 sections. Section I, Geodiversity in the Wielkopolska National Park, has 2 papers on the geological identification of Czarny Dó&lstroke; basin bog, and the morphometry of Kociolek lake. Section II, Biodiversity in the Wielkopolska National Park - selected problems, has 5 papers on: the vascular plant flora of the park, red ring rot of Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris) caused by Phellinus pini in the park, disease symptoms and fungi in Quercus petraea in the Wielkopolska and Wolin National Parks, the diversity and quality of dominant habitats of the Jaros&lstroke;awieckie lake, and possibilities of protecting the wolf in Polish national parks. Section III, Human impact on the geodiversity and biodiversity in the Wielkopolska National Park, has 4 papers on: human activity and lake pollution of the Witobelsko-dymaczewska Drainage Channel, the spatial distribution of air pollution based on monitoring in 1986-94, fluorine deposits in pine needles as an indicator of environmental pollution, and the park as a potential tourism area for wheelchair users. Section IV, Reports, reviews, chronicles, has 9 short articles.

bibl.et: Research on final moisture content as a factor of wood drying quality.
bibl.ft: Ispitivanje konačnog sadrz&hacek;aja vode kao čimbenika kvalitete sušenja.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Forestry of the Zagreb University, Zagreb, Croatia.

ab.p: According to the forthcoming obligatory standard, a study was made of the final moisture content oakwood dimension parts (for parquet flooring) during kiln drying. The final moisture content was estimated by moisture meters and determined using the oven-dry method on each of the 30 samples per kiln load. After the moisture meter reading, each sample was sawn into 18 pieces for the oven drying method, to determine the range of moisture readings and to compare it with the forthcoming drying quality standard. The oven-dry method showed a difference in results from the moisture meter readings, and a difference in the moisture content between the inner and outer layers of the oakwood dimension parts. An estimation of the moisture content (measured with a moisture meter on 1/3 of the thickness) did not fulfil the expectations, if compared with oven-dry results. The differences in the moisture content between the readings at 1/2 and 1/6 of thickness are classified as the highest possible class, which shows the right conditioning treatment. It can be concluded that the real moisture content in wood is very different from the values measured by moisture meters, that it has greater variation, and that the proposed methods of standardised measurements and drying quality class determination have to be seriously reconsidered.

bibl.do: Bulletin Technique - Office National des Forêts
bibl.et: Do silvicultural sheared strips lead to differences between edge trees and inside trees in a young stand of sessile oak?
bibl.ft: Le cloisonnement sylvicole induit-il des différences entre les arbres de bordure et les arbres intérieurs dans un jeune peuplement de chêne sessile?
bibl.aa: ONF - Département des Recherches Techniques, Bd de Constance, 77300 Fontainebleau, France.

ab.p: The influence of silvicultural sheared strips upon some form and growth characteristics of sessile oak (Quercus petraea) trees was evaluated in two natural sessile-oak regeneration stands in the state forest at Bertranges where sheared strips have been present for 15 years. Neither the intensity of tilt for dominant trees, nor the number of curvatures depended on their situation in the woody strip. Growth was also independent of position. Some branching characteristics were influenced by the distance to the sheared strip but only in the youngest stand. It is concluded that sheared strips do not compromise the quality of young stands.

bibl.et: A modeling approach of PAR environment in a tropical rain forest in Sumatra: application to remote sensing.
bibl.ct: 1st ECOSUMMIT meeting, Copenhagen, Denmark, August 1996..
bibl.aa: Centre d'Etude de la Biosphère, CNES/CNRS/UPS, 18 Av. Edouard, Belin, 31055 Toulouse, Cedex, France.

ab.p: A modelling study, using a new radiative transfer model (Discrete Anisotropic Radiative Transfer (DART)) was applied to a tropical rain forest site in central Sumatra. Intensive field work led to detailed structural data on a 1 ha plot. Reflectance images and within stand radiation were simulated for different scales of analysis, viewing and illumination configurations, and leaf biomass. The results demonstrated the great dependence of remote sensing measurements and within stand absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) upon experimental conditions. The impact of forest structure on two hypotheses commonly used for simulating CO2 assimilation and for relating this quantity to remote sensing was examined: within stand PAR exponential profiles, and constant ratio of light absorption among leaves. It is concluded that there is potential for using the DART model, alone or with remote sensing, to better understand PAR environment and consequently photosynthetic responses of tropical rain forest.

bibl.et: Predictors of white-tailed deer grazing intensity in fragmented deciduous forests.
bibl.aa: Department of Fisheries and Wildlife, University of Minnesota, St. Paul, MN 55108, USA.

ab.p: Measurements from 11 maple-basswood (Acer saccharum-Tilia americana) forest fragments in southcentral Minnesota were used to examine the predictability of deer (Odocoileus virginianus) grazing intensity on understory forbs based on local winter deer density, composition of the landscape surrounding each forest fragment, and characteristics of forb populations within the forest. In early summer, grazing intensity on 6 palatable forb species at most sites was inversely correlated with the availability of alfalfa (Medicago sativa) within a 1.5-km radius of the stand (r² = 0.66); winter deer density and forb flowering rate within the stand were additional important predictors of grazing intensity. Later in the growing season, most variability in the intensity of grazing among forest fragments could be explained either by the availability of row crops, alfalfa, and fields within a 1.5-km radius of the stand (r² = 0.75) or by a combination of winter deer density and forb abundance within the stand (r² = 0.75). Results suggested that parks and preserves with low densities of palatable plant species in the forest understory may be especially susceptible to effects of deer grazing. It is recommended that changes in landscape composition (e.g., increased row-cropping or conversion of land to residential developments) should be an important consideration in the management of deer densities in areas designed to protect native forest communities, and that if there is reduced cultivation of alfalfa or increased conversion of row crops to residential development, there may be a corresponding need to reduce local deer numbers.

bibl.et: Tree flora of Pasoh forest.
bibl.aa: Forest Research Institute Malaysia, Kepong, 52109 Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

ab.p: This tree flora described in this book is based on data from a 50-ha permanent plot established in the Pasoh Forest Reserve in Peninsular Malaysia, by the Forest Research Institute Malaysia (FRIM) in collaboration with the Smithsonian Tropical Forest Research Institute (USA). The purpose of the plot was to study the population biology of trees in primary lowland forest. The enumeration of the plot included all free standing trees and saplings of ≥1 cm diameter; climbers were excluded. The flora also includes additions of some species observed outside the plot. The plot contained 335&thin;240 trees belonging to 814 species, 290 genera and 78 families. The tree species diversity is comparable with that recorded anywhere in the world, and similar to that of other aseasonal forests in Malaysia. The forest is of uniformly low density and there are no clear dominant species, although the Euphorbiaceae are most species diverse and abundant, followed by Myrtaceae and Lauraceae. Emergents and shrubs constitute only 12% of the tree flora, with most species canopy or understorey. A comparison with the tree flora of Malaya showed that 25% of the species in Malays are present in the Pasoh plot. The book is arranged in 4 chapters: Introduction; Vegetative characters useful for tree identification; Botanical keys; and Descriptions of families, genera and species. The descriptions form the main part of the book (pp. 117-440) and are arranged in alphabetical order of family and species; keys to genera and species are included. There are indexes to botanical and Malay names.

bibl.et: Forest perturbations and biodiversity during the last ten thousand years in French Guiana.
bibl.aa: Laboratoire d'écologie générale MNHN/URA 1183/CNRS, 4 avenue du Petit Château, 91800 Brunoy, France.

ab.p: Tropical forests can be described as a mosaic of juxtaposed eco-units corresponding to different stages of regeneration after treefalls. However, these small-scale regeneration mechanisms alone cannot account for the different patterns of species distribution, plant communities and population structures found in this habitat. Vegetation pattern was examined in pristine tropical rain forest on the Les Nouragues research station, French Guiana. The presence of charcoal layers in the soil and the study of sediments along streams suggested that large-scale forest fires deeply affected the tropical forest vegetation, even in high rainfall areas such as the study site. Many atypical plant distribution and population structure patterns, in relation to what would be expected from present-time regeneration processes, can be explained by these large-scale events which happened during the last few thousand years.

bibl.do: The ecological history of European forests: based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996.
bibl.et: Wood-pasture in Dutch common woodlands and the deforestation of the Dutch landscape.
bibl.ct: The ecological history of European forests: based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996.
bibl.aa: DLO Winand Staring Centre for Integrated Land, Soil and Water Research, Department of Historical Geography, PO Box 125, 6700 AC Wageningen, Netherlands.

ab.p: Forest grazing has been reintroduced in parts of the Netherlands to improve the nature conservation value of woodland. A small historical ecological study was undertaken to gain an insight into the long-term effects of grazing on the development of vegetation. Late medieval regulations drawn up by commoners demonstrate some of the problems that grazing animals caused. It is concluded that, in general, the amount of grazing led to the destruction of woodland and that it is unlikely that heavy grazing led to high nature conservation values. Open glades in woodland eventually became so extended that no woodland survived. The regulations studied provide little information about the size of herds of grazing animals. They do show, however, the great importance placed on the time of the year when it was allowable to drive herds into the woods.
