bibl.et: Street treets in Mexico City: delegaciones Iztacalco and Iztapalapa, Federal District.
bibl.ft: Situación del arbolado de alineación de la ciudad de México: Delegaciones Iztacalco e Iztapalapa, Distrito Federal.
bibl.aa: Campo Experimental Pachuca, CIRCE, INIFAP, SAGAR, Mexico.

ab.p: Inventories of urban street trees and shrubs were made in Iztacalco and Iztapalapa, Federal District , Mexico. Thirteen neighbourhoods and 3190 trees were sampled in Iztacalco over 28.9 km, and 22 neighborhoods and 5436 trees in Iztapalapa over 47.28 km. Each tree or shrub was identified taxonomically, and quantitative characteristics were evaluated (diameter (DBH) total height, location, available space for plant growth) and also some qualitative characteristics (health, physical condition of stem and foliage, age class, pruning type, and pavement damage). In Iztacalco 68 different trees and shrubs species were identified; the most frequently occurring species were Fraxinus uhdei (16.83%), Ligustrum lucidum (13.73%), and Cupressus lindleyi (13.44%). In Iztapalapa 81 trees and shrubs species were identified; the most frequently occurring were Ligustrum lucidum (9.95%), Cupressus lindleyi (9.47%), Fraxinus uhdei (8.74%), Jacaranda mimosifolia (8.43%), and Erythrina coralloides (7.27%). The average DBH was 13.6 cm in Iztacalco, and 11.5 cm in Iztapalapa; the average total height was 3.10 m and 3.9 m respectively. Both locations had a high percentage of trees with good stem and foliage health conditions. A high percentage of trees had not been pruned and a high percentage were causing no damage to pavements.

bibl.et: The influence of natural and economic factors on the quality of game habitats.
bibl.ct: Utjecaj prirodnih i gospodarkih čimbenika na kakvoc´u staništa divljači.
bibl.aa: Department of forest protection and hunting, Faculty of forestry, University of Zagreb, Svetošimunska 25, HR-10000 Zagreb.

ab.p: Various measurable natural and anthropogenic characteristics (including economics) were measured throughout the north-west of Croatia, during 1994 and 1995, to produce a comprehensive model for use in short and long term large game management planning. Data was collected at 2 different scales, on a grid of 1 × 1 km sample plots, arranged 4 km apart, covering the entire study area and a linear area estimation based on smaller areas (hunting grounds). Data recorded included exposure, inclination, vegetation composition, settlements, thoroughfares and water features. Collected data was then processed and realistic conditions for game management in an area calculated mathematically. The graphic models based on several samples are intended to give the final results on the habitat quality for individual game species. Data was then processed to construct a model for game management.

bibl.do: Mitteilungen der Forstlichen Versuchs- und Forschungsanstalt Baden-Württemberg
bibl.et: Vegetation and stand structure in Bannwald Napf, Southern Black Forest.
bibl.ft: Vegetation und Bestandesstruktur im Bannwald Napf, Südschwarzwald.
bibl.pb: Forstliche Versuchs- und Forschungsanstalt Baden-Württemberg, Ministerium für Ernährung, Landwirtschaft Umwelt und Forsten
bibl.aa: Forstliche Versuchs- und Forschungsanstalt, Baden-Württemberg, Postfach 708, 79007 Freiburg, Wonnhaldestr. 4, 79100 Freiburg, Germany.

ab.p: A study was conducted during 1995-96 to document long-term changes in forest structure entailing plant surveys of quadrats (225 m² each) at Bannwald Napf, in the Southern Black Forest. The most common plant community on the east and west facing slopes was woodrush (Luzula luzuloides and L. sylvatica)/beech (Fagus sylvatica) forest, and on the north-facing slopes and higher parts woodrush/fir (Abies alba) forest. Together these made up 82% of the area surveyed. Other communities recorded were maple/beech forest with subalpine tall shrub communities on mesic sites often close to small streams, and woodruff (Galium odoratum)/beech forest on lower west-facing slopes. The assessment of the forest stand was based on 101 circular plots either 0.1 or 0.05 ha dependant on the morphological situation. Spruce made up 67% of the living timber, beech 17% and maple 5%. Deciduous trees were dominant in the lower layers of the stands, particularly mountain ash (Sorbus aucuparia). Dead woody matter totalled 111 m³/ha, 80 m³ of standing snags and 31 m³ logs. 87% of dead matter was spruce. Natural regeneration exhibited a change in species composition favouring spruce. Compared with data collected in 1982 the living volume of trees had decreased by 80 m³/ha. A comparison of the 1996 data to a forest stand assessment conducted in a nearby similar commercial forest, indicated that it had a greater living volume than the reserve, and a higher percentage of spruce. A larger proportion of maple and mountain ash regeneration was noted in the commercial forest.

bibl.et: Vision and goals for a provincial forest administration.
bibl.ft: Leitbild und Zielsystem für eine Landesforstverwaltung.
bibl.aa: Staatskanzlei Rheinland-Pfalz, Mainz, Germany.

ab.p: At present in Germany not only the state forest administrations but also private owners and community forests all operate multi-functional forestry, largely owing to the example and influence of state forests. With falling profit margins, increasing emphasis is placed on cost-cutting, with the attendant danger of overlooking non-profitable functions (environmental protection, recreation, etc.). Accordingly a creative discussion of vision and goals in forestry is needed, leading to a formulation of minimum standards.

bibl.et: Basic considerations and practical experience in hunting methods adapted to species.
bibl.ft: Grundsätzliche Überlegungen zu und praktische Erfahrungen mit artangepassten Bejagungsmethoden.
bibl.aa: Institut für Wildbiologie und Jagdkunde, Universität Göttingen, Germany.

ab.p: The behaviour of various game animals is discussed in relation to different forms of hunting, viz. chasing (beating, driving, etc.) or still hunting (luring, shooting from high-seats, stalking, etc.). The increasing practice of close-to-nature silviculture means that the standard traditional form of hunting, viz. shooting from high-seats, is no longer adequate to regulate game populations. Traditional forms of hunting and new forms of hunting with hounds have been evaluated in German national parks and large state forests for roe deer (Capreolus capreolus), red deer (Cervus elaphus) and wild boar (Sus scrofa). Better estimates of game populations can be obtained by means of so-called 'count-hunting'.

bibl.et: Sociological aspects of small private forests.
bibl.ft: Zur Soziologie des Kleinprivatwaldes.
bibl.aa: Institut für Forstpolitik, Universität Freiburg, Germany.

ab.p: A sociological analysis is made of the very heterogeneous group of small forest owners in Germany (ca. 1.2 million people). Different types of owners are distinguished, viz. those for whom the forest is a main or a subsidiary source of income, those for whom it is mainly a hobby or leisure resource, those for whom it is a sleeping asset or a burden, and those who neglect it. In the light of these findings, it will be necessary to develop a much more sophisticated forest policy for small private forests in Germany.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Seeds and fruits of tropical rainforest plants: interpretation of the range in seed size, degree of defence and flesh/seed quotients.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Sciences, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge CB2 3EA, UK.

ab.p: A review is presented of recently published work or work in press concerning tropical fleshy fruits, in particular the dry mass quotient of flesh:seed in the context of seed mass:seed number trade-off. It is based mainly on work undertaken on the lowland rain forests of NE Queensland, Australia, but also covers studies from Singapore and the Venezuelan Amazonas. In this chapter 4 issues are tackled; (i) the huge range of seed size within any one functional group (e.g. shade tolerant trees), rather than the differences in mean size between functional groups, (ii) the basis for forests on extremely nutrient-poor soils having smaller seeds than those on less nutrient-poor soils, while often being dominated by one species with relatively large seeds, (iii) the reason why some species have fruits which give their seeds great physical or chemical protection while others do not, and lastly (iv) the relationship between dry mass quotient and seed mass:seed number trade-off.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Patterns in post-dispersal seed removal by neotropical rodents and seed fate in relation to seed size.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Laboratoire d'Ecologie Générale, CNRS URA 1183,4 Avenue du Petit Château, F-91800 Brunoy, France.

ab.p: Experiments were conducted on Barro Colorado Island, Panama, during June to August 1990 (along the R.C. Shannon Trail), to test the effect of seed size (>1 cm) and weight (>0.1 g) on the level of removal and fate for several tree species (Doliocarpus, Cupania, Eugenia, Brosimum, Virola, Licania and Gustavia) illustrating a variety of seed size and dispersal syndromes. The role of seed fate was explored in the context of the habitat in which the seeds landed. Two habitats were recognized based on the frequency of agoutis (Dasyprocta punctata) observed along one transect across the forest (one agouti-rich area located close by the young forest, and one agouti-poor area further in the old forest). Patterns of seed removal as well as the fate of small to large seeds (especially the probability of seed caching), changed between species and habitat depending on seed reward. Small seeds (≤1 g weight and ~1 cm long) had a low probability of being missed by vertebrates, and no effect of the visitation rate of agoutis. Removal by mammals mostly accounted for predation, although the seeds of Eugenia (1.2 g) were cached by rodents more frequently (12%) than those of Cupania (0.2 g; 2%) and Doliocarpus (0.7 g; 0%). Among medium seeds (~1-3 g and 1-2 cm), the habitat and the quality of seed nutrient reward in cotyledons differentially affected removal and fate. High removal in Brosimum seeds (2.2 g) with edible cotyledons corresponded to either predation or caching. On the contrary, removal in Virola seeds (3 g), with toxic cotyledons, accounted for caching more frequently. Greater burying rates occurred in Virola where agouti sightings were lower. Among large seeds (>3 g and >2 cm), fate was independent of habitat and month for the large nutrient-rewarding Gustavia seeds (12 g) only, seeds of which were more often buried than the less nutrient-rewarding Licania seeds (6 g). In the latter, predation was dependent on habitat and month. It is concluded that similar patterns of seed removal result in contrasting seed fate pathways depending on seed size, a gradient of caching rate being observed from the small to the larger seeds. It is suggested that change in caching rate is related to change in agonistic and caching behaviour among agouti populations which vary in density, and that a method of seed labelling may be essential to conclude whether rodents are effective seed dispersers.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Disturbance, phenology and life-history characteristics: factors influencing distance/density-dependent attack on tropical seeds and seedlings.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: International Institute of Entomology, 56 Queen's Gate, London SW7 5JR, UK.

ab.p: A review is presented of the research dedicated to testing the predictions of the Janzen-Connell model of density/distance (or frequency)-dependent attack on seeds and seedlings over the past 25 years. Both theoretical and experimental field tests are also detailed. A compilation of these studies suggests that invertebrate, but not vertebrate, attack generally conforms to the model despite varying forest types, locations and species. This disparity, linked to differences in search tactics and selection criteria, may explain in part why a consensus has been so elusive. The influence of spatial scale on predation effects and the seasonal pattern (and scale) of reproduction in tropical trees and lianas are discussed in relation to their influence on frequency-dependent attack. Large synchronous fruiting events within a population (or among populations of congeners), which can satiate predators, is a commonly accepted way of explaining low predation rates near trees. However, spatial and temporal scales of seed availability are not mutually exclusive influences; there are several different combinations of these two scales (reproductive adult density and individual adult crop size) which can produce the same number of seeds and seedlings available for attack. It is suggested that offspring escape predators either through dispersal or by being unpredictably abundant in time. In addition, this de facto assumption of the Janzen-Connell model, along with the lack of attention paid to the important role that light availability might play in determining the outcome of seed and seedling attack, may have misled most attempts at predicting the effects of attack on population dynamics of tropical trees. It is suggested that an increase in light availability can buffer the effects of attack by invertebrates, leading to establishment where normally under low light conditions there would be mortality. Light-dependent escape may occur as a consequence of reducing seedling susceptibility to attack, by increasing the efficacy of compensatory growth in seedlings, or by marginalizing the impact of seed reserve on seedling growth (the redundancy model). In conclusion, the role of disturbance of tropical forests (which occurs at different frequencies and magnitudes), is highlighted, and it is suggested that this variation may affect the relative importance of light-dependent escape, since the level of disturbance determines the likelihood of an attacked seed or seedling being in a location exposed to a particular light environment.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Gap-size niche differentiation by tropical rainforest trees: a testable hypothesis or a broken-down bandwagon?
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities : the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.aa: Oxford Forestry Institute, South Parks Road, Oxford, OX 13RB, UK.

ab.p: In this chapter a review is presented of the literature concerning tropical rain forest trees which are specialized for optimum growth in treefall gaps of different sizes. There is evidence of partitioning at an ecologically crude guild level (pioneers vs. climax species). However, as the overwhelming majority of tropical rain forest tree species are climax species, it is within this group that tests of the hypothesis are critical. Amongst climax species, whilst differences in ecology have been demonstrated, there is a paucity of evidence of niche differentiation on a gap-size gradient. Reasons for the apparent lack of success in finding niche differentiation are explored. The difficulty in measuring forest gap sizes presents a significant practical problem in addition to the variability of microclimates on a variety of spatial and temporal scales which undermines many of the simplistic assumptions about gap environments made in this theory. Both experimental and observational approaches to detecting differences in seedling responses to gaps suffer from numerous practical and theoretical shortcomings, which are discussed. It is concluded that the forest light climate is an inappropriate environmental gradient for niche differentiation of the majority of tropical rain forest trees, and that an excessive emphasis on canopy gaps has obscured the fact that processes occurring elsewhere in time and space are of crucial importance in determining community composition.

bibl.et: First experiences of Brosimum alicastrum Sw. (Guáimaro) in the National Botanical Garden.
bibl.ft: Primeras experiencias sobre manejo de Brosimum alicastrum Sw. (Guáimaro) en el Jardín Botánico Nacional.
bibl.aa: Jardín Botánico National, Universidad de la Habana, Habana, Cuba.

ab.p: Brosimum alicastrum occurs throughout the West Indies, Mexico and Central America but in Cuba it occupies a limited area in the eastern part of the country. It is utilized for firewood, charcoal, rustic carpentry and occasionally as forage for horses. Using a group of trees established in the National Botanical Garden in 1972, observations were recorded on fruiting and seed germination. The best period for collecting fruits is in August, while seed germination and transplanting can be done with relative ease. Direct seeding is feasible if there are enough seeds.

bibl.et: Profitability of willow cultivation for energy production in Finland.
bibl.ct: Environmental issues for short rotation bioenergy production..
bibl.aa: University of Helsinki, Department of Forest Economics, P.O. Box 24, FIN-00014 Helsinki, Finland.

ab.p: The potential profitability of short rotation willows [Salix spp.] on private farms in Finland as a potential renewable energy source was determined by analysing the effects of selected cultivation costs, land rent, interest rate and subventions. The traditional NPV (Net Present Value) method was chosen, supported by an IRR (Internal Rate of Return) analysis and the calculation of B/C-ratios (Benefit-Cost-Ratio). The basic growth and yield data used are based on results from several experimental willow plantations, and the profitability calculations are based on those cultivation and harvesting systems which are seen to be most likely in Finland in the early stages of commercial willow cultivation. Without any subventions, the minimum profitable energy price required was about M&thin;130 MW h-1, when the annual average yield was 8000 t ha-1 (dry matter); the present average price for wood energy is around M&thin;60 MWh-1. The results resemble those from other Nordic countries, in that subventions are needed to make willow cultivation profitable for private farmers when using presently available machinery and existing energy price levels. However, willow cultivation seemed to be competitive in comparison with most other agricultural energy plants.

bibl.et: Soya protein used as a chelant of copper in waterborne preservatives.
bibl.aa: Iowa State University, IA 50014, USA.

ab.p: A new wood preservative system, in which soya protein was introduced to chelate copper cations, was investigated. Experimental results indicated that soya protein HM90 greatly improved leaching resistance of copper cations fixed in ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa) sapwood. By adding 8 and 16 kg/m³ of soya protein HM90 in ammoniacal copper sulfate solution, the retention of treated wood after leaching was 70% of initial retention on average. Because of the chelation of soya protein, the retention of copper protein after leaching was increased by 40% on average compared with that without protein. Moreover, lower concentrations of copper sulfate were preferred for fixation of copper protein. However, in comparison with copper sulfate, there seemed no significant improvement with copper protein in ponderosa pine blocks with regard to decay resistance to the brown-rot fungus Postia placenta [Oligoporus placenta]. The threshold retention of unleached blocks treated with copper protein was the same as those treated only with copper sulfate.

bibl.aa: Flemish Forestry Association, Geraardsbergse Steenweg 267, B-9090 Melle, Belgium.

ab.p: Several policy and scientific documents emphasize the importance of the realization of new urban forests in densely populated and scarcely wooded areas. The development of a methodology to select the most suitable locations for the establishment of new large urban forests is discussed. The most suitable and feasible locations are selected by means of a multicriteria analysis consisting of 3 phases.

bibl.et: Soil mapping in Tasmania's state forest.
bibl.aa: Forest Practices Unit, 30 Patrick St., Hobart, Tasmania, Australia.

ab.p: A five-year project commenced in 1990 to characterise and map soils on state forests in Tasmania, Australia, with special reference to sustainable forest management and site suitability for plantations. A computer database and a system for recording soil and site information in the field were developed. An improved method for assessing soil erodibility, and a classification of site suitability for plantations based on land resource information were also developed. Mapping of three 1:100 000 sheets (Pipers, Forester and Forth) was completed by the end of 1995. They cover approximately 154&thin;000 ha of state forest. Explanatory reports provide details of soil properties, environmental features and potential degradation hazards, and prescribe sustainable management practices. Soil surveys were carried out on 6500 ha. A handbook characterising a range of common forest soils from around Tasmania, together with management recommendations, was completed.

bibl.et: Modeling the reliability of wood tension members exposed to elevated temperatures.
bibl.aa: Forintek Canada Corp., Suite 4100, C.T.T.C., 1125 Colonel By Drive, Ottawa, ON K1S 5R1, Canada.

ab.p: The merit of approaching fire safety design from the standpoint of reliability is the impetus of this paper. Reliability, a direct function of time to failure, is a measure of performance that falls naturally under a performance-based code. The objectives of this study focus on advancing our understanding of the structural behaviour of light-frame wood members subject to tension and elevated temperatures, and on the time to failure under a given stress and temperature history. A model based on linear damage accumulation theory was developed to predict the time to failure. This model is based on a kinetic theory for strength as a function of temperature and stress, coupled with a kinetic term, to express the pyrolytic process as a form of damage. The model, which requires the short-term strength as an input, fits well to experimental data on nominal 2×4 structural lumber tested at three different rates of tension loading, and at 150, 200, and 250°C, and room temperature. The model also predicts, with reasonable accuracy, the behaviour of lumber under constant load at 250°C. It predicts that lower-grade material generally has a lower reliability index; however, those differences are insignificant as far as current design practices are concerned. The reliability is sensitive to variability in temperature but not to variability in stress.

bibl.et: Chitinase accumulates systemically in wounded poplar trees.
bibl.aa: Immunex Inc., Seattle, WA 98101, USA.

ab.p: Young leaves of poplar (Populus spp.) trees accumulate novel mRNAs shortly after the mature leaves have been mechanically wounded. These systemically wound-induced (win) mRNAs are thought to encode proteins involved in plant defence. Transgenic tobacco plants that ectopically expressed a win6 cDNA contained a novel chitinase activity that was not present in normal tobacco. This demonstrated that Win6 was a chitinase. Win6 and a related protein, Win8, accumulated in wounded plants of Populus trichocarpa and P. deltoides × P. trichocarpa [P. interamericana]. Win6 and Win8 had low isoelectric points (about 4) as predicted from their nucleotide sequence. The wound-inducible increase in Win6 and Win8 was correlated with an increase in chitinase (EC 3.2.1.14) activity in poplar leaf extracts. It is concluded that mechanical wounding induces chitinase in poplar trees, and it is suggested that the induced chitinase activity could act to increase the tolerance of poplars to opportunistic wound pathogens.

bibl.et: Rain forest research and conservation: the Sinharaja experience in Sri Lanka.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, Faculty of Science, University of Peradeniya, Sri Lanka.

ab.p: Sinharaja, the largest and least degraded lowland rain forest in Sri Lanka, is recognized as a National Heritage Wilderness Area, an International Man and the Biosphere Reserve, a World Heritage Site, and a hot spot of biodiversity. It has acquired that status because of its biogeographic value and high species endemism. Over the years it has changed from being a wilderness associated with traditional mysticism to supporting a regime of exploitation and then to a conservation area. Research at Sinharaja began with tree enumerations to estimate its timber potential, but has been systematically expanded over the years into an interdisciplinary research programme, particularly since the forest acquired its protected status in the late 1970s. The research includes studies on the phytosociology of the tree flora, restoration and regeneration ecology, soil biology and nutrient cycling, reproductive biology and genetic diversity of underutilized species, ecology of birds and small mammals, long-term forest dynamics, rural sociology, and resource economics. Sinharaja was one of the 10 programme sites for the Tropical Soil Biology and Fertility Programme of UNESCO/IUBS, and continues to be included in the Long-term Forest Dynamics Programme launched by the Centre for Tropical Forest Science of the Smithsonian Institution. Research information generated so far has not only enhanced the conservation value of this forest but has also contributed to its management for multiple uses. Sinharaja serves as an outdoor laboratory at all levels of education, especially the secondary and tertiary levels. It is also the most popular lowland rain forest in the country for ecotourism.

bibl.et: Pregermination treatments of bagalunga seeds (Melia dubia Cav.).
bibl.aa: Ecosystems Research and Development Sector, Department of Environment and Natural Resources, Region 8, Tacloban City, Philippines.

ab.p: Pregermination treatments to hasten seed germination of Melia dubia seeds evaluated. These were oven drying at 50°C at varying time intervals, hot water treatment, soaking in tap water, cracking of fruits and/or extraction of seeds or complete removal of endocarp. Soaking fruits at varying lengths of time, oven drying or hot water treatment did not significantly increase seed germination compared with the control. Extracted seeds gave the highest germination which was comparable to that of cracked fruits. Seedling emergence took place over a shorter period with these 2 treatments compared with the other treatments.

bibl.do: The ecological history of European forests: based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996.
bibl.et: Savanna in Europe.
bibl.ct: The ecological history of European forests: based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996.
bibl.aa: Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, UK.

ab.p: This chapter is an introduction to the occurrence, history, functioning and conservation of those European tree-lands in which the trees are scattered among non-tree vegetation. Contrary to common belief, these are real ecosystems intermediate between forest and grassland; they result from various combinations of natural factors and human uses of land; they were more abundant in the past than today; and they are not sharply distinct from the savannas of other continents. They are of special importance since they contain most of the ancient trees (other than coppice stools) in Europe.

bibl.do: The ecological history of European forests: based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996.
bibl.et: Development and dynamics of agricultural parks in West Africa.
bibl.ct: The ecological history of European forests: based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996.
bibl.aa: Special Research Programme 268, Botanisches Institut, Geobotanik und Pflanzenökologie, Siesmayerstr. 70, 60323 Frankfurt/Main, Germany.

ab.p: Agricultural parks are traditional agroforestry systems which are very common in West Africa. They are mainly composed of multipurpose trees and they are undoubtedly an anthropogenic creation. Selection, promotion and introduction of tree species lead to different types of agricultural parks. These parks are strongly related to changes in population density. Based on interdisciplinary historical studies in the West African savanna a model of the development of agricultural parks for the last 100 to 200 years has been established. This is a further step towards an improved understanding of the complex historical processes in the savanna landscape.

bibl.do: The ecological history of European forests: based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996.
bibl.et: Pollard meadows: Multiple use of human-made nature.
bibl.ct: The ecological history of European forests: based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996.
bibl.aa: Department of Ecology and Systematics, University of Helsinki, PO Box 7, FIN-00014 Helsinki, Finland.

ab.p: In many parts of Europe park-like, man-made wooded meadows occur with a vegetation that comprises patches of open meadow alternating with copses of deciduous trees and shrubs, thus forming a mosaic complex. Two kinds of wooded meadows can be discerned, namely coppice meadows, the trees of which have multiple stems growing from a common stool, and pollard meadows, the trees of which are cut at some height above the ground. The main product of coppice meadows is hay. The trees are cut with an interval of often some decades, producing stakes, poles, firewood and wood for carpentry, at which time also loppings (leafy twigs for fodder) are collected. The main products of pollard meadows are hay and loppings. Hazel nuts, crab apples and other fruits, as well as wooden products are also gathered. Both types of wooded meadows are frequently used for grazing during a short period of the year. Pollard meadows can be found in several parts of Europe; along the shores of the Baltic Sea (e.g. SW Finland, S Sweden) as well as in the mountains of western Norway, Spain and northern Italy. Today, all of the very few Finnish, and the bulk of the more numerous Swedish pollard meadows, are located in nature reserves and managed more as outdoor museums than as genuine pollard meadows. However, in the mountains of Europe pollard meadows are still used by peasants for hay and loppings.

bibl.et: The production of fodder trees in Valdagno, Vicenza, Italy.
bibl.ct: The ecological history of European forests: based on presentations given at the International conference on advances in forest and woodland history, held at the University of Nottingham in September 1996.
bibl.aa: Università Degli Studi, Istituto di Selvicoltura, Via S.Bonaventura 13, 50145 Firenze, Italy.

ab.p: This case-study focuses on a small livestock farm in northeastern Italy and uses topographic and dendrometrical surveys, interviews with peasants, and quantitative modelling of past cultivation systems and their productivity. From the 1920s until 1992, one-third of the fodder supply derived from trees. The results highlight the conflicting needs of timber production and livestock raising. In this sense fodder trees could serve as an important element of conserving the cultural significance of the forests in the region, and contribute to species diversity and richness.

bibl.do: Journal of East African Natural History
bibl.et: Forest regeneration in the Tana River Primate National Reserve, Kenya.
bibl.aa: Department of Geography, Miami University, Oxford, OH 45056, USA.

ab.p: This paper examines forest regeneration in the Tana River Primate National Reserve, using data on the size-class abundances and site conditions of major canopy tree species. Forests vary from those dominated by Pachystela msolo to mixed forests of greater species richness with Sorindeia madagascariensis and Diospyros mespiliformis or with Garcinia livingstonei and Mimusops obtusifolia. The low occurrence of saplings and narrow range of soil conditions supporting mature individuals project a relative decline for P. msolo in the study area. Size-class associations between six major canopy trees show a successional tendency toward greater species diversity but a decline in the regeneration of primate resources. Significant differences in the environmental conditions of Ficus sycomorus, P. msolo and S. madagascariensis document possible causal changes in the physical environment. The effects of riverine changes on the regeneration of primate habitat and its persistence potentially jeopardises long-term conservation in this small reserve.

bibl.et: Pinus pumila (Siberian dwarf pine) on the Kamchatka Peninsula, Northeast Asia.
bibl.aa: Kamtchatka Institute of Ecology, Russian Academy of Sciences, Petropavlovsk-Kamtchatsky, 683024, Russia.

ab.p: A description is presented of the ecological features and reproductive characteristics of Pinus pumila in typical habitats on the Kamchatka Peninsula, Russia. A study was conducted to investigate seed production variability and distribution within this area during 1990 at the Bolgit field station, Kamchatka. Permanent plots on an existing transect were selected for cone crop measurement and data collection (position in the landscape, ground cover of P. pumila, plant community type, condition of water supply, average seasonal height of skeleton branches and shading). The number of immature female buds and mature cones on each germinating shoot and branch were recorded in addition to the number of cones damaged by insects (Cecidomyia pumila and Eupithecia adietaria) and by birds. Cones and seeds were collected and mass of cones, seed and nuclei, number of seed scales/cone and total seed quantity/cone measured. Samples for geographic and macro-ecological comparison were collected during 1990-93 at other locations on the peninsula. It is concluded that P. pumila exhibits such a high potential of seed production in time and space that abiotic and biotic impacts act on it in terms of modification only, not regulation. Environmental factors such as sudden mid-summer frosts, insect population outbreaks etc considerable lowered crop size but did not cause a crisis in crop size as the plants had compensating mechanisms such as the formation of annual seed production microhabitat mosaics or an increase in seed number. Seed production was not significantly dependent on altitude or general site condition. However, this was only true when the plants were not shaded by neighbouring trees. When P. pumila grew as the lower canopy of relatively dense Larix forests, the Larix shaded the dwarf pine due to its faster growth and under these conditions P. pumila did not produce seeds but reproduced vegetatively via adventitious roots during its whole life. It is suggested that P. pumila is an alpine plant because photosynthetic ability, seed-producing potential, seed protection and shoot production all increase with altitude. It is concluded that P. pumila's seed production potential exceeds the possibilities of its realization in this region.

ab.p: A review is presented of the morphology, reproduction, geographical distribution, ecological dynamics, fossil record, classification and taxonomic relationships, economic value and conservation status of Sequoia sempervirens on the Pacific Coast, USA. Future research proposals are discussed.

bibl.et: Distribution and ecology of low freshwater coastal forests of the Yucatán Peninsula, Mexico.
bibl.aa: Centro de Investigación Científica de Yucatán, A.C. Cordemex, C.P. 97310 Mérida, Yucatán, México.

ab.p: A review of the geographical distribution and ecology of the low-stature freshwater coastal forests of the Mexican part of the Yucatán Peninsula is presented. A study was conducted in the Sian Ka'an Biosphere Reserve in Quintana Roo, Mexico, for 6 years in 5 communities (4 inundated forests and a palm swamp) dominated by different species (Dalbergia glabra, Bucida spinosa, B. buceras, Haematoxylon campechianum and Acoelorrhaphe wrightii, respectively). The forests primarily occur on marl or gley soils which were low in nutrient availability and had poor drainage. The hydroperiods and water depths varied between communities depending on elevation and soil depth. In each community, 4 plots (200 m²) were sampled for botanical composition and structure. Distribution of species by life from is tabulated and it was observed that the number of tree, orchid and bromeliad species from tasistal to pucteal occurs along a gradient of decreasing hydroperiod, from the tasistal and mucal communities (longest inundation) to the bucidal (intermediate) to the tintal and pucteal communities (shortest inundation). The number of tree species present was low when compared to other tropical forests. The ecological characteristics of dominant tree species (as above plus Erythroxylum confusum, Malpighia lundelli and Cameraria latifolia) are presented in tabular form.

bibl.et: Taxodium-Nyssa (Cypress-Tupelo) forests along the coast of the Southern United States.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Northeasten Forest Experiment Station, Radnor, PA 19087, USA.

ab.p: A study was conducted on the current extent and character of Taxodium-Nyssa forests along the coast of the southern USA from Delaware to Galveston Bay, the inland boundary being set at 250 km from the Atlantic and Gulf coastlines. The study site covered part or all of 6 physiographic sections of the Atlantic Plain Province which itself contains all or part of 11 states, and source data was used from successive large-scale forest inventories conducted by the USDA Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) project, which utilised both aerial photo samples and sample locations visited on the ground (1984 onwards). The basal area of dominant and codominant stems within the dominant size class (2.5-10.0 cm, 10.0-25.0 cm or >25 cm dbh) of stems for each sample location was used to classify the lowland forest associations. Geographic distribution and species composition were analysed by using total tree dry weight (estimated using regression equations). Taxodium was observed throughout the study area, was not limited to a particular range of soil pH, was common in the permanent swamps of the region and was concentrated in the Mississippi Alluvial, Floridian and Sea Island sections. T. distichum occurred in the floodplains of large rivers, while T. distichum var nutans was common on upland swamps. N. aquatica typically thrived in alluvial soils common in low, wet flats or sloughs and in deep swamps. It was noticeably absent from the Floridian section. It is estimated that Taxodium-Nyssa forests total 1.6 million ha or 13% of lowland forest in the USA, the coastal study region containing 33.1 million ha or 41% of the southern lowland forest. The most common associates include Fraxinus spp., N. sylvatica var biflora, Acer rubrum and quercus laurifolia. It is concluded that decreases in the area of Taxodium-Nyssa forests have slowed, but that the lack of natural regeneration in permanently flooded swamps will continue to forestall the replacement of existing stands following harvest or natural disturbance.

ab.p: The impacts of hurricanes (high winds, tidal storm surges, torrential rain etc) on the freshwater forested wetlands and upland coastal forests of the southeastern USA are detailed, highlighting hurricanes Hugo (South Carolina 1989) and Andrew (Florida 1992).

bibl.et: The effect of sea level rise on coastal wetland forests: the Mississippi Delta, USA, as a model.

ab.p: The Mississippi River Delta area of Louisiana, USA, is used as a model for the effects of sea level rise (this area has been experiencing a relative rise of about 1 m per century caused by regional subsidence) on coastal wetland forests in relation to the potential impacts of eustatic sea level rise on coastal wetland forests in other areas. The causes of wetland loss are detailed (geological, catastrophic, human and biological factors) and the effects of waterlogging and salinity on forested wetland communities reviewed. The ecology of wetland forests and the impact of rising water levels is highlighted in relation to hydrology, vertical accretion, botanical composition and structure, vegetation productivity, nutrient cycling and decomposition. It is suggested that forest management should aim for the maintenance of vertical accretion at a rate approximately equal to that of the water level rise by enhancing suspended sediment input into forested wetlands, and that freshwater inputs (via river diversion), may help to lessen the effects of saltwater intrusion.

bibl.et: Coastal forest management and research.
bibl.aa: School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06511 USA.

ab.p: A summary of the major threats to coastally restricted forests and their attendent management strategies is presented with reference to proposals for future research. Information is drawn from previous chapters in the book and highlights the ecology of forest fires, the maintenance of a diverse gene pool, restoration and protection, biological diversity, ecological strategies of wetland trees, niche breadth and the Taxodium-Nyssa forest ecosystem. Correlations between the properties of coastally restricted species and their environment are summarized and tabulated. It is concluded that the most significant differentiating characteristics may be found at the community level.

bibl.et: Testing tree seeds for vigor: a review.

ab.p: This review suggests that precise evaluations of seed vigour tests and their application to seeds of woody plants is not yet possible. This is due to the wide genetic variation, primarily manifested in variable maturity and dormancy, that exists in most tree seed lots. Sensitive measurements of germination rate during standard germination tests have proved to be as good, if not better, than vigour tests in judging the quality of seed lots. Accelerated aging, leachate conductivity, and germination rate all show promise, but extensive tests of field emergence are needed to validate the laboratory test procedures and interpretation.

bibl.et: Drought tolerance, xylem sap abscisic acid and stomatal conductance during soil drying: a comparison of young plants of four temperate deciduous angiosperms.
bibl.aa: School of Natural Resources, 1-31 Agriculture Building, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO 65211, USA.

ab.p: Patterns of water relations, xylem sap abscisic acid (ABA) concentration ([ABA]) and stomatal aperture were compared in greenhouse experiments with drought-sensitive black walnut (Juglans nigra) and black willow (Salix nigra), less drought-sensitive sugar maple (Acer saccharum) and drought-tolerant white oak (Quercus alba). Strong correlations among reduction in predawn water potential, increase in xylem sap [ABA] and stomatal closure were observed in all species. Stomatal response was more highly correlated with xylem [ABA] than with ABA flux. Xylem sap pH and ion concentrations appeared not to play a major role in the stomatal response of these species. Stomata were more sensitive to relative changes in [ABA] in drought-sensitive black walnut and black willow than in sugar maple and white oak. In the early stages of drought, increased [ABA] in the xylem sap of black walnut and black willow was probably of root origin and provided a signal to the shoot of the water status of the roots. In sugar maple and white oak, leaf water potential declined with the onset of stomatal closure, so that stomatal closure also may have occurred in response to the change in leaf water potential.

The ecological and economic implications of reintroducing large-scale elm plantings are discussed.

bibl.et: Photosynthetic characteristics in mulberry during water stress and rewatering.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, Sri Krishnadevaraya University, Anantapur - 515 003, India.

ab.p: Three-month-old pot-grown mulberry plants (Morus alba cv. Kanva-2) were subjected to a drought stress by withholding water supply. As the leaf water potential (ψW) was dropping progressively with the severity of treatment and increasing stress duration, the values of leaf area, dry mass accumulation, total chlorophyll (Chl) content, net photosynthetic rate (PN), stomatal conductance (gs), and transpiration rate (E) were declined. The photosystem 2 (PS2) photochemical efficiency significantly decreased only at a severe stress treatment. The intercellular CO2 concentration (Ci) remained unaltered during a mild stress, yet it increased under moderate and severe stresses. The Ci/gs ratio reflected the mesophyll efficiency during water stress. Rewatering of the plants led to an almost complete recovery of PN, E, and gs, indicating that a short-term stress brings about reversible effects only.

bibl.et: Dynamics of spruce regeneration in pine plantations.
bibl.aa: Institut Lesovedeniya RAN, Uspenskoe, Moscow obl. Russia.

ab.p: An analysis was made of Picea abies regeneration observed in a plantation of Pinus sylvestris aged 52 years, on soddy podzolic clay-loam soils, and also in several mixed Pinus sylvestris/Picea abies plantations. In the pine plantation the first spruce regeneration appeared at about canopy closure (6-12 years), and subsequent generations of spruce regeneration appeared at intervals of ca. 20 years. In mixed plantations with 1 row of pine alternating with 1 or more rows of spruce, spruce natural regeneration did not appear until the plantations were ca. 70 years old.

bibl.et: Treatment of barrel wood infected with acetic acid bacteria.
bibl.aa: Department of Fruit Science, South-west Missouri State University, Research Campus, Mountain Grove, MO 65711.

ab.p: Four barrel sanitizing treatments were compared for their effectiveness on wood infected with acetic acid bacteria. These treatments included hot water and solutions of chlorine, sulfur dioxide, and potassium carbonate. Pieces of stave wood ("mini-staves") in sterile flasks of wine plugged with cotton were used instead of barrels of wine. An initial experiment looked at all four treatments and a control (water rinse) using mini-staves that had two sides sealed with a wet surface liner (the sides that would normally be the stave ends). The mini-staves were contaminated with a strain of Acetobacter aceti. Only the hot water treatment (85°C to 88°C water for 20 minutes) was successful in eliminating the bacteria. A second experiment studied the hot water and control treatments using mini-staves without sealed sides. These were contaminated with either a strain of A. ceti or A. pasteurianus. The hot water treatment was successful in eliminating both strains of bacteria.

bibl.et: Effect of NaCl salinity on growth and mineral partitioning in Quercus robur L., a rhythmically growing species.
bibl.aa: Laboratoire de Biologie Forestière associé INRA, Equipe d'Ecophysiologie Cellulaire, Université Henri Poincaré, BP 239, 54506 Vandoeuvre-lès-Nancy Cedex, France.

ab.p: The sodium salt sensitivity of common oak (Quercus robur) was evaluated in hydroponic culture with 2-week-old seedlings and using INRA-Morizet nutrient solution. The addition of 20 or 40 m&smallcap;M NaCl to the nutrient solution reduced only the length and weight of roots and first flush stems, the second flush being fully expanded even in the presence of 40 m&smallcap;M NaCl. Both leaf number and leaf area were unaffected by increasing NaCl concentration, while this increase induced significant leaf damage, especially in first flush leaves. Stem starch storage was reduced at 40 m&smallcap;M NaCl. Q. robur seedlings were observed to compartmentalize sodium easier than chloride when the NaCl concentration increased, while chloride exhibited a lower uptake rate compared to sodium. Sodium was preferentially accumulated in the roots and this accumulation occurred at the expense of potassium uptake. It is suggested that a decrease in leaf ATP content observed in seedlings submitted to NaCl treatments may indicate sodium exclusion from the leaves, especially in the second flush. The relationships between growth response, starch storage and mineral distribution in Q. robur seedlings are discussed.

bibl.et: The DFRC method for lignin analysis. Part 3. NMR studies.
bibl.aa: U.S. Dairy Forage Research Center, U.S.D.A.-Agricultural Research Service, and Department of Forestry, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, U.S.A.

ab.p: Two key reactions in the DFRC method [derivatization followed by reductive cleavage] were examined by NMR. Both acetyl bromide (AcBr) derivatization of lignin and Zn reductive elimination of the β-bromo derivatives from lignin were highly selective and essentially quantitative. Treatment with AcBr in acetic acid efficiently converted β-aryl ether substructures of lignins into β-bromo ethers while γ-hydroxy and phenol groups were acetylated; the following Zn step cleaved brominated β-aryl ethers forming the expected cinnamyl acetates. In view of the high selectivity of AcBr reactions with lignin units and the solubilization of lignocellulosic materials, AcBr derivatization of lignins can be used for NMR characterization of whole lignins.

bibl.et: Characterization and applications of oils extracted from Canerium schweinfurttii, Vitex doniana and Xylopia aethiopica fruits/seeds.
bibl.aa: Department of Science and Technology, Nnamdi Azikiwe University, P.M.B.5025, Awka, Nigeria.

ab.p: Preparation of oils from Canerium schweinfurttii [Canarium schweinfurthii] , Vitex doniana and Xylopia aethiopica was carried out by petroleum ether (60-80) extraction. The percentage oil yields from the dried seeds were 45.3±1.2, 29.6±1.2 and 11.5±2.5, respectively. The percentage oil from the dried pulps of Canarium schweinfurthii and Vitex doniana were 38.0±5.0 and 0.5±0.2, respectively. With respect to their physico-chemical properties, the seed oils of Canarium and Xylopia were semi-drying, had relatively high saponification values and were used for making alkyd resins which could be used for making paints. The oil from Vitex doniana seed had high iodine and low saponification values and was used for skin cream, resin and paint production. The oil from Canarium pulp had low iodine and saponification values and was used for the production of polish and solid soap. Proximate analysis of the pulps of Canerium and Vitex doniana showed that the percentage moisture contents were 21.3±3.0% and 44.0±5.0%, with ash 2.5±0.4 and 3.10±0.5, protein 3.04±0.5 and 3.7±0.5%, fibre 2.5±1.0 and 6.0±0.7%, vitamin C 294 mg/100 g and 1000 mg/100 g, while carbohydrate contents were 35.31±0.5 and 46.68%, respectively. Both fruits had good contents of vitamin C and could serve as important vitamin sources.

bibl.et: Prediction of the buckling stress of intermediate wooden columns using the secant modulus.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Science and Engineering, Shimane University, Nishikawazu-cho 1060, Matsue, Shimane 690, Japan.

ab.p: Several buckling tests were conducted on wooden columns with intermediate slenderness ratios (λ) and examined the empirical formulae. On the basis of the examination, an equation was formulated for predicting the buckling stress (σ) of an intermediate wooden column. Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) and buna (Japanese beech, Fagus crenata) were used for the studies. A compressive load was applied to the specimen supported with pin ends, and the buckling stress was predicted by the tangent modulus theory and two empirical equations: those of Tetmajer and Newlin-Gahagan. The predicted σ-λ relations were compared with the test results, and the applicability of these predictions were examined. Based on the comparisons, an equation was formulated that can predict the σ-λ relations of materials with various stress-strain characters in the plastic strain range.

bibl.et: Blackening of sugi (Cryptomeria japonica) heartwood in relation to metal content and moisture content.
bibl.aa: Department of Environmental and Natural Resource Science, Faculty of Agriculture, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, 183-8509, Japan.

ab.p: Blackening in heartwood was investigated in relation to the metal content and the moisture content in xylem of 50-year-old sugi (Cryptomeria japonica) seedlings planted in a steeply sloped stand in Okutama district (Itsukaichi Tokyo), where blackened heartwood is frequently found. The potassium, calcium, iron, and manganese contents were examined in the variously blackened heartwood and normal heartwood by an atomic absorption method. It was recognized that potassium increased relative to the degree of the blackening of heartwood, resulting in a significant correlation between them. This finding implies that an increase in potassium has an important role in the blackening of heartwood. Moisture content has a tendency to increase in the blackened heartwood so it seems that the large accumulation of potassium is associated with the high moisture content in heartwood.

bibl.et: Leaf growth pattern in co-existing evergreen and deciduous species of Kumaon Himalaya.
bibl.aa: G.B.P.I.H.E.D., Himachal Unit, Kullu Shamshi, 175 126, India.

ab.p: Leaf growth patterns were studied in 3 pairs of evergreen and deciduous species (Quercus floribunda and Fraxinus micrantha, Litsea umbrosa and Populus ciliata, and Sarcococca hookeriana and Rhamnus virgata, respectively), occurring at an elevation of 2025-2150 m in the Kumaon Himalaya, India. One hundred emerging shoots in each of the 10 individual trees per species distributed evenly in the tree crown were tagged prior to budbreak (i.e. 1000/species). From this tagged population, 100 leaves were collected at monthly intervals and their length and width measured. Leaf initiation occurred earlier in evergreen species with the exception of L. umbrosa. Peak leaf pool size was attained early in deciduous species (June to early July), and later (October) in evergreen species. The rate of leaf expansion was highest in deciduous species. Specific leaf mass in the initial period and root length/leaf area-unit was higher in evergreen species than in deciduous species, while leaf area was higher in deciduous species compared to evergreen species. It is suggested that deciduous species grew so as to utilize the maximum favourable period to achieve annual growth, while the evergreen trees, with low photosynthetic rate, had a greater root:shoot ratio resulted in them being able to take each possible advantage over a long period of time, despite occupying the same microsite.

bibl.et: Floristic study on Vetal hill and its adjacent hills in greater Pune area.
bibl.aa: Division of Plant Sciences, Agharkar Research Institute, Pune 411 004, India.

ab.p: Vetal hill is located to the west of the Pune Municipal Corporation, covering an area of about 10.5 km². It consists of slopes and low-lying hillocks, with diverse vegetation of both the lower and higher plant groups. During last two decades, part of this area has been converted into a recreation centre by the Forest Department, Government of Maharashtra, with afforestation programmes being undertaken. The natural vegetation has a dry deciduous nature, without tall trees and with medium-sized trees and shrubs constituting the chief woody components of the forest. In floristic studies conducted since 1986, 416 species in 316 genera and 101 families have been reported, which are listed in this paper by family.

bibl.et: Measurements of branch area and adjusting leaf area index indirect measurements.
bibl.aa: Department of Soil Science, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 1525 Observatory Drive, Madison, WI 53706, USA.

ab.p: Estimates of leaf area index obtained with indirect measurement techniques are frequently questioned due to light interception by woody elements and a non-random distribution of foliage elements. Usually, branches are assumed to be positioned randomly with respect to leaves or shoots in the canopy. However, in this study of boreal forest architecture, branches are shown to be preferentially shaded by other non-woody elements (e.g. shoots or leaves) in both coniferous and deciduous species of the boreal region. A new instrument called a Multiband Vegetation Imager (MVI) was used to capture two-band (Visible, 400-620 nm and Near-Infrared, 720-950 nm) image pairs of contrasting Canadian boreal forest canopies at 4 sites in 2 study regions during the Boreal Ecosystem-Atmosphere Study (BOREAS). In the BOREAS northern study area near Thompson, Manitoba, image pairs were captured at an old Populus tremuloides site in May 1994 before leaf emergence and July 1994 after leaf emergence, and at an old Pinus banksiana field site in July 1994. In the southern BOREAS study area near Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, image pairs were taken at an old P. tremuloides site in July 1995 and July 1996 and at an old Picea mariana site in July 1996. The spatial relationship of branches and photosynthetically active foliage was studied to estimate the fraction of the effective branch hemi-surface area index (Bc) that is masked by leaves and shoots. It is suggested that an approach which corrects indirect LAI measurements by using the LAI-2000 will correct for the following biases: the effective canopy branch hemi-surface area that is not masked by leaves or shoots in the canopy, the amount of stem hemi-surface area beneath crowns, leaf (or shoot) and branch non-random spatial distributions in the canopy, and the fraction of maximum LAI resulting from defoliation in the canopy. In boreal aspen, MVI image analysis indicated that 95% of the effective branch hemi-surface area was masked by other foliage in the canopy, while in P. banksiana and P. mariana forests 80-90% of the effective branch hemi-surface area was masked by other foliage in the canopy. These estimates suggest that the fraction of indirect LAI that consists of branches intercepting light may be less than 10%. Therefore, it is concluded that branches generally do not intercept a significant amount of beam radiation in boreal forests, and do not significantly bias indirect LAI measurements. However, stems, which comprise 30-50% of the total woody area in this study, may not be preferentially shaded by leafy foliage. Therefore, stem contribution to indirect LAI estimates measured with the LAI-2000 or a similar instrument cannot be overlooked. MVI estimates of the total branch hemi-surface area index agree to within 10-40% of direct measurements made in similar species; however, it is suggested that the error between indirect and direct measurements may be due largely to difficulties associated with obtaining adequate sampling so that the error may fall within the noise level of measurements.

bibl.et: Predicting the short-term properties of chipboard using composite theory.
bibl.aa: Building Research Establishment, Garston, Watford WD2 7JR, UK.

ab.p: The applicability of models for describing the short-term properties of chipboard [particleboard] were investigated using the results from experiments conducted on samples of a laboratory-made board (comprised of Scots pine, Pinus sylvestris, chips and urea formaldehyde resin), and sections of urea formaldehyde and Scots pine strips. The "rule of mixtures" equations, modified for short fibre composites, were employed to predict the strength and stiffness of the particleboard. They were found to provide a good estimate of both the particleboard strength and modulus of elasticity, with the assumptions being made that the chips were aligned parallel to the direction of applied stress and that the chips could be treated as having cylindrical geometry. The results of this investigation revealed that particleboard is a highly unusual material; compared with conventional fibre-reinforced composites, it has a very high volume fraction of fibres, and the similar moduli of elasticity of the fibres and matrix can result in the concentration of stress in the matrix rather than in the fibres. However, these factors did not prevent the assessment and development of appropriate short fibre composite models to predict the strength and stiffness of particleboard.

index.de: composite boards\materials\models\particleboards\properties\strength\theory

bibl.et: Liquid penetration of precompressed wood VI: Anatomical characterization of pit fractures.
bibl.aa: Laboratory of Property Enhancement, Division of Wood Biomass Science, Wood Research Institute, Kyoto University, Uji 611-0011, Japan.

ab.p: Pit fractures of refractory coniferous heartwoods caused by precompression in the radial direction were investigated and are discussed in terms of improved liquid penetration. Small cracks appeared at the boundary between the torus and margo, along the outer margin of the margo, and on the torus when specimens were compressed and deformation was fixed by drying. The most remarkable cracks were generally observed for Cryptomeria japonica. Pseudotsuga menziesii showed peculiar detachment of the torus from the pit border, and Larix leptolepis exhibited only small cracks on the torus. These fracture patterns were clearer when the precompressed specimens were recovered by water impregnation and then redried.

bibl.et: On the cell wall fine structure of 1600 year-old, water-saturated oak wood.
bibl.ft: Zur zellwandstruktur von 1600 jahre altem, wassergesättigtem eichenholz.
bibl.aa: Bundesforschungsanstalt für Forst- und Holzwirtschaft, Institut für Holzbiologie und Holzschutz, Leuschnerstr. 91, D-21031 Hamburg.

ab.p: Water-saturated oak wood from the "Mayence Roman ships" (4th century A.D.) was investigated by transmission electron microscopy. The studies on the cell wall fine structure revealed that in most cells the middle lamella and the innermost secondary wall layer (S3) remained structurally unaltered. On the other hand, the secondary wall layers S1 and S2 became heavily degraded. The characteristic degradation pattern indicates the involvement of bacteria.

bibl.et: Resource congruence and forest regeneration following an experimental hurricane blowdown.
bibl.aa: Department of Organismic and Evolutionary Biology, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02138, USA.

ab.p: Catastrophic uprooting of forest canopy trees creates mounds, pits, and other microsites that provide opportunities for regeneration of particular species. Environmental factors were measured on five types of microsites created by simulated blowdown of a mixed deciduous forest in central Massachusetts, USA. Spatial variation in resource levels was determined, and congruence among different resources at each site was quantified. Effects of simulated blowdown on light levels and CO2 concentrations were more pronounced after three years than effects on nitrogen availability and other soil resources. Spatial heterogeneity in light levels and net nitrification rates was greater in the blowdown, but heterogeneities of soil organic matter concentration and net mineralization rates were greater in the undisturbed forest. Availability of nitrate, a limiting resource in most New England forests, was low on mounds and in pits, but high on the vertical portion of forest floor resulting from uprooting of canopy trees. At a spatial scale relevant to seedlings, resource congruence was greater in the undisturbed forest than in the experimental blowdown, primarily because of the effects of blowdown on light levels. Congruence in the blowdown increased with an increase in spatial scale, but congruence in the undisturbed forest was similar at both spatial scales. Seedling growth of two birch species (Betula papyrifera and B. alleghaniensis) was correlated with light levels and with congruence among soil resources. It is concluded that immediate disturbance effects on microtopography and light levels determine recruitment patterns of colonizing species, with changes in soil resource levels influencing later community development. Furthermore, some species appear to respond to resource congruence, which may provide an additional dimension to the regeneration niche.

bibl.et: Characteristics of life cycle assessment for pulp and paper industry.
bibl.aa: Pulp and Paper Research Centre, University of Quebec in Trois-Rivières, PO Box 500, Trois-Rivières Quebec, Canada G9A 5H7.

ab.p: Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) is becoming a useful tool for environment management. This paper describes the unique qualities of the forest products industry within the boundary of a product system. The forest products industry, unlike many others, is based on a raw material that is renewable and sustainable. This industry is also characterized by a biological transformation or fixation of carbon dioxide in trees. The forest products life cycle inventory also includes the recyclability and feedstock energy of wood and paper products inputs, intermediate processes of wood feedstock and methane emission from landfilled wood and paper products.

bibl.et: Biogenic emissions by oak trees common to Mediterranean ecosystems.
bibl.aa: Laboratoire Chimie Energie- Environnement, Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Chimie de Toulouse 118, route de Narbonne, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 4, France.

ab.p: Significant amounts of volatile organic compounds of anthropogenic and/or biogenic origin are regularly released into the atmosphere and play an important role as precursors to photochemical air pollution. Biogenic emissions were measured by enclosing an intact branch in a Teflon cuvet. The principal species studied were Quercus ilex and Quercus pubescens in an experimental site in a Mediterranean type forest located in Viols-en-Laval near Montpellier, France. The evolution of global terpene emissions were recorded in June 1995. The evolution of terpene emission rates versus light (PAR), internal temperature within the cuvet, CO2 exchange and transpiration (H2O) were determined. The only terpene emitted by Quercus pubescens was isoprene; it was strongly correlated with light intensity, photosynthetic activity and transpiration. Quercus ilex was a strong monoterpene emitter; most emissions took place during the diurnal period and were closely correlated with light-triggered physiological activities. There was no simple correlation between leaf temperature and terpene emission. The temperature of the leaves did not appear to play a significant role in the regulation of the monoterpene emission. It is concluded that light, with its effect on assimilation and stomatal behaviour, is the most important factor for monoterpene emission by Quercus ilex and isoprene emission for Quercus pubescens.

bibl.do: Proceedings of the NATO Advanced Workshop on science and technology to save and better utilize Central and Eastern Europe's forests, Saulberg, Lower Bavaria, Germany, July 15-19, 1996.
bibl.et: Environmental factors and state of Ukrainian forests: monitoring and impact assessment.
bibl.ct: Proceedings of the NATO Advanced Workshop on science and technology to save and better utilize Central and Eastern Europe's forests, Saulberg, Lower Bavaria, Germany, July 15-19, 1996.
bibl.aa: Ministry of Forestry of Ukraine, Kreshchatik 5, 252005 Kiev, Ukraine.

ab.p: Ukrainian forests, which cover 14.3% of the country, require monitoring for the damage caused by air pollution. About a third of forests are affected by fallout from the Chernobyl incident. The main criteria for the estimation of damage are defoliation and discoloration of forest stands. From 1990-95, mean defoliation increased from 10% to 23%, and the proportion of moderately and severely defoliated trees increased from 4% to 27%. Recent decreases in air pollution concentrations have not been reflected by lower ratings for defoliation or discoloration. This was considered to be due to the cumulative effects of air pollution, but may also be partly explained by pests, fungi or extreme weather conditions. Monitoring has been extended since summer 1995 and information on forest types has been included. Research on the possible effects of climatic change is briefly described.

bibl.et: Sensitivity of mycobacteria to different species of Eucalyptus L'Herit.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Ciências Biológicas, Faculdade de Ciências Farmacêuticas, Universidade do Estado de São Paulo, Araraquara, SP, Brasil.

ab.p: Sensitivity profile of 10 mycobacteria of clinical interest, to extractives from eight different species of Eucalyptus was studied. A Proportion Method Indirect Test was performed to detect resistant bacilli utilizing 5 and 10 mg/ml of essential oils incorporated to Lowestein-Jensen medium. Mycobacterium tuberculosis and other slow growing mycobacteria were more sensitive to essential oils than faster growing ones. The most effective essential oils, in decreasing order, were Eucalyptus citriodora, Eucalyptus maculata and Eucalyptus tereticornis.

bibl.et: Characteristics of the soil and water table in an Alnus japonica (Japanese Alder) swamp.
bibl.aa: Botanic Garden, Faculty of Agriculture, Hokkaido University, Sapporo 060, Japan.

ab.p: A discussion is presented which relates the height and fluctuation of the water table and the physiochemical features of soils as important site factors in the differentiation of Alnus japonica swamp from other communities (e.g. willow forests, reed swamps, grass and swamp communities) in the cool-temperate zone of Japan. Soil surveys were conducted at 33 selected points within 52 stands during 1981-84 in the northern part of Honshu Island. At each site the soil profile was assessed (depth and thickness of horizons, colour, texture, organic matter content, gravel features, compactness, root distribution and 2-2′-dipyridyl reaction) and a small tributary basin (Tashiro) was also selected to study seasonal changes in the water table. Features of the soil and water table are presented for peatland and non-peatland soil types. It is concluded that the supply of available nutrients determines the gradient between A. japonica swamps and other hydrophilus communities under water saturated conditions. In addition the height and fluctuation pattern of the water table were important factors in differentiating between A. japonica swamp stands and more mesic Ulmus or Fraxinus forests.

bibl.et: Flower morphometry of Rhizophora mangle (Rhizophoraceae): geographical variation in Mexican populations.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Ecología Evolutiva, Instituto de Ecología, UNAM, Apartado Postal 70-275, México 04510, D.F. Mexico.

ab.p: Patterns of intra- and interpopulation variation in flower morphology were studied in 12 populations of the red mangrove, Rhizophora mangle from Mexico: five from the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea, and seven from the Pacific Coast. Six floral attributes were measured from a sample of 1370 flowers. Significant differences among populations were found for all six attributes. Because floral attributes were all correlated, scores derived from principal factor analysis were used to describe the variation in flower morphology. Two factors explained essentially all of the variance in flower morphology. Corolla and calyx size had a strong effect on factor 1, while gynoecium size had the higher effect on factor 2. Nested analyses of variance on the scores from both factors revealed significant differences between coasts, among populations within coasts, and among plants within populations. Nonetheless, this variation cannot be explained as a result of clinal variation, as indicated by a series of regression analyses. Cluster analysis (UPGMA) showed that a population from the Pacific coast was clustered together with those of the Atlantic, and the arrangement of populations within each coast showed no evident geographical pattern. It is proposed that frequent events of extinction and recolonization by a few individuals, followed by selfing, may produce differentiation among populations of red mangrove.

bibl.do: AFZ/Der Wald, Allgemeine Forst Zeitschrift fur Waldwirtschaft und Umweltvorsorge
bibl.et: Effects of climatic change on forest growth and the forest protection situation in Bavaria.
bibl.ft: Auswirkungen einer Klimaveränderung auf das Waldwachstum und die Waldschutzsituation in Bayern.
bibl.aa: Bayerische Landesanstalt für Wald and Forstwirtschaft, Freising, Germany.

ab.p: Trends in temperature and precipitation in Germany are reviewed, with reference to the climatic requirements and growth of Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris, Fagus sylvatica and Quercus robur. It appears that the climate is already changing, and that the general recommendation must be to establish, promote and maintain stable mixed stands with great diversity of appropriate tree species and structure, plus great genetic variability. Very dry and wet sites should be left largely to natural succession or be managed extensively. Picea abies is no longer suitable as the main species on fresh sites in areas with average annual precipitation under 700-800 mm, and should be replaced by more appropriate species. There seems to be no need to modify stocking targets for oak, while beech can be cautiously promoted on drier soils and also on moist sites. A temperature increase of up to 2 K should cause no problem for Pinus sylvestris.

bibl.et: Soil-vegetation interrelationships in Isoberlinia woodlands in northwestern Nigeria.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, University of Uya, P.M.B. 1017, Uyo, Nigeria.

ab.p: Isoberlinia woodlands in NW Nigeria were sampled in 280 quadrats (100 m²) regularly spaced along established transects from upper to lower slopes. Vegetation measurements included density, basal area, crown cover and height of woody species ≥3 m high. Also, total number of species and canopy cover per plot, and species diversity were determined. Soil pits were systematically excavated along the transects, and soil samples taken from each horizon in each pedon, air-dried and analysed for physical and chemical properties. Canonical correlation analysis (utilizing principal component scores of soil and vegetation variables) was used to show the interrelationships between soil and vegetation components. Results showed a reciprocal relationship between plant size and silt, manganese and aluminium. There existed a positive relationship between plant height and species diversity, and soil reactions and nutrient status. Aluminium also related positively with plant density and canopy cover. Hence canonical correlation analysis identified soil variables which affected the vegetation components, indicating that soil and vegetation are interdependent.

bibl.et: Application of isodegradation curves in nature conservation.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, Janus Pannonius University, H-7624 Pécs, Hungary.

ab.p: A highly diverse limestone rock and forest vegetation (Remete Gorge, Hungary) was studied by analysing 113 phytosociological sample plots and mapped on a surface of 57 ha. In the study several impact factors (including the effects of tourism and recreation) were identified and mapped. For evaluating their degradational effects on the flora and vegetation the categories of plant sociability and their naturalness (suitability to the environment) were used, which are closely correlated to the C-S-R strategies [see Grime, J. P. Plant Strategies and Vegetation Process Chichester, UK; John Wiley and Sons, 1979, 222 pp.]. The SBTs different naturalness values are given and they express the grade of intactness and/or degradation by using statistical formulas like degradation quotient (DQ). DQ-values projected to the vegetation map enabled the production of an environmental degradation map. The grade of degradation was calculated from the presence/absence data and cover of species. Locating this data on the map enabled places of a similar grade of degradation to be connected by isolines drawn by computer. By analysing isodegradation curves (ISODEGs), human impact was easily recognisable (e.g. in the vicinity of water-purification plant, burn areas, etc.). ISODEGs are more widely spaced in areas where plant communities resist degradation, e.g. in the Querco-Carpinetum, however, when the isodegradation curves enter into areas occupied by less resistant communities such as as Mercuriali-Tilietum and Ceraso-Quercetum pubescentis, they become closer together. Isodegradation curves were considered useful for detecting and comparing stages of degradation and studying its processes and they indicate areas in need of active protection.

bibl.et: General and specific biomarkers in some tertiary fossil woods from Canadian Arctic.
bibl.aa: Istituto per la Ricerca sul Legno (C.N.R.), Firenze, Italy.

ab.p: Four fossil woods, between 55 and 65 million years old, coming from the Canadian Arctic regions were analysed with respect to their dichloromethane extract components. In comparison with the extracts of younger fossils they contained only a limited number of components which belonged, furthermore, to relatively few classes of compounds namely aliphatic hydrocarbons, fatty acids, long chain alcohols and diterpenes. The fossil identified as a Douglas fir [Pseudotsuga menziesii] had only one of the expected compounds owing, perhaps, to the rather low amount of extractives or terpenes in the original wood. Another fossil was tentatively identified as a spruce [Picea sp.], while of the remaining two unidentified fossils one could be attributed to a terpene-rich species (e.g. larch) while the other to a species rich in extractives different from diterpenes. However, much more data, based on samples taken from various locations and with a different composition of extractives are needed in order to determine the influence of a specific environment on aging.

bibl.do: Journal of the Institute of Wood Science
bibl.et: The machining properties of rubberwood laminated veneer lumber (LVL).
bibl.aa: The Buckinghamshire College, London, UK.

ab.p: The power requirements when machining rubberwood (Hevea brasiliensis) LVL and solid rubberwood were evaluated under different machining variables. Power requirements were recorded for all machining situations, and regression equations were developed for estimating power consumption when machining these materials. Generally, power consumption increased with increasing feed speed, chip thickness, and material density. Further, it is evident that rubberwood LVL is four times as abrasive as solid rubberwood, which in turn may hamper its potential use in high-volume furniture production as a replacement for solid rubberwood.
