bibl.et: Potential for using small-diameter ponderosa pine: a wood fiber projection.
bibl.aa: College of Engineering and Technology, Box 15600, Northern Arizona Univ., Flagstaff, AZ 86011-1560, USA.

ab.p: A projection is made here on the quantity of wood fibre that might be available for conversion to value-added products if a large-scale forest restoration plan were initiated. The analysis is limited to the ponderosa pine [Pinus ponderosa] forests of Arizona and the adjacent Gila National Forest in New Mexico. The fibre projections were obtained by comparing small forest plot samples and National Forest surveys against a logical and well-documented forest treatment configuration. The point-in-time analysis suggests that thinning for restoration could generate approximately 1&thin;004 million ft³ of wood fibre derived from extra trees in the 5- to 16-inch diameter at breast height size classes. The estimated cost of harvesting and delivery, however, appears to exceed the value current users may be willing to pay for the resource.

bibl.et: The role of grade and thickness in the degradation of fire-retardant-treated plywood.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Serv., Forest Prod. Lab., One Gifford Pinchot Dr., Madison, WI 53705-2398, USA.

ab.p: In some cases, fire-retardant-treated plywood used since 1980 for roof sheathing has rapidly degraded and failed, apparently because of thermally induced acid hydrolysis. This study sought to determine whether plywood grade or thickness influences the manner in which fire-retardant treatment (FRT) and subsequent high-temperature exposure affects the strength properties of plywood. The effects of FRT were evaluated on two thicknesses and three commercial grades of southern pine plywood as well as plywood constructed from nearly defect-free N-grade veneer. Specimens were treated with monoammonium phosphate (MAP), then subjected to exposure at 66°C (150°F) and 75% relative humidity for either 30, 60, or 90 days. Modulus of rupture (MOR), work to maximum load (WML), and modulus of elasticity (MOE) of the specimens were evaluated. Results suggest that the rate of plywood degrade resulting from FRT, redrying, and subsequent high-temperature exposure is largely independent of plywood quality or grade. Although the initial strength loss caused by FRT and redrying appeared greater for the thinner plywood, degrade during subsequent temperature exposure appeared to be independent of plywood thickness. Thus, it appears that findings from previous studies on thermal degrade using high quality, N-grade plywood are readily applicable to commercial grades and thicknesses. Evaluation of the effects of knots and voids on MOR revealed that these defects are only partially responsible for the difference in bending strength among specimens.

bibl.et: Comparison of growth habits under various light conditions between two climax species, Castanopsis sieboldii and Castanopsis cuspidata, with special reference to their shade tolerance.
bibl.aa: School of Informatics and Sciences, Nagoya University, Nagoya, 464-01 Japan.

ab.p: Two experiments were conducted to examine the difference in shade tolerance between two climax species, Castanopsis sieboldii and Castanopsis cuspidata, in Aichi Prefecture in the warm-temperate climate of Japan. In the growth experiment, the seedlings of the two species were raised under five light conditions, 100%, 30%, 10%, 3% and 1% relative light intensity (RLI). The growth of C. sieboldii greatly exceeded that of C. cuspidata, particularly under higher light conditions. In a heavy shading experiment, the seedlings of the two species were grown under three light conditions (0, 0.15 and 0.3% RLI). While all seedlings of C. sieboldii died within 2 years under 0.15 and 0.3% RLI, about half of the seedlings of C. cuspidata survived more than 2 years under 0.15% RLI, and about 70% survived more than 4 years under 0.3% RLI. It is concluded that C. cuspidata was more shade tolerant than C. sieboldii, and the possibility that C. sieboldii might be more tolerant of drought stress than C. cuspidata is discussed.

bibl.do: The drylands of Africa: local participation in tree management.
bibl.et: The drylands of Africa: local participation in tree management.

ab.p: The book addresses some of the sensible and practical mechanisms by which land users in drylands use, manage and control their natural resources. It attempts to explain what such land users are doing and how the mechanisms used can be, or are being, improved in a manner that could be adapted. The emphasis is on practice and the use of case examples, from in particular the drylands of East and West Africa. The primary focus is on pastoral land-use systems, although the boundary between pastoralism and dryland agriculture is often ambiguous, and is an area of land-use conflict, particularly over areas of richer vegetation; accordingly, examples are taken from both types of system. While the book emphasizes the role of woody vegetation, and trees in particular, many of the lessons are of wider use, for instance, for grazing management and conservation. The concern is not with the silvicultural aspects of trees but how people use them, and what embodying rules and regulations (both customary and statutory) exist for their management. There are 10 chapters: (1) Introduction; (2) Pastoralists: shrewd land managers; (3) Trees in drylands: local knowledge and expertise; (4) Access to, and ownership of trees and natural resources; (5) Arid and semi-arid lands development; (6) Participation and pastoral natural resource management; (7) Women and men: men and women; (8) Implications for research; (9) Monitoring, evaluation and the future sustainability; and (10) Conclusions. A subject index is included.

bibl.et: Ecology and biogeography of Pinus.
bibl.ms: many refs at ends of chapters
bibl.aa: Institute for Plant Conservation, Botany Department, University of Cape Town, Rondebosch 7700, South Africa.

ab.p: This book presents a definitive review of pine ecology and biogeography written by 40 of the world's leading authorities on the genus. In the face of increasing human pressure and global climatic change, it provides an essential reference for all concerned with the management of natural and planted pine forests. The book is arranged in 6 parts, with 21 chapters. Part One, Introduction, contains 1 introductory chapter. Part Two, Evolution, phylogeny and systematics, has 2 chapters. Part Three, Historical biogeography, has 4 chapters on palaeoecology. Part Four, Macroecology and recent biogeography, has 3 chapters. Part Five, Ecological themes, has 9 chapters, covering fire and pine ecosystems, evolution of life histories, genetic variation, seed dispersal, ecophysiology, mycorrhizas, effects of pines on soil, insect-pine interactions, and diseases and ecology. Part Six, Pines and humans, has 3 chapters, covering pines in cultivation (a global view), Pinus radiata and its spread over the world, and pines as invaders in the southern hemisphere. Glossaries of scientific terms and English common names, and indexes to biota/taxa and subjects are included.

bibl.et: Photosynthesis of black spruce, jack pine, and trembling aspen after artificially induced frost during the growing season.
bibl.aa: Centre de recherche en biologie forestière, Pavillon Abitibi-Price, Université Laval, Sainte-Foy, QC G1K 7P4, Canada.

ab.p: Light-saturated photosynthesis following artificial frosts was monitored for black spruce (Picea mariana), jack pine (Pinus banksiana) and trembling aspen (Populus tremuloides) stands near Thompson, Manitoba. In a study with small trees (2-3 m tall), none of the species exposed to -9°C in May or to -6 and -9°C in August, 1994, recovered within the 23- and 14-day monitoring periods, respectively. Black spruce and jack pine treated at -6°C in May recovered within 5 and 23 days, respectively. Black spruce treated at -3°C in August recovered within 10 days. Frosts were applied to the upper and lower canopies of mature black spruce and jack pine in June and to mature trembling aspen in July. For black spruce, the lower canopy did not recover whereas the upper canopy partially recovered over the 10-day monitoring period. For jack pine and trembling aspen, there were no differences in recovery between canopy levels. Jack pine treated at -5.5°C recovered within the 10-day monitoring period whereas at -8.5°C, it only partially recovered. Although recovery period varied with species, phenological state, and frost temperature, gradual recovery of photosynthesis over 5-21 days seems a reasonable modelling algorithm for boreal tree species when growing season frosts lower than -3°C occur. However, cooling rates in our experiments were greater than those that normally occur in nature.

bibl.et: Relationship between field performance, family, embryo morphology, and isozyme heterozygosity, and in vitro reactivity in jack pine.
bibl.aa: Groupe de recherche en écologie forestière, Département des sciences biologiques, Université du Québec à Montréal, C.P. 8888, Succursale Centre-Ville, Montréal, QC H3C 3P8, Canada.

ab.p: The influence of field performance, family, embryo morphology, and isozyme heterozygosity level on in vitro reactivity of Pinus banksiana was evaluated on embryos from five superior families, five inferior families, and a mixed seed lot from Quebec. Embryo length, number of cotyledons, and isozyme heterozygosity were determined for each embryo. Seed germination and fresh weight were determined on a family level. On average, superior families showed higher percentages of embryos that formed buds in vitro. Within each performance class, the analysis based on initial number of embryos revealed differences among families for the percentage of green embryos and embryos with adventitious buds and shoots. When calculations were based on green embryos only, i.e., excluding embryos that remained white, there were no differences among families. Thus, the overall in vitro potential of a family appears to be strongly dependent upon the capacity of embryos to turn green. On a per family basis, seed germination was positively correlated with most in vitro characters, with the exception of mean shoot length per shoot-forming embryo. Small embryos had a lower probability of producing buds and shoots, and embryos with three cotyledons showed a higher mortality than embryos with four or more cotyledons. No significant relationships were observed between heterozygosity level and in vitro reactivity, with analyses performed on green embryos only.

bibl.et: Biomass production in a plantation of Acacia mearnsii De Wild. in the State of Rio Grande do Sul.
bibl.ft: Produção de biomassa em um povoamento de Acacia mearnsii De Wild. no estado do Rio Grande do Sul.
bibl.aa: Dep. de Ciências Florestais/Centro de Ciências Rurais/Universidade Federal de Santa Maria, (055) 220-8444, 97150-900 Santa Maria-RS, Brazil.

ab.p: The biomass was estimated of a 9-yr-old Acacia mearnsii plantation in the town of Butiá, RS, Brazil. Based on inventory data, the diameter distribution of the plantation was analysed and grouped into 10 classes. From each one of the diameter classes obtained, one tree was selected. The selected trees were destructively sampled to determine biomass of the above-ground parts (leaves, dead and live branches, wood and bark), and regression equations derived for estimating biomass from diameter at breast height (DBH). Using these equations, plantation the biomass was estimated as 158.51 t/ha, 12.3% belonging to the canopy (leaves 4.23, live branches 11.28 and dead branches 4.02 t/ha) and 87.7% belonging to the stems (wood 125, and bark 13.98 t/ha).

bibl.et: Development of thinned balsam fir during an epidemic of spruce budworm.
bibl.ft: Développement de sapinières éclaircies exposées à une épidémie de tordeuse des bourgeons de l'épinette.
bibl.aa: Direction de la recherche forestière, Ministère des Ressources naturelles du Québec, 2700, rue Einstein, Sainte-Foy, QC G1P 3W8, Canada.

ab.p: In 1968, three intensities of low thinning were applied in 33-year-old balsam fir (Abies balsamea) stands of eastern Quebec in order to remove 0, 20 and 30% of the total basal area. Sample plots were located in two distinct areas, one of which was annually sprayed with insecticides (aminocarb or fenitrothion) between 1978 and 1982 while the other was never protected against a spruce budworm (Choristoneura fumiferana) outbreak that occurred between 1976 and 1983. A total of 32 sample plots (0.04-ha) were periodically measured between 1968 and 1994. Low thinnings mostly removed non-merchantable trees (diameter at breast height <9.1 cm) and left 5000-7000 trees/ha while stand density of control plots reached 10&thin;000 stems/ha. From 1968 to 1976, net annual increment in merchantable volume was around 8 m³/ha but no differences were detected between thinning levels. During the period of severe defoliation caused by spruce budworm (1976-85), net annual increment in merchantable volume of sample plots sprayed with insecticides decreased by 50% but returned to its initial value after 1985. Net annual increment of sample plots that were never protected against spruce budworm was strongly negative during the outbreak period until all trees were dead. While thinning level only slightly affected merchantable yield of sample plots during the 26-year period, mean annual diameter increment was inversely proportional to stand density. The analysis of the development of stand density as a function of mean volume of trees shows that mortality rate of all sample plots was similar to that given by the self-thinning rule. This suggests that even trees of the most heavily thinned plots suffered from strong intraspecific competition.

bibl.et: Chamaecyparis thyoides (Atlantic white cedar) in the United States.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest service, Southeastern Forest Experiment Station, Asheville, NC 28802, USA.

ab.p: Broad-scale inventory data collected by the U.S. Department of Agriculture Forest Service was utilised to establish baseline totals for the entire Atlantic white cedar (Chamaecyparis thyoides) resource. The data were collected by Forest Inventory and Analysis (FIA) Research Work Units at the northeastern, southeastern and southern Experiment Stations of the USDA and used permanent sample plots systematically distributed across timberland to attain a proportionate sample of all major forest types, sites and ownerships in a region. Each sample plot represented 1000 to 3000 ha and at each sample location FIA used a multi-point cluster plot to assure a representative sample of trees and associated stand conditions. Collectively the cluster points sampled approximately 0.4 ha of timberland. At each point, trees 12.7 cm dbh and larger were selected using a basal area factor of 8.61 m²/ha. Trees between 2.5 and 12.7 cm dbh were tallied on circular fixed area plots that shared common point centres with each variable-radius plot centre. Plots established in prior surveys were relocated and remeasured to determine the elements of change between inventories (mortality and removals), the period between remeasurement varying between 6 and 10 years. Each of the 44&thin;000 FIA sample plots was examined to determine if C. thyoides was present; at least one stem 2.5 cm dbh or larger was a prerequisite for inclusion in the study. C. thyoides was not present in the Maine, New Hampshire or Rhode Island samples. Inventories were conducted between 1980 and 1990 in 3 regions; North Atlantic (Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Jersey and New York), South Atlantic (North Carolina, South Carolina and Virginia) and Gulf (Alabama, Florida and Mississippi). The results considered the extent, distribution and characteristics of C. thyoides highlighting volume characteristics of C. thyoides, species composition of the sample plots (co-existing species etc) and estimates of net annual growth and removal of C. thyoides. It is concluded that whereas C. thyoides occurs across a substantial portion of the eastern US, it has limited stocking in many of the stands in which it occurs. Evidence of the species was found on almost 215&thin;000 ha, but accounted for 50% or more of total tree stock on only 44&thin;000 ha. C. thyoides was a more dominant component of the total stand on sites that have hydric soil conditions, compared to more mesic soils. The merchantable volume across the ecosystem is estimated to be 9.8 million m³. Based on estimates of net annual growth and annual removals, the volume of C. thyoides during the past decade has increased by ~186&thin;000 m³ annually.

bibl.et: Reconstruction of the Mashantucket Pequot Cedar Swamp paleoenvironment using plant macrofossils, new England, USA.
bibl.aa: Yale University Dept. of Anthropology and School and Forestry and Environmental Studies, New Haven, CT 06511, USA.

ab.p: A study was undertaken to determine the late-Quaternary woodland transitions at Pequot Cedar Swamp in Ledyard, Connecticut, using sediment cores to identify plant macrofossils preserved since the last glaciation of the region. The value of these identifications for interpreting the effects of climate change and to trace the prehistoric local vegetation patterns that led to the present Acer rubrum and Chamaecyparis thyoides swamp, was demonstrated. It is concluded that the entrance of Picea spp. and A. balsamea and the early advent of Pinus strobus in southern New England occurred 12&thin;000 years ago. During the Holocene, evidence indicated fluctuating water levels and temperatures. Aggregated, chemically altered sediments and the outward spread of shrubs indicated that periods of drying altered the sediment accumulation only to be followed by periods of a higher water table sufficient to support diverse plant populations. During the second half of the Holocene, the extreme variations in water availability decreased enough to form an acceptable habitat for C. thyoides. Anaerobic preservation left a macrofossil record of a number of constant companions to C. thyoides in that today would be classed as a predominantly A. rubrum swamp.

bibl.et: Plant community structure in Chamaecyparis thyoides swamps in the New Jersey pinelands Biosphere reserve, USA.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Biological Sciences, Arkansas Tech University, Russellville, AR 72801, USA.

ab.p: A study was conducted during 1985 to evaluate the development of plant community structure in cedar swamps in the New Jersey Pinelands and to determine the extent to which environmental parameters, disturbance and fragmentation influence community structure. Eighteen cedar swamp sites were selected within the 400&thin;000 ha Pinelands National Reserve which ranged in time since logging from 60 to 130 years and represented an intermediate-growth stage. Sites were selected according to size (0.5-5 ha, 5-20 ha and >20 ha) and within each size category, 3 swamps were surrounded by Pinus rigida lowland or upland and 3 by hardwood swamps. The effects of fragmentation (reduced swamp size and increased hardwoods) were assessed. Tree diameter measurements and point-to-plant distances obtained with the point-centred quarter method were used to calculate density, dominance (basal area) and frequency values. Relative values were determined and averaged to obtain an importance value for each species. size-class densities of live and dead tree stems were determined from dbh measurements and stem counts within a 5 m² circular plot at each point. Shrub, sapling and seedling densities were also calculated within this area, and forbs present recorded. Stand age was determined by coring C. thyoides trees selected at randomly placed points along the transect within each site. The results are presented in relation to swamp species composition (low tree species diversity and richness), community structure (ranges from pure stands of C. thyoides to a mixture with hardwoods such as A. rubrum, Magnolia virginiana, Nyssa sylvatica and Betula populifolia), stand structure (young-, intermediate-, and old-growth stands), and forest management. It is concluded that the degree of variability in species composition and distribution within the swamps is determined primarily by disturbance history and hydrology, and it is suggested that to stop habitat loss it is important to provide optimal conditions for cedar regeneration (fire occurrence and logging at intervals greater than 75 years, seasonal flooding, moderate water table fluctuation, deer browsing prevention, low A rubrum abundance and minimal shrub cover).

bibl.et: Atlantic white cedar in North Carolina, USA.
bibl.aa: Extension Forestry, College of Forest Resources, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC 27695 USA.

ab.p: Joint research efforts by the US Forest Service, Weyerhaeuser and North Carolina State University to grow Atlantic white cedar (Chamaecyparis thyoides) are described after a brief history of white cedar exploitation in North Carolina is presented. It is concluded that C. thyoides may be successfully established on appropriate sites suitable prepared for planting. Growth and survival were best on sites characterized by deep organic, low pH soils. Rooted cuttings were more reliable and easier to grow than bare rooted seedlings, yet both were observed to have the potential for artificial regeneration. Severe competition and deer browsing must be controlled. to assure successful establishment.

index.up: Chamaecyparis\Cupressaceae\Pinopsida\gymnosperms\Spermatophyta\plants\eukaryotes\North America\America\Developed Countries\OECD Countries\Appalachian States of USA\Southern States of USA\USA\South Atlantic States of USA

bibl.et: Population genetic analysis of Chamaecyparis thyoides in New Hampshire and Maine, USA.
bibl.aa: Department of Natural Resources, University of New Hampshire, Durham, NH 03824, USA.

ab.p: An example of isoenzyme analysis is presented which is used in assessing the genetic variability of protein polymorphisms in Chamaecyparis thyoides which is limited in scope (only a few northern populations were sampled) due to the limitations in estimation of allele frequencies and rare allele detection. Twenty trees (at least 15 m from each other) in each of 8 populations (4 at the 30 ha US Forest Service Massabesic Experimental Forest, Alfred, Maine and 4 more widely spread in New Hampshire) were sampled. The cedar stands sampled were not genetically depauperate, nor did their variation levels suggest they may be the result of founder events. It is suggested that the genetic and fossil evidence indicates that they are relict populations from a time when the species was more widespread. The presence of unique alleles in the Cedar Swamp Pond population suggests that this population is retaining unique alleles in response to low-level selection pressures and/or it is large enough to retain unique alleles and/or it is undergoing gene flow from nearby populations containing similar allelic frequencies. It is concluded that if the stands in this area are undergoing gene migration, and there is a large breeding population, then it is possible that a large portion of the gene pool may be preserved from an earlier time when the species was more widespread in south-central New Hampshire.

ab.p: Relative suitability of different nitrogen fixing and non-nitrogen fixing tree species on mine overburdens of Jayant, Singrauli, India, was studied. Fifty-four months after planting, Eucalyptus tereticornis recorded the highest score in respect of survival, collar diameter and height followed by Cassia siamea among non-nitrogen fixing tree species. Of the N-fixing species, Albizia procera scored the highest value followed by Dalbergia sissoo. These 4 species were considered to be most promising for reclaiming mine spoil.

ab.p: An account is given of practical experience in roundwood measurement by harvesters in Germany, and the expectations of this technique. This is based on papers and discussions at a conference in May 1997, and a demonstration of roundwood measurement and calibration of the measuring system on a modern Valnet 911 harvester. It is concluded that it is not yet time for timber to be sold by harvester measure in Germany, but that harvester measure can already be useful as a check.

bibl.et: Cambial electrical resistance as an indicator of condition and nutritional status of pedunculate oak and sessile-flowered oak.
bibl.ms: 21 ref

ab.p: The paper was presented at the 5th meeting of the Natural Sciences Department of the Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts, July 8th, 1996. During a period of two years electrical resistance was measured in the tree cambial zone and live bark of undamaged and damaged trees on three experimental plots of pedunculate oak (Quercus robur) and one plot of sessile-flowered oak (Quercus petraea). In both species highest resistance was determined during the vegetational interphase and the lowest during the vegetational season, when the cambial zone is best developed. In all measurements, damaged trees showed higher resistance than undamaged, or less damaged trees. Trees in less favourable social positions recorded higher electrical resistance than trees with favourable social positions. Trees progressively dying back, as well as dead trees have relatively low electrical resistance due to the release of ions, as a consequence of wood mass decay.

bibl.et: Early height growth of western white pine provenances in British Columbia plantations.
bibl.aa: Canadian Forest Service, Pacific Forestry Centre, 506 West Burnside Road, Victoria, B.C. V8Z 1M5, Canada.

ab.p: To estimate the limits of seed transfer to and within British Columbia, heights of 36 western white pine (Pinus monticola) provenances were analysed for geographic patterns 5-13 years after planting on 24 sites. A maximum of 17 provenances were grown on a site. California and Oregon sources are not recommended due to poor height growth. Percentage differences between tallest and shortest provenances varied from 16% to 31%. Washington State and Idaho sources can be used on coastal sites but are not recommended on northern-interior sites. Northern-interior provenances are recommended for local sites, especially those beyond the species' natural range. The data support establishment of separate seed orchards, one for each of the coastal and interior portions of this disjunct species.

bibl.do: General Technical Report - Southern Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.et: Forecasting loblolly and shortleaf pine seed crops.
bibl.ct: Proceedings of the Eighth Biennial Southern Silvicultural Research Conference, Auburn, Alabama, 1-3 November, 1994.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Southern Forest Experiment Station, Monticello, AR, USA.

ab.p: Preliminary guidelines are presented for forecasting acceptable seed crops for natural regeneration of loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) and shortleaf pine (P. echinata). Sample trees are visually placed in one of three cone-density classes (few, average, good), based on cone spacing, occurrence of cones in clusters, and distribution of cones within the crown. The procedure was tested during 1993 in 17 stands in Arkansas, Oklahoma, Louisiana and Mississippi, USA. Stands represented a wide range of stand conditions and sites. Classification took <1 minute per tree. The stand's mean cone rating and basal area explained 58% of the variation in seed production. Only 2 seed crop failures occurred, and both were correctly forecasted.

bibl.et: Optimization of the rotation of forest stands.
bibl.ft: Optimização da revolução dos povoamentos plorestais.
bibl.aa: Escola Superior Agrária de Coimbra, Bencanta, 3040 Coimbra, Portugal.

ab.p: The concept and determination of the optimal rotation is discussed, with special emphasis on the optimal economic rotation. The methods used for estimating optimal rotation in financial terms include Annual Forest Value Growth Percentage (AFVG%) and Willingness to Pay for Land (WPL), in due consideration of the future land value (WPL1), at the end of the rotation period. The effects of variations in annual income/expenditure, stumpage prices and interest rates, in addition to the effect of intangible benefits (countryside, recreation, etc.) on the trend of AFVG% during the rotation, or on the maximization of WPL1 are evaluated.

index.de: costs\forest economics\forest plantations\interest rates\land\multiple use\optimization\rotations\stumpage value\theory\valuation

bibl.et: Remote sensing of forest resources in Portugal: realities and perspectives.
bibl.ft: Detecção remota de recursos florestais em Portugal: realidades e perspectivas.
bibl.aa: Universidade de Trás-os-Montes e Alto Douro. Apt. 202, 5000 Vila Real, Portugal.

ab.p: After an overview of the composition and economic value of forest resources in Portugal, several associated problems, such as forest fires, are discussed. Suggestions are for the use of several technologies, such as remote sensing and geographical information systems, for the study and management of these resources. Reference is also made to several difficulties which have had a delaying effect on the diffusion and better use of such technologies, and several suggestions are made for increasing their application.

bibl.et: Variation in density of red deer (Cervus elaphus L.) in an area of the international part of the Tejo River: the influence of habitat, pasture and hunting.
bibl.ft: Variacão da densidade de veados (Cervus elaphus L.) numa área do tejo internacional: influência do habitat, pastoreio e caça.
bibl.aa: Estação Florestal Nacional, Tapada das Necessidades, 1350 Lisboa, Portugal.

ab.p: In 1995-96 three counts of a red deer population were carried out in an area of the international part of the Tejo River (in Portugal and Spain), using line transect sampling with the registration of perpendicular sighting distances. Using the DISTANCE program, global densities were calculated, as well as the densities of each class of individual (females, males, young and total), and the densities in each of the 4 parts into which the study area had been divided. Values were calculated for the young/female ratio and the sex ratio, and sexual segregation analysed over time in each part of the study area. Female density was related to the sampling date, the macrohabitat, the existence of grazing by sheep and goats and the small game exploitation carried out in each sub-area. It is concluded that the areas of degraded Eucalyptus stands had a higher density of deer than the montado areas of azinho [groves of holm oak, Quercus ilex], and that the areas used for grazing and intensive small game shooting were partially avoided by the animals. The implications of the results are discussed, and management actions proposed.

ab.p: A brief account is given of employment generation through reclamation of waste land in a fuel plantation/afforestation project in Gurgaon, Haryana, India. bibl.aa: Murugappa Chettiar Research Centre (MCRC), Madras, India.

ab.p: Details are given of inputs, costs and expected returns from plantations of curry leaf (Murraya koenigii), tuberose (Polianthes tuberosa), mango (Mangifera indica), neem (Azadirachta indica) and casuarina (Casuarina equisetifolia) - the first 4 planted as commercial crops, and the last as a fuelwood species - on acid degraded soil in a village in Tamil Nadu. Organic methods, including the use of natural pesticides, were used. Social impacts are discussed. Casuarina grew well and is expected to produce good fuelwood/biomass yields.

bibl.et: Yields of eddo (Colocasia esculenta) and maize (Zea mays) in association with Erythrina fusca and Calliandra calothyrsus.
bibl.ft: Producción de ñampí (Colocasia esculenta var. antiquorum) y maíz (Zea mays L.) en asocio con Erythrina fusca y Calliandra calothyrsus.
bibl.aa: CATIE, Turrialba, Costa Rica.

ab.p: Production of maize and eddo with one harvest of each crop per year, were evaluated in an alley cropping system with Calliandra calothyrsus and Erythrina fusca, and in monoculture, in Costa Rica. Trees were planted in rows 6 m wide with spacings of 0.5, 1 and 2 m between trees, and pruned twice yearly. Data are presented and discussed on weight and number of commercial and total corms produced for each crop, dry weight of harvested grain for maize, and biomass production of trees in 1991-93. Crop yield varied between tree spacings, tree species and harvest. For both crops, starting at the second harvest, yields in alley cropping were greater than in monoculture. In the third harvest, maize yields were greater with E. fusca than C. calothyrsus. Biomass production by C. calothyrsus was greater than that by E. fusca, and greater at closer spacings.

bibl.av: De Carvalho, D.\De Souza, A. M.\De Oliveira, A. F.
bibl.et: Production of monokaryotic cultures and inter- and intrapopulation sexual compatibility for the ectomycorrhizal fungus Pisolithus tinctorius.
bibl.ft: Produção de culturas monocarióticas e compatibilidade sexual intra e interpopulacional para o fungo ectomicorrízicio Pisolithus tinctorius.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Ciências Florestais, Universidad Federal Federal de Lavras, CP 37, 37200-000, Lavras, MG, Brazil.

ab.p: Basidiospores of P. tinctorius from 2 mature fruit-bodies (A and B) from 2 different sites (in Minas Gerais, Brazil) reforested with Eucalyptus sp. were germinated on various test media for production of monokaryotic cultures. MMN agar medium was used with or without host seedlings of Eucalyptus camaldulensis (2/petri dish), and with or without abietic acid (100 mg/litre) and/or activated charcoal (0.3 g/petri plate) - 8 treatments in all. Spore germination began after 60 days and 54 monokaryotic colonies were obtained before 120 days. The highest germination efficiency was observed in the treatment with seedlings and both additives; growth of 75 and 68% of monokaryotic colonies was promoted from fruit-bodies A (population A) and B (population B), respectively. In the sexual compatibility study, 9 monokaryotic colonies (2 from population A and 7 from population B) were paired on MMN agar medium using a half diallel mating design. After 4 wk, 2 small samples of mycelium from the interface of paired colonies were transferred to fresh MMN agar medium. After 15 days, the colonies growing from these samples were examined microscopically for the presence of clamp connections which were used to indicate dikarion formation. These results showed that the sexual compatibility of the 2 two P. tinctorius populations studied is tetrapolar and that they are genetically compatible to produce hybrid cultures for introduction into fungal breeding programs.

bibl.et: The Coccinellidae collected from Tsuga with Adelges tsugae Annand (Homoptera: Adelgidae).
bibl.aa: Institute of Plant & Environmental Protection, Beijing Academy of Agricultural & Forestry Science, Beijing 100081, China.

ab.p: Expeditions were made to Yunnan and Sichuan, SW China, with the aim of searching for potential natural enemies of the hemlock (Tsuga [chinensis]) woolly adelgid, Adelges tsugae. The collection made contained 45 coccinellid. Eight species belonging to 4 genera are described here; of these, 5 species were new. Two of the species were shown to be adelgid predators in the laboratory.

bibl.et: Coreidae (Heteroptera) associated with native forest plants.
bibl.ft: Coreidae (Heteroptera) associados a espécies florestais.
bibl.aa: Engenharia Florestal, UFSM. 97. 119-900, Sqanta Maria, RS, Brazil.

ab.p: Insects were sampled in canopies of 10 tree species at a forest border in Caibaté, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, from August 1993 to July 1995. The insects were collected every 15 days, using a conical funnel, by shaking the tree branches over the funnel. Eleven species of Coreidae were identified. The most numerous species was Jadera sanguinolenta [Rhopalidae], and Casearia sylvestris was the host with the highest number of species and insects. Myrocarpus frondosus was not host to any species of Coreidae.

bibl.et: Bostrichidae (Coleoptera) inn Pinus caribea var. hondurensis in Agudos, São Paulo State.
bibl.ft: Altura de vôo de Bostrichidae (Coleoptera) em Pinus caribaea v. hondurensis em Agudos, SP.
bibl.aa: FEIS/UNESP, Departamento de Biologia, Av. Brasil, 56, 15378-000, Ilha Solteria, SP, Brazil.

ab.p: Nine flight heights of ethanol baited flight traps model ESALQ-84 were tested between November 1987 and October 1988 in a Pinus caribaea var. hondurensis stand. Six insect species were trapped, with Bostrychopsis uncinata was the most frequent, abundant and captured. The flight height preference of Bostrichidae (Coleoptera) in general was 2.0 m but only for B. uncinata was there a significant difference between heights; this species was also more captured in traps at 2.0 m height. Heavy flights occurred in the months of October-November, coincident with an increase of rainfall after a dry season.

bibl.et: Balochistan's ancient junipers: bringing sustainable management to dry-zone forests.
bibl.aa: Forest Health Management International, 2248 Shawnee Court, Fort Collins, CO 80525, USA.

ab.p: The Ziarat forest in southwestern Pakistan is a fragile ecosystem. Forest health is poor because of harsh growing conditions and dwarf mistletoe (Arceuthobium oxycedri) infestations, and natural regeneration of the native juniper (Juniperus excelsa) is sparse. Human use of the forest, especially fuelwood harvesting and grazing, has caused severe degradation. Because if its location, advanced age and range of goods and services it provides, the Ziarat forest is a unique resource. The local people are aware of the tenuous condition of their forest, and attempts to manage this forest in a sustainable manner have begun.

index.de: degraded forests\forest health\forest management\forests\fuelwood\grazing\mistletoes\multiple use\old-growth forests\parasitic weeds\weeds

bibl.et: Rehabilitation of understocked loblolly-shortleaf pine stands - I. Recently cutover natural stands.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Southern Research Station, Monticello, AR 71656, USA.

ab.p: Two loblolly-shortleaf pine (Pinus taeda-P. echinata) stands were cut in 1979 to stocking levels of 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50% to simulate recently cutover, understocked, uneven-aged stands. Number of trees ranged from 38/acre for 10% stocking to 213/acre for 50% stocking; corresponding total basal areas were 4 and 16 ft²/acre, respectively. One stand was on a good site (site index=90 ft at age 50) with silt loams, the other on a medium site (site index=75 ft at age 50) on loamy sands in southern Arkansas. As a rehabilitation treatment in 1980, all broadleaved trees with groundline diameter ≥1 inch were injected with Tordon 101 [picloram + 2,4-D]. At 2, 5, 10, and 15 years after treatment, the stands were inventoried to determine: (1) rate at which the understocked stands recovered, and (2) minimum stocking levels required for successful rehabilitation. During 15 years of rehabilitation, the understocked stands changed dramatically, and because of rapid growth of residual pines, stocking levels, basal areas, and tree volumes increased markedly. Stands having at least 20% residual stocking and 5 ft²/acre of pine basal area reached an acceptable stocking level of 60% (based on number and size of trees), or 45 ft²/acre of basal area within 15 years. Stands at this minimum stocking threshold produced 4600 and 3000 board feet (Doyle)/acre of sawtimber volume on the good and medium sites, respectively, during the 15 year period.

bibl.do: Research Bulletin of the Niigata University Forests
bibl.et: A simple method for evaluating fine-scale variation of chlorophyll concentration within a leaf.

ab.p: A simple method using an optical scanner was developed, and its applicability was investigated for 6 broadleaved tree species: the deciduous species Celtis sinensis var. japonica, Robinia pseudoacacia and Prunus yedoensis; and the evergreen species Camellia japonica var. decumbens, Camellia sasanqua and Castanopsis cuspidata var. sieboldii. The leaf chlorophyll concentration measured by the SPAD-501 chlorophyll meter was highly correlated with the green digital value of the image obtained from the optical scanner. Although the regression relationship between leaf chlorophyll concentration and green digital value was different among species, the coefficient of determination (R²) was >0.9 in each species, indicating that the green digital value was a suitable index for detecting the fine-scale variation of chlorophyll concentration within a leaf.

bibl.et: Pre-germination temperature and the survivorship and onward growth of Mediterranean fire-following plant species.
bibl.aa: Biodiversity and Ecology Division, School of Biological Sciences, University of Southampton, Bassett Crescent East, Southampton, SO16 7PX, UK.

ab.p: The effects of heat treatment on seedling survivorship and onward growth was investigated in six common fire-following Mediterranean plant species (Anthyllis vulneraria, Cistus creticus, C. salvifolius, Hippocrepis unisiliquosa, Pinus brutia and P. halepensis). In the first experiment, seeds of five species were heated to temperatures ranging between 80 and 120°C (at 10°C intervals) for 10 min and subsequent seedling growth monitored over 8 weeks. Survivorship for the two pine species was reduced after seeds were heated above 90°C. Onward growth for Pinus halepensis and the legume, Anthyllis vulneraria, was negatively affected by increasing pre-germination temperature. Survivorship and growth for both Cistus species was unaffected by heating seeds up to 110°C. The second experiment examined more closely seedling performance of Hippocrepis unisiliquosa seedlings when seeds were heated to temperatures ranging between 50 and 90°C (at 10°C intervals) for 5, 10, 15 and 20 mins. Increasing pre-germination temperature and the length of time seeds were exposed to heating significantly reduced seedling growth rates in this species. The effect of fire on seedling emergence, growth and survivorship in the field is discussed with reference to the adaptation of the six species to post-fire regeneration and the patterns of seedling regeneration observed in the field.

bibl.do: Dynamics of tropical communities: the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.et: Dynamics of tropical communities: the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.ct: Dynamics of tropical communities: the 37th symposium of the British Ecological Society, Cambridge University, 1996.
bibl.ms: many refs at ends of chapters
bibl.aa: Geobotanisches Institut, Universität Bern, Alternbergrain 21, CH-2013 Bern, Switzerland.

ab.p: The 22 papers in this book were presented at a symposium held at Cambridge University on 1-3 April 1996, which considered the problems confronting advancement of the understanding of the dynamics of tropical communities when there is stochasticity and change at all scales in time and space. Tropical communities are recognized as among the most species-rich and dynamic in the world, yet far from existing as dynamic equilibria, large and unpredictable disruptive events are seen as dominating the longer-term dynamics set against the background of global change. This book challenges the idea of dynamic equilibrium still further, arguing for a new approach/framework based on a time-scale of decades to centuries, for finding new ways to handle unpredictability and uniqueness, and for evaluating species diversity and community change at different scales. The papers included are arranged in increasing order of the scale of the processes principally addressed; 12 and 5 papers, respectively, discuss various aspects of the dynamics of tropical rain forests and savannas, and the rest cover other tropical ecosystems. Specific topics covered are: seed and fruit characteristics of tropical rain forest plants, their post-seed dispersal predation, and factors influencing seed and seedling predation; gap-size niche differentiation in tropical rain forest trees; the effects of fishing on predatory and prey fishes on Fijian reefs; architecture and the development of rain forest trees, the limits to their distribution, and community structure and the demography of primary species; risk spreading and reducing tactics of West African anurans; limits to the exploitation of Serengeti wildebeest; phenology and dynamics of the Korup rain forest (Cameroon); primates, phenology and frugivory in the Lopé rain forest (Gabon); the effects of habitat fragmentation on plant-pollinator interactions; a spatial model of savanna function and dynamics; evolution and diversity in Amazonian floodplain communities; community dynamics of arboreal insectivorous birds in African savannas; species richness of African grazer assemblages; niche specificity among tropical trees; disturbance and succession on the Krakatau Islands (Indonesia); major disturbances in tropical rain forests; the impact of traditional and modern cultivation practices, including forestry, on Lepidopteran diversity; and the assessment of spatial pattern and change with time in tropical rain forests.

bibl.do: Forest biodiversity research, monitoring and modeling. Conceptual background and Old World case studies.
bibl.et: Forest biodiversity research, monitoring and modeling. Conceptual background and Old World case studies.
bibl.ct: Forest biodiversity research, monitoring and modeling. Conceptual background and Old World case studies.
bibl.ms: many refs at ends of chapters, Man and the Biosphere Series Volume 20. Also published by UNESCO, Paris, France
bibl.aa: SI/MAB Biodiversity Program, Quad 3123 MRC 705, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, DC 20560, USA.

ab.p: Most of the chapters in this book were originally presented at the international symposium 'Measuring and monitoring forest biological diversity: the international network of biodiversity plots', held in Washington, DC, May 23-25, 1995, coordinated and sponsored by the Smithsonian Institution/Man and the Biosphere (SI/MAB) Biodiversity Program. Section I, Forest monitoring framework (2 chapters), is introductory and provides the theoretical framework behind plot-based monitoring. Section II, Monitoring and modeling forest biodiversity (17 chapters), describes how plot-based results have been put to a variety of uses, such as defining the number of trees to be sampled in smaller plots, monitoring climatic change, ground-truthing satellite imagery to map forests, analysing global trends in tree mortality, determining seed-dispersal patterns, and developing new analytical techniques for assessing patterns of diversity. Section III, Europe (3 chapters) outlines some of the monitoring programmes and networks currently in place in Europe. The remainder of the volume presents case studies from Africa and Australia (Section IV, 5 chapters), and South East Asia (Section V, 10 chapters). A concluding chapter gives an overview of some of the important research directions highlighted in the book. A subject index is included. A companion volume describes similar work in North, Central and South America and the Caribbean.

bibl.do: Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden
bibl.et: An ecological perspective on biodiversity investigations: examples from Australian eucalypt forests.
bibl.ct: Proceedings of the 43rd Annual Systematics Symposium of the Missouri Botanical Garden: 'New tools for investigating biodiversity', 4-5 October 1996.
bibl.aa: Division of Wildlife and Ecology, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, PO Box 84, Lyneham, Canberra, ACT 2602, Australia.

ab.p: Australian government agencies and research institutions are devoting considerable resources to the development of new approaches and tools for conserving and managing Australia's biodiversity. Issues of data quality, choice of analysis method, ecological theory and GIS (geographic information system) use are discussed using examples from recent Australian studies with emphasis on the scientific components. The problem of data quality is examined in terms of a suitable minimum data set and the need for a survey design for representative sampling using results from a survey of 24&thin;000 km² in northeastern New South Wales. Examples of analytical tools for modeling species distribution, e.g., generalized linear models (GLM) and generalized additive models (GAM), are presented using data from a database of 9537 plots and 273 tree species for an area of 40&thin;000 km² in southeastern New South Wales. The necessity for ecological theory, in particular continuum theory as opposed to community concepts, is examined in the context of these results. The interface between ecological and evolutionary theory is discussed drawing on the results of statistical modeling (GLM) of species richness patterns of Eucalyptus subgenera in the same area. The predictive use of GIS in mapping vegetation, using statistical modeling (GAM) and multivariate classification techniques, is demonstrated with an application to a comprehensive regional assessment (CRA) process for establishing a regional conservation plan. These methods and analytical tools have been collated into a package, BioRap, which also includes methods for the selection of priority areas for conservation. Rapid progress is being made in developing new tools. However, theory for ecological, statistical, environmental and evolutionary processes is urgently needed to ensure use of these emerging tools for investigating and managing biodiversity.

bibl.do: Growing broadleaves: silvicultural guidelines for ash, sycamore, wild cherry, beech and oak in Ireland.
bibl.et: Growing broadleaves: silvicultural guidelines for ash, sycamore, wild cherry, beech and oak in Ireland.
bibl.pb: National Council for Forest Research and Development (COFORD)
bibl.aa: Maurice Kennedy Research Centre, University College, Dublin, Irish Republic.

ab.p: This book is a complete guide to growing the native and naturalized broadleaved species of Ireland: ash (Fraxinus excelsior), sycamore (Acer pseudoplatanus), wild cherry (Prunus avium), beech (Fagus sylvatica) and oak (Quercus robur and Q. petraea). There are 8 chapters: (1) Introduction - historical background, policies and incentives for afforestation, and benefits; (2) Silvicultural strategies and procedures - national strategy, general silvicultural strategies for broadleaves, and silvicultural procedures; (3) Soils - introduction, summary of optimum site/soil conditions for broadleaved species, soil formation and distribution in Ireland, and the major soils; (4) Ash; (5) Sycamore; (6) Wild cherry; (7) Beech; and (8) Oak. The 5 chapters devoted to the species are all arranged similarly: summary; natural distribution and occurrence; provenance; ecological demands & characteristics of the species; production goals; stand establishment; formative shaping; tendingg; pruning; thinning; and underplanting. A glossary, bibliography, appendix (giving details of existing stands of the 5 species - forests/properties, compartments/subcompartments, species, planting year, stocking, top height, dbh (diameter at breast height), altitude and soil type) and subject index are included.

bibl.aa: Str&hacek;ední lesnická škola, 753 01 Hranice, Czech Republic.

ab.p: The development of basic legal concepts in game management in the Czech Republic are analysed including: banned hunting methods, the control of hunting, hunting dogs, shooting licences and insurance, huntsman qualifications, damage caused by game, and hunting organizations. Conclusions are drawn from the analyses and comparison of historical legal regulations with present game management law of the Czech Republic.

bibl.do: Nature is culture: indigenous knowledge and socio-cultural aspects of trees and forests in non-European cultures.
bibl.et: Nature is culture: indigenous knowledge and socio-cultural aspects of trees and forests in non-European cultures.
bibl.aa: Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland

ab.p: This book investigates the perceptions and attitudes of individuals and local communities in relation to the conservation of trees and forests, and the meaning of a forest reflected in its cultural perception. The 12 chapters by various authors (which include an introduction by the editor) discuss: the Kissia and Kuranko forest islands of Guinea; indigenous knowledge, the influence of religious beliefs and rituals on forest conservation, and the role of Tamang women in forest management, in Nepal; livelihoods in mountain forests in Japan; the Lawa swidden farmers of Thailand; tree (substitute) marriage, and the sociocultural aspects of particular tree species, in India; management of the Ecuadorean rain forest by the Huaorani people; war, forests and the environment in Sierra Leone; indigenous knowledge of trees and forests in non-European societies. It is concluded that the so-called virgin forests of the world owe much to their symbiotic relationship with the indigenous people living in and on the margin of the forests. Human activities have 'managed' the world's forests, resulting in a greatly enhanced biodiversity.

bibl.et: On the applicability of Landsat TM images to Mediterranean forest inventories.
bibl.aa: Centre de Recerca Ecològica i Aplicacions Forestals, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona, 08193 Bellaterra, Barcelona, Spain.

ab.p: Landsat TM (thematic mapper) images were used in combination with field measurements to create mathematical models for predicting tree canopy cover, stand basal area, and stand stem volume of Mediterranean forests. The independent variables used were reflectances of 6 TM bands (1-5 and 7) and 2 vegetation indices (NDVI, the normalized difference vegetation index, derived from TM 3 and 4; and NDVIc, a modified NDVI for coniferous forests, derived from TM 3, 4 and 5). The data were from 2 sites in NE Spain - the Osona region, which has a forested area of 710 km², highly variable relief, and an altitude range of 700-1000 m (main species Pinus sylvestris and Quercus ilex), and the Solsonès region, which has a forested area of 600 km² and an altitude range of 600->2000 m (main species P. sylvestris and P. nigra subsp. salzmannii [P. nigra subsp. cebennensis]). Radiometric data from the TM images were related to field data from a forest inventory by means of regression analysis. Trials using plots with radiometrically homogeneous surroundings were carried out to evaluate the effect of high spatial heterogeneity frequently found in Mediterranean forests. Simple regression models were found to be consistent with the expected radiometric response of vegetation, and most of the multiple regression models fitted the observations sufficiently to make quantitative predictions for field variables from the remote sensing images. According to this study, however, these models should be regarded as exploratory models rather than fully operational ones. Spatially and non-spatially related factors are suggested as causes of the remaining dispersion of the models created.

bibl.et: Volatile organic compound emissions from young black spruce trees.
bibl.aa: Department of Land Resource Science, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario N1G 2WI, Canada.

ab.p: Black spruce (Pinus mariana) trees are an important component of the vast northern boreal forest and therefore may influence global atmospheric chemistry. Variations in the volatile organic compound (VOC) emission rate of young (3 years old) black spruce trees as a function of light and temperature were found to be consistent with the functions suggested by Guenther et al. [Guenther, A., Monson, R., Fall, R. (1991). Observations with eucalyptus and emission rate algorithm development. J. Geophys. Res., 96(D6):10799-10808]. VOC emission rates were determined using a fast response hydrocarbon detector in conjunction with a glass cuvette. This allowed the VOC emission rate to be determined on a real-time basis. Summation of separate equations for isoprene and monoterpenes yielded a predictive total VOC emission rate model as a function of light and temperature which was based on total hydrocarbon data provided from the fast response hydrocarbon detector. Speciations of the spruce emissions provided further evidence that temperature relationships of the isoprene and monoterpene emission rate could be fitted to the general functions proposed in the literature. The base VOC emission rate at standard conditions was found to be 9 ± 4 µg C h-1 (g dry needle weight)-1.

bibl.et: Deforestation and global market pressures.
bibl.ct: CASID conferences 1995 & 1996: selected articles.

ab.p: Recent quantitative models of deforestation have concentrated on highlighting relatively straightforward correlations between rates of deforestation and its direct and indirect domestic causes, ignoring complex linkages. It is argued that deforestation in the developing regions of Latin America and the Caribbean, Africa and Asia is part of a structural transformation determined in part by North-South relations through global markets. Besides domestic factors, the global pressures of demand for wood from the tropics also explain the pattern and rate of deforestation. Thus, deforestation is due to circular causation, which cannot be captured by standard linear econometric techniques.

index.de: deforestation\econometrics\economic development\land clearance\markets\mathematical models\tropics

bibl.et: Effects of far-red light on the growth, mycorrhizas and mineral nutrition of Scots Pine seedlings.
bibl.aa: Finnish Forest Research Institute, Suonenjoki Research Station, Suonenjoki, Finland.

ab.p: The effects of supplementary far-red sidelight on the formation of mycorrhizas and on the accumulation and allocation of dry weight and mineral nutrients were studied in Pinus sylvestris seedlings under controlled conditions. Starting one week after germination, the seedlings were subjected to 2 different light quality regimes: control and simulated sparse-canopy conditions (FR+). In the FR+ regime, light reflected by neighbouring plants was simulated by means of supplementary far-red light sources, which reduced the horizontal red/far-red photon ratio (R:FR) without affecting PAR. Seedlings were harvested after 3 months of treatment. The FR+ regime resulted in increased stem height and decreased total dry weight. Dry weight allocation to needles was unaffected, whereas dry weight allocation to roots was reduced and that to stems was increased in FR+ treated seedlings. The total number of short root tips and developing mycorrhizas per seedling were lower in FR+ treated than in control plants. Most short roots were developing mycorrhizas, while non-mycorrhizal short roots and mycorrhizas with mantle or external mycelium were very scarce. Changes in the allocation of nutrients in general followed the changes in dry weight allocation, and changes in nutrient content followed those in total dry weight. However, mismatches among these changes resulted in significant changes in nutrient concentrations in some organs: the concentrations of N and K in needles and the concentration of N in stems were higher in FR+ treated than in control seedlings. It is suggested that changes in biomass and nutrient allocation under low R:FR may promote rapid height growth during early development in stands of Scots pine seedlings, but that concomitant reductions in the growth of the root system and mycorrhizas may negatively affect tree performance over the long term.

bibl.do: The effects of selective logging in monodominant tropical forests on biodiversity: final report of ODA project number R6057.
bibl.et: The effects of selective logging in monodominant tropical forests on biodiversity: final report of ODA project number R6057.
bibl.pb: Budongo Forest Project, Institute of Biological Anthropology, University of Oxford
bibl.aa: Institute of Bioogical Anthropology, University of Oxford, 58 Banbury Rd., Oxford, OX2 6QS, UK.

ab.p: A 3-year study was set up to investigate the impact of selective logging in monodominant forests on wildlife, particularly concentrating on primates and birds. The research showed that primates and other frugivorous animals benefited from selective logging in these conditions because the removal of the dominant tree species lead to increased production of trees bearing fleshy fruits that they prefer to feed on. Certain insectivorous birds, particularly sallying, ground feeding and leaf gleaning insectivores decreased in numbers following logging because of changes in forest structure and composition. Results were obtained from the Budongo Forest reserve in western Uganda and verified in monodominant forest in the Ituri forest.

bibl.et: Study on techniques for controlling density of Larix olgensis industrial plantations.
bibl.aa: Heilongjiang Provincial Institute of Forestry Science, Harbin 150040, China.

ab.p: The developmental pattern of stand density in Larix olgensis industrial plantations in China was simulated based on the Markov theory, and the distribution of stem diameter in 20-60 yr old plantations predicted. Data on the predicted diameter distribution are tabulated, and shown to fit actual data well. In tests on density control by intermediate fellings (thinning) of trees of diameter ≤11 cm in 20-25 yr old stands, to give stand densities of 0.5, 0.6, 0.7 and 0.8, volume increment was most at a density of 0.7.

bibl.et: The influence of meteorological conditions on the size of the annual increment based on the example of Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga mensiesii Franco) from Beskid Z&dotover;ywiecki.
bibl.ft: Wp&lstroke;yw czynników meteorologicznych na wielkośc´ przyrostów radialnych drzew na pyzyk&lstroke;adzie daglezji zielonej (Pseudotsuga menziesii franco) wyste&hook;puja&hook;cej Beskidzie Z&dotover;ywieckim.
bibl.aa: Zak&lstroke;ad Klimatologii Leśnej AR - Kraków, Poland.

ab.p: In studies in mountain forests on acid brown soil at Glinka and Zlatna, Poland, a total of 19 Pseudotsuga menziesii trees were felled and their growth rings compared with climatological data from 1900/1910 to 1990 (depending on tree age). The sensitivity to low winter temperature of this species was confirmed; growth ring width was reduced following low temperatures in winter and early spring. Cambial growth was slightly increased by high precipitation in April and May.

bibl.do: Research Bulletin of the Hokkaido University Forests
bibl.et: Development of the Japanese larch forestry in Hokkaido: Analysis of statistical data.
bibl.aa: Laboratory of Forest Management, Department of Forest Science of Agriculture, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan.

ab.p: Afforestation with Japanese larch [Larix leptolepis] in Hokkaido, Japan, started in the middle of the Meiji era (1866-1912). Throughout the succeeding Taisho and Showa eras, the species was, after todomatsu [Abies sachalinensis], the second-most popular species for afforestation. After World War II, afforestation of fast-growing Japanese larch was promoted, centred on private forests, and rapidly increased after 1950. As a result, Japanese larch forests covered 485&thin;000 ha in 1985, accounting for 33% of Hokkaido's artificial (plantation) forests. Due to stagnant timber prices since the 1970s however, its planting area has been decreasing yearly. This report describes the development of Japanese larch forestry, forest products and trade in Hokkaido to 1997, accompanied by statistical data. The first part gives details of afforestation areas and coverage (by age class) from 1948, and demonstrates that there is an abnormal age structure. Part 2 gives details of felling, including the balance between regeneration felling and thinning, and log production volume by usage (sawlogs, mine props, pulpwood, other). Part 3 gives breakdowns for lumber production (for construction materials, civil engineering materials, packing materials, dunnage materials, pallet materials, drum materials, and other). Almost all lumber (packing, dunnage, drum and pallet materials) other than that for construction and civil engineering materials is shipped to major export industries in Honshu, including the automotive and electrical machinery industries. Part 4 gives details of prices, which have been only maintained from 1973 to now, so that compared with the increases in general commodity prices, Japanese larch prices have dropped, thus posing disadvantages for the management of Japanese larch forestry.

bibl.et: Freshwater forests of continental margins: overview and synthesis.
bibl.aa: School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06511, USA.

ab.p: This chapter presents a comparison of the physical and biological properties of the coastally restricted tree species considered in the book (distribution, longevity, reproduction and growth habit, morphology, ecological strategies and evolutionary patterns), a comparison of the coastal forest envionments (climate, soils, precipitation, biogeography, fire, fog etc.), including implications for species selection, and a synthesis of the species environment overviews. Comparisons concentrate on the non-deciduous needle conifers of the north temerate zone.

bibl.et: Chamaecyparis forests: a comparative analysis.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany & Plant Pathology, Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR 97331, USA.

ab.p: The conifer genus Chamaecyparis includes 7 taxa, 2 each in Japan, Taiwan and western North America and one in eastern North America. All grow in coastal environments. These trees have similar scalelike foliage, their woods are decay resistant, relatively strong and easy to work and are valuable for local use. However, these superficially similar species differ in their maximum size and age, form, habitat and the composition and structure of the forests where they grow. This chapter surveys and contrasts the characteristics (range, microclimate, environment, associated flora, forest physiognomy etc.) of native forests in which Chamaecyparis species are important.

index.de: age of trees\botanical composition\coastal plant communities\coniferous forests\distribution\environmental factors\flora\forests\habitats\microclimate\size

bibl.et: Reproduction and forest decline of Chamaecyparis nootkatensis (Yellow-cedar) in southeast Alaska, USA.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Region 10, Juneau, AK 99801, USA.

ab.p: A review of the silviculture of Chamaecyparis nootkatensis is presented along with the results of recent investigations (1981 to the present day) conducted in Alaska, USA, regarding the reproduction (sexual and vegetative), community relationships and aetiology and epidemiology of C. nootkatensis decline in southeastern Alaska. It is suggested that neither a pathogen nor air pollution is the primary cause of mortality and that reforestation can proceed at healthy productive sites. It concluded that the decline is naturally induced and that the extreme decay resistance of the species (which has enabled the reconstruction of the onset and development of decline which started before 1900) may require further study. The forest decline has already reduced the population of C. nootkatensis on more than 200&thin;000 ha in addition to timber harvesting. It is concluded that with limited natural reproduction, artificial regeneration may become necessary to reestablish and perpetuate this tree species.

bibl.et: Problems and research needs for Chamaecyparis nootkatensis forest management in coastal British Columbia, Canada.
bibl.aa: Sustainable Forestry Division, MacMilan Bloedel Ltd. Nanaimo. BC V9R 5H9, Canada.

ab.p: A review of the regeneration problems (natural regeneration, vegetative propagation, cone and seed development and ecophysiology) of Chamaecyparis nootkatensis is presented in addition to a review of the silvicultural challenges and research needs for C. nootkatensis production in British Columbia. It is concluded that to provide silvicultural options for forest land managers, reliable stand establishment must be achieved, which requires the development of high-quality propagules from both seeds and cuttings. Recent research in British Columbia indicates that C. nootkatensis seedlings and stecklings may be suitable for regeneration of shelterwoods and small clearcuts and as such it is suggested that current research should be focused on ensuring an efficient infrastructure for achieving short-term regeneration objectives. The use of C. nootkatensis in helping to reconstruct past climates and in providing early warning of regional climatic change is discussed in addition to the consequences of human disturbance on C. nootkatensis as an ecological resource.

index.de: coastal plant communities\coniferous forests\forest ecology\forest management\forests\natural regeneration\physiology\plant development\propagation\research\reviews\silviculture

bibl.et: Genecology of Chamaecyparis nootkatensis.
bibl.aa: British Columbia Forest Service, Cowichan Lake Research Station, Mesachie Lake, BC V0R 2N0, Canada.

ab.p: A review of a study involving seedlings originating from a rangewide population collection in which the morphological and physiological traits of Chamaecyparis nootkatensis were measured with regard to adaptation to the environment, is presented. Seedlings from 33 rangewide populations and 171 families were grown for 3 years in a field trial at the Cowichan Lake Research Station, Vancouver Island, Canada. It was observed that C. nootkatensis is intermediate between generalist and specialist modes and that significantly more genetic variability was attributed to within populations than between them. Differences between populations of C. nootkatensis seedlings in growth, phenological and cold-resistance traits were significant but moderate when correlated with latitude and altitude of seed origin. Southern and high-elevation populations were taller and more susceptible to cold damage. The adaptive trends of C. nootkatensis and the relevance of these to current seed transfer guidelines are discussed.

bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Siskiyou National Service, Grants Pass, OR 97526, USA.

ab.p: A review of the Port Orford Cedar Action Plan for the protection and maintenance of Chamaecyparis lawsoniana within its native environment is presented in relation to programme planning, disease control strategies, disease monitoring, research requirements and programme accomplishments (screening for resistance to P. lateralis, a breeding programme to increase resistance levels, analysis of conditions that promote the spread of the disease and methods of detection of the disease). The new discovery of P. lateralis on Taxus brevifolia is discussed in relation to mapping and monitoring the infection.

bibl.et: Regeneration ecology of Chamaecyparis obtusa and Chamaecyparis pisifera (Hinoki and Sawara Cypress), Japan.
bibl.aa: Department of Environmental and Resources Management, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Okayama, Ikayama 700 Japan.

ab.p: Site differences between C. obtusa and C. pisifera within areas of sympatry are discussed and reproduction (sexual and vegetative) and regeneration characteristics (recruitment, seed production, seed size, seed dispersal, seed germination and seedling emergence) are reviewed. It is concluded that the regeneration characteristics of C. obtusa and C. pisifera are markedly different, and that vegetative layering of the latter is an effective mechanism for its population maintenanceor for regeneration in habitats where seedling recruitment is usually ineffective.

bibl.et: Biodiversity over the last thousand years in managed vegetation in southern Sweden.
bibl.ft: Biologisk mångfald under tusen år i det sydsvenska kulturlandskapet.
bibl.aa: Ekologiska institutionen, Zooekologi, Lunds universitet, Ekologihuset, S-223 62 Lund, Sweden.

ab.p: Major vegetation changes in Götaland, S. Sweden, during the last millennium are reviewed, and an attempt to assess concomitant changes in biological diversity is made. A thousand years ago, forests and mires dominated the landscape, except in some coastal areas where open meadows prevailed. The forests were composed of several types of deciduous trees, especially oak (Quercus), birch (Betula) and beech (Fagus) in the south, and, on poor soils, mainly of pine (Pinus). Most forests were open grazing forests (pasture woodland), but ancient trees and large dead trees were still common. In some areas, rich deciduous forest dominated by lime (Tilia) and oak still occurred. During the following 700 years the forests were opened up by man, but biologically important structures of the virgin forests, viz. ancient trees, large dead trees and wetlands, remained abundant. During this period, biodiversity increased until the coverage of old-growth forest decreased to about 20% of the surface area. The period 1800-1995 was a period of declining biodiversity, mainly due to local and regional extinction of species dependent on ancient trees and large dead trees. On the other hand, biodiversity among vascular plants and vertebrates changed comparatively little. However, these latter groups comprise less than 5% of the total biodiversity among macroorganisms. The very high biodiversity connected with decomposing wood, the fauna and flora of which has been affected most by the activities of man during the last 200 years, is stressed. In Sweden, the total species diversity connected with dead wood amounts to several thousand species, mainly fungi and insects. Restoration of old-fashioned landscape types is now being carried out in several places, using the landscape of the 19th century as a model. However, during this period the biodiversity was lower than previously, since natural disturbance caused by windfalls, fire, and natural water level fluctuations were no longer occurring. Therefore, the use of mediaeval landscapes as a model for restoration is recommended. This will lead to higher biodiversity, and may be economically beneficial (wood products, meat, tourism). Studies of such landscapes provide insights useful in conservation and when developing sustainable forestry.

bibl.et: Structural characteristics of old- and second-growth stands of longleaf pine (Pinus palustris) in the Gulf Coastal Region of the USA.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Biology, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, USA.

ab.p: Structural differences in Pinus palustris stands were quantified among (1) one xeric old-growth stand, (2) two xeric second-growth stands, and (3) one seasonally flooded flatwoods second-growth stand using quadrats ranging from 100 m² to 10&thin;000 m². The mean density and size of pines, the frequency and size of open spaces, and the scale of aggregation for each stand were estimated. The mean density of pines was higher in the two xeric second-growth stands than in the old-growth stand, but variability at the old-growth stand was higher, suggesting discrete patches of densely stocked small trees, interspersed with larger trees and open spaces. This pattern was not present at either xeric second-growth stand. In contrast, the density of trees at the flatwoods site was lower and the frequency of open areas higher than for any other stand. The size class distribution at the old-growth stand was characterized by more small and large trees and fewer intermediate-sized trees than at the second-growth stands. The mean size of all trees at the old-growth stand was larger than at the second-growth stands, but it decreased with increasing quadrat size, reflecting the inclusion of smaller trees in larger quadrats; this pattern was not present in two of the three second-growth stands. The dynamics of old-growth stands can provide a framework for interpreting patterns observed in second-growth stands. In an old-growth stand, the death of older, larger trees creates open patches allowing recruitment of juveniles. Patches of suitable size for recruitment were not present at the xeric second-growth stands. It is suggested that proactive management of xeric second-growth stands by selective removal of small groups of overstory trees would allow a more uneven size distribution and would create open areas for recruitment. The flatwoods site differed from the xeric second-growth sites and thus is likely to require different management regimes.

bibl.et: The reduction of Acacia burkittii to Acacia acuminata subsp. burkittii (Acacia sect. Juliflorae: Fabaceae, Mimosoideae).
bibl.aa: National Herbarium of New South Wales, Royal Botanic Gardens, Mrs Macquaries Road, Sydney, NSW 2000, Australia.

ab.p: Acacia burkittii has long been separated from A. acuminata mostly on the basis of phyllode shape and width, as well as other less consistent phyllode characters. Further morphological investigation found that their separation is no longer justified. Therefore, A. burkittii is here transferred to A. acuminata as subsp. burkittii. Acacia acuminata subsp. acuminata is endemic to south-west Western Australia, while A. acuminata subsp. burkittii extends from south Western Australia to western New South Wales.

bibl.do: Manuals of dipterocarps for foresters: Java to New Guinea.
bibl.et: Manuals of dipterocarps for foresters: Java to New Guinea.
bibl.ms: Published jointly with CIFOR for the DFID (UK Department for International Development) Forestry Research Programme
bibl.aa: Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh, 20A Inverleith Row, Edinburgh EH3 5LR, UK.

ab.p: This book is one of a series of 7 manuals aiming to cover all timber-size Dipterocarpaceae occurring in the tropical rain forests of Malesia. The manuals are produced by a project funded by grant R6512 to ABW Associates (Cambridge, UK), from the UK DFID Forestry Research Programme managed by the Natural Resources Institute, UK. Each manual is restricted to a different geographical area. The manuals include text (dichotomous keys based on forest characters; information on silviculture, timber, wood anatomy and uses; line drawings of leaves and fruits); and one or more 3.5" diskettes with an interactive multi-access key. These are based on a database in DELTA (DEscriptive Language for TAxonomy) format and the PANDORA relational database system (held at the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh). The database can also be used to produce tailor-made local manuals. This particular manual contains details of the project, information on how to use the manual, and the manual proper - an introduction (on recognition of the family, genera and timber groups, taxonomy, economy, timbers, ecology and silviculture; and summary of the 24 species occurring from Java to New Guinea - which includes Nusa Tenggara, Sulawesi, Maluku, Irian Jaya and Papua New Guinea); a key to all groups of timber-size dipterocarps from Java to New Guinea; and descriptions of the Dipterocarpaceae family and the genera Anisoptera, Dipterocarpus, Hopea, and Shorea (including red meranti and white meranti). There is 1 diskette. A glossary and indexes to scientific and common names are included.
