bibl.et: Carbon dioxide, populations and communities.
bibl.ms: ref. at end of each chapter; Physiological ecology series
bibl.aa: Institute of Botany, University of Basel, 4056 Basel, Switzerland.

ab.p: This book, developed from a workshop held at the Leuenberg Conference Center near Basel, Switzerland, in August 1994, includes 28 chapters which discuss the responses of populations and communities, and the resulting evolutionary responses, to elevated atmospheric carbon dioxide. Species and communities discussed in relation to CO2 increases include: Raphanus raphanistrum and Plantago lanceolata; Brassica juncea; calcareous grasslands; European vegetation; tropical plant communities; Mediterranean old-field communities; annual grasslands; temperate grasslands; heathlands; Quercus ilex macchia; fire regimes; symbiotic nitrogen fixation; plant-fungal interactions; plant competition in general, and between legumes/non-legumes in permanent grassland, between grasses and Trifolium repens, and between Picea abies and Calamagrostis epigejos; forest insects; and forage quality for ruminants. There is a subject index.

bibl.do: General Technical Report - Southern Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.et: Pine growth and plant community response to chemical vs. mechanical site preparation for establishing loblolly and slash pine.
bibl.ct: Proceedings of the Eighth Biennial Southern Silvicultural Research Conference, Auburn, Alabama, November 1-3, 1994.
bibl.aa: Southern Forest Experiment Station, Auburn University, AL, USA.

ab.p: The effects of chemical and mechanical site preparation methods for establishing loblolly (Pinus taeda) and slash (P. elliottii var. elliottii) pine were studied, following integrated fuelwood-pulpwood harvesting and conventional whole tree logging of pines and hardwoods in southern Alabama, USA. Re-vegetation was assessed in year 1, planted pines were measured after 2 and 5 years, and the soil bulk density was examined. Site preparation treatments generally shifted the herbaceous component from grasses to forbs and blackberries (Rubus spp.). After integrated harvesting, mechanical and herbicide treatments performed equally well for loblolly pine, while discing treatments yielded greater 5th-year volumes than herbicide methods with slash pine. On conventional harvested sites, mechanical and chemical treatments performed equally well. Pine volumes were 10-fold greater within-windrows than between windrows. A single discing treatment returned top soils to pre-harvest bulk densities.

bibl.et: Intra-specific variation in nitrogen economy among three mountain birch provenances.
bibl.aa: Department of Ecological Botany, University of Uppsala, Villavägen, 14, SE-752 36 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: Intra-specific relationships between growth traits and nitrogen economy were studied for seedlings of mountain birch (Betula pubescens subsp. tortuosa [B. tortuosa]) originating from three climatically different regions within the northern forest margin in sub-arctic Fennoscandia. The experiment was carried out using potted seedlings grown in Abisko, northern Sweden, through two complete growing seasons. The seedlings were grown in peat and assigned to two different temperature (ambient and 2.5° warmer) and fertilizer treatments (1 and 10 g N/m² per season) in a factorial design. Significant differences among provenances were found in almost all growth and nitrogen economy traits studied. The differences in growth rate, which reached 47%, were explained primarily by leaf weight ratio (biomass allocation to leaves) and secondly by leaf area productivity (biomass production per unit leaf area). Both the nitrogen productivity and residence time of nitrogen (with respect to above-ground nitrogen losses) varied between provenances; no significant relationship was found between these two traits. Differences in residence time of nitrogen were more related to biomass loss ratio (leaf biomass losses per unit total plant biomass production) than to nitrogen concentration of abscised leaves. The intra-specific variation in nitrogen economy between mountain birch provenances is discussed with respect to the possibility of significant genotype × environment interaction.

bibl.et: Identification of brassinosteroids with epimerized substituents and/or the 23-oxo group in pollen and anthers of Japanese cedar.
bibl.aa: Department of Biosciences, Teikyo University, Utsunomiya 320, Japan.

ab.p: Brassinosteroids in pollen and anther samples of Japanese cedar (Cryptomeria japonica) collected from Niigata Prefecture were analysed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) after being purified by reverse-phase HPLC. Four stereoisomers of 23-dehydrobrassinolide, 3 stereoisomers of 28-homobrassinolide and an isomer of homodolicholide were identified, although stereochemical structures of these brassinosteroids remain undetermined. The 23-dehydrobrassinolide stereoisomers are the first brassinosteroids identified with an oxo group located at the C23 position. In addition, previously-described brassinosteroids 3-dehydroteasterone, typhasterol and dolicholide were identified.

bibl.et: Impacts of intensive urbanization on trees in Hong Kong.
bibl.aa: Department of Geography and Geology, University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam Road, Hong Kong, China.

ab.p: Trees in cities face a severe limitation of plantable space and an exceptionally stressful growing environment. In Hong Kong, shortage of developable land has relegated trees to a lower priority and intensified urban impacts on them, relative to other cities. The vicissitudes of urban growth and trees since the founding of Hong Kong are reviewed, and eleven specific conflicts between urbanization and trees in Hong Kong are described. Redevelopment of existing buildings has raised site coverage by impervious surface and taken away ground-level planting space within and around affected lots. Infilling of relatively low-density areas mainly for government and institutional land-uses has increased development density and removed existing greenery and planting spaces. Road construction and improvement has widely damaged roadside trees and removed valuable and conspicuous greenery. Proliferation of underground utilities has fuelled the contest for usable space and precluded planting in many places. Widespread and frequent roadside trenching, associated with utilities and the laying of cable television and telecommunication networks has incurred massive root damage at roadsides. Poor soil quality commonly beset by chemical and physical constraints has caused chronic poor tree performance. Intrusion into urban parks and other green enclaves by buildings and roads has usurped the limited stock of green spaces. Encroachment into peri-urban woodlands has deprived the city of fringing mature greenery with conservation, landscape and amenity worth. Plantable space in reclaimed lands has been intensively used with inadequate allocation for trees. Protection and preservation of champion specimens has lacked statutory means and a coordinated policy. Reinforcement and demolition of stone walls has destroyed many large trees on unique mural habitats. Quality of arboricultural practice is poor, particularly in the private sector. Possible solutions to these limitations in Hong Kong are suggested, and have implications for other cities facing similar problems.

bibl.et: A system of equations for prediction of plywood veneer total yield and yield by grade for loblolly pine plywood bolts.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Forestry, Oklahoma State Univ., Stillwater, OK 74078, USA.

ab.p: A system of equations was developed that predicts square foot veneer total yield and yield by grade for loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) plywood bolts. The system predicts square foot yields based on a 1/8-inch peel for all veneer, grade B and better full sheets, grade C full sheets, grade D full sheets, a miscellaneous category consisting of grade C and better strips as well as fishtail and center cut, and a category consisting of grade D strip and D saw core (full sheets that cannot meet requirements for grade D). The equation for prediction of total square foot veneer yield is a linear function of bolt volume within the small-end diameter inside bark (SEDib) excluding the core, and volume in the tapering portion of the bolt outside the cylinder defined by SEDib. Equations for grade yield are constructed by multiplying predicted total yield by a function that predicts the ratio of yield in a particular grade to total yield. Therefore, the system is constrained so that predicted total yield is equal to the sum of predicted yields by grade category. The ratio function depends on independent variables such as bolt grade, SEDib, and bolt position in the tree. Since total volume was a dependent variable in one of the system equations and a predictive variable in other nonlinear system equations, nonlinear 3-stage least squares techniques were used to estimate parameters in the system.

bibl.do: General Technical Report - Southern Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.et: Volunteer pines and hardwoods mediate responses of planted loblolly pine to site preparation.
bibl.ct: Proceedings of the Eighth Biennial Southern Silvicultural Research Conference, Auburn, Alabama, 1-3 November, 1994.
bibl.aa: Daniel B. Warnell School of Forest Resources, University of Georgia, Athens, GA, USA.

ab.p: In the Georgia Piedmont, USA, planted Pinus taeda, volunteer pines (P. echinata) and hardwoods were measured 12 growing seasons after 6 site preparation treatments. Treatments were clear cutting (CC), manual cutting (CC + CUT), shearing + chopping (SC), shearing + chopping + herbicide (hexazinone) (SC + H), shearing + root raking + burning + discing (SRBD), and SRBD + N fertilizer + sulfometuron (SRBD + FH). With increasing treatment intensity, basal area of planted pines increased (from 6.5 to 23.2 m²/ha), and decreased in volunteer pines (from 22.0 to 5.3 m²/ha) and hardwoods (from 6.6 to 0.9 m²/ha). Volumes of planted pines (75.5-111.1 m³/ha) following SC, SC + H, SRBD and SRBD + FH treatments were 3-4.5 times that in the CC treatment (24.0 m³/ha). The total volume of planted and volunteer pines in CC + CUT (130.1 m³/ha) differed little from SC, SRBD and SRBD + FH treatments (121.9-133.8 m³/ha).

bibl.do: General Technical Report - Southern Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.et: Growth and physiological characteristics of planted loblolly pine and red maple grown in pure and mixed stands.
bibl.ct: Proceedings of the Eighth Biennial Southern Silvicultural Research Conference, Auburn, Alabama, 1-3 November, 1994.
bibl.aa: Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, VA, USA.

ab.p: Loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) and red maple (Acer rubrum) were grown for 5 years in pure stands and 50:50 mixtures with a ground cover of tall fescue (28 kg/ha Festuca arundinacea) or under weed-free conditions (use of glyphosate) on the upper Piedmont of Virginia, USA. By the end of the 5th growing season, the relative size of both species depended on stand composition and herbaceous cover. Although red maple was more suppressed by tall fescue, high survival will likely allow the eventual development of a larger red maple component in mixed stands, due to the decline of herbaceous vegetation and the development of an overstorey.

bibl.do: General Technical Report - Southern Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.et: The importance of selection gain in walnut agroforestry management.
bibl.ct: Proceedings of the Eighth Biennial Southern Silvicultural Research Conference, Auburn, Alabama, 1-3 November, 1994.
bibl.aa: University of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA.

ab.p: Black walnut (Juglans nigra) nut production is a viable source of income for landowners involved in black walnut management. An evaluation of nut production under alley cropping management in Missouri, USA, in 934 juvenile trees, over a 7-year period, revealed that 80% of trees produced an annual average of ≤100 nuts/tree between the ages of 7 and 15, while only 2% produced >200 nuts/tree. A highly significant increase in nut production can be realized by using nut production records as a guide for thinning.

bibl.do: General Technical Report - Southern Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.et: Planting production rate, survival, and growth of bare-root oak and loblolly pine seedlings subjected to various root-handling treatments.
bibl.ct: Proceedings of the Eighth Biennial Southern Silvicultural Research Conference, Auburn, Alabama, 1-3 November, 1994.
bibl.aa: Daniel B. Warnell School of Forest Resources, University of Georgia, Athens, GA, USA.

ab.p: Different root handling treatments (light and heavy pruning, balling, and dug-hole planting) were applied to bare-root northern red (Quercus rubra) and cherrybark oaks (Q. falcata var. pagodifolia) and loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) seedlings. Oak seeds were sown in a nursery at densities of 100-529 per m² in December 1992, and planted in December 1993 in North Carolina and Georgia, USA. Pine seedlings were raised at a density of 256 seedlings per m² and planted in Georgia. Seedling weight of oak declined with greater sowing density. Planting production rate showed that the dug-hole method was 3-5 times slower than other treatments. Survival and first-year growth of pine was greater for the dug-hole method than for other treatments.

bibl.et: Effect of tree age and soil type on tannin per cent from the bark of Acacia nilotica.
bibl.aa: Forest College and Research Institute, Tamil Nadu Agricultural University, Mettupalayam-641 301, India.

ab.p: Studies were undertaken in Tamil Nadu, India, to determine the best type of soil and length of felling cycle (rotation) for obtaining the maximum tannin content from the bark of Acacia nilotica. Of the 7 soil types tested (calcareous, red, sandy loam, clay, and 3 black soils - cultivated, and submerged or non-submerged tank bed), black soil from cultivated conditions was best (giving bark with 20% tannin content), followed by tank beds non-submerged (18.8%) and clay loam (18.2%). Calcareous soil gave the least bark tannin (10.6%). Bark tannin content in relation to felling age (4-11 yr) was tested on red and black soils, and the results indicated that the best felling age was 10-11 yr.

bibl.et: Diameter and height distributions in a gallery forest tree community and some of its main species in Central Brazil over a six-year period (1985-1991).
bibl.aa: Departamento de Engenharia Florestal, Universidade de Brasília, Caixa Postal 04357, 70900-900 Brasília, DF, Brasil.

ab.p: Diameter and height structure were studied over 6 yr in approximately 64 ha of the Gama gallery forest in Brasília, Brazil. Trees from 10 cm dbh (diameter at breast height) were measured every 3 yr from 1985 in 151 (10×20 m) permanent plots. Natural regeneration (individuals under 10 cm dbh) was measured in subplots within the 200 m² plots. Most individuals and species were under 45 cm in diameter and 20 m in height, while the maximum diameter for individual species ranged from 30 to 95 cm. The diameter structure was typical of a mixed tropical forest with the number of individuals decreasing with increasing size classes and showing little change over the 6 yr. The most abundant species occupied different positions in the canopy and had different size structures.

bibl.et: Study on the infesting characteristics of Dioryctria yiai and estimation on its larval density.
bibl.aa: Institute of Subtropical Forests, Chinese Academy of Forestry Sciences, Fuyang, Zhejiang 311400, China.

ab.p: Dioryctria yiai is an important pest insect infesting 2-year-old cones of Pinus massoniana in China. Infestation by its overwintered larvae and its population density in seed orchards were studied. The overwintered larvae were mainly (58.85%) distributed on 2-year-old cones on branches of the 6th-7th whorls with an infested cone rate 53.6%. Its larval numbers and the infested cone rate were positively correlated with the number of male inflorescences.

bibl.do: Nature is culture: indigenous knowledge and socio-cultural aspects of trees and forests in non-European cultures.
bibl.et: Culturing trees: socialized knowledge in the political ecology of Kissia and Kuranko forest islands of Guinea.
bibl.ms: refs at end of book
bibl.aa: School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, UK.

ab.p: The shared significance of Kissia and Kuranko forest islands in the Kissidougou Prefecture of Guinea, which have their origin in the encouragement of forest regeneration in savanna, and in tree planting, is described. Areas discussed are: settled islands in savanna; representations of forest-island creation and enrichment; sacred institutions in forest islands; forest representation in ethnic identity and political discourse; and felling trees and forests. It is concluded that the significance of Kissidougou's forest islands varies widely. The people of Kissia and Kuranko have a detailed understanding of vegetation and the soil, water, fire and animal processes which influence it. Indigenous knowledge of trees and forests relates not only to practical concerns but also to people's understanding of themselves and their place in wider social and political struggles.

bibl.do: Nature is culture: indigenous knowledge and socio-cultural aspects of trees and forests in non-European cultures.
bibl.et: The perceived environment as a system of knowledge and meaning: a study of the Mewahang Rai of Eastern Nepal.
bibl.ms: refs at end of book

ab.p: Topics discussed are: the Rai of eastern Nepal; perceptions of the environment in Rai culture; environmental knowledge; specific aspects of their (agricultural and agroforestry) farming systems, including erosion control, soil fertility management, pest management, weed control, genetic resource management and microclimatic management; the cognitive structure of the environment; and the ecology of ritual. The people's perception of the environment was based on both their knowledge of the environment and their relationship with the supernatural. It is concluded that development strategies which incorporate cultural explanations of the human-environment relationship must be examined for their efficacy in empowering groups of people, like the Rai, who are economically and politically marginalized by society.

ab.p: The livelihood of Japanese mountain villagers and the way in which the predatory character of certain activities is culturally recognized is discussed. Tatari is a curse or retribution which, it is believed, occurs when the roles of nature are infringed. Topics discussed and related to tatari are: forest livelihoods; hunting and fishing; forestry; and livelihood and danger.

bibl.do: Nature is culture: indigenous knowledge and socio-cultural aspects of trees and forests in non-European cultures.
bibl.et: Forests and trees in the cultural landscape of Lawa swidden farmers in northern Thailand.
bibl.ms: refs at end of book
bibl.aa: Geography Department, South Asia Institute, University of Heidelberg, Germany.

ab.p: Different forms of swidden farming (shifting cultivation) practised by various tribes (hill tribes) in northern Thailand are discussed. Swidden farming is considered as one of the chief determinants of vegetation composition and development. Areas discussed are: the Lawa of northern Thailand; the farming economy; the swiddening cycle; secondary swiddening on fallow swiddens; and the role of trees and forests in the Lawa cultural landscape. It is noted that the Lawa farming system retains trees and forests as an inherent part of the system. This preserves the physiognomy of the wooded landscape, while increasing its diversity.

bibl.do: Nature is culture: indigenous knowledge and socio-cultural aspects of trees and forests in non-European cultures.
bibl.et: The Huaorani and their trees: managing and imagining the Ecuadorian rainforest.
bibl.ms: refs at end of book

ab.p: The forests of Amazonian Ecuador, the homeland of the Huaorani Indians, their history and tree myths are discussed. The intervention and management of the peach palm (Bactris gasipaes) by the Huaorani Indians is highlighted. Also discussed is the concept of the native Amazonians, including the Huaorani Indians, as forest managers and agroforesters. It is concluded that the Amazon forest is partly the result of ancient management practices which has enriched its biodiversity. The highly diverse cultivation systems developed by Amazon people are highlighted. It is shown that agroforestry plans and commercial developments cannot be entirely successful unless they include careful documentation and analysis of the diverse ways in which different indigenous cultures represent and use forest resources.

bibl.et: Where trees do matter for society: the socio-cultural aspects of sal (Shorea robusta) and salap (Caryota urens L.) in the Similipal Hills of Orissa, India.
bibl.ms: refs at end of book
bibl.aa: Institute of Oriental and Orissan Studies, Cuttack, India.

ab.p: It is shown that trees are an integral part of the social and socioeconomic life of rural communities, and this is demonstrated in the culture of Hill Kharia people, who collect honey from beehives in sal trees, and the Kuttia Kondh, who extract wine from the salap tree (the kittul or fish-tail sago palm). Specific aspects considered are: the habitat of sal; Similipal - a forest reserve in Orissa; the method of collecting honey, marketing honey, and causes of decreasing honey yields; salap - the place of the species in the world of the Kuttia Kondh, a description of the tree and its uses (collecting sago from the pith, making 'toddy' from the inflorescence and pith and fermenting it, and preparing drums and water pipelines from the root base and stems), ownership of salap trees and their role in social intercourse, salap tree lore, and conservation management of salap.

bibl.do: Nature is culture: indigenous knowledge and socio-cultural aspects of trees and forests in non-European cultures.
bibl.et: War, forests and the future: the environmental understanding of the young in Sierra Leone.
bibl.ms: refs at end of book

ab.p: The attitudes of young people in Sierra Leone to forests and their reliance upon forest products are discussed, under the following headings: forest products and youth subsistence; experience of the forests; forests and the future; and deforestation and war. Two-thirds of the 421 young people interviewed believed that forests in Sierra Leone were diminishing. A total of 614 suggestions were put forward to reverse the trend, 26% of all suggestions being reafforestation rather than management of existing natural forest. Some 41% of suggestions involved regulation, while 42% involved technical solutions. It is concluded that the young people of Sierra Leone have a sound grasp of current environmental changes and the problems that these might cause, and clear and cogent ideas about possible solutions.

ab.p: This chapter is based on studies made in 2 villages (Sunnamsa and Djavnamsa) in central Nepal [date not given]. The economic and cultural values of forests and trees are discussed, including: the role of trees in the subsistence economy of the Tamang; natural setting and forest cover of the 2 villages; the significance of forest (including private ownership of woods); the significance of single trees (garden trees and trees in agricultural fields); Tamang religion and perceptions of nature (including social dimensions in forest management); ownership and social balance; gender and forest in Tamang society (gender relations in forest management, Tamang women as sustainers of a social balance and the significance of the forest for Tamang women). Details are given of tree names and their economic uses in an appendix at the end of the chapter.

bibl.et: Seed extraction from pond pine cones by oven drying.
bibl.aa: Development Company of Xin'anjiang, Chun'an County 311700, Zhejiang Province, China.

ab.p: Cones of pond pine (Pinus serotina) were oven dried at fixed temperatures (40, 45, 50 and 55 °C) for different periods (24, 32, 40 and 48 h), and seed extraction and germination recorded. The best drying temperature was 40-50°C, and the drying time 24 or 32 h. Average germination rate under these conditions was 88%, and viability was 67%. The economic benefits of oven drying vs. sun drying are discussed.

bibl.et: The value of mesquite for the rural Southwest. Fine lumber and soil improvement.
bibl.aa: Center for Semi-Arid Forest Resources, Caesar Kleberg Wildlife Research Institute, Texas A&M University-Kingsville, Kingsville 78363, USA.

ab.p: Mesquite (Prosopis spp.) has great value as lumber and fuelwood, and its high-carbohydrate pods are suitable as food for humans, domestic livestock and wildlife. It is, however, detested by ranchers because it invades cattle pastures. Recent evidence suggests that silvicultural practices of thinning and intercropping may provide a permanent reduction in encroachment of young seedlings, an increase in soil fertility from nitrogen fixation, and a source of fine, reddish brown furniture-grade lumber on which significant new industries can be based. Such industries would benefit rural areas in many parts of the world as well as the American Southwest.

bibl.et: A tally system for monitoring the presence and movement of lumber in a woodworking enterprise.

ab.p: An account is given of an in-mill computer information system for tallying lumber as it goes through the mill, developed in Russia for a large mill sawing three different species of softwoods and producing four grades of lumber, each of which is resawn into numerous different sizes (cross-sections). Accordingly, at any given time the number of species/grade/cross-section combinations being handled may be as many as 150-180. The lumber is formed into standard export packages, non-standard packages containing boards of >3 different lengths, and lath packages. The computerized tally system provides information on how much lumber of a given species, grade and cross-section is in the form of standard export packages, non-standard packages, and lath packages. Each package receives a set of computer tally-sheet print-outs containing all the relevant information, any changes in the position or status of the package are recorded, and the computer record updated.

bibl.et: Regulation of ponderosa pine foliar physiology and insect resistance mechanisms by basal area treatments.
bibl.aa: School of Forestry, College of Ecosystem Science and Management, Northern Arizona University, Flagstaff AZ 86011-5018, USA.

ab.p: Foliar physiology and several measures of tree resistance to insect attack were compared among ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa var. scopulorum) trees growing in thinned stands. Measurements were made in a second-growth ponderosa pine forest in northern Arizona where basal area treatments (6.9, 18.4, 27.6, 78.2 m² ha-1) were experimentally maintained by frequent thinnings for 32 years before the measurements began in 1994. Most of the physiological characteristics measured were affected by the basal area treatments. As stand basal area increased from 6.9 to 78.2 m²ha-1, predawn water potential, midday water potential, net photosynthetic rate, resin production, phloem thickness, and foliar toughness decreased. Foliar nitrogen concentration was greatest in trees in the intermediate basal area treatments. It is concluded that the physiological condition of second-growth ponderosa pine can be manipulated by silvicultural control of stand basal area. The data support the hypothesis that high stand basal area increases tree stress and decreases tree resistance to insect attack.

The main topics covered are a review of forestry literature on S. aucuparia; dendrology; seed harvesting and plant production; risk factors, damage and protection; the involvement of S. aucuparia in young stands of principal forest species; simulation of silvicultural consequences of fellings in mixed beech-spruce [Fagus-Picea] stands containing S. aucuparia; the current status of S. aucuparia in state forests in Nordrhein-Westfalen, Germany; afforestation of extreme sites (sewage farms and high-altitude sites) with S. aucuparia; the utilization of S. aucuparia in the past and today (covering uses of berries, flowers, leaves, twigs, bark and wood); the importance of S. aucuparia for birds and mammals; and the historical role and treatment of S. aucuparia in the forests of the Sauerland mountains, Germany.

bibl.do: AFZ/Der Wald, Allgemeine Forst Zeitschrift fur Waldwirtschaft und Umweltvorsorge
bibl.et: Nitrogen saturation and destabilization of Scots pine ecosystems.
bibl.ft: Stickstoffsättigung und Destabilisierung von Kiefernökosystemen.
bibl.aa: Institut für Forstökologie, Eberswalde, Germany.

ab.p: A field study was carried out of the species composition of ground vegetation, the growth behaviour of the tree layer, and the aerial biomass and annual dry matter production of the whole stand in 5 pure Pinus sylvestris forests in NE Germany, suffering different degrees of N saturation. Stands were 65-80 years old with an annual average rainfall of 540-600 mm. The total N deposition below the crown ranged from high (>40 kg per ha per year) to low-moderate (20-30 kg per ha per year). Over saturated stands were becoming more open and destabilized, as shown by the development of a light- and water-demanding layer of Calamagrostis epigejos. Pure pine stands on these poor sites should be converted to close-to-nature stands of broadleaves or mixed broadleaves-pines, thus providing more shading of the ground, increasing N storage in the tree layer, and decreasing the spread of C. epigejos.

bibl.et: On the modeling of tree structure - case of Cryptomeria japonica and Chamaecyparis obtusa.

ab.p: The structural characteristics and parameters of the branches and stems of Cryptomeria japonica and Chamaecyparis obtusa in Japan were measured taking account of the fact that the trees consisted chiefly of the crown. The parameters measured were height, length, and azimuth of the branches. Crown structure was studied by analysing the height and direction of branches. The branches of Cryptomeria japonica grew upward with several rotations round the stem every year. A model of this structure consisted of rotating small portions of the branches based on a structural analysis of the tree crown. Graphic images of tree structure were produced using this model.

bibl.et: Evaluation of physiological-biochemical indices for diagnosis of damage to Scots pine by pollutants.
bibl.aa: Institut Lesa Karel'skogo NTs RAN, Petrozavodsk, Russia.

ab.p: Young plants of Pinus sylvestris were fumigated with sulfur dioxide under controlled conditions. The pollutant affected nearly all the physiological and biochemical features examined, especially the essential oils (volatile terpenoids), natural growth regulators, proline and phospholipids. Significant structural changes were observed in the cells of the needles. For early diagnosis of the condition of forest stands in areas subject to industrial pollution, it is recommended to monitor the composition and content of essential oils.

bibl.et: Distribution of populations of phyllophage insects in relation to the landscape/ecological characteristics of the sites.
bibl.aa: Tsentr po Probleman E&dotover;kologii i Produktivnosti Lesov RAN, Moscow, Russia.

ab.p: Studies were made in pure Pinus sylvestris stands 80-100 years old in Siberia to investigate the connection between local site characteristics and the populations of insects defoliators (Bupalus piniarius, Semiothisa liturata, Dendrolimus pini, Gilpinia virens, and Hyloicus morio [Sphinx morio]). The site characteristics considered were : maximum temperature in June, July, August and September, relative humidity, absolute soil moisture content, maximum temperature range, altitude, aspect, gradient, and stand diameter, height and density. The locations considered were valley bottoms, north slopes, narrow plateaux, south slopes, and crests. The study indicates that climate change (warming) will help insect pests to 'occupy' more northerly areas.

bibl.et: Use of biosolids in the forest: technology, economics and regulations.
bibl.ct: Special issue. Environmental guidelines for developing sustainable energy output from biomass: workshop proceedings of the International Energy Authority Bioenergy Agreement Task XII Activity 4.4 "Environmental issues", 17-23 September 1995, Ontario, Canada and Michigan, U.S.A..
bibl.aa: University of Washington College of Forest Resources, Seattle, WA 98195, USA.

ab.p: Biosolids (the residuals settled out after the treatment of municipal waste water) represent a major waste by-product from society that must be managed in responsible ways. Because of their high nutrient and organic matter content, biosolids can be beneficially recycled into forest sites for site improvement purposes. This paper discusses the major advances in technology, economics and regulations that have made the forest an attractive alternative for biosolids use in the USA, with specific reference to research done in the Pacific Northwest, as part of the Pack Forest Program of the University of Washington. Research to date on forest application of biosolids has clearly demonstrated the validity of this management technique. Since the early 1970s, many aspects of the use of biosolids in forests have been investigated, leading to the development of application techniques, operations and management practices, and assessment of environmental impacts. Growth response measurements suggest that, depending upon the actual transportation cost, there is a high potential that the additional growth will either offset or exceed the costs of applications. To supplement technological advances and documentation of benefits, new regulations based on technically sound exposure risk assessment, and guidelines, describe the framework for proper management practices. These will often include recommendations for site selection, site design and site plans.

bibl.et: A site-growth study of Eucalyptus grandis in the Mpumalanga escarpment area.
bibl.aa: Port Elizabeth Technikon, Saasveld campus, P/B X6531, George, 6530, South Africa.

ab.p: A site-growth study was conducted on Eucalyptus grandis on the granitic soils of the Mpumalanga escarpment area, southern South Africa. The objectives were twofold - to identify those site factors that can be related to the growth of the species, and to develop a statistical site-growth model for the quantitative evaluation of sites for tree growth performance. An integrated approach was followed using multiple regression analysis, incorporating attributes on topography, climate and physical and chemical soil characteristics, with site index at 20 years (SI20) as the dependent variable. The growth of E. grandis was mainly influenced by factors controlling available soil moisture, together with the organic carbon content of the topsoil. A statistically significant site-growth model was developed, although the model showed bias by overpredicting at low potential sites and underpredicting at high potential sites. This could be ascribed to the use of a growth model (for standardizing on growth data to SI20) that was developed in a geographically different area (Langepan, Zululand), since suitable site-specific growth models are not yet available for the study area.

bibl.et: Ambient tropospheric ozone in the Ukrainian Carpathian Mountains and Kiev region: detection with passive samplers and bioindicators plants.
bibl.aa: Central Botanical Garden, National Academy of Sciences, Timiryazevskaya St 1, 252014 Kiev, Ukraine.

ab.p: Ambient concentrations of tropospheric ozone (O3) were measured at four highland forest locations in the Ukrainian Carpathians and in two lowland locations in the Kiev region during two summer seasons, from August to September 1995 and July to September 1996 by using O3 passive samplers. The ozone passive samplers were calibrated against a Thermo Environmental Model 49 ozone monitor located at the Central Botanical Garden in Kiev. The two-week long average concentrations at the Carpathian Mountains were higher in 1995 than 1996. Average ozone concentrations in Kiev were higher in 1995 than in 1996, and Kiev ozone concentrations were similar to the lowland forest concentrations. The lowest ozone concentrations in Kiev occurred in mid-morning and the highest concentrations in the afternoon. Ozone-sensitive tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum) cv. Bel-W3 plants at the Botanical Garden in Kiev were injured from exposure to ambient concentration of ozone in both 1995 and 1996 summers. Ozone injury symptoms were found on morning glory (Ipomoea purpurea [Pharbitis purpurea]) and native plants (e.g. Sambucus racemosa and Humulus lupulus) elsewhere in Kiev and at some of the study sites in the Carpathians.

bibl.et: Forest health and environmental pollution in Slovakia.
bibl.aa: Institute of Landscape Ecology, Slovak Academy of Sciences, PO Box 254 Štefánikova St., No. 3, 814 99 Bratislava, Slovakia.

ab.p: As a mountainous and forested country (40.6% forest cover) in central Europe, Slovakia has a large variety of vegetation zones, forest types, and a rich diversity of forest tree species. The most important tree species are beech (Fagus sylvatica), Norway spruce (Picea abies), oak species (Quercus sp.), Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris), silver fir (Abies alba), European hornbeam (Carpinus betulus), European larch (Larix decidua), poplars and willows (Populus sp., Salix sp.), and other hardwood broadleaves. Sources of pollution in the country and emissions from neighbouring countries have resulted in a heavily polluted environment in some regions. Forest health monitoring data on environmental pollution from 1987 to 1994 that use forest ecosystem stability as the ecological criterion indicate that forest health in Slovakia has been adversely affected by air pollution. Average defoliation varies from 26 to 30% for all species. Defoliation for coniferous species is 27-35% and for broadleaves 19-27%. However, defoliation and foliage discoloration of trees, especially of conifers, have been reduced in recent years. These trends may be related to changes in the economy in central European countries in which the decrease of industrial activity has resulted in the decrease of pollution load. However, high percentage of salvage cut (about 60% of the total annual cut) indicates serious ecological instability and impaired health status of Slovakian forests.

bibl.et: Role of forest sector and bioenergy in limiting the carbon emissions of Finland.
bibl.ct: Special issue. Greenhouse gas balances of bioenergy from forestry and wood industry: selected papers from a workshop held in Stockholm, Sweden on 29-31 May 1996, organized by Task XV of the International Energy Agency's Implementing Agreement on Bioenergy (IEA Bioenergy).
bibl.aa: Technical Research Centre of Finland, P.O. Box 1606, FIN-02044 VTT, Espoo, Finland.

ab.p: The greenhouse impacts of the Finnish forest sector, including the forest biomass, forest industry, forest products in use, foreign trade and waste management (in landfills) are discussed. The main carbon storages and flows are estimated and the greenhouse gas balance presented, both totally (including imports and excluding exports) and on a national level (including both imports and exports). These are quite different and emphasize the importance of mutual international understanding of the principles of carbon accounting. The history of the greenhouse impact is also estimated and two future scenarios for the forest sector are compared. The present use and potential for additional use of bioenergy is also reviewed, and the impact of expanded bioenergy use on the national CO2 emissions is illustrated with scenario examples.

bibl.do: Journal of the Japanese Forestry Society
bibl.et: Ecological evaluation of reforestation at the burnt forest site.
bibl.aa: Fac. Integrated Arts and Sci., Hiroshima Univ., Higashi-Hiroshima 739-0046, Japan.

ab.p: The vegetation recovery process and amount of eroded soil were surveyed and compared in reforested and abandoned stands after forest fires at 2 locations (Yasu-ura, 2 sites, burnt in 1986; and Akitsu, 1 site, burnt in 1975) in [Honshu] Japan. The sites were originally Pinus densiflora forest. Reforestation was carried out on terraces or natural slopes 1-3 yr after the fires, using P. thunbergii and Alnus sieboldiana [A. firma] (Akitsu) and P. thunbergii, A. firma and Quercus acutissima (Yasu-ura). Reforestation, especially terrace planting, affected the successional pattern and species composition of post-fire vegetation. Recovery of woody plant biomass in the reforested stands was more rapid than in the abandoned stands. In the early stages after reforestation, woody biomass was slightly larger in the terrace-planted stands than the natural-slope planted stands, but 12 yr after reforestation, the woody biomass in the natural-slope planted stands was larger than that in the terrace-planted stands. These differences are attributed to the fact that the natural-slope planted stands included both planted species and naturally regenerated species, while the terrace-planted stands consisted mainly of planted species. The amount of eroded soil in the natural-slope planted stands was less than in the terrace-planted stands and the abandoned stands. There were no significant differences in the amount of eroded soil in the terrace-planted stands and the abandoned stands.

bibl.et: Ecosystem dynamics at disturbed and undisturbed sites in North Queensland wet tropical rain forest. III. Nutrient returns to the forest floor through litterfall.
bibl.aa: Department of Accounting and Finance, James Cook University of North Queensland, Townsville, Queensland 4811, Australia.

ab.p: The nutrient contents and accessions in litterfall over a period of 3 yr are reported for undisturbed areas and at 2 sites disturbed by selective harvesting some 25 yr previously, in tropical rain forest in Queensland, Australia (the first 2 papers in this series, same authors, were in Journal of Tropical Ecology (1993) 9 (3) 349-363, 364-380). Mean concentration ranges (mg g-1 dry weight) of nutrients in litterfall were 10-12 for N, 0.33-0.43 for P, 3.6-4.3 for K, 6.0-10.5 for Ca, and 1.7-2.6 for Mg. These concentrations are in the middle to lower part of the spectrum of values recorded for tropical forests. Accessions of nutrients in litterfall (kg ha-1 yr-1) were 59-64 for N, 1.9-2.4 for P, 20-24 for K, 34-63 for Ca, and 9-16 for Mg. These rates, particularly for N and P, are among the lowest recorded for tropical forests. There were no consistent between-site differences in total nutrient accessions in small litterfall. In terms of the contribution of litterfall to the accession of nutrients to the forest floor, this suggests that the logged sites have recovered from the effects of selective harvesting within 25 yr. Nutrient accessions at each site were distinctly seasonal, with maximum accessions occurring in the late dry season to late in the wet season. Leaf-fall accounted for the largest proportion of nutrient accessions over the study period, although at certain times accessions in both reproductive material and wood were significant. A cyclone which crossed the coast near the study sites resulted in large nutrient accessions over a short period but had little effect on the total annual accession. A comparison with previous studies of litterfall in Australian tropical rain forests indicates that nutrient return in litterfall is directly related to soil fertility.

bibl.av: Yue, Z.\Li, Y. H.\Cheng, X. P.
bibl.et: A case study of effect of lateral roots of Pinus yunnanensis on shallow soil reinforcement.
bibl.aa: Yunnan Institute of Geography, 28 Jiaochong East Road, Kunming 650223, China.

ab.p: The mechanical effect of lateral to horizontal roots in enhancing the in-plane tensile strength of soil in the rooted soil zone is called a traction effect. It is one way in which plant roots can contribute to lateral reinforcement of a shallow soil mass. The existence of such an effect was investigated in the root system of a pine forest (Pinus yunnanensis) in the Hutiaoxia Gorge, Yunnan, SW China, and its magnitude evaluated through modelling and a direct in situ test at one site (Erdui) in the upper gorge. The model was developed from previously published models which quantified the mechanical interaction between soil and a single root being extracted, and used coefficients derived from root data collected in dense and sparse forest in the upper part of the Hutiaoxia Gorge. The modelling prediction indicated that the lateral roots produce tremendous tractive resistance in the upper soil (0-60 cm below the surface), with a magnitude of 4169 N, on a vertical cross-sectional area of 105 mm² in the top part of the soil (0-20 cm). The direct in situ test showed that the tractive resistance exerted by the lateral roots averages 561 N in the top 0-20 cm and for the same vertical area, or an increase of sliding-pulling resistance of 38%. Under the influence of this tractive resistance, the tensile strength of the upper rooted soil was increased by at least 5.7 kPa. The mechanical processes involved in the traction effect, variation in tractive resistance and its potential magnitude, and implications for slope stability and erosion control are discussed.

bibl.et: Associations between breeding bird abundance and stand structure in the White Mountains, New Hampshire and Maine, USA.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Northeastern Forest Experiment Station, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, USA.

ab.p: Associations of forest cover-type, stand size-class, and stand structure were compared with abundance of breeding bird species in 20 forest stands in the White Mountains National Park, northern New England, to test the hypothesis that the 3 stand variables measured were equally associated with numbers of forest birds. Regression models were fitted to data from each data source to predict the log number of individuals for each species. The analyses were restricted to cover-types with >1 size-class and to size-classes representing >1 cover-type, and to bird species with at least 10 observations/yr for 2 yr (surveys were done in June 1979 and 1980). Of 31 bird species meeting these criteria, a significant association was detected between bird abundance and structure data for 30 species, with cover-type data for 19 species, and with size-class data for 10 species. Stand structure was the best predictor of bird abundance for 25 species, cover-type for 5 species, and size-class for none. Of the 14 structure variables used in the analyses, total foliage volume of large and mid-size deciduous trees, density of mid-size trees, total woody stem density, total deciduous understorey volume and total volume of large conifers were most frequently important in explaining variation in species abundances. Although each species had a unique set of structural affinities, multi-layered stands were apparently more important to long-distance migrants, in general, than to resident/short distance migrants.

bibl.et: Patterns of vegetation along the Omo River in southwest Ethiopia.
bibl.aa: Department of Environmental Science, Policy and Management, College of Natural Resources, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA.

ab.p: A study was undertaken to investigate the botanical composition of riverine vegetation along the perennial Omo River, Ethiopia. The floristic and physiognomic characteristics of riverine vegetation were studied at selected sites, ranging from the relatively straight channel section in the modern delta to a strongly meandering (upstream) section of the river. A combination of open canopy woodland, shrub thicket and grassland (with scattered tree emergents) prevailed on the more recently exposed levees, in and near the modern delta, while closed canopy woodland and forest predominated on fore levees in the meandering segment. Floristic diversity was relatively low at all study sites. Ficus sycomorus, Tapura fischeri, Melanodiscus oblongus, Celtis integrifolia [Celtis laevigata] and Trichilia roka [Trichilia emetica] were most significant in upstream forest sites, whereas Cordia sinensis, Acacia mellifera, Ziziphus mauritiana and Ficus sycomorus were more common in communities nearer the lake. Older forests generally contained greater diversity of more woody species, greater tree height and truck diameter than downstream levee vegetation, but they did not exhibit clear stratification. Species patchiness was broadly characteristic of the riverine zone, particularly the mudflats (ancient floodplains) extending away from the fore levees. Fires were frequently set by local inhabitants throughout the grasslands of the lower Omo Basin, but had only limited impact on woodland and forest vegetation. It is suggested that fire may be a significant factor in the establishment of sharp boundaries between the closed canopy woodland/forest along the river and the more xerophytic vegetation of the mudflats where fires are common.

bibl.et: The response of Norway spruce seedlings to simulated acid mist.
bibl.aa: Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, Bush Estate, Penicuik, EH26 0QB, UK.

ab.p: Four pot experiments are reported in which Norway spruce (Picea abies) seedlings, of different nutrient status, were treated with acid mist for one growing season in open-top chambers (OTCs). Combinations of H+, SO42-, NH4+ and NO3- were applied at different frequencies of application and supplying different rates of S and N (kg ha-1). Plant growth, visible injury, frost hardiness and nutrient status were observed. Both acidity (≤ pH 2.7) and SO42- ions were necessary to induce visible injury. Mist containing SO42-, H+ and to a lesser extent NH4+ significantly reduced winter frost hardiness. Increasing the misting frequency, and to a lesser extent the overall dose, increased the likelihood of acid mist causing visible injury and reducing frost hardiness. Post-planting stress, low N status and needle juvenility increased the likelihood of acid mist causing visible injury. Increased plant vitality, adequate N status and growth rate reduced the likelihood of acid-mist-induced reductions in frost hardiness. Principles underlying the responses of spruce seedlings treated in controlled conditions to acid mist are discussed.

bibl.et: A method for classifying commercial tree species of an uneven-aged mixed species tropical forest for growth and yield model construction.
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry and Natural Resource, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, USA.

ab.p: The sparse distribution of timber species in the tropical rain forest has been a major obstacle in the construction of timber growth and yield models for forest management planning. Models for individual species usually have biased parameter estimates because of the sparse representation of those species. A technique is presented for pooling species with similar growth characteristics into groups to minimize the level of bias in the estimation of model parameters. The data set used consisted of mean annual increments of diameter growth generated from 3 successive 5-yr measurements of forty 1-ha plots from 4 management units within the moist semideciduous forests of Ghana. Principal component, canonical discriminant, and approximate covariance estimation for clustering procedures were used to transform and improve the sphericity and separation of multivariate diameter increment data. The k-th nearest neighbour clustering technique was used to evaluate the most likely number of species clusters within the population covered by the data. The average linkage, complete linkage, and Ward's minimum variance hierarchical clustering procedures were separately applied to the transformed data to identify the characteristics of inherent structures as the basis for classifying similar species into groups. An objective reclassification criterion was used to evaluate the performance of the 3 clustering methods. Optimal species groupings were attained, with 86.3% cluster recovery, by applying Ward's minimum variance method to data transformed by the canonical discriminant procedure. Consequently, 6 species growth classes were formed on the basis of the similarities of species growth increment patterns. This objective procedure is guaranteed to produce optimal species groups, with minimal internal variations, suitable for developing unbiased estimates of growth model parameters. The analytical procedure should be applicable to most tropical forest ecological types similar to the moist semideciduous forest.

bibl.et: Salinity effects on the leaf water relations components and ion accumulation patterns in Avicennia germinans (L.) L. seedlings.
bibl.aa: Laboratorio de Biología Ambiental de Plantas, Universidad Simón Bolivar, Caracas, Venezuela.

ab.p: The physiological traits involved in leaf water relations were evaluated in Avicennia germinans seedlings growing in the mangroves (dominated by Rhizophora mangle, Laguncularia racemosa and A. germinans) of Bocaina Lagoon within the San Esteban National Park, Venezuela, during 1996-97. Analysis of pressure-volume (P-V) curves and sap osmometry were combined to evaluate osmotic adjustment and cell elasticity, and the contribution of accumulated inorganic ions to osmotic potential was estimated. Seedlings growing in soils with interstitial water salinity above that of normal sea water showed a modification of the relationship between water potential and relative water content. Thus, their leaf osmotic potential at maximum turgor (Ψπ(max)) and at zero turgor (Ψπ(0)) was 1.41 and 1.82 MPa lower respectively, than that of the seedlings from the low salinity site. Volumetric moduli of elasticity (ε) were between 17 and 23 MPa. Thus, ε was about 6 MPa lower in high-salinity plants indicating that their cells were slightly more elastic. Ionic concentration analysis showed that σ [anions] and σ [cations] were higher in the high-salinity site (22-35%) while the water content/unit dry mass was only 12-17% lower. Reduction in water content was insufficient to explain the increase in ion concentration. Ion concentration explained 73 and 66% of the osmotic potential estimated by P-V curves for leaves from low- and high-salinity sites, respectively. It is concluded that the leaves of A. germinans seedlings adapt to hypersaline soils by increasing solute concentration and cell elasticity. It is suggested that both processes allow leaf water uptake and turgor maintenance over a large range of soil water potential.

bibl.et: Relationship between leaf anatomical and morphological characteristics and sclerophylly of eight tree species from a fragment of the Atlantic tropical rain forest.
bibl.ft: Relação entre características morfo-anatômicas foliares e esclerofilia em oito espécies arbóreas de um trecho de floresta pluvial Atlântica.
bibl.aa: Departament de Botânica, Universidade Federal do Paraná, Curitiba, Brazil.

ab.p: Leaf morphology and anatomy of eight tree species (Clethra scabra; Clusia cruiva; Gomidesia schaueriana; Hieronyma alchorneoides [Hyeronima alchorneoides]; Nectandra oppositifolia; Protium kleinii; Ternstroemia brasiliensis; and Virola oleifera) is described from lowland rain forest in the Reserva Volta Velha, Itapoá county, Santa Catarina, Brazil. All these species depict anatomical features indicating sclerophylly which is considered an adaptation to oligotrophic soils. Associated with the sclerophylly, these species are heliophytes and have large distribution ranges, which suggest a strategy to colonize and survive in areas of adverse environmental features.

bibl.et: Cell-wall biosynthesis in differentiating cells of pine root tips.
bibl.aa: Dipartimento di Biologia, Università di Lecce, via prov. le Lecce-Monteroni, 73100 Lecce, Italy.

ab.p: The patterns of incorporation of radioactivity from D-[U-14C]glucose into pectins, hemicelluloses and cellulose synthesised in differentiating cells of pine [Pinus halepensis] root-tips were analysed after sequential solvent extractions. The percentage composition of the radioactive glycosyl residues of hot-H2O- and Na2EDTA-+NH4-oxalate-+NaBH4-extractable cell-wall polymers was very similar. All sections of pine roots investigated synthesised a remarkably large amount of polymers rich in galactosyl and arabinosyl residues. These polymers may create in the wall a highly hydrated gel compartment structurally and physiologically important for the roots. The KOH-extractable polymers are rich in glucosyl and xylosyl residues.

bibl.et: Forest resource accounting: preliminary estimates for the state of Maharashtra.
bibl.aa: Indira Gandhi Institute of Development Research (IGIDR), Mumbai, India.

ab.p: The paper seeks to develop a forest resource accounting system for Maharashtra, and incorporate it into the existing SNA (System of National Accounts). The SNA is an integrated system that gives information on all aspects of an economy's performance, but since it focuses on goods and services that are bought and sold, does not include non-marketed services provided by natural assets, such as forestry. Forests contribute to human welfare through the provision of services such as watershed protection, carbon sequestration and recreation, which do not meet the production criteria of the SNA. The macroeconomic indicators in the SNA, such as GDP, are not, therefore true measures of aggregate economic welfare. A second limitation of the SNA is that it makes no provision for the depreciation of natural capital - for example, when a forest is harvested or converted to other uses, it takes into account only the value of the timber and other minor forest products, but makes no allowance for depreciation of forest capital. The paper first discusses different approaches to natural resources and environmental accounting, and then outlines the System of Integrated Environmental and Economic Accounting (SEEA) developed by the UN, which integrates all existing frameworks. It goes on to discuss the scope for implementing the SEEA framework, and illustrates in detail its implementation for Maharashtra. This involves first constructing the physical and monetary resource accounts, and then incorporating them into the SEEA framework. Trial estimates are given of the Environmentally-adjusted Domestic Product (EDP), and the whole procedure and results are discussed and analysed.

ab.p: Illustrated taxonomic accounts are given of the 3 species of Olacaceae found in Veracruz, Mexico: Heisteria media, trees to 25 m tall, Ximenia americana and Schoepfia schreberi, both small trees or shrubs.

bibl.av: Dong, X. B.\Zhu, Y. J.\Han, Y. H.\Zhang, Y.\Fu, J. Q.
bibl.et: Forest felling and stability of partial forest ecosystem.
bibl.aa: Northeast Forestry University, Harbin 150040, China.

ab.p: Investigations were carried out on felling systems in relation to soil and water conservation in the the forest areas of the Daxing'an [Nei Menggu province], Xiaoxing'an [Heilongjiang Province] and Changbai [Jilin Province] Mountains, China. Strip felling or shelterwood felling was found to be the best method for the Daxing'an Mountains area. When the felling strip was set to 50-100 m in width and the remaining strip was 50-80 wide, the operational intensity must be controlled at 60%. In the Xiaoxing'an and Changbai Mountain areas, for stands dominated by spruce [Picea] and fir [Abies], selection felling of <25% in intensity should be used, and for broadleaved-Korean pine [Pinus koraiensis] mixed forest, felling intensity should be controlled to within the range of 24-34%. It is emphasized that felling methods, felling intensity, skidding methods and operational seasons need to be chosen according to local conditions so that the stability of the forest ecosystem is minimally disturbed.

bibl.av: Zhu, C. Q.\Liu, X. D.\Zhang, Q.\Lei, J. P.\Wang, S. J.
bibl.et: The biomass of intensive and extensive cultured poplar plantations.
bibl.aa: Chinese Academy of Forestry, Beijing 100091, China.

ab.p: Biomass and its allocation were studied in intensive and extensive poplar (Populus simonii × Populus pyrimidalis [Populus nigra var. italica] cv. 'Chifengensis 36' [Populus 'Chifengensis 36']) plantations in [Liaoning Province] China. Relationships between growth factors (height, diameter at breast height, volume) and biomass were established, and the dynamics of stem biomass and total biomass in the 2 types of plantations studied. Biomass production was significantly different in the 2 types of plantations, with total values and distribution in organs higher in the intensive than in the extensive plantations. Intensive silvicultural measures are therefore recommended for managing poplar plantations. A suitable age for felling these plantations is at about 13 years.

bibl.et: Seminatural silviculture in southwest Germany.
bibl.aa: Institute of Forest Growth, University of Freiburg, Freiburg, Germany.

ab.p: A brief historical overview shows the mainstream development pattern in German silviculture and outlines the adjacent role of naturally-oriented silviculture. The rationale for seminatural silviculture is discussed with reference to its ecological and economical aspects. Elements of seminatural silviculture of the Baden-Württemberg-concept are introduced. This concept is not purely a preservation strategy, but recognises the importance of timber production. Some aspects of selection forests, such as the special case of uneven-aged forests with a long tradition in southwest Germany, are mentioned. As there are still a lot of even-aged (pure) forests in Southwest Germany, transformation strategies towards uneven-aged mixed forests are shown with the aid of some examples. Criteria and indicators for seminatural silviculture which have to be developed on a regional or local scale, can be used as a basis for establishing a certification process for southwest German forests. Seminatural silviculture is considered as a rational and integrated silvicultural system to fulfil future requirements of forests in a dynamically changing world.

bibl.et: Study on the economic benefit of lesser black poplar pulp plantation.
bibl.aa: Heilongjiang Forest Research Institute, Harbin 150040, China.

ab.p: An economic analysis was made of 8-21 yr old black poplar [Pinus nigra] pulpwood plantations in [Heilongjiang Province] China. Economic maturity was reached at 12-13 years old under the prevailing economic conditions, based on various economic indexes (such as internal rate of return, net present value, cost benefit ratio, land equivalent value, etc.). This was considered to be a least-risk rotation period, although the technologically mature age ([in terms of wood properties] and corresponding rotation period) was lower. The age of quantitative maturity maturity was also different.

bibl.do: Roots 1997: proceedings of the 1997 rural practice research conference of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, held on 8-9 January 1997 at the University of Reading.
bibl.et: Sustainable management of sport and recreation in the New Forest, Hampshire.
bibl.ct: Roots 1997: proceedings of the 1997 rural practice research conference of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, held on 8-9 January 1997 at the University of Reading.
bibl.aa: Land Management Research Unit, Department of Land and Construction Management, University of Portsmouth, Portsmouth, UK.

ab.p: A definition is presented of sustainability in relation to the New Forest, UK, and an assessment of the degree to which this is being achieved is discussed. The impact of recreation on riparian woodlands, heathlands, ancient woodland and on wildlife is discussed in relation to social sustainability, accessibility, the rural economy and the pressures unique to the New Forest. Data is from an empirical research project undertaken during 1995 which provides primary data on levels and patterns of recreational use and their environmental impact. It is concluded that current levels of recreational use are not sustainable in such an area of conservation value and a summary of holistic recreation management tools is presented which include site specific and species specific action plans, long term environmental monitoring of the status of habitats and species and the success of management initiatives, long term recreational monitoring programme and the implementation of the precautionary principle.

bibl.et: Summary of water yield experiments at Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, New Hampshire.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Northeastern Forest Experiment Station, Durham, NH 03824, USA.

ab.p: Changes in water yield are summarized for experimental treatments performed on three gauged, forested watersheds at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest in New Hampshire. The treatments included clear-felling and herbicide applications performed on watershed 2 during 1965-68, progressive strip-cutting performed on watershed 4 during 1970-74, and whole-tree harvesting performed on watershed 5 during 1983-84. Responses in annual water yield varied markedly among treatments. Clear-felling and 3 successive years of herbicide applications caused annual water yields to increase by an average of 288 mm, or 32%. The strip-cutting and whole-tree harvesting treatments caused maximum annual increases in water yield of 114 mm (8%), and 152 mm (23%), respectively. Most of the water yield increases occurred as augmentation to low flows during the growing season, although some peak flows were also increased. Volume of snowmelt runoff was relatively unaffected. Increases in annual water yield diminished rapidly as forests regenerated and were undetectable within 7-9 years after treatment. Unexpected decreases in annual water yields occurred for years 13-30 after the clear-felling and herbicide treatment and for years 8-25 after the strip-cutting due to the regenerating forests having greater proportions of tree species with lower stomatal resistances.

bibl.et: The occurrence of two types of entomopathogenic bacilli in natural populations of the spruce budworm, Choristoneura fumiferana.
bibl.aa: Biology Department, Saint Mary's University, Halifax, NS B3H 3C3, Canada.

ab.p: Two types of pathogenic bacilli were found in cadavers of spruce budworm (Choristoneura fumiferana) larvae and pupae on balsam fir (Abies balsamea) foliage sampled in 1987-88 in several locations in New Brunswick, Canada. One type forms spores and protein crystals at sporulation typical of Bacillus thuringiensis (B.t.), while the other forms spores but no crystals. The noncrystal-producing bacillus is argued to be Bacillus cereus rather than an acrystalliferous variety of B.t.. The bacilli infect budworm during most of its life cycle, from hibernating second-instar larvae to pupae, with varying rates of infection, but are never a major cause of mortality. The bacilli also infect other lepidopterous species occurring on balsam fir foliage. Circumstantial evidence indicates that both bacilli occur naturally on the foliage, despite the history of aerial application of B.t.-based insecticides near, if not directly over, the study plots. A subtle impact of these bacilli on the dynamics of spruce budworm populations is discussed.

bibl.et: Forest resources use through the mixed nonmarket valuation methods.
bibl.aa: Kangwon National University, Chuncheon, Korea Republic.

ab.p: The valuation of natural resources using the mixed nonmarket valuation method is considered as an economic indicator in cost-benefit analysis for decision-making on which forest-related amenity/recreational facilities should be chosen when many options are available. The method should enable more accurate identification of the potential benefit of the forest areas for any development programme in the Korea Republic.

bibl.av: Jeon, H. S.\Song, Y. G.\Kim, C. S.\Joung, H. H.
bibl.et: Effective management of forestry insurance.
bibl.aa: Forestry Research Institute, Seoul, Korea Republic.

ab.p: The importance of forest insurance is emphasized and a plan addressed for its efficient management, based on a survey of the available data and literature on forest insurance, and a mail survey to foresters and forest cooperatives in the Korea Republic. The main causes of inactivity in the field of forest insurance on the supply side included insufficient statistical data on forest disasters (such as forest fires), the complexity of the valuation method for standing trees and damaged trees, unwillingness to insure and reinsure, and insufficient public relations. The main causes of inactivity on the demand side included the forester's low recognition of the need for forest insurance, the low profitability of forestry, and unwillingness on the part of insurance companies. On the government side there was a lack of active effort to promote the need for forest insurance. As a first step in improving the situation, indirect government support for forest insurance is urged, and as a second step, the introduction of fraternal insurance by forest cooperatives. The third step could be the introduction of a government forest insurance scheme.

bibl.et: Highly effective biological preparations for forest nurseries.
bibl.aa: MGUL, Moscow, Russia.

ab.p: Studies have been made since 1986 in Russia on the use of various biological preparations to improve production on soils which had been subjected for a long time to the use of chemicals (fertilizers and pesticides). These preparations are based on selected strains of soil microorganisms and lactic-acid bacteria, and include N-fixing, phosphate-decomposing and growth-regulator-synthesizing microorganisms. Seed germination activator (APS), soil microflora activator (APM), azotovit and bactophosphin have been developed and tested in experimental and semi-commercial conditions. Results are given on the use of these preparations singly or in various combinations in the production of Picea abies seedlings in various Russian nurseries. Data are tabulated on germination, and on the dimensions and phytomass of the seedlings and the yield of standard planting stock. APS, APM, azotovit and bactophosphin [phosphobacterin] have already been recommended for agricultural use, and have also proved suitable in forest nurseries. The dosages recommended are APM 1 litre, APS 0.7-0.8 litre, and azotovit and bactophosphin 0.2 litre per hectare. The use of these biological preparations will allow a reduction of 25-30% in the rates of N and P fertilizers applied.

bibl.et: Silvicultural/ecological evaluation of Russian and Finnish methods and equipment in the conversion of broadleaved stands.
bibl.aa: KirNIILP, Russia.

ab.p: Studies were made on the logging and conversion of broadleaved stands (Betula sp./Populus tremula overstorey, with an understorey of Picea abies) by two different methods, viz. (1) conventional Russian method, i.e. felling by chainsaw, skidding tree-length logs by tractor to upper landing, loading, and extraction by lorry; (2) the Finnish method, i.e. assortment logging with harvester and Valmet 862 forwarder. Data are presented on soil hardness in the tracks (ruts), and damage to stand and advance growth. In the stand conversion treatments, 30-70% of the standing volume of the top (broadleaved) storey was removed, reducing its density to 0.3-0.5. The main advantage of assortment logging over conventional logging is that a smaller area of the stand is cleared but assortment logging does cause greater soil compaction and damage to the residual stand and advance growth. Four years after the conversion fellings (removing up to 70% of stand volume) the health of the stands is generally satisfactory.

bibl.et: Effect of recreational pressure on the stability of biogeocoenoses as a function of slope steepness.
bibl.aa: Botanischeskii˘ Sad DVO RAN, Russia.

ab.p: The effect of slope gradient on the stability of vegetation communities under recreational pressure (trampling) was studied in the Far East of Russia. Resistance to trampling decreases with increasing slope gradient, and a coefficient K is proposed reflecting the decrease in permissible recreational pressure on slopes. K is taken as 1.0 for level ground, and decreases to 0.02 for a slope of 70°. A formula is developed for calculating the recreational capacity of a site.

bibl.do: Environmental Science and Pollution Research International
bibl.et: Theoretical aspects of pollutant stress.
bibl.aa: Botanical Institute, Johann Wolfgang Goethe University, Siesmayerstrasse 70, D-60323 Frankfurt/Main, Germany.

ab.p: Symptoms of tree damage observed in Europe and overseas are often described as premature senescence. However, experiments with fumigated poplars have shown that the term premature senescence is misleading if undue emphasis is placed on features common to both normal and premature senescence. Consequently, the term should be replaced by a concrete description of the stress symptom noted, e.g., premature leaf loss or premature starch degradation. Such stress symptoms are usually non-specific, just like the mechanisms of stress avoidance or stress tolerance themselves. A stress model taking account of ecological, physiological and evolutionary aspects is presented; it is shown that the different stress phases are influenced by various factors, e.g., the photosynthesis capacity of the leaves. The stress reactions displayed by fumigated poplars serve as illustrations for this model. Different species of the genus Populus can be classified as more or less pure C-strategists. It is postulated that this group of plants, in particular, is disturbed by various stress parameters, such as air pollutants, if shoot growth or metabolite transport is impaired.

bibl.et: Osmotic potential of several hardwood species as affected by manipulation of throughfall precipitation in an upland oak forest during a dry year.
bibl.aa: Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, P.O. Box 2008, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6422, USA.

ab.p: Components of dehydration tolerance, including osmotic potential at full turgor (ψπ0) and osmotic adjustment (lowering of ψπ0), of several deciduous species were investigated in a mature, upland oak forest in eastern Tennessee. Beginning July 1993, the trees were subjected to one of three throughfall precipitation treatments: ambient, ambient minus 33% (dry treatment), and ambient plus 33% (wet treatment). During the dry 1995 growing season, leaf water potentials of all species declined to between -2.5 and -3.1 MPa in the dry treatment. There was considerable variation in ψπ0 among species (-1.0 to -2.0 MPa). Based on ψπ0 values, American beech (Fagus grandifolia), dogwood (Cornus florida) and sugar maple (Acer saccharum) were least dehydration tolerant, red maple (A. rubrum) was intermediate in tolerance, and white oak (Quercus alba) and chestnut oak (Quercus prinus) were most tolerant. During severe drought, overstorey chestnut oak and understorey dogwood, red maple and chestnut oak displayed osmotic adjustment (-0.12 to -0.20 MPa) in the dry treatment relative to the wet treatment (no osmotic adjustment was evident in understorey red maple and chestnut oak during the previous wet year). Osmotic potential at full turgor was generally correlated with leaf water potential, with both declining over the growing season, especially in species that displayed osmotic adjustment. However, osmotic adjustment was not restricted to species considered dehydration tolerant; for example, dogwood typically maintained high ψπ0 and displayed osmotic adjustment to drought, but had the highest mortality rates of the species studied. Understory saplings tended to have higher ψπ0 than overstorey trees when water availability was high, but ψπ0 of understorey trees declined to values observed for overstorey trees during severe drought. It is concluded that ψπ0 varies among deciduous hardwood species and is dependent on canopy position and soil water potential in the rooting zone.

ab.p: Three quaternary pavine alkaloids, caryachine N-metho salt, neocaryachine N-metho perchlorate and crychine N-metho perchlorate, were isolated from a callus culture of Cryptocarya chinensis. Neocaryachine N-metho salt is reported for the first time as a natural product. The effect of various culture media components on the growth of callus, and the production of caryachine N-metho salt were also investigated.

bibl.et: Vitality of the mountain spruce stands in Romanka and Lipowska Forest complex versus macro- and micro-elements in tree needles and chemical properties of the top layers of mineral soils.
bibl.ft: Z&dotover;ywotnośc´ drzewostanów świerkowych regla dolnego w kompleksie Romanki k Lipowskiej a zawartośc´ makro- i mikroelementów w ig&lstroke;ach drzew oraz w&lstroke;aściwości chemiczne wierzchnich warstw gleb.
bibl.ms: Prace No. 845
bibl.aa: Zak&lstroke;ad Gospodarki Leśnej Regionów Górskich, Instytut Badawczy Leśnictwa, ul Fredry 39, 30-605 Kraków, Poland.

ab.p: Forest decline started in the 1970s in the higher mountain spruce [Picea abies] stands in this area of Poland, but this has now stopped and local improvements in forest condition have been noticed. Analyses of selected elements in sample needles and top mineral soil layers from spruce stands of different vitality growing at varied altitudes and slopes in the mountain area demonstrated that harmful factors attributable to air pollution might be increased contents of iron, sulfur and nitrogen in needles, and increased nitrogen and sulfur in the soil. Accompanying the cessation in forest decline were an increase in average soil acidity, a doubling of magnesium and potassium, a decrease in calcium, and a decrease in nitrogen on SE and SW exposures, particularly at 1000-1100 m altitude. Increased acidity accompanying improvement in vitality has also been noticed in the top layers of mineral soils in other mountain spruce and fir [Abies] stands.

bibl.et: Nesting success of Kentucky and hooded warblers in bottomland forests of South Carolina.
bibl.aa: WR-ALC/EMX, 216 Ocmulgee Ct., Robins Air Force Base, Georgia 31098, USA.

ab.p: Nesting success of Kentucky warblers (Oporornis formosus) and hooded warblers (Wilsonia citrina) was studied in 15 bottomland hardwood forests on the Savannah River Site, South Carolina, during 1993-94. The Mayfield success rate for Kentucky warbler nests (N=26) and hooded warbler nests (N=33) was 34.7% and 28.7%, respectively. Successful Kentucky warblers pairs fledged more (P<0.001) young (3.7, SE=0.2) than hooded warbler pairs (2.7, SE=0.2). Both species successfully reproduced in small bottomlands, including sites <50 m in width, but all sites were enclosed by mature pine forests. This minimized edge contrast and may have increased the functional size of the bottomland forests, thereby improving the suitability of the sites for nesting habitat for the warblers.

However, only a small percentage of damage was caused by insect pests.
