bibl.et: Crown condition and nutrient status of red spruce (Picea rubens Sarg.) in West Virginia.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Pathology, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA.

ab.p: The appearance, foliar nutrient status, and soil nutrient availability were determined for 9 trees in each of 39 red spruce stands at high altitudes in West Virginia, USA, in July-November 1990. Stands of red spruce (a relic species) in this region and other parts of the high Appalachians have been reported in low health for some time. In West Virginia they have been associated with both insect attack and fungal disease, but this study investigated nutritional aspects of the forest decline. Visual evaluation of crown conditions for all 351 trees sampled resulted in median values of 5% for discoloration and 10% for defoliation. The most common symptom of discoloration was needle chlorosis, found on the upper surface of collected branches. Defoliation generally occurred beginning with the older year-classes of needles and progressed outward towards the branch tips. The levels of discoloration and defoliation varied to such an extent among stands, plots, and trees within a plot, that a single causal agent was not likely to have been responsible for the observed symptoms. Foliar nutrient levels were compared with observed crown condition but were inconclusive in proving a definite relationship between crown condition and any individual nutrient; levels of foliar N and P were negatively correlated with defoliation, but not with discoloration or live crown ratio; yet, foliar K was negatively correlated with both discoloration and defoliation and positively correlated with live crown ratio. While individual sample trees exhibited symptoms of reduced health and vigour, the majority of red spruces sampled during the course of this study appeared healthy.

New single-tree assortment tables and stand assortment tables have been compiled for use in assessing the merchantability of the forest resources of the Urals.

bibl.et: Insect indicators of human interference and degradation of forest ecosystems.
bibl.aa: Institut Lesa SO RAN, Russia.

ab.p: The paper discusses and illustrates the way in which insects can serve as indicators of ecosystem change and degradation under various forms of human impact, viz. industrial pollution, fire, fellings, grazing and recreational pressure. The insects present can help in distinguishing the three main stages in the decline of ecosystem stability, viz. (1) initial reversible stage; (2) digression, irreversible change; and (3) degradation, breakdown of ecosystems.

bibl.do: Tropical moist forest silviculture and management: a history of success and failure.
bibl.et: Tropical moist forest silviculture and management: a history of success and failure.
bibl.aa: Correspondence address: M. S. Philip, Department of Forestry, University of Aberdeen, Aberdeen, UK.

ab.p: Silviculture in tropical forests has a long history, going back many centuries, and active management for timber production began about 200 years ago. There is, therefore, a considerable body of evidence regarding both sustainable and destructive forestry practices in these forests, the future of which is the subject of one of the great scientific and public debates of the late 20th century. Based on extensive research of the literature and 50 years of experience by each author (the first author is deceased, and the book has been completed by the second author), this book provides a highly relevant, definitive history of the development of silvicultural systems in tropical moist forest (a broad term which encompasses many forest types). Much of the information is made widely available for the first time. The book demonstrates that sustainable timber production in many of these forests is not only possible, but that the techniques necessary have been known to foresters for many decades. The book is arranged in 4 main chapters. Chapter 1, 'Early times: the early exploitive and conservation phases', traces the early history of tropical forest silviculture and management up to 1900. Chapter 2, 'Post-1900 to the late 1950s - conservation continues: forest management and colonialism', has sections on India, Sri Lanka, Burma [Myanmar], Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Queensland (Australia), the Caribbean, Central and northern South America, and Africa. Chapter 3, 'The global exploitive phase - the late 1950s to the mid-1990s', introduces the various aspects of change covered (deforestation, population growth, the timber trade, the conservation movement, etc.) and goes on to discuss forest policy and the objects of management, land-use planning and the forest estate, economics, silviculture in selected countries, ecology, silviculture and management operations, silviculture and the environment for management, research, non-wood forest products, conservation, social aspects of management, international actions, and training for silviculture and management; examples from many countries are described in detail. The last chapter, 'Summary and conclusions', discusses lessons from the past, the current state of silviculture and management, and the current debate. An appendix and subject index are included.

index.de: colonialism\deforestation\forest management\forests\history\nature conservation\silviculture\sustainability\tropical rain forests

bibl.et: Evaluation and growth prognosis of permanent sample plot inventories.
bibl.ft: Zur Auswertung und Zuwachsprognose von permanenten Stichprobeerhebungen.
bibl.aa: Biometrie und Datenverarbeitung, Abt. Waldwachstum, Niedersächsischen Forstlichen Versuchsanstalt, Göttingen, Germany.

ab.p: Permanent sample plot inventories are quite common in German forestry. However, growth values resulting from repeated measurements are often influenced by short-term climatic variations. Computer programs (BWIN and KSP) are presented, which can be used to estimate average growth of permanent sample plots and to evaluate inventory data.

bibl.et: Structure and silvicultural development of small-scale forestry in Baden-Württemberg.
bibl.ft: Struktur und waldbauliche Entwicklung des Kleinprivatwaldes in Baden-Württemberg.
bibl.aa: Freiburg, Germany.

ab.p: The changes and problems of small-scale forestry in Baden-Würrtemberg, Germany, are described, based on agricultural statistical data of 1971-91 and the federal forest inventory 1987. The changes in agricultural structures and the development of private forests (up to 200 ha) are connected with the change of socio-economic conditions after World War II. Three different periods are described in which forest policy had to meet the economic interests of forest owners (1945-64, timber production) and the changing needs of society (social benefits of forestry, protection forests, recreational forests). Thus, the aims of forest policy were adjusted to changing socio-economic conditions. This was also clear in subsidiary financial programmes. Although such programmes improved the state of private forests and the conditions of small-scale forestry, problems remain and are increased by the reduction of personnel in forest services and the cut-down of financial means.

bibl.et: Influence of decay on the dielectric properties of wood.
bibl.aa: Danish Technological Institute, PO Box 141, Gregersensvej, DK-2630 Taastrup, Denmark.

ab.p: To find new methods for the detection of mycelium of wood-destroying fungi in ancient building wood, the influence of decay on dielectric properties of wood was investigated. Six blocks of pine softwood (Pinus sylvestris) were compared for weight losses due to infection with Serpula lacrymans [S. lacrimans]. Results indicated that methods for the detection of decay at the initial stage (based on measurements of direct conductivity and permittivity [dielectric constant] at a single frequency) were less useful, because the differences between decayed and uninfected wood were less significant.

bibl.et: Comparison of soda lime and infrared gas analysis techniques for in situ measurement of forest soil respiration.
bibl.aa: CSIRO Forestry and Forest Products, P.O. Box E4008, Kingston, ACT, 2604 Australia.

ab.p: At high efflux rates the dynamic infrared gas analysis (IRGA) method generally provides a higher estimate of soil CO2 efflux than does the static soda lime absorption method. In laboratory tests, soda lime absorbed 98% of added CO2, provided sufficient moisture was present. Field comparisons in the boreal forest in northern Manitoba, Canada, showed IRGA estimates of soil respiration to be fourfold greater than those for soda lime over an 8-h period, while limited comparisons between soda lime and IRGA soil respiration estimates in a radiata pine (Pinus radiata) plantation near Canberra, Australia, over 24 h resulted in IRGA estimates being 40% higher (range -3 to 86%). There was no strong correlation between the two methods at either field site. Field measurements of CO2 concentration in the headspace of a chamber containing soda lime showed CO2 buildup equivalent to 20-100 min of CO2 flux from the soil. Measurements made with chambers of different volumes showed no significant difference in either soda lime or IRGA estimates of CO2 efflux. Disturbance of chambers in the field did not stimulate short-term rates of soil respiration when measured with an IRGA, nor could temporal scaling be shown to markedly overestimate CO2 efflux rates.

index.de: boreal forests\carbon dioxide\forest plantations\forest soils\forests\infrared spectroscopy\measurement\respiration\techniques

bibl.do: New Zealand Journal of Forestry Science
bibl.et: Genotypic variation in symptoms of upper mid-crown yellowing and Cyclaneusma minus in a Pinus radiata stand.
bibl.aa: New Zealand Forest Research Institute, Private Bag 3020, Rotorua, New Zealand.

ab.p: In New Zealand, low needle retention in Pinus radiata is often associated with infection by a needle-cast fungus, Cyclaneusma minus, and with a condition known as upper mid-crown yellowing (UMCY). Variability in the expression of these 2 disorders is known to be controlled by both environmental and genetic factors. In order to estimate the degree of genetic control, adjacent seedlings and clonal trees (6 clones selected for vigour in the nursery) were assessed at age 22 yr for symptoms of UMCY and of C. minus in stands thinned to 3 final-crop stocking rates. Estimates of genotypic and non-genetic variance and of broad-sense heritability (ratio of genotypic to phenotypic variance) were obtained in 2 ways: (a) by subtracting the observed within-clone variance from the phenotypic variance of seedling trees, and (b) by directly estimating clone-to-clone variance. Values obtained by these methods agreed well with each other and with earlier estimates made in a nearby seed orchard. Factors related to method of propagation and physiological ageing are, therefore, unlikely to inflate clonal variation. Clones may be the more cost-effective indicator for UMCY studies. Genotypic variance in resistance to both disorders is considered to be sufficiently high (at least 64% for UMCY and 44% for C. minus) to warrant consideration in silvicultural practices.

bibl.et: Decay patterns of CCB treated Eucalyptus camaldulensis Dehn and CCA treated Heritiera fomes Buch.- Ham poles.
bibl.aa: Office of the Timber Products Specialist, Wood Testing and Research Laboratory, Rural Electrification Board (REB), REB HQ Building, Joarsahara, Khilkhet, Dhaka-1229, Bangladesh.

ab.p: Studies on the decay pattern and suitability of CCB treated Eucalyptus camaldulensis, and CCA-C treated Heritiera fomes poles reveal that Eucalyptus camaldulensis is more suitable for wood poles if the whole of the sapwood is treated with a fixed type of preservative. The boron compound in CCB leaches out from outer surfaces of poles but all components of CCA-type C remain in wood. CCA-C treated H. fomes poles failed earlier due to incomplete penetration of inner sapwood as well as transition wood. Low concentration of copper and chromium compounds can protect the attack by decay fungi but equivalent boron compounds can not protect the attack of termites. It was observed that the service life of poles is increased with an increase in the thickness of the treated shell.

ab.p: In 1996, FERIC compared the value of logs manufactures by various systems at two sites in coastal second-growth forests in British Columbia. At site 1, the value recovered by a Timberjack 1270 single-grip harvester manufacturing short logs at the stump was compared with the theoretical maximum value as predicted by a grader. Also, the log value recovered by a conventional manual falling and bucking system was compared with that of a grader. At site 2, the value recovered by a Steyr KP60 processor manufacturing conventional length logs from tree lengths at roadside was compared with the values as predicted by a grader, and by a bucker at roadside.

bibl.et: Biosorption of metals for wood waste effluent clean up.
bibl.re: Paper prepared for the 28th Annual Meeting of the IRG, Whistler, Canada, 25 May to 30 May, 1997. 12 ref.
bibl.aa: CTBA, Centre Technique du Bois et de l'Ameublement, 10 avenue de St-Mandé, 75012 Paris, France.

ab.p: The common filamentous fungi can sorb metal ions from aqueous solutions. The biosorption of metal ions like copper Cu2+, chromium Cr6+ and arsenic As5+ by dead fungal mycelia was investigated. Two industrial fermentation byproducts were tested: Mucor miehei [Rhizomucor miehei] and Aspergillus oryzae. The adsorption of metal ions depends on parameters such as chemical treatment of fungi before biosorption (acid or basic treatment), pH, adsorption time, metal ions and biomass concentrations. 88% of Cu2+ was recovered in one hour by Aspergillus oryzae and Mucor miehei (untreated and basic biomass). Cr6+ was adsorbed in 24 hours by these untreated biomass with a yield comprising between 40% and 65%. Similar results were observed for As5+ adsorption with Mucor miehei in regulated pH conditions. The most efficient systems - Aspergillus oryzae (basic treatment) and Mucor miehei (untreated) - were investigated in adsorption experiments on copper chrome arsenate (CCA)-preservative solution (3% m/m). The adsorption yields for copper and chromium were respectively 90% and 80% in 24 hours. Removal of metals from CCA waste water could be realized by these developed systems on site instead of conventional expensive processes.

bibl.et: Long-term changes in water and soil chemistry in spruce and beech forests, Solling, Germany.
bibl.aa: Department of Soil Science and Geology, Agricultural University Wageningen, P.O. Box 37, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands.

ab.p: Long-term changes (1969-91) in the chemistry of bulk precipitation, throughfall water, soil water, and exchangeable base cations were analysed in a beech (Fagus sylvatica) and a spruce (Picea abies) forest in Solling, Germany. Time trends in dissolved and exchangeable pools of base cations in the soils were compared with simulations from a simple mechanistic soil chemistry model to identify the processes controlling long-term changes in soil chemistry. In the early 1970s, profound acidification occurred in the spruce and beech soils due to increasing concentrations of dissolved SO4. After 1976, atmospheric deposition of SO4 decreased significantly as a result of reduced industrial emissions. Nevertheless, acidification continued in the spruce soil due to declining atmospheric inputs of Ca and Mg and continuously high dissolved SO4 in the soil. In the beech soil, with lower deposition levels, smaller declines of base cation deposition, and a more diluted soil solution, reduced atmospheric inputs of SO4 in the 1980s started a recovery of the soil's base saturation.

bibl.et: Effects of annual fires on the production of fleshy fruits eaten by birds in a Brazilian Amazonian savanna.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Ecologia, Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia, Caixa Postal 478, 69.011-970, Manaus - AM, Brazil.

ab.p: A study was conducted during 1985 to 1992 to analyse the fruiting of different plant species in 1 ha of Amazonian savanna on the bank of the Tapajós River, Brazil, dominated by the grasses Paspalum carinatum and Trachypogon plumosus. The study evaluated the fleshy fruits from tree and shrub-layer species eaten by birds (e.g. Protium heptaphyllum, Anacardium occidentale, Bellucia dichotoma, Eugenia biflora, amasonia arborea, Smilax santaremensis and Chomella ribesioides). The area was burned in the first 2 years, protected during the following 2 years and burned again in the last 2 years. The number of tree species fruiting did not differ significantly between years with or without fire. The number of shrub-layer species fruiting was markedly reduced in years with fire, but the responses varied between species. Data on changes in shrub cover after 2 consecutive years of fire indicated that species also responded differently in terms of the biomass lost due to fire. The 2 most abundant genera of shrubs, Miconia and Myrcia, had their cover reduced by up to 95% and 72%, respectively. The area made available due to the loss of shrubs was occupied mainly by the grass Paspalum carinatum. The fires and the decrease in the availability of fruits occurred during the season in which most species of birds breed, and it is suggested that an interval of less than 3 years between fires may be insufficient for shrub-layer species to recover.

bibl.do: General Technical Report - North Central Forest Experiment Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.et: Changes in down dead wood volume across a chronosequence of silvicultural openings in southern Indiana forests.
bibl.ct: 11th central hardwood forest conference. Proceedings of a meeting held at the University of Missouri, Columbia, MO, March 23-26, 1997.
bibl.pb: North Central Forest Experiment Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry and Natural Resources, 1159 Forestry Building, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907-1159, USA.

ab.p: The volume and decay stages of fallen dead wood were evaluated across a chronosequence of 46 silvicultural openings and 10 uncut control stands in Fagus/Acer saccharum/Arisaema forests to determine how fallen dead wood volume changes with stand development. Openings ranged in age from 8 to 26 years and were divided into 3 age groups: (a)<12 years, (b) 12-16 years, and (c) <greater than>16 years. Individual logs were assigned to decay stages ranging from freshly fallen (stage 1) to near total decomposition (stage 5). The volumes of fallen dead wood in age groups (a) and (b) were greater than those of the control plots (80-100 years old) and decreased with increasing plant age. This trend held true for both large and small diameter material. Fallen dead wood from decay stages 1 and 5 was scarce in all opening age groups. Age group 1 and 2 plots contained significantly greater volumes of moderately decayed material (decay stages 3 and 4) than the control stands. It was concluded that after an initial pulse of fallen dead wood just after cutting, dead wood decreased with stand age in mid-successional stands (such as the control stands in this study) and was much lower than in old growth stands.

bibl.et: Large-scale comparison of reforestation techniques commonly used in the Lower Mississippi alluvial valley: first year results.
bibl.ct: 11th central hardwood forest conference. Proceedings of a meeting held at the University of Missouri, Columbia, MO, March 23-26, 1997.
bibl.pb: North Central Forest Experiment Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Center for Bottomland Hardwood Research, Southern Research Station, Stoneville, MS 38876, USA.

ab.p: Four methods of restoring bottomland hardwood forests were compared in studies in Sharkey County, Mississippi, USA. 32-ha plots were either left to old field succession, planted with Nuttall oak (Quercus nuttallii) with or without a companion crop of Populus deltoides, or acorns were direct sown. Planting took place in March 1995, direct sowing in May and the plots were assessed in autumn. Survival was 92% for P. deltoides, 63% for planted oaks and 11% for oaks from acorns. No trees were found in the old field succession plots. Seedling damage by rodents was evident. Establishment of planted oaks was sufficient for wetland restoration purposes irrespective of the nurse crop, the main function of which would be to provide wildlife habitat and income in about 10 years.

bibl.et: Canopy gaps in rain forest on Christmas Island, Indian Ocean: size distribution and methods of measurement.
bibl.aa: Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, Monash University, Clayton, Victoria 3168, Australia.

ab.p: A method described by Brokaw, N. V. L. in 1982 (Biotropica 114 (2) 158-160) to measure canopy gaps used at least 8 coordinates of direction and distance, and considered that irregularities of outline tended to cancel out in the final estimate of size. This method was tested with data from tropical rain forest gaps on Christmas Island, and gap sizes on the island were compared with those of mainland tropical forests. Brokaw's definition of a forest gap (any 'hole' extending through all vegetation layers of the surrounding vegetation to within 2 m of the ground) was extended to include gaps in which openings extended to an average height of 3 m above the ground, and direction/distance coordinates were increased to 16 compass directions (N., NNE, NE, ENE etc.). Some 54 (90%) of the 60 gaps measured were formed by the fall of 1 or more trees, and 6 (10%) by the fall of large branches. Gaps ranged in size from 17 to 700 m², with 90% ≤120 m². Median gap area was 40-60 m², but size distribution was strongly skewed towards smaller sizes, and exclusion of the 1 large 700 m² gap gave an average size of 45.9 m². Comparison of size estimates made using 8 and 16 distance/direction coordinates indicated that (assuming the 16-coordinate estimates to be more accurate) the 8-coordinate method underestimated gap size, usually by 10-20%, and less frequently by 0-10 and 20-30%. The gap sizes reported are similar to those for other tropical forests.

bibl.et: Influence of rubber (Hevea brasiliensis) tree shade on growth performance and seed yield of pigeon pea (Cajanus cajan) intercrop.
bibl.aa: Regional Research Laboratory, Bhubaneswar 751 013, India.

ab.p: Rubber (Hevea brasiliensis) plants obtained by bud grafting 1-yr-old seedlings were transplanted into a well prepared field site at Bhubaneswar, Orissa, in June 1990-93 [spacing not given]. In October 1994, when the rubber plants were 1-4 yr old, pigeon peas (Cajanus cajan) var. ICPL-85063 (ICRISAT) were sown as an intercrop, leaving a 1.5 m uniform space around the saplings, and maintaining 45-50 cm between intercrop rows, which had 10-15 cm spacing between plants. Measurements were made of light conditions and crop growth and yields in each treatment, including a pigeon pea monoculture in the open. With gradual increase in rubber tree shade there was a progressive decrease in pigeon pea height, numbers of branches and pods, seeds per plant and per hectare grain yield. General growth parameters and yield of pigeon pea were higher in the first, second and third year of rubber growth, but were abruptly reduced in the fourth year due to closure of the tree canopy. Light intercepted by the pigeon peas followed the same pattern, falling from 53.25% in the open, through 51.78-42.55% in the 1-3 yr old rubber plants, to 8.44% in the 4-yr-old plants. The results suggest that pigeon peas can be grown in the inter-row spaces profitably in the first 3 years of rubber growth but that its continuation beyond this will be uneconomic.

bibl.et: Management of spruce (Picea smithiana) and silver fir (Abies pindrow) forests in western Himalayas.
bibl.aa: Correspondence address: Department of Forestry, PNG University of Technology, Lae, Papua New Guinea.

ab.p: An account is given of the management of spruce/silver fir temperate coniferous forests of Western Himalayas, based on a study area of 2551.50 ha in Rajgarh Forest Division, Himachal Pradesh. The forests were stock mapped and total enumeration carried out. Growth data were collected from sample trees and plots and local volume tables prepared. Growing stock and annual increments were assessed (average volume 327.37 m³/ha.; average number of trees 324.2/ha.; average annual increment 7.09 m³/ha). Forests are to be managed under a selection system with ≥60 cm exploitable diameter and a 15-year felling cycle. The yield is to be regulated by the number of selection trees recruited from lower diameter classes to exploitable diameter class during the felling cycle and expressed as a percentage. Provision for the removal of over-mature trees is made to avoid decay. The annual prescribed yield for deodar (Cedrus deodara), kail (Pinus wallichiana) and spruce/silver fir is fixed at 36, 18 and 900 selection trees which are 35, 35 and 30% of the total number of selection trees, and 32, 15 and 45% of the annual volume increments of the species, respectively. Managed under this selection system, the forests will achieve normalcy in due course and provide sustained yield in perpetuity.

bibl.et: Ecological studies on Rosa webbiana Wall. ex Royle in cold desert areas of Spiti Valley in Himachal Pradesh.
bibl.aa: Conifers Research Centre, Shimla (Himachal Pradesh), India.

ab.p: Rosa webbiana is a deciduous shrub with edible fruits with a high vitamin C content, found on dry open slopes of the inner Himalayas. The study area had practically no forest, and consequently shrubs like R. webbiana are use for the energy requirements of the local people. As well as on-site studies, investigations on propagation of the species were also undertaken at the Conifers Research Centre, Shimla. The seeds should be treated with concentrated sulfuric acid for 20 minutes to enhance germination. Propagated can also be carried out by stem cuttings and root suckers. Stems and branches contribute the most to total biomass, followed by roots and leaves in that order. Approximately 20 shoots sprout from a single root stock and form a colony over barren slopes which controls erosion. Total biomass on a dry weight basis was 5.42 kg/plant and the energy value ranged from 3.1 to 4.2 kcal/g dry weight. An average bush accumulates 20615 kcal of energy per plant.

bibl.et: Analysis of threats to Gir ecosystem.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Wildlife protection.
bibl.aa: Gir (W) Division, Junagadh (Gujarat), India.

ab.p: An analysis is made of threats to Gir forest ecosystem sanctuary/protected area in Gujarat. The major threats to this are mostly anthropogenic and include illegal grazing by domestic livestock, encroachment for agricultural use, illegal removal of forest produce, poaching, traffic and transport, pilgrimage, tourism, development of industries and large-scale mining, forest fires and man-wild animal conflicts. Quantitative and qualitative assessments are made of these threats. A narrow genetic base due to inbreeding also poses a significant threat to the survival of Asian lion in the area. Administrative shortcomings to the efficient management of the area are also discussed.

bibl.et: An experimental test of habitat selection by rodents of Algonquin Park.
bibl.aa: Department of Zoology, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON N1G 2W1, Canada.

ab.p: Using an enclosure experiment, it was tested if substrate selection by deer mice (Peromyscus maniculatus), redback voles (Clethrionomys gapperi) and woodland jumping mice (Napaeozapus insignis) matched habitat-use patterns determined from trapping data. Mice were introduced into a 5 m diameter enclosure containing substrates from 3 habitats, maple (Acer saccharum), mixed (Picea glauca and Populus tremuloides) and coniferous (Pinus strobus and Picea glauca) forests. Trapping data (1991-95) were taken from a long-term monitoring study of small mammal populations in Algonquin Park, Ontario, Canada. If competition or predation affects habitat distribution patterns, then, given a choice, mice should select different substrates in the enclosures from those they use in the field. Alternatively, if habitat use is not constrained by interactions with competitors or predators, then habitats used in the enclosure should match habitat distributions observed in the field. Habitats used in the field did not match habitats selected in the enclosure experiment for deer mice and woodland jumping mice. Redback voles selected habitats similar to those used in the field. It is concluded that interspecific competition and/or predation may limit availability of habitats for deer mice and woodland jumping mice.

Systematic forest observations have been performed since 1990 as part of the International Co-operative Programme on Assessment and Monitoring of Air Pollution Effects on Forests and since 1994 within the Forest Health Monitoring Programme. Data on tree crown conditions showed that stands of the most common tree species were relatively slightly damaged and that defoliation had a tendency to decrease.

bibl.et: Study on the performance of nail joints assembled with Taiwania lumber from thinning.

ab.p: Taiwania (Taiwania cryptomerioides) lumber from thinnings was used as the assembling members in an investigation of the performance of nailed joints. The influence of diameter of box nails, number of nails used, and position of lumber in the tree trunk, on the lateral resistance of nail joints, were analysed. The results indicated that an averaged 100.7% increment in lateral resistance was found for each additional box nail up to five nails in a row. The values of lateral resistance of nailing substrates cut from logs with larger diameter was 11.7% lower than those from thinning logs. However, an average 112.4% increment per nail was found as the number of nails increased. The lateral resistance of nail joints fabricated with 10d box nails was 1.25 times as much as those fabricated with 8d nails due to the larger diameter of the nail shanks. There were 39.9% and 64.4% increments in initial rigidity of nail joint fabricated with every additional nail up to five 8d and 10d nails, respectively. Furthermore, the initial rigidity of nail joint fabricated with 10d nails was 25.2% higher than that of 8d nails.

bibl.et: Evaluation of the combustion gas toxicity of fire-retardant treated lignocellulosic materials.

ab.p: The main purpose of this study was to investigate the combustion gas toxicity of fire-retardant-treated wood (Cunninghamia lanceolata) and pulp board with nine formulations of fire retardant. The combustion gas toxicity of the fire-retardant-treated specimens were evaluated by the toxicity index method prescribed in the UK Naval Engineering Standard (NES) 713 and the mice exposure method adopted by the Japanese Building Regulation, which is the same as the Ministry of Construction Notification 1231-1976. The untreated specimens were also tested in the same way for comparison. The experimental results are summarized as follows: (1). The fire-retardant treatment of China fir and pulp board specimens limited the development of CO2 and CO gases, but reinforced that of the other gases. (2). When the specimens were completely ignited, the total toxicity of the gases produced increased with increasing retention of fire-retardant chemicals. (3). The gases developed from the treated specimens had less influence on the mice than that from the untreated ones in the same exposure time when the specimens were not completely ignited. (4). The incapacitation time of mice was strongly affected by the amounts of CO2 and CO gases developed.

bibl.et: In vitro propagation of Nothofagus nervosa (Phil.) Dim. et Mil.
bibl.aa: PROVEG-CADIC, cc 92 (9410) Ushuaia, Tierra del Fuego, Argentina.

ab.p: A study was carried out to determine suitable culture conditions for in vitro propagation of Nothofagus nervosa. A medium with a low salt concentration as broadleaved tree medium plus L-glutamine was suitable for shoot multiplication. Multiplication rates of 1:7 to 1:11 were obtained with 0.55 µ&smallcap;M BA (6-benzylaminopurine) at the 63th day. Rooted shoots (96.7%) were obtained with 0.61 µ&smallcap;M IBA (indole-3-butyric acid) and one week darkness at the induction stage. Rooted plants were then acclimated and 50% survival was obtained after 2 months.

bibl.et: An approach to tree plantation by auger hole method.
bibl.aa: Soil Science Division, Bangladesh Forest Research Institute (BFRI), Chittagong, GPO Box No. 273, Bangladesh.

ab.p: The common pit size for tree seedling planting is 30×30×30 cm, but smaller sizes would be cheaper in labour costs, especially on sloping land. Tests were made in 1992-94 of the survival and growth of seedlings of Acacia auriculiformis and Hopea odorata in 3 pit sizes (30×30×30, 20×20×20 and 15×15×15 cm) at sites in Bangladesh (for A. auriculiformis on the upper ridges of the Sitakunda High Hills, and for H. odorata on degraded low hill slopes at the BFRI campus). The 2 larger size pits were made using the traditional hoe method, and the smallest using an auger. Survival and growth data at 3, 9 and 18 months after planting showed no superiority of the larger pit sizes. The larger pit sizes took 2-3× as long to dig as the smaller one (and had associated greater costs), and the smaller one was also advantageous in minimizing soil erosion. Its use is, therefore, recommended.

bibl.do: Mokchae Konghak = Journal of the Korean Wood Science and Technology
bibl.et: The relationship between anatomical characteristics and compression strength parallel to grain in major species of Lepidobalanus.
bibl.ms: English figures and tables.
bibl.aa: College of Agriculture, Chonbuk National University, Chonju 561-756, Korea.

ab.p: This study was carried out to get some basic information on mechanical properties of Korea Lepidobalanus for rational utilization of wood. Five species - Quercus variabilis, Q. aliena, Q. serrata, Q. mongolica, Q. acutissima belonging to Lepidobalanus were investigated in this research. The relationship of anatomical characteristics to compression strength parallel to grain was analysed using stepwise regression technique. All possible combinations of 21 independent variables were regressed on compression strength parallel to grain. Among the proportion of wood structural elements, the factors that had the greatest influence on compression strength parallel to grain appeared to be proportion of ray in earlywood in Q. variabilis and Q. acutissima, proportion of wood fibre in latewood in Q. aliena and Q. serrata and proportion of vessel in earlywood in Q. mongolica respectively. In the size of wood element and its structure, the factors that had the greatest influence on compression strength parallel to grain were microfibril angle in Q. variabilis, Q. serrata and Q. mongolica and length of wood fibre in Q. aliena and Q. acutissima.

bibl.et: Leucaena: A genetic resources handbook.
bibl.pb: Oxford Forestry Institute, University of Oxford
bibl.ms: Also available in Spanish.
bibl.aa: Oxford Forestry Institute, Department of Plant Sciences, University of Oxford, South Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3RB, UK.

ab.p: This publication is an output from international research projects funded by the UK Department for International Development (DFID) under the Forestry Research Programme. It was originally conceived as a means of communicating and disseminating more widely the results of research work carried out by the Oxford Forestry Institute (OFI) over a decade, but alongside presenting this work, the handbook also assembles, synthesizes and presents data from previous research on all aspects of Leucaena genetic resources. There are 11 chapters: Introduction; Systematics; Species characteristics; Ethnobotany and indigenous domestication; Hybrids; Germplasm collections; Seeds: collection, processing, storage and pretreatment; Conservation; Domestication; Identification - a key; and Species accounts - silvicultural characters, ecology, taxonomy. Four appendices provide (1) a checklist of accepted names, synonyms, doubtful and excluded names and types, (2) details of the OFI Leucaena seed collections, (3) details of seed distribution and trials, and (4) details of the OFI Material Transfer Agreement. An index to scientific names is included.

ab.p: Taiwania cryptomerioides is an economically important tree species indigenous to Taiwan. This paper reviews the extractives isolated and identified from the [wood], which include 9 lignans, 8 flavones, 21 sesquiterpenoids, 18 diterpenoids, 3 lipids, 2 cyclitols, and 1 steroid. bibl.et: Effects of environment and grazing disturbance on tree establishment in meadows of the central Cascade Range, Oregon, USA.
bibl.aa: Division of Ecosystem Science and Conservation, College of Forest Resources, Box 352100, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98195-2100, USA.

ab.p: Within the last century there has been widespread establishment of trees (mainly Abies grandis, Pseudotsuga menziesii, A. lasiocarpa, Picea engelmannii, Tsuga mertensiana and Pinus contorta) in mountain meadows of the Pacific Northwest. Patterns of tree invasion at 17 meadow sites in the central Cascade Range of Oregon, USA were reconstructed. These sites represented diverse physical environments and vegetation types and had different histories of recent anthropogenic disturbance (sheep grazing). Spatial distributions and age structures of invasive tree populations were analysed with respect to climatic records and grazing history. Patterns of establishment varied considerably among meadows, reflecting strong differences in environment and grazing history. In montane hydric meadows, tree establishment was spatially clumped beneath large old trees and on elevated microsites; however the timing of invasion differed between sites with stable versus fluctuating water tables. In upland mesic/dry montane meadows, timing of invasion corresponded with cessation of sheep grazing (early 1940s) and the onset of wetter summers (mid 1940s). In the subalpine zone, climate and aspect interacted to produce contrasting histories of invasion on north-and south-facing slopes. Establishment on north-facing slopes, concentrated in heath-shrub communities, coincided with regional warming (about 1920-1945) when snow packs were lighter and melted earlier. Recruitment of trees onto south-facing slopes occurred later, when conditions were wetter (1945-1985). In many environments, the spatial distribution of recruitment suggested that once trees have established, autogenic factors become increasingly important as individual trees or groups of trees alter the physical or biotic conditions that once inhibited establishment. Knowledge of the factors that influence invasion, and of their varying importance across gradients in environment and vegetation, is critical to predicting future changes in these dynamic systems.

bibl.et: Investigating canopy regeneration processes through individual-based spatial models: application to a tropical rain forest.
bibl.aa: Correspondence address: CNRS UMR 5558, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, 43 Bd du 11 Novembre 1918, 69622 Villeurbanne cedex, France.

ab.p: Observations of circular structures in a permanent plot in a natural dense tropical rain forest of the Western Ghats (India) led to formulation of new hypotheses on the spatial organization resulting from interactions between trees, and a canopy regeneration process is proposed that does not involve treefall gaps. The peculiar spatial circular structure observed is composed of a central dominant tree with less than 2 trees under its crown and 5 or more other trees forming a ring at the limit of its crown. Such a structure is supposed to occur under certain conditions, and in particular, under strong competition for light. A regeneration mechanism is described based on replacement of the central tree by a shift to one of the trees in its peripheral ring so that progressive recovery of the canopy occurs without large gap dynamics. A spatial simulator of forest dynamics was built in order to investigate the occurrence of such spatial structures and to examine their role in canopy regeneration. The model is an individual-based spatial model for mixed uneven-aged forest stands and accounts for annual evolution of the trees in the simulated stand, incorporating mortality, recruitment, growth and competition processes. The main originality of this model lies in the description of crown growth in 8 cardinal directions, and in the use of neighbour position and size to express competitive interactions. The model demonstrates the development of the circular spatial structures in simulated stands like those observed in the permanent tropical forest plot and shows that the proposed canopy regeneration mechanism can occur in the absence of perturbation.

bibl.et: Contrasting seed storage behaviour among different species of Meliaceae.
bibl.aa: Department of Agriculture, The University of Reading, Earley Gate, PO Box 236, Reading RG6 6AT, UK.

ab.p: Seeds of six species of Meliaceae were tested for germination following desiccation and subsequent hermetic storage for up to 26 months in different environments. Seeds of both Aglaia clarkii and Sandoricum koetjape were very sensitive to desiccation; no seeds survived desiccation to 20% moisture content or below. In contrast, stones of Melia azedarach survived desiccation to 3.5% moisture content and viability was maintained during 26 months' subsequent hermetic storage in 14 of the 15 environments which combined factorially five stone moisture contents between 3.5 and 11.7% with three temperatures between -20°C, and 10°C, the exception being that environment which provided the highest moisture content and temperature (i.e. 10°C with 11.7% moisture content) in which loss in viability was considerable. Seeds of Azadirachta indica tolerated desiccation to moisture contents in equilibrium at 20°C with 30-55% r.h. depending on seed lot, and a considerable proportion of seeds survived further desiccation to moisture contents in equilibrium with 6.5 to 30% r.h. Seeds of Swietenia macrophylla and Khaya senegalensis were more tolerant of desiccation than those of Azadirachta indica, but some loss in viability was detected on desiccation to moisture contents in equilibrium with 17% r.h. Moreover, the longevity of all three species in hermetic air-dry storage was shorter at cooler (-20°C and 0°C) than at warmer (10°C) temperatures. It is concluded that Aglaia clarkii and Sandoricum koetjape show recalcitrant seed storage behaviour, while Melia azedarach shows orthodox seed storage behaviour, but that Azadirachta indica, Khaya senegalensis and Swietenia macrophylla show intermediate seed storage behaviour. It is suggested that combining information on four criteria (seed weight, shape, moisture content at maturity, and plant ecology) may provide a guide to likely seed storage behaviour in Meliaceae.

bibl.do: Tree root damage to buildings. Volume 1: causes, diagnosis and remedy. Volume 2: patterns of soil drying in proximity to trees on clay soils.
bibl.et: Tree root damage to buildings. Volume 1: causes, diagnosis and remedy. Volume 2: patterns of soil drying in proximity to trees on clay soils.
bibl.aa: Willowmead, Ickleton Road, Wantage, Oxon. OX12 9JA, UK.

ab.p: This 2-volume set of books provides a comprehensive analysis of, and practical guide to, how the interaction of trees, soils and water can cause foundation movement and damage to buildings. The problems addressed are multidisciplinary, involving structural engineers, engineers, arboriculturalists, soil scientists, insurers and their loss adjusters, architects, and builders and planners, as well as providing work to the legal profession. All aspects of the problems involved are addressed. Volume 1 has 20 chapters, each with a brief summary and a case study at the end; essential points are highlighted. The first 10 chapters describe the interactions of trees, soils, water and buildings: (1) Introduction; (2) The tree - an account of tree physiology and growth; (3) The root system; (4) The soil - types and behaviour in relation to water content; (5) Seasonal changes in soil moisture content; (6) Persistent moisture deficits - when the winter process of rewetting of the soil after summer drying is not complete; (7) Interaction between trees and buildings - soil and foundation movements, buildings and persistent water deficit, and the influences of buildings on the soil and tree roots; (8) Influence of the weather; (9) Comparative effects of different species, and of individual trees and groups; and (10) Other forms of damage by tree roots - direct physical damage and damage to drains and underground services. Chapters 11-16 describe the investigation of damage: (11) Strategy for investigating damage; (12-14) Site investigations: I. The building; II, The soil; and III. The tree; (15) Monitoring building movement; and (16) Heave and recovery: diagnosis and prediction. Chapters 17-20 address remedy and prevention: (17) Remedial action after damage; (18) Prediction and prevention of damage; (19) The legal framework; and (20) A revised role for the professions. Volume 1 ends with a list of references, cross references between botanical and common names, and a subject index. Volume 2 presents the accumulated results from 3 research projects which started in 1978 (with the Milton Keynes (UK) Development Corporation), and were extended in 1981 (under instruction from the UK National House-Building Council) and 1983 (under instruction from the UK Department of the Environment). These investigated the pattern of soil drying, both spatially and with time, that occurs in the proximity of trees on clay soils. A total of 60 trees on open-field sites were studied. These included a range of tree species and clay soil types. The relevance and application of these results to urban situations are addressed in Volume 1. The methods used in the research are described in the introduction to Volume 2 - they involved the use of 5 neutron probe access tubes per tree, by means of which the soil water profiles of each were monitored over long periods. The rest of the volume presents detailed research data for each tree, including photographs and coloured diagrams. These cover the overall time period 1978-94, although different periods apply to different trees.

bibl.do: Economic assessment of selected forest uses in the Central Highlands of Victoria: final report. ABARE report to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.
bibl.et: Economic assessment of selected forest uses in the Central Highlands of Victoria: final report. ABARE report to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.
bibl.pb: Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE)
bibl.ms: ABARE Project 1406

ab.p: In order to address the conflicts arising over the use of Australia's native forests, Commonwealth and state governments have have established Comprehensive Regional Assessments (CRAs) of Australian forests. The aim is to sign joint Commonwealth-state Regional Forest Agreements (RFAs) which will set out agreed uses for the duration of the agreement. ABARE's role in the RFA process in the Central Victorian Highlands is to assess the economic implications of the forest resource use options for the region. The topics addressed are: existing resource use and forest industry structure; major resource use options other than conservation (including major and minor forest products, mining, tourism and apiculture); forest industry development options (based on potential resource access, quantity and quality, market possibilities and industry development plans, including the potential for internationally competitive value added projects); and realistic combinations of resource use and industry development options, and their economic consequences. The results of the analysis are presented in 7 chapters: (1) Introduction; (2) Economic values of natural resources; (3) Forest related industries in the Central Highlands; (4) The Central Highlands timber industry - sawntimber, pulpwood processing, outlook for logging and wood processing industries and forest products markets, and development opportunities; (5) Mineral resources and mining; (6) Tourism and recreation; and (7) Other forest uses and minor timber products.

bibl.et: Recultivation of short rotation coppice.
bibl.ft: Rekultivierung von Kurzumtriebsplantagen.
bibl.aa: Bayerischen Landesanstalt für Landtechnik, Vöttinger Strasse 36, D-85354 Freising, Germany.

ab.p: For recultivation of poplar [Populus spp.] and willow [Salix spp.] stands, various implements and measures were tested. With surface mulching (forest mulcher), only a 35% reduction of regrowth was attained. By using a stool rotavator (40 cm tillage depth), regrowth was reduced by 80%. Combining both measures with additional cultivation of a follow crop was even more effective. From time studies and the cost rates for machine use, recultivation costs are mostly below 1000.-DM per ha.

bibl.et: Tractor-mounted chain delimber in the production of fuelwood longwood.
bibl.ft: Maataloustraktorin ketjukarsintalaite polttopuurankojen valmistuksessa.
bibl.aa: TTS-Institue (Work Efficienct Institute), Forestry Bulletin, Box 28, FIN-00211, Helsinki, Finland.

ab.p: The efficiency and costs of using a mechanical delimber were studied. The mean diameter of pine [Pinus], spruce [Picea] and birch [Betula] raw material delimbed by the chain delimber was between 5 and 9 cm with average lengths of between 3.0 and 4.7 m. Delimbing productivity was 2.5-2.9 m³/h at the landing using a loader, and 0.9 m³/h in the woods when fed manually (1.0 m³/h when a loader was used). Technical problems encountered included jamming of wood at the output opening and rapid filling up with delimbing debris of the space under the chain axles. Freshly-felled trees were processed more efficiently than dried wood. After storage for 3.5 months wood moisture content was between 2 and 13% lower than wood delimbed by bill hook or chainsaw. Production costs were M125-168/m³ at the landing and M110/m³ in the woods, this is M15-58/m³ more than using a chainsaw.

bibl.et: The generic position of Lithraea brasiliensis Marchand (Anacardiaceae): evidence from fruit and seed structure.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa.

ab.p: Material of Lithraea brasiliensis at RBG Kew is known under the name Rhus brasiliensis, a combination that has never been validly published. The anatomy of the pericarp and seed coat of L. brasiliensis was studied, from herbarium material collected in Santa Catarina, Brazil, to see if there is any evidence to support this combination. From the results, the similarity of the inner mesocarp and osteosclereid layer suggest a very close alliance of L. brasiliensis with species of Rhus.

bibl.et: Ziziphus for drylands - a perennial crop solving perennial problems.
bibl.aa: Central Arid Zone Research Institute, Jodhpur, Rajasthan 342003, India.

ab.p: An overview is given of cultivation of the multipurpose tree Ziziphus, from the viewpoint of its suitability for drylands in Africa. Wild species such as Z. spina-christi and Z. abyssinica grow naturally in Ethiopia, Zimbabwe, Kenya and other parts of eastern Africa. The Indian species, Z. mauritiana, is already being tested in Senegal and Zimbabwe. The paper outlines climate and soil requirements, and cultural/silvicultural methods, and discusses the use of Ziziphus in agroforestry systems.

bibl.et: Effects of accidental and prescribed fires on miombo woodland, Zambia.
bibl.aa: Biological Sciences Department, University of Zambia, Box 32379, Lusaka, Zambia.

ab.p: This paper discusses the effects of an accidental late dry season fire in a 34-yr-old fire protected plot, and of prescribed annual early and late dry season burning in other experimental plots, on litter and developmental characteristics of coppiced miombo woodland. The plots were set up in 1960 when the old-growth uneven aged miombo woodland was clear felled. Based on measurements made in 1996, compared with early burning, the accidental fire significantly reduced tree species diversity, basal area and surface litter. Annual late burning over a 36-yr period has suppressed woodland development but 9 species considered to be fire-tolerant have persisted. The study supports an early burning policy to reduce the risk of late fires and promote miombo woodland regeneration.

bibl.et: Issues in using valuation techniques cross-culturally: three cases in Zimbabwe using contingent valuation, observed behaviour and derived demand techniques.
bibl.ct: Special issue: 15th Commonwealth Forestry Conference papers. Selected papers from the conference held in Zimbabwe in May 1997.
bibl.aa: Department of Rural Economy, University of Alberta, Edmonton, T6G 2H1, Canada.

ab.p: This paper reviews valuation issues which arose from using three different techniques in case studies of forest resource valuation in Zimbabwe. These involve an exploration of contingent valuation to value alternative uses of a forest, the use of observed behaviour to value one forest product (fuelwood), and the use of derived demand techniques to value a variety of forest products. The studies suggest that despite some problems associated with each of the techniques, they all have promise in specific contexts of forest resource valuation. However, in each case the technique must be applied with much care to be appropriate to the particular institutional, social and cultural setting.

bibl.et: Phenology and flowering periodicity of neotropical dry forest species: evidence from herbarium collections.
bibl.aa: Department of Physiology and Cell Biology, Haworth Hall, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS 66045-2106, USA.

ab.p: To examine the potential contribution of herbarium material to the description and analysis of tropical tree phenology, flowering times and geographical distribution were graphed for 1673 flowering collections from 18 species native to Neotropical dry forests and phenological differences between species were analysed. These include the timing and duration of flowering as well as morphological differences such as flowering on leafless twigs vs. flowering on shoots bearing old or new foliage. Species-specific flowering periods of herbarium collections are similar to those observed in phenological field studies, but are often longer because of the larger geographical and temporal sampling range. Conspecific collections of different geographical origin show distinct differences in flowering periodicity, which are correlated with differences in the timing and intensity of the dry season. Interspecific differences in the timing of phenology relative to the dry season indicate differences in the control of phenology by seasonal drought. Herbaria thus represent a large potential source of phenological information which can either supplement and extend phenological field studies or provide phenological information for dry forest species not studied in the field but well represented in herbarium collections.

bibl.et: Plant phenology in relation to water availability: herbaceous and woody species in the savannas of northern Cameroon.
bibl.aa: ORSTOM, BP. 11416, Niamey, Niger.

ab.p: Phenological patterns of herbaceous and woody plants well represented in the Sudano-Sahelian savannas of northern Cameroon were studied in relation to water availability in 3 contrasted soil types (a ferruginous soil, a typical vertisol, and a badly degraded exploited vertisol) over 20 months including 2 rainy periods (April 1986-November 1987). Mean annual precipitation in this region is 800 mm, entirely restricted to the period May-June to September-October, but redistribution of rainwater by varying soil substrates leads to considerable heterogeneity in available water resources for plants. Results are discussed in terms of probable competition for water resources among co-occurring plants and the adaptations shown by observed patterns to prevailing environmental conditions. Water stress is seen to be a limiting factor to plant growth but does not constitute the sole trigger for the phenological phases observed, nor is it the principal factor responsible for the preponderance of annual species in the herbaceous stratum.

bibl.et: Germination and development of sown mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla King) in secondary tropical dry forest habitats in Costa Rica.
bibl.aa: Corespondence address: Department of Ecological Botany, Uppsala University, Villavägen 14, S-752 36 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: The effects of irradiance, root competition and water availability on germination and seedling establishment of Swietenia macrophylla were investigated in tropical secondary dry forests in the Guanacaste Conservation Area, Costa Rica. The fate of experimental seeds sown in the middle and at the beginning of the rainy season (in August 1991 and May 1992, respectively) was studied in abandoned pasture, and in deciduous and semi-evergreen secondary forest. In the pasture, experimental treatments were mown and unmown grass. In the forest sites, thinning to increase light and trenching to reduce root competition were combined in a factorial design. Effects of moisture availability on germination were tested by supplementing natural rainfall in the initial rainy month. Germination at the beginning of the rainy season was not influenced by the supplementary water and was higher in the semi-evergreen forest than in the deciduous forest and pasture. In the forests, germination was little affected by irradiance or root competition. More seeds germinated in unmown than in mown pasture during the initial rains, but were not influenced by mowing when sown in the peak of the rainy season. Seedling mortality was low (<10%) during the initial months, but increased greatly in the dry season. Seedlings germinating early in the rainy season had a higher survival than those germinating later. The relatively slight effects of the different treatments and habitats on seedling establishment suggest that this species is rather insensitive to the large microsite variation in secondary vegetation.

ab.p: The influence of alkaline dust pollution (pH of water solution of dust 12.3-12.7) from a cement plant (Kunda town, Estonia) on chlorophylls and carotenoids of the needles of 60-80 year old Norway spruce [Picea abies] was studied on sample plots established at different distances from the emission source. The highest sensitivity to dust impact was measured in the content of chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, carotenoids and elements regulating or participating in the biosynthesis of pigments (Mg, Fe, N, Mn).

bibl.et: New data concerning the evolution of the vegetation in Lillo pinewood (Leon, Spain).
bibl.aa: Unidad de Botánica, Dpto Biología, Facultad Ciencias, Universidad Autónoma de Madrid, E-28049 Madrid, Spain.

ab.p: A pollen study is presented of a peat bog sited in the pinewood of Lillo, which is the only mass of Pinus sylvestris in the Cantabrian Range of Spain. The diagram shows an initial phase where a well-developed pinewood was dominant with deciduous species, followed by a selective clearance process of Pinus. Finally, the pinewood recovers again towards a similar state to that described at the beginning of the profile. Radiocarbon dates point that the timing of peat formation took place around 1720±60 yr BP and the deforestation around 780±80 yr BP. The results have allowed explanation of the autochthonous character of the Lillo pinewood, which remains as one of the few relics of the southern slopes of the Cantabrian Range.

ab.p: A treatment involving dipping seeds in Rhizobium biofertilizer slurry for 24 h and then sowing increased germination of Dalbergia sissoo to 78% (compared with 50% in control untreated seeds). The treatment also increased shoot height and root length of 3-wk-old seedlings to 4.5 and 5.0 cm, respectively, as against 2.8 cm each in the control. The total length of seedlings from treated seeds was almost double that of controls.

bibl.et: Socio-economic considerations for regional farm forestry development.
bibl.aa: Johnstone Centre, Charles Sturt University, PO Box 789, Albury, NSW 2640, Australia.

ab.p: Farm forestry in Australia is increasingly promoted as a national strategy likely to deliver important benefits in terms of expanding opportunities for commercial wood production, assisting the move to more sustainable agriculture and enhancing regional development. While the benefits from farm forestry are often cited as social, economic and environmental in nature, there is little detailed analysis of the extent of the socioeconomic benefits that will flow to regional communities. It is argued that despite increasing interest by landholders, industry and government, it cannot be assumed that the benefits of farm forestry will necessarily be delivered to all stakeholders. As such, farm forestry development needs to be underpinned by adequate analysis of how regional stakeholders, particularly small-scale growers, are to benefit from farm forestry. Australian and international experiences are reviewed to present some of the key socioeconomic considerations for regional farm forestry.

bibl.et: Impact of windthrow risk on the management of forest estates in the Canterbury region in New Zealand.
bibl.aa: Forestry Economics, School of Forestry, University of Canterbury, Private Bag 4800, Christchurch, New Zealand.

ab.p: A model was constructed to address the harvest scheduling problem under risk of occurrence of catastrophic events. The model was made up of an optimization and a simulation model. The optimization model provided an optimal harvest pattern under deterministic conditions. The simulation model modified the optimal harvest pattern according to a function of random risk assessing the performance of the system through net present value (NPV). The model was run a large number of times estimating mean, standard deviation and a frequency distribution for NPV, using as a case study data from a forest estate of 8412 ha located in Canterbury, New Zealand, owned by the Selwyn Plantation Board Limited. The random component of the system was windthrow occurring at different times and with different intensities. Storms were generated randomly over a planning horizon of 50 years considering an average return period of 28 years between 2 successive storms. The intensity of damage was assumed to be proportional to the historical damage. As a result, NPV after taxes regarding the management of the forest estate was reduced by 11% on average. Windthrow brought about economic losses due to reduced harvest following windthrow, reduced recovery (80%), increased total establishment costs, and the fact that trees were harvested before optimal rotation.

ab.p: From 10 May 10 to 5 June 1996, floristic dendrological field studies were conducted on Melos and Kimolos Islands. The woody flora of Melos included 66 species, and 23 of these are reported for the first time, while the woody flora of Kimolos was much poorer, with 28 wild species and 35 cultivated ones. For 32 species occurring on Melos, point maps of distribution were elaborated, mainly on the basis of the author's herbarium and field notes. Two alphabetical lists of cultivated trees and shrubs are also presented.

bibl.et: Useful plants of the Los Tuxtlas rain forest (Veracruz, Mexico): considerations of their market potential.
bibl.aa: Instituto de Ecología, Departamento de Ecologia de los Recursos Naturales, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Apartado Postal 70-275, México D.F. 04510, Mexico.

ab.p: The 640 hectare large Los Tuxtlas rain forest reserve was analysed for the commercial potential of its 860 native flowering plant species. Excluding plants with medicinal or chemical use, 91 species (10.6%) are found in the market, and an additional 72 species (8.4%) were considered to have market potential. For each of the 163 species, the following information is given: scientific and common name, geographic distribution, growth form, use, and market status. Of the 163 species, 2.4% are endemic to the Los Tuxtlas region, 10.4% are restricted to Mexico, 42.3% extend further into Central America, and 39.3% occur also in South America, while 20.2% are found in the West Indies. The majority of species (68.7%) are trees. In terms of use categories, 35.0% are employed for their timber, 32.5% for their fuelwood, 24.5% for ornamental purposes, 22.7% for their edible fruits, leaves or flowers, 11.0% for plywood or paper, 6.1% for artwork and weaving, and 1.2% as fodder plants. The more than 160 marketable species would make it possible to develop species-diverse forests of high commercial value, as an alternative to current land use in which forest is converted into cattle pastures.

bibl.et: Clonal expansion and seedling recruitment of Oregon grape (Berberis nervosa) in Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) forests: comparisons with salal (Gaultheria shallon).
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Resources, Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR 97331, USA.

ab.p: Seedling regeneration and morphology of Oregon grape (Berberis nervosa) and salal (Gaultheria shallon) were studied in thinned and unthinned Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) stands in the central Coast Range, Oregon. Above- and below-ground growth of both species were significantly and negatively correlated with stand density. Oregon grape appears to have less potential for vegetative spread than does salal. It produced two to three times fewer rhizome extensions, and rhizome extensions were only half as long as those of salal. Oregon grape seedlings were common in areas of moss ground cover among patches of the two species. Salal seedlings were restricted to decaying logs. Seedling densities of Oregon grape in thinned stands were more than six times those in unthinned stands. For Oregon grape, understorey establishment is accomplished by seedling establishment and recruitment of new genets. In contrast, salal maintains itself in forest understories primarily through vegetative growth, since its seedling establishment is restricted mainly to decayed wood. Continual recruitment of new aerial stems or ramets enables Oregon grape to maintain a dense cover once it is established in the understorey.

bibl.et: The effect of edge knots on the strength of SPF MSR lumber.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Wood Sci., Univ., of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada.

ab.p: An experimental program was performed to evaluate the impact of adjustments of edge knot visual quality on the tension and bending strengths of 1650f-1.5E 38- by 89-mm Spruce-Pine-Fir [Picea-Pinus-Abies] machine-stress-rated lumber. A closed-form solution was developed to establish the strength property probability distribution of a new combined grade containing visual quality level knots (edge knots). Simulations were conducted verifying the closed-form solution. The results indicate that the level of edge knots to be included in the new grade is important. In this study, the new grade exceeded the bending strength and edgewise modulus of elasticity requirements but failed to meet the tension strength requirement due to the quality and quantity of visual quality level knots included in the grade mix.

bibl.et: Responses of juvenile trees to above- and belowground competition in nutrient-starved Amazonian rain forest.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Sciences, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EA, UK.

ab.p: A study was conducted at La Esmeralda on the Rio Orinoco, Venezuela, during 1993-94 in an Amazonian caatinga vegetation type on waterlogged, nutrient-poor, albic arenosols characterized by a layer of humus-rich sand overlying a bleached white-sand E horizon. Saplings were selected which were 0.6-1.9 m tall, >0.5 m from a mature tree, >2 m from another studied sapling and free of herbivore damage. Twelve saplings for each of 13 tree species (including Bombacopsis amazonica, Caraipa pedunculata, Protium carolense, Macrolobium gracile, Eperua obtusata and Dendropanax arboreus) were selected in canopy gaps and 12 in 1 ha understorey. Trenches were cut to ~40 cm depth, effectively isolating the saplings from below-ground competition with neighbouring vegetation. Within the trenched plots, all seedlings and saplings other than the labelled one were cut at the base and cleared, ensuring that observed effects were not confounded by the effects of competition with neighbouring vegetation. Trenching was also conducted around plots of naturally regenerating seedlings of various phases. Trenching increased the aboveground growth rate of saplings and seedlings of a wide variety of species. Analysis of foliar nutrient concentrations and a fertilizer experiment confirmed that nitrogen was limiting, while measures of soil moisture potential and stomatal resistance gave no indication of water shortage. It is suggested that belowground competition had an impact on growth rate because established trees allocate a large proportion of biomass to fine-root production (further reducing the availability of nutrients in an inherently poor soil), and penetration of daylight to the sapling layer was greater than under other tropical lowland rain forests (1-3% vs. 0.5-1%). Although trenching had no effect on percentage mortality (12% over 18 months), it reduced the percentage of naturally regenerating seedlings exhibiting net leaf loss from 28 to 8%. The magnitude of response was similar in gaps and understorey and was similar among species, and it is suggested that trenching had a greater effect on resource allocation than on the rate of photosynthesis or respiration.

bibl.et: Agroforests: pre-domestication of forest trees or true domestication of forest ecosystems?
bibl.aa: ORSTOM/ICRAF, P.O. Box 161, Bogor 16001, Indonesia.

ab.p: Domestication of forest resources and artificialization of forest ecosystems in tropical forest areas are often encompassed in a linear way: from wild resources to genetically improved trees, from complex ecosystems to controlled tree plantations. This linear evolution might be true for professional forestry or horticulture. However, it does not embrace the complexity of smallholder farmers practices for forest resources utilization. Incorporating forest resources in production systems is not a new practice in the tropics, it even constitute the very basis of a whole facet of indigenous agricultures. But this agroforestry practice is not usually considered as a full domestication process. And, in spite of an increasing amount of academic interest for indigenous forest-like plantation models, agroforestry research is not yet fully considering the prospects of these models as far as forest species are concerned. The paper focuses on the discussion of Indonesian examples of ecosystem manipulation and plant domestication. Complex agroforestry systems have been developed by local people for the management of resources ranging from locally consumed forest fruits to highly valuable industrial products such as resins and latexes. This indigenous agroforestry is presented as an elaborate process of total transfer, not only of selected forest resources, but also of true forest structures, from the sphere of 'nature' to that of 'agriculture'. This process is analysed as a particular domestication strategy which integrates conventional species domestication techniques to an original attempt of ecosystem domestication. Prospects for further developing this 'agroforest strategy' for the domestication of forest species are then discussed.

There are 16 chapters: (1) Agroforestry: definition, principle and importance; (2) Classification of agroforestry; (3) Agroforestry in farming systems; (4) Agroforestry practices - in India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Philippines, Vietnam and Nigeria; (5) Agroforestry in conservation of natural resources; (6) Multipurpose trees and shrubs - brief descriptions of 35 species; (7) Silvicultural techniques in agroforestry; (8) Plantation crop based agroforestry; (9) Fruit and vegetable crops in agroforestry; (10) Supporting technologies for agroforestry development; (11) Compatibility between crops, animals and woody perennials; (12) Agroforestry for degraded lands; (13) Biofertilizers in agroforestry; (14) Economic aspects of agroforestry; (15) Participatory management in forestry; and (16) Agroforestry practicals - 11 practical lessons covering silvicultural practices, different types of agroforestry systems, and erosion control.

bibl.et: Artificial defoliation, decapitation of the terminal bud, and removal of the apical tip of the shoot in sessile oak seedlings and consequences on subsequent growth.
bibl.aa: Unité de recherche croissance, Production et qualité des bois, Institut national de la recherche agronomiqe, Centre de Nancy, F-54280, Champenoux, France.

ab.p: Damage caused by late frost, browsing by game and insect herbivory was simulated on 1-year-old nursery-grown sessile oak (Quercus petraea) seedlings in northeastern France in May 1996. The portion of stem produced during the first growth flush, referred to as the growth unit (GU), was artificially defoliated and/or decapitated, or the apical part of the GU was removed in the period of apparent rest before the second growth flush. In comparison with control seedlings, defoliation, decapitation combined with defoliation, and apical part removal (1) caused earlier production of the GU in the second flush, (2) reduced length and number of leaves in the GU produced during the second flush, (3) consequently reduced the portion of stem produced during the entire growing season (the annual GU), and (4) increased the number of branches of the GU damaged during the first flush. In contrast, decapitation alone caused later production of the GU of the second flush and had apparently no effect on height growth components. In all treatments, the number of branches that developed on the GU produced during the first flush increased.

bibl.et: Biophysical interactions in tropical agroforestry systems.
bibl.ct: Special issue : Directions in agroforestry research. Adapted from selected papers presented to a symposium on tropical agroforestry organized in connection with the annual meetings of the American Society of Agronomy, 5 November 1996, Indianapolis, Indiana, USA.
bibl.aa: International Centre for Research in Agroforestry, PO Box 30677, Nairobi, Kenya.

ab.p: The rate and extent to which biophysical resources are captured and utilized by the components of an agroforestry system are determined by the nature and intensity of interactions between the components. The net effect of these interactions is often determined by the influence of the tree component on the other component(s) and/or on the overall system, and is expressed in terms of such quantifiable responses as soil fertility changes, microclimate modification, and allelopathy. The paper reviews such manifestations of biophysical interactions in major simultaneous (e.g. hedgerow intercropping and trees on croplands) and sequential (e.g. planted tree fallows) agroforestry systems. In hedgerow intercropping (HI), the hedge/crop interactions are dominated by soil fertility improvement and competition for growth resources. Higher crop yields in HI than in sole cropping are noted mostly in inherently fertile soils in humid and subhumid tropics, and are caused by large fertility improvement relative to the effects of competition. However, yield increases are rare in the semiarid tropics and infertile acid soils because fertility improvement does not offset the large competitive effect of hedgerows with crops for water and/or nutrients. Whereas improved soil fertility and microclimate positively influence crop yields underneath the canopies of scattered trees in semiarid climates, intense shading caused by large, evergreen trees negatively affects the yields. Trees in boundary plantings compete with crops for above- and below-ground resources, with below-ground competition of trees often extending beyond their crown areas. The major biophysical interactions in improved planted fallows are improvement of soil nitrogen status and reduction of weeds in the fallow phase, and increased crop yields in the subsequent cropping phase. In such systems, the negative effects of competition and microclimate modification are avoided in the absence of direct tree-crop interactions. Future research on biophysical interactions should concentrate on (1) exploiting the diversity that exists within and between species of trees, (2) determining interactions between systems at different spatial (farm and landscape) and temporal scales, (3) improving understanding of below-ground interactions, (4) assessing the environmental implications of agroforestry, particularly in the humid tropics, and (5) devising management schedules for agroforestry components in order to maximize benefits.

index.de: acid soils\agroforestry systems\agrosilvicultural systems\allelopathy\alley cropping\biophysics\boundaries\crop yield\fallow systems\improved fallow\interactions\intercropping\microclimate\plant competition\planting\research\reviews\semiarid zones\soil fertility\soil types\tropical soils\tropics\weed control

bibl.et: Leaf epicuticular wax of Salvadora persica grown on saline black soils.
bibl.aa: Central Soil Salinity Research Institute, Regional Research Station, Anand 388 001, Gujarat, India.

ab.p: In order to understand the role of different physiological traits in imparting high salinity tolerance in Salvadora persica, leaf epicuticular waxes (LEW) were analysed from September 1994 to April 1996 in saplings planted in September 1993 at 2×4 m spacing on black soils of varying salinity at Khanpur, Gujarat. Soil salinity also varied between seasons (30-75 dS/m in April - summer; and 25-55 dS/m in September - rainy season). Plants were categorized into 4 groups according to in situ salinity. The wax components were fractionated by TLC. Results indicated that leaf epicuticular wax content increased with increase in in situ salinity, and from September to April, attaining maximum amounts in April, when soils had high salinity (60-75 dS/m) in the top 30 cm soil layer. However, samples collected from non-saline fields (adjacent to the experimental site) had lower amounts of waxes irrespective of the seasons. Onset of the monsoon and further recharging of the soil reduced both salinity and the LEW content. Composition of LEW showed the presence of high amounts of primary- and secondary alcohols, OH-β-diketones and aldehydes under high salinity. The relevance of the qualitative and quantitative changes in leaf epicuticular wax content in relation to salinity tolerance is discussed.
