bibl.av: Huang, J. S.\Ding, B.\Huang, H. Q.\Gao, M. L.
bibl.et: The relation between wood cell structure of Casuarina and the resistance for Anoplophora chinensis.
bibl.ms: English figures and tables.
bibl.aa: Fujian Academy of forestry, Fuzhou 350012, China.

ab.p: The results of wood tissue micro-dissection of four Casuarina strains are reported. The physical characteristics of wood vessels, lignified cells between vessels and rays are reported, and the mechanism of insect resistance is clarified. The wood vessel number of the high-resistant strain C44 was few and the unit area (1 mm²) contained only 20.25 vessels which accounted for merely 9.72% of the wood area; the lignified cells between vessels were relatively evident and the ratio of wall thickness to lumen diameter was maximal (56.59%); the indexes of the beam number [strips?], length and width of rays within the unit area and the area proportion were minimal. These results indicate that the xylem water content of the strain is low, its wood is hard and compact and the nutrients provided by the xylem are few. These conditions are unfavourable to the survival and development of the larvae of Anoplophora chinensis (a stem-boring pest).

index.de: forest pests\insect pests\pest resistance\rays\resistance\vessels\wood anatomy

bibl.et: Agroforestry for sustainable development in arid zones of Rajasthan.
bibl.aa: Arid Forest Research Institute, P.O. Krishi Mandi (Basni), Jodhpur - 342005, India.

ab.p: This review paper discusses the paramount importance of agroforestry in the arid zones of Rajasthan, India. Besides providing food, fodder, fuel, timber and several other products for day-to-day use, agroforestry offers security to inhabitants and their animals during the quite frequent famines and droughts. Agriculture alone would not be a stable enterprise in the region, but forestry with agriculture provides support to the farming system by conferring stability and generating an assured income. In addition to this social and economic role, the utility of agroforestry practices in increasing soil fertility and growth and yield of crops, and providing supplementary food and fodder from the (multipurpose) tree components of the systems, is widely recognized. Examples of practices used are discussed and a summary table of tree and crop components in relation to climate and soil fertility status provided. Future policy issues and recommendations are outlined.

bibl.et: Marjan Park Forest, development, present state and directions for future treatment.
bibl.ft: Park šuma Marjan, razvoj, sadašnje stanje i smjernice za buduc´i tretman.

ab.p: Marjan Park Forest, an amenity and recreation park near Split, Croatia, was established by planting Pinus halepensis and Cupressus sempervirens on highly degraded and rocky soil during 1884-1941. The forest, which covers 167 ha, is predominantly pure, even-aged stands which discourage natural regeneration, and is also unsuitable for recreation or aesthetic functions. Future management of the forest is discussed.

bibl.et: Utilization of browse supplements with varying tannin levels by Ethiopian Menz sheep. 2. Nitrogen metabolism.
bibl.aa: International Livestock Research Institute (IITA), P.O. Box 5689, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

ab.p: The effect of different condensed tannin concentrations on protein metabolism from browse supplements was investigated in a 90-day trial using 66 male Ethiopian Menz sheep. Teff straw (Eragrostis tef) was fed ad libitum (control diet), or supplemented with 190 g dried leaves of 6 Sesbania sesban accessions with increasing levels of condensed tannin (S1-S6), lablab (Dolichos lablab [Lablab purpureus]), tagasaste (Chamaecytisus palmensis), leucaena (Leucaena leucocephala) and goetzei (Sesbania goetzei) in a completely randomized block design. The condensed tannins were highest in goetzei, S6, S5 and leucaena, intermediate in S4, S3, S2 and S1, and lowest in tagasaste and lablab. The supplemented animals had significantly higher total dry matter and nitrogen (N) intake than the ones fed teff straw alone. The digestibility of N was lower for the control diet than for any other treatment. S1 and S2 supplemented diets had significantly higher N digestibilities than all other diets. Faecal N, urinary N and urinary N per kg N excreted were significantly different between diets. With increasing tannin levels (among Sesbania accessions) there was a significant decrease in urinary N (S1 > S2 > S3 > S4 > S5), and an increase in faecal N (S1< S2 < S3 < S4 < S5). Supplementation increased faecal N output significantly as well as the N retention. Among the forage supplements, N retention was significantly lower in lablab-, tagasaste-, leucaena-, S4- and goetzei- supplemented diets, than for S1, S2, S5 and S6. Apparent nitrogen digestibility was positively correlated with the supplement dry matter and crude protein (CP) degradation after 24 h, and with the CP content; it was negatively correlated with acid detergent fibre and neutral detergent fibre. The CP degradability characteristics of the forages differed in water solubility (93-470 g kg-1 CP), rate of degradation (2.58-9.73 %/h), lag phase (-1.36-13.37 h), and estimated escape protein (262-619 g kg-1 CP). With increasing tannin levels (among Sesbania accessions), there was a significant decrease in the rate of degradation (S1 > S2 > S3 > S4 > S5), and an increase in the estimated escape protein. The estimated rumen degradable protein (supplements) varied from 482 to 744 g kg-1 CP, while intestine digestible protein and the undegradable protein varied from 140 to 314 g kg-1 CP. Hence the browses can supply adequate levels of rumen degradable and bypass protein.

bibl.et: Effects of acid irrigation and liming on nitrate reduction and nitrate content of Picea abies (L.) Karst. and Oxalis acetosella L.
bibl.ct: Special issue. Höglwald research: biological effects of acidification and liming on a nitrogen saturated ecosystem of Picea abies (L., Karst).
bibl.aa: Lehrstuhl für Pflanzenökologie, Universität Bayreuth, D-95440 Bayreuth, Germany.

ab.p: During August 1991 at the Höglwald field station, southern Germany, a study was conducted in an 80-year-old Picea abies stand to investigate nitrate reductase activity (NRA) and nitrate concentration per unit biomass in tree roots from 4 different soil horizons and in the leaves and roots of Oxalis acetosella plants, in relation to acid irrigation and liming treatments (control, acid irrigation with H2SO4 (pH 2.7-2.8) in 15 to 18 irrigation events, normal irrigation, liming (4 t/ha dolomite) in April 1984, liming + acid irrigation or liming + normal irrigation). Liming increased and acid irrigation reduced soil nitrate availability when compared to control plots. The nitrate assimilation capacities of the respective plant compartments per unit of soil volume or ground area were calculated from the NRA per unit of biomass and from the biomass distribution of plants on the various treatments. Mean NRA per unit of biomass in Picea abies roots ranged between 0.23 and 0.09 µmol NO2-/g d.w. per h without significant effects from soil horizon or treatment. P. abies exhibited different root distributions from limed and unlimed treatments within the soil profile, but root biomass per unit of ground area (295 to 220 g d.w./m²) was unaffected. The nitrate assimilation capacity of P. abies roots per unit of ground area was between 19.5 and 11.4 µmol NO2-/m² per h without major treatment effects. In the laminae of O. acetosella, the mean NRA per unit of biomass ranged between 2.91 and 0.27 µmol NO2-/g d.w. per h and, in contrast to P. abies, treatment effects were observed such that NRA on limed plots increased and on acid irrigated plots reduced when compared to control plots. The mean leaf biomass of O. acetosella per unit of ground area was between 9.57 and 0.66 g d.w./m² and responded in a similar manner. A cumulative response to the variations in nitrate availability was found in O. acetosella leaves with regard to NRA per unit of ground area (27.85 to 0.18 µmol NO2-/m² per h). The different responses of P. abies and O. acetosella to changes in soil nitrate availability are discussed with respect to their suitability in preventing soil nitrate leaching.

bibl.et: Tree cultivation in Calakmul, Mexico: alternatives for reforestation.
bibl.aa: National Institute for Research in Forestry and Agriculture (INIFAP), Chetumal, Quintana Roo, Mexico.

ab.p: The Agroforestry Project of Calakmul was initiated in 1991 with the aim of offering farmers attractive production alternatives, and at the same time, contributing to reforestation. The farming system in the area includes collecting forest products, raising trees, crop produce and small animals in home gardens, and the traditional milpa system - a shifting cultivation system in which forest is felled, burned and planted with maize and other crops for 2 yr, followed by fallow and return to forest. However, both forest and agricultural land in the area are losing value. Participants in the agroforestry project were given fruit trees, and mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla) and Spanish cedar (Cedrela odorata) - formerly exploited from the forest but now scarce - to plant alongside their maize crops. Researchers from ICRAF and its international and national collaborators documented the lessons learned from this project, which are discussed in the article.

bibl.et: Opportunities for growing short-rotation woody crops in agroforestry practices.
bibl.pb: National Agroforestry Center, USDA Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Station/USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service, East Campus-UNL
bibl.aa: National Agroforestry Center Western Office, c/o University of Washington, Dept. of Geological Sciences, Box 351310, Seattle, WA 98195, USA.

ab.p: Technologies are readily available for growing hybrid poplars (Populus spp.) and willows (Salix spp.) in block plantings as short rotation woody crops (SRWC) for fuel and fibre production. This paper discusses the incorporation of SRWC species and technologies into agroforestry systems in the USA. Examples described include windbreaks, living snow fences, timberbelts, riparian buffer strips and waste water (both agricultural and community) treatment plantings. The economics of such systems are outlined. It is suggested that opportunities for income generation from SRWC in agroforestry exist where (1) soil and climate are favourable for the annual production of at least 4-8 t/acre, and (2) a market exists within a reasonable distance. The productivity of timberbelt (strip) plantings of SRWC can be as great as that of block plantings (but is more spread out). Rotations vary from 3 to 12 yr. It is noted that in many states fibre farming is considered to be agriculture, and that if rotations are <10 yr, SRWC is not subject to forest practice regulations and growing and harvesting are similar procedures used in agricultural crop production. Where markets do not exist poplars and willows are incorporated into agroforestry systems mostly for conservation purposes.

bibl.et: Growth reduction in spruce infected by Inonotus tomentosus in central British Columbia.
bibl.aa: University of Northern British Columbia, Faculty of Natural Resources and Environmental Studies, 3333 University Way, Prince George, BC V2N 4Z9, Canada.

ab.p: Volume growth of spruce trees infected by the root rot fungus, Inonotus tomentosus, was measured and compared with volume growth of healthy trees in two spruce-dominated (Picea glauca and Picea glauca × engelmannii) stands in central interior British Columbia. Whole volume, decayed wood volume, and volume increment over 5-year periods were measured by felling and sectioning trees, then digitizing every fifth annual ring. Disease severity was classified according to the number of infected roots on each tree. Decay volumes were significantly (P <0.05) related to disease severity rating and had a significant effect on net volume. Tree growth declined slowly over time relative to healthy trees, but differences among disease severity classes were only significant for the most recent 10 to 15 years. Larger trees had the greatest chance of being infected, but had the advantage of a more dominant canopy position, which may hide the effects of root disease on growth relative to healthy, and usually smaller, trees.

ab.p: Ecological units of the Northern Region (northern Idaho, Montana, North Dakota) of the USA are described and mapped at the subsection level of the Forest Service National Hierarchical Framework of Ecological Units. bibl.et: Study on variation in bamboo wood properties of Phyllostachys heterocycla var. pubescens.
bibl.ms: English figures and tables.
bibl.aa: Zhejiang Forestry College, Lin'an 311300, China.

ab.p: Fibre morphology, tissue measurements, cellulose content and basic density of the wood of Phyllostachys heterocycla var. pubescens [Phyllostachys pubescens] were determined. The variations in the bamboo wood properties were related to age, diameter at breast height (DBH), position in the culm from inner to outer and base to top, and internode from lower to upper end and node. The fibre length was determined mainly by position in the culm and the internode, and not by age and DBH. The tissue measurements were related to DBH, not to age, but cellulose content and basic densities were all related to age, DBH and positions in the culm. Judging from the variation in bamboo wood properties, small culms were superior to big culms when the bamboo wood was used as a raw material for paper-making.

bibl.av: Park, S. H.\Lee, Y. B.\Bae, G. Y.
bibl.do: Journal of the Korean Society for Horticultural Science
bibl.et: Anion evolution in plants and the factors involved.
bibl.aa: Department of Environmental Horticulture, Univ. of Seoul, Seoul 130-743, Korea Republic.

ab.p: Amounts of anions [in the air] were compared in polluted and unpolluted areas in 2 forest areas (Kanagawa and Sizuoka city, November 20-24), and in the urban district and the industrial area of the urban district of Kawasaki city (October 24-31) [year not stated] in Japan. The highest amounts were found in forest areas; in the other areas anion concentrations were higher at sites with than without plants, indicating that plants were significantly involved in anion evolution [emission]. Factors influencing anion emission in plants were analysed using potted plants of Populus sieboldii, Pinus densiflora and Glochidion obovatum. Increases in light intensity and humidity increased anion emission. It is suggested that increases in humidity caused by transpiration act as a major factor in anion emission in plants. In the tree species investigated anion emission was greatest in P. sieboldii, less in G. obovatum and slightly less again in P. densiflora. This result was consistent with differences in transpiration exhibited by the species.

bibl.et: Ecology and conservation of raptors in forests.
bibl.aa: Forest Research, Woodland Ecology Branch, Northern Research Station, Roslin, Midlothian EH25 9SY, UK.

ab.p: Background information is provided on the status and ecology of raptors (birds of prey) in Britain and the legislation that gives them full protection. Based on this information, management techniques are proposed that will improve man-made conifer forests in the uplands for this group of birds, and the food webs upon which they are dependent. The role of raptor predation is reviewed, and its importance in maintaining the fitness and health of prey populations is stressed. Contrary to widely held views, there is little evidence to support claims that raptors are responsible for the current declines in a number of bird species. In fact, the diversity and breeding performance of raptors in forests reflects the increasing variety of wildlife to be found within these man-made habitats. Different raptors are capable of exploiting a wide range of forest habitats. Both young and old forests support more species than the thicket stage, and forest edges are important features. All raptors under consideration here are solitary breeders which exhibit regular spacing of breeding pairs in suitable habitats. Their densities are governed primarily by food-supplies. Secondary factors which may limit numbers include shortage of nest sites, competition with other species for scarce resources, contamination with pollutants and illegal killing. Management techniques for improving forests include maintaining or enriching food-supplies through habitat management at the landscape scale, conserving and improving nest sites, and minimizing disturbance. The transformation of even-aged conifer forests in the uplands into more complex habitats through small-scale patch clear-felling will diversify raptor populations and their food-supplies. Examples are given of how the size and spatial arrangement of clear felled areas can affect the distribution of raptor species. At present, the lack of old trees within these relatively young habitats is limiting their potential for raptors and their prey. Hence, planning for large areas of old trees will enable these forests to become even more important wildlife habitats in the future.

bibl.et: Diseases and disorders of forest trees: A guide to identifying causes of ill-health in woods and plantations.
bibl.aa: Forestry Commission, UK.

ab.p: This handbook is arranged in 3 parts. Part I, 'A guide to diagnosing tree problems', provides guidelines for investigating health problems and covers field investigation procedures (equipment and sampling), symptoms and their assessment, the distribution of damage, timing the occurrence of damage, and diagnosing the cause. Part II, is a 30-page 'Key to major diseases and disorders of plantations and woodlands' in the UK, and Part III, 'Notes on common diseases and disorders of plantations and woodlands', describes important features of the diseases and disorders covered in Part II. The 8 sections of Part II are: Abiotic disorders affecting several species; Root diseases of conifers; Diseases, disorders and pests of spruce (Picea spp.); Diseases, disorders and pests of pine (Pinus spp.); Diseases, disorders and pests of larch (Larix spp.); Diseases, disorders and pests of forest broadleaves; Causes of physical damage; and Stain and decay. The handbook includes only the commonest and most important damaging agents (which in the case of diseases are mostly fungal, and in the case of pests, mostly insects). A subject index is included.

bibl.et: Sustainable forest management in Malaysia.

ab.p: The forest cover and types found in Malaysia, and the importance of the forests socially and economically are described. The development of Malaysian forest management is then described in 3 sections, pre-1940, 1940-57 and post-1957. The development of forestry policy is outlined, and approaches to sustainable forest management reviewed with reference to natural forest, forest plantations, forest development and rehabilitation, helicopter logging, multi-storied forest management and the Bentong Model Forest. It is concluded that the long-term management objectives must balance the needs and wants of society, local and global, with the economic growth of the country and the environment.

bibl.et: Eucalyptus wood shrinkage and collapse.
bibl.ft: Ritiro e collasso del legno di Eucalyptus.
bibl.aa: Centro di Sperimentazione Agricola e Forestale SAF, Roma, Italy.

ab.p: Variations in wood volume often occur in those species which are liable to shrinkage and collapse. Research was undertaken (in Italy) into the relations between volume shrinkage and collapse, and wood chemical and anatomical properties of eight eucalypts: E. camaldulensis, E. dalrympleana, E. gomphocephala, E. grandis, E. gunnii, E. occidentalis, E. trabutii and E. viminalis. Wood samples, collected at breast height from three 10-year-old trees of each species, were tested and volumetric shrinkage, wood collapse, wood basic density, wood moisture content, vessel and fibre size and chemical composition were determined. Volumetric shrinkage proved to be positively correlated to the ratio cell wall area/lumen area, and negatively correlated to content of 1% NaOH extractives. Conversely, wood collapse was positively correlated to 1% NaOH extractives content, and negatively correlated to the ratio cell wall area/lumen area. The relationship with said ratio and with the extractive content did not prove to be linear, and could be suitably expressed by a parabolic function of n order. For both traits, most recorded variability could be regarded as a function of the ratio, which is an estimate of the relative proportion of fibre wall substances. The use of these tests to aid selection in tree breeding programmes is briefly discussed.

bibl.et: Vertical distributions of plant nutrients and heavy metals in Salix viminalis stems and their implications for sampling.
bibl.aa: Department of Ecology and Environmental Research, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, P.O. Box 7072, S-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: Five-centimetre pieces from 2- (sandy soil) and 3- (clay soil) year-old shoots of Salix viminalis (clone 78183) were sampled at 1 m vertical intervals in late March-early April 1993 from first-rotation fuel plantations in central Sweden. The stand on clay was sampled again 2 years later. Concentrations of P, K, Ca, Mg, S, Mn, Zn, Cu, Ni and Cd increased significantly with height, which was assumed to be mainly a consequence of increasing bark proportions. The increase was least consistent for Cd. Differences in concentration gradients between elements were ascribed in part to their differential redistribution in the tissues. With respect to vertical concentration gradients along the shoot the elements ranked in the same order in the 2-, 3- and 5-year-old shoots. For example, Ni increased most from the lowest to the highest sampling level (sixfold increase in the 5-year-old shoots), followed by P and Cu (fourfold). Concentrations of Ca, Mn and Zn doubled, and Cd increased by 20%. It was shown that for the 3-year-old shoots a slight shift in the sampling point location could result in a 10% change in the measured shoot Ni concentration. In the older shoots, where concentration gradients were mainly found in the upper parts but the bulk of the biomass was in the lower shoot parts, a shift in sampling point location would probably be of less importance.

bibl.et: Occurrence of tannins in leaves of beech trees (Fagus sylvatica) along an ecological gradient, detected by histochemical and ultrastructural analyses.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Biology, Laboratory of Applied and Forest Botany, Piazzale delle Cascine 28, I-50144 Firenze, Italy.

ab.p: Descriptions are given of the morphological and histochemical alterations occurring in field-grown leaves of Fagus sylvatica from three sites located along an ecological gradient at Vallombrosa, Tuscany, Italy: from a site in cool and protected conditions to one located on a mountain ridge, where the trees grow on a thin layer of soil and are exposed to the wind and to intense solar radiation in summer. The morphological data show that, as the ecological conditions of the stand worsen, individual leaf surface decreases, while the thickness of the leaves and their specific dry weight increases. Histochemical and ultrastructural tests show a marked increase of phenolics during the course of the year. These substances, present primarily in the leaves of trees growing in stress conditions, have been identified mainly as tannins. They accumulate in the vacuoles, especially those of the upper epidermal layer and the palisade mesophyll; at a later stage they appear to be solubilized in the cytoplasm and retranslocated, eventually impregnating the outer wall of the epidermal cells amidst the cellulose fibrils, where they cluster together and form an electron-opaque layer between the wall and the cuticle. Observation of the epidermal cells also reveals that the outer cell wall is thicker. The roles of secondary metabolites in protection and detoxification processes, and the possible ecological significance of these alterations in the ecophysiology of beech trees are discussed.

bibl.ft: Zmiany biometryczne drzewostanu sosnowego i wydajności pracy przy pozyskiwaniu surowca drzewnego w ramach czyszczen´ póz´nych i trzebiez&dotover;y wczesnej.

ab.p: The purpose of the work was to compare outputs of wood harvesting operations in a 19-year-old and a 32-year-old stand of pine [Pinus sylvestris]. The output of the wood harvesting process, in which a light chainsaw, an axe for delimbing and a horse for skidding were used, reached 0.15 m³/h (operation time) in the younger stand (late cleaning), and 0.34 m³/h in the older one (first thinning). The most time consuming operations were delimbing and horse skidding together with the manual hauling of trees to the skidding strip. The percentage of these operations reached 38% of the total operation time.

bibl.et: Ethanol-kraft pulping and papermaking properties of aspen and spruce.
bibl.aa: School of Forest Resources, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA.

ab.p: The kinetics of solvent-kraft pulping was investigated for aspen (Populus tremuloides) and spruce (Picea excelsa [Picea abies]). Kinetic parameters were determined at three pulping temperatures (150, 160, and 170°C) and four mole fractions of ethanol (0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3). Activation thermodynamics of the solvent-kraft delignification process were investigated based on classical transition-state theory. A mathematical model was developed to estimate the pulping productivity of the solvent-kraft process in a continuous digester. The simulation shows a 50% increase in the reaction order of delignification and a 30% decrease in the activation energy of delignification with increasing ethanol mole fraction in the cooking liquor. Activation Gibbs' free energy of delignification increased steadily with ethanol content, while activation enthalpy and entropy of delignification showed dynamic behaviour. Estimated pulping productivity increased by a factor of 2.5. The results suggest that addition of ethanol to conventional kraft pulping liquor increases pulping productivity through the combined effects of faster delignification, increased pulp yield, and a decrease in the activation energy of delignification.

bibl.et: Ontogenetic basis of polyad symmetry in Samanea saman (Jacq.) Merr.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, University of Karachi, Karachi 75270, Pakistan.

ab.p: Samanea saman [Albizia saman] possesses a more or less radially symmetric polyad. The polyad is formed by eight equal sized, decussate tetrads, thus consisting of 32 pollen grains in total. Following studies of polyad ontogeny, three rounds of premeiotic mitosis were found to occur in the sporogenous cell, giving rise to 8 nuclei. However, these nuclear divisions are not followed immediately by cytokinesis and cell wall formation. All 8 nuclei remained in the same cell arranged equidistant around the periphery; radial walls were then laid down and a group of 8 PMCs formed. This group of radially arranged PMCs underwent meiosis giving rise to the 32-cell polyad. In addition, the results showed that the symmetry of the polyad is affected by premeiotic nuclear divisions in the sporogenous cell which precede cell wall formation.

The strains could be divided tentatively into 2 physiological forms: strains A and C were the same form, and B belonged to another form. Inoculating poplars in the field and poplar callus with the 3 strains showed that strain C was the most pathogenic.

bibl.et: Use of composted plant residues in urban forests.
bibl.ft: Zum Einsatz Grünschnittkomposten in stadtnahen Forsten.
bibl.aa: Plan-Zentrum, Umwelt, Büro für ökologische Planung, Herne, Germany.

ab.p: Municipal composts produced in summer and winter from plant residues were analysed (pH, organic C, total N, C/N ratio, contents of minerals and heavy metals) and found to meet the German RAL standards for good-quality compost products. The compost was applied on four urban forest sites at Witten (Ruhr region) to improve the shallow oligotrophic brown soils which had low nutrient status and relatively high contents of heavy metals. Analyses were made of the physical and chemical characteristics of the Ah horizons after the compost had been applied. The results indicate that the compost is a long-term soil-improver with a useful fertilizer effect. A single compost application gives ca. 240 kg N/ha (of which 96 kg is mineralizable), and actually helps to reduce the contents of heavy metals in the soils.

bibl.et: Tree-ring growth and structure of Pinus uncinata and Pinus sylvestris in the Central Spanish Pyrenees.
bibl.aa: Department of Ecology, University of Barcelona. Avda. Diagonal, 645. Barcelona 08028, Spain.

ab.p: Tree-ring structure and formation were compared for Pinus uncinata and Pinus sylvestris in the Central Spanish Pyrenees. Ring width and the number of tracheids in the latewood and in the entire ring were measured monthly during the growing period in 1993. Both species developed the major part of the tree ring between 10 June and 18 July, although the tree ring formed earlier in P. sylvestris. Tree-ring growth was delayed in the highest elevation stand. Ring width and the number of tracheids in the tree ring were functionally correlated. Pinus uncinata had smaller tree rings with fewer cells in radial transects. Latewood development, including formation, later coloration, and cell wall apposition, started in July and ended in October. Tree rings show greater latewood density and colour contrast in P. uncinata. Characteristic tree rings show latewood tracheids with thin cell walls and wide cell lumina in many P. sylvestris cores. The analysis of the intra-annual ring growth and structure variability has thrown light on some interannual assumptions such as phenological variability controlled by climate. In conjunction with past dendroclimatological studies, this work shows the existence of a delay between ring growth and structure and their controlling climatic factors.

bibl.et: Air and soil microclimates of deciduous woodland compared to an open site.
bibl.aa: NERC Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, Oxford University Field Laboratory, Wytham, Oxford, OX2 8QT, UK.

ab.p: Forest microclimate has been monitored continuously for more than 3 years at 2 sites (one high forest, one abandoned coppice) in deciduous woodland at Wytham Woods, Oxford, UK. Automatic weather stations provided hourly data for wind speed, photosynthetically active radiation (PAR), vapor pressure deficit (VPD) and, in particular, temperature at different heights above the ground and at different depths in the soil. These data were compared with values from an open semi-natural grassland site at the same location. Air temperatures could be up to 3°C lower under the canopy than at the open site under sunny conditions in summer, but the differences averaged 0.6 (coppice) and 0.9°C (high forest) during the summer months and barely differed over winter. Effects of forest cover on soil temperatures were much greater and under the woodland they neither fell below 0°C nor rose above 20°C even at 5 mm depth, in contrast to temperatures under bare earth and grass. The temperature of a grass (Deschampsia cespitosa) tussock at the soil surface under the canopy was intermediate between soil and air temperature; in comparison to grassland plants at an open site it experienced a much smaller range of temperatures. The differences between both soil and air temperature under the canopy and in the open were significantly correlated with solar radiation, presence or absence of canopy leaves and wind speed. Soil water content had no significant effect on soil temperature, partly because thermal diffusivity was relatively insensitive to it and partly because soil heat flux was small. Seasonal changes in canopy leaf cover caused a large peak of PAR under the canopy in spring prior to bud burst in trees and a much smaller one in the autumn after leaf fall. Wind speed under the canopy was also affected by the presence of leaves and was proportionally lower in summer and autumn than winter and spring.

ab.p: The meanings of Indian forests are explored in this book, and their relevance in diverse settings (such as political imagery, novels, the management of wildlife reserves, the significance of scared groves, and participatory forest management) discussed. There are 9 chapters by various authors: (1) Introduction (by the editor); (2) Mountain forests in Tamil culture (Dubiansky, A. A.); (5) Folk-models of the forest environment in highland Malabar (Freeman, R.); (6) Forests in Garhwal and the construction of space (Linkenbach, A.); (7) People's rights in a bird sanctuary: the case of Bharatpur (Madsen, S. T.); (8) NGOs and forest management in Karnataka (Potter, D.); and (9) Autonomous and Joint Forest Management in India's Jharkland: lessons for the future?

bibl.do: Clearcutting the Pacific rain forest: production, science, and regulation.
bibl.et: Clearcutting the Pacific rain forest: production, science, and regulation.

ab.p: An analysis is made in this book of the social, environmental and political roots of the deforestation crisis in the Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) regions of British Columbia, Washington and Oregon between 1880 and 1965. In the first part of the book (Machines managers and work, 2 chapters) a labour process analysis is made of the technological and managerial innovations that introduced a factory regime to coastal logging. In the second part (Clearcutting, conservation and the state, 4 chapters), the book goes on to study the environmental, scientific and political history of clear felling. The growing awareness is documented of the impact of felling practices on forest renewal and the development of silvicultural regulations in the American and Canadian contexts. An analysis of the relationship between governments and corporations in policy making suggests that regulatory initiatives served corporate rather than social or ecological ends.

bibl.et: Ulmus wallichiana (elm) - An endangered tree of economic value.
bibl.aa: Forest Tree Seed Laboratory, Forest Research Institute, New Forest, Dehradun, India.

ab.p: Ulmus wallichiana subsp. wallichiana has been given the status of endangered species (IUCN 1978). Valued as a fodder for cattle or goats, it is lopped heavily by an increasing population in the hilly regions of the Himalayas from Afghanistan to India and Nepal. This report describes briefly its economic value, distribution, description, cultivation and conservation measures.

bibl.av: Qin, G. F.\Zhou, Z. C.\Jin, G. Q.\Huang, H.\Fang, S. R.
bibl.et: Evaluation of the productivity of plus-tree open-pollinated families from natural stands of Masson pine.
bibl.aa: Research Institute of Subtropical Forestry, CAF, Fuyang, Zhejiang 311400, China.

ab.p: An analysis was made of genetic variation and productivity in plus-tree open-pollinated families in a series of progeny test plantations of Masson pine (Pinus massoniana) in Zhejiang Province, China. Significant variations were found among the families for height, DBH (diameter at breast height) and stem volume at 5-10 yr old which were under moderate or high genetic control. At 10 yr old the heritabilities for the 3 growth traits were more stable with family genetic variation coefficients decreasing with age. Age-age correlation analysis indicated that height and stem volume at age 10 could not be predicted by height under age 5, so the first selection for growth traits at family level should be made at over 5 yr old. Height was considered to be the main criterion for evaluation of family productivity. Of 405 families tested, 167, 96 and 32, respectively, had heights 10, 15 and 20% more than control trees, and were selected to provide a basis for roguing in seed orchards and parental selection for controlled pollination, etc.

bibl.et: Comparison of pine and eucalypt profitabilities and costs in South Africa between 1991 and 1995.
bibl.aa: P.O. Box 35562, Menlopark, 0102, South Africa.

ab.p: The annual cost surveys conducted by Forestry Economics Services are used to establish profitability and cost trends from 1991 to 1995. Numerous factors such as topography, changing markets, changing techniques and the mix of growers participating in the surveys imply that comparisons need to be treated with caution. Nevertheless these surveys are the most detailed and comprehensive sets of published information on forestry cost in South Africa and provide very valuable benchmarks to tree growers. Growing pines [Pinus spp.] has become more profitable over the five years under review, mainly as a result of timber prices that have increased at approximately double the rate of inflation. The costs to grow and market pine timber increased at a rate slightly higher than inflation. Growers benefited by a 142 % improvement in profits on average. Eucalypt [Eucalyptus spp.] growing by comparison became less profitable. Mining-timber prices did not rise as sharply as the other major products, whereas production costs increased at approximately double the rate of inflation, causing profits to rise by 20 % against a 42 % rate of inflation for the five-year period.

bibl.et: Values and objectives of non-industrial private forest owners in Finland.
bibl.aa: Finnish Forest Research Institute, Helsinki Research Centre, Unioninkatu 40 A, FIN-00170 Helsinki, Finland.

ab.p: The purpose of the study was to create an empirical typology of non-industrial private forest owners based on forest values and long-term objectives of forest ownership, to identify these types by owner and holding characteristics, as well as to analyse silvicultural and harvesting behaviour in these groups. The analysis was based on survey data on 245 forest owners in southeastern Finland. The results indicated that general forest values and long-term objectives of forest ownership are not strongly correlated. The results further suggested that the sole emphasis on economic benefits of forests does not lead to the most active silvicultural and harvesting behaviour. Multi-objective owners, who underlined both monetary and amenity benefits of their forest property, were the most active in their silvicultural and cutting behaviour. Non-timber objectives seemed not to exclude wood production: a group called recreationists harvested slightly less than other owners. Recreationists were willing to invest in forestry but were selective with respect to management practices. The results can be used in planning and implementation of public forest policy such as allocation of the resources of forestry extension services. Forest industries should also benefit from a knowledge of the objectives of roundwood sellers.

index.de: forest economics\forest ownership\forest products industries\logging\multiple land use\objectives\planning\private forestry\recreation\silviculture\surveys

bibl.et: A review of studies on stand basal area growth models.
bibl.aa: Research Institute of Forest Resources Information Technique, CAF, Beijing 100091, China.

ab.p: The basal area growth model is the main component of stand growth and yield prediction models. Based on an analysis of some common basal area growth models (such as the Richards and Schumacher models), four important aspects of such models are discussed. (1) Three variables should be included in the model, i.e. site quality index, age and stand density index. (2) Thinned and unthinned stand growth models should be considered at the same time (in this connection the method used for calculating the index of suppression used in basal area prediction of thinned stands is introduced in detail). (3) The construction of the thinning index needs stand factors for before and after thinning. (4) Other desirable properties for proposed models include asymptotic properties, compatibility, monotonicity, and invariance of projection length.

index.de: basal area\forests\growth models\mathematical models\reviews

bibl.av: Wang, X. S.\Wang, J. H.\Wang, Y. C.\Dong, X. G.\Chang, G. S.\Cui, Z. L.
bibl.et: Effect of cutting length on rooting and growth of two-year-old plantlets of Larix kaempferi in the nursery.
bibl.aa: Research Institute of Forestry, CAF, Beijing 100091, China.

ab.p: The rooting and growth of cuttings 10, 15 and 20 cm long of Larix kaempferi [L. leptolepis] was studied in a nursery in China. Cuttings of all sizes rooted satisfactorily (88-99%) although the rooting percentage of 10 cm cuttings was significantly higher than that of 15 and 20 cm cuttings. The height of the rooted cuttings in the first year varied significantly according to the cutting length. If the height of rooted cuttings was ≥16 cm, the survival percentage after transplanting to the field, percentage of 2-year-old plantlets harvested and percentage of first-class plantlets were significantly higher than that those of cuttings 12.2 cm tall. Compared to the cuttings of 10 cm in length, The cuttings 15 and 20 cm long cuttings produced more 2-year-old plantlets and more first-class plantlets than the 10 cm cuttings per 100 cuttings.

bibl.et: The effects of the hydroabsorbent TerraCottem on the growth of Norway spruce (Picea abies L. Karst.) and beech (Fagus sylvatica L.) seedlings.
bibl.ft: Vplyv hydroabsorbentu TerraCottem na rast semenáčikov smreka obyčajného (Picea abies L. Karst.) a buka lesného (Fagus sylvatica L.).
bibl.aa: Technická Univerzita, Lesnícka Fakulta, T.G. Masaryka 24, 960 53 Zvolen, Slovakia.

ab.p: Norway spruce (Picea abies) and beech (Fagus sylvatica) seedlings were grown during 1996 in a plastic greenhouse or in the field in peat/bark compost supplemented with 0, 4, 6 or 8 kg/m³ hydroabsorbent TerraCottem. In autumn, 40 seedlings of each species were collected from each treatment to evaluate seedling height, root system length, hypocotyl diameter and fresh and dry weight of root system. The stimulatory effects of TerraCottem were significant for all evaluated traits of Norway spruce and for root system length and root system fresh weight of beech. Application of 8 kg/m³ TerraCottem inhibited growth of beech and Norway spruce seedlings. However, application of 4 or 6 kg/m³ TerraCottem improved the growth of Norway spruce and beech seedlings.

bibl.et: Growth of young trees of Acer platanoides and Quercus robur along a gap-understory continuum: interrelationships between allometry, biomass partitioning, nitrogen, and shade tolerance.
bibl.aa: Estonian Institute of Ecology, Riia 181, Tartu EE 2400, Estonia.

ab.p: Growth and biomass partitioning across a natural light gradient were determined in saplings (0.3 to 2.6 m in height) of relatively shade-tolerant A. platanoides and relatively shade-intolerant Q. robur for dependence on relative irradiance, calculated from hemispherical photographs (RI), and on total tree height (H). H and RI were independent, and all allometric relationships between H and the parameters of plant biomass and dimensions were positively affected by RI, signifying that at a common H, saplings increased horizontal growth relative to vertical growth in environments with greater irradiance. Root mass ratio (coarse plus fine roots per total plant biomass) increased with increasing irradiance in both species. Whilst root mass ratio values were similar for both species, Q. robur had a larger stem mass ratio, whilst A. platanoides had a greater leaf mass ratio (LMR). Leaf mass per area (LMA) was generally lower in A. platanoides. As a result of these interspecific differences in fractional allocation of sapling biomass in foliage and biomass requirement for construction of foliar surface area, leaf area ratio was larger in A. platanoides. Relative growth rate of standing biomass was significantly correlated with RI in both species. Net assimilation rate/unit leaf area (NAR) was larger in Q. robur. In these species a similar RGR (NAR × LAR) was achieved in a completely different way: A. platanoides increased the intercepting foliar area, whilst Q. robur increased the productivity per unit area. Growth analysis repeated on a nitrogen basis demonstrated that nitrogen use efficiency was similar between the species, and that the species differences in NAR resulted from different foliar N concentrations. Fractional nitrogen investment in foliage was independent of species, but lower nitrogen cost of leaves allowed A. platanoides to construct a more extensive foliar display with the same nitrogen investment in foliage. Biomass allocation between different compartments was also dependent on sapling size. With increasing H, A. platanoides maintained a constant proportion of biomass in foliage, but the relative amount of foliage decreased in Q. robur. Therefore, due to a decreasing investment of resources in foliage construction with advancing sapling ontogeny, saplings of similar height require more light to survive in Q. robur than in A. platanoides. Greater investment of biomass in leaves vs. standing biomass may result in lower volume gain and reduced competitive ability in more open habitats in A. platanoides. These results indicate that interspecific differences in allometry and nitrogen allocation patterns significantly alter species competitive relations during sapling development across the gap-understorey continuum.

index.de: allometry\biomass\canopy gaps\foliage\forest trees\growth\increment\leaf area\light intensity\net assimilation rate\nitrogen metabolism\plant development\plant height\plant nutrition\roots\shading\trees\understorey\woody plants

bibl.et: Methods for testing the behaviour of active ingredients of wood preservatives in soils - possibilities and limitations.
bibl.aa: Federal Research Centre for Forestry and Forest Products, Institute of Wood Biology and Wood Protection, Leuschnerstr. 91, D-21031 Hamburg, Germany.

ab.p: In the past, investigations concerning the environmental behaviour of wood preservatives were made to an increasing extent but no uniform methods of test have existed. The adsorption-desorption or migration behaviour of active ingredients of wood preservatives in soils can be investigated both in experiments on a practical scale and on a laboratory scale. Both investigation results are only generally valid to a limited extent, due to the variability of the substance system wood preservative/soil. Laboratory tests, however, are more suitable for the purpose of ecotoxicological assessments as new generations of wood preservatives can be incorporated in the observations. The possibilities of batch and column tests are discussed.

index.de: field tests\laboratory tests\methodology\soil pollution\techniques\testing\wood preservatives

bibl.et: Variations in the secondary metabolite camptothecin in relation to tissue age and season in Camptotheca acuminata.
bibl.aa: School of Forestry, Wildlife and Fisheries, Louisiana Agricultural Experiment Station, Louisiana State University Agricultural Center, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, USA.

ab.p: Variation in concentration of the secondary metabolite, camptothecin (CPT), was investigated in relation to leaf, branch and tree age, season, and leaf drying method in Camptotheca acuminata saplings growing at the Citrus Research Station, Port Sulphur, Louisiana. Younger leaves contained higher CPT concentrations than older leaves. Within a branch, there was a linear decline in CPT concentration from leaves at the apex of the branch down to leaf 7. Comparing leaves of similar age, those from younger trees had higher CPT concentrations than those from older trees. Over the course of the growing season, there was a steady decline of 11% per month in leaf CPT concentration. Branches showed a similar seasonal decline in CPT concentration to leaves; however, the rate of decline was threefold greater in leaves than in branches. Freeze-dried tissues had a 27% higher CPT concentration than oven- or air-dried tissues, suggesting that oven- and air-drying caused degradation of CPT. The decline in CPT concentration with tissue aging may reflect a genetically determined mechanism whereby, in young trees, chemicals serve as a first line of defence against attacks by herbivores and pathogenic microorganisms until other mechanisms are developed and deployed. It is hypothesized that chemical defence mechanisms are programmed for early ontogenic stages, whereas they are induced by biotic and abiotic factors during later ontogenic stages.

bibl.et: The influence of mycorrhizal fungi on soil structure and their importance for bio-engineering.
bibl.ft: Der Einfluss von Mykorrhizapilzen auf die Bodenstruktur und deren Bedeutung für den Lebendverbau.
bibl.aa: WSL, CH-8903 Birmensdorf, Switzerland.

ab.p: A review is made of the importance of mycorrhizal fungi in bio-engineering work, i.e. the establishment or re-establishment of vegetation on difficult sites, especially on bare slopes. Trees used in revegetation work require certain levels of nutrients, humus and soil structure in order to survive and thrive, and some indicator values are presented for 13 species of Salix, and for Alnus incana, A. glutinosa and A. viridis. Data are also presented on the structure (granule diameter) of soil samples from a graded ski-piste in Parsenn, Davos, where patchy vegetation is starting to become established, and also on the development of ground vegetation in the first 25 years after the retreat of a glacier. The role of micro-organisms and mycorrhizal fungi in creating a substrate suitable for plants to germinate and grow is reviewed, especially the role of ectomycorrhizal fungi in soil aggregation and reducing erosion. Experiments have shown that the application of mycorrhiza mycelium nearly doubles the stability of structureless substrates, and greatly increases their erosion resistance.

bibl.do: Imperata Project Paper - Improving Smallholder Farming Systems in Imperata Areas of Southeast Asia
bibl.et: The role of grazing animals in the natural regeneration of Samanea saman in degraded pasture areas in the Philippines.
bibl.pb: Centre for Resource and Environmental Studies (CRES), Australian National University
bibl.aa: College of Forestry and Environmental Management, Isabela State University, Philippines.

ab.p: There is a symbiotic relationship between water buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) and naturally regenerating Samanea saman [Albizia saman] in the Philippines. Grazing animals have been observed feeding on seed pods of the tree, and when the indigestible seeds are excreted by the animals, the seeds germinate in the fertile medium of the animal dung. Over time, a continuous natural regeneration of Albizia has occurred. This unique system has the potential to convert marginal grasslands to silvopastoral sites through natural means. An analysis is undertaken here of the bioecological basis for the symbiotic relationship between grazing animals and Albizia, in order to help formulate the dimensions of what seems to be a sustainable tree-animal based production model. The contributory factors which enhance such relationships are examined, with the aim of evolving a successful reforestation model which builds on the natural process of regeneration on degraded grasslands. This study site was in the Province of Cagayan, Luzon, Philippines. The methodology consisted of a series of bioecological experiments, plus a socioeconomic survey, in which the perceived benefits of Albizia were evaluated - these included shade for grazing animals, use of the pods as a feed supplement, and use of the wood for construction material, charcoal, fuelwood and furniture. The bioecological experiments addressed such issues as seed germination, seed digestibility and forage preference by grazing animals. The socioeconomic component was included to determine the income gains to the farmer from Albizia.

ab.p: Nursery investigations are reported on the use of cuttings from stumps and roots of 4 species of Vismia (V. guianensis, V. cayennensis, V. japurensis and V. latifolia), in the EMBRAPA experimental station N. of Manaus, Amazonas, Brazil. Rooting of cuttings was better in V. cayennensis and V. japurensis than the other 2 species, and root cuttings rooted better than shoot cuttings from stumps for all 4 species. Length of cuttings (short or long) made no difference to rooting.

bibl.et: Survival strategies of terrestrial invertebrates in Central Amazonian inundation forests: a response to long-term flooding.
bibl.ft: Estratégias de sobrevivência de invertebrados terrestres em florestas inundáveis da Amazônia Central: uma resposta à inundação de longo período.
bibl.aa: Instituto Max-Planck para Limnologia, Grupo de Trabalho en Ecologia Tropical, Caixo Postal 165, D-24302 Plön, Germany.

ab.p: Inundation forests in central Amazonia and their adjacent shores are covered by several metres of flood water for 5-7 months each year. Terrestrial invertebrates have adapted to this ecosystem by evolving several survival strategies. The fauna comprises both terricolous and arboreal animals, with both groups including non-migrants and migrants. Migratory reaction of terricolous animals is horizontal (following the high-water line), vertical (temporary ascent to stems or canopy of trees) or includes a temporary flight to upland forests. Non-migrants have active or dormant stages under water. The latter pass inundation in naturally available retreats, in self-made retreats or as eggs. Non-migrant arboreal invertebrates reproduce and live exclusively in the stem and canopy region, whereas migrants include life stages that live on the ground as well. Characteristics and examples of species are given for each of these categories. The flood pulse is regarded as the original determinant of migration. However, most invertebrates have become sensitive to secondary, mainly abiotic factors. Only in a few species is migration still directly related to the cycle of flood.

index.de: animal behaviour\behaviour\flooding\forests\survival

bibl.et: What to do about softwood? A review of respiratory effects and recommendations regarding exposure limits.
bibl.aa: Occupational Hygience Programme, Department of Health Care and Epidemiology, University of British Columbia, BC, Canada.

ab.p: Wood dust has been classified as a human carcinogen by the International Agency for Research on Cancer with a footnote that the evaluation was based on a marked excess of sino-nasal cancer among workers exposed primarily to hardwood dusts. Because the epidemiological data on the carcinogenic effects of softwoods are weaker than for hardwoods, standard-setting for softwood dust presents a greater dilemma. Unfortunately, the studies of wood dust and cancer do not have the quantitative exposure data necessary for standard-setting for either hardwoods or softwoods. Asthma, non-asthmatic airflow obstruction, and both upper and lower respiratory symptoms have been associated with exposure to both 'allergenic' and 'non-allergenic' softwood dusts, and an association with increasing intensity of exposure has been observed in multiple studies. The available evidence seems to indicate that to prevent these non malignant effects, the level of exposure to all softwood dust should be at least as low as 2 mg/m³. A standard of 1 mg/m³ may be more appropriate to provide a safety margin to protect more sensitive workers. It may be that some of the health effects observed are due to the natural components of wood, such as resin acids or monoterpenes, or to moulds.

index.de: asthma\hardwoods\neoplasms\occupational health\respiratory diseases\softwoods\standards\wood dust

bibl.et: Efficacy test of Eagle 480 AS herbicide towards alang-alang (Imperata cylindrica Beauv.) on grassland area and under Acacia mangium plantation.
bibl.ft: Uji efikasi herbisida Eagle 480 as terhadap alang-alang (Imperata cylindrica Beauv.) pada lahan terbuka dan di bawah tegakan Acacia mangium.

ab.p: An experiment was done in Depok, West Java, on control of I. cylindrica using 3 dosages of Eagle 480 AS ([amidosulfuron] at 5, 6 or 7 litres/ha), or manual control. Dry weight of I. cylindrica on the 2 site types (open grassland and under Acacia mangium plantation) was compared with control untreated values 1, 2 and 3 months after treatment. The best dosage on open grassland (i.e as a site preparation method) was 7 litres/ha, while 5 litres/ha was sufficient under Acacia mangium, and caused little or no growth inhibition (although growth was best in the manual control treatment).

bibl.et: Occurrence of diseases in mate (llex paraguariensis St. Hil.) in the southern region of Brazil.
bibl.ft: Doenças em erva-mate (llex paraguariensis St. Hil.) na região sul do Brasil.
bibl.aa: Centro Nacional de Pesquisa de Florestas, CP 319, 83411-00, Colombo, PR, Brazil.

ab.p: The planting of Ilex paraguariensis has been increasing in the southern region of Brazil. However, few studies on disease occurrence and the importance of diseases have been done on the species. For example, severe losses of seedlings are frequently noted in the nurseries, but the causal agent has not been identified. This paper reports on a survey (including laboratory investigations) of diseases in nurseries and commercial plantations in Paraná, Santa Catarina and Rio Grande do Sul. The most frequent fungal diseases observed in the nurseries were damping off caused by Rhizoctonia sp., Fusarium sp. and Pythium sp., leaf spots caused by Cylindrocladium spathulatum and Colletotrichum sp., and defoliation induced by C. spathulatum. The main problem in plantations was defoliation induced by several agents, including C. spathulatum. Galls were observed in some seedlings induced by Meloidogyne sp. The diseases decreased seedling quality and resulted in estimated production losses of 25-30%.

bibl.et: Effects of blackout on British Columbia spruce seedlots at Red Rock Research Station.
bibl.pb: FRDA Research Program, Research Branch, BC Ministry of Forests and Lands
bibl.aa: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd, 65 Front Street, Nanaimo, B.C. Canada.

ab.p: Four dynamic photoperiod (short-day) treatments, each declining in parallel with the natural ephemeris (nominal 19-, 17-, 15-, and 13-h days), were applied for three durations (2, 4, or 6 weeks) to six seedlots from three spruce species (Picea glauca, P. engelmannii, and P. sitchensis × P. glauca) at Red Rock Research Station, near Prince George, British Columbia. Short-day dynamic photoperiod treatments effectively controlled seedling height without inducing major root dry matter loss, and upon planting, all stock had minimal phenological disruption and there was no carry-over effect on first-year collar diameter increments. No one blackout regime was best for all species and seedlots, suggesting that unique blackout strategies are required for species and seedlots with different levels of physiological vigour. The dynamic blackout treatment appeared to induce less phenological perturbations in the Sitka-white spruce hybrid than previously indicated for conventionally applied static (e.g., constant 10-h day and 14-h night for four weeks) blackout treatments. This indicates the need for direct comparisons between static and dynamic applications of blackout, both at the nursery and in the field.

bibl.et: An assessment of the strategic importance of the hardwood resource in British Columbia.
bibl.pb: FRDA Research Program, Research Branch, BC Ministry of Forests and Lands
bibl.aa: Nawitka Renewable Resource Consultants Ltd., Victoria, BC, Canada.

ab.p: The important broadleaved tree species in British Columbia are Alnus rubra, Acer macrophyllum and Populus balsamifera subsp. trichocarpa on the coast, and P. tremuloides, Betula papyrifera and P. balsamifera subsp. balsamifera in the interior. This report describes the ecology of hardwood forests, their multiple use potential for wildlife, fisheries, recreation, cultural importance and aesthetics, and the resources and utilization of the wood.

bibl.et: Differences in the response of carbon assimilation to summer stress (water deficits, high light and temperature) in four Mediterranean tree species.
bibl.aa: Instituto Superior de Agronomia, Tapada da Ajuda, P-1399 Lisboa Codex, Portugal.

ab.p: Daily changes in photoprotective mechanisms were studied in sun leaves of Quercus suber, Q. ilex, Olea europaea and Eucalyptus globulus trees during summer 1995 at Herdade do Paço de Camões, Portugal. Even though stomatal closure explained most of the diurnal variation in carbon assimilation throughout the summer, a decline in the photochemical yield of photosystem II also occurred, as a result of an excess of intercepted solar radiation when carbon assimilation was limited by stomatal closure due to high vapour pressure deficits and/or soil water deficits. These changes were accompanied by the conversion of violaxanthin to antheraxanthin and zeaxanthin which was correlated with thermal dissipation of excess photon energy. In spite of a common general response, differences between species were observed. Olea europaea, which is a slow-growing tree, had the lowest net photosynthetic rates, the highest proportion of carotenoids in relation to chlorophyll and the highest rates of de-epoxidation of violaxanthin. This enabled a large thermal dissipation of the excess intercepted radiation but led to rather low values of light use for photochemistry (about 20%). In contrast, in E. globulus, a fast-growing tree, photosynthetic rates were the highest, thermal dissipation of absorbed radiation the lowest and maximum values of light use for photochemistry reached about 50%. The two Quercus species exhibited an intermediate response. A high degree of co-ordination is apparent between stomatal behaviour, photosynthetic capacity and photoprotection mechanisms.

bibl.et: A mathematical model to describe the dynamic response of a spruce tree to the wind.
bibl.aa: Institut für Bioklimatologie, Georg-August Universität, Göttingen, Germany.

ab.p: A mathematical, computer-based, dynamic sway model of a Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) tree was developed and tested against measurements of the movement of a tree within a forest. The model tree was divided into segments each with a stiffness, mass and damping parameter. Equations were formulated to describe the response of every segment which together form a system of coupled differential equations. These were solved with the aid of matrices and from the resulting modes, the transfer function of the tree was found and used to calculate the movement of the tree in the wind. Comparison of the modelled movement of a tree in response to the measured wind speed above a forest canopy gave good agreement with the measured movement of the top of the tree but less satisfactory agreement close to the base. The comparison also pointed to the complexity of tree response to the wind and inadequacies in the model. In particular, the branches need to be treated as coupled cantilevers attached to the stem rather than simply as masses lumped together.

L.); (8) Defining the role of non-native broadleaves for growing timber in Britain (Kerr, G.); (9) Growth characteristics of locally grown native provenances compared with translocated and foreign stock (Samuel, C. C.); (11) Native and non-native trees as factors in habitat selection by woodland birds in Britain (Fuller, R. J.); (12) Non-native trees in the rural landscape: why and where (Bell, S.); (13) Urban trees: the role of natives in the urban landscape (Barker, G.); (14) The case for native trees and woodland for nature conservation and the merits of non-native species (Kirby, K.; Latham, J.; Hampson, A.); (15) Can ethical considerations contribute to determining the choice of trees species and woodland types? (Worrell, R.); (16) A tangle of wood tales (Clifford, S.); (17) Native woodland schemes and their place in the general pattern of British forestry (Jenkins, D.); and (18) Introduction and cultivation of exotic forest trees in Italy (Ciancio, O.; Mercurio, R.; Nocentini, S.).

bibl.do: Biodiversity and conservation of the indigenous forests of the Kenya highlands.
bibl.et: Biodiversity and conservation of the indigenous forests of the Kenya highlands.

ab.p: The author of this report is formerly an ecologist at the East African Agriculture and Forestry Research Organisation at Muguga, Kenya. The account is arranged in 6 main parts: Introduction: biodiversity and the biotic community; Exploited and secondary forests; Wildlife and forest regeneration; Microclimate and occult precipitation; Rehabilitating exploited forests; and Forest parks and reserves. Four annexures give: (1) a provisional check list of forest trees in South West Kenya, by 11 forest types; (2) Examples of residual and secondary forest components after selective felling in 4 forest types; (3) provisional check lists (two) of forest birds in montane and intermediate forests, and in western moist intermediate forests; and (4) 2 check lists of forest animals - a partial list not including larger game animals, and additional species found only in western moist intermediate forests.

bibl.do: Forest resource use options in Tasmania: economic implications.
bibl.et: Forest resource use options in Tasmania: economic implications.
bibl.pb: Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE)

ab.p: In order to address the conflicts arising over the use of Australia's native forests, Commonwealth and state governments have have established Comprehensive Regional Assessments (CRAs) of Australian forests. The aim is to sign joint Commonwealth-state Regional Forest Agreements (RFAs) which will set out agreed uses for up to 20 yr. The 2 key outcomes from the Tasmanian RFA were to establish a comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) reserve system, and to ensure security of access to specified native forests for wood production and mining for the duration of the agreement. The objective of this study is to provide information on forest related industries in Tasmania, including their contribution to the Australian and Tasmanian economies, and to assess the economic implications of the resource use options considered in the RFA - the activities most likely to be affected are the logging and wood processing industries, and the mining and mineral processing industries, although forest based tourism and recreation and some minor forest products industries may also be affected. This report discusses these issues in 7 chapters: (1) Introduction; (2) Forest related industries in the Tasmanian economy; (3) Tasmania's logging and wood processing industries; (4) Tasmania's mining and mineral processing industries; (5) Tourism and recreation in Tasmania's forest areas; (6) Economywide effects of reduced output from Tasmania's forestry and mining industries; and (7) Concluding comments.

bibl.av: Liang, C.\Lin, Z. F.\Kong, G. H.
bibl.et: Photosynthesis-light response characteristics of subtropical tree species seedlings under different irradiances.
bibl.aa: South China Institute of Botany, Academia Sinica, Guangzhou 510650, Guangdong, China.

ab.p: Pot experiments were carried out with seedlings of 4 species (Pinus massoniana, Schima superba, Castanopsis fissa and Cryptocarya concinna), dominant in Dinghushan subtropical forests, Guangdong. The seedlings were grown under 100, 40 and 16% of natural illumination for one year, and their photosynthesis/light response curves were determined under a series of light intensities (0-2500 µmol quanta m-2 s-1). Dark respiration rate (DRR), maximum net photosynthetic rate (Amax), quantum use efficiency (QUE), light compensation point (LCP), and light saturation point (LSP) were compared under different irradiances. the results showed that C. concinna is shade-tolerant and has a limited photosynthetic potential for acclimatizing to high PFD [photosynthetic flux density]; the Amax of seedlings growing under 100% sunlight was about 58% of those growing under heavy shade (16% sunlight). P. massoniana, S. superba and C. fissa are sun-loving species with higher DRR, Amax, LCP, LSP, and photosynthetic potential. P. massoniana showed a limited photosynthetic potential for acclimatizing to low PFD, while S. superba and C. fissa showed a relatively high photosynthetic potential for acclimatizing to high and low PFD. The relationship between photosynthetic physiological characters of tree species and their successional status is discussed.

bibl.et: Combining ability analysis on the main characters of Pinus tabulaeformis.

ab.p: Analysis of the progeny of diallel crosses, including self and reciprocal crosses, between 5 Pinus tabulaeformis parents, showed that there were differences in inheritance characteristics of the F1 generation, determined by general combining ability (GCA), specific combining ability (SCA), and reciprocal effects, with GCA the main determinant. Two crosses with higher genetic gain were identified.

bibl.do: Advances in Forestry Research in India
bibl.et: An ecological reconnaissance of lateritic forest of South West Bengal.
bibl.aa: Tropical Forest Research Institute Jabalpur, MP, India.

ab.p: A comparative ecological survey was conducted in forests under different management regimes, such as coppice sal (Shorea robusta) forests managed by Forest Protection Committees (FPCs), preservation plots managed by the Forest Department and plantation forests. Detailed data are tabulated on the species found in the forests, with IVI (Importance Value Indexes) for them all, and community phytosociological indexes and similarity indexes. The comparison showed that FPC managed forests are more biodiverse. Variations in phytosociological parameters in the differently managed communities are attributed to their different management status rather than to any environmental factor. The results of this study may help in taking future management decisions for ecorestoration in the degraded forests of this region through Joint Forest Management (JFM) involving the local community.

bibl.do: Advances in Forestry Research in India
bibl.et: Women's participation in joint forest management - governing factors and a development model.
bibl.aa: Resource Survey And Management Division F.R.I., Dehradun, UP, India.

ab.p: The importance of a change in women's role from that of wage labour to that of decision maker in the success of any afforestation programme of new areas, or in the protection of degraded forests, is emphasized. The new Joint Forest Management (JFM) Programme, which aims to both plant and protect forests, was started in India in 1990. For the success of this programme the participation of people, particularly women, is necessary. Mostly women are engaged in collection of fuelwood, fodder and small timber from forest, so they have the direct contact with the forest. Such programmes cannot succeed without the participation of these women. A number of factors are responsible for the successful participation of women in JFM programmes. In this paper, these factors are discussed and the necessary components for a development model which allows equal opportunities for members of village communities are noted.

bibl.av: Peng, C. L.\Lin, Z. F.\Lin, G. Z.\Wei, C. M.
bibl.et: Effect of human activities on atmospheric CO2 concentration in subtropical forests and carbohydrate content of two species of woody plants.
bibl.aa: South China Institute of Botany, Academia Sinica, Guangzhou 510650, Guangdong, China.

ab.p: The effect of human activities, including tourism, religious activities, and industrial waste gas, were investigated on atmospheric CO2 concentration of subtropical forest [in Dinghushan nature reserve, Guangdong Province] and the carbohydrate content of 2 tree species, Schima superba and Pinus massoniana. The results showed that human activities not only changed the daily variation, but also the vertical distribution of CO2 within forests. Compared with the control site (in the core area of the Biosphere Reserve), the CO2 concentration in disturbed sites increased by 4-11 µl/litre. The total contents of soluble sugars and non-structural carbohydrate in leaves of the 2 tree species decreased with increasing intensity of human activities, and the trends of decrease were consistent with the increasing of CO2 concentration. The contents of soluble sugars and starch were more sensitive to human activities in leaf samples from the upper canopy than the lower canopy, while the effect of human activities on the content of cellulose was not significant. The carbohydrate metabolism of S. superba and P. massoniana responded differently to human activities.

bibl.av: He, X. Y.\Zhang, C. G.\Yang, S. H.\Chen, W.
bibl.et: Role of nitrogen-fixing trees in mixed forest II. Seasonal variation patterns of N and P contents in leaves of nitrogen-fixing trees.
bibl.aa: Institute of Applied Ecology, Academia Sinica, Shenyang 110015, Liaoning, China.

ab.p: The seasonal variation in contents and export rate of N and P in leaves and the export course of N and P in senescent leaves were studied in nitrogen-fixing and non-nitrogen-fixing tree species [in Liaoning]. There was an obvious seasonal variation of N and P contents in the leaves of all trees tested trees, with an average variation rate of 21-23%. Variation was maximum at the senescent stage, and during this stage, the dynamic characteristics of N and P in the leaves were different between nitrogen-fixing and non-nitrogen-fixing trees. The former displayed a low export rate, and the N content in their fallen leaves was 1.6-3.7 times higher than that of the latter. The N content in leaves of nitrogen fixing trees was about 2.5% in the growing season.

bibl.av: Zhang, Z. M.\Cui, K. M.\Li, J. B.
bibl.et: Changes of polysaccharide grain content and amylase isoenzyme in relation to periodicity of cambial activity in Pinus bungeana shoots.
bibl.aa: College of Life Sciences, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China.

ab.p: Studies in [Beijing] China, showed that the cambium of P. bungeana resumed its activity in early April with cell proliferation of immature xylem and phloem cells increasing. Some mature xylem cells occurred during the last 10 days of April,and the xylem and phloem were rapidly formed after May. Latewood was first formed at the beginning of June. Production of new xylem ceased in early August, and of phloem cells in mid-September. Seasonal changes of polysaccharide grain content in the tissues of P. bungeana were significantly correlated with the annual cycle of cambial activity. Polysaccharide grains continued to increase before and after cambial reactivity and then decreased gradually from June onwards after the latewood had been first formed, until it almost disappeared in the following January; gradual accumulation began again after March. The isoenzyme study revealed only one band of amylase after cambium reactivation, and 3 bands after ceasing to produce xylem; another 2 bands occurred in early December. These 5 bands all disappeared after reactivation of the cambium.

bibl.pb: FRDA Research Program, Research Branch, BC Ministry of Forests and Lands
bibl.aa: Canadian Forest Service, Pacific Forestry Centre, 506 West Burnside Road, Victoria, B.C. V8Z 1M5, Canada.

ab.p: The Forest Ecosystems Dynamics Programme was established in the early 1990s by the Pacific Forestry Centre to assess the effects of environmental changes on forest biodiversity, to assess the effects of forestry practices on carbon and nutrient dynamics in coastal forests, to conserve genetic resources, and to address the climate change issue in the Pacific and Yukon Region of Forestry Canada. The proceedings include 31 presentations which summarize the work completed up to the time of the full-scale review of the project in February 1993, with the recommendations of the review panel.

bibl.et: Vegetation and seedling development following site preparation in the ESSFwm subzone of Glenogle Creek, Nelson Forest Region, British Columbia: a case study.
bibl.pb: FRDA Research Program, Research Branch, BC Ministry of Forests and Lands
bibl.aa: Forestry Canada, Pacific Forestry Centre, 506 Burnside Road, Victoria, B.C. V8Z 1M5, Canada.

ab.p: A study of the response of vegetation and planted Engelmann spruce (Picea engelmannii) seedlings to operational site preparation procedures for reforestation was initiated in 1986 in the Glenogle Creek Watershed of southeast British Columbia. The five site preparation techniques tested consisted of (1) brush blade with contour, (2) brush blade across contour, (3) FMC (a flex-track forwarder) blade with contour on gentle to moderately steep terrain; (4) FMC dip and dive on steep slopes; and (5) prescribed burning on moderately steep slopes. Untreated plots were located in the undisturbed areas between scarified strips. Scarification was conducted in brush land rated not satisfactorily restocked (NSR). Slash burning was performed following more recent logging, but would be similar to a brown and burn treatment of NSR land. The study was conducted on a northeast-facing slope in the ESSFwm biogeoclimatic subzone. This report presents data on vegetation development and Engelmann spruce growth during the first 5 years following planting. Re-establishment of vegetation appears to have been sufficiently retarded by all site preparation techniques to allow planted Engelmann spruce seedlings to establish. Growth of Engelmann spruce seedlings was significantly better on the burned site than on scarified sites, and better on the dip and dive and brush blade across contour treatments than on other scarification procedures. Fireweed (Epilobium angustifolium) was the most prominent invader, and some spruce seedlings were crowded and overtopped by it, becoming either spindly or deformed. Natural regeneration may be achieved, provided scarification is conducted, but could be delayed for over 10 years.

index.de: artificial regeneration\burning\forestry machinery\plant competition\seedling growth\seedlings\site preparation\stand establishment\tillage\vegetation management\weeds

bibl.et: Numerical predictions on the soil thermal effect under surface fire conditions.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Engenharia Mecânica - F.C.T.U.C., Universidade de Coimbra, 3000 Coimbra, Portugal.

ab.p: A control volume numerical method is used to predict the temperature distribution inside a soil column, the surface of which has been swept by a two-dimensional flame front with pre-defined velocity and temperature distributions. Natural and forced convection, as well as radiation effects are included in the specification of the soil surface thermal boundary condition. The flame residence time and maximum temperature are identified as two major parameters to characterize the flame front. As expected, the heat penetration depth is confined to the near vicinity of the soil surface. Moreover, horizontal heat conduction throughout the soil does not always have a significant effect on its global, transient temperature distribution. The influence of wind velocity and of soil thermal diffusivity upon its temperature distribution are analysed. Radiation is the dominant contribution in the whole heat transfer process between flame and ground surface.
