ab.p: Essential oils were extracted by hydrodistillation from foliage of Abies nordmanniana, A. bornmuelleriana and A. equi-trojani in natural stands and A. cilicica in a plantation in Turkey, and the antimicrobial activity was tested against 11 bacteria and a yeast. The greatest activity was shown by A. cilicica and the least by A. bornmuelleriana and A. equi-trojani. None of the essential oils showed activity against Escherichia coli.

bibl.aa: Instituto de Ciencias Naturales, Santafé de Bogotá, Colombia.

ab.p: The first chapter gives a historical review of vegetation studies in Colombia and the second describes the methods (both classical and computerized) of studying the vegetation. The third, main chapter describes 1008 plant communities, with notes on their geographical distribution, ecological features, and dominant and associated species. The final chapter discusses the distribution of vegetation types within Columbia, noting that the Andean region has the largest number of identified types. This is possibly because the region has more access than other areas and has had more visits by botanists.

bibl.et: Game damage prevention concept for the canton of Glarus.
bibl.ft: Wildschadenverhütungskonzept des Kantons Glarus.
bibl.aa: Geroldsegg, CH-8722 Kaltbrunn, Switzerland.

ab.p: A concept for the prevention of game damage was established as part of forest management planning in the canton of Glarus, Switzerland, in 1995. Measures were proposed for game management and habitat improvements. Regular surveys (every 3-4 years) of game damage and forest regeneration provides the data for an ecologically sound hunting plan. Random sampling in special areas provides information on the annual development of game damage. Efficient game damage prevention (50% reduction of damaged areas in 2004 and 20% damage allowed in protection forests) should be reached in stages of 3-4 years in different sectors (hunting, forestry, agriculture and nature conservation, tourism and spatial planning, traditional protection measures). All measures are subject of separate plans. A concept working group was set up by the government to coordinate proposed measures.

ab.p: Trials with Pinus patula comprised of 283 families from 15 provenances collected within the native range of Mexico have been established during 1985-93 by Smurfit Carton de Colombia at 9 sites. In addition, 99 families of first and second generation selected material from a breeding programme in South Africa have been planted to expand the genetic base in the tree improvement programme. Height, survival and volume increment are reported.

bibl.et: Genetic parameters of wood quality characteristics in Eucalyptus grandis.
bibl.ft: Parâmetros genéticos de características de qualidade da madeira em Eucalytpus grandis.
bibl.aa: Champion Papel e Celulose Ltda., 13840-000 Mogi-Guaçu-SP, Brazil.

ab.p: The genetic parameters were estimated of wood quality characteristics in a progeny test of half-sib families of Eucalyptus grandis in Bortas, São Paulo, Brazil. The evaluations were performed at the age of 84 months. Significant genetic differences were found between progenies for wood basic density, fibre length and felting index. However, no significant genetic differences were found for fibre width, lumen diameter, thickness of fibre wall, Runkel index, flexibility coefficient and wall fraction coefficient. The phenotypic, genetic and environmental correlations were not high.

bibl.av: Jiao, R. Z.\Yang, C. D.\Tu, X. N.\Sheng, W. T.
bibl.et: Changes in undergrowth, soil microorganisms, enzyme activity and nutrients in different development stages of a Chinese fir plantation.
bibl.aa: Research Institute of Forestry, CAF, Beijing 100091, China.

ab.p: Studies were made of the soil biology under Chinese fir (Cunninghamia lanceolata) plantations [aged 4, 7, 15, 18, 24 and 25 yr old in Jiangxi] China. With the reduction of undergrowth cover which occurs between juvenile and medium ages, soil microorganisms (bacteria, actinomycetes and fungi other than actinomycetes) and soil enzyme activity (especially proteinase, phosphorylase and sucrase) and organic nutrient content fell rapidly. Later, with the increase in undergrowth cover which occurs with further maturation of the stand, the amount of soil microorganisms and enzyme activity (especially the proteinase, phosphorylase and sucrase) and the organic nutrient content increased gradually. The decrease in phosphorylase and hydrogen peroxidase at medium ages caused an accumulation of phenolic compounds in the soil. It is suggested that this one of the causes of yield reduction or low survival in successive rotations of Chinese fir.

bibl.av: Song, X. B.\Zheng, W. F.\Zhang, X. W.\Ma, S. T.
bibl.et: Influence of infection by mycoplasma like organisms (MLO) on Paulownia tissues and cells.
bibl.aa: Forestry Research Institute of Shanxi Province, Yangling, Shanxi 712100, China.

ab.p: Investigations were made of the characteristics of tissues and cells of Paulownia tomentosa × P. fortunei infected by mycoplasma-like organisms (MLOs). An electron microscopic study showed that a large amount of callose had accumulated in infected cells, and filled the sieve tube mesh and the pathways between cells. Using atomic absorption spectrometry, the rate of electrolyte seepage from xylem and cortex was measured; in healthy xylem it was 59.17%, but in the infected xylem it was only 8.82%, while in the cortex the converse reaction was found µ electrolyte seepage was 2.26% in healthy cortex but 21.81% in infected cortex. Microscopy also showed that the thickness of cambium in healthy branches was 10.28 µm, but in infected branches it was 6.71 µm. The relative thicknesses of the cortex and xylem in healthy and infected tissues were similar.

index.de: cytology\effects\forest trees\hybrids\infection\mycoplasma-like organisms\plant diseases\plant pathogenic bacteria\plant pathogens\plant pathology\plant tissues\trees\woody plants

bibl.av: De Barros, N. F.\De Souza, A. L.\Da Silva, A. F.
bibl.et: Biomass and nutrient distribution in different forest and pasture vegetation in Rio Doce Valley, MG.
bibl.ft: Distribuição de biomassa e de nutrientes em diferentes coberturas florestais e pastagem na região do Médio Rio Doce - MG.
bibl.aa: EMBRAPA/CPATSA, 563000-000 Petrolina, PE, Brazil.

ab.p: Biomass and distribution of major nutrients (N, P, K, Ca and Mg) were evaluated in 7 vegetation types in order to assess possible losses in productivity as a consequence of clearing natural Atlantic Forest for other land uses in Minas Gerais, Brazil. The vegetation types included were: a natural forest representing the Atlantic Forest; a 25-yr-old secondary forest; 24-yr-old plantations of braúna (Melanoxylon brauna [Melanoxylum brauna]), angico (Newtonia contorta) and angico + ipê (Paratecoma peroba); an 8-yr-old Eucalyptus citriodora plantation; and natural pasture of Mellinis minutiflora [Melinis minutiflora]. Total biomass was lowest in the secondary natural forest but similar among the other forest types. In the plantations biomass distribution followed the order stemwood > stembark > branches > leaves, whereas in the natural forests the order was stemwood > branches > stembark > leaves. Nutrient concentration in the live tree component did not show large variations among forest types, but they were much higher in the forest floor of the natural forests than in the plantations. Nitrogen concentration was lowest in the pasture litter and the E. citriodora forest litter. The nutrient capital of the plant-soil (0-60 cm depth) system indicates that the substitution of natural forest could result in loss of productivity mainly when the land is used for pasture, followed by planting brauna. The mixed plantation of angico + ipê was the most similar land use to natural forest in terms of nutrient capital.

bibl.et: Termite control in eucalypt forests with fipronil (Regent 20G) applied to the soil surface.
bibl.ft: Controle de cupins em florestas de eucalipto com o inseticida fipronil (Regent 20G) aplicado em cobertura.
bibl.aa: Dep. de Defesa Fitossanitária, FCA/UNESP, Faz. Lageado, 18603-970 Botucatus, SP, Brazil.

ab.p: The efficiency of fipronil in subterranean termite (Heterotermes tenuis and Cornitermes sp.) control was evaluated in a 2-yr-old Eucalyptus grandis plantation in Minas Gerais, Brazil. Doses of 2.5, 5.0, and 7.5 g per plant of Regent 20G (fipronil) were applied on the soil surface around tree stems, and infestation by the 2 termite species was monitored at intervals over 1 yr. The best termite control was with 5.0 and 7.5 g Regent 20G per plant, with control during the evaluation period at 84.0-92.90% and 96.0-100.06%, respectively,. The doses of 2.5 g Regent 20G and 10 g Termicidol powder (aldrin/standard) per plant showed lowest average efficiencies of termite control of 58.8 and 67.6%, respectively. No insecticide phytotoxicity to E. grandis was observed.

bibl.et: Training evaluation of chainsaw operators in timber cutting - a case study.
bibl.ft: Avaliação do treinamento de operadores de motosserra no corte florestal - um estudo de caso.
bibl.aa: Dep. de Engenharia Florestal, UFV, 36571-000 Viçosa, MG, Brazil.

ab.p: Data for this study were obtained from a contracting firm located in the state of São Paulo, Brazil. The logging performance of chainsaw operators was evaluated in order to verify whether they were carrying out their work correctly (i.e. applying the techniques and procedures taught during training). The overall performance coefficients of the workers were 68.0, 77.0 and 84.2%, respectively, at 30, 60 and 90 days after training; these values are significantly different between training periods. When the evaluation was done on work technique (procedures which the workers had the greatest difficulty in performing correctly) a lower performance coefficient (58.8%) was obtained 30 days after training. However, the quality of the final product (the work done) was very satisfactory, with a performance coefficient of 80.3% obtained 30 days after training. The most difficult operation for the workers to perform was to maintain the correct posture during felling. No problem was detected in relation to the use and conservation of personal protection equipment.

bibl.et: Foliage determinants of light interception in sunny and shaded branches of Fagus sylvatica (L.).
bibl.aa: Laboratoire d'écophysiologie végétale, CNRS-URA 2154, Université Paris-Sud, 91 405 Orsay Cedex, France.

ab.p: A 3D digitizing device was used to acquire architectural information regarding the branches from open-grown and understorey saplings of Fagus sylvatica. Branch and shoot images were reconstructed from the data set using image synthesis software (freeware POV-Ray®). Image analysis enabled the quantitative investigation of light interception at the shoot and the branch scales, the derivation of relevant structural parameters at both scales, and the investigation of the relationships between the observed shift with light environment on the independent effects of leaf inclination, within-shoot shading, shoot density and dispersion within the branch. Leaf display pattern (at the branch and shoot scale), was strongly affected by light availability. At the shoot level, reduced self-shading in shaded conditions resulted in an increased light capture (<32%), expressed on a leaf area basis in the vertical direction. At the branch level, a shaded environment resulted in a substantial increase of 60%. Considering that incident irradiance varies by a factor of 20 between understorey and open conditions, plasticity in branch architecture allows to reduce the discrepancy in the amount of intercepted light to a factor 12. This difference in light capture ability at the branch level resulted from: (i) more horizontally inclined leaves in the shade; (ii) a greater branch leaf area index in sunny conditions; and (iii) a more regular shoot dispersion in shade. Results are discussed in terms of optimal architecture for carbon gains, and the use of this method for the parameterization of radiative transfer models is emphasised.

index.de: branches\carbon\computer software\cycling\environmental factors\foliage\forest trees\habit\image processing\imagery\interception\leaf angle\leaf area index\leaves\light\mathematical models\models\morphology\shade\shoots\trees\woody plants

bibl.et: Douglas fir.
bibl.ft: Le Douglas.
bibl.ms: refs. at end of each chapter

ab.p: This technical handbook, written for landowners, foresters and silviculturalists, comprises 9 chapters which outline the planting, tending, harvesting and economics of Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) forest management in France. It contains many tables, maps (black and white, and colour) and photographs, which together with the short, clear texts within each chapter, summarize the research undertaken under the aegis of AFOCEL over the last 35 years. Chapters 1 and 2 outline the features and history of this exotic species in Europe and France. Chapters 3, 4, 5 and 6 (the creation of Douglas fir plantations, stand development, tending and harvesting, Douglas fir wood properties, and increment and yield) are the most detailed; Chapters 7, 8 and 9 describe important regions in France for Douglas fir, the economy of plantations and timber, and Douglas fir and the environment.

bibl.et: An introduction to the Sapindaceae in Thailand.
bibl.aa: Rijksherbarium/Hortus Botanicus, University of Leiden, P.O. Box 9514, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands.

ab.p: The Sapindaceae are distributed from India to the Pacific Ocean. Morphological characteristics are discussed, often in relation to ecology - the members of the family are small trees or shrubs. Details of flower biology, fruit dispersal, and germination are provided. The economic use of the plants is described, and special attention is given to the classification, concepts of species, evolutionary origin, and the ongoing development of new species in relation to geological changes. In addition a synoptical key to the genera (and species if the genus is monotypic) is provided. This key allows for identification from incomplete material. An analytical (or dichotomous or bracketed) key will be presented in the Flora of Thailand, together with keys to species.

bibl.et: Sacred grove relics as bird refugia.
bibl.aa: Centre for Interdisciplinary Studies, 9 Old Calcutta Road, Talpukur, Barrackpore 743 187, India.

ab.p: Sacred groves are patches of natural vegetation dedicated to certain local deities, from which no harvesting of living matter is permitted by the local communities. Ecologists currently recognize these sacred groves as a unique cultural institution for conserving local biodiversity. Numerous sacred groves are among the last representatives of climax vegetation in the Western Ghats and NE India, whereas sacred groves in other parts of the country have dwindled due to colonial land use policies and erosion of traditional values regarding natural resource use. Nevertheless, hundreds of relics of sacred groves exist in the tribal tracts of eastern India, and much of the tribal cultural life in West Bengal has been reported to be still centred around these relics. The observations reported here are the result of an ethnobiological survey conducted from early April to June 1996 in Jamboni, Jhargram, Gidhni, Belpahari and Banspahari Forest Ranges of western Midnapore district, West Bengal. As in a previous study, remnants of sacred grove were found in almost every tribal village in the region. Most of these groves, locally called Jahiristhan, are relics of ancient sacred groves, containing 10-20 trees, amidst a denuded lateritic expanse. The tree species mostly found in these relics include sal (Shorea robusta), asan (Terminalia tomentosa), karam (Adina cordifolia), banyan (Ficus benghalensis), aswath (F. religiosa), pial (Buchanania lanzan), piya-sal (Pterocarpus marsupium), neem (Azadirachta indica), and mahua (Bassia latifolia [Madhuca longifolia]). All these species are also found in sal forests, albeit mostly in reproductively immature stages. The relative habitat preferences of a large number of local bird species were investigated in the sacred groves, sal forest and settlement areas (including farm fields). Details are tabulated of the results of this investigation with brief discussion.

index.de: biodiversity\cultural heritage\forest trees\habitat selection\nature conservation\religion\trees\wild birds\woody plants
index.od: Azadirachta indica\birds\Buchanania lanzan\Ficus benghalensis\Ficus religiosa\Haldina cordifolia\Madhuca longifolia\plants\Pterocarpus marsupium\Shorea robusta\Terminalia elliptica

bibl.et: Conservation of India's endangered mega animals: tiger and lion.
bibl.aa: Tata Energy Research Institute, Habitat Place, Lodi Road, New Delhi 110 003, India.

ab.p: In the first half of the 20th century, lions and (particularly) tigers were decimated in India by the British and the Indian royalty for sport. At present tigers are being killed for sale of their bones and other parts to meet the unprecedented demand for traditional Chinese medicine. Despite this, India has the largest number of tigers in the world. It also harbours the only living population of the Asian lion in the world today. The conservation status of both species (and that of the Asian lion in particular), and appropriate conservation strategies, are discussed, including approaches based on ecosystems and on genetics.

bibl.do: African rainforests and the conservation of biodiversity: proceedings of the Limbe conference, Limbe Botanic Garden, Cameroon, 17-24 January 1997.
bibl.et: African rainforests and the conservation of biodiversity: proceedings of the Limbe conference, Limbe Botanic Garden, Cameroon, 17-24 January 1997.
bibl.ct: African rainforests and the conservation of biodiversity: proceedings of the Limbe conference, Limbe Botanic Garden, Cameroon, 17-24 January 1997.
bibl.ad: Gauld, I. D.\Bennun, L.\Musah, A. J.\Cheek, M.\Besong, J. B.\Lengeler, J. C.\Brocklesby, M. A.\Gardner, A.\Mupada, E.\Shepherd, G.\Davies, G.\Vabi, M. B.\Vermeulen, C.\Kemp, R. H.\Ndoye, O.\Emerton, L.\Ambrose-Oji, B.\Angoué, C. A.\Negussie, G.

ab.p: This conference was organized by Earthwatch Europe, with the support of the European Commission DGVIII, the Mount Cameroon Project (Limbe), the UK Department for International Development (DFID), and the UK Tropical Forest Forum. The proceedings includes plenary papers, a selection of working group papers, and a summary of the conference recommendations. A full list of all the papers presented is included in the conference agenda at the end. The 19 papers in the proceedings (all in English except for 2 in French) are arranged under 4 themes which are the same as the topics addressed by the working groups. Theme 1, Biological inventory and monitoring, has 4 papers: Inventory and monitoring biodiversity: a taxonomist's perspective (a plenary paper by Gauld, I. D.); Using forest birds to evaluate forest management: an East African perspective (Bennun, L.; Fanshawe, J.); Recent botanical inventories in Ghana and the FROGGIE programme (Musah, A. J.); and Plant inventory for conservation management: the Kew-Earthwatch programme in Western Cameroon, 1993-96 (Cheek, M.; Cable, S.). Theme 2, Participatory approaches to forest management, has 5 papers: Best options for securing the future of African rain forest (a plenary paper by Besong, J. B.); Local people's participation in forest resource assessment: a review of field experience [in Africa, America and Asia] (Lengeler, J. C.); Developing participatory forest management: the user group analysis on Mount Cameroon (Brocklesby, M. A.; Oji, B. A.; Tekwe, C. F.); Community forest management at the Kilum-Ijim Forest Project [in Cameroon]: lessons learned so far (Gardner, A.; Anders, S.; Asanga, C.; Jeremiah, N.); and Towards collaborative forest management in the conservation of Uganda's rain forests (Mupada, E.). Theme 3, Institutional frameworks for forest conservation, has 4 papers: Linking international priority-setting to local institutional management. (Shepherd, G.; Brown, D.); Limbe Botanic Garden: how botanic gardens can support forest conservation, and approaches to long-term financing for conservation centres in Africa (Davies, G.; Ndam, N.); Institutional framework for biodiversity conservation in Cameroon (Vabi, M. B.; Gartlan, S. J.); and Problématique de la délimitation des forêts communautaires en forêt dense humide, Sud-Est Cameroun [Problems in delimiting community forests in dense rain forest in South-East Cameroon] (Vermeulen, C.). Theme 4, Valuing forest resources for conservation purposes, has 6 papers: How to give sufficient value to the forest to keep it standing? (Kemp, R. H.); The markets of non-timber products in the humid forest zone of Cameroon (Ndoye, O.; Perez, M. R.); Livelihood values and conservation in Mount Kenya Forest. (Emerton, L.); Valuing forest products from Mount Cameroon (Ambrose-Oji, B.); Les facteurs socio-économique de protection ou conservation de la forêt en milieu rural [Socioeconomic factors in the protection or conservation of forest in rural areas in Gabon] (Angoué, C. A.); and Use of traditional values in the search for conservation goals: the kaya [homestead] forests of the Kenyan coast. (Negussie, G.).

bibl.et: Application of laser incising to microwave drying of sugi square lumber with black-heart.
bibl.aa: Department of Environment and Natural Resouce Science, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Fuchu, Tokyo 183, Japan.

ab.p: Laser incising was tested as a pretreatment to reduce the drying time for low permeable softwood such as sugi (Cryptomeria japonica) with black-heart. The square lumber (120×120×1000mm) of sugi with black-heart and initial moisture contents between 160 and 230% were incised by laser treatment. The square lumber specimens were then dried after sealing end faces with silicone adhesive. Four types of drying methods were used: alternating microwave heating and dehumidification drying, alternating microwave heating and conventional kiln drying, microwave drying, and kiln drying. It was found that the moisture content of a laser incised square lumber was reduced significantly by microwave heating and microwave drying, but there was no significant difference for the other drying methods. Drying time could be reduced to about 1/260 of the conventional kiln drying time, i.e. only 6 hours of so, by using continuous microwave drying for densely laser-incised square lumber.

bibl.do: Journal of Beijing Forestry University, English edition
bibl.et: The status and advances of genetic improvement of Populus tomentosa Carr.
bibl.aa: College of Forest Resources and Environment, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing 100083, China.

ab.p: Populus tomentosa is considered to be the best native poplar species in China. Therefore, a national programme for selection and breeding of the species was established in 1983. Since then, much work has been done, including research on (1) collection and conservation of genetic resources and the establishment of a clonal archive and arboretum, (2) provenance tests and clonal selection for plywood and construction timber, (3) back-cross breeding for pulpwood, (4) multiple crossing for resistance to cold and drought, (5) triploid breeding, and (6) development of a rapid system of vegetative propagation. Brief accounts are given of each of these programme parts.

bibl.et: Accelerated aging of slash pine seed.
bibl.aa: Conifers Research Centre, Shimla-171 001 (H.P.), India.

ab.p: As part of a training course at Mississippi University, USA, an accelerated aging test was conducted on slash pine (Pinus elliottii) seeds which were aged at 100% RH (relative humidity) at 39, 41 or 45°C for 24-120 h (at 24 h intervals). This test is a method of estimating seed vigour and storability. Germination parameters, leachate conductivity and moisture content of the treated seeds was determined. A slight increase in germination and seed vigour was observed in 96-h aged seed at 39°C, otherwise all aging treatments reduced seed germination with seed death reached after 72 and 48 h of aging at 41 and 45°C. Seed moisture contents and leachate conductivities increased as temperature and aging period increased.

bibl.do: Journal of World Forest Resource Management
bibl.et: Making the poorest poorer: policies, laws and trade in medicinal plants in Nepal.
bibl.aa: Unit of Forestry, Department of Economics and Natural Resources, Royal Veterinary and Agricultural University, Thorvaldsensvej 57, 1871 Frederiksberg C, Copenhagen, Denmark.

ab.p: Nepal's forests are rich in medicinal and aromatic plants (MAPs). A large number of these are commercially utilized and provide an important source of income to hill and mountain farmers. Nepal's forest policy and forest-related programmes provide perhaps the best framework for the improved utilization of MAPs of any developing country. However, the new forest legislation of 1993 and 1995 is still inconsistent with declared long-term policy objectives and will continue to be detrimental to hill and mountain farmers by lowering income from MAP collection. The underlying reasons for this dichotomy are discussed, and illustrated by a case study of the utilization of MAPs in Gorkha District, central Nepal. Alternative policy solutions are discussed, including the need to place MAPs higher on the policy agenda, re-evaluate the approach taken to MAP utilization, and fundamentally change forest legislation.

bibl.do: Journal of World Forest Resource Management
bibl.et: The recreational value of tropical forests in Malaysia.
bibl.aa: Centre for Research in Environmental Appraisal and Management, Department of Town and Country Planning, University of Newcastle upon Tyne, Newcastle upon Tyne, NE1 7RU, UK.

ab.p: Forest Recreation Areas (FRAs) in Malaysia are one element of a forestry strategy directed towards the sustainable use of the remaining areas of tropical forest. FRAs provide informal recreational opportunities, free of charge to the public. In this study the recreational value of FRAs was estimated using a contingent valuation method. To assess the validity of the results, individual travel cost models were developed for three FRAs. Both sets of results correspond over a number of criteria. The aggregate benefits of FRAs exceed the costs of their provision, and more could be justified on benefit/cost grounds. Despite this, FRAs will not result in the conservation of large areas of tropical forest in Malaysia.

bibl.et: Quantitative variation of trace elements in needles of Pinus massoniana from different provenances and their correlation with annual growth.
bibl.aa: Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjiang 210037, Jiangsu, China.

ab.p: Ten trace elements in needles of Pinus massoniana were analysed during dormancy using an inductively coupled plasma quantometer (ICPQ); the samples were from a trial of 10 provenances in [Zhejiang] China. Annual growth of DBH (diameter at breast height) and height of the provenances was also measured. There was variation of trace element contents among provenances, with the contents of several elements negatively correlated with the latitude and the longitude of origin. A stepwise regression analysis between trace element content and DBH and height growth indicated that the content of Li could be used as an early test for the growth of Pinus massoniana.

bibl.et: Chapter 5. Forest futures for Papua New Guinea: logging or community forestry?
bibl.ct: Environment and development in the Pacific Islands.
bibl.pb: National Centre for Development Studies, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Australian National University

ab.p: An historical analysis of the economic and environmental crisis in Papua New Guinea, focusing on forest resources and policy, the growth of logging, logging for export, the government and difficulties in controlling illegal logging, and the establishment of the Pacific Heritage Foundation in 1992. The latter is an NGO which recognizes the right of the landholder/community to use the forest as a source of income, but promotes sustainable use (for logging) through community projects established under strict criteria, which are regarded as preferable to the uninhibited destruction of the forests which has been carried out by foreign-based logging companies.

bibl.ct: Environment and development in the Pacific Islands.
bibl.pb: National Centre for Development Studies, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Australian National University

ab.p: This chapter responds to the previous one by Henderson, M., which discusses the history of the forest (logging) industry and forest policy in Papua New Guinea, and promotes sustainable (NGO based) alternatives to the existing exploitation based on community involvement. Three aspects are addressed: the definition of sustainable forest management, the distribution of economic rent from large-scale logging operations, and the nature of community attitudes to the choice between sustainable and unsustainable forms of development.

bibl.et: Flora and vegetation of the Quaternary temperate stages of NW Europe: evidence for large-scale range changes.
bibl.ct: Past and future rapid environmental changes: the spatial and evolutionary responses of terrestrial biota. Proceedings of the NATO advanced research workshop held at Crieff, Scotland, 26-30 June 1995.
bibl.ms: NATO ASI Series. Series I, Global environment change, vol. 47
bibl.aa: Department of Geography, Museum Building, Trinity College, Dublin 2, Irish Republic.

ab.p: The interglacial response of plant taxa in north west Europe during the Pleistocene and Holocene periods is examined using oxygen isotope records and comparison between terrestrial interglacial sequences and GRIP ice core studies. Successive recolonization by plant taxa is examined, patterns in contraction and expansion in plant ranges are constructed and the species composition and distribution of forests is investigated, for both north-west Europe and Ireland in particular.

bibl.av: Hsieh, H. C.\Cheng, C. C.\Chen, Y. C.
bibl.et: Building an expert system for forest land classification.
bibl.aa: Division of Forest Management, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, 53 Nan-Hai Rd., Taipei, Taiwan.

ab.p: The forest-land classification expert system described in this study used the Nexpert Object expert system tool with object-orientated methods to represent related data and production rules. The rule-based knowledge built into this expert system mainly included study results of forest land classification in the Lukuei Experimental Forest of the Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, supplemented by the forest site quality classification expertise of the Taiwan Forest Bureau, and the slope-land land-use classification criteria of the Taiwan Soil and Water Conservation Bureau. One special feature of the expert system was linking the attribute and spatial data from the ArcView geographical information system to support database queries, and the other was connecting hypertext and graphs from the HSC multimedia system to show hierarchical descriptive knowledge. The expert system was based on a personal computer with user-friendly window interfaces and could offer or explain domestic forest-land classification knowledge, including classification systems, classification procedures, database queries, and suggestions. End-users are able to attain desired information about forest-land classification through the inferences from forward or backward chaining mechanics. The functions of the expert system successfully achieve the objectives of consultation and inquiry, education, training, and comparison.

bibl.et: Effect of seed maturity on storability of Litsea acuminata seeds.
bibl.aa: Hengchun Station, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, 203 Kungyuien Rd., Hengchun, Pingtung County, Taiwan.

ab.p: Litsea acuminata seeds were harvested at different dates in two regions of Taiwan and stored at 5°C in sphagnum moss with different moisture contents. Seeds collected 2 weeks before maturity stored less well than did mature seeds. The germination percentages of maturing seeds from the Fu-shan region stored at 5°C for 3 months rapidly declined from 86 to 15%, but mature seeds maintained 70% germination after 12 months under the same storage conditions. In contrast, seeds from the Lien-hua-chi region exhibited better storability. The germination of maturing seeds decreased to 60% over 3 months and to 30% over 7 months at 5°C storage temperature, but mature seeds maintained 80% germination for 12 months. Seeds stored in sphagnum with different moisture contents showed no significant differences in storability among treatments. When air dried for 72 h, germination percentages of L. acuminata seeds decreased from 98 to 24%, and the linear relationship between germination percentage and seed moisture content shows that the lower the moisture content, the greater the damage to seeds. The seeds can thus be described as recalcitrant in their storage behaviour.

index.de: forest trees\moisture content\seed collection\seed germination\seed maturation\seed moisture\seeds\storage\trees\variation\viability\woody plants

bibl.et: A study on the relationship of shelter-forest microclimatic effects on man-made oasis and crop production in Wulanbuhe sandy region.
bibl.aa: Desert Forest Experimental Centre, CAF, Dengkou, Nei Menggu, China.

ab.p: The study was carried out during 1992-95 in Wulanbuhe [Nei Menggu] China, in an experimental shelterbelt network of Populus bolleana [P. alba var. pyrimidalis]. The windbreak efficiency of the network was 39-40% in the leafless season and 55.8-56.2% when the trees were in leaf. Temperatures in the windbreak area decreased by 0.4-0.6°C, with larger decreases (1.2°C) in July (the hottest month). Evapotranspiration rate decreased by 24.3-24.7%, relative humidity increased by 8-15%, and days of desiccating hot wind decreased by 58.8% (33.3% near light windbreaks [spacing 2×8 m] and 87.5% near more dense types [2×1 m]). Under the protection of the network, the yield of crops (field and vegetable and plantation crops) increased by 5.14%, reaching 468 kg/ha, with a value of PBY&thin;655.2/ha.

bibl.et: Introduction and cultivation of Pinus caribaea Morelet in China II. Silviculture and future development.
bibl.aa: Research Institute of Forestry, CAF Beijing 100091, China.

ab.p: The first paper of these 2 discussed the introduction and genetic improvement of Pinus caribaea in China (same authors, Forest Research (1996) 9 (6) 625-632), where it has become an important forest plantation species in tropical and subtropical zones, with great potential for the development of commercial forestry. This paper reviews the silviculture, disease and insect problems and utilization of the species in China. The critical importance is emphasized of matching sites with different varieties or provenances for increasing productivity, and of using genetically improved seed and vegetative propagation of selected genetic material. It is recommended that more attention should be paid to the maintenance of long-term site productivity, and to the possibilities of establishing mixed plantations of P. caribaea with Eucalyptus or Acacia.

bibl.av: Lou, Y. P.\Wu, L. R.\Shao, D. F.\Yan, Z. W.
bibl.et: Effect of long-term management of pure Phyllostachys pubescens stands on soil fertility.
bibl.aa: Research Institute of Subtropical Forestry, CAF, Fuyang, Zhejiang 311400, China.

ab.p: Soil fertility was compared in a mixed bamboo/forest tree stand and in two pure bamboo (Phyllostachys pubescens) stands in [Zhejiang] China. The pure stands had resulted from silvicultural conversion of the mixed stand at different growth stages. At neighbouring sites, the soil fertility of the mixed stand was better than that of the pure bamboo stands after long-term management. As the management term of the pure bamboo stands increased natural soil fertility declined, with the rate of decline faster in the first 10 years than the second 10 years after conversion. The soil fertility index varied at different rates over this period. The fertility decline is attributed to both the silvicultural characteristics of the bamboo and the management regime. Details of the growth dynamics of the pure stands are given in an earlier paper (Lou YiPing et al. (1997) Forest Research 10 (1) 35-41).

bibl.av: Liang, C. J.\Li, G. H.\Li, G. W.\Gao, R. T.\Zhao, Z. Y.\Sun, J. Z.
bibl.et: Study on the use of systemic and pyrethroid insecticides to control Anoplophora glabripennis and Apriona germarii.
bibl.aa: Ressearch Institute of Forest Protection, CAF, Beijing 100091, China.

ab.p: Branches of Broussonetia papyrifera and Acer saccharum were soaked in aqueous solutions of carbofuran, aldicarb, phorate and monocrotophos at concentrations of 50 and 100 (B. papyrifera only) mg/kg for use as lure branches for Anoplophora glabripennis and Apriona germarii. The mortality of adults of these species under the different treatments ranged from 83.82 to 98.88% for Anoplophora glabripennis (best treatment 50 mg/ml aldicarb) and 89.2-100% for Apriona germarii (best treatments aldicarb and phorate). If the branches were sprayed with aqueous solutions of monocrotophos, esfenvalerate, alphamethrin [alpha-cypermethrin], fenpropathrin and cyhalothrin at concentrations of 50, 25 and 12.5 mg/kg to control adults of Apriona germarii, mortality was between 0 and 100%, with the medium and lower concentrations, and esfenvalerate, alphamethrin, fenpropathrin and cyhalothrin being most effective. If 60 ml phorate, 60 or 120 ml monocrotophos, 75, 150, or 300 g aldicarb, or 75, 150, or 300 g carbofuran was applied to each tree of Acer saccharum, mortality ranged from 62.50 to 100%, with the best treatment 75 g aldicarb (100% mortality).

index.de: aldicarb\alpha-cypermethrin\carbofuran\chemical control\cyhalothrin\esfenvalerate\fenpropathrin\forest pests\insect control\insect pests\insecticides\monocrotophos\mortality\pest control\phorate\plant pests\pyrethroid insecticides\systemic action

bibl.et: Responses of photosynthesis, carbohydrates and antioxidants in needles of Norway spruce to slow and rapid changes in ozone.
bibl.aa: Forstliche Bundesversuchsanstalt, Abt. Forstpflanzenphysiologie, Rennweg 1, A-6020 Innsbruck, Austria.

ab.p: Five-year-old spruce (Picea abies) seedlings were exposed in growth chambers for 49 days to either charcoal-filtered air, slowly increasing O3 concentrations from zero up to 100 nl/litre in weekly steps of 25 nl/litre, or immediately to 100 nl/litre of O3. During the investigation period gas exchange, carbohydrate and antioxidant contents of the current flush were measured. In needles which experienced slowly increasing O3 concentrations, cumulative O3 uptake was approximately 30% lower than in needles continuously fumigated with 100 nl/litre of O3. The higher O3 uptake in the permanent 100 nl/litre O3 treatment caused a pronounced decline in net photosynthesis, in the efficiency of CO2 uptake and in the starch content of the seedlings. Initially the ascorbate pool increased, but after 5 weeks of exposure ascorbate concentrations declined and were comparable to values obtained in charcoal-filtered controls, while the thiol contents were enhanced during fumigation with permanent 100 nl/litre O3. In contrast, slowly increasing O3 caused a significant increase in total needle ascorbate throughout the fumigation period, which probably prevented an O3-induced decline in the photosynthetic machinery as photosynthesis was not affected although the thiol contents were not enhanced. Furthermore, starch content was slightly higher than in O3-free controls. These results suggest that seedlings of Norway spruce have the possibility to acclimate to O3 stress, as slowly increasing O3 concentrations seemed to increase resistance and the seedlings were able to compensate.

bibl.et: Harvesting pulpwood and firewood using a tractor-mounted single-grip harvester.
bibl.ft: Kuitu- ja polttopuun hakkuuta maataloustraktorin yksiotehakkuulaitteella.

ab.p: The TTS-Institute's Department of Forestry conducted a work study on the AM 240 felling-delimbing-cross-cutting device. The timber was prepared into pulp- and fuelwood. The tops of the pulpwood stems and stems smaller than pulpwood were made into fuelwood. The base machine used was an agricultural tractor. The study is part of a research project titled Forest Owners' Energy-Wood Harvesting Technology. The combined productivity of preparing pulpwood and fuelwood varied between 2.8 and 4.1 m³ per effective hour. Thus, the productivity achieved was of the same order as that reported in an earlier TTS-Institute study on the devices AM 200 model. The outturns on the sample strips included a fair amount of crooked hardwood timber, which lead to reduced productivity. During the work study the felling device functioned reliably.

bibl.et: Diversity of higher plants in deciduous broadleaved forests on the northern slope of Taibai Mountain.
bibl.aa: Biology Department, Northwestern University, Xian 710069, China.

ab.p: Studies on the northern slope of Taibai Mountain, Shaanxi, China, showed that species diversity varies considerably along the temperature and rainfall gradient. Of the 6 types of forest, species diversity was highest in the Quercus aliena var. acuteserata forest. The species diversity index and evenness index for different strata is in the following order: shrub stratum > herb stratum > tree stratum. As for the species richness, the order is herb stratum > shrub stratum > tree stratum. All of the five indices show very little variation among communities in the shrub stratum while those in tree stratum and herb stratum vary considerably.

index.de: botanical composition\deciduous forests\forests\mountain forests\precipitation\species diversity\temperature

bibl.et: Deposits in heartshakes in wood. Part 2. The formation site of organic materials.
bibl.aa: CSIRO Forestry and Forest Products, Private Bag 10, Roasebank MDC, Clayton Victoria 3189, Australia.

ab.p: Crystalline or almost pure organic compounds can be formed either alone or with two or three related compounds in juxtaposition in shakes in central heartwood. The compounds may not always be present in the more complex extractives formed at the heartwood periphery. The largest amounts of deposits were in the innermost or widest portion of the shake in the following species which were studied: Intsia bijuga, Dacrydium, Anisoptera curtisii, Pinus elliottii, and Orites excelsa. The extractives were predominantly terpenoid or benzenoid. No evidence could be found of a source of substrate, energy or specific enzymes necessary for the selective biosynthesis of these deposits. They are considered to be formed in situ by an undetermined mechanism during enlargement of the shake.

index.de: benzene\extractives\heartwood\resin pockets\shakes\terpenoids\wood defects

bibl.et: Relations of small mammal populations to even-aged shelterwood systems in sub-boreal spruce forest.
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Sciences, Faculty of Forestry, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada.

ab.p: Natural regeneration of cutover forest lands and integration of nontimber resources into forest management have generated investigation of alternative silvicultural systems to clearcutting. The hypothesis that a shelterwood silvicultural system would adversely affect dynamics of small mammal populations in 30% and 50% basal area (BA) removal stands was investigated, and natural seed production, predation, and germination under a shelterwood canopy were evaluated, in the southcentral interior of British Columbia. The forest cover was primarily mature stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii-Pinus contorta. Deer mice (Peromyscus maniculatus) and southern red-backed voles (Clethrionomys gapperi) were the most common small mammal species prior to harvest, and both species continued to be dominant in the first and second year postharvest. Abundance and recruitment of red-backed voles was 50% higher in shelterwood (treatment) than unharvested (control) stands. The shelterwood harvest did not affect abundance or recruitment of deer mice. There were no differences in average survival of deer mice and red-backed voles between control and treatment stands. Mean body mass of adult male deer mice was similar in control and treatment stands but was lower for red-backed voles in the 50% BA removal than control stands. Seedfall crops in the second year postharvest were 7.4-29.6 times larger than in the first year on treatment and control units, but there was no difference between units in either year. Seed predation seemed to fluctuate with seasonal levels of small mammal populations (lower in spring and higher in fall) but not with the amount of seed crop available. Germination occurred in 62% of the seeds that survived overwinter on the seedbeds created during harvesting. Thus, regeneration success, as measured by seed survival and establishment, did not seem affected by the small mammal communities in 30% and 50% BA removal stands.

index.de: boreal forests\coniferous forests\forests\population dynamics\regeneration\seed germination\seed predation\seed production\seeds\shelterwood system\silvicultural systems\small mammals\wild animals\wildlife

bibl.et: Frequency domain resampling of time series data.
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Resource Management and Geometrics, SLU, S-901 83 Umeå, Sweden.

ab.p: This thesis is primarily concerned with the use of resampling methods for regression models for time series data. The thesis consists of an introduction and five papers, three of which have been published in the statistical literature. Four of the papers treat different aspects of regression models while the fifth paper is concerned with resampling of the autocovariance and autocorrelation estimator. The method is based on the frequency domain representation of the data and estimators. Compared with previously suggested frequency domain techniques the methods proposed in this thesis differ in that resampling of unstudentized data is performed, i.e. data with different distributions are resampled.

index.de: forest inventories\forests\regression analysis\statistical analysis\time series

bibl.et: The palaeoenvironment of Carihuela Cave (Granada, Spain): a reconstruction on the basis of palynological investigations of cave sediments.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Biología Vegetal (Botánica), Facultad de Biología, Universidad de Murcia, Campus de Espinardo, 30100 Murcia, Spain.

ab.p: Two new pollen diagrams from Carihuela Cave, SE Spain, are presented, completing the Pleistocene sequence which covers the interval between the last Interglacial and the Late Glacial. There is a correspondence between the litho- and biostratigraphy including pollen and microfauna. Thermoclastic scree, cryophyllous rodents, and Artemisia and/or Poaceae steppes are associated with the recession of thermophilous vegetation. The best palynological criterion for palaeoenvironmental reconstruction from cave sediments is the composition of the pollen assemblages rather than the pollen frequencies, with the number of mesothermophilous taxa being of critical importance. In the absence of absolute dates for much of the record, there is evidence in the Carihuela pollen record for: interglacial conditions at about 117&thin;000 BP, with assemblages dominated by Quercus and Olea; a pre-Würmian phase with episodic forest regressions; 2 Pleniglacial maxima with an extension of steppe-like vegetation and disappearance of thermophilous elements; an inter-Pleniglacial episode beginning at about 45&thin;200 BP, with Pinus and the consistent presence of mesothermophilous taxa; and a Late Glacial stage including several short stages of Quercus colonization, one of them at about 12&thin;320 BP, and the Younger Dryas event.

ab.p: The development of mechanization for establishing fast-growing forests in China is discussed. Use of machinery for ground clearing and preparation, planting, weeding, soil loosening, fertilizer application, irrigation and thinning is described. It is suggested that key research areas are in machinery for thinning and fertilizer application.

ab.p: Sprouting of M. officinalis had no obvious effects on total biomass, and fresh leaf weight of aerial parts, although it did influence DBH [diameter at breast height] and trunk growth. It is therefore recommended that sprout growth should be controlled.

bibl.av: Zhu, W.\Hu, J. J.\Ma, X. H.\Liu, S. C.
bibl.et: Chemistry of physiopathology of the interaction between poplars and canker pathogen. II. A preliminary investigation of the influences of crude extracts of canker pathogen on the hosts.
bibl.aa: Department of Basic Courses, NWFC, Yangling Shaanxi, 712100, China.

ab.p: Extracts of crude toxin were separated from the metabolites of Dothiorella gregaria cultured in modified No. 3 culture medium to which extracts of healthy poplar bark had been added. Poplar leaves on twigs from trees with different disease resistance were treated with the crude toxin extracts. Black blotches and wilting occurred in the treated leaves. Permeabilities of the cell membranes and the content of proline in treated leaves increased. The influence of the crude toxin on disease susceptible Populus beijingensis was stronger than that on the disease resistant P. tomentosa.

ab.p: The stem rust of willow (Uredo sp.) is a serious fungus disease newly discovered in Gansu, Ningxia, Qinghai, Tibet [Xizhang] and Shandong, China. It mainly invades the trunk phloem, leaves, stipe and inflorescence. Among several Salix varieties, S. mastsudana var. pendula was found to be the most susceptible to the disease.

bibl.et: Prevention reduces losses during southwest fire siege.

ab.p: The strategy developed in 1996 by the interagency Southwest Fire Management Board, which co-ordinates fire prevention for Arizona, New Mexico and west Texas, USA, to combat large-scale human-caused wildfires is described. Analysis of fire statistics showed that the special fire prevention and suppression efforts implemented during the 1996 fire severity period (May to July) reduced the number of fires and the number of acres burned.

bibl.et: Effects of crown position and plant age on rooting of jack pine long shoot cuttings.
bibl.aa: Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada Research Centre, Morden, Manitoba, Canada.

ab.p: Rooting success of long shoot cuttings of jack pine (Pinus banksiana) was found to be influenced by crown location effects among 5-30-year-old trees. Despite some variation in response, mid to lower crown cuttings generally rooted more readily than upper crown cuttings. The highest rooting frequencies observed for 4-, 5-, 6-, 7-, and 10-year-old trees ranged from 45 to 75%, whereas cuttings from 30-year-old trees showed a rooting frequency of 28%. These results are encouraging in light of the general perception that jack pine is difficult to propagate by rooted cuttings, and they suggest that operational asexual propagation may be feasible.

index.de: cuttings\forest trees\propagation materials\rooting\shoot cuttings\trees\vegetative propagation\woody plants

bibl.et: Ecotechnologies for the sustainable management of tropical forest diversity.
bibl.aa: Institute of Ecology and Systematics (IES), Ministry of Science, Technology and Environment, Carretera de Varona km 3 1/2, Capdevilla Municipio, Boyeros, AP 8029, Havana 10800, Cuba.

ab.p: A review is given of long-term basic studies on the functioning and succession of different forest systems, which have been conducted at the Sierra del Rosario Biosphere Reserve, western Cuba, since 1974. Key components of the research are: (1) holistic management of functional groups of tropical trees; (2) improved understanding of landscape function; and (3) the use of mycorrhizal-based ecotechnologies for tropical afforestation. A recently developed classification system for tropical tree species, which organizes 221 species according to functional, successional and regenerative strategies, is described. Stages of silvigenesis are outlined, based on observations of tropical succession following the death of primary trees in the 1.0 ha 'Vallecito' plot, and revisions to existing terminology are suggested to facilitate the functional classification of tropical forest ecosystems. An intensive study of a 2.3 km² area in which 5 abiotic variables, 6 other functional variables and 12 successional strategies were used to classify tree species into 29 distinct ecosystems, is also described. Functional characterization of symbiosis between vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizae (VAM) and primary forest trees was also investigated in 8 plots in the Vallecito area, with results suggesting that VAM could play an important role in the management of fruit and forest nurseries. Experiments which have used mycorrhizal-based ecotechnologies to transplant Glomalean fungal diversity to tree nurseries are also described.

index.de: afforestation\ecology\ecosystems\forest trees\forestry practices\forests\mycorrhizal fungi\mycorrhizas\plant succession\reviews\sustainability\trees\tropical forests\vesicular arbuscular mycorrhizas\woody plants

ab.p: Comparisons of growth differences between species and among provenances for a 5-year-old forest with 13 Eucalyptus grandis provenances and 14 E. saligna provenances at an altitude of 100 m on an impoverished mountain area in [Zhejiang Province] China, showed that adaptability, growth coefficient, straightness, diameter and height ratio, etc. of E. grandis was better than that of E. saligna. The species only differed in cold tolerance. Some fast-growing fine provenances were evaluated. These provenances were from the coast area of Australia.

bibl.et: The Euphorbiaceae of Sonora, Mexico.
bibl.aa: Rancho Santa Ana Botanic Garden, 1500 North College Avenue, Claremont, California 91711, USA.

ab.p: Descriptions are given for 19 genera and 143 species of Euphorbiaceae found in the state of Sonora, Mexico. Dichotomous keys for the identification of genera and species are provided. Bibliographic citations, type information, synonyms, brief habit descriptions, times of reproduction, habitat preferences as well as elevational range within Sonora, geographical distribution, and representative specimens are given for each species. When appropriate, notes on uses, taxonomic or nomenclatural problems, and other points of interest are discussed.

bibl.et: Study on the distribution of precipitation by Pinus tabulaeformis plantation in the Taiyue forest region.
bibl.aa: Research Institute of Tropical Forestry, Chinese Academy of Forestry, Guangzhou 510520, China.

ab.p: This paper discusses the distribution of rainfall by two P. tabulaeformis plantations with different canopy densities in the Taiyue Forest Division of Shanxi province during the growing seasons of 1992-93. The distribution of precipitation by canopy was dependent on rainfall class, i.e. the higher the rainfall class was, the less interception, and the more stemflow and throughfall. The distribution was also influenced by canopy density. The distribution in every month was mainly dependent on the pattern of rainfall: high interception, lower throughfall and stemflow during the dry season and reversed conditions during the rain season. The interception, stemflow and throughfall of a site with a canopy density of 0.9 were 15.9%, 2.1% and 82.0%, respectively, over the whole growing season, while those of a site with the canopy density of 0.6 were 13.6%, 1.9% and 84.5%, respectively. It is concluded that suitable stand densities should be selected to increase the rainfall under the canopy, raise the soil moisture content and accelerate the growth of forests in dry regions.

bibl.aa: Research Institute of Forestry, CAF, Beijing 100091, China.

ab.p: The effects of the hydrological action of litter on the main vegetation in Taihangshan Mountain were studied. The results showed that in the process of water conservation by the forest, the litter can regulate and hold 2-5 mm rainfall, increase infiltration by 21.3-50.3%, decrease soil surface evaporation 222.0%, and decrease runoff silt content in the earth's surface 11.5 kg/m³.

bibl.et: Diversity of nesting box occupants in mixed forests of Lithuania.
bibl.ct: Inkilu&hook; gyventoju&hook; i&hook;vairove&dotover; mišriuose lietuvos miškuose.
bibl.aa: Institute of Ecology, Akademijos 2, 2600 Vilnius, Lithuania.

ab.p: Use of nesting boxes with entrance holes 35 mm in diameter was studied from April-October in 2 mixed Norway spruce (Picea abies) and decidous forests in Lithuania during 1984-93. The first site was dominated by stands of 30-80 years old, comprising mostly Populus tremula, Betula pendula, P. abies, Alnus glutinosa and Fraxinus excelsior. The second site was dominated by 100 to 130-year-old oak (Quercus) groves with Norway spruce and maple (Acer platanoides). In spring the dominant bird species in nest boxes were Fiecedula hypoleuca and Parus major whilst dormice (Muscardinus avellanarius) and wasps (Dolichovespula saxonica) were also common. In autumn, M. avellanarius and the yellow-necked mouse Apodemus flavicollis were the most common occupants. Nest boxes were also used by an increased spectrum of birds for overnighting during autumn.

bibl.et: Influence of recreation on the forests of Palanga.
bibl.ct: Rekreacijos poveikis palangos miškams.
bibl.aa: Klaipe&dotover;da University, H. Manto 84, 5808 Klaipe&dotover;da, Lithuania.

ab.p: Influence of anthropogenic recreation on resort forests of P. sylvestris and associations with undergrowth grass communities in Palanga, Lithuania, was studied during 1988-94. Due to intensive use by holidaymakers, forest paths and areas used for sports have formed, and moss and lichen cover, grass layers and forest cover have become scanty resulting in exposure of the subsoil. Monitoring of 4 separate sites indicated that the number of mechanically-damaged plants increased with higher recreation use and visitation. It is concluded that the frequency of holidaymakers in the Pinetum cladoniosum [Pinetum cladinosum] association should not exceed 1-2 people/ha, otherwise the number of coniferous seedlings and understorey trees diminishes markedly. A limit of 4 people/ha is proposed for sufficient maintenance of Pinetum deschampsiosum forest types.

bibl.av: Tang, Y.\Cao, M.\Zhang, J. H.\Ren, Y. H.
bibl.et: The impact of slash-and-burn agriculture on the soil seed bank of Trema orientalis forest.
bibl.aa: Kunming Institute of Ecology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Kunming 650223, China.

ab.p: This study deals with the impact of slash and burn agriculture on the soil seed bank of a 4-year-old Trema orientalis forest in Xishuangbanna, China. Seed storage is significantly reduced from 65&thin;355 seeds/m² to 1070 seeds/m² by slash and burn agriculture. There were 60 species in soil seed bank before slash and burn and 29 species after. Fire leads to an increase of burn-resistant seeds. The succession of forest is retarded by slash and burn agriculture.

bibl.et: Mineral nutrition of Quercus pubescens in Romania: physitypes and correlations between physiotypes, environment and development. Part 2.
bibl.ft: Nutrit&tail;ia minerala˘ a stejarului pufos (Quercus pubescens Willd.) din România: fiziotipuri s&tail;i tipuri de corespondent&tail;a˘ fiziotip-mediu-desvoltare. (II).
bibl.aa: Institutul de Cerceta˘ri s&tail;i Amenaja˘ri Silvice, Bucharest, Romania.

ab.p: Data are presented on soil (0-60 cm) and leaf analysis of Quercus pubescens stands on chernozemic, rendzinas and calcareous rocky soils at altitudes ranging from 50-300 m, 450-550 m and 600-700 m, north of the Danube River and in Dobrogea province, Romania. Mineral nutrient contents of two physiotypes, viz a normal physiotype and a calcium tolerant physiotype were investigated in relation to soil water content, soil texture and human activity. The results are related to broadleaved tree species' suitability for planting in various forest ecosystems.

bibl.et: A study on seed rain of the nanmu (Phoebe bournei) population at Luoboyan Natural Reserve in Fujian.
bibl.aa: College of Forest Resources and Environment, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, China.

ab.p: From 21 December 1995 to 10 January 1996, seed rain of 36 individuals of nanmu was recorded in 1-m² quadrats arranged under average density crowns. Seed banks of the species were measured separately in 48 quadrats of volume 0.05 m³ (0.05×1×1 m). The amount of seed rain was closely related to the climate (relations with precipitation, temperature, humidity and wind speed are analysed), especially to humidity, and also to diameter size of individual trees. The climaxes of the seed rain curves were mostly in January 1996, especially during the middle period of this month. Four patterns of seed rain are discussed. The seed bank mostly consisted of seeds produced in the most recent year.

bibl.et: Site classification of Robinia pseudoacacia in the area north of the Yangtze River, Anhui Province.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Forestry, Anhui Agricultural University, Hefei 230036, China.

ab.p: Survey data from 108 sample plots and stem analysis data from 176 sample trees of Robinia pseudoacacia, in plantations in the area north of the Yangtze River were employed analysed and combined to classify the site types present. A basic 3-class system, defined in terms of major factors including landform, local topography, climate, soil types, was proposed. Two site type regions, 6 subregions, 9 sections and 29 site types were were identified.

ab.p: Experiments on the control of temperature, fertilizer and water in a stand of Phyllostachys praecox in [Zhejiang] China showed that under optimum conditions shoots could be produced throughout, and that it was even possible to obtain mass shooting in January and February when the price of shoots was at its peak. bibl.et: Chemical constituents of eucommia fruit.
bibl.aa: Department of Basic Courses, NWFC, Yangling, Shaanxi 712100, China.

ab.p: The oil content, physicochemical characteristics and aliphatic acid composition of the oil, amino acid composition of the kernel protein, and vitamin and mineral element contents were determined of the fruit of Eucommia ulmoides. The kernel was rich in nutrients, such as protein 28.62% and oil 27.65%. The oil was mainly composed of α-linolenic acid, linoleic acid and oleic acid. Myristic acid was detected from for the first time from eucommia oil.

bibl.et: Carbon dioxide supercritical fluid extractions of essential oil from leaves of Cinnamomum zeylanicum.
bibl.aa: Division of Wood Chemistry, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, 53 Nan-Hai Road, Taipei, Taiwan.

ab.p: Variations in yields and components of essential oils from the leaves of Cinnamomum zeylanicum were determined under different extraction pressures using of liquid carbon dioxide in a supercritical fluid extraction method (SCF). Components of the essential oils were analysed and identified by means of retention times (RT) in gas chromatography (GC) and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). Essential oil yields under 80, 100 and 120 kg/cm² pressures of carbon dioxide extraction were 0.81, 1.12 and 1.47 ml/100 g, respectively. The yields of essential oils using the SCF method were a little lower than those obtained using a conventional steam distillation method. Twenty components were identified in the essential oil. The main components were eugenol, cinnamic aldehyde, linalool, bornyl acetate, and α-phellandrene. Other minor components, such as α-pinene, camphene, β-pinene, limonene, 1,8-cineole, terpinolene, benzaldehyde, β-caryophyllene, 4-terpineol, α-terpineol, borneol, benzyl acetate, geraniol, 3-phenyl propanal, and isoeugenol were also identified. The major component of the essential oil obtained using both the SCF and steam distillation methods was eugenol. The contents of eugenol extracted under 80, 100 and 120 kg/cm² pressure in the SCF method were 80.83, 84.87 and 87.45% of the total essential oil, respectively. These values were lower than those obtained using conventional steam distillation (92.26%). There was little difference in the contents of the other component with respect to different extraction pressures of the SCF method.

index.de: chemical composition\essential oils\eugenol\extraction\foliage\forest trees\leaves\plant composition\techniques\trees\variation\woody plants\yields

bibl.et: Long-term dynamics of a relict ancient forest in an urban area.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Ecology and Nature Protection, Institute of Botany, Warsaw University, Aleje Ujazdowskie 4, PL-00-478 Warszawa, Poland.

ab.p: The diversity of communities and the vegetation changes caused by large town pressure were studied in Las Bielan´ski, a remnant of natural forest vegetation in Warsaw and, for more than a century, and a popular recreation ground for its inhabitants. The natural vegetation of Las Bielan´ski comprises flood-plain forest, Ficario-Ulmetum campestris, covering the flood terrace, and oak-lime-hornbeam forest, Tilio-Carpinetum, occurring on the higher parts. The natural diversity of the phytocoenoses reflects soil fertility and moisture while anthropogenic variation is related to the intensity of human pressure, which is greatest in the most accessible parts of the forest. The degradation of forest communities is indicated by a decrease in the proportion of forest coenoelements, i.e. character species of Querco-Fagetea, which are being replaced by the character species of scrub and brushwood communities and meadows, and synanthropic species. At the same time, the proportion of various life-forms in the ground layer changes. Natural forest communities are dominated by geophytes in spring and hemicryptophytes in summer. Intense direct human pressure promotes an increased abundance of therophytes. Shady therophytic forests (Tilio-Carpinetum with Chelidonium majus), which constitute the first phase of degradation, are being succeeded by open grassy woodland (Tilio-Carpinetum with Taraxacum officinale), and eventually by open park-like grassy communities Poa pratensis-Agrostis tenuis [Agrostis capillaris] with single remaining trees. In comparison with 1929, both the vegetation and habitats of Las Bielan´ski are apparently less diverse, due to a decreased water-table, soil eutrophication and flora synanthropization.

index.de: forest decline\forest recreation\forest trees\forests\grasslands\plant communities\species diversity\synecology\trees\understorey\urban areas\urban forestry\urban parks\vegetation\woodland grasslands\woody plants

bibl.et: Influence of site factors on Salix growth with emphasis on nitrogen response under different soil conditions.
bibl.aa: Department of Short Rotation Forestry, SE-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: This thesis summarises studies of the impact of site related factors and nitrogen fertilization regimes on production in willow coppice stands. Above-ground, woody biomass production in different clones of Salix viminalis L. and S. dasyclados Wimm. was measured during several years in willow stands growing on different soil types. One study was carried out in eight commercially grown Salix viminalis stands, in three different geographical regions in south Sweden. Cumulative stem production during five years ranged from 16 to 54 tonnes DM ha-1. Generally, production was found to increase with increasing content of clay in the soil. This was interpreted to be due to the favourable soil conditions provided by clay soils, implying the presence of a fair amount of stored plant-available water at the beginning of the growing seasons. Effects of nitrogen fertilization on cumulative stem production during four years in a S. viminalis stand were evaluated in a field experiment. Nitrogen was applied annually according to a response surface, experimental design. Fertilization performed in the second growing season from planting was most efficient in terms of enhanced yield per amount of nitrogen supplied. Effects of nitrogen fertilization on stem production in different clones of S. viminalis and S. dasyclados, in five different field experiments were evaluated. Generally, nitrogen fertilization enhanced yields considerably during the four years studied. Site conditions influenced mainly the average production levels. However, the ability of the clones to utilise applied N efficiently, turned out to be strongly affected by site conditions. Effects of pre-harvest nitrogen fertilization on willow coppice regrowth during three years were evaluated in one field experiment. Cumulative stem production during the period was negatively affected by pre-harvest treatment. Leaf nitrogen concentration was negatively correlated to pre-harvest fertilization towards the end of the period. These results implied that plant-available nitrogen was lower if high amounts of fertilizers had been applied during the period before harvest. Apparently, nitrogen had been lost from the system, indicating that the possibility to accumulate nitrogen in recyclable pools, under certain conditions, may be more difficult than previously assumed. The Appendix contains 3 papers from the thesis which have been published elsewhere or are in press.

index.de: biomass\clay soils\clones\coppice\fertilizers\increment\nitrogen\plant nutrition\site class assessment\soil fertility\soil types

bibl.et: The analysis of key sources of mortality of the brown bear (Ursus arctos L.) in Slovenia in the last 6 years (1.4.1991-31.3.1997).
bibl.ft: Analiza ključnih vzrokov smrtnosti rjavega medveda (Ursus arctos L.) v Sloveniji v obdobju zadnjih 6 let (1.4.1991-31.3.1997).
bibl.aa: Biotehniška fakulteta, Oddelek za gozdarstvo, 1000 Ljubljana Večna pot 83, Slovenia.

ab.p: Data from the Slovenian Central Register of Large Carnivores, established in 1991, showed that shooting (mostly trophy hunting) accounted for 88% of the total extraction of 257 brown bears (Ursus arctos) in Slovenia between April 1991 and March 1997. Traffic collisions caused 7.8% of mortality. More males than females are killed which is changing the sex structure of adult animals. Changes in hunting targets and conservation of the bears are discussed.

bibl.et: Mycobioindication of pollution of two forest sites.
bibl.ct: Proučevanje propadanja gozdov v Sloveniji v obdobju 1985-1995.
bibl.aa: Gozdarski inštitut Slovenije, Večna pot 2, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia.

ab.p: Types of ectomycorrhizas were studied in soil cores collected in 1993 from 2 Norway spruce (Picea abies) sites differentially affected by pollution from the coal-fired power station in Šoštanj, Slovenia. Twenty morphotypes of ectomycorrhizas are briefly described, and more detailed descriptions are given of Lactarius lignyotus and Hydnum rufescens associations with P. abies, based on anatomical and molecular studies. The occurrence of fruit bodies did not correspond to the occurrence of ectomycorrhizal types. It is suggested that H. rufescens can be used as an indicator of unpolluted sites and Paxillus involutus as an indicator of polluted sites in Slovenia.

bibl.do: Land Management Handbook - Ministry of Forests, British Columbia
bibl.et: Caribou habitat use in the Chelaslie River migration corridor and recommendations for management.
bibl.aa: B.C. Ministry of Forests, Prince Rupert Forest Region, Bag 5000, 3726 Alfred Avenue, Smithers, BC VO1 2N0, Canada.

ab.p: Movements and habitat use of radio-collared caribou within the Chelaslie River "migration corridor" of the Tweedsmuir-Entiako herd were monitored from spring 1993 to spring 1995. It was found that the area was more than just a migration movement corridor, with some animals wintering in the area. Use of the area was substantial in winter 1993/94, when caribou were most often associated with old forest on poor or low sites and with wetland/forest mosaics. In periods of primarily migration movement, habitat selection was less distinct. Management recommendations made for the area include maintaining a significant amount of the area in old or mature forest, limiting harvest to lower-value caribou habitat and lower-use areas, access control, and application of silvicultural techniques that maintain or encourage recovery of forage and caribou passage.

bibl.et: Empirical method to estimate basic density in small wood samples.
bibl.ft: Método empírico para estimar la densidad básica en muestras pequeñas de madera.
bibl.aa: Departamento Forestal, Universidad Autónoma Agraria Antonio Narro, 25315 Buenavista, Saltillo, Coahuuila, Mexico.

ab.p: An empirical method to calculate the volume of small samples of wood obtained with an increment borer was developed in order to estimate specific gravity of P. greggii samples. The empirical method was compared with the water displacement method and the maximum moisture method. Mean values, standard deviation and specific gravity data obtained with the empirical method were significantly correlated with those values obtained by the other methods. The empirical method is therefore a reliable technique for estimating the specific gravity of small samples of regularly shaped wood, whilst being faster and simpler than other techniques tested.

bibl.et: Top-pruning bareroot hardwoods: a review of the literature.
bibl.aa: School of Forestry, Alabama Agricultural Experiment Station, Auburn University, Alabama, USA.

ab.p: This paper briefly reviews top-pruning hardwoods with respect to literature published over the last 60 years. Top-pruning hardwoods before lifting reduces the costs involved with lifting, packing, storing, shipping and planting. The practice also decreases the chance of dieback. For some sites (and some years), top-pruning will increase the probability of survival. Top-pruning hardwoods does not seem to reduce average heights after 5 years in the field, will often increase early height growth. For several species, top-pruning before transplanting appears to have no long-term effect on stem form. There are no reported long-term effects of top-pruning on seedling physiology.

Three types of forest (western subalpine and moist coastal forests of Pseudotsuga menziesii/Tsuga heterophylla and mixed conifer forests dominated by Pinus ponderosa with Abies concolor, A. grandis and P. menziesii as codominants) are examined in relation to the evaluation of the weather hypothesis in relation to forest fires.

bibl.et: A market segmentation analysis of desired ecotourism opportunities.
bibl.pb: Natural Resources Canada, Canadian Forest Service, Ontario Region
bibl.aa: Lakehead University, Thunder Bay, Ontario, Canada.

ab.p: This study was designed to identify ecotourism opportunities desired by visitors and potential visitors to northern Ontario, Canada, to develop segmentation profiles of potential ecotourists, and to identify specific sectors that would provide a demand for ecotourism. The study was conducted using 2 surveys. The first survey focused on summer travellers, visitors to the area, and residents. In total, 1&thin;008 surveys were distributed to people intercepted randomly at different visitor information centers during July and August 1995. Of these, 556 useable questionnaires were returned (55%). The second survey, conducted by mail, focused on people who have an interest in outdoor recreation as indicated by their membership in recreational organizations. Questionnaires were mailed to Canadians (1&thin;000 members of the Mountain Equipment Cooperative) and Americans (1&thin;000 members of Recreation Equipment Incorporated). This mailing was also stratified by residency, with particular concentration on areas adjacent to or in the near vicinity of northern Ontario. There were 799 usable questionnaires returned (43%). As responses differed between the 2 survey groups, the 2 questionnaires were studied separately. Principal component analysis and cluster analysis identified 5 different market segments in the group of intercept survey respondents, 3 of which show a potential demand for ecotourism in northern Ontario, the Enthusiasts, Adventurers and Naturalists. The same statistical analysis was performed on the data of mail survey respondents. Analysis of these questionnaire results identified 6 different market segments, 4 of which emerged as good targets for ecotourism. Three are similar to the intercept survey, namely the Enthusiasts, Adventurers, and Naturalists, the fourth group were the Escapists. The segments that have been identified will allow operators and marketers in the tourism industry to identify specific target markets and to develop the product and service packages that best suit each of the segments.

ab.p: Based on 12-year-old data on provenance tests of Pinus massoniana in wood property at 4 test locations in China, significant variations of the effects of provenances, test locations and provenance × location interactions were found in specific gravity (SG) and tracheid length (TL). It was shown that there was an increasing trend in SG of provenances from the Southwest to the Northeast of the range. According to the variations of SG, TL and stem volume (V) at different levels, V may be regarded at the most important in provenance selection for pulpwood; V and wood property possess the same importance in individual selection within provenances.

bibl.av: Liu, S. L.\Wu, D. D.\Zhou, J. R.\Yuan, C. L.\Tai, X. W.\Zhu, D. H.\Gong, W. G.\Xiang, K. F.\Wang, Z. H.\Zhang, J. D.\Ma, Z. X.\Zhao, J. P.\Liu, B. T.
bibl.et: Grazing function of the protective forests on grassland.
bibl.aa: Liaoning Sand Fixation and Afforestation Research Institute, Fuxin 123000, Liaoning, China.

ab.p: Grazing experiments using sheep on forested and non-forested grassland were set up in Liaoning Province, China, to study basic dynamics, grazing rate, daily feeding, behaviour, resistance to disease, physical activities, grass recovery and vegetation changes. Results showed that protective forests on grassland have clear ecological, economic and social benefits. With the protective forests, grazing capacity was able to be increased by 0.675 sheep/hm² and overall productivity of the grassland was increased. Grazing rate on forested grassland was 10.5% higher than that on non-forested grassland. Time required for grass recovery after grazing by sheep on forested grassland was 2-4 days shorter than that on non-forested grassland. There was a significant difference between the physical activity of sheep feeding on both grassland types. Forests can substantially help sheep to maintain their normal metabolism and reduce energy consumption during hot summer conditions.

bibl.aa: Departamento de Zoologia, Instituto de Biologia, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, Caixa Postal 6109, 13083-970 Campinas, São Paulo, Brazil.

ab.p: Litter frogs were sampled in the dry/cold season of 1995 in plots at different distances from the stream bed at sites at 850 and 1000 m alt. in the semi-deciduous mesophytic forest at Serra do Japi, Jundiaí, São Paulo. Five species were found, three at each site. Eleutherodactylus guentheri comprised 82% of the individuals at the higher site and E. juipoca 67% at the lower site. The density of individuals was higher at the higher site and near the stream.
