bibl.et: New methods reduce costs of small-scale production of fuelwood.
bibl.ft: Uudet menetelmät alentavat polttopuun pientuotannon kustannuksia.

ab.p: The goal in the small-scale production of wood fuels in the context of the National Bioenergy research programme in Finland is to reduce production costs by 20% when compared to the 1992 cost level. Also, new harvesting technology and new work methods will be developed for forest owners and small entrepreneurs in the course of the research programme. The goal of the research work will be to improve the competitiveness of harvesting machines, devices and work chains when dealing with small-diameter trees and logging residues. The aim in the development of measuring methods and quality requirements for purchased fuelwood is to eliminate obstacles resulting from the ambiguities in the measuring and quality of fuelwood. The objective of the fuelwood utilisation research is to eliminate technical obstacles and to develop new action models for organising energy generation in the categories of building-specific and district heating. Also marketing of the new action models to potential entrepreneurs and heating energy purchasers is an important part of the work. The main objective of the work on the development of fireplaces is to reduce flue gas emissions. The main subject of development of heating equipment designed for buildings is stoker burners for wet fuels.

bibl.do: Annual Report of the Hokkaido Research Center, Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute
bibl.et: Relation between people and forest in Japan. Forest management by landscape concept.
bibl.aa: Hokkaido Research Center, Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, Sapporo 062, Japan.

ab.p: When intending to manage a forested watershed, several viewpoints of forest management have to be taken into account, such as land conservation, wildlife, recreation and timber production. This synthesis is necessary for developing multiple use of a forest. For that objective, the 'Landscape Concept' is used. According to this concept, a landscape is a set of components which are organized in a hierarchy and its level. In this report, forested watershed management methods were analysed using mathematical programming and the landscape concept. In these viewpoints of forest management, these were separated into two types of data, i.e., quantitative data such as timber production, and qualitative data such as wildlife habit. Quantitative data was analysed by goal programming, and qualitative data was analysed by the landscape concept which is presented by GIS (a geographical information system). In this paper, timber production, water conservation, land conservation, habitat of Bubo blakistoni [Ketupa blakistoni], as components of forest management in Shiretoko peninsula, Hokkaido, Northern Japan, were analysed. The place of habitat of Ketupa blakistoni completely conflicted with cutting areas. As a result the following two cases were considered: 1. cutting trees is not allowed at all; and 2. It is possible to cut trees in an area selected according to the landscape concept. Finally, by using the above mentioned method, watershed management plans were proposed.

index.de: conservation\cutting\felling\forest management\forest products\forests\landscape\multiple use\water conservation\watershed management\wild birds\wildlife

bibl.et: White birch (Betula pubescens) is a potential species for veneer, plywood and saw mills.
bibl.ft: Hieskoivu on varteenotettava vaneri-ja sahapuu.
bibl.aa: Finnish Forest Research Institute, Finland.

ab.p: Market perspectives for the birch-based veneer and plywood industries as well as sawmills and further-processing plants are continuously favourable. These sectors of mechanical wood processing continue to be rather profitable, thanks to an intensive product development and implementation of new technology. However, they occasionally suffer from a severe lack of birch logs. Veneer and plywood industries demand more than 18-cm logs yielding totally or nearly knot-free veneers. Sawmills in addition need logs yielding products with green knots only. Birch sawmills use logs as small as 14 cm by top diameter, and may use logs upto 10 cm. White birch is considered the least valuable of the main species in Finland as regards their commercial value. However, white birch accounts for 41% of all birch veneer and plywood timber resources in Southern Finland. White birch is the most important in the forestry of Western Finland, especially in Ostrobothnia which is rich in drained peatland forests. The importance of white birch is growing in the other parts of Southern Finland as well. White birch is a worthy alternative on sites and in silvicultural conditions that are as difficult for the more productive species, Scots pine [Pinus sylvestris], Norway spruce [Picea abies] and common birch [Betula verrucosa].The author studied the quality of white birch for veneer and plywood on a large amount of material, 2306 trees in total, by comparing with 340 common birches. Based on its quality, white birch was better suited to veneer and plywood than was previously thought but not as good as common birch.

bibl.av: Lo-Cho, C. N.\Chung, H. H.\Chiu, C. M.
bibl.et: Effect of thinning and pruning on the growth of Taiwan red cypress (Chamaecyparis formosana Matsum) plantations.
bibl.aa: Division of Forest Management, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, 53 Nan-Hai Rd., Taipei, Taiwan.

ab.p: The study was carried out in a 14-yr-old red cypress (Chamaecyparis formosana [C. formosensis]) plantation located in Compartment No. 104 of AliShan Working Circle, Taiwan. A thinning-from-below approach was used in the thinning experiment, in which a plantation was either left unthinned (control) or thinned to 25 m²/ha of absolute basal area (BA). In the pruning experiment 3 treatments were applied: (a) pruning up to 1/2 of tree height; (b) pruning up to 2/3 of tree height; and (c) no pruning (control). Growth was measured 5 yr after treatments. Thinning regime to 25 m²/ha BA resulted in increased volume growth. Pruning up to 1/2 of tree height also improved growth. Pruned trees showed less tapering than unpruned trees. Pruning also improved tree roundness and increased volume growth. Wound occlusion was recorded on about 11 branches per pruned tree. The diameters of these branches were about 0.2-8.5 cm. Five years after pruning, the percentage of wound occlusion was only about 73. The low percentage of occlusion is attributed to the large size of the branches, so it is suggested that pruning of red cypress should be carried out when plantations are young and the branches are small. Thinning gave increased spacing which enhanced branching, so it is recommended that the trees retained after thinning should be pruned to prevent branching and/or forking.

index.de: branches\branching\forest plantations\growth\healing\increment\pruning\size\spacing\stem form\taper\thinning\volume

bibl.do: Forest Research Report - Ontario Forest Research Institute
bibl.et: A dendrochronological fire history of Opeongo Lookout in Algonquin Park, Ontario.
bibl.aa: 1-30 Agriculture Building, School of Natural Resources, University of Missouri, Columbia, Missouri 65211, USA.

ab.p: Fire-scarred stumps and natural snags of red pine (Pinus resinosa) on a 70-m high bluff along the Costello Creek, 2 km S. of Lake Opeongo, were dated using dendrochronological methods. A fire scar chronology was constructed from 18 of the red pine samples that contained 34 dated fire scars. The composite fire scar chronology spanned 358 years from 1636 to 1994. The fire-return interval was 46 years between 2 medium intensity fires and was 27 years between fires of low or high intensity. Fire frequency at the study site increased at around 1780 to a mean of 17 years. No fires were observed after 1940. Analysis of pith and outside ring data indicated that the fires were not of the stand replacement type. The steep topography and exposed rocky surfaces may have mitigated the effects of intense fires on stand survival. About 66% of the pines were scarred during the 2 medium intensity fires. The variation in fire occurrence from 1636 to 1994 is associated with the movement of people into and out of the area. Before 1780, disease epidemics killed many natives in Ontario, and others were displaced during fur trade wars, which led to a reduction in anthropogenic fires. As a result, only 1 fire was recorded between 1636 and 1779. Beginning about 1780, natives and later Europeans began immigrating into the study area, and fires began to increase in frequency. After 1940, efforts to suppress fires increased, and fire was practically eliminated in the study area.

index.de: dendrochronology\forest fires\history

bibl.et: Evaluation on ecological benefit of protective forest systems at a county scale.
bibl.aa: Northeast Forestry University, Harbin 150040, China.

ab.p: Data on air temperature, air humidity, wind velocity, crop yield and forest cover percentage were collected and investigated in some of counties of Heilongjiang Province, China, where protective forest systems were established in the last 30 years. An evaluation index to estimate the ecological benefit of protective forest systems was set up, which consists of both a vegetation index and a climate index. The former includes a forest cover percentage index and a crop yield index; the later has three variable indexes, wind velocity, air temperature and air humidity. A comprehensive ecological benefit index was developed through analysis and calculation. Taking Zhaozhou County and Anda County as examples, the ecological benefits since establishment of protective forest systems of the two counties were evaluated dynamically using the index.

bibl.av: Zheng, X. G.\Zheng, X. L.\Zhang, Q. H.\Yu, J. L.
bibl.et: Age distribution and season dynamics of root biochore [rhizosphere?] soil nutrition of white birch-Korean pine stand.
bibl.aa: Heilongjiang Forest Management Institute, Harbin 150040, China.

ab.p: Three or four experimental plots were set up in young, mid-age and mature stands in [Heilongjiang Province] China, on the same site group, and rhizosphere sampling of white birch [Betula platyphylla] and Korean pine [Pinus koraiensis] was done in June, August and October. Sample organic matter, pH and other properties were tested and analysed. Soil nutrients in the white birch and Korean pine rhizospheres were mutually compensated. Acid-base mutual compensation and balanced process were present in the rhizosphere of the two species. In the age-distribution and dynamic process of rhizosphere soil, nutrients and pH value, mid-age trees or stands acted as a converter connecting young stand with mature stands.

bibl.do: Bulletin of the Tokyo University Forests
bibl.et: People's expectation for forests: a case study in Morotsuka village and Bunkyo ward.
bibl.aa: The University Forest in Chichibu, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Tokyo, Japan.

ab.p: A questionnaire survey was conducted by mail to study the urban-rural difference in people's perception of forests. There are significantly different answers between the regions to 9 out of the 15 questions asked. Residents in Morotsuka, a mountain village outside Tokyo, were more interested in forests, and visited them much more often than their counterparts in Bunkyo ward, inside Tokyo. The mountain village visitors had more definite purposes for visiting forests such as fishing and picking edible wild plants. The same definite attitude was found in the attitude towards forestry. Rural people generally appreciated the functions of forests, including water resource conservation and recreational functions. On the other hand, both rural and urban residents had rather similar tastes as to the type of forests preferred. They prefer older forests, either natural or artificial, and shared expectations for the future functions of forests.

ab.p: Studies on carabids were carried out in various types of forest habitats in different parts of the Świe&hook;tokrzyskie Mountains of Poland. Considerable differences in composition and structure were noted between carabid communities collected from similar forest habitats situated in different parts of the mountains and from different forest habitats situated in the same mountain region.

bibl.et: Agarwood as a high-value commodity in East Kalimantan.
bibl.ft: Kayu gaharu komoditi elit di Kalimantan Timur.

ab.p: Garrowood (aloewood or agarwood) is a non-wood forest product used for perfumery, medicine and incense. Its price depends on the resin content, with the highest quality (super) fetching >Rp&thin;1 million/kg, and the lowest quality ('kamedangan') <Rp&thin;100&thin;000. Beacuse of the possible very high value of garrowood, many trees have been felled which do not contain the resinous wood or contain only kamedangan quality wood. There are more than 10 garrowood producing trees in Indonesia, of which Aquilaria spp. (A. hirta, A. malaccensis, A. microcarpa) is the best; other species include Aetoxylon sympetalum, Dalbergia parvifolia, Enkleia malaccensis, Gonystylus bancanus, G. macrophyllus, Wikstroemia polyantha and W. tenuiramis. Because of unreasonable felling, Aquiliaria is now an endangered species. Garrowood occurrs in diseased tree, with the highest quality of garrowood in trees which have been diseased the longest. This paper descibes garrowood production and the trees producing garrowood in East Kalimantan. In order to prevent the extinction of Aquiliaria prohibition of felling is recommended, except for diseased trees. Both cultivation of the species, and research on the stimulation of garrowood production are required.

The papers are: (1) Recent trends in forest policy and forest policy research in Denmark (Boon, T. E.); (2) Forests and Finnish rural policy (Nerg, J.); (3) Economical, ecological and social sustainability in the new forest policy in Finland (Niskanen, A.; Pirkola, K.); (4) 'Zero-profit' as a turning point - forest policy implications (Blum, A.) - in Germany; (5) On the role of the state in German forestry: implications for forest policy and forest policy science (Schanz, H.); (6) Urban forest policy-making in the Netherlands: a matter of shared responsibility (Konijnendijk, C. bibl.et: Bentuang Karimun National Park: integrated conservation and development in Indonesia.
bibl.aa: WWF Indonesia Programme, JI. Budi Karya No. 7, Kompleks BPD - Waduk Permai, Pontianak 78122, West Kalimantan, Indonesia.

ab.p: The International Tropical Timber Organization (ITTO) has funded a project for the Bentuang Karimun National Park (BKNP) in West Kalimantan, through the Department of Forestry of Indonesia. It started on November 1995 and is implemented by WWF Indonesia. The main objective is to develop a model of natural forest management through a national park system that not only will serve conservation of species and ecosystems, but will also accommodate other purposes such as the socioeconomic development of local and regional communities. This will include: (1) the development of the BKNP as a national park by conserving the biodiversity values of the area and also its research, educational, recreation and tourism potential; and (2) to initiate regional development and promote economic, scientific, educational, cultural, and touristic cooperation between Indonesia and Malaysia, particularly between West Kalimantan and Sarawak.

bibl.et: The use of Marshal/Suscon granules to protect plants from Hylobius damage.

ab.p: Techniques and safe practices for the use of Marshal/suSCon granules (active ingredient carbosulfan, as a slow-release formulation) to protect young forest trees from damage from Hylobius abietis and species of Hylastes beetles, when established on ex-conifer sites are described. The mode of action is described and it is recommended that 10 g of Marshal/suSCon granules are applied to the base of the hole at time of planting. Initial protection for the plants should be provided by permethrin applied as a pre-planting treatment or as a top spray after planting. The results of an experiment with Sitka spruce [Picea sitchensis] transplants which was part of a UK programme forming the basis for the current recommendations are summarized.

bibl.et: Historical evidence on the incidence and role of common property regimes in the Indian Himalayas.
bibl.aa: 56 Thornhill Houses, Thornhill Road, London N1 1PB, UK.

ab.p: Historical evidence is often used in contemporary debates about future policy to promote particular ideological positions on the role that common property regimes should play. This paper examines these positions and argues that forest common property regimes in the Indian Himalayas (the study uses the Uttarakhand region in Uttar Pradesh) historically provided only one of an interdependent set of production strategies.

bibl.et: Floodplain forestry: progress in the Great Western Community Forest.

ab.p: An outline is given of progress so far, and of aims to be achieved, in the Great Western Community Forest Project, one of 12 such urban fringe projects in the UK, extending for 200 km² of Wiltshire and Oxfordshire in central-southern England, centred on the fast-growing town of Swindon, and including the rivers Cole and Ray - both targeted as national demonstrations in river restoration. The aim is to create integrated river corridors for recreation and conservation which still support thriving agriculture. It is hoped that this recreation of floodplain woodlands could restore many of the natural and functional benefits of the area's rivers.

bibl.et: Nutrient release dynamics in decomposing leaf litter in two Mediterranean deciduous oak species.
bibl.aa: INRA/CSIC, Cordel de Merinas 40, 37008 Salamanca, Spain.

ab.p: The release and dynamics of macronutrients from decomposing leaf litter were determined for two deciduous oak species: Quercus pyrenaica growing in 4 stands in Salamanca, Spain on a humic Cambisol (Sol brun forestier), and Q. lanuginosa [Q. pubescens] growing in a stand in Montpellier, France on a rendsic Leptosol (Rendzine). The same processes were studied after leaf-litter exchanges between the French stand and a Spanish stand. Nylon litter bags (1 mm² mesh), containing 10 g of leaves, were placed in the 5 stands and collected every 2 months when they were weighed and analysed for N, P, Ca, Mg and K. The mean amount of nutrients in the decomposing leaves decreased over the 36-month period. The four Q pyrenaica stands were classified into two groups involving different nutrient release processes, without any relation to yearly litterfall. For the Q lanuginosa stand, the results obtained were similar to those for one of the Q pyrenaica groups. Similar nutrient release processes occurred in the litter-bags collected from native stands and after exchanges between the two species, with a quick release of K, followed by Mg and P. Higher Ca accumulation was noted for the Q pyrenaica litter as compared with Q lanuginosa litter. For N, the results were very different between the two species and the two locations.

bibl.et: Adhesion of blastospores of Sclerophoma pityophila to water-borne paints is mediated by soluble extracellular compounds released during early stages of germination.
bibl.aa: Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, Department of Forest Products, Wood Biology Section, P.O. Box 7008, S-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: Adhesion of blastospores of Sclerophoma pityophila [Sydowia polyspora] to different water-borne wood paints in relation to the stage of germination varied to a wide extent. The highest number of blastospores adhered to an acrylic paint containing a cellulose extender. The number of blastospores that adhered to paint films on wood differed from the number of blastospores that adhered to free paint films of the same paints. Under the experimental conditions used, blastospores in freshly made spore suspensions did not adhere to paint films on wood. Maximum adhesion of blastospores occurred when the spores were preincubated for between 150 and 210 minutes. With longer preincubation times the adhesion of blastospores decreased drastically. By applying a concentration series of pullulan, a polysaccharide known to be produced by the blue stain fungus Aureobasidium pullulans, it was shown that this polysaccharide could promote adhesion of ungerminated blastospores of S. pityophila to a paint film in concentrations of 0.16 mg/litre or higher. It was also shown, by exchanging supernatants and blastospores from spore suspensions preincubated for different time periods, that adhesion of newly harvested blastospores was improved by soluble extracellular compounds, probably polysaccharides similar to pullulan, released from germinating blastospores of S. pityophila.

bibl.et: Heat and the wildland firefighter.
bibl.aa: 5 Allen Street, Glebe, NSW 2037, Australia.

ab.p: A study was conducted to continuously assess fire fighters' thermal environment and physiological responses while they attempted to suppress well-developed experimental bushfires of intensities commonly faced by hand-tool crews, and also while they built fireline in the same way without fire, during 3 summers in Australian eucalypt forests. Fire fighters paced themselves at their preferred work rates. They worked far enough from the flames to avoid painful intensities of radiant heat (>2 kW/m²) on their bare faces, hands and forearms, and usually experienced 1.6 kW/m² (little more than the intensity of sunlight). Fire had negligible effects on average air temperature, humidity or wind speed. Indices of heat stress usually exceeded occupational limits proposed for heat-acclimatized men, but little additional strain resulted. Fire fighters' metabolic heat load from exertion (488 W) was more than twice the combined heat load (200 W) from fire and weather, indicating that the main task for fire fighters' clothing may be to let heat out. Evaporation was effectively the sole means of heat dissipation, and predicted and measured sweat losses both exceeded one litre/hour. Fire fighters' light, loose and well-ventilated cotton or wool clothing ensured free evaporation of sweat, which completely dissipated the high heat loads they experienced. By this means they maintained their deep body temperature and heart rate at constant and sustainable levels over a wide range of work duration, and of heat from weather and fire. It is concluded that because of appropriate clothing and work practices heat stress may not be a problem for Australian wildland fire fighters.

bibl.et: Mill residue volume factor changes in Idaho and Montana.
bibl.aa: Bureau of Business and Economics Res., Univ. of Montana, Missoula, MT 59812, USA.

ab.p: This paper reports mill residue factors indicating volumes of residue generated per thousand board feet (MBF) of lumber produced and per thousand square feet (MSF) of plywood produced by mills in Idaho and Montana. Historic trends and projected changes are detailed. Since 1969 there has been an approximate 30% reduction in the volume of residue produced per MBF of lumber and a 20% reduction per MSF of plywood produced by Idaho mills. Montana's sawmills and plywood plants saw a 16 and 11% decline, respectively. The largest changes among the various components of mill residue were decreases in sawdust, planer shavings, and bark. Much smaller changes were observed in the volume of chips or coarse residue generated, and the volume of coarse residue generated per unit of lumber and plywood produced increased slightly over the past 25 years in Montana. The analysis indicates that in the next decade, the volume of mill residue per unit of lumber produced will decline 9 to 25 %, for plywood the decline is expected to be 10 to 14%. Improved mill technology, such as better log positioning, thinner sawkerfs, smaller target green lumber sizes, greater drying and planing efficiency, and plywood lathes capable of peeling to a smaller core diameter, has been primarily responsible for reductions in the volume of residue produced.

bibl.et: Manufacturing parquet from small-dimension hardwoods - an alternative.
bibl.ft: Parkettfertigung aus Laubschwachholz - eine Alternative.
bibl.aa: Forstliche Versuchsanstalt Rheinland-Pflaz, Trippstadt, Germany.

ab.p: Trials were made at producing finished parquet from small-dimension hardwoods (oak [Quercus sp.], ash [Fraxinus sp.], maple [Acer sp.], beech [Fagus sp.]). The raw staves (1100×80×29 mm) were dried, cut to length (55 cm) and then processed (processing flow-chart presented). The yield of raw staves from ca. 258 m³ of small roundwood was 29-44% (average 34.5%). The volume yield of finished parquet from the raw staves was 40-50%, and from the roundwood 12-20%. The yields of mosaic parquet from the raw staves were between 1 and 13%. The yield and economics of the operation are discussed. The results indicate that this form of conversion is promising for a category of material (small hardwood roundwood) which is difficult to market.

bibl.et: The significance of resorption of leaf resources for shoot growth in evergreen and deciduous woody plants from a subarctic environment.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Ecological Botany, Uppsala Univ., Villavägen 14, SE-752 36 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: A field experiment was conducted on 5 evergreen (Andromeda polifolia, Empetrum hermaphroditum, Oxycoccus microcarpus [Vaccinium oxycoccus], Rhododendron lapponicum and Vaccinium vitis-idaea) and 4 deciduous (Betula nana, Betula pubescens subsp. tortuosa [B. tortuosa], Vaccinium myrtillus and V. uliginosum) woody plants on a subalpine heath near the Abisko Scientific Research Station, Sweden, to investigate the variation in the relative importance of resource resorption from the leaves to support new growth. Plants were defoliated before leaf senescence in autumn and before resource mobilisation in early summer, respectively, and responses were measured in terms of growth emerging the season following defoliation. Averaged across all species, defoliation had general effects on growth and the nutrient status of new shoots. Shoot, leaf and stem weights, leaf area, leaf dry weight per unit area, shoot dry weight per unit phosphorus (P) and shoot nitrogen (N) and P pool sizes were reduced in defoliated shoots. Shoot P concentrations in defoliated plants were increased in comparison with controls, and leaf area per unit shoot dry weight increased, particularly in the evergreen plants. Leaf number, leaf N and P per unit leaf area, shoot N concentrations and shoot dry weight per unit N were not significantly affected by the treatment. However, no significant life-form specific responses were observed. In contrast, marked differences were found between species in their response to defoliation. The resorption of dry matter, N and P from old leaves to support new growth was equally important in deciduous and evergreen woody species despite morphological, physiological and phenological differences between these life-forms. The magnitude of growth depression in response to defoliation across all species was not correlated to the amount of dry matter or nutrients removed, to the species' resorption efficiency or to the potential benefit of resorption in terms of future growth.

bibl.et: Changes in the three dimensional architecture of the cell wall during lignification of xylem cells in Eucalyptus tereticornis.
bibl.aa: Wood Research Institute, Kyoto University, Uji, Kyoto 611, Japan.

ab.p: The three dimensional architecture of the cell wall during differentiation of xylem cells in Eucalyptus tereticornis was visualized by rapid-freezing and deep-etching electron microscopy. A highly porous structure was demonstrated in cell corner, middle lamellae and primary walls of both cambium and enlarging xylem cells, but disappeared after lignification of the xylem cells. The porosity of the structure was abruptly diminished by the encrustation of lignin as well as dense deposition of cellulose microfibrils in differentiating xylem cells. This study is the first to detect rosettes, cellulose synthesising enzyme complexes, in the differentiating xylem cells of a woody plant, and provides the first account of the visualization of the three dimensional architecture of xylem cell walls before and after lignification.

bibl.et: Heterobasidion annosum root and butt rot of Norway spruce, Picea abies: colonization by the fungus and its impact on tree growth.
bibl.ms: ref. at end of papers
bibl.aa: Dept. of Forest Mycology and Pathology, SLU, Box 7026, S-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: Diameter growth losses associated with wood decay were quantified on a nationwide scale in Sweden, and volume growth losses were measured in 2 Norway spruce stands. Diameter growth losses were 8-10% during a 5-year period in the nationwide study and 23% in one of the stands, whereas in the other stand, no volume losses could be attributed to decay. The effects of stump moisture content, temperature and time elapsed between felling and inoculation on the establishment of Heterobasidion annosum spore infections in stumps were investigated among stumps resulting from thinnings and clear fellings. Furthermore, inoculations with H. annosum conidia were made between 0 h and 4 weeks after thinning. The incidence of stump infections was lower on clear felled areas than in thinned stands, but high enough to warrant stump treatment on clear fellings. A positive relationship was found between heartwood moisture content and the proportion of heartwood infected, whereas the opposite relationship was found for sapwood. The establishment of new conidiospore infections decreased with time and stumps were no longer susceptible to infection 3 weeks after felling. Roots of stumps and trees on forest land or former arable land were inoculated with H. annosum-treated sawdust. The growth rate of H. annosum in roots of stumps was 25 cm/year, corresponding to 2.5 to 3 times the growth rate in tree roots. Previous land use did not affect the fungal rate of spread. The average initial spread rate of H. annosum in naturally infected Norway spruce stems was estimated at 30 cm/year.

bibl.et: Plant viruses in soil and water of some forest ecosystems in Croatia with a review of viruses found in forest and ornamental woody plants.
bibl.ft: Biljni virusi u tlu i vodi nekih šumskih ekosustava Hrvatske s pregledom virusa na&dstroke;enih u šumskom i ukrasnom drvec´u.
bibl.aa: Prirodoslovno-matematički fakultet Zagreb, Marulic´ev trg 9a, Zagreb, Croatia.

ab.p: Tobacco necrosis virus has been found in soil samples of 3 forest districts (Turopolje, Vukomeričke Gorice and Medvednica) in central Croatia. Tobacco mosaic and tomato mosaic viruses have been found in water (streams and ditches) samples in forests in the same 3 districts. A list shows the 19 genera of forest and ornamental trees and shrubs previously reported to have virus infections in Croatia. The most frequent viruses are cucumber mosaic virus, cherry leaf roll virus and some rhabdoviruses.

bibl.et: Possibilities and reliability of the growing stock and increment estimation based on the 1995 forest decline inventory.
bibl.ft: Moz&hacek;nosti in zanesljivost ocene lesne zaloge in prirastka na podlagi popisa propadanja gozdov 1995.
bibl.ct: Proučevanje propadanja gozdov v Sloveniji v obdobju 1985-1995.
bibl.aa: Gozdarski inštitut Slovenije, 1000 Ljubljana, Večna pot 2, Slovenia.

ab.p: Forest decline inventories have been conducted since 1985 on a 4×4 km grid in Slovenia. This is the only objective forest survey at the national level. Inventories are conducted on 712 tracts, each comprising 4 plots with 6 trees. Basal area was determined by both the Bitterlich and 6-tree method. Growing stock, increment and sampling errors were computed separately for each method. Two versions of the 6-tree method were used: estimates were significantly higher for the original method than for a modified method which does not take account of the 6th tree. The modified 6-tree method and the Bitterlich method gave similar results, giving national averages of 281.26 and 283.17 m³/ha for growing stock and 6.63 and 6.72 m³/ha per year for increment, respectively. Results are compared with official Forest Service field estimates, and are also presented by forest region.

bibl.ft: Priroda i parkovni objecti u opc´ini Rijeka.

bibl.et: Richness of species and growth-forms within sclerophyll and mesophyll vegetation in eastern Australia.
bibl.aa: Department of Environmental Biology and Horticulture, University of Technology, Sydney, PO Box 123 Broadway, NSW 2007, Australia.

ab.p: The patterns in total species richness and in the richness of the dominant growth-forms of vegetation communities of coastal sclerophyll and mesophyll vegetation in eastern Australia are examined. Plant species richness data were obtained from two 500 m² quadrats from 50 sites within a single geographical region (in the Ku-ring-gai Chase National Park) north of Sydney, New South Wales. Concentrically nested subquadrats within each quadrat enabled the determination of species-area relationships for total species richness and its components. Three growth-forms were examined (trees, shrubs and ground cover) and patterns in the richness of these components were compared to those exhibited by total species richness. Total species richness was higher in sclerophyll communities on Hawkesbury Sandstone soils than in adjacent mesophyll communities on Narrabeen shales and sandstones. Significant patterns in total species richness within the two soil types were also found. Shrub and ground cover species richness showed strong correlations with total species richness, with higher richness in the sclerophyll communities. However, tree species richness contributed little to the patterns in total species richness. It is suggested that differential patterns in the components of total species richness must be taken into account for effective modelling of natural areas based on species richness and diversity parameters.

index.de: biodiversity\botanical composition\forests\plant communities\sclerophyllous forests\sclerophyllous scrub\shrubs\soil types\species diversity\synecology\trees\understorey\vegetation\vegetation types\woodlands\woody plants

bibl.et: The programme of tending and maintenance of the ecological and social functions of the Zagreb park forests.
bibl.ft: Program njege, obnove i odrz&hacek;avanja, te ekološke i socijalne funkcije park-šuma na području grada Zagreba.
bibl.aa: Zavod za uzgajanje šuma, Šumarski fakultet Sveučilista u Zagrebu, Croatia.

ab.p: The amenity forests and other urban trees in Zagreb are the remnants of ancient natural forests. This paper describes their silviculture, regeneration and maintenance, the structure of 17 forests covering 1258 ha of the 2400 ha total area of amenity forests in Zagreb, and their ecological and social functions in relation to hydrology, erosion, climate, air pollution, aesthetics, recreation, etc.

bibl.et: Climate change and terrestrial biomass: what if trees do not migrate?
bibl.aa: Western Ecology Division, National Health and Environmental Effects Research Laboratory, USA Environmental Protection Agency, 200 S.W. 35th, St., Corvallis, OR97333, U.S.A.

ab.p: Climate changes induced by doubling atmospheric greenhouse gas (2×GHG) concentrations are expected to affect the distribution of global vegetation and thereby, the amount of carbon it stores. The role of the terrestrial biosphere as a source or sink for carbon during climate change is critical: if increased GHG concentration and warming enhances carbon storage, thereby reducing atmospheric concentrations, the climate changes would also be ameliorated. If instead, carbon storage is reduced, the warming could induce a positive feedback to further increase atmospheric concentrations already on the rise from burning of fossil fuels. Differing climate-defined static vegetation classifications have been used to project biome distributions for climates induced by 2×GHGs. These projections assume that species extirpation and invasion will track perfectly distributions of climate variables and they predict enhanced terrestrial carbon storage. However, theoretical calculations and palaeoecological evidence suggest an alternative, more realistic simplifying assumption: trees will be extirpated but will not invade new territory before 2×GHG climate is attained. Projections of global terrestrial carbon under future climates were made using both assumptions. Simulated terrestrial carbon under delayed immigration decreased 7 to 34 Pg from modern values in contrast to increases projected under instant migration in this and earlier model exercises.

index.de: carbon\carbon cycle\carbon sequestration\climatic change\extinction\forest trees\geographical distribution\global warming\greenhouse effect\models\palaeoecology\simulation\spread\storage\trees\vegetation types\woody plants

bibl.et: Pteridophytes of an Araucaria forest. 1. Life forms and patterns of geographical distribution.
bibl.ft: Pteridófitas de uma floresta com araucária. 1. Formas biológicas e padrões de distribuição geográfica.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Botâanica da Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Av. Paulo Gama s/n, CEP 90040-060, Porto Alegre, RS, Brasil.

ab.p: A floristic survey of understorey pteridophytes was performed in an Araucaria forest located near São Francisco de Paula, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. A total of 13 families, 26 genera and 41 species was recorded. All species were analysed according to life form types and patterns of geographical distribution. The families Aspleniaceae, Polypodiaceae and Hymenophyllaceae had the highest species richness. The study of life forms revealed the occurrence of most of the major categories present in tropical and subtropical moist forests, with the exception of chamaephytes. The pteridophyte flora is represented by 5 pantropical and 36 neotropical species, including several categories of geographical spread.

index.de: flora\forests\geographical distribution\life form\species diversity\tropical forests\understorey

bibl.et: A method for enhancing tree species proportions from aerial photos.
bibl.aa: Natural Resources Canada, Canadian Forest Service, Pacific Forestry Centre, 506 W Burnside Road, Victoria, British Columbia, V8Z 1M5, Canada.

ab.p: Species proportions estimated from aerial photos will often deviate significantly from, usually greater, ground based sample estimates. To enhance photo-interpreted species proportions to better match ground observations this study proposes a cross-correlation memory matrix model as the most promising approach to a notoriously difficult problem. Ground and photo data from 246 stands in three sites in coastal British Columbia were used for model estimation and validation. Enhanced photo-based tree species proportions were, in most stands, closer to the ground estimates than the raw estimates. Changes in species proportions due to enhancement appeared reasonable when considering the actual species mix and stand structures. Two popular indices of species richness derived from photo proportions were biased downward. The proposed method effectively reduced the bias in one index. The model is easy to implement in operational inventories.

bibl.et: Preserving nature through intensive plantation forestry: the case for forestland allocation with illustrations from British Columbia.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Forestry, University of British Columbia, Canada.

ab.p: Historically British Columbia's forests were managed under the implicit assumption that virtually the whole forested land base would, one day, be available for timber production. The BC Forest Service and licensees incorporate non-timber values into timber production plans through a process of 'integrated resource management' which attempts to consider wildlife, riparian habitat, recreation, water flows, grazing and other forest uses in each decision about each hectare where logging is to occur. Under this extensive form of management, silvicultural investments are low. This policy has clearly failed either to satisfy legitimate demands from the environmental community or to produce the predictably high levels of timber harvest needed to sustain the forest products industry and industry-dependent communities. The core problem is that, despite a vast forest estate in British Columbia, land has become scarce. It is therefore logical to substitute capital, labour and knowledge for land in forest production processes. Such a policy could lead to substantially higher, sustainable timber harvests as well as a system of parks that covers more than half the Province. Implementing such a policy requires a change in forest management approach to zone the landscape and manage each zone intensively for a specific purpose. For the bulk of commercial timber production, intensively managed plantations appear to represent the best technological option. New directions in British Columbia's forest policy - land-use zoning, a new forest practice code, and dedicated capital for silvicultural investments - generally move towards this objective, but implementation remains uncertain. Major impediments include dysfunctional forest tenure arrangements and a comparatively poor information base.

bibl.et: A sustainable plan for conserving forest biodiversity in far East Russia and northeast China.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Portland Forestry Sciences Laboratory, 1221 S.W. Yamhill Street, Suite 200, Portland, Oregon, 97208-3890 USA.

ab.p: An ongoing, trinational project (involving Russia, China and the USA) is providing the first environmentally sustainable economic development plan for the Ussuri River watershed (URW) in Far East Russia and northeast China. The URW is host to a unique mix of northern taiga and southern subtropical biota, and contains many endemic, relict, and highly threatened species of plants and animals. In Russia, severe monetary inflation and a shift to a market economy have left some aspects of forest biodiversity in jeopardy, particularly policing for wildlife poachers, regulating CITES (international wildlife trafficking) violations, ensuring long-term sustained production of timber and non-timber forest products, protecting unique habitats, and adequately staffing scientific reserves and funding needed research. In China, broad scale conversion of remaining wetlands to agriculture and rice paddies, and of diverse native forests to intensively managed, monocultural plantations, is helping to sustain the economy but is sacrificing biodiversity. A proposed sustainable land use plan has (1) mapped resource use areas, including both proposed and existing transborder nature areas, (2) encouraged foreign investment in both countries, and (3) encouraged sustainable development of natural resource markets that will be compatible with long-term conservation of biodiversity. A hallmark of this plan is integrating the needs of the people with the capacity of the land through both environmental protection and wise resource use.

bibl.et: Influence of micro-site on the growth and seed crop of the European larch (Larix decidua Mill.) in a clonal seed orchard near Bjelovar.
bibl.ft: Utjecaj mikrostaništa na uspijevanje i urod sjemena europskog ariša (Larix decidua Mill.) u klonskoj sjememskoj plantaz&hacek;i kraj Bjelovara.
bibl.aa: Šumarski institut, 10450 Jastrebarsko, Croatia.

ab.p: Soil physical and chemical properties, and cone and seed production were studied during 1994 in the Klokočevac clonal larch (Larix decidua) seed orchard near Bjelovar, Croatia. Results showed that differences in the cone and seed crops, and in the growth of the trees measured on 2 plots, could be explained by differences in the soil water regime and soil nutrients, aeration of the rooting zone, humus content, and available P and K. Microsite factors appeared to have a stronger effect on seed production than did genotype.

bibl.et: Minerotrophic Pinus rotundata mires in the south-German forelands of the Alps emphasizing their syntaxonomic position.
bibl.ft: Minerotrophe Bergkiefernmoore im süddeutschen Alpenvorland unter besonderer Berücksichtigung ihrer syntaxonoischen Stellung.
bibl.aa: Büro für Vegetations- und Landschaftsökologie, Kappelweg 1, D-82497 Unterammergau, Germany.

ab.p: Pinus rotundata [P. uncinata] mires, a pine-dominated wet woodland, were examined with particular reference to the classification of the community and its position in the syntaxonomic system. Site conditions and importance for nature conservation are also discussed. The community occurs on sites ranging from acid, oligobasic to subneutral, basic mires, and thus varies in species composition. It is suggested that P. rotundata mires should be termed a Carex lasiocarpa-Pinus rotundata community, and that they represent a climax stage of vegetation succession. The community is of high nature conservation value.

bibl.et: 40-ton trucks on forest and rural roads.
bibl.ft: 40-Tönner auf Wald- und Güterstrassen.
bibl.aa: Departement Wald- und Holzforschung, ETH-Zentrum, CH-8092 Zürich, Switzerland.

ab.p: At present, the official Swiss transport policy is based on the 28-ton truck weight limit. However, in future Switzerland will introduce the 40-ton truck weight limit, resulting in standard use of 4-axle trucks with a total weight of 32 tons and 5-axle tractor-semi trailers. The effects of these trucks on forest and rural roads was assessed and showed that road damage was less than expected. Four-axle trucks with 2 tandem axles and 5-axle tractor-semi-trailers with 2 single axles and 1 tridem axle had a favourable stress distribution on road pavements. They caused less damage than present trucks with their overloading of 15% for timber transports. The basic pavement design for Swiss forest and rural roads needs no change. The transport of timber by EU-conforming trucks should become cheaper because of greater productivity. The use of 40-ton trucks is economically, ecologically and technically suitable.

index.de: costs\damage\road transport\roads\rural roads\timbers\transport\vehicles

bibl.et: Net primary production of forests: a constant fraction of gross primary production?
bibl.aa: College of Forestry, Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR 97331-7501, USA.

ab.p: Considerable progress has been made in the ability to model and measure annual gross primary production (GPP) by terrestrial vegetation. But challenges remain in estimating maintenance respiration (Rm) and net primary production (NPP). To search for possible common relationships, annual carbon budgets were assembled from six evergreen and one deciduous forest in Oregon, USA, three pine plantations in New South Wales, Australia, a deciduous forest in Massachusetts, USA, and a Nothofagus forest on the South Island of New Zealand. At all 12 sites, a standard procedure was followed to estimate annual NPP of foliage, branches, stems, and roots, the carbon expended in synthesis of these organs (Rg), their Rm, and that of previously produced foliage and sapwood in boles, branches, and large roots. In the survey, total NPP ranged from 120 to 1660 g C m-2 year-1, whereas the calculated fraction allocated to roots varied from 0.22 to 0.63. Comparative analysis indicated that the total NPP/GPP ratio was conservative (0.47 ± 0.04 SD). This finding supports the possibility of greatly simplifying forest growth models. The constancy of the NPP/GPP ratio also provides an incentive to renew efforts to understand the environmental factors affecting partitioning of NPP above and belowground.

bibl.et: A model of frost impacts on seasonal photosynthesis of Eucalyptus pauciflora.
bibl.aa: Ecosystem Dynamics Group, Research School of Biological Sciences, Australian National University, Canberra, ACT 0200, Australia.

ab.p: A model of the time course of frost impacts on seasonal photosynthesis of Eucalyptus pauciflora was constructed, incorporating seasonal shifts in frost hardiness and both short- and long-term impacts on the initial slope and saturated level of the photosynthetic light response curve. The approach is an extension of Sands' model which calculates daily canopy photosynthesis as a function of daily irradiance and temperatures without the impacts of cold nights. Modelled effects of frost on cumulative photosynthesis over 8 months were highly non-linear and rather sensitive to the temporal sequence of minimum temperatures and extent of frost hardening. Most of the effects were associated with long-term damage caused by a few severe or unseasonal frosts. Shifting either plant sensitivity or minimum temperatures by several degrees had large impacts on predicted outcomes. These results are consistent with other observations that the increase in frost severity associated with land clearing is impeding eucalypt regeneration in interior Australia and may be applicable to other frost-prone areas.

bibl.et: Saal's heavy thinning model for birch.
bibl.ft: Das Saaler Birken-Lichtwuchsmodell.

ab.p: A silvicultural system to obtain fast growing birch (Betula spp.) stands on nutrient-rich and hydromorphic glacial loams in Saal, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany, is described. Natural regeneration was used, allowing an undisturbed growth up to a height of 8-10 m. The system used the extreme light-demanding properties, fast youth growth and self-pruning capacity of birch. After 30 years, the selected elite stems are favoured by heavy thinnings, resulting in an open stand diameter increment and the production of veneer timber at the end of the rotation period (80 years). A second thinning is recommended after 50 years. A financial evaluation showed the problems and the lack of importance of traditional timber production. Using the heavy thinning model resulted in improved veneer quality. The lower total increment was equalled by higher prices for veneer qualities. The model of Saal is interesting from ecological, silvicultural and economical viewpoints and could increase the small and irregular production of birch veneer timber.

bibl.et: Pinus nigra - an underestimated species?
bibl.ft: Schwarzkiefer - eine unterschätzte Baumart?
bibl.aa: Forstliche Bundesversuchsanstalt, A-1131 Vienna, Austria.

ab.p: An account is given of a thinning trial in a stand of Pinus nigra var. austriaca established by direct sowing in 1862 in Lower Austria. The three thinning plots (light, moderate, and heavy thinning) were installed in 1882, and results are given up to age 135 (in 1996). Up to age 70 the top height was smaller on the heavy thinning, but in the following 30 years top height was similar on all plots. After age 100, height increment was greatest on the moderate thinning. Top height gave good agreement with Altherr's yield table. Total value production over the whole period was almost identical on the three plots, viz. 1296, 1343 and 1308 m³/ha, corresponding to total m.a.i. of 9.6-10 m³/ha. The results indicate that on good sites P. nigra can give good growth rates and produce wood of high quality.

bibl.do: The saga of participatory forest management in India.
bibl.et: The saga of participatory forest management in India.

ab.p: Although almost all Indian states have passed enabling resolutions to facilitate Joint Forest Management (JFM), programme implementation has been uneven. Based on visits to JFM villages in 5 states (Uttar Pradesh, Haryana, Gujarat, West Bengal, Orissa), this book provides a critique of past and current forest policies, and a review of the implementation of participatory forest management and its mechanisms (collective action, state sponsored participation, and complementary programmes). The constraints of government policies are described and reasons for the maintenance of communal action over time are examined and placed in the wider context of property regimes.

bibl.do: Research results for thinning and pruning eucalypt plantations for sawlog production in Tasmania.
bibl.et: Research results for thinning and pruning eucalypt plantations for sawlog production in Tasmania.

ab.p: Detailed results are given from thinning and pruning trials with Eucalyptus spp. (E. nitens, E. regnans, E. globulus) at various locations in Tasmania, Australia, carried out as part of a federally funded project managed by the Forests and Forest Industry Council of Tasmania. The results indicate that it is feasible to grow large 50-60 cm sawlog sized eucalypts in plantations, and that thinning improves diameter growth rate, while pruning increases quality and is essential to the production of high-quality knot-free timber. However, a financial analysis showed that sawlog production is only likely to be financially viable on very high quality sites managed under a commercial thinning regime. A provisional management regime is outlined.

ab.p: The history of leisure time, social changes and their influences on different types of recreation (including forest recreation) are described.

bibl.do: General Technical Report - Pacific Northwest Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.et: The Alexander Archipelago wolf: a conservation assessment.
bibl.ms: Conservation and resource assessments for the Tongass land management plan revision (Shaw, C. G., III, Technical coordinator)
bibl.aa: Alaska Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK 99775, USA.

ab.p: Information is summarized on the morphology, distribution, taxonomy, genetics and ecology of Alexander Archipelago wolves (Canis lupus ligoni) in the Tongass National Forest of SE Alaska. Three issues for the conservation of the wolves are discussed: loss of long-term carrying capacity for deer, primarily because of logging; increased mortality associated with improved human access from roads; and continued high levels of harvesting of wolves by humans.

bibl.et: Hunting, wildlife management and the Federal Hunting Act in Germany.
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Science, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Hokkaido, Nishi 9, Kita 9, Kita-ku, Sapporo 060, Japan.

ab.p: Forests are ecosystems with multiple basic functions, viz. wood production and conservation of the environment, including the soil, water functions, etc. Forest policy provides the interface between the natural and social sciences in forestry, and these interrelations include the needs for products and services, and incorporate wildlife management. Wildlife management is closely related to forestry and should be coordinated and integrated with forest management. Past developments in forestry can be characterized as a change from forest exploitation to a modified forest management incorporating different forest functions. Sustainable forest management and the development of overall land use policies was developed hundreds of years ago. In Germany, hunting played an important role in the development of an integrated forest management policy. In Japan, multiple-use forestry is a basic concept in forest policy. Water conservation, wood production and soil protection are emphasized, but wildlife management does not seem so important in Japanese forest management. Recently, the extent of damage by game has been highlighted in Japan. In this light, this paper focuses on wildlife management activities and the Hunting Act in Germany, in an attempt to make a contribution to the development of a wildlife management system for Japan.

bibl.et: Condition and dynamics of the Russian Far East forests in 1966-1993.
bibl.aa: Far East Forestry Research Institute, Volochaevskaya, 71, 680020 Khabarovsk, Russia.

ab.p: The Russian Far East Forests are a great ecological and natural resource of significance to the Asia-Pacific region. Evaluation of the condition and dynamics of these forests helps in the evaluation of sustainable forest use trends in nature protection activities and the identification of research needs. In this paper, the condition of the Forest Service land as at January 1993 is described, and forest dynamics between 1966 and 1993 is analysed. On the basis of the analysis, the ecological and timber potential of the Far East forests is evaluated.

bibl.et: Progress in chanterelle (Cantharellus cibarius) cultivation.
bibl.ft: Les progrès dans la maîtrise de la culture de la chanterelle, Cantharellus cibarius.
bibl.ct: Champignons et mycorhizes en forêt.
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Mycology and Pathology, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, Box 7026, S-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: A short account is given of the current status of research worldwide into techniques for the production of the chanterelle, Cantharellus cibarius. One of the major obstacles that has delayed laboratory research on this species is the high infection rate of the fruit bodies with large numbers of microorganisms, especially fluorescent Pseudomonas bacteria. Details are given of recent work in isolating the mycelium in pure culture. It was cultivated in a liquid medium to obtain mycorrhizas. A hyphal suspension was then added to young Pinus sylvestris seedlings cultivated under axenic conditions with a nutrient solution containing glucose. When the mycorrhizas formed, the seedlings were transferred to non-sterile pots placed in a greenhouse. After one year the external mycelium of the mycorrhizas is large enough to support fruit body formation.

bibl.et: Wildlife management and game protection in Bia&lstroke;owiez&circleover;a Primeval Forest in 1991-1997 (part 1, part 2).
bibl.ft: Gospodarka &lstroke;owiecka i ochrona zwierzyny w Puszczy Bia&lstroke;owieskiej w latach 1991-1997 (cze&hook;śc´ 1, cze&hook;śc´ 2).

ab.p: Changes are described in the numbers and hunting use of several species of game mammals (red and roe deer, wild boar, European elk, foxes and hares), rare animals (marten and badger), those without significance for hunting (squirrel) and protected species (wolf and lynx) in the Bia&lstroke;owiez&dotover;a Forest over the period 1991-97. Since 1995 the protection and game management of mammal populations have tended to follow a pro-ecological model of hunting, with the aim of conserving forest biodiversity not only as regards the species and quantitative composition of predatory mammals and their prey, but also of plants constituting food for herbivores. Four ways of attaining this goal are as follows described. (1) Maintaining optimal numbers of large herbivores (including an account of the rank of the endangered European bison) that do not cause ecological degradation of the environment and also allow for multiple use by man. (2) Through well managed hunting use and protection, bringing back the right proportions of individual species in the population of large mammals living in the forest (abatement of the deer numbers, increasing populations of European elk, roe deer, wild boar, hare and badgers). (3) Bringing back the right age and gender structure inside the red deer population (increasing the share of males and the youngest deer) and wild boar (increasing the share of animals in older age classes). (4) Continual monitoring of the condition of populations of game and protected animals in order to react quickly to the effects of predictable and unpredictable factors of both a biotic and an abiotic nature.

bibl.et: Pathogenic fungi occurring on introduced pine species in the arboretum at Rogów.
bibl.ft: Grzyby patogeniczne wyste&hook;puja&hook;ce na introdukowanych gatunkach sosen w Arboretum w Rogowie.

ab.p: Differences in tree health were observed in 17 introduced pine species in the Rogów Arboretum in Poland. The worst health was observed in Pinus cembra var. sibirica [P. sibirica. Pinus rigida, Pinus peuce and Pinus banksiana showed the best state of health. Nineteen species of fungi were found on the introduced pine species. The most pathogenic species was Armillaria obscura, and Heterobasidion annosum was also of great importance. Cronartium ribicola was the greatest threat for the five-needle pine species.

bibl.et: Shoot and root formation on cut pieces of viviparous seedlings of a mangrove, Kandelia candel (L.) Druce.
bibl.aa: Graduate School of Agriculture, Gifu University, Gifu, 501-11, Japan.

ab.p: For re/afforestation of mangroves in tropical countries, the lack of viviparous seedlings to plant is a problem. To attain the maximum use of the viviparous seedling, the cut-piece method has been proposed by some Thai foresters. In laboratory experiments with 300 viviparous seedlings of Kandelia candel (collected in Okinawa, Japan, in May 1996), single seedlings were partitioned into lengths of 1, 2, 3, 5, and 10 cm. Each cut piece was planted in sandy soil in a 40×60 cm container, and the formation of roots and shoots was checked for 168 days. The 1-cm treatment showed the lowest rate of shoot emergence (1.1-3.3%). Shoot formation was highest (63.3-93.8%) for cut pieces originating from the upper position on the seedling (the top 10-12 cm) which included the plumule, but lower (0-26.6%) in the cut pieces containing no plumule. Among the cut pieces originating from a lower position (the bottom 10-12 cm), shoot formation was higher (34.2-50.0%) in cut pieces containing no radicle; no shoot formation was observed in cut pieces containing a radicle except in the 10-cm treatment (26.7%). The number of grown cut pieces produced per single viviparous seedling was highest in the 3-cm treatment (206.7%), followed by the 2-cm treatment (200.0%). The efficiency and problems of this method are discussed.

bibl.et: Seasonal and yearly variations of fine-root biomass and necromass in a Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris L.) stand.
bibl.aa: Finnish Forest Research Institute, Vantaa Research Centre, P.O. Box 18, FIN-01301 Vantaa, Finland.

ab.p: Seasonal variations of the Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris), dwarf shrub and grass fine-root biomass and necromass were studied in a pole stage naturally regenerated Scots pine stand in eastern Finland during 3 successive growing seasons (1985-1988). The biomass of Scots pine fine roots varied annually and seasonally in the humus layer between 19±5 and 139±22 g/m², in the upper mineral soil layer between 90±14 and 279±0 g/m², and in the lower mineral soil layer between 68±17 and 217±73 g/m². The seasonal minimum and maximum of understorey vegetation fine-root biomass were in the humus layer 35±6 and 235±42 g/m², in the upper mineral soil layer 26±0 and 165±0 g/m², and in the lower mineral soil layer 14±0 and 36±5 g/m². The seasonal fine-root necromass varied in the humus layer from 2±0 to 1398±236 g/m², in the upper mineral soil layer from 86±0 to 1267±366 g/m², and in the lower mineral soil layer from 8±0 to 753±306 g/m². The major part of the living Scots pine fine roots (62%) was in the mineral soil immediately below the humus layer, but almost all dwarf shrub roots and grass roots were in the humus and in the upper mineral soil layers. Most dead fine roots (82%) were in the humus layer and in the uppermost mineral soil layer. The variations of Scots pine fine-root biomass, dwarf shrub and grass fine-root biomass and necromass did not show a distinct and clear pattern within any growing season although there were significant differences between the same month during different growing seasons. Some of the observed variations could be explained by climatic factors related to drought.

bibl.et: Influence of the proportions of the tree species on rooting, water regime, nutrient regime and increments of a mixed spruce/beech stand at the Höglwald site.
bibl.ft: Einfluss des Baumarten-anteils aud Durchwurzelung, Wasserhaushalt, Stoffhaushalt und Zuwachsleistung eines Fichten-Buchen-Misch-bestandes am, Standort Höglwald.
bibl.pb: Forstwissenschaftlichen Fakultät der Universität München & Bayerische Forstliche Versuchs und Forschungsanstalt
bibl.aa: Lehrbereich für Waldrenährung, LMU, München, Germany.

ab.p: Studies were made in 1994-1996 in Bavaria in a 90-year-old stand of Picea abies/Fagus sylvatica, and in a pure stand of each species of identical age. Data are presented on rooting patterns, hydrology, C and N stocks, humus morphology and soil acidity, atmospheric deposition, litter fall, seepage, increment, horizontal extent of tree species effects, and prediction. Volume increment of pure spruce was ca. twice that of pure beech; the increment of a mixed stand containing 40% beech was nearly 90% of that of the pure spruce stand. It is better to achieve the desired proportion of broadleaves by intimate mixture than by group planting.

bibl.et: Towards a tenure policy framework for sustainable forest management in Canada.
bibl.aa: Department of Rural Economy, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta T6G 2H1, Canada.

ab.p: Currently, forest tenure policies in Canada and elsewhere are dominated by concepts associated with sustained yield (SY) that may preclude the realization of sustainable forest management objectives. This paper identifies how tenure policies based on SY concepts of allowable annual cuts could change in order to address a more holistic view of forest associated with sustainable forest management. Topics covered are harvesting policies with reference to annual allowable cuts and regulations designed to protect non-timber resources, and processing policies, with reference to stipulations on a tenure holder to allow access to crown timber and log export restrictions. Regeneration policies are also discussed, in terms of requirements, subsidies and allowable cut effect.

bibl.et: The potential for biological control to reduce Hylobius abietis damage.

ab.p: To reduce the reliance on insecticides, the development of an integrated forest pest management system may soon present an alternative solution for the control of the insect pest Hylobius abietis. This note describes the potential of entomopathogenic nematodes to control H. abietis and also outlines studies on the parasitic wasp Bracon hylobii. Natural enemies are also listed.

bibl.et: A Sitka spruce height-age model with improved extrapolation properties.
bibl.aa: Research Branch, British Columbia Ministry of Forests, PO Box 9519, Stn. Prov. Govt., Victoria, British Columbia, V8W 9C2, Canada.

ab.p: The height-age model for Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) currently recommended for use in British Columbia, Canada has poor extrapolation properties. Therefore, a new height-age model was developed, using stem analysis data collected from the Queen Charlotte Islands. Care was taken to meet the standard regression assumptions. In particular, accounting for within-plot serial correlation improved the extrapolation abilities of the model by eliminating the crossing-over effect. The new model is being recommended for use in British Columbia as it offers better extrapolated height and site index estimates without sacrificing accuracy at young ages.

bibl.do: Arboriculture Research and Information Note - Arboricultural Advisory and Information Service (AAIS)
bibl.et: Sensitivity of broadleaved trees to desiccation and rough handling between lifting and transplanting.
bibl.pb: Arboricultural Advisory and Information Service, Forestry Commission Research Station
bibl.aa: Northern Research Station, Roslin, Midlothian, EH25 9SY, UK.

ab.p: Annual expenditure in the UK on planting broadleaved trees for amenity is many millions of pounds. The high mortality levels and poor growth often experienced following planting are a cause for concern. Handling between the nursery bed and planting can cause damage which is not initially obvious, but can seriously impair outplanting survival and performance. In experimental desiccation damage, the roots of 2-yr-old (1+1) bare rooted nursery stock of 4 amenity broadleaved species (pedunculate oak, Quercus robur; beech, Fagus sylvatica; ash, Fraxinus excelsior; and Norway maple, Acer platanoides) were significantly affected by desiccation and to a lesser extent, rough handling. These species were generally most tolerant during mid-winter to early spring; detailed seasonal trends in their tolerance to the two stresses are described. There were also significant differences among the species; for example, desiccation had a particularly severe effect on maple whereas oak was more resistant. The optimum planting time will depend not only on the species' resistance to these stresses but also on many other factors, such as conditions at lifting and at the planting sites, which are not included in this study.

bibl.et: Project Aquarius 8. Sweating, drinking, and dehydration in men suppressing wildland fires.
bibl.aa: National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety (Worksafe Australia), GPO Box 58, Sydney, NSW 2001, Australia.

ab.p: The fluid balance of fire fighters was measured while they attempted to suppress well-developed experimental bushfires of intensities commonly faced by hand-tool crews, and also while they built fireline in the same way without fire, during 3 summers in Australian eucalypt forests. They consistently sweated at rates of 1-2 kg/hr while building fireline and at half these rates for the whole work day. Drinking and dehydration were proportional to sweat loss, and on average fire fighters replaced 43% of their sweat loss during fireline construction and 63% for the whole work day. During fireline construction they dehydrated at an average rate of 654 g/hr (0.9% body mass) and a maximum rate of 2 kg/hr (2.6% body mass). The scientific observers sweated less than half as much as the fire fighters but also drank less and became almost as dehydrated. These findings emphasise the need for work practices that guarantee an adequate water intake before, during and after fire fighting. Regression equations are presented for predicting sweat rate (hence water requirements) from activity, fire, body mass and air temperature.

bibl.et: Using silica ash as an adhesive in the production of low-toxicity particleboards.
bibl.aa: Lesotekhnicheskaya Akademiya, St Petersburg, Russia.

ab.p: Experiments were made in which water glass (sodium silicate solution) was used with UF resin to make particleboards. It was necessary to increase the pressing period in order to remove the bound water and to harden the silica, but formaldehyde emission from these boards was reduced 5- to 8-fold. To avoid the adverse effect of the alkaline oxides in water glass, further experiments were made using stabilized ash (SiO2)n added to UF resin in amounts of 0, 10, 20, 30, 40 or 50%. Experiments were also made in which the wood particles were treated with the ash (SiO2)n and then hot-pressed at 150°C. Data are tabulated on the physical and mechanical properties of the boards. The results show that by using the silica ash to pre-treat the particles, or mixed at a rate of 15% into the adhesive, it is possible to produce boards of class E1 having high strength properties and water resistance. The increased adhesion of the resin and the ability of the SiO2 colloidal particles to sort formaldehyde mean that it is possible to reduce board density by ca. 10%, with consequent savings in materials and production cost.

bibl.et: Clearcut harvesting and structural dynamics of a boreal forest in Saskatchewan.
bibl.aa: Prince Albert Model Forest Association, Box 2406, Prince Albert, SK S6V 7G3, Canada.

ab.p: Long-term inventory projections for some 84&thin;000 ha of productive boreal mixedwood in Saskatchewan were combined with fragmentation analysis to investigate sustained timber production and nature conservation. A spatially unrestricted clearcut harvesting regime was simulated for a 100-year period (1984-2084). The model showed that current harvest rates of 1.5 m³/ha per year could be sustained, but the age class distribution of the forest would markedly shift towards younger stands. Maximizing timber yields could raise harvest rates by 10%. These harvest rates would make it increasingly difficult to set aside permanently productive forest for ecosystem protection and alternative forest uses. A reduction of current harvest rates by at least 30% would support forest conservation. Spatial restrictions of the harvesting regime would be required to prevent forest fragmentation.

bibl.et: The level and trends in wood use in Poland and in the European Union countries. Situation and perspectives.
bibl.ft: Poziom i kierunki zuz&dotover;ycia drewna w Polsce oraz w krajach Unii Europejskiej. Stan obecny i perspektywy.

ab.p: Forecasting forest resource and wood utilization over a timespan exceeding 30 years is risky due to both unforeseeable causes (such as political and economic changes throughout Europe), and to possible substantial changes in the preference of choices made by the public. This report constitutes a critical review of the analyses of the current production and use of wood in the countries of the European Union and in Poland, and discusses the factors directly influencing the shape of those relations in the future. The forecasts suggest that to the year 2020 Scandinavian countries will maintain a stable and high level of production and trade in raw wood and wood products, while the other countries of the European Union will maintain a continually increasing demand for those products. The demand for paper and cardboard will grow considerably, while the demand for sawnwood will lessen slightly. In Poland there the change in wood resource will not cause an important rise of wood harvesting, and its technical quality will not change. The amounts of paper and wood-based panels will grow, especially after Poland becomes an EU member. It is expected that up to 2020 the EU will import raw wood from the USA, Canada, and to a lesser extent, from Chile and New Zealand plantations. Greater amounts of imported wood from the NIS (Newly Independent States) countries are not taken into account. A limitation on tropical wood imports to the EU, including Poland, should also be expected.

bibl.et: New modification of drying kilns for forest industrial enterprises.
bibl.aa: Ural'skaya Gosudarstvennaya Lesotekhnicheskaya Akademiya, Ekaterinburg, Russia.

ab.p: Details are given of the basic specifications of a range of IU kilns, developed in Russia as more fuel-efficient versions of the Ural-72 kiln, and capable of operating with various forms of energy (steam, gas, generator gas, electricity, hot water). These kilns are of the single-stack type and have a charge capacity of 5.8 or 14.7 m³. The design of two kilns is illustrated, viz. the single-stack electric IU-IE kiln, and the two-stack gas IU-2TG kiln.

bibl.et: Fungi occurring in acorns with symptoms of brown spottiness and mummification.
bibl.ft: Grzyby wyste&hook;puja&hook;ce na z&dotover;o&lstroke;e&hook;dziach z objawami brunatnej plamistości i mumifikacji.

ab.p: Thirty-nine species of fungi were found on acorns from two forest districts in NW Poland, with symptoms of spots on the coats and cotyledons, and nitrification and mummification of the cotyledons. Two species occurred often - Phomopsis glandicola and Cystodendron dryophilum. In numerous samples from the Kaczory Forest District, Cylindrocarpon cf. gracile, Phacidium lacerum and Phialophora botulispora were also common. In most cases the fungal species found was closely linked to the kind of symptoms found. Acorns with single spots were colonized mainly by Phomopsis glandicola, with Cylindrocarpon cf. gracile and Phialophora botulispora often accompanying. On acorns with medium and highly advanced spottiness and decay, the proportion of Cystodendron dryophilum increased. Deeply nitrified and mummified acorns were colonized almost solely by Cystodendron dryophilum. Almost none of the fungi mentioned above were found in acorns which had undergone thermal treatment. Such acorns were almost exclusively colonized by Mucor racemosus f. sphaerosporus, Penicillium and Sporothrix schenckii. Dying sprouts were colonized mainly by Cylindrocarpon cf. gracile and Phacidium lacerum.

bibl.et: The growth of pedunculate oak (Quercus robur L.) and European ash (Fraxinus excelsior L.) in individual plastic covers.
bibl.ft: Wzrost de&hook;bu szypu&lstroke;kowego (Quercus robur L.) i jesionu wynios&lstroke;ego (Fraxinus excelsior L.) w plastikowych os&lstroke;onach indywidualnych.
bibl.aa: Economic Forestry Group Limited Company za udoste&hook;pnienie siedmioletniej plantacji jesionowej do realizacji ninejszych badan´, Poland.

ab.p: The results are summarized of experiments in Poland in which 2-yr-old oak and European ash seedlings were grown in shelters made from plastic materials. Growth increases in height, dbh (diameter at breast height), biomass, growth ring width and bark thickness were observed in plants growing in shelters over a period of up to 7 yr. Increases reached (on average) 5× and 3× in height and dbh, respectively, for oak, and 2× for both parameters in ash. The greatest increases were observed in biomass - 60× increases for oaks in shelters and 7× increases for ash. No statistically significant effect of the colour or texture of the shelters used was found. the main effects of the shelters are suggested as improvement of microclimate and protection from browsing by wildlife.

bibl.et: Threat factors to nature in national parks and their valuation (1986-1995).
bibl.ft: Czynniki zagraz&dotover;aja&hook;ce przyrodzie parków nardowych i ich ocena (1986-1995).

ab.p: This paper is a continuation of previous papers published in Sylwan in 1988 (141 (8) [full reference not known] and 141 (9) 37-43), and assesses threats in 20 Polish national parks (which have increased in both number and area over the study period) for 3 selected years (1986, 1990, 1995). The main threats remained the same (industry, tourism, forest pests and municipal wastes) but intensity varied, and had generally decreased. The overall condition of the environment was improved. The greatest threats (in descending order) were in the Karkonosze, Ojcow and Wielkopolski national parks, followed by the Tatra, Kampinos, Pieniny and Świe&hook;tokrzyski national parks (where the situation had not changed much). Other threatened parks were the Sto&lstroke;owe Mountains and Wolin national parks. In the remaining national parks the threats were small or very small.
