bibl.et: Squirrel monkeys in Costa Rica: drifting to extinction.
bibl.aa: Department of Anthropology and Division of Comparative Medicine, 1350 Turlington Hall, PO Box 117305, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611 7305, USA.

ab.p: A survey of Central American squirrel monkeys (Saimiri oerstedii oerstedii and S. o. citrinellus) was conducted during 1996 in the Pacific wet lowlands of Costa Rica during 19 to document localities where this animal was still evident despite a decline in population numbers. Based on this survey, it was confirmed that at least 1246 squirrel monkeys remained in 26 spatially dispersed localities, but the total population size was assessed to be far below that which would provide long-term genetic viability. Deforestation and habitat fragmentation spurred by agricultural anf forestry (e.g. plantations of Gmelina arborea and silviculture) and tourism development contributed to this decline. Suggested management strategies include a reduction in deforestation, the maintenance of secondary growth and early successional habitats (Cecropia, Piper, Miconia, Palicourea and Lycianthes genera provide much of the fruit and arthropod components of the monkey diet), stabilization of food resources by the planting of Psidium guajava, and the maintenance of safe travel routes across roads and between forest patches (maintenance of branches overhanging roads, the limitation of bush and tree clearance from roadsides and beneath powerlines, provision of ropes or other branch substitutes across narrow clearings and the insulation of power lines).

bibl.et: Evolution of CO2 during the fixation of chromium containing wood preservatives on wood.
bibl.aa: Wood Science and Technology Center, University of New Brunswick, 1350 Regent Street, E3C 26C, Fredericton, NB, Canada.

ab.p: A titration procedure was used to confirm carbon dioxide evolution from wood treated with solutions containing chromic acid and to quantify the effects of species (red pine [Pinus resinosa] vs soft maple [Acer saccharum]), solution concentration and reaction temperature on the rate and amount of CO2 evolved. Small blocks or chips were vacuum treated with either chromated copper arsenate (CCA) wood preservative or chromic acid solutions and the release of CO2 monitored until the reaction was complete. Significant volumes of CO2 were measured. This is attributed to the oxidation and subsequent decarboxylation of primary hydroxyl groups on wood constituents. The ratio of moles of CO2 produced to moles of chromium added to the wood ranged from about 0.07 to 0.24 depending on the wood species, solution properties and fixation conditions. This accounted for from 9 to 32% of the total oxidation potential of the hexavalent chromium applied. The relative amounts of CO2 produced were higher for maple than for red pine. The rate of CO2 evolution was also higher in the maple samples, consistent with the higher rate of chromium reduction in soft maple compared to red pine. The amount of CO2 produced was approximately proportional to the amount of hexavalent chromium in the CCA treating solution although the ratio of CO2 produced to chromium added to the wood increased slightly with increasing solution concentration. The relative amounts of CO2 produced increased with increasing fixation temperature over the 50-90°C range in both species. The rate of CO2 evolution was accelerated as the fixation temperature was increased. The rates and amounts of CO2 produced were similar for CCA and CrO3 treatments containing the same concentration of chromic acid. Copper and arsenic components of the CCA solution did not appear to have any effect on the decarboxylation reaction.

index.de: carbon dioxide\chromium\fixation\preservative treated wood\wood preservation\wood preservatives

bibl.et: An industry evaluation of the reuse, recycling, and reduction of spent CCA wood products.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Wood Sci. and Forest Prod., Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, VA 24061-0323, USA.

ab.p: Over 6 billion board feet of lumber treated with chromated copper arsenate (CCA) is produced annually in the United States. Although the Environmental Protection Agency and most states currently allow disposal of spent CCA-treated wood products in landfills, it is possible that disposal may be restricted in the future. The objectives of this research were to identify the barriers that limit the use of spent CCA fibre in the wood composite industry and to recommend alternatives for this spent resource. A mail survey to wood composite manufacturers and personal interviews indicated that most respondents were not in favour of using this recycled product in conventional wood composite manufacturing. Their primary concerns were the safety of workers and environmental problems that may arise with composite products that are contaminated with treatment chemicals. Suggested uses from these respondents included fuel, specialty treated wood composites, and wood-non-wood composites. Based upon secondary literature, mail survey data, and personal interviews, recommendations and future research activities are suggested.

Robusta [Populus 'Robusta'] (spacings 4, 6, 8 and 10 m). The method of compilation and application of the tables is explained, and various auxiliary tables for site classification, thinning, normal stocking, normal b.a., form factor, etc. are also presented.

bibl.et: Comparison of ant diversity in the leaf litter of mixed and pure native tree plantations in the humid Atlantic lowlands, Costa Rica.
bibl.aa: Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, 205 Prospect Street, New Haven, Connecticut, CT 06511, USA.

ab.p: Ants, chosen as good indicators of biodiversity, were collected in June-July 1996 from the litter of experimental plantations of Albizia guachapele, Dipteryx panamensis, Terminalia amazonia and Virola koschnyi in pure plots or mixed plots in which all species were represented and from natural regrowth plots. The effects on ant numbers and species diversity of proximity to a secondary forest were also examined. A total of 220 ants from 9 genera were collected: Crematogaster, Cyphomyrmex, Ectatomma, Hyponera, Lachnomyrmex, Pachycondyla, Paratrenchina, Pheidole, Solenopsis, Tapinoma, Wasmannia. The results suggest that the mixed-forest plantations and those adjacent to a secondary forest supported a greater number of ant genera than the monoculture plantations.

bibl.et: Farmers of the forest.
bibl.aa: University of Reading, Department of Agricultural Botany, Reading, UK.

ab.p: An account is given of the sustainable agricultural practices of the Tawahka, a small group of Amerindians living along the Río Patuca in the Honduran Mosquitia region, where they practice shifting cultivation. The Tawahka are a riverine and forest people who have been farming in this region of the Central American rain forest belt for as long as 4500 yr. After an introduction, farming practices in the uplands and the lowland fields and gardens are described. Comparisons are also made with the practices of other indigenous groups, and with the unsustainable ranching practices of the neighbouring Spanish speaking Ladinos.

bibl.et: Regression models describe and predict benefits of vegetation management for black spruce.
bibl.aa: Canadian Forest Service, Great Lakes Forestry Centre, Sault Ste. Marie, ON P6A 5M7, Canada.

ab.p: Data collected from an experiment in Kenogaming Township, Ontario, were used to develop quantitative models describing the effects of stock type (bare root or one of 3 sizes of paperpot), planting season (May or July 1982), and weed control (glyphosate hand application in August 1984) on basal diameter, height, volume and survival of black spruce (Picea mariana) trees up to age 11 years. The time-dependent regression models showed that reduction in weed competition almost always had a beneficial effect on crop volume and basal area growth, but tree height and survival showed little response to weed control.

bibl.et: Testing the archaeological potential zoning system.

ab.p: Previous research has indicated that the occurrence of Aboriginal archaeological sites is frequently associated with certain environmental features (such as sources of stone or the occurrence of shelter). These environmental features were used to zone areas of state forest in Tasmania according to the likelihood of finding sites. In a zone of high archaeological potential a greater proportion of coupes are required to be surveyed before logging than in a low zone. Tests of the reliability of the system confirmed that in dry forests higher densities of archaeological remains were consistently found in areas zoned as high, with no significant differences between medium and low zones. For wet forests zoning based on a range of environmental factors did not produce ant differences between zones.

bibl.et: Juvenile growth of spruce under air pollution. Results of a case study over 25 years.
bibl.ft: Das Jugendwachstum von Fichte unter Immissionsbelastung. Ergebnisse einer Fallstudie über 25 Jahre.
bibl.aa: Institut für Waldwachstum und Betriebswirtschaft, Forstliche Bundesversuchsanstalt, Seckendorff-Gudentweg 8, A-1131 Wien, Austria.

ab.p: The juvenile development of afforestation stands of spruce [Picea abies] and other species, and parameters to determine the impact of air pollution have been measured since 1972 at 3 sites, located at 1050, 1300 and 1900 m from the melting plant at Gailitz-Arnoldstein in Carinthia, Austria. Data were recorded on air quality, and needle and soil analysis. Despite strong efforts since 1987 to reduce air pollution, legal sulfur threshold levels were exceeded in needles from all sites, although a clear reduction of sulfur in needle content and air concentration was found. The different distances of sites from the source of emission resulted in corresponding differences in all parameters. Although the impact of air pollution extended beyond the most distant site, increment was extremely high on this site. Both other sites showed a reduced growth, but the present increment at the 1300 m-site reached normal values.

bibl.et: Conflicts in forestry in critical times. An analysis of the present discussion on forest policy.
bibl.ft: Konflikte in der Forstwirtschaft in krisenhafter Zeit. Eine Analyse der aktuellen forstpolitischen Diskussion.
bibl.aa: Institut für Forstpolitik, Arbeitsbereich Landnutzungspolitik, Universität Freiburg, Bertoldstrasse 17, D-49076 Freiburg, Germany.

ab.p: Traditionally, German foresters appeared to be a homogeneous social group. However, the forestry crisis forced forest politicians to discuss a new common strategy to cope with economic and ecological challenges. Well-organized groups (e.g. private forest owners associations, forest workers' union) were increasingly unable to agree on a common leading idea about the vital goals of forest management and forest policy. Some of the topics discussed seemed to anticipate internal (within the forestry sector) and external (with other parts of society) conflicts. Internal conflicts were described as endogenous social group conflicts, using Dahrendorf's conflict theory. The theoretical approach to conflict management is described, including the identification of major participants, the analysis of the vital topics of the conflict and the potential measures taken (preferably by participants). Some results of a survey of important interest groups on conflict management are presented.

ab.p: The current paper discusses the importance of the dry rot fungus [Serpula lacrimans] as one of the most destructive fungi causing timber decay in buildings. Besides a systematic and an identification key, the behaviour of the fungus is shown. Examples of timber decay show that prevention and control strategies are much more effective than rectifying damage. Various detection methods and treatments are shown.

bibl.et: Natural abundance of 15N in forests across a nitrogen deposition gradient.
bibl.ct: Special issue: The whole ecosystem experiments of the NITREX and EXMAN projects.
bibl.aa: Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, Bangor Research Unit, UWB, Deiniol Rd., Bangor, Gwynedd, LL57 2UP, UK.

ab.p: Chronic atmospheric nitrogen deposition can alter the rate of internal nitrogen cycling and increase the magnitude of N leaching losses in forested ecosystems. As fractionation of nitrogen in favour of the lighter 14N occurs during various transformations associated with N-enrichment and nitrogen loss, it has been proposed that the 15N signal of vegetation may provide a useful tool in evaluating the past and current N status of forested ecosystems. A series of coniferous forests at 5 sites across a European nitrogen deposition gradient within the NITREX project (Sweden, Denmark, UK, and the Netherlands - 2 sites) provided an opportunity to test the relationships between nitrogen supply from atmospheric deposition and the relative 15N-enrichment of vegetation to soil, across a large geographical area. Most δ15N values for above- and below-ground tree components, soil at 4 depths, bulk precipitation and/or throughfall water and soil solution or outflow water values, were within those observed elsewhere except for a few notable exceptions. There was a significant positive relationship between the δ15N enrichment of the tree foliage relative to the soil horizons (or the enrichment factor), and nitrogen flux in the throughfall if Aber forest, N. Wales, UK, was excluded from the regression analysis. An unusually high enrichment factor at the Aber site indicated that a the high rate of N cycling at the site was in excess of that predicted from current N deposition. This was attributed to the effect of ploughing and tree planting on the relatively N- and clay-rich mineral horizons at Aber compared with other sites. Highly significant relationships between enrichment factors and parameters describing internal rates of N cycling, such as litterfall N flux and nitrification rates in upper soil horizons, supported this conclusion. There appears to be a strong link between the rate of N cycling and the δ15N enrichment factor, rather than N deposition or nitrate leaching per se. These results confirm the potential use of the δ15N enrichment factor to identify sites influenced by nitrogen deposition. However, consideration should be taken of other site characteristics and land management practices which also influence soil N dynamics and N cycling.

bibl.et: Biogeochemical modelling of EXMAN research sites: a comparison.
bibl.ct: Special issue: The whole ecosystem experiments of the NITREX and EXMAN projects.
bibl.aa: Department of Chemical Engineering II, P.O. Box 124, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden.

ab.p: The EXMAN project was conducted to assess the effects caused by atmospheric deposition on forest ecosystems in Europe. The dynamic biogeochemical model, Soil Acidification in Forest Ecosystems (SAFE), was used to simulate the soil and soil solution chemistry at 4 EXMAN sites (Ballyhooly, Ireland; Höglwald and Solling, Germany; and Klosterhede, Denmark), all Norway spruce [Picea abies] plantations, from 1800 to 2000. The model considers soil processes (cation exchange, weathering, solution equilibria) and external forcing function (deposition, hydrology, nutrient uptake), and was successfully calibrated to all EXMAN sites. Base cation budgets were evaluated, and they demonstrate the importance of nutrient cycling for the element fluxes in the rooting zone. The stands at Ballyhooly and Höglwald have higher litterfall rates and lower canopy leaching rates than those at Klosterhede and Solling. SAFE suggests that the soils at Höglwald and Ballyhooly are still being depleted of base cations, while Klosterhede and Solling are close to a steady-state or show slight recovery. Comparison with soil solution data show that SAFE reproduces the pH in solution in the most soil layers. One exception was the O-layer in Höglwald, where underpredicted pH resulted from overestimation of nitrification. Base cation concentrations were well reproduced for all layers for all sites. SAFE predicts that base cation concentrations at all sites have reached a peak, and will decline. Calculated aluminium concentrations were within the range of the observations. The model shows that nutrient cycling dominates O-layer chemistry. N-uptake appears to follow the fine root biomass distribution. To reproduce base cation fluxes correctly, base cation uptake had to be allocated to lower soil layers. Al-solubility was similar for comparable sites. The effects of shortcomings in the SO2-4 chemistry of SAFE on model predictions were discussed. The model predicted the major effects of the 'clean rain' manipulation on soil solution at Solling - decreased Al and base cation concentrations and increased pH. The model application to the Klosterhede manipulation was difficult to evaluate due to the temporal variability in experimental data, caused by the marine influence.

bibl.et: Water and element fluxes calculated in a sandy forest soil taking spatial variability into account.
bibl.ct: Special issue: The whole ecosystem experiments of the NITREX and EXMAN projects.
bibl.aa: Environmental Science and Technology Department, RIS<O> National Laboratory/Danish Forest and Landscape Research Institute, POB 49, DK-4000 Roskilde, Denmark.

ab.p: Water and element fluxes in the unsaturated zone of soils are most often calculated on the basis of average water fluxes and average soil solution concentrations. However, if the input of water and elements exhibit a strong systematic variability, this will most likely be reflected in the flow of water and elements in the soil. In such cases the 'average' based calculations will be subject to significant errors. In order to overcome this problem, this paper describes a method to calculate the water and element fluxes in the soil of a Norway spruce (Picea abies) plantation taking into account the known stem-distance related variability in both water and element fluxes. The calculations are based on studies and previous findings of spatial variability in a Norway spruce plantation at Klosterhede, western Denmark (one of the NITREX and EXMAN project sites), and use the soil water and heat model, SOIL. This model includes a description of the hydrological and thermal properties of each soil layer, and a vegetation description; it is driven by meteorological variables. The suggested method leads to an improved Cl-balance when calculated for 6 yr (1989-94). The possible factors responsible for the errors in water and element fluxes are discussed and preferential flow paths, sampling under big trees, errors in modelling evapotranspiration and incorrect weighing between subareas are concluded to be the most important.

index.de: cycling\errors\evapotranspiration\forest plantations\forest soils\hydrology\mathematical models\movement\nutrients\sampling\sandy soils\soil chemistry\soil solution\soil water movement\spatial variation

bibl.et: Process-based forest productivity models and their application in forest management.
bibl.aa: Cooperative Research Centre for Temperate Hardwood Forestry and CSIRO Division of Forestry and Forest Products, G.P.O. Box 252-12, Hobart, Tasmania, 7001, Australia.

ab.p: Few process-based forest productivity models have become incorporated into forest management systems. The prevalent perception is that process-based models are suited only for research applications and that management questions will be solved only by using descriptive empirical models. This is despite the fact that the latter can neither deal satisfactorily with changing environmental and management conditions nor answer all questions currently asked by managers. This paper develops the proposition that the end-use specifies the design and scale of forest simulation models, and that given the range of questions now asked in forest management a range of models is required. The spatial and temporal resolution, and the input and output data required to address typical forest management questions are examined. A survey of recent literature examines in which areas, and by whom, existing forest productivity models are being applied. It is concluded that many current management questions can be adequately answered using models in which a phenomenological approach is applied to predict annual forest growth at the stand-scale. Lumped-parameter process-based models and hybrid models provide the most immediate means through which understanding of the biological processes underlying forest growth can be included in forest management systems. However, more detailed process-based models can play an important role in validating simpler models, in the development of generalizations applicable over long time scales and for testing hypotheses about the way trees function and respond to interacting stresses. Guidelines are also given on model structures appropriate for different classes of management questions.

index.de: decision making\forest management\forests\growth models\prediction\productivity\resolution\simulation models

bibl.et: Woody understory response to changes in overstory density: thinning in Allegheny hardwoods.
bibl.aa: SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry, Syracuse, NY 13210, USA.

ab.p: Understanding the effects of silvicultural treatments on understorey vegetation is important in predicting the consequences of such treatments, not only on regeneration but also on wildlife habitat, visual qualities, and recreation. An empirical model of understorey response that could be generalized to other forest types is developed in this paper. The data used were from understorey populations of tree species analysed for 15 yr following thinning to different residual relative densities in 50- to 55-yr-old Allegheny hardwoods in 2 even-aged stands in NW Pennsylvania (primary overstorey species Prunus serotina, Acer saccharum, Acer rubrum, Fagus grandifolia). The average number of stems 1 ft (0.3 m) tall to 1 in. (2.5 cm) dbh (diameter at breast height) increased for 3 to 5 yr after thinning and then levelled-off or decreased after 10 or 15 yr. The greatest density of understorey stems developed at low residual density. In stems 1 to 3 ft (0.3 to 0.9 m) tall, the densities of shade-tolerant species were unresponsive to thinning while the shade-intolerant species were most responsive. The shade-intolerant and shade-intermediate species increased in importance over time in the more heavily thinned treatments. In the 3 ft (0.9 m) tall to 1 in. (2.5 cm) dbh size class, shade-intolerant and shade-intermediate species were more responsive to thinning than tolerant species, but shade-tolerant species remained more important numerically throughout the study. Ingrowth to >1 in. diameter classes was greatest by shade-tolerant stems, increased over time, and was enhanced by thinning. Repeated measures analysis of variance was used to model the number of stems in these 3 size classes and 3 shade-tolerance classes as a function of residual relative density at thinning and time since treatment. These models explained 0.08-0.80 of the variation in stem numbers, depending on the size and tolerance class. These descriptions might be improved by reference to prior conditions of the regeneration or interfering herbaceous competition, but a model that required this information would not be capable of predicting responses to future treatments.

bibl.et: Characterization of the tree spatial distribution in small plots using the pair correlation function.
bibl.aa: Institute for Forest, Akademgorodok, Krasnoyarsk-36 660036, Russia.

ab.p: The method of pair correlation function has been modified to allow treatment of spatial distributions when the data are scattered over a number of separate sample plots. The method provides an opportunity to detect significant deviations from a random pattern, which is not possible for separate individual plots. Two sets of data were studied - (i) a Norway spruce (Picea abies) stand, and (ii) a mixed oak-beech (Quercus robur-Fagus sylvatica) forest - using field data from Saxony, Germany, from the data library on experimental forests at Dresden University. Larger spruces had a greater radius of spatial correlation than smaller spruces. The arrangement of these trees has a negative correlation, with a radius of ca. 2.2-2.4 m. In spite of a decrease of density over 30 yr, the radius remained practically the same. Mutual arrangements of oaks and beeches depended on the dimensions of the beeches. Larger beeches had a larger radius of spatial correlation with the oak stems.

ab.p: A collection of 24 papers presented at a IUFRO symposium in Hungary in 1996. The relationship between the State forest authority and private forest owners is described for various European countries, especially countries in Eastern Europe where forests have only recently been returned to private ownership. The countries covered are: Lithuania, Latvia, Austria, Switzerland, Slovakia, Germany, Italy, Czech Republic, and Hungary. The 3-page English summary describes ways in which State forest authorities can assist private forestry and build up a partnership with associations of forest owners.

bibl.et: Physiological basis of the light use efficiency model.
bibl.aa: University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW 2052, Australia.

ab.p: The observation that, for unstressed plants, light use efficiency of a plant canopy, defined as the ratio of net primary productivity (NPP) to absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (APAR), is approximately constant with respect to changes in APAR, implies that NPP can be modelled using a linear relationship with APAR. However, such a linear relationship is counter-intuitive because the relationship between leaf photosynthesis and absorbed light is strongly nonlinear. Three arguments have been advanced to explain the observed linear relationship between NPP and APAR. A detailed, physiologically based model of canopy radiation absorption and photosynthesis (MAESTRO) was used to analyse these arguments. This model was validated using data for Picea sitchensis and Pinus radiata. The first argument is that the canopy is structured so that radiation is distributed throughout the canopy such that most leaves are exposed to non-saturating quantum flux density, resulting in a linear response of canopy photosynthesis to APAR. Simulations of MAESTRO indicated that this explanation is inadequate, because daily values of canopy photosynthetic light use efficiency calculated with MAESTRO were highly variable regardless of canopy structure. The second argument is that variability in light use efficiency decreases with increasing time scale. The simulations showed that this is true to some extent, although simulated annual canopy photosynthetic light use efficiency still varies across sites with different LAI or light climate. The third argument is that changes in canopy nitrogen content act both to maximize net canopy photosynthesis and to keep light use efficiency constant. This argument could not be tested with the model, but the failure of the first two explanations suggests that this third explanation deserves closer attention.

index.de: canopy\forest trees\light\models\photosynthesis\simulation models\trees\use efficiency\woody plants

bibl.aa: Forest Protection Division, Tropical Forest Research Institute, Jabalpur (Madhya Pradesh), India.

ab.p: Simultaneous infection is reported of stored seeds of Albizia lebbeck and of the insect pest Bruchus bilineatopygus [Bruchidius bilineatopygus] infesting the seeds, by the seedborne pathogenic fungus Fusarium oxysporum.

bibl.et: Special issue: The whole ecosystem experiments of the NITREX and EXMAN projects.
bibl.ms: refs at ends of papers
bibl.aa: Norwegian Institute for Water Research (NIVA), PO Box 173 Kjelsås, N-0411 Oslo, Norway.

ab.p: Twenty-nine papers are included describing results from these 2 research networks of large-scale manipulation experiments carried out under the auspices of the EU Commission of European Communities: NITREX - NITRogen saturation EXperiments; and EXMAN - EXperimental MANipulation of Forest Ecosystems in Europe. The research was set up in the late 1980s to address concern in Europe over the adverse ecological effects of regional air pollution and acid deposition in relation to forest decline and the nutrient enrichment of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems. The first of the 29 papers (by the editors) is introductory, and gives a general outline of the experiments. The following 11 papers cover results over multiple sites from the NITREX (8) and EXMAN (3) projects. The next 15 papers present results from individual sites in both projects. The last 2 papers discuss the limitations of manipulations involving large roof experiments (which have been used in both projects), and the value of the 2 projects and associated modelling exercises in providing information on the ecological effects of air pollution/acid deposition on forests, and evidence for environmental policymaking.

bibl.et: Crown condition and increment.
bibl.ft: Kronenzustand und Zuwachs.

ab.p: Increment and crown diameter data of >4000 spruce [Picea] trees in Austria were used to select suitable parameters for providing a reliable indication for the condition of forests. Increment decreased with increasing defoliation, especially after needle losses of >25%. Basal area increment and basal area increment related to crown diameter were clearly related with increment losses.

bibl.et: Insects inhabiting cones of Norway spruce Picea abies (L.) Karst. in selected stands of the Beskid Śla&hook;ski Mts.
bibl.ft: Owady zasiedlaja&hook;ce szyszki świerka pospolitego Picea abies (L.) Karst. w wybranych drzewostanach Beskidu Śla&hook;skiego.
bibl.aa: Katedra Entomologii Lesn´ej, Akademia Rolnicza, Kraków, Poland.

ab.p: Field and laboratory investigation of insects in cones of Picea abies were conducted in the selected stands in the Beskid Śla&hook;ski Mts. (southern Poland) in 1994-95. Some 320 cones were collected from 16 spruces growing in the Bielsko-Bia&lstroke;a Forest District (Katowice Forest Region). Out of these 80 cones and 4800 seeds were analysed by cutting. The remaining cones were used for individual and mass rearing of insects. As a result of these investigations 295 insect specimens representing 8 species, and belonging to 5 orders (Heteroptera, Coleoptera, Hymenoptera - 2 parasitoids, Lepidoptera and Diptera) were obtained. Gastrodes abietum was the most numerous species (138 specimens). Other species were Ernobius abietis, Cydia strobilella, and Kaltenbachiola strobi, with 82, 29 and 18 specimens, respectively. The index of cone infestation of cones varied from 0.009 (for Eurytoma sp) to 0.431 (for Gastrodes abietum). A serious loss of seeds was caused by C. strobilella, reaching 33.21% of all seeds analysed. Damage to seeds caused by Megastigmus strobilobius was negligible, amounting to 0.02%. During the study a parasitoid of C. strobilella (Liotryphon strobilellae) was reared. Its percentage in relation to the number of individuals of its host amounted to 35.5%. Other parasitoids were encountered were Torymus azureus from K. strobi and Eurytoma sp., and a possible parasitoid of Ernobius abietis.

bibl.et: The use of technical methods of forest protection against game animals.
bibl.ft: Granice stosowania technicznych metod ochrony lasu przed zwierzyna&hook;.

ab.p: Methods of forest protection against game animals used in Poland between from 1956 onwards are described, with details of areas treated and repellents and coverings [tree guards] used. For the years 1994 and 1995 details are given for different regions. For protection against increased pressure by deer on forest regeneration there is an increasing use of repellents year by year, as well the use of various tree protective covers. In 1995, out of about 390&thin;000 ha of forest plantations and thickets exposed to damage, plantings were protected over an area of 155&thin;000 ha, using about 2184 t of repellents and several hundred thousand plastic covers.

bibl.et: Natural insecticides from the neem tree (Azadirachta indica A. Juss) in forest protection.

bibl.aa: Zak&lstroke;ad Ochrony Lasu (Pracowania Odporności), Instytut Badawczy Leśnictwa, Warsaw, Poland.

ab.p: Based on the literature (and in some cases on experimental tests), the activities of insecticidal preparations from the neem tree against the more important forest pest insects are reviewed. The insecticides proved to be relatively safe for the environment and may be useful against forest pest insects from the orders Lepidoptera, Hymenoptera, Coleoptera and others.

bibl.et: Benefits conferred by "timid" ants: active anti-herbivore protection of the rainforest tree Leonardoxa africana by the minute ant Petalomyrmex phylax.
bibl.aa: Institut des Sciences de l'Evolution, Université Montpellier II, Place Eugène Bataillon, 34095 Montpellier, France.

ab.p: A study conducted on a L. africana population in rainforest in S. Cameroon estimated that in the absence of the small host-specific ant Petalomyrmex phylax, insect herbivory would reduce the leaf area by about one-third. The ants therefore contribute considerably to the fitness of the plant. The estimates take into account not only direct damage, such as removal of leaf surface by chewing insects, but also the effects of sucking insects on leaf growth and expansion. Sucking insects are numerically predominant in this system, and the hitherto cryptic effects of ant protection against the growth-reducing effects of sucking insects accounted for half of the total estimated benefit of ant protection. It is proposed that the small size of workers confers a distinct advantage in this system. Assuming that resource limitation implies a trade off between size and number of ants, and given the small size of phytophagous insects that attack Leonardoxa, it is concluded that fine-grained patrolling by a large number of small workers maximises protection of young leaves of this plant. Since herbivores are small and must complete their development on the young leaves of Leonardoxa, and since a high patrolling density is required for a fine-grained search for these enemies, numerous small ants should provide the most effective protection of young leaves of Leonardoxa. Other factors that may have influenced worker size in this ant are also discussed.

bibl.et: The damage situation affecting Douglas-fir in the North Rhine-Westphalian Eifel.
bibl.ft: Die Schadsituation an Douglasie in der nordrhein-westfälischen Eifel.
bibl.ct: Stand der Ursachenforschung zu Douglasienschäden - derzeitige Empfehlungen für die Praxis. Tagungsbericht zum Douglasien-Kolloquium am 15.-16. April 1997 in Adenau (Eifel), Germany [Herausgeber: Maurer, W.; Tabel, U.].
bibl.aa: Forstamt Bad Münstereifel, Untere Forstbehörde Rheinland, 53902 Bad Münstereifel, Germany.

ab.p: According to a recent inventory, 1370 ha of Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) are present in forests of the North Rhine-Westphalian part of the Eifel mountain range, Germany. This is 1.5% of the total forested area and most stands are relatively young (up to 60 years old). A little more than 10% of these stands contained more than one third of individuals with sparse foliage and frequent efflux of resin, and were classified damaged. In the rain lee-sided areas of the Eifel, 25% of stands were damaged. Within those stands, a differentiation in damaged and healthy individuals was obvious which could not be explained by site differences. Diseased trees or stands could become healthier over the years. Genetic variation within seeds may play an important role.

bibl.et: Experimental investigations on the light climate in virgin forest plots in North Borneo.
bibl.ft: Experimentelle Untersuchungen des Lichtklimas in Urwaldparzellen Nordborneos.
bibl.pb: Institut für Pflanzenbau & Tierhygiene in den Tropen & Sub Tropen
bibl.aa: Botanical Institute, University of Kiel, 24098 Kiel, Germany.

ab.p: A study was made of the 3-dimensional distribution of the light on 8 plots in four different successional stages of lowland dipterocarp rainforest in Deramakot Forest Reserve, Sabah: undisturbed primary forest (Parashorea tomentella/Eusideroxylon zwageri type); secondary forest 20 years after a selective felling in primary forest; pioneer stand 35 m high with Macaranga hypoleuca and Anthocephalus chinensis; and clearings (gaps) 250 m² in size formed by the death of one large tree or 450 m² formed by felling. The light climate (PPFD, in µmol m²/s) was measured by sensors with the aid of specially constructed cableways, along a strip 12-20 m long at three different heights in the stands. The results are presented and discussed in detail, showing the great importance of the light climate for stand structure and succession. Appendices give comprehensive floristic and biometric survey data for all the study plots.

bibl.et: Geographic variation in susceptibility of Alberta lodgepole pine to western gall rust.
bibl.aa: Department of Renewable Resources, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB T6G 2H1, Canada.

ab.p: Seedlings from 291 open-pollinated families of lodgepole pine (Pinus contorta var. latifolia) from three breeding regions (B1, B2, and C) in west-central Alberta were evaluated in the greenhouse during 1992-94 for their response to infection by western gall rust (WGR) (Endocronartium harknessii). Region C is a foothill outlier whereas the two western regions are under strong cordilleran influence in the Rocky Mountains. Significant variation in WGR resistance was found among and within regions. A general east-west trend was observed, with western and high-elevational families being more susceptible to WGR infection. Regression of WGR resistance on geographic origins of families accounted for up to 25% of the among-family variation. However, the among-family variation in region C could not be predicted by any geographic variables. Canonical discriminant analysis of WGR resistance and geographic variables could discern families in region C from those in regions B1 and B2. While the widespread introgression from jack pine (P. banksiana) could contribute to WGR resistance in lodgepole pine, the observed geographic variation could also be a selection gradient induced by regional patterns of geoclimatic conditions for WGR development.

bibl.et: Ignition probability of organic soils.
bibl.aa: Intermountain Fire Sciences Laboratory, Intermountain Research Station, P.O. Box 8089, Missoula, MT 59807, USA.

ab.p: Evaluating the effects of prescribed fire and wildland fire requires a greater understanding of the fire behaviour of organic soils. Determining the ignition limit of organic soils over a wide geographical area of northern and southeastern USA is the subject of this study. Side ignitions were attempted with an electrically powered red-hot coil to simulate common ignition by lateral smouldering. Inorganic content was fixed by the sample's origin. Moisture content was altered to establish a moisture range that included the ignition limit. Recorded successes and failures of attempted ignitions were analysed through logistic regression to give ignition probability based on the moisture and inorganic content and the organic bulk density. These probabilistic results lend themselves to lightning and person-caused fire occurrence predictive systems required for wildfire management. A limited comparison of results with an earlier study in which peat moss ignition was tested shows encouraging similarities.

bibl.et: Shrub growth and demography in arid Karoo, South Africa: inference from wood rings.
bibl.aa: FitzPatrick Institute, University of Cape Town, Rondebosch 7700, South Africa.

ab.p: Wood samples of a range of sizes were collected from the poisonous shrub Pteronia pallens in April 1994, and shrub growth (shoot extension and flowering) monitored between January 1988 and December 1993 at the Tierberg Karoo Research Centre, South Africa. Basal diameters were measured in 1988, 1990 and 1991. It was inferred that P. pallens produces annual growth rings the width of which was influenced by water availability, and that an individual shrub can live up to 150 years. There were no obvious correlations between recruitment frequencies and periods of above average rainfall. It is suggested that the reduction in competition after drought, or grazing, may account for the timings of P. pallens recruitment periods.

bibl.et: The potential for improving Western Hemlock pulp, paper and structural wood quality.
bibl.ct: Timber management toward wood quality and end-product value. Proceedings of the CTIA/IUFRO International Wood Quality Workshop, Quebec City, Canada, August 18-22, 1997.
bibl.aa: British Columbia Forest Service, Research Branch, 31 Bastion Sq, Victoria B.C., Canada.

ab.p: An earlier paper looked at the effectiveness of genetic selection of western hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla) to improve traits of growth (height and diameter), fibre properties (length and coarseness) and wood density using open-pollinated families. Reported here are a group of selections that were made from the first study and the methodology used to investigate how selection fro these traits can affect both paper quality and structural wood strength.

bibl.do: Tropical Forestry Reports - Department of Forest Ecology, University of Helsinki
bibl.et: Socioeconomic evaluation of land-use alternatives in the Blue Nile flood basin of the Sudan.
bibl.pb: Department of Forest Ecology, University of Helsinki
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Economics, University of Helsinki, PO Box 28, FIN-00014 Helsinki, Finland.

ab.p: Optimal land-use in the gerf land of the Blue Nile flood basin of the Sudan is discussed from the social welfare point of view. The alternative land use options considered were Acacia nilotica plantations, eucalyptus plantations and bananas. The study focused on estimating a macroeconomic model, derivation of shadow prices for goods, services and factors of production with emphasis on empirical estimation of the labour shadow price, estimation of the economic value of alternative land uses, and of the social value through derivation of interpersonal and inter-temporal income distribution weights. Financial analysis was also undertaken. The evaluation technique adopted was cost-benefit analysis using the Little-Mirrlees-Squire-van der Tak (LMST) approach. The results indicate that eucalyptus plantations are the optimum land-use option on the basis of growth maximization (economic analysis) as well as maximization of growth with equity as a constraint (social analysis). The A. nilotica option came second to eucalyptus, while bananas performed poorly with negative contribution in most cases. The financial analysis which used distorted market prices revealed that all three land-use alternatives were profitable, with eucalyptus being the most profitable and A. nilotica the least. Compared to the financial profitability, the economic profitability of the two forest options was considerably higher, while the profitability of the banana option was lowest. Contrary to conclusions commonly derived from similar studies in developing countries, the investigation of the unskilled labour markets in the study area indicated that the opportunity cost of this labour was considerably higher than the average market wage rate. The implications of the results for policymaking and policy design were discussed.

bibl.et: The role of ectomycorrhizae in the nitrogen nutrition of forest trees.
bibl.ft: Le rôle des ectomycorhizes dans la nutrition azotée des arbres forestiers. (Résumé).
bibl.ct: Champignons et mycorhizes en forêt.
bibl.aa: Laboratoire de Recherches sur les Symbiotes des Racines (UR 375), INRA-ENSA, 1 Place Viala, F-34060 Montpellier Cedex, France.

ab.p: Low nitrogen (N) availability appears to limit the primary production of temperate and boreal forests over much of Eurasia and North America. As a consequence, trees have developed mycorrhizal associations alongside a wide range of alternative trophic adaptations (e.g. N2-fixing symbioses) when competing for limited resources of specific nutrients. Ectomycorrhizas are major nutrient absorbing organs, and it is important to establish the mechanisms and processes whereby N is mobilized, assimilated and transported within the symbiotic tissues and the associated host plant. A short overview is given of such processes in ectomycorrhizal systems, including a brief description of the enzymes that catalyse the sequential steps of the pathways of primary N assimilation, the N pathways operating in a variety of ectomycorrhizal associations, and a discussion of the current understanding of the organization of N-assimilating enzymes in the symbionts and their interaction with carbon metabolism. The mechanisms controlling the transport of N between symbionts are also discussed.

bibl.et: Site classification of poplar plantations.
bibl.ft: Typologie des stations dans les peupleraies cultivées.
bibl.aa: AFOCEL, Région Nord-Est, Route de Bonnencontre, F-21170 Charrey-sur-Saône, France.

ab.p: This study investigated the contribution of site typology to a better understanding of the environment in the surroundings of a 150-ha poplar (Populus sp.) plantation in Indre-et-Loire, western France. After a brief description of the region and the methodology used, details of the vegetation typology are outlined. Vegetation is shown to reflect site conditions even in environments such as cultivated poplar stands. The methods of phytoecology, therefore, are shown to be applicable, with adjustments, to the 'artificial' environment of a forest plantation.

bibl.et: The brown bear of the Carpathians in Romania.
bibl.ft: L'ours des Carpates en Roumanie.
bibl.aa: Régie Nationale des Forêts, Maramures, Romania.

ab.p: Romania has a large natural population of brown bears [Ursus arctos] inhabiting the favourable ecological conditions of the Carpathian mountains (an area of more than 3 million hectares), which recently has been increasing. This has prompted attempts by foresters to establish optimal bear population levels, and develop forest management techniques which are designed to enrich the natural environment and so increase optimal bear densities. As a result, bear management focuses on the removal of high quality animals using hunting techniques that require hunters to be highly skilled, but who are rewarded by worthwhile trophies.

bibl.et: How to read the results of Resistograph M.
bibl.aa: Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Institute for Material Research II, PO Box 3640, D-76021 Karlsruhe, Germany.

ab.p: Two impact devices for the detection of the internal decay of suspected hazardous trees - the Resistograph M300 and the Resistograph M500, which provide a drilling profile printout for use in trees and construction timber to a maximum depth of 500 mm are described. Twenty figures demonstrate the results provided by the Resistograph in the detection of decay, wet wood cracks and tension wood.

bibl.et: Defining indicators and standards for recreation impacts in Nuyts Wilderness, Walpole-Nornalup National Park, Western Australia.
bibl.aa: Correspondence address: Major Project Review Unit, Habitat and Enhancement Branch, Department of Fisheries and Oceans, Stn 327, 555 West Hastings Street, Vancouver, BC V6B 5GB, Canada.

ab.p: A central issue in wilderness management is not the number of users per se, but the impacts those users can have on environmental conditions and the quality of experience of other visitors. This study draws on two recreation planning frameworks, the limits of acceptable change and visitor impact management, to translate management goals into quantitative management objectives through indicators and standards. Potential indicators and standards were identified, via a mailback survey conducted in 1995, for Nuyts Wilderness Area on the south coast of Western Australia. Environmental conditions of greatest influence on the quality of visitor experience were amount of litter, inadequate disposal of human waste, presence of wildlife, walk trail erosion, vegetation loss and tree damage. Standards were determined for two biophysical indicators (tree damage and vegetation loss) and four social indicators (number and size of groups, litter and human-made structures such as signs). Respondents had the lowest level of tolerance and set the highest standards for litter and damage to trees. Tolerance levels for social effects such as the number of other groups seen were higher. Standards were similar across sites for all indicators except vegetation loss where respondents were more willing to accept change at the campsite than elsewhere. These results suggest that management efforts can be differentially directed toward indicators of greatest concern, such as litter and tree damage. The study findings also suggest that managing to meet the expectations of 50% of visitors regarding acceptable and unacceptable impacts is feasible, especially where impacts do not currently exceed acceptable levels, whereas striving to meet the expectations of 75% of visitors requires reducing impacts by at least half. Such reductions may be impossible and create unrealistic expectations among visitors and managers alike.

index.de: camping\damage\environmental impact\erosion\forest recreation\forest trees\forests\indicators\injuries\national parks\recreation\standards\trails\trees\vegetation\wilderness\woody plants

bibl.et: Holocene tree limit history in the northern French Alps stomata and pollen evidence.
bibl.aa: Lab. Botanique Historique et Palynologie, IMEP, CNRS URA 1152, case 451, Faculté Saint Jérôme, F-13397 Marseille, Cedex 20, France.

ab.p: Certain aspects of the Holocene tree limit history in the northern French Alps are inferred from both pollen and stomata analysis conducted in a subalpine marsh (2080 m asl). The proposed chronology is based on 14C AMS dating of terrestrial plant macrofossils. In the area, Betula invaded this altitudinal level at the beginning of the Holocene prior to 9100 yr B.P., whereas the first occurrence of Pinus stomata is recorded much later at around 7000 yr B.P. Afterwards five periods of stomata accumulation are recorded (6480-6130, 5600-4990, 4730-4470, 3200-2870 and 2680-2300 yr B.P.). The low pollen influx in the first four periods and the occurrences of Artemisia at the beginning of these periods indicate that stomata accumulation resulted from a reduction of the tree cover. The climatic and/or anthropogenic origin of these stomata accumulations is discussed. A good correlation appeared with five of the nine phases of Holocene climatic deterioration described in the Swiss and Austrian Alps. In this study, the combination of pollen influx and stomata determination proved to be a useful tool for understanding the tree limit history. Discrepancies in the occurrence of Pinus in an adjacent area imply it is difficult to find universal indicators of tree line fluctuations even in a small area.

index.de: alpine vegetation\history\palaeoclimatology\palaeoecology\palynology\pines\pollen\stomata\treelines

bibl.et: Residual stand damage following cut-to-length harvesting operations with a farm tractor in two conifer stands.
bibl.aa: Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, Department of Operational Efficiency, S-901 83 Umeå, Sweden.

ab.p: Residual stand damage during harvesting operations was recorded and the influence evaluated of factors such as distance of the tree from the strip road, machine parts, operational phase, on the occurrence of tree wounds. The logging machine used was a farm tractor equipped with a crane mounted on the front axle and a single grip harvester head. The study was carried out in 2 stands located in SE Sweden. Stand 1 was a 30-yr-old Norway spruce (Picea abies) plantation on an afforested pasture while stand 2 was a 90-yr-old mixed stand of Norway spruce, Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris), birch (Betula pendula) and aspen (Populus tremula). The mean damage was 6.3% for the first stand and 6.5% for the second. Some 65% of the wounds were less than 50 cm² in area, with 91% of the damage occurring on the stem and 9% on or below the root collar; 66% of the wounds produced by the stem under processing or by the harvesting head, while only 10% of the wounds were produced by the tractor wheel. Damaged trees were distributed evenly in the crane reach zone. Significant differences were found between rut depths after 1, 2, 4 and 6 passes of the tractor in stand 1.

bibl.et: Implications of dioecy for sustainable forest management.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Science, Lincoln University, PO Box 84, Lincoln, Canterbury, New Zealand.

ab.p: The dense podocarp forests of New Zealand, and in South Westland in particular, are unusual in that they are dominated by dioecious trees. Females and males of dioecious species perform different reproductive functions and consequently may use resources in different ways. This differential resource use can result in females and males differing in growth rate, age at maturity, and lifespan, which in turn can result in differences between the sexes in size distribution, age distribution and number within a population. Differences in growth rate and size in particular could result in one sex being harvested at a greater rate than the other, altering the natural sex ratio - an outcome that may have important implications for the long-term sustainability of managed dioecious forests. Differences between the sexes are reviewed for the 2 species studied in New Zealand (kahikatea, Dacrycarpus dacryoides and rimu, Dacrydium cupressinum) and additional data on rimu sex are presented from differently-aged landforms in Saltwater Forest, South Westland. Female dominated, male dominated, and 1:1 ratios of the sexes have all been found, and in some instances differences in growth rate reported. The implications of dioecy and differences in growth and mortality between the sexes are discussed, and areas of research required for sustainable forest management are suggested.

The theoretical framework and the empirical findings presented are largely based on two research projects conducted at the European Forest Institute in 1994, the results of which have been published in various papers by Hellström & Palo in 1994 and 1995 (from the first project, in which the roles of public and private forest sector research in Europe were charted), and by Hellström in 1995 (from the second project, in which case studies on the effects of changing funding patterns and policies on research activities were conducted in Finland and Norway as an initiative for further comparative studies in Europe).

bibl.et: Non-destructive determination of lignin syringyl/guaiacyl monomeric composition in native wood by fourier transform Raman spectroscopy.
bibl.aa: Kameyama Research Center, Forestry Research Institute, Oji Paper, 24-9 Nobono-cho, Kameyama 519-02, Japan.

ab.p: The feasibility of using FT-Raman spectroscopy for rapid non-destructive determination of lignin syringyl/guaiacyl (S/G) monomeric composition was examined using Eucalyptus camaldulensis and E. globulus, including samples of various ages and colours, which are of importance as a plantation source of pulpwood in Japan. The application of 2nd derivatives transformation of Raman spectroscopic data revealed highly significant correlations between wet chemical and Raman predicted values with correlation coefficient (r) = 0.998 and standard error of prediction (SEP) < 0.07 points in the calibration (for known samples), and r = 0.935 and SEP < 0.32 points in the prediction (for unknown samples), respectively. Consequently, this non-destructive method has proved its validity for analysing Eucalyptus native wood meal samples, regardless of their age and colour to determine lignin S/G monomeric composition. Using FT-Raman spectroscopy, elite tree selection based on quality aspects for pulp and paper production can be performed.

bibl.et: Urban forestry: UK experience in practice.
bibl.ms: Paper presented at the 31st National Arboriculture Conference, Exeter, UK, 8-10 September 1997
bibl.aa: Milton Keynes Parks Trust Ltd, Campbell Park Pavilion, 1300 Silbury Boulevard, Campbell Park, Milton Keynes, MK9 4AD, UK.

ab.p: The definition of urban forestry is discussed in relation to its environmental and sociological requirements, and the siting of UK urban forests. The author argues that, despite such initiatives as the national and community forests, determination of appropriate sites is hampered by contemporary mind sets concerning (1) the supposed shortage of development land in rural areas, and (2) fear of infrastructure projects. It is argued that infrastructure projects provide very effective vehicles for the introduction of urban forestry, and the example of Milton Keynes is given as an illustration. Future challenges are outlined, and the possibility of establishing new urban forested settlements on the clay belts running from Swindon to Cambridge is then suggested as a way in which the housing, transportation and recreational needs of future generations could be met.

bibl.do: Technical Report - Forest Engineering Research Institute of Canada (FERIC)
bibl.et: Partial cutting in mountainous old-growth forests in coastal British Columbia: Harvesting productivity and cost, and residual stand impacts.
bibl.pb: Forest Engineering Research Institute of Canada (FERIC)
bibl.aa: FERIC Western Division, 2601 East Mall, Vancouver, BC, V6T 1Z4, Canada.

ab.p: The Forest Engineering Research Institute of Canada (FERIC) and International Forest Products Limited (Interfor) developed and implemented a partial cutting trial at Chamiss Bay on the west coast of Vancouver Island. The study was conducted to investigate the harvesting feasibility of partial cutting in old-growth stands on steep slopes. The study sites were located within the Very Wet Maritime subzone (Submontane variant) of the Coastal Western Hemlock [Tsuga heterophylla] biogeoclimatic zone (CWHvm1). Harvesting, using manual falling and cable-yarding systems, was done in the summers of 1995 and 1996. Two partial cuts (referred to as retention units), two strip cuts, and one clearcut were included in the harvesting study. The retention units had high levels of tree retention, 65 and 70% by basal area, with uniform dispersal of the retained trees. Harvesting productivities and costs were derived from shift-level production reports. Post-harvest surveys were conducted to quantify residual stand damage and soil-disturbance levels in the retention units. In the 65% retention unit, falling productivity was 31% lower and falling cost was 45% higher than in the clearcut. However, falling productivity was reduced by only 2% in the 70% retention unit, compared to the clearcut, mainly because of a marked difference in timber type between this unit and the clearcut. Cable-yarding productivity, measured in volume of logs per productive machine hour, was 34 and 30% lower in the 65 and 70% retention units, respectively, than in the clearcut. Yarding costs, based on scheduled machine hours, were 46 and 32% higher in these same units. These are the relative differences in yarding productivity and cost for the Chamiss Bay trial where a clearcut in similar steep terrain, with no landings, was used for comparison. Post-harvest surveys showed that 34 and 37% of the residual stems had at least one scar of any size, and 12 and 10% of the residual stems had at least one scar that was ≥900 cm², in the 65 and 70% retention units, respectively. Exposed mineral soil was observed on only 1.4 and 1.5% of the soil surface area in the 65 and 70% retention units, respectively. The productivity and cost results for the retention units provide important new information to help forest operators plan, budget, and implement future partial-cutting trials and operations. The trial showed the potential to harvest timber on sensitive sites, with conventional equipment and crews, thus creating an opportunity to augment timber supplies.

bibl.et: Effect of cowdung and chemical fertilizers on the growth of Acacia mangium seedlings.
bibl.aa: Bangladesh Forest Research Institute, P. O. Box 273, Chittagong-4000, Bangladesh.

ab.p: Growth response of Acacia mangium seedlings to cowdung and NPK fertilizer was studied at Bangladesh Forest Research Institute, Chittagong. Either individually or combined, the fertilizers caused significant increases in seedling height and biomass production. The best growth was obtained with cowdung without NPK fertilizer at a soil/cowdung ratio of 3:1; ratios of 4:1 and 5:1 were less effective in increasing growth. NPK fertilizer alone (tested at concentrations of N20P20, N20K20, N60P60, N60K60, N20P20K20 and N60P60K60, in ppm) showed less effect on the growth of the seedlings, although NP combinations increased growth better than NK or NPK. However, soil/cowdung at 5:1 + N60P60 promoted only slightly less growth than soil/cowdung at 3:1, with the next best treatment being soil/cowdung at 4:1 + N20P20.

bibl.et: Biogeography and forest biodiversity in New Zealand.
bibl.aa: Centre for Conservation Biology, School of Environmental and Marine Sciences, University of Auckland, New Zealand.

ab.p: The first part of the paper discusses the concept of plant biodiversity in relation to its scale dependence: biogeography is mainly concerned with the larger scale patterns (the origins of the New Zealand flora and its regional biodiversity patterns - gamma-diversity, in which geological and climatic history are important); altitudinal gradients illustrate variation at the landscape level - beta-diversity; and alpha-diversity is diversity at the community scale (in which disturbance may play a key role). The geographical and altitudinal patterns of biodiversity in New Zealand are outlined and some comments made on the implications of this for reserve network planning. A brief case study comparing biodiversity in kauri (Agathis australis) and beech (Nothofagus solanderi) forests is given, and biodiversity and sustainability are discussed in relation to operational plantation forestry (mainly of Pinus radiata). The last part of the paper addresses ongoing conservation activities including the protection of endangered species and particular areas, the creation and management of nature reserves.

bibl.et: January issue: South East Asia and Baltic special.
bibl.ms: refs
bibl.aa: Fire Ecology Research Group, c/o Freiburg University, PO Box, D-79085 Freiburg, Germany.

ab.p: The bulk of this issue is made up of collections of articles on the forest fire situation in South East Asia (pp. 4-56) and the Baltic countries (pp. 57-81). These are 2 contrasting areas, in the first of which there is too much fire and smoke, and in the second of which where nature conservationists and land managers are beginning to consider restoring fire in order to protect the cultivated landscape. The South East Asia section concentrates mainly on the 1997 Indonesian forest fires, starting with a report from the Indonesian Environmental Impact Monitoring Agency describing the land and forest fires, reviewing control measures, and evaluating national coordination efforts in combating the fires. Most of the fires are designated as caused by man (during both traditional and commercial forestry broadcast burning activities) and are, therefore, manageable and preventable; in 1997 they were exacerbated by the delayed onset of the monsoon. Recommendations are made for immediate and long-term activities. The rest of the articles on the 1997 Indonesian fires in the SE Asian section cover the UN assessment of the fires (including discussion of the role of the UN, international assistance to Indonesia, and environmental and tourism impacts), remote sensing of smoke and fire, Indonesian and regional initiatives in fire and smoke management and policy development, the 1997 wildfire season and the impact of fire management projects in Indonesia (Kalimantan and Sumatra), and reports from a special session of the Consultative Group on Indonesian Forests on the 1997 fires and from an international workshop on national guidelines on the protection of forests against fire held in Bogor. The remaining 2 articles in the SE Asian section are from Malaysia (an overview) and the Philippines (fire protection in Mountain Province). The Baltic section starts with an overview of the whole region (including a history of European regional smog from peat swamp burning in Germany), and contains overview articles from Estonia, Finland, Germany, Norway, Russia, Sweden and the UK. The remainder of the issue contains the usual country notes (from Canada, Spain, Switzerland and the USA), news and reports.

bibl.et: Importance of drainage ditches in emissions of methane from mires drained for forestry.
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Ecology, P.O. Box 24, FIN-00014, University of Helsinki, Finland.

ab.p: Methane (CH4) fluxes from drainage ditches and adjoining strips between the ditches were measured in autumn 1995 at a drained forested (Pinus sylvestris) mire in Finland. The fluxes were measured at different mire sites using static chambers (diffusion and plant-mediated transport) and inverted funnels (ebullition). The emissions (chamber measurements) of CH4 from drainage ditch bottoms, ditch sides, and strips between ditches ranged from 0 to 595, from 0 to 78 and from 0 to 33 mg/m² per day, respectively. The ebullition of CH4 from ditches was rather small, ranging from 3 to 37 mg/m² per day, which was less than 10% of the CH4 flux measured by the chambers. As the proportion of ditches of the total peatland area is rather small, the inclusion of methane fluxes from ditches would not considerably change the previous estimates of the effect of drainage on the greenhouse gas balance of Finnish peatlands.

bibl.et: Dendroecology and successional status of two contrasting old-growth oak forests in the Blue Ridge Mountains, USA.
bibl.aa: The Pennsylvania State University, School of Forest Resources, 4 Ferguson Building, University Park, PA 16802, USA.

ab.p: Dendroecological techniques were used to investigate the dynamics and successional development spanning three centuries of two virgin, old-growth forests dominated by Quercus rubra (mesic site) and Quercus prinus (xeric site) on the Blue Ridge Mountains of west-central Virginia. In the Q. rubra stand, a large increase in recruitment of this species between 1820 and 1850 was associated with a sharp increase followed by a larger decrease in the master tree ring chronology. The decrease in growth between 1837 and 1844 coincided with a predicted southward displacement of the summertime position of the polar front from eastern Canada. There was a virtual cessation of tree recruitment between 1850 and 1910, suggesting that the Q. rubra stand went through a "midlife" stem exclusion stage. However, another period of peak recruitment between 1920 and 1940 coincided with chestnut blight (Endothia parasitica [Cryphonectria parasitica]) and extreme drought in the region. Oak recruitment in the Q. prinus stand was fairly continuous and exhibited peaks from 1710 to 1730 and in the 1940s that were associated with releases in radial growth. An increase in Q. rubra in this stand occurred between 1860 and 1950. There was also a trend of increasing growth in the oldest Q. prinus trees from 1860 to the present, particularly between 1930 and 1960. The xeric Q. prinus stand had only a small component of potential oak replacement species and appears to represent an edaphic climax for this genus. The large increase of mixed-mesophytic species during the 1900s in the Q. rubra stand indicates its transitional nature in the absence of periodic fire.

bibl.et: Modeling temporal variability of boreal landscape age-classes under different fire disturbance regimes and spatial scales.
bibl.aa: Integra Research Inc., 5 Reed Drive, Ajax, ON L1S 5S4, Canada.

ab.p: Natural fire disturbances are known to have had a significant role in boreal forests at the stand and landscape levels. Van Wagner's exponential model gave useful insight into the theoretical dynamics of the forest age distribution in fire-disturbed landscapes. His work motivated extensions to the theoretical model and more empirical tests in a variety of landscapes. The empirical tests have had mixed results. While Van Wagner stated that the model is theoretical, and warned that one should expect to find variability in landscapes in any case, there is the risk that the exponential model can be misunderstood or inappropriately applied if variability is not adequately considered. An existing theoretical simulation model of landscape fire disturbance (FLAP-X) was used to explore the temporal variability of two selected landscape attributes: the percentages of old growth and recently disturbed area. It was found that under characteristic boreal fire disturbance regimes, these percentages can vary widely over time even at large spatial scales due to the spatiotemporal autocorrelation of disturbances. Some of the consequent implications of managing a landscape for naturalness at multiple spatial scales when there is a wide range of conditions that can be considered natural are discussed.

bibl.et: Fitting seven taper functions to stem profiles of Pinus hartwegii Lindl. trees of north-eastern Mexico.
bibl.ft: Ajuste de siete modelos de ahusamiento a los perfiles fustales de Pinus hartwegii Lindl. del nordeste de México.
bibl.aa: Facultad de Ciencias Forestales, Universidad Autónoma de Nuevo León, Carr. Nacional Km 145, 67700 Linares, NL, Mexico.

ab.p: A study was carried out to evaluate the goodness of fit of seven taper functions to 109 stem profiles of Pinus hartwegii trees in NE Mexico. Trees were cut during forest management operations and diameter of several stem sections was measured. In total, 1613 observations of diameter and height were used to fit the Clutter, Biging, Amidon, Rustagi & Loveless, Kozak1, Kozak2 and the Variable-Form of Newnham taper functions by least squares techniques in linear and non-linear regression analyses. The taper functions were fitted to stem profiles of 20 additional trees (307 observations) of the same species. To test the goodness of fit, estimators of the coefficient of determination and the standard error, as well as bias in diameter and volumes were estimated. The results showed that the Variable-Form taper function described best the stem profiles and volumes of the 20 test trees. Therefore, this taper function is recommended to estimate any of the described parameters.

bibl.et: Relationship between decayed roots and aboveground decay in three conifers in Ontario.
bibl.aa: Forest Pathology Consultant, 47 Cumberland Drive N.W., Calgary, AB T2K 1S8, Canada.

ab.p: A study was conducted to relate aboveground decay and stain to that occurring in the roots and lower stump of 501 white spruce (Picea glauca), 1343 black spruce (Picea mariana), and 1383 balsam fir (Abies balsamea) ranging in age from 27 to 208 years old, from 165 stands in northern Ontario. Decay and stain caused by Inonotus tomentosus, Scytinostroma galactinum, Coniophora puteana, and all fungi combined, estimated at ground level (0 cm height) and at 30 cm height in white spruce and black spruce, were highly correlated with decay and stain in the roots and belowground portion of the stump in living trees (r²=0.45-0.79). The coefficients of determination were smaller with these fungi in balsam fir and with Armillaria ostoyae in all three conifers (r²=0.10-0.45). Equations are presented for estimating root decay and stain by the above fungi and all fungi together, in the major roots and lower stump, in each of white spruce, black spruce, and balsam fir. In applying the equations, the independent variables of decay and stain estimated at stump height (15 cm), and tree age, measured at 15 cm, are from a 10-tree sample of each species that provides the level of root decay and stain in the stand for that tree species. Soil texture, soil moisture regime, and the percentage of potential crop trees standing dead or windfallen in the stand, are also included in some equations.

bibl.et: Leaf characteristics reflect growth rates of 2-year-old Populus trees.
bibl.aa: Pacific Northwest Research Station, Forestry Sciences Laboratory, 3625 93rd Ave SW, Olympia, WA 98512-9193, USA.

ab.p: The relationships between biomass or growth rates and leaf characteristics were examined for 2-year-old trees of two clones of Populus (P. trichocarpa and P. deltoides × P. trichocarpa). Leaf characteristics were total plant leaf area or leaf weight, mean size (or weight) of fully expanded terminal leaves, and foliar concentrations and contents of N, P, K, Ca, Mg, total chlorophyll and total available carbohydrates. Sample trees (n=156) were chosen from two irrigation regimes (high or low) and several fertilizer treatments (varying amounts of N, P, K and lime) to provide a wide range of environmental conditions and growth rates for each clone. Total plant leaf area or weight was strongly correlated with total aboveground biomass (r=0.98-0.99); however, mean size (area or weight) of the fully expanded terminal leaves was also quite strongly correlated with biomass (r=0.64-0.72), height growth (r=0.54-0.72), and diameter growth (r=0.53-0.73). With one exception (correlation between foliar K concentration and height growth of one clone, r=0.67), leaf size characteristics were more strongly correlated with biomass or growth than were concentrations or contents of foliar chemicals. Since size of the terminal leaves is easy to measure, it may be useful as a simple indicator of potential productivity.

bibl.et: What makes a big tree special? Insights from the Chicagoland Treemendous Trees program.
bibl.aa: North Central Forest Experiment Station, 845 Chicago Avenue, Suite 225, Evanston, IL 60202, USA.

ab.p: In 1995, a local version of the American Forests big trees programme (Treemendous Trees) was initiated in the Chicago area by Openlands Project and the Morton Arboretum. In addition to the numerical information about tree sizes required on the nomination form, many participants attached notes and sometimes lengthy letters that detailed various aspects of the nominated trees. A qualitative analysis of these written materials identified a number of recurrent themes that sometimes went far beyond the physical size dimensions to describe aesthetic and functional values, and symbolic and emotional meanings. This information may help urban foresters better understand the breadth and depth of values people have for urban trees - particularly large ones. Results also have implications for obtaining more and better information from big tree programmes, and for using these programmes as vehicles for developing collaborative partnerships between urban foresters and citizens in knowledge discovery and sharing.

bibl.et: Estimating hedonic price equations for a timber stumpage market using stochastic frontier estimation procedures.
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry, Mississippi State University, Mississippi State, MS 39762-9681, USA.

ab.p: Statistical techniques developed for stochastic frontier analysis are applied to hedonic price functions within the context of the timber stumpage market when there is price uncertainty on the part of both sellers and buyers. The error term of the hedonic price function has an asymmetric component whose distribution depends on the presence or absence of a consultant. This provides a more plausible model of such timber markets with uncertainty. Empirical results on a sample of 298 timber sales from North Carolina, USA support the model.

bibl.et: Uncertainty and forest land use allocation in British Columbia: vague priorities and imprecise coefficients.
bibl.aa: University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada.

ab.p: Recently, increasing weight has been placed on nontimber values in forest management. Both the multiple objectives and the parameters that support decision making in forestry are often imprecise and vague. In this paper, the concepts of fuzzy set theory are explained and then applied to the problem of allocating public forest land on Vancouver Island among competing land uses (wood production, recreation, nature conservation). The resulting employment and revenue benefits are also considered in the analysis. Two principal sources of fuzziness are identified - those related to uncertainty in classification (specification of management objectives) and those related to uncertainty concerning how actions affect objectives (imprecise technical coefficients). By comparing the results of classical and fuzzy decision models, it is concluded that the latter approach can be judged an improvement over the former. The fuzzy land-use allocation appears to be more consistent with the political decision making process that has evolved in British Columbia, which relies on consultation and consensus seeking among various interest groups. The analysis also yields insights into the robustness of outcomes and suggests priority areas for further research.

bibl.et: Growth and physiological responses of young loblolly pine stands to thinning.
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry, College of Forestry and Wildlife Resources, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Virginia 24061-0324, USA.

ab.p: Although yield responses to thinning in loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) have been well documented, short- and long-term morphological and physiological changes are largely unknown. To investigate these responses, three 8-yr-old, 0.2024-ha replicate stands of loblolly pine in an old field in Virginia, were thinned by 50% in May 1988, and bole growth and morphological changes in the crown were measured annually for the next 6 yr. In situ gas exchange measurements were monitored in the upper and lower third of the crowns monthly during the third through to the sixth growing seasons following thinning. First- and second-year physiological responses to thinning have been reported earlier (Ginn et al. (1991) Forest Science 37 1030-1040). Thinning slowed live crown recession and increased crown diameters resulting in increased photosynthetic surface area per tree. Over the 6-yr study period, the crown diameters of thinned trees increased by 82% while the crown diameters of control trees increased by only 20%. Larger bole diameters were observed for thinned trees 4 growing seasons after thinning. Photosynthetic rate and needle conductance did not increase overall, but were increased in the lower crown foliage of thinned trees. Needle dark respiration was higher in thinned stands in both the upper and lower crowns. Increased bole diameter growth is likely to be the result of the large increases in foliar biomass as well as of initially higher physiological activity in the lower crowns of thinned stands.
