bibl.do: Advances in ecological sciences. Volume 1: Ecosystems and sustainable development.
bibl.et: The effect of afforestation as a restoration measure in a degraded area in a Mediterranean environment near Lorca (Spain).
bibl.aa: Department of Physical Geography, Utrecht University, PO Box 80.115, 3508 TC Utrecht, Netherlands.

ab.p: In a marl limestone area near Lorca, south eastern Spain, the effects of afforestation on overland flow and erosion processes were studied in 2 catchments during 1995-97. The natural vegetation in the area consisted mainly of Stipa tenacissima (perennial grass) and Pinus halepensis, but in 1983 Pinus halepensis was also planted on terraces created with heavy machinery, to improve the water infiltration rates on hill slopes. Precipitation and total discharge in ditches were monitored, and crest stage tubes were used to establish locally if overland flow occurred during an event. Surface runoff after heavy rainfall was increased and consequently erosion enhanced in the reforested areas. Most importantly the creation of the terraces resulted in preferential flowpaths being created by the bulldozer, perpendicular to the contour lines. Secondly on north facing slopes the originally present, fairly well developed, natural vegetation was destroyed. Since vegetation cover as well as the presence of a humus layer are important factors on reducing erosion risk, this lead to an initial increase in erosion. Thirdly the growth rates of Pinus halepensis were slow such that in 1997, 14 years after planting, the trees sometimes have reached no greater height than 80 cm and the coverage percentage was still very low. It is concluded that the negative impacts on erosion of afforestation in the first 14 years after planting were greater than the gains.

bibl.et: Analysis of damage caused by wind, snow and ice in the forests of Slovakia.
bibl.aa: Forest Research Institute, T. G. Masaryka 22, 960 92 Zvolen, Slovakia.

ab.p: The volume of salvage cutting (SC) caused by wind, snow and ice between 1961 and 1995 in Slovakian forests was evaluated from records of the Forest Protection Service (1971-96), the Total Forest Management Plan (1994) and Permanent Forest Inventory (1994). SC caused by wind, snow and ice during 1985-95 was 800&thin;000, 180&thin;000, and 35&thin;000 m³, respectively. Volume of SC was also related to forest regions and tree species; both were classified into 3 categories of wind, snow and ice-breakage hazard: low, moderate or high. This analysis confirms the steady increase in wind, snow and ice SC in Slovakia, and total volume is expected to reach 1&thin;400&thin;000 m³ by 2005. Norway spruce (Picea abies) and silver fir (Abies alba) were the species most frequently damaged by wind, Norway spruce and Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris) by snow, and Scots pine and European beech (Fagus sylvatica) by ice. It is concluded that these results can be used to modify tree species composition in forest stands in regions where there is a need to increase stand stability.

bibl.do: Document - International Research Group on Wood Preservation
bibl.et: Evaluation of the efficiency of industrial kiln type CCA fixation chambers.
bibl.ms: Paper presented for the 27th Annual Meeting, West Indies, 19 May - 24 May, 1996.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Forestry, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario M5S 1A1, Canada.

ab.p: Six commercial CCA treating plants in Canada were assessed for the fixation efficiency of their hot air fixation chambers in drying southern pine [Pinus (Southern)]. The wood temperature was measured with thermocouples over the fixation period at different locations in the chamber and at the end of the fixation cycle, the degree of chromium fixation was determined by a boring leaching procedure. There was a great variation in the effectiveness of the chambers, related to the heat transfer efficiency of the kilns. Both an adequate steam supply and efficient air circulation are essential to ensure quality fixation in a reasonable time frame. In plants without this, the wood deep in the lumber piles is still in a mainly unfixed state when removed from the fixation chamber. In contrast, for CCA treated wood allowed to fix under ambient temperature conditions, the interior of bulk piled lumber fixes faster than the outer wood or stickered wood. This results from the cooling effect of water evaporation from the exposed lumber as it dries.

bibl.do: Document - International Research Group on Wood Preservation
bibl.et: The influence of the natural extractives of opepe (Nauclea diderrichii) and African padauk (Pterocarpus soyauxii) timbers on their durability.
bibl.ms: Paper prepared for the 27th Annual Meeting, West Indies, 19 May - 24 May, 1996.
bibl.aa: Building Research Establishment, Bucknalls Lane, Garston, Watford WD2 7JR, UK.

ab.p: Many timbers contain chemical extractives that undoubtedly play a key role in the timber's natural durability. Opepe (Nauclea diderrichii) and padauk (Pterocarpus sp.) are both very durable timbers (class 1), yet they are described as being moderately permeable. This suggests the presence of biocidal chemicals within these timbers, rather than simple blocking agents. Initial trials on the location and role of the extractives are presented, including the changes in bioresistance of the extracted timber to laboratory pure strains of brown and white rot fungi. The extractives responsible for the enhanced durability are probably located within the cell wall and require polar solvents such as methanol or acetone to remove them. These solvents will be used in further extractive studies. This project forms part of a wider program of research concerned with novel approaches to wood preservation, based upon a detailed understanding of wood chemistry. The overall objective is to develop environmentally benign techniques for timber preservation.

bibl.do: Tree demography in the tropical rain forest of Guyana.
bibl.et: Tree demography in the tropical rain forest of Guyana.

bibl.ad: Werger, M. J. A.\Malta, E. J.\Rijks, M. H.\Hammond, D. S.\Machado, J. L.\Reich, P. B.\Boot, R. G. A.

ab.p: This book (also a doctoral thesis) is based on the results of a relatively small population study of 3 tree species (Dicymbe altsonii, Chlorocardium rodiei, Duguetia neglecta) in the Guyana rain forest, carried out as part of the Tropenbos-Guyana Programme, which is based at Mabura Hill, a logging community in the Demerara Timbers concession. Exploitation of the area started in 1986, and in 1988 an ecological reserve and field station were established in primary rain forest for the Tropenbos Programme. The research results are presented in 9 chapters, some co-authored with Zagt, accepted for publication elsewhere. They are: (1) Introduction; (2) Community structure and the demography of primary species in tropical rain forest (with Werger, M. J. A.) - a general introduction to population biology and its relation to species diversity, including the role of seedlings in determining forest composition and the major factors affecting plant succession; (3) Pre-dispersal and early post-dispersal demography, and reproductive litter production in the tropical tree Dicymbe altsonii in Guyana; (4) Stem sprouting of Dicymbe altsonii in the tropical rain forest of Guyana: impact of soil type and potential for regeneration (with Malta, E. J.; Rijks, M. H.); (5) Delayed germination of Chlorocardium rodiei in the tropical rain forest of Guyana (with Hammond, D. S.); (6) Distribution and demography in relation to light and size for seedlings of three Guyanese tropical rain forest species. (with Machado, J. L.; Reich, P. B.); (7) Seedling dynamics of Chlorocardium rodiei in logged-over rain forest in Guyana; (8) The response of tropical trees to logging: a cautious application of matrix models (with Boot, R. G. A.); and (9) Summary and conclusions.

bibl.et: The effect of response time on conjoint analysis estimates of rainforest protection values.
bibl.aa: Southern Research Station, U.S. Forest Service, P.O. Box 12254, Research Triangle Park, NC 27709, USA.

ab.p: This paper reports the first estimates of willingness-to-pay (WTP) for rain forest protection in the threatened Atlantic Coastal Forest ecosystem in NE Brazil. Conjoint analysis data were collected from Brazilian tourists in Bahia for recreation bundles with complex prices. An ordered probit model with time-varying parameters and heteroskedastic errors was estimated. The main empirical results showed that: (1) utility parameters vary systematically with response time, (2) respondents use different anchors and scales in rating attribute differences, (3) mean WTP estimates for nature park attributes converge to stable values as response time increases, and (4) private forests provide public benefits to Brazilians.

bibl.et: Economic value of big game hunting: the case of moose hunting in Ontario.
bibl.aa: Department of Agricultural Economics & Business, University of Guelph, Ontario, Canada.

ab.p: Greater emphasis in recent years on sustainable resource management in forestry has generated higher demand for information on various non-timber values. Since most of the non-timber resources are not exchanged in conventional markets, their economic values are not readily available. This paper estimates the demand for and the economic value of a popular non-timber resource, recreational moose hunting in Ontario, using the travel cost method. In view of censored and truncated nature of moose hunting trips data and the bag limit, 4 alternative count data models were used - Poisson, Geometric, Negative Binomial type II and Creel and Loomis, to estimate the demand for recreational moose hunting. The results indicate that the demand declines with higher travel cost and lower income and that it is both price and income inelastic. The results also indicate that truncation reduces the magnitude of both price and income elasticities. Finally, the estimated consumer surplus varies widely across model specifications. A direct implication of this result is that it is not only important to generate meaningful economic values of various non-timber resources, but it is also important to select the most appropriate set of values from a number of alternatives. Given the data and institutional characteristics, it is recommended that the estimated benefits from the truncated Geometric and the Creel and Loomis models (C$175 to C$210 per moose hunting trip) should be used for policy purposes.

bibl.et: The control of Mucanum sp. causing damage to seedlings of Shorea javanica in Krui, West Lampung.
bibl.ft: Percobaan pengendalian hama kepik Mucanum sp. yang merusak bibit Shorea javanica di Krui, Lampung Barat.

ab.p: Shorea javanica, especially seedlings in the nursery in West Lampung, Sumatra, were frequently attacked by the the insect pest Mucanum sp. (Pentatomidae), resulting in death or wilting of the seedling. Two systemic insecticides, Dimecron 50 EC [phosphamidon] and Azodrin 15 WSC [monocrotophos] (7 or 10 ml/litre), and the microbial insecticide Florbac FC [Bacillus thuringiensis subsp. aizawai] (3 or 5 ml/litre) were tested for control of the pest in a nursery experiment with 1-yr-old polybag seedlings carried out from September to December 1995. All the insecticides were effective as preventative agents against Mucanum.

bibl.et: Preliminary study on the infestation rate of the scale insect (Chionaspis spp.) in Rhizophora mucronata plantation in the Suwung mangrove forest, Bali.
bibl.ft: Kajian tentang derajat penularan "scale insect" pada tanaman Rhizophora mucronata di hutan mangrove Suwung, Bali.

ab.p: Infestation and damage caused by scale insects (Chionaspis spp.) were investigated [from October 1994] to April 1996 in pure Rhizophora mucronata stands planted on 59 ex-fishpond plots in the Suwung mangrove forest before 1993, and in 1993 and 1994. Infestation rate was determined from the number of trees having the scale insect in a plot consisting of 5×5 plantation lines, while damage rate was determined from the number of trees in a plot of 30 live trees having many scale insects and with almost all of the leaves wrinkled and/or yellowish. Analysis of the data showed that there was a correlation between the infestation rate and altitude of the leaf-layer of the R. mucronata stand, with a tendency for greater infestation when the leaf-layer was over the high water level at the highest tide (HWL/HT), and reduced infestation (or no infestation) when the leaf-layer was below the HWL/HT level. Seven of 53 R. mucronata stands infested with scale insects had a damage rate >10%. Based on the the mortality found (>5% of R. mucronata planted at the fishpond areas were found to be dead during the last 4 months of observations, from December 1995 to April 1996), these plantations may face a serious problem in the near future, if no insect control programme is started.

bibl.et: Modeling timber harvest scheduling problems with multiple criteria: an application in Spain.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Economía y Gestión, ETS Ingenieros de Montes, Universidad Politécnica de Madrid, Spain.

ab.p: A multicriteria procedure is presented for forest planning problems. The basic ingredients of the procedure are multigoal programming, compromise programming, and results connecting the best-compromise solutions with the concept of utility optima. The main feature of the procedure lies in the easy and transparent utility interpretation of some single best-compromise solutions even when the utility function, as is usual in a forestry context, is virtually unknown. The theoretical developments are applied to a timber harvest scheduling problem in the Dehesa de la Garganta, a public forest in the Segovia mountains of central Spain divided into 3 stands - 2 (joint area of 379 ha) managed for conservation, and the third (212 ha) with Pinus sylvestris plantations of various ages (up to 160 yr old) and site classes managed for timber production. The criteria considered are: (a) the net present value of the forest over the planning horizon, (b) the equality of harvest volume in each cutting period, (c) the area control criterion which looks for an ending regulated or even-aged forest, and (d) the ending inventory restraint. The preferential weights incorporated into the models are derived from the application of the Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) method to a group of experts in forestry matters. Several utility formulations are tested: (1) a separable and additive utility function linear in each criterion (i.e. a compromise solution for metric 1); (2) a Rawlsian utility function where the maximum deviation is minimized (i.e. a compromise solution for metric ∞) and (3) a family of quasi-Rawlsian utility functions.

bibl.et: Measuring softwood lumber value: a conjoint analysis approach.
bibl.aa: Keystone Veneers, Inc., Williamsport, Pennsylvania 17701, USA.

ab.p: Conjoint analysis (a technique combining mathematical psychology and psychometric approaches) was used to determine softwood lumber value perceptions among buyers of wood for preservative treatment in the USA and to determine trade-offs between lumber attributes and price. Utility functions for each lumber attribute and a model to estimate overall lumber value were developed. Wane was found to be the most important attribute in the evaluation of lumber value, followed by price, accuracy of grading, damage to the lumber package, lumber straightness, and lumber moisture content (in that order). Utility scores of individual respondents and simulation techniques were used to quantify trade-offs between quality and price. Buyers of softwood lumber for preservative treatment were found to be willing to pay a higher price to obtain wane-free lumber. The results of the study provide guidelines for softwood lumber suppliers seeking to differentiate their product while maximizing customer-perceived product value.

bibl.et: Field performance of containerized black spruce seedlings with root systems damaged by freezing or pruning.
bibl.aa: Natural Resources Canada, Canadian Forest Service, Laurentian Forestry Centre, Sainte-Foy, Quebec G1V 4C7, Canada.

ab.p: Roots of 2-year-old black spruce seedlings (Picea mariana) were exposed to freezing temperatures to destroy 20, 40, 60 and 80% of the root systems. For comparison, root systems of other seedlings were pruned to eliminate the same proportions of roots. Treated and control seedlings were planted in spring 1992 at Forêt Montmorency (the Université Laval forest Research Station, 50 km north of Quebec City, Canada). From 1992 to 1995, survival, shoot height and stem diameter were measured. Mortality mainly occurred in 1993, the year after planting; pruned seedlings showed practically no mortality while seedlings with 20, 40, 60, and 80% of their root systems affected by frost showed mortality rates of 0, 6, 17, and 24%, respectively. Shoot height and stem diameter decreased with increasing root damage when compared with controls. After 3 yr on the planting site, shoot height was reduced by 2, 8, 11, and 18% while stem diameter was reduced by 4, 21, 25, and 24% for 20, 40, 60, and 80% frost damage, respectively. For pruned seedlings, shoot height was increased by 3% at 20% damage and was decreased by 1, 3, and 13% for 40, 60, and 80% root damage while stem diameter was reduced by 1, 4, 8, and 19% for 20, 40, 60, and 80%, respectively. Use of damaged seedlings on the planting sites should be limited in order to reduce the cost of replacement planting.

bibl.do: Agroforestry innovations for Imperata grassland rehabilitation.
bibl.et: Agroforestry innovations for Imperata grassland rehabilitation.
bibl.ct: Agroforestry innovations for Imperata grassland rehabilitation.
bibl.aa: ICRAF South East Asia Regional Programme, PO Box 161, Bogor, Indonesia.

ab.p: This book is a repackaged version of a special issue of Agroforestry Systems (Volume 36, Nos 1-3, 1996/1997) containing 13 papers from a workshop held in Banjarmasin, South Kalimantan, Indonesia, from January 23 to 27, 1995, and attended by over 70 participants from 14 countries, mostly Asian. Most of the papers represent a multi-disciplinary synthesis provided by a team of specialists, which was later revised and expanded to address concerns raised at the workshop. The papers were grouped into 4 themes: Setting the scene (2 papers); Sustainable land use options on current or potential Imperata land (4 papers); Reclamation pathways: existing and potential smallholder practices (4 papers); and Social, economic, and policy issues for successful reclamation (3 papers). The last paper contains the workshop recommendations. After the workshop, a policy seminar including workshop participants and Indonesian decision makers was held at the Ministry of Forestry in Jakarta, and the key recommendation from this was that 'Where production land is covered by Imperata grassland in blocks of 10&thin;000 ha or more, smallholder farmers who rehabilitate that grassland by planting and managing trees in small plots should receive property rights over all the products, including the timber'. An author index is included. The original issue of Agroforestry Systems and its constituent papers have already been noticed separately.

bibl.do: Conservation biology principles for forested landscapes.
bibl.et: Conservation biology principles for forested landscapes.
bibl.ms: refs at ends of chapters
bibl.aa: Research Branch, British Columbia Ministry of Forests, Victoria, BC, Canada.
bibl.ad: Parminter, J.\Eng, M.\Sacken, A. von\Von Sacken, A.\MacKinnon, A.\Lofroth, E.

ab.p: The purpose of this book is to improve forest planning and decision making processes by providing up-to-date information on ecological issues related to the sustainable use of forested lands. There are 8 chapters by different authors covering various issues/topics, and research needs are specifically addressed at the end of each. The chapters are: (1) Natural disturbance ecology (Parminter, J.); (2) Spatial patterns in forested landscapes: implications for biology and forestry (Eng, M.); (3) Connectivity (Harrison, S.; Voller, J.) - an ecological term describing connections among habitats, communities and ecological processes; (4) Riparian areas and wetlands (Voller, J.); (5) Interior habitat (Sacken, A. von); (6) Biodiversity and old-growth forests (MacKinnon, A.); (7) The dead wood cycle (Lofroth, E.); and (8) Managing for edge effects (Voller, J.). Most of the references are North American. A subject index is included.

bibl.do: Radar for the rain forest: a monitoring system for land cover change in the Colombian Amazon.
bibl.et: Radar for the rain forest: a monitoring system for land cover change in the Colombian Amazon.
bibl.pb: International Institute for Aerospace Survey and Earth Sciences (ITC)
bibl.ms: ITC Publication No 53, Thesis - Wageningen Agricultural University
bibl.aa: Department of Land Resources and Urban Sciences, ITC, Enschede, Netherlands.

ab.p: The research reported in this book and doctoral thesis was carried out at ITC in cooperation with the Department of Water Resources, Wageningen University, Tropenbos Colombia, Corporación Colombiana para la Amazonia-Araracuara, and Instituto Geográfico Agustin Codazzi, during projects involving the monitoring of tropical rain forests funded by the Tropenbos Foundation and the Netherlands Remote Sensing Board (BCRS). A radar remote sensing system is presented for land cover monitoring in tropical rain forests, based on ERS-1 SAR (European Remote Sensing Satellite-1 Synthetic Aperture Radar) images. Because of its generic structure, the system can be applied to a variety of areas. The system was developed in the pilot site of San José del Guiviare, in the Amazon rain forests of Colombia, where much forest clearing has resulted from settlement from other parts of the country. Field data were collected between 1990 and 1994, and 9 ERS-1 images were available for the period 1992-94. Procedures are described for processing and classifying the radar images. Two sets of decision rules are advanced, the first based on the relation between land cover structure class and backscatter level, and the maximum change in backscatter level over 3 subsequent images, and the second describing the possible changes in land cover between two moments in time as calculated by the BOSTOS model. The second set of rules enables unlikely changes to be excluded and makes monitoring more accurate. Classification accuracies achieved were >60% for forests, ~40% for secondary vegetation, and 89-90% for pastures and natural grasslands; these were better than accuracies obtained using a maximum likelihood classifier. Accuracy can be further improved by initializing with an accurate land cover map and further developing the models underlying the rule sets. If probabilities (rather than probable choices) are used the system could be made self-learning. It could also be extended to other types of sensors.

bibl.et: Forest ecology.
bibl.aa: School of Natural Resources and Environment, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1115, USA.

ab.p: This text is designed for undergraduates interested in forest ecology, management, conservation and restoration, and provides a current perspective on the material by emphasizing forest ecosystems and plant ecology topics of community, succession and biota using a landscape-ecosystem or geo-ecosystem approach. Topics covered include concepts of forest ecology, ecosystems at multiple spatial scales, long term ecosystem change, climate, soils, physiography, carbon balance, nutrient cycling, landscape ecology and biodiversity. Ecosystem dynamics and the forest environment (light, temperature, fire, climate etc) are highlighted.

bibl.do: Mitteilungen der Eidgenössischen Forschungsanstalt für Wald, Schnee und Landschaft
bibl.et: Disturbance as an ecological principle: a re-evaluation of the importance of traditional forest uses for species and habitat conservation, illustrated by the butterfly fauna of a riparian forest in northern Switzerland.
bibl.ft: Dominanzminderung als ökologisches Prinzip: eine Neubewertung der ursprünglichen Waldnutzungen für den Arten- und Biotopschutz am Beispiel der Tagfalterfauna eines Auenwaldes in der Nordschweiz.
bibl.pb: Eidgenössische Forschungsanstalt für Wald, Schnee und Landschaft
bibl.aa: Wildforschung und Naturschutzökologie, Universität Zürich-Irchel, Winterthurerstrasse 191, CH-8057, Switzerland.

ab.p: The butterfly fauna of riparian forests in the Thur valley (near Flaach, canton of Zurich, Switzerland) were surveyed, and the survey data compared with records made during the period 1918-30, in order to describe the faunal changes brought about by the transition from traditional forest uses to high forest management during the 20th century. Traditional forest uses included coppice and coppice-with-standards on moist sites in old river channels, and pine [Pinus sp.] forests on the dry sandy soils of former islands (where underwood and brush was regularly removed). Additionally, forest litter and grass would have been removed and/or grazed. These forest management practices produced highly structured, varied and ecotonal habitats favoured by light. The ecological consequences of both traditional 'extractive' uses, and the more intensive stem timber production of a high forest system are discussed. The ecological hypothesis of intermediate disturbance is discussed in relation to these land use changes. The concept of naturalness, the place of mankind within the aims of nature conservation, and some basic principles for managing open forest are also discussed.

bibl.et: Conservation of exchangeable cations after clear-cutting of a northern hardwood forest.
bibl.aa: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Syracuse University, 220 Hinds Hall, Syracuse, NY 13244-1190, USA.

ab.p: Clear-cut logging of northern hardwoods disrupts forest nutrient cycling, often enhancing export of mineral nutrients (Ca, Mg, K) in drainage waters. When these leaching losses are added to mineral nutrient export in harvested wood, the total can be a significant fraction of the standing stocks of some ecosystems. Thus, changes in soil chemical properties after logging are important in determining the long-term implications of harvesting on nutrient availability and site fertility. Results of extensive analyses of soils on a clear-cut northern hardwood stand at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, New Hampshire, indicate that pools of exchangeable Ca, Mg, and K (1 &smallcap;M NH4Cl) were unchanged in the first 8 years (to July 1991) after clear-cutting (whole-tree harvest) in winter 1984-85. Decreases in exchangeable cation concentrations in upper soil horizons (Oa and E horizons) were offset by large increases in the spodic (Bh and Bs1) horizons. Effective cation exchange capacity (CECe) increased by 30-60% in spodic horizons 3 years after cutting and remained elevated after 8 years. Since soil organic matter (OM) is the principal source of CECe in these Spodosols, it appears that clear-cutting has altered the charge properties of OM. The CECe/OM ratio increased by approximately 25% in the first 8 years after clear-cutting. Some of this change may have been due to pH changes, but much of it appears to be the result of changes in the character of OM. Because of its importance in regulating CECe, the preservation and alteration of OM in spodic horizons are important mechanisms of mineral nutrient retention after clear-cutting.

bibl.et: Mineral nutrients and growth of fertilized Eucalyptus grandis in the state of São Paulo, Brazil.
bibl.ft: Nutrientes minerales y crecimiento de árboles abonados de Eucalyptus grandis en el estado de São Paulo.
bibl.aa: Embrapa/CNP Florestas, Caixa Postal 319 - Colombo/PR - CEP 83411-000, Brazil.

ab.p: This paper discusses the relationship between nutrient concentrations in the leaves and soil, as well as tree height growth in 3-year-old Eucalyptus grandis plantations. The survey was carried out in five locations in the Cerrado region of the State of São Paulo, Brazil. Two plantations were on red yellow latosol (Orthic Ferralsol) and 3 were on quartz sand (Ferralic Arenosol). It was concluded that the trees were adequately nourished with S, Fe, Mn and Zn; P concentrations in the leaves were below the optimum reported in literature; K and Mg were the nutrients that most seriously limited tree growth in all locations despite fertilizer application; concentrations of 2.6 and 7.5 mg/g DM of Mg and K were adequate levels for both nutrients; fertilization with N, P, K and Mg can increase the growth of the trees in all locations; Ca and B concentrations in the leaves were not related to the growth of the trees, showing a dilution effect.

bibl.et: Effect of plantation management on the physical environment.
bibl.ft: Impacto del manejo de plantaciones sobre el ambiente físico.
bibl.aa: Universidad Austral de Chile, Casilla 567, Valdivia, Chile.

ab.p: This review summarizes the main environmental impacts of radiata pine (Pinus radiata) and eucalypt (Eucalyptus spp.) plantation projects in Chile on the physical environment, and proposes some guidelines for mitigation. Site preparation, road construction, and ground-based logging (including log skidding and machinery displacements) are the operations that cause the major impacts on the physical environment. The main impacts on soil are compaction, displacement, erosion by water, and nutrient depletion. Major impacts on hydrology are disturbances in the hydrologic balance as a consequence of changes in interception, evapotranspiration and surface runoff, and physico-chemical water quality. Mitigation guidelines according to the fragility of the regional terrain are oriented toward comprehensive planning and the use of more appropriate establishment and harvesting techniques.

bibl.et: Population indicators of Rhyacionia buoliana (Schiff.): relations between apical infestation, infestation degree and population density.
bibl.ft: Indicadores poblacionales de Rhyacionia buoliana (Schiff.): relaciones entre infestación apical, grado de infestación y densidad poblacional.
bibl.aa: Instituto de Silvicultura, Universidad Austral de Chile, Casilla 567, Valdivia, Chile.

ab.p: The pine shoot moth (Rhyacionia buoliana), an introduced species in Chile with a specific association with Pinus radiata, shows different responses to the quality and amount of food resources and to microclimate. This paper analyses some population indicators, such as apical infestation, infestation degree and density. Some relations between them are also determined, monitoring (during 1987-93) the interaction the moth and host on two site classes of a young plantation established in 1986 in the province of Valdivia, X Region of Chile. The results corroborate former studies which indicated the need to protect young plantations (less than 4 years) and show that the shoot number is a key factor, especially in young trees, affecting the high rates of apical infestation even at low pest density.

bibl.et: Indigenous micro-hymenopteran parasitoid species associated with poplar defoliator, Clostera cupreata (Lepidoptera: Notodontidae).
bibl.aa: Forest Entomology Division, Forest Research Institute, Dehra Dun 248 006 UP, India.

ab.p: An appreciable number of indigenous micro-hymenopteran parasitoid species were found to be associated with the poplar (Populus) defoliator Clostera cupreata in the Tarai region of Uttar Pradesh and Haryana. These include four egg parasitoids (Telenomus colemani, Trichogramma chilonis, Ooencyrtus lucina and Pediobius sp.) three larval parasitoids (Aleiodes percurrens, Eupelmus sp. and an unidentified ichneumonid), and two pupal parasitoids (Brachymeria euploeae and Brachymeria sp.). Six of these (Telenomus colemani, Trichogramma chilonis, Pediobius sp., Aleiodes percurrens, Eupelmus sp. and Brachymeria sp.) were been recorded for the first time. Data from a two-year survey (1995-96) on seasonal population (percentage parasitism) trends of the parasitoids in poplar nurseries and plantations in Uttar Pradesh and Haryana are presented and discussed.

bibl.et: Effects of grazing and site exposition on the natural regeneration of mixed pine-oak-stands in the eastern Sierra Madre/Mexico.
bibl.ft: Auswirkungen von Beweidung und Standortexposition auf die Verjüngungsfähigkeit von Kiefern-Eichen-Mischbeständen in der östlichen Sierra Madre/Mexiko.
bibl.aa: Facultad de Ciencias Forestales, UANL, Linares, Mexico.

ab.p: The structure of natural pine (Pinus estevezii)-oak (Quercus polymorpha, Q. virginiana and Q. rysophylla)-forests in the mountainous zone of the Sierra Madre, Mexico, was investigated during 1996 in non-protected and protected (since 1985) stands. The structure showed significant site differences in growth of mature stands and natural regeneration density. These site characteristics depended on the exposition. On the climatically favourable north- and west facing slopes, the biomass of mature stands was at least 30% greater compared to drier stands on southern and eastern slopes. The natural regeneration density was twice as high on the better site expositions. Grazing was mainly a problem for the regeneration of oaks.

bibl.do: The bamboos. Proceedings of an International Symposium, London, 25-29 March 1996.
bibl.et: Fungal deterioration of bamboo cell walls.
bibl.ct: The bamboos. Proceedings of an International Symposium, London, 25-29 March 1996.
bibl.pb: Academic Press for the Linnean Society of London
bibl.ms: Linnean Society Symposium Series No. 19
bibl.aa: Department of Timber Technology Research Group, Imperial College, Prince Consort Road, London SW7 2BB, UK.

ab.p: Decomposition of young and mature culm material of Phyllostachys viridi glaucescens after inoculation with white (Coriolus versicolor), brown (Coniophora puteana) and soft rot (Chaetomium globosumo) fungi was compared with that of Betula pendula and Pinus sylvestris. In general, bamboo was no more susceptible to decay by white and brown rot fungi than the wood species. The bamboo was intermediate in susceptibility to decay by soft rot fungi between B. pendula and P. sylvestris, with the young culm being more susceptible than mature material. Two distinct decay stages were revealed by detailed examination of the soft rot decay: cavity formation within the fibre cell walls; and a general dissolution of cell walls, depending on the degree of lignification of the tissues. These results are discussed with respect to the structure, maturation and composition of bamboo cell walls.

bibl.et: Latitudinal cline of requirement for far-red light for the photoperiodic control of budset and extension growth in Picea abies (Norway spruce).
bibl.aa: Dept of Forest Genetics, Swedish Univ. of Agricultural Sciences, Box 7027, S-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: Picea abies seedlings of six populations originating from latitudes between 67 and 47°N. were grown for 4-8 weeks in continuous incandescent (metal halogen) light at 300 µmol m-2 s-1 and 20°C and then transferred, at the same temperature, to a daily regime of 8 h incandescent light (300 µmol m-2 s-1) followed by 16 h cool white fluorescent light (40 µmol m-2 s-1). Cool white lamps are deficient in far-red light, with a R:FR ratio of 7.5 compared with 2.0 for the incandescent lamps. All the seedlings from 67° and 80% of those from 64° ceased extension growth and set terminal buds within 28 days of the change of regime. The seedlings from 61° and further south continued growing, as did control seedlings from 67° grown as above but with incandescent light at 20 µmol m-2 s-1 replacing cool white illumination. To distinguish between a clinal and ecotypic pattern of variation, the interval between 64° and 59° was investigated by growing populations originating from this latitude range in the same regimes as before. After 28 days in the cool white day-extension regime, the percentage bud set was 86 for the population from 64°, 0 for the population from 59° and 25-50 for the intermediate populations, i.e. the populations showed a clinal variation in requirement for far-red light according to latitude. Thus northern populations of Picea abies appear to behave as 'light-dominant' plants for the photoperiodic control of extension growth and bud set, whereas the more southern populations behave as 'dark-dominant' plants.

bibl.et: Growth and utilisation of 22-year-old managed Eucalyptus regnans.

ab.p: E. regnans was planted in 1973 on a farm site at Esk, North Island, New Zealand, at 620 stems/ha. Herbicide was applied pre- and post-planting, and fertilizer applied at 30 g urea/tree. Some form pruning was done in 1975, butt log pruning to 6 m in 1980, and thinning to 290 and 120 stems/ha in 1980 and 1983, respectively. Grazing with sheep started in 1975 and with cattle in 1977. In 1995, a MARVL [the computer program Method for the Assessment of Recoverable Volume by Log types] inventory was carried out to determine sawlog yield by log quality class. The MARVL data showed large-diameter stems with more than half the merchantable sawlog component as pruned butt logs; the next main component was pulpwood, reflecting the 350 mm minimum sawlog diameter. Sawing and peeling studies were carried out on 15 sample trees selected across the diameter range, and felled and cross cut into an assortment of pruned peeler bolts, pruned sawlogs and large- and small-branched sawlogs. Sawn timber was air dried in summer 1995-96 and re-assessed in mid-1996. Data on the results are tabulated. The logs sawed well converting with a quarter sawn green timber grade recovery of 46% of roundwood volume. Pruning did not significantly increase clears (there were large defect cores) but increased clear board length. On drying there was minor collapse, and more severe internal checking. The bolts peeled well with a usable yield of green veneer of 60%, but this had high tangential shrinkage and showed splitting on drying. There was some decay and staining associated with pruning, and kino (gummosis) pockets were present bit these were only significant for veneer production. It is suggested that drying technology needs to be improved for satisfactory utilization of young managed E. regnans.

bibl.et: Effects of forestry clear-cutting on numbers and sizes of brook trout, Salvelinus fontinalis (Mitchill), in lakes of the Mastigouche Wildlife Reserve, Québec, Canada.
bibl.aa: Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Faune, Service de la faune aquatique, Québec, Canada.

ab.p: Brook trout angling data, collected between 1971 and 1991, were analysed before, during, and after logging operations for 20 lakes located within 200 m of a clear felling area and 16 reference lakes undisturbed by logging. The mean weight of catches by anglers remained unchanged over the 3 periods, while catches per unit of effort (CPUE) and biomass per unit of effort (BPUE) decreased, respectively, by 18 and 22% after clear felling. These changes reflected a significant modification in population dynamics, probably caused by logging operations. Results indicated that the negative impacts on aquatic fauna were felt more strongly on water bodies located in watersheds where felling was greater; CPUE was inversely correlated with a cumulative felling index (CI) developed from physiographic parameters. An increasing interannual trend of the spring-flood discharge of the order of 8% was noted. It was hypothesized that this increase might damage spawning and nursery habitats, hence affecting recruitment and offering a possible part of the explanation for the variations in fishing success. The cause-to-effect links and the mechanisms associated with changes affecting fish populations following deforestation remain to be clarified.

bibl.et: Comparison of litter dynamics in native and exotic riparian vegetation along the Middle Rio Grande of central New Mexico, USA.
bibl.aa: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico 87131, USA.

ab.p: Litter dynamics were compared at sites in the Middle Rio Grande Valley dominated by native cottonwoods (Populus deltoides) or exotic saltcedar (Tamarix ramosissima [T. chinensis). Litter production was greater at cottonwood sites. Two floods did not affect litter production at the saltcedar site, but 3 years of flooding may have slightly increased litter production at the cottonwood site. Decomposition was similar in the 2 types of leaves and was increased by flooding in both. Forest floor litter was greater at cottonwood sites, and was decreased by flooding at the saltcedar site but not at the cottonwood site. It is suggested that flooding may help reduce the impact of fires by increasing decomposition and reducing the standing stock of forest floor organic matter.

bibl.do: Bwa yo: important trees of Haiti.
bibl.et: Bwa yo: important trees of Haiti.

ab.p: The first part of the book covers 9 wood species, 4 fruit species and 4 recent exotics, giving information for each species on importance, taxonomy and botanical features, distribution and ecology, tree characteristics, utilization, propagation, biomass studies, growth performance and tree improvement. The second (larger) part gives technical information on pests and diseases, wood properties and energy values, medicinal uses, biomass and volume tables, common and scientific names, and tree proverbs. Much of the information in the book was the result of research and extension activities in agroforestry supported in Haiti by USAID since 1981.

bibl.do: Research Paper - Intermountain Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.et: Response of a depleted sagebrush steppe riparian system to grazing control and woody plantings.
bibl.pb: Intermountain Research Station, USDA Forest Service
bibl.aa: Intermountain Research Station.

ab.p: To find out if a depleted riparian system in the sagebrush (Artemisia spp.) steppe of eastern Oregon would respond quickly to improved management, five management treatments were applied for 7 years, ranging from ungrazed to heavily grazed treatments, including in some cases, planting of woody species. While the results varied, all treatments were too limited to significantly restore the damaged areas within the 7-year span. Although some improvements were made in woody plant densities, little meaningful change occurred in the frequencies of herbaceous wetland plants, densities of small wildlife, or stream channel morphology. It was concluded the restoration would take many years, possibly decades, without increased revegetation efforts and continued reductions in grazing in this riparian system damaged over 150 years. Appendices list the plant species found and the presence of transient bird species, wide-ranging raptors and resident birds in 1987, 1990 and 1993.

bibl.et: Vector diagnosis of nutrient dynamics in mesquite seedlings.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Forestry, University of Toronto, 33 Willcocks Street, Toronto, Ontario M5S 3B3, Canada.

ab.p: Vector analysis is applied to interpret temporal interrelationships between plant biomass and nutrient status with time, as demonstrated using young mesquite (Prosopis chilensis) containerized seedlings. Conventional (single dose or constant top dressing), and exponential (pure or modified exponential) NPK fertilizer schedules were used to induce contrasting plant nutrient status in the seedlings over a 12-wk growing season. Progressions in nutrient status (determined by shoot analysis) showed that conventional fertilizing resulted in nutrient dilution, whereas pure exponential fertilizing achieved steady-state nutrient conditions after an initial deficiency. The modified exponential schedule attained steady-state nutrition for most of the experimental period. These trends were similar for all 3 fertilizer elements. This study demonstrated that dynamic time dependent responses such as steady-state nutrient conditions, nutrient dilution, and accumulation can be identified using traditional vector analysis provided a fourth variable, time (t), is introduced. This approach also allows simultaneous comparisons of multiple elements on the same nomogram, facilitating assessment of differential nutrient absorption during seedling development.

The population density could not be explained completely by habitat (altitude and proportion of wooded areas).

bibl.et: Exploring the error structure of taper equations.
bibl.aa: Multiresource Inventory Techniques, Rocky Mountain Forest and Range Experiment Station, USDA Forest Service, 240 W. Prospect Road, Fort Collins, CO 80526-2098, USA.

ab.p: Much work has been done fitting taper equations to specific tree bole shapes, but few researchers have investigated what effect the correlated error structure has on the fit of a taper equation. The Max and Burkhart (1976) taper equation was used in conjunction with a number of equations which modelled the covariance structures. The equations proposed were continuously differentiable, which simplifies the fitting process, and selected to minimize the number of parameters. A maximum likelihood method was proposed to fit these equations and test the statistical significance of the correlated errors. Accounting for the correlated errors structure in the equation fitting process significantly improved fit. Tests showed a small, but significant, bias of 1.05% (±0.143%) when the correlated errors were ignored.

ab.p: The relative importance of tree species and tree provenance for plantation success is discussed in the context of Germany, and it is concluded that the provenance is more influential than the species. As the choice of species will influence wood supply for future generations, the risk should be spread by planting a range of species: softwoods and hardwoods, light-coloured woods and dark woods, fungus-resistant woods and tannin-free woods, etc. It also seems appropriate to plant exotic species with special wood properties on suitable sites for posterity.

bibl.et: Influence of stand structure and needle physiology on the development of outbreaks of the nun moth (Lymantria monacha L.) in pine stands (Pinus sylvestris L.) in a permanently damaged area of Niedersachsen.
bibl.ft: Einfluss von Bestandesstrukturen und Nadelphysiologie auf die Entstehung von Massenvermehrungen der Nonne (Lymantria monacha L.) in Kiefernbeständen (Pinus sylvestris L.) eines Dauerschadgebietes in Niedersachsen.
bibl.aa: Niedersächsische Forstliche Versuchsanstalt, Abteilung Waldschutz, Grätzelstrasse 2, D-37079 Göttingen, Germany.

ab.p: The effects of stand structure and pine needle physiology on outbreaks of Lymantria monacha in pine forests in Niedersachsen, Germany, were investigated during August 1993-June 1994. A high proportion of trees of Kraft class 3 in unthinned stands lead to high intraspecific competition and physiological changes in pine needles. This improved the mean area-related food quality which promoted the development of insect pests. An area-related assessment of food quality enabled the prediction of possible outbreaks. Strict ground thinning measures in outbreak areas and the removal of pines of the lower social classes 3 to 5 caused a deterioration in the area-related food situation for needle-feeding insects.

bibl.et: Biomass and nutrient content of a short rotation coppice of Beaupré poplar planted on a non-alluvial acidic soil improved by fertilizers.
bibl.ft: Biomasse et minéralomasse d'un taillis à courte révolution de peuplier Beaupré installé sur un sol acide hors vallée, amélioré par fertilisation.
bibl.aa: J. Ranger, Équipe Cycles Biogéchimiques, Centre INRA de Nancy, 54280 Champenoux, France.

ab.p: The effect of fertilizer application on production of a short-rotation coppice (SRC) stand of Populus 'Beaupré' was tested in the Luthenay-Uxeloup forest, Nièvre, France. Several treatments - p, NPK or NPKCa - were compared to a control (no fertilizer) in a block experiment. The stand was established in 1984, treatments were applied in 1985 (twice), 1986, 1987, 1990 and 1992, and the stand was harvested after in 1993. The improvement in production was significant for all treatments, compared to the control. The NPKCa treatment was the best one. Absolute production values were too low for the industrial development of short-rotation forestry in these ecological conditions, where water availability during the growing season appears to be the primary limiting factor. The real potential of the site for SRC was not fully explored during this test, owing to the unusually dry climatic conditions during the 1980s. However, this SRC did efficiently utilize nutrients for dry matter production, compared with other SRCs studied. Soil mineral enrichment was already apparent at the end of the first rotation. Future studies should test fertilizer application to restore nutrients lost during harvest on production rates of the next generation.

bibl.et: Heteroblastic sequence and leaf development in Leea guineensis.
bibl.aa: Department of Biology, University of Northern Iowa, Cedar Falls, Iowa 50614-0421, USA.

ab.p: The leaves initiated at successive nodes in the heteroblastic series in Leea guineensis seedlings become progressively more complex in construction. Leaves at the first four nodes are simple and are followed by transitional forms between nodes 5 and 7. These transitional leaf forms are compound in nature, and intermediates such as deeply lobed leaves are not observed. At successively higher nodes, the compound nature of the leaves becomes progressively more complex. The most common sequence of leaf morphologies is simple (nodes 1-4), trifoliate to pinnate (nodes 5-7), bipinnate (by node 8), and tripinnate (by node 11). The developmental morphology of the simple leaves in the sequence was markedly different from the compound leaves that followed. However, the early stages of development of the compound leaves, regardless of their degree of complexity, were very similar. Therefore, there appears to be a striking developmental distinction between the simple leaves and the compound leaves in the sequence. Simple leaf primordia become centrally concave and assume a characteristic folded appearance, whereas compound leaves have up to three orders of branching and are structurally more complex. However, compound leaves of different levels of complexity seem to share certain developmental features. At its maximum, the compound nature of the leaf can best be described in terms of subunits of seven leaflets. Thus, the complexity of the leaf can be viewed as a reiteration of the basic unit. The increase in compound leaf complexity does not alter the rate of leaf production.

bibl.et: Industrial utilization of medicinal plants in developing countries.
bibl.ct: Medicinal plants for conservation and health care.
bibl.aa: Chemical Industries Branch, Industrial Sectors and Environment Division, United Nations Industrial Development Organization, P O Box 300, A-1400 Vienna, Austria.

ab.p: The majority of the rural people in developing countries use plant based traditional medicines for health care. These are still produced using age old methods which can affect their quality, stability and efficacy. Resurgence of interest in green products in the industrialised countries has created an expanding market for plant based products that could be produced by developing countries to be competitive provided the quality and safety specifications could be satisfied. The constraints for the development of such industries in developing countries and the requirements for overcoming these have been identified. The possibilities for value addition, processing and product improvement, and technical assistance needs of developing countries for the industrial utilization of medicinal plants are indicated.

bibl.et: Understory plant response to site preparation and fertilization of loblolly and shortleaf pine forests.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station, Albuquerque, NM 87106, USA.

ab.p: The influence of site preparation and P fertilizer application on the successional trends of shrubs and herbaceous plants growing on lands of widely ranging subsoil texture managed for southern pine (Pinus taeda and P. echinata) production was examined in Arkansas, Louisiana, and Texas, USA. Burning-injecting, chopping-burning, chopping-burning-discing, double-chopping, shearing-burning, shearing-windrowing, and shearing-windrowing-discing site preparation methods were applied in a completely randomized split-plot design to sites with subsoil textures consisting of loam, gravelly-clay, silt, silty-clay, and clay, both fertilized with 73.4 kg P/ha and unfertilized. Site preparation method, subsoil texture, and fertilization influenced production of Paspalum spp. and other forbs the first growing season following treatment, but no treatment combination affected plant groups in subsequent years. Total herbaceous production increased 24 to 35-fold over pretreatment levels the first growing season after treatment. While site preparation methods had little influence on herbaceous biomass, subsoil texture affected herbaceous production the first year after treatment, with loam subsoils being most productive. Although annual composites were the most abundant herbaceous group the first year after treatment, they were largely replaced by perennial grasses by the third post-treatment growing season. By the seventh growing season following treatment, herbaceous production declined on all subsoil textures with composition and yield approximating pretreatment estimates. Subsoil texture influenced shrub density only in the first and third growing seasons after treatment. During the first few years after site preparation, herbaceous production appeared inversely related to shrub density. In the first and third post-treatment growing seasons, fertilization significantly increased total herbaceous production and biomass of composites and legumes. But 7 years after application, total herbaceous production and biomass of bluestems [Poa spp.], other grasses, and sedges was greater on unfertilized areas. The absence of differences among treatments by the seventh post-treatment growing season indicates an overall long-term similarity in the degree of disturbance caused by application of each method in this ecosystem.

bibl.et: The effect of community structure on social forestry outcomes: insights from Chota Nagpur, India.
bibl.ct: Sixth annual conference of the International Association for the Study of Common Property Resources, University of California, Berkeley, June 1996.
bibl.aa: Environmental Studies Program, University of North Carolina, One University Heights, Asheville, NC 28801, USA.

ab.p: Based on survey research among 18 villages in the hilly Chota Nagpur Plateau, SE Bihar, India, theories of collective action and common property resource management were used to investigate the relationship between social differentiation, local institutional capacity and wealth distribution, and the likelihood of success of private or community-based social forestry strategies. The results provide a basis for distinguishing among communities according to the probable effectiveness of different forms of social forestry, as well as for determining appropriate roles for external organizations interested in promoting social forestry. Discussion of other factors such as local leadership, land and tree tenure, relations with external institutions, and ecological variation which affect social forestry outcomes is also included.

bibl.av: De Barros, N. F.\De Novais, R. F.
bibl.et: Requirement and distribution of boron in eucalypt seedlings.
bibl.ft: Exigencia y distribución de boro en plantas de eucalipto.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Solos/UFV, 36571-000, Viçosa (MG), Brazil.

ab.p: Seedlings of two provenances of Eucalyptus camaldulensis (provenances S. less susceptible, and PR, more susceptible to tip dieback), E. dunnii, E. globulus, and E. urophylla were grown in nutrient solution with various levels of B (0; 0.01; 0.03; 0.1, 0.5 and 2.5 mg/litre) in three replicates. Dry matter production and B concentration were evaluated when seedlings were 114 days old. The maximum dry matter yield of E. camaldulensis-S and E. dunnii was 18.9 and 18.1 g/pot, while it was 23.6 and 24.9 g/pot for E. urophylla and E. camaldulensis-PR. The dry matter of E. globulus increased linearly with B levels. The B levels in the nutrient solution associated with the maximum yield was between 0.044 and 0.049 mg/litre for E. camaldulensis-S and PR and E. urophylla; it was 0.096 mg/litre for E. dunnii and above 0.1 mg/litre for E. globulus. The critical concentration of B in seedling shoots was 115 mg/g for E. dunnii, 137 mg/g for E. globulus, 108 mg/g for E. urophylla, and 95 and 88 mg/g for E. camaldulensis-PR and -S, respectively. The difference between the two provenances of E. camaldulensis is due to the higher functional B-requirement of provenance PR as compared with provenance S. Seedling dieback intensity in the control treatment (0 mg/litre) followed the same sequence as observed for the critical concentrations.

bibl.do: Forest Fragmentation and Biodiversity Project Report - Ontario Forest Research Institute
bibl.et: Development of a landscape ecological model for management on Ontario forests: phase 2 - extension over an east/west gradient over the province.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Geography, University of Toronto, ON, Canada.

ab.p: A landscape ecological data and simulation system is extended across an east-west gradient in the Province of Ontario. The system uses a range of satellite and GIS data to compute landscape level forest ecosystem productivity, forest evapotranspiration and runoff production as well as the spatial patterns of soil and litter water content. The model responds directly to data describing stand conditions, stand position in the landscape (e.g. relative drainage, slope, aspect), and daily weather data. A hierarchical structure to the model can be realized by linking local landscape level predictions to larger regional to provincial level observations by coarse resolution satellites. Potential management use of the system includes forecasting and investigating spatial and temporal patterns of forest productivity and runoff production at different scales, under different management strategies and under different climatic conditions, and the use of predicted soil and litter water patterns for fire hazard and fire spread rating and modelling. Field observations from the Petawawa National Forestry Institute, the Turkey Lakes Experimental Watershed, and the Rinker Lake area near Lake Nipagon were used to validate and diagnose model predictions.

bibl.et: Growth grammars simulating trees - an extension of L-systems incorporating local variables and sensitivity.
bibl.ct: Special issue on Functional-Structural Tree Models. Papers selected from the Helsinki workshop on Functional-Structural Tree Models, 12-13 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Universität Göttingen, Abteilung für Forstliche Biometrie und Informatik, Büsgenweg 4, D-37077 Göttingen, Germany.

ab.p: The rule-based formal language of 'stochastic sensitive growth grammars' was designed to describe algorithmically the changing morphology of forest trees during their lifetime under the impact of endogenous and exogenous factors, and to generate 3-D simulations of tree structures in a systematic manner. The description in the form of grammars allows the precise specification of structural models with functional components. These grammars (extended L-systems) can be interpreted by the software GROGRA (Growth grammar interpreter) yielding time series of attributed 3-D structures representing plants. With some recent extensions of the growth-grammar language (sensitive functions, local variables) it is possible to model environmental control of shoot growth and some simple allocation strategies, and to obtain typical competition effects in tree stands qualitatively in the model.

bibl.et: Effects of rock climbing on populations of presettlement eastern white cedar (Thuja occidentalis) on cliffs of the Niagara Escarpment, Canada.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario N1E 4T7, Canada.

ab.p: Cliffs of the Niagara Escarpment support a self-sustaining pre-settlement forest of eastern white cedar (Thuja occidentalis) in which some trees are over 1000 years old. Many of the cliffs are also popular locations for recreational rock climbing. A study was conducted during May to October 1995 which employed a stratified random sampling design to assess the impact of rock climbing on populations of cliff-face and cliff-edge trees. Tree density and age structure were compared between 4 climbed and 3 unclimbed sites in the vicinity of Milton, Ontario. Signs of physical damage were also recorded for the trees sampled at each site. Living tree density on the cliff face was lowest in climbed areas, and the age structures of these forests indicated that the numbers of older and younger age classes had been reduced on climbed cliff faces compared with un-climbed areas. A high percentage of trees on climbed cliff faces exhibited evidence of damage by humans. These trends were not as apparent on cliff edges where other disturbances had affected age structure. It is suggested that cliff faces be explored for the presence of pre-settlement forest and that recreation managers of lands with exposed cliff faces incorporate rock climbing considerations into their management plans. It is concluded that monitoring programmes would help track levels of disturbance and that education of the climbing community would be the most effective long-term solution to limiting disturbance in sensitive areas.

bibl.et: The use of bushland, corridors, and linear remnants by birds in southeastern Queensland, Australia.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Griffith University, Nathan, Queensland 4111, Australia.

ab.p: A field study was conducted during December 1992 to March 1993 and late May to early August 1993 in a 3100 km² area of southeastern Queensland, to investigate bird use of riparian corridors in pastoral and urban surroundings and riparian linear remnants within an urban context. Vegetation types included Acacia, Eucalyptus, Melaleuca, Banksia and Casuarina in addition to rain forest species, shrubs, grass and bracken. The avifauna of these remnants was compared with dryland and riparian sites within continuous bushland, and their use by previously derived response-guilds of birds to bushland clearing was also assessed. 3567 individuals of 102 bird species were recorded. Riparian bushland supported more species and had greater bird abundances than dryland bushland. Corridors and linear remnants supported densities of many bushland-dependent species similar to those in bushland; this varied with species' patterns of large-scale migration and residency. Bushland-dependent winter migrants used both corridors and linear remnants extensively. Bushland-dependent residents were most abundant in continuous bushland and least abundant in linear remnants, possibly reflecting the constraints of central place foraging. The effects of isolation were only evident in resident bushland-dependent species. Local habitat variables were significantly associated with variation in abundance of some types of birds within corridors and linear remnants; however, the differences in bird abundances attributable to spatial characteristics were greater than those attributable to habitat characteristics. The effects of bushland fragmentation and isolation were mediated by the extent to which species were dependent upon bushland and their patterns of large-scale migration or residency. It is concluded that local habitat, and possibly more importantly altitude, may influence site use by winter migrants and generalist species.

bibl.do: Bulletin of National Pingtung Polytechnic Institute
bibl.et: Study on the kiln drying of teak, India-charcoal trema, Formosan alder and schefflera tree 3-cm thick lumber.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Forest Products Technology, National Pingtung Polytechnic Institute, Pingtung, China.

ab.p: Four species of lumber, teak (Tectona grandis), India-charcoal trema (Trema orientalis), Formosan alder (Alnus formosana) and schefflera tree (Schefflera octophylla) 120(L)×12(W)×3(T) cm, were dried with high-temperature drying (HTD), conventional kiln drying (CKD) and conventional-high-temperature (two stage) drying (CHD). With this information available a lumber process will be able to ascertain if one method is more suitable than the other. Drying with HTD could reduce drying time by about 57%, and energy consumption was reduced by about 38% compared with CKD. Less drying defects were observed for Formosan alder dried with CHD; drying time was decreased 30% and the energy consumption was reduced by 27% compared with CKD. Conventional kiln drying (CKD) was more suitable for teak and India-charcoal trema than HTD. Except Schefflera tree, more collapse and honeycomb were observed while dried with HTD. The shrinkage ratio of Formosan alder diminished with CHD, but increased in other three species with HTD. Wood dried with HTD, had somewhat lower values in hardness and impact bending strength with all the four species, but slightly higher values of MOR and MOE of static bending and cleavage strength in India-charcoal trema.

bibl.et: Radiata pine wood properties model.
bibl.ct: IUFRO WP S5.01-04. Proceedings, second workshop: Connection between silviculture and wood quality through modelling approaches and simulation software, Berg-en-Dal, Kruger National Park, South Africa, August 26-31, 1996.
bibl.pb: Institut National de le Recherche Agronomique (INRA), Département d'Économie et de Sociologie Rurales, Laboratoire d' Économie Forestère et Agricole
bibl.aa: New Zealand Forest Research Institute, Private Bag 3020, Rotorua, New Zealand.

ab.p: Data on the biological variation in wood properties has been a research focus at NZ Forest Research Institute for a long time. The research started with those wood characteristics judged to be the most significant in their impact on utilisation (wood density, tracheid length, heartwood) and has progressed to include a wider range of phenomena such as resin pockets and spiral grain. Most (but not all) characteristics conform to more or less regular patterns of variation both within trees and in response to major climatic factors such as temperature and rainfall, as well as silvicultural treatments. The existence of patterns in the wood properties has enabled the initiation of an ambitious programme to model wood property variations as a first step in the integration of wood quality, tree growth and wood processing models. This report describes progress to date on the wood properties model - WOODPRO.

bibl.do: Journal of Jiangsu Forestry Science & Technology
bibl.et: Comparative study on growth and soil properties under different successive rotation of Chinese fir.
bibl.aa: Xiayang Forest Farm, Nanping, Fujian 353005, China.

ab.p: Differences in growth, soil chemical properties and soil enzyme activities were studied between the first rotation and second rotations of Chinese fir [Cunninghamia lanceolata] in Jiangsu. Height, diameter and volume in the second rotation were significantly lower than in the first rotation. The soil organic matter, available N, P and K, and exchangeable Mg in the second rotation were significantly lower tan in the first rotation. Activities of soil catalase, protease, acid phosphatase, sucrase, polyphenol oxidase [catechol oxidase] and urease in the second rotation were significantly lower than in the first rotation. It is suggested that the deterioration in soil chemical properties and soil enzyme activities with successive rotations causes the yield decline in 20-yr-old plantations.

bibl.et: Effects of temperature and tissue nitrogen on dormant season stem and branch maintenance respiration in a young loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) plantation.
bibl.aa: Southern Research Station, USDA Forest Service, 3041 Cornwallis Road, Research Triangle Park, NC 27709, USA.

ab.p: Dormant season (November-February) maintenance respiration rates (Rm) were measured in stems and branches of 9-year-old loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) growing in plots at the Southeast Tree Research and Education Site, Laurinburg, North Carolina, under conditions of controlled nutrient and water supply to determine the relationships between Rm and tissue size (surface area, sapwood volume, sapwood dry weight), tissue nitrogen content and temperature. Dormant season Rm per unit size (i.e., surface area, µmol m-2 s-1; sapwood volume, µmol m-3 s-1; or sapwood dry weight, nmol g-1 s-1) varied with tissue size, but was constant with respect to tissue nitrogen content (µmol mol-1 N s-1). Cambium temperature accounted for 61 and 77% of the variation in stem and branch respiration, respectively. The basal respiration rate (respiration at 0°C) increased with tissue nitrogen content, however, the Q10 did not. Improved nutrition more than doubled stem basal respiration rate and increased branch basal respiration by 38%. Exponential equations were developed to model stem and branch respiration as a function of cambium temperature and tissue nitrogen content. It was concluded that failure to account for tissue nitrogen effects on respiration rates will result in serious errors when estimating annual maintenance costs.

bibl.et: Plybamboo manufacturing of tali bamboo (Gigantochloa apus).
bibl.ft: Pembuatan bambu lapis dari bambu tali (Gigantochloa apus).
bibl.ms: English figures and tables.
bibl.aa: Forest Products and Socio-economics Research and Development Centre, Bogor, Indonesia.

ab.p: Bamboo plywood was manufactured from tali bamboo (Gigantochloa apus) in full-sized sheets. The nominal dimension of the 3-ply plybamboo was 213.5×91.5×1.2 cm and it was glued with urea formaldehyde liquid glue. To improve the durability of plybamboo, the preservatives CCB (chlorine, chromium, boron) and borax were added into the glue mixture to the amount of 5% of the weight of urea formaldehyde liquid. The first group was made of bamboo for all layers and the other was made of bamboo for the outer layers and red meranti veneer (Shorea sp.) of 4-mm thick for the core. The objective of this study was to observe the quality of plybamboo in full size dimensions, to determine the effect of preservative addition and the kind of layers of plybamboo on mechanical properties and the recovery of bamboo strip and plybamboo products. The results revealed that the recovery of bamboo strips was 67.62% (4.7 mm-thick) and the recovery of plybamboo was 54.45%. The moisture content and thickness met Indonesian standards, but the length and width of plybamboo only met the standard in 50% of cases. In general the bending strength and the bonding strength of plybamboo met the Japanese standard. Modulus of rupture of plybamboo with CCB preservative was the lowest, while the highest was plybamboo using meranti veneer as the core layer.

index.de: bamboos\boric acid\manufacture\plywood\properties\wood preservation\wood preservatives

bibl.et: Metal distribution in the Laguna Lake Water system and adsorption of some metals by carbonized wood powder.
bibl.aa: Laboratory of Wood Composite, Wood Research Laboratory, Kyoto University, Uji, Kyoto, Japan.

ab.p: The metal distribution in the Laguna lake water system was assessed using water samples taken from the surface, middle and bottom portions of the lake at five designated sampling points. Trial purification of the waste water was conducted using raw and carbonized wood powder from wood wastes of Acacia mangium. Beneficial and dangerously toxic metals were present in all the water samples. Sodium (Na) was the most dominant alkali metal followed by potassium (K), magnesium (Mg) and calcium (Ca). Toxic metals such as arsenic (As), cadmium (Cd), cobalt (Co), chromium (Cr), copper (Cu), lead (Pb), iron (Fe), mercury (Hg), zinc (Zn), etc., were found but each concentration was below the water quality criteria set by the National Pollution Control Commission of the Philippines. Adsorption tests showed that wood waste from Acacia mangium could be potential purification material in treating Laguna lake water samples, and especially raw and carbonized wood powder of this species could be used as material in adsorbing heavy metals like Zn Cu.

ab.p: The concept of the taper equation and its formulation were studied in relation to problems in drawing up merchantable volume tables. A general formula for a new (optimal) taper equation is presented, and its use is illustrated for Chinese fir [Cunninghamia lanceolata] in Hunan province. The new equation is shown to have advantages over previously published taper equations.

bibl.et: Ontogenetic changes in size, allometry, and mechanical design of tropical rain forest trees.
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry, Wageningen Agricultural University, P.O. Box 342, 6700 AH Wageningen, Netherlands.

ab.p: Size, allometry, and mechanical design were measured for trees of three canopy species in a tropical rain forest in French Guiana. Mechanical design was expressed as the safety factor, using the elastic-stability model, and the wind resistance factor, using the constant-stress model. Changes with ontogeny were described as regressions using stem diameter as the independent variable, and they were compared between species. Height, crown size, and the wind resistance factor increased with ontogeny. The safety factor decreased to a minimum and then increased continuously in thicker trees. The crown width/height ratio did not change with ontogeny. Interspecific differences in allometry and mechanical design were related to the adult stature of the species, and not to shade tolerance. The short stature species (Vouacapoua americana) was less slender (height:DBH (diameter at breast height) ratio) and had a higher crown width/height ratio than the tall stature species (Goupia glabra and Dicorynia guianensis). Vouacapoua had a higher safety factor, but a similar wind resistance factor. The safety factors of the study species were lower than those of two temperate tree species because of a higher slenderness. Differences in safety factors between tropical and temperate trees may result from unrealistic assumptions of the elastic-stability model, and may also be related to lower light levels and/or wind rates in the tropics.

bibl.et: Lodgepole pine in North America.
bibl.aa: Wood Science Laboratory, Inc., Corvallis, MT 59828, USA.

ab.p: This five-part text (published in 3 volumes) describes the several subspecies of lodgepole pine (Pinus contorta) that grow in North America. Volume 1 includes the first part, which describes the resource and the species' origin, physiology and silvicultural aspects, with a final extended chapter on fungi, mistletoes, adverse atmospheres, animals and insects that attack lodgepole pines. Volume 2 includes parts II and III. Part II is concerned with water, forage for livestock, wildlife and recreation in lodgepole pine forests. Part III characterizes the tree parts, including gross characteristics of foliage, stems, stumps and roots, anatomy, chemistry, specific gravity, wood-water relationships, mechanical properties and defects in trees and logs. Volume 3 includes the final two parts. Part IV, describes the processes by which lodgepole pine is converted to products, including harvesting, debarking, milling, machining, drying, treating, and conversion of dead trees. The final part discusses the major products resulting from such processes, including solid wood products, composites, pulp and paper, and energy and chemicals. There is an index at the end of volume 3. References are included at the end of each chapter.

bibl.et: The role of relations between the ground and the water in forest engineering management.
bibl.ft: Rola warunków gruntowo-wodnych w inz&dotover;ynieryjnym zagospodarowaniu lasów.
bibl.aa: Katedra Uz&dotover;ytkowania Lasu i Inz&dotover;ynierii Leśnej SGGW, Warsaw, Poland.

ab.p: The report discusses the impact of groundwater characteristics on the planning of forest infrastructure [in Poland]. It presents methods for describing forest site types in terms of their groundwater characteristics and humidity so that infrastructure planning assessments may be made with regard to water management, forest communication networks (roads), forest housing, recreational capacity building and fire control. Engineering methods for forest water resource management pertain to the regulation of water relations in soils, water retention, water intake for various purposes, and runoff and erosion control facilities. Three groups of forest site types are recognized in terms of their groundwater characteristics/humidity, and according to their suitability for location of individual houses and forest settlements. The impact of groundwater relations on the recreational management of forests is also discussed.

ab.p: The available data on Polish provenances of Norway spruce (Picea abies) included in Polish field trials have been compiled, and are presented in a table in normalized form, together with means for forest complexes and for forest regions. Fast growing populations as well as poor populations occur throughout the country - and this finding also concerns the most famous populations from the High Beskids and from Bial&lstroke;owiez&dotover;a. Therefore, more detailed information is needed about specific provenances. Some provenances deserve special recommendation as suitable for planting well outside the region of their occurrence. This applies to the provenances Istebna, Wisl&lstroke;a, Ujsol&lstroke;y, Karkonosze, Puszcza Solska and Wysoczyzna Mazowiecka.

bibl.et: Effect of birds and bears on seed germination of fleshy-fruited plants in temperate rainforests of southeast Alaska.
bibl.aa: Institut Mediterrani d'Estudis Avançats, Crtra. Valldemossa, Km 7.5, E-07071 Palma de Mallorca, Spain.

ab.p: The effects of avian and mammal seed dispersers on seed germination were investigated for six common plant species (5 shrubs and one forb) in the temperate rain forests of southeast Alaska. Patterns of germination behaviour were compared between defecated seeds and control (unpassed) seeds for a period of two years. Seed passage through vertebrate frugivores (Ursus arctos and U. americanus) enhanced germination in two species, Rubus spectabilis and Sambucus racemosa, and a similar trend was observed in Ribes bracteosum. In contrast, it did not affect seed germination in Oplopanax horridus, Streptopus amplexifolius and Vaccinium ovalifolium/alaskaense. No differences in germination behaviour were found between bear- and bird-treated seeds, suggesting that seed retention time (much greater in bears than in birds) in the digestive tract did not relevantly affect germination. Differences among frugivore effects were detected only for S. racemosa, with the varied thrush (Ixoreus naevius) enhancing germination more than the American robin (Turdus migratorius) and black bears. The two colour morphs of R. spectabilis showed similar germination patterns, suggesting that seed dispersers do not exert an important selective pressure contributing to the maintenance of the polymorphism, at least through the mechanism of a differential effect on germination. The results of this study support the idea that the advantages of animal seed dispersal lie more in seed movement away from the parent plant than in seed treatment within the digestive tract of the disperser.
