bibl.et: Effects of native and exotic forest on benthic stream biota in New Zealand: a colonization study.
bibl.aa: Correspondence address: Department of Streams and Riparian Areas, National Environmental Research Institute, Silkeborg, Denmark.

ab.p: Algal biomass, microbial activity and invertebrate colonization were investigated in 20 streams in the South Island, New Zealand. Sixteen streams drained catchments with native forest (Nothofagus solanderi var. cliffortioides on the eastern side of the Southern Alps, and mixed-podocarp/Nothofagus forest on the western side) or exotic forest plantations (mostly Pinus radiata, with some stands of Pseudotsuga menziesii) and 4 were unshaded, non-forested sites (grassland/scrub). Algal biomass on stones was highest at the unshaded sites and was greater at forested sites east of the Alpine Divide than at forested sites on the western side. Algal biomass on nutrient-diffusion substrata also showed significant location (east > west) and nutrient effects. However, responses to nutrient additions were variable among stream groups, with unshaded and eastern native-forest streams showing the strongest response. Abundances of invertebrates (mainly Chironomidae) colonizing diffusion substrata were positively correlated with algal biomass in eastern native forest streams and unshaded streams but not the other treatments. Microbial activity, expressed as loss in weight of cellulose cloth over a 3-week period, was unaffected by location/vegetation type but increased significantly in response to nutrient additions.

bibl.et: The fundamental work of Walter Wittich during his stay at Eberswalde.
bibl.ft: Die grundlegenden Arbeiten Walter Wittichs in seiner Eberswalder Zeit.
bibl.aa: Forstliche Forschungsanstalt Eberswalde, Alfred-Möller-Str., 16225 Eberswalde, Germany.

ab.p: Brief biographical details are presented of the German forester Walter Wittich and his extreme views on the "Dauerwald" (permanent forest) concept are critically discussed. His main scientific findings focused on the influence of clear felling and soil cultivation, the impact of tree species on top soil, and the significance of the water balance. The importance of Wittich's findings for today's forestry in northeastern German lowlands is underlined.

bibl.et: The Flathead Indian Reservation: resetting the clock with uneven-aged management.
bibl.aa: Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes, 104 Main Street SE, PO Box 235, Ronan, MT 59864, USA.

ab.p: The use of uneven-aged management as a silviculture tool is examined, with particular reference to the practices of the Salish and Kootenai tribes, located on the Flathead Indian Reservation, in north-western Montana, USA. A historical account of selective forestry is given, followed by a review of the Earl Wilcox demonstration forest case study, in which the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) established uneven-aged stocking in an irregular stand of ponderosa pine [Pinus ponderosa] and Douglas fir [Pseudotsuga menziesii]. The project aimed to calculate the optimum residual growing stock levels necessary to maximise board-foot growth and to ensure the creation of a new age class of reproduction within each cutting age. Interim results are presented and various considerations for field implementation of selection systems are given, including: regeneration, stand testing and planning within the context of the ecosystem.

bibl.et: The enigma of yellow-cedar decline. What is killing these long-lived, defensive trees?
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, State and Private Forestry, Pacific Northwest Research Station, 2770 Sherwood Lane, Suite 2A, Juneau, AK 99801, USA.

ab.p: The decline of yellow cedar (Chamaecyparis nootkatensis), which has occurred across numerous islands in South East Alaska, USA, since approx. 1880, is documented. Symptoms of diseased trees are described and the potential biotic factors responsible are discussed, with reference to various field studies in the area. Site factors and epidemiology are then reviewed, with particular attention paid to the strong association of disease with poor drainage. The distribution of decline is compared to various possible abiotic effects, including bog expansion, soil toxicity and freezing. Finally, the possibility of long-term climate change is examined as the most likely cause of decline.

bibl.et: Intraindividual variations of volatile terpene contents in Pinus caribaea needles and its possible relationship to Atta laevigata herbivory.
bibl.aa: Escuela de Química, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Central de Venezuela, Caracas, Venezuela.

ab.p: Volatile terpene content variations in Pinus caribaea needles were examined in relation to season, day hour and canopy level in a 54 ha plot of 23-year-old trees at Uverito, Venezuela. Results showed that the concentration of β-pinene was lower and that of sabinene and caryophyllene higher in the dry season than in the rainy season. β-Pinene, camphene and β-phellandrene were more abundant in needles located at the lower canopy level, and limonene, α-ocimene, and the mixture of myrcene + α-phellandrene were more abundant at the upper canopy level. Camphene, sabinene, myrcene + α-phellandrene and β-cadinene + γ-cadinene were more abundant in the afternoon, with lower concentrations at night. These results indicate that intraindividual variations in the contents of volatile terpenes in P. caribaea needles are significant even in regard to interindividual differences. The foraging pattern of the leaf-cutting ant Atta laevigata, as observed in a Caribbean pine plantation, could be, in part, related to these intraindividual variations.

bibl.et: Public goods in Swedish forests: Essays on nonmarket valuation and environmental policy.
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Economics, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, S-90183 Umeå, Sweden.

ab.p: This thesis is based on 6 papers (included as an appendix) published in or submitted to various journals. The thesis deals with the benefits of forest environmental commodities, as estimated by the Contingent Valuation Method (CVM), and environmental policy in the presence of such commodities. The first 4 papers present empirically orientated work using the CVM, while the remaining 2 are theoretical and policy orientated. The results of 2 CVM case studies discussed in the first paper indicate that much of the benefit of tourist trips is attributable to forest characteristics and that these benefits can be increased by modifying forest management practices. The next 2 papers analyse a mail CVM survey on the benefits of the wolf in Sweden and a telephone follow-up survey which addresses the problem of value inference due to sample non-response. The fourth paper presents non-parametric estimators of the mean Willingness-To-Pay and its variance for use in the discrete choice version of the CVM. Paper 5 analyses cooperative and adversarial institutions for conflict resolution, using Sweden and the USA s examples, while the final paper extends the question of predator management from benefit estimation to conflict analysis.

bibl.et: Integrating wildfire into strategic planning for Sierra Nevada forests.
bibl.aa: College of Forestry, Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR 97331, USA.

ab.p: This study combines the spatial simulation of forest development on a large landscape, including wildfire occurrence and effects, with the search for management actions that achieve multiple goals. The approach was applied to the late-successional, mixed-conifer zone of the Eldorado National Forest, in the Sierra Nevada, California. Resulting analysis suggests that active management (prescribed fire and timber harvest) could enable the simultaneous movement toward the goals of developing complex forest structure and reducing high-severity fire, while also limiting watershed disturbance and providing a regular timber harvest.

bibl.et: Paper or plastic? The United States' demand for paper and paperboard in packaging.
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 1630 Linden Drive, Madison, WI 53706, USA.

ab.p: Analysis of consumer demand for packaging suggests that: plastic packaging is a luxury good, while paper packaging is a normal good, paper packaging demand increases with the price of plastic packaging, and that demand for paper packaging is most sensitive to its own price, and to the income of consumers. In a complementary analysis of input demand in the converting paper industry it was found that the demand for each paper grade is price inelastic, capital and other materials are substitutes for paper, while labour is a complement, technical change rapidly decreases the use of unbleached kraft packaging and industrial converting, and increases the use of other grades. The demand for each paper grade, derived from the consumer demand and the factor demand functions, showed that, from 1983 to 1991, the demand for paper in packaging was influenced mainly by consumer income, and by the price of paper packaging, and less so by the price of paper itself, or by the price of plastic packaging.

ab.p: Systematic observations were made at a single Ficus tiliifolia tree during December 1991 in the Parc National de Ranomafana in an area of pristine primary eastern humid forest. Data are presented on the vertebrate species that visited the tree (lemurs, parrots, passerine birds, rodents etc), estimates of total fruit production and proportion consumed by frugivores, and the chemical analysis of these fruits.

bibl.et: Economic geography, forest distribution, and woodpecker diversity in central Europe.
bibl.aa: Grimsö Wildlife Research Station, Department of Conservation Biology, Forest Faculty, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, S-730 91 Riddarhyttan, Sweden.

ab.p: The completeness of the woodpecker guild was used as a biodiversity indicator to test the hypothesis that forest biodiversity in Europe is inversely related to the degree of urban-economic development. Woodpecker diversity was related to several socioeconomic indices in 20 central European countries where the basic physiogeographic conditions are similar. As predicted, woodpecker diversity was low in highly developed countries with a long history of intensive land use, whereas in less-developed, peripheral countries, the woodpecker diversity was much higher and no species had been lost. The negative correlation between the degree of urbanization and woodpecker diversity was interpreted as a causal link between neotechnological landscape degradation and the decline of biodiversity. Alternative hypotheses related to the slow postglacial dispersal of species and climatic differences between western and eastern Europe that might explain the observed pattern of woodpecker diversity are discussed and rejected. The relative importance of particular woodpecker species for the level of woodpecker diversity shows that species depending on naturally dynamic temperate forests are particularly sensitive to anthropogenic changes. Future prospects for forest biodiversity in Europe are discussed with reference to ways of avoiding the biodiversity loss in E. Europe which has occurred in W. Europe as habitat features such as big or old trees and tree species mixtures have been replaced by monocultures.

bibl.et: SEM study of the weathering effects on painted wood.
bibl.ct: SEM ispitivanje djelovanja atmosferilija na površinski obra&dstroke;eno drvo.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Forestry, Zagreb University, Croatia.

ab.p: For the purpose of evaluating the performance and durability of modern wood coatings with low organic solvent content, natural and artificial exposure trials of various specimens were performed and subsequently the conditions of the coating, of the substrate and of their link was assessed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Two types of European softwood species were used as a substrate, namely pine (Pinus sylvestris) and spruce (Picea abies), and they were used either as coated panels or as microtomed wood sections ('thin strips'), which were exposed behind a detached film of a coating. Solvent borne (sb) coatings were compared with modern water-borne (wb) coatings. Semitransparent stains were compared with opaque white paints. Pine and spruce did not show significant differences in their failure modes, film-holding properties or UV light resistance under semi-transparent coatings. However, spruce was shown to undergo somewhat smaller structural changes with weathering. The paints did not penetrate the cell wall but firmly adhered to the S3 layer of the lumina. The solvent-borne coatings (both paint and stain) penetrated deeper into the wood surface than the water-borne coatings. The opaque paints fully protected the wood from the effect of light through a 14-month period of natural exposure and maintained the coherent protective coating. The water-borne paint exhibited more brittle characteristics on the fractured transverse surface than the solvent-borne paint. The stains varied in their protective effectiveness. The thick water-borne stain showed a tough, sound failure mode, good adhesion but very poor penetration into wood surface. The thin coating of the solvent-borne stain was degraded by light, and the interface with the wood was affected, resulting in the development of brittleness of both wood and coating and leading to adhesion failures preceding the detachment of the film. Thin strips with detached films of coatings realistically represented the surface of coated wood specimens, and were easy to handle, to detach and subsequently to investigate both mechanically and microscopically. The combination of strength measurements and the microscopic evidence proved particularly effective for the interpretation of the changes occurring at the very surface of wood components i.e. at the wood-coating interface. The microscopic observations confirmed that the progress of wood photodegradation can be successfully detected by the combination of the state of deterioration of anatomical elements on radial surfaces and by fractographic evidence on cross sections.

bibl.et: Estimating biomass and biomass change of tropical forests: a primer.
bibl.aa: Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Sciences, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL, USA.

ab.p: Climate change is a global issue in which forests play an important role. Changes in the cover, use and management of forests produce sources and sinks of carbon dioxide which are exchanged with the biosphere, and estimation of the magnitude of these sources and sinks requires reliable estimates of the biomass density of forests. These are the background issues to this primer on biomass estimation, which focuses on tropical forests whose high potential biomass gives any changes taking place in them a particular significance. The paper is concerned with one important component of the biomass, viz. above-ground woody biomass of trees with a diameter of at least 10 cm breast height (dbh). There are 7 main parts: (1) Introduction; (2) Purpose and scope of primer on estimating biomass; (3) Methods for estimating biomass density from existing data - approaches based on volume data or on stand tables, and estimates for individual trees, plantations and other forest components; (4) Primary data and field measurements for biomass estimation - improvements in forest inventories, and field measurements for developing biomass regression equations; (5) Biomass density estimates for Developing Countries based on existing inventories - tropical African, American and Asian countries; (6) Biomass estimates from GIS modelling - general approach and examples of results; and (7) Future directions to estimate biomass change - from field studies and from remote sensing/field studies and GIS modelling. The primer is intended for use by planners of forest inventories and in training for forest inventory.

ab.p: Thale Noi is a small lake (2673 ha) N. of Thale Luang in Phatthaling Province, Thailand. It is surrounded by open swamp forest (Melaleuca) to the N., by protected national reserve Melaleuca forest to the S., and by sedge beds and rice paddies. Aspects of the area discussed are its natural resources, socioeconomics, tourism, environmental changes (sedimentation and drainage) and status of the protected area - retention of the site as a non-hunting area (but not upgrading to national park status) is recommended.

bibl.do: Impact of diseases and insect pests in tropical forests. Proceedings of the IUFRO Symposium, Peechi, India, 23-26 November 1993.
bibl.et: Mycorrhizal symbiosis in tropical trees in relation to control of root pathogens.
bibl.ct: Impact of diseases and insect pests in tropical forests. Proceedings of the IUFRO Symposium, Peechi, India, 23-26 November 1993.
bibl.aa: Department of Agricultural Microbiology, University of Agricultural Sciences, GKVK Campus, Bangalore 560 065, India.

ab.p: Although ectomycorrhizal fungi are associated with a few tree species, the common mycorrhizal association in tropical trees is the vesicular arbuscular mycorrhiza, which is reviewed. The symbiosis is so well balanced that, although many of the host cells are invaded by the fungal endophytes there is no damage to the host cells and the association enhances the growth and vigour of the host plant. The mycorrhizal plants have greater tolerance to toxic heavy metals, drought, soil salinity, transplantation shock and root pathogens. Mechanisms of suppression of root pathogens by mycorrhizal fungi appear to be physical through modification of cell wall, chemical through production of antimicrobial compounds and biological through altered rhizosphere microflora. This potential can be exploited in field by further understanding the defence mechanisms and the conditions favouring the expression of their protective ability.

bibl.et: Threats to mangrovev vegetation from marine wood-boring and fouling organisms along Indian Coast.
bibl.ct: Impact of diseases and insect pests in tropical forests. Proceedings of the IUFRO Symposium, Peechi, India, 23-26 November 1993.
bibl.aa: Institute of Wood Science and Technology, Indian Council of Forestry Research and Education, Bangalore 560 003, India.

ab.p: Damage caused by marine organisms is recognized as an important factor causing decline of the mangrove ecosystem. Twenty three species of molluscan borers (Families - Teredinidae and Pholadidae) and 4 species of crustacean borers (Family - Sphaeromatidae) have been reported from mangroves along Indian coasts. In some localities, over 50% of the plants and aerial roots were found infested in varying intensities. Several species of foulers, mainly barnacles, oysters, gastropods, serpulids and bryozoans, settle heavily on various parts including the growing buds of saplings submerged during high tide affecting the vigour, vitality and growth of the saplings. Remedial measures to prevent biodeterioration of mangroves are discussed and the research needs are identified.

bibl.et: Soil pest complex and its control in the establishment of commercial plantations in South Africa.
bibl.ct: Impact of diseases and insect pests in tropical forests. Proceedings of the IUFRO Symposium, Peechi, India, 23-26 November 1993.
bibl.aa: Institute for Commercial Forestry Research, University of Natal, P.O. Box 375, Pietermaritzburg, South Africa.

ab.p: A complex of soil pests contribute to 10-20% failure of transplants from reaching full establishment. This pest complex includes termites, white grubs, cutworms, tipulid larvae, millipedes and nematodes. Chemical control as one of the options in the management of these pests was evaluated. Success of the traditional application of gamma BHC [lindane] 0.6% dust was variable. The controlled release formulations of carbosulfan and chlorpyrifos and the synthetic pyrethroid deltamethrin SC at different rates of application showed promise for control of white grubs using plots of Eucalyptus grandis and Acacia mearnsii.

bibl.et: Partitioning of chlorinated solvents between pine needles and air.
bibl.aa: Department of Chemistry, The University of Edinburgh, King's Buildings, West Mains Road, Edinburgh EH9 3JJ, UK.

ab.p: The equilibrium partitioning of tetrachloromethane (CCl4), trichloroethene (C2HCl3), tetrachloroethene (C2Cl4) and 1,1,1-trichloroethane (C2H3Cl3) between the gas phase and both needles and hexane-extractable leaf waxes of Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris) was measured at room temperature (20°C). Needles and wax came to equilibrium with gas-phase concentrations in the range 2.5-1500 mg m-3 within 6 hours. Partition ratios (PR: g m-3 needle/g m-3 gaseous nitrogen) for whole needles were 9, 27, 200 and 10 for CCl4, C2HCl3, C2Cl4 and C2H3Cl3 respectively; for extractable wax the partition ratios were 90, 390, 2100 and 950 respectively. The partition ratios are similar to published data for Norway spruce. There was a linear relationship between log(PR) for whole needles and the octanol-air equilibrium constant, log(Koa), suggesting that the PR depends on the balance between the octanol-water equilibrium constant and aqueous solubility. There was also a linear relationship between log(PR) and boiling point for the 4 chlorinated hydrocarbons studied.

bibl.do: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture
bibl.et: Identification of substances responsible for the 'sawdust' aroma in oak wood.
bibl.aa: Faculty of Enology, University Victor Segualen, Bordeaux II, 351 Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cedex, France.

ab.p: The unpleasant 'sawdust' odour sometimes found in wines aged in new barrels was studied by gas chromatography olfactory detection and mass spectrometry. A particularly aromatic zone had several chromatographic peaks, corresponding to certain characteristic odours which could be detected by smelling the gas effluent. These included the subtle rancid, weedy odour of 'sawdust'. Various carbonyl components were identified in this particular zone. These included (E)-2-nonenal, 3-octen-1-one, (E)-2-octenal and 1-decanal. These molecules were the primary cause of disagreeable oak wood odours. By measuring (E)-2-nonenal in wines, after derivation by O-(2,3,4,5-pentafluorobenzyl)-hydroxylamine (PFBOA), it was possible to correlate the concentration of this unsaturated aldehyde with the intensity of the 'sawdust' character noted in tasting. The possible explanations for the presence of these carbonyl compounds are debatable. The carbonyl content varied from one wood sample (Quercus alba and Q. petraea) to another. However, controlling the toasting of the wood, both in the laboratory and in the cooperage, produced a major reduction in the extractable (E)-2-nonenal content and eradicated the 'sawdust' character of the wine.

bibl.et: A reconstruction of the North Atlantic Oscillation using tree-ring chronologies from North America and Europe.
bibl.aa: Tree-Ring Laboratory, Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Palisades, NY 10964, USA.

ab.p: Tree-ring records, six from eastern North America and four from northwestern Europe, were used to develop the first reconstruction of the winter North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO). The reconstructed series spans the interval AD 1701-1980 and explains 41% of the variance in the NAO over the AD 1874-1980 calibration period. The reconstruction also captured the spectral properties of this index, suggesting that the oscillatory character of the NAO is a long-term feature of the North Atlantic climate system.

ab.p: To understand the molecular biological basis for tension wood formation, first, a stem of 3-yr-old Eucalyptus camaldulensis was inclined and fixed for 2 weeks to produce tension wood. A cDNA library of differentiating xylem to produce tension wood was constructed using RNA from the inclined stem and λgt 11 phage as vector. The activity of 31 clones of this DNA were then assessed.

bibl.et: Rule based modeling of thinning regimes for a distance dependent single tree growth simulator by implementing a fuzzy logic controller.
bibl.ct: Recent advances in forest mensuration and growth and yield research. Proceedings from 3 sessions of Subject Group S4.01 Mensuration, growth and yield at the 20th World Congress of IUFRO, held in Tampere, Finland, 6-12 August 1995.
bibl.pb: Danish Forest and Landscape Research Institute
bibl.aa: Chair of Forest Yield Science, Faculty of Forest Science, University of Munich, Hohenbachernstr. 22, D-85354 Freising, Germany.

ab.p: A thinning model is presented that can be implemented in distance dependent single tree growth simulators. The most central module of this thinning model is a fuzzy logic controller which consists of a merely simple rule base with no more than seven rules. The only input variables are relative tree diameter and a distance dependent competition index, the output variable addresses the thinning decision of a single tree. The rule base is designed using formally defined thinning instructions, empirical data from experimental plots and simulation results. Evaluation of the rule base is maintained by applying the max-prod-inference, the defuzzification of the resulting thinning decision follows the centre of gravity method. The thinning model was validated using independent data from experimental plots. The rule based approach to model thinning regimes can be extended to sophisticated thinning instructions for mixed species stands.

index.de: decision making\diameter\forest management\forests\growth\IUFRO\mixtures\models\plant competition\silviculture\simulation\thinning

index.up: Western Europe\Europe\Developed Countries\European Union Countries\OECD Countries

bibl.do: Recent advances in forest mensuration and growth and yield research. Proceedings from 3 sessions of Subject Group S4.01 Mensuration, growth and yield at the 20th World Congress of IUFRO, held in Tampere, Finland, 6-12 August 1995.
bibl.et: Parameters for describing stand structure.
bibl.ct: Recent advances in forest mensuration and growth and yield research. Proceedings from 3 sessions of Subject Group S4.01 Mensuration, growth and yield at the 20th World Congress of IUFRO, held in Tampere, Finland, 6-12 August 1995.
bibl.pb: Danish Forest and Landscape Research Institute
bibl.aa: School of Forestry, University of Montana, Missoula, MT 59812, USA.

ab.p: Desirable stand conditions which may meet many multiple resource objectives can generally be expressed in terms of stand structures. A stand structure approach to forest management therefore provides a unifying theme for multiple resource management. Traditional approaches for describing structure generally include measures of size class distributions and measures of stand density. New approaches include models of crown dynamics, distributions of leaf area in stands, and classifications based on processes of stand growth and competition. Descriptions of forest stand structure are presented for stand- and landscape-level analyses. For stand-level analysis, three structures are examined: single-species, even-aged stands; mixed-species, even-aged stands; and single-species, multi-aged stands. The latter two structures are more complex than the former structure. The landscape analysis example involves stands with variable species compositions and age structures. Approaches for describing structure to meet different objectives require different methodology. All approaches have a common theme of relying on crown characteristics to describe stand structure. These newer approaches provide three-dimensional measures of structure whereas traditional approaches were primarily two-dimensional. Parameters for describing stand structure include height development patterns and their implications for crown development. Leaf area is identified as a useful parameter for linking stocking relations with structural development and growth prediction. Canopy cover by size class appears to be useful for landscape-level analysis. Landscape-level analysis parameters are particularly useful if discernible from aerial photogrammetry or remote sensing. Arranging these parameters in a hierarchy may have the advantage of facilitating effective management at multiple scales.

ab.p: The environment in urban areas is becoming worse and forests are recognised as an important part of the city for the increasing population and facilities. This study was carried out to analyse topography of the environment as a basis for reasonable management and utilization of urban forest areas in Taejon city and its environs (Korea Republic) using Landsat-5 TM and digital terrain altitude data. Forested areas were estimated from Landsat-5 TM data. Distribution of altitude, slope and aspect was derived from digital terrain altitude data. Forest in the Taejon area covers 55.1% of the total area, nearly 5 times the urban area.

ab.p: To study vegetational structure of the Korean warm temperate region, fifty two plots were surveyed in evergreen broadleaved forests of southern islands. Vegetational structures among sites were dissimilar because of geographical isolation and artificial disturbance. Surveyed plots were generally classified into three groups: (1) plant succession has proceeded naturally; (2) the site was disturbed and managed for a long time; and (3) the site was afforested and has developed into evergreen broadleaved forest. The species present in over 80% of the plots were Machilus thunbergii [Persea thunbergii], Eurya japonica [Cleyera japonica], Trachelospermum asiaticum var. intermedium, Cinnamomum japonicum and Ligustrum japonicum.

bibl.ft: La forêt en jeu: l'extractivisme en Amazonie centrale.
bibl.pb: Office de la Recherche Scientifique et Technique Outre-Mer (ORSTOM)
bibl.aa: ORSTOM, Laboratoire d'ethnobiologie-biogéographie, MNHN, 43, rue Cuvier, 75005 Paris, France.
bibl.ad: Aubertin, C.\Meira, M.\Carneiro Filho, A.\Pinton, F.\Emperaire, L.\Santos Pereira, H. dos\Dos Santos Pereira, H.\Rasse, E.\Bressolette, V.\Mitja, D.\Lescure, J. P.\Salgado, I.\De Castro, A.\Castro, A. de\Bahri, S.\Coelho Ferreira, M.

ab.p: The book is a summary of the main findings of a programme of inter-disciplinary research on extractivism (defined as the gathering of a variety of non-timber forest products for trade) in Central Amazonia (12 areas in Amazonas) implemented from 1990 to 1995 by the French Institute for Scientific Research for Development in Cooperation (ORSTOM) and the Brazilian National Institute for Research in Amazonia (INPA). Nineteen chapters are included in 4 sections: Historical approach (3 chapters by Aubertin, C., Meira, M., Carneiro Filho, A.); Extractivism, a composite of production systems (3 chapters by Pinton, F. & Emperaire, L., dos Santos Pereira, H., Rasse, E. & Bressolette, V.); Ecological aspects (7 chapters by Carneiro Filho, A. (2 chapters), Mitja, D. & Lescure, J. P., Emperaire, L. & Mitja, D., Salgado, I., de Castro, A., Emperaire, L. & Lescure, J. P.); Current trends (6 chapters by Pinton, F. & Aubertin, C., Aubertin, C., Bahri, S., Coelho Ferreira, M., Lescure, J. P.). There is also a general reference section, a glossary of terms and an index of botanical and local plant names.

bibl.do: Fighting for the rain forest: war, youth & resources in Sierra Leone.
bibl.et: Fighting for the rain forest: war, youth & resources in Sierra Leone.
bibl.ms: African Issues. Published by the International African Institute in association with James Currey Publishers and Heinemann Publishers (ISBN 0-435-07405-9 hardback and ISBN 0-435-07406-7 paperback)
bibl.aa: University College, London, UK.

ab.p: This book is a critical examination of Kaplan's 'New Barbarism' thesis in relation to the war in Sierra Leone which began in March 1991, carried out by an ethnographic analysis. The essential propositions of the New Barbarism thesis as related to the anarchy which has spread throughout the forests of Sierra Leone are that the war was a product of social breakdown caused by population pressure and environmental collapse. These propositions are found to be wanting in several major respects - although the local history of resource acquisition is relevant to understanding the causes of the war, there is no uncontrolled environmental crisis, and data on population trends and land resources do not support the thesis. Instead political failures are cited by the young people involved (the rebel group is small with a War Council of 21 members and several thousand young members who are initially conscripted), and the violence of the conflict is shown to be rooted culturally in the hybrid Atlantic world of international commerce in which Europeans and Americans have played a prominent and often violent part. The war of terror is being fought in the rain forest where long-term patterns of primitive accumulation of forest and mineral resources have fed a politics dominated by patrimonial distribution. The political elite has built support through distributing resources according to bureaucratic rationality or accountability. Patrimonial distribution went into sharp decline in the 1980s and tested the loyalty of the young people in particular; also, as a result of political machinations and resource shortages the state's capacity to control some of its peripheral regions was weakened. The analysis of the war is presented in an introduction (War in Sierra Leone: New Barbarism in Africa?), 8 chapters (1. Insurgency in Sierra Leone: context, events & interpretations; 2. State recession and youth: the political culture of patrimonial decline; 3. Forest conversion: the making & remaking of forest society; 4. Bush war and primitive accumulation: the voices of young people; 5. Videos & violence: youth exposure to modern media; 6. Environment & violence: is population pressure a likely cause of war?; 7. On the edge: state recession & social exclusion; and 8. War, resources & the future: youth attitudes to forest insurgency), and a conclusion (War-peace transitions: scope for citizen action). An afterword and postscript (30 pages) have been added to the reprinted edition, updating on the situation, and providing further analysis.

bibl.et: Influence of moisture content on beech wood strength observed with various ways of mechanical loading.
bibl.aa: Katedra náuky o dreve, Drevárska fakulta, T.G. Masaryka 24, Technická univerzita vo Zvolene, 960 53 Zvolen, Slovakia.

ab.p: The influence of moisture content on the change of beech (Fagus) wood strength was tested using various ways of mechanical loading (compression, tension, shear, static bending). The highest values of strength (exclusive of shear) were reached at zero moisture content and they decreased with increasing moisture content until fiber saturation point (FSP) was reached. Further moisture increase above FSP caused no increase in strength. The results are discussed from the mechanical, structural and thermodynamic points of view.

ab.p: The principles of forestry policy, forest resources, and trade policy are discussed in relation to Slovakia. It is pointed out that state subsidies would be required if some forests are to be maintained mainly for their environmental benefits because of reduced income from sales of timber. The value of timber from commercial forestry may be increased by restricting the export of raw timber as opposed to finished forest products. It is suggested that the Slovak forest products industry could not compete in a European competitive market because of low quality production.

bibl.et: An astructural analysis of national forest policy and employment.
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Science, Texas A&M University, Texas, USA.

ab.p: Linkages between sector-specific policy and sector employment are explored using a nonstationary Markov chain analysis. When parameterization of transition probabilities between employment sectors includes policy variables, hypothesis tests can determine policy impact relative to other variables. This astructural approach eliminates bias inherent in structural models. Application of this technique to Oregon's forestry sector and national forest policy demonstrates that macroeconomic forces have statistically important effects on employment while national forest policy, measured as timber sold or timber cut, does not. This result raises questions about forest policy impact analysis and assumptions inherent in national forest policy implementation.

bibl.et: Forestry effects on bedload yields in mountain streams.
bibl.aa: School of Education and Community Studies, Liverpool John Moores University, I. M. Marsh Campus, Barkhill Road, Liverpool L17 6BD, UK.

ab.p: Bedload traps installed on headwater tributary streams in the Balquhidder catchments of central Scotland were operated over a 27-month period. Mean annual bedload yields measured in 6 forested tributaries of the catchment ranged from 0.171 ± 0.103 to 25.259 ± 5.795 t km-2, with a mean of 9.321 ± 1.999 t km-2 (n=86) and D50 of 8 mm. In the paired moorland catchment, the range in mean annual bedload yield in 3 tributaries was from 0.901 ± 0.395 to 5.93 ± 1.645 t km-2 with a mean of 2.869 ± 0.885 t km-2 (n=36) and D50 of 32 mm. This difference was statistically significant; bedload yields seemed to increase in proportion to the area of the catchment under mature forest. Timber harvesting operations were associated with increases in bedload yields in 2 headwater streams but short trap records before and after forestry operations meant that changes were not statistically significant. Ploughing and drainage ditching of moorland caused tributary bedload yields to increase in one stream but to decrease in another; neither change, however, was statistically significant. Yields reported are generally lower than in other parts of upland Britain (comparative data are tabulated), although differences in measurement methods make direct comparisons difficult. Bedload makes up a relatively small proportion of the total sediment load at Balquhidder in comparison with data from other studies in Ayrshire and mid-Wales. The dataset available from which to assess bedload yields in the British uplands is developing but further clarification of the delivery-ratio effect for bedload is needed from catchments with a wide range of geology, climate and catchment size.

bibl.do: Technical Publication - ASEAN Forest Tree Seed Centre Project
bibl.et: Genetic studies of Pterocarpus macrocarpus Kurz.: variation in fruit and seed size and quality within and among natural populations.

ab.p: Fruit and seed traits of Pterocarpus macrocarpus trees in 9 natural populations in Thailand were studied over 2 yr (1990-91) as part of an ongoing research project on genetic variation in this economically important species. Significant variation was detected among and within populations and between years for all fruit and seed traits. In the second year of sampling, almost all of the re-sampled trees produced fruit with larger wings but smaller seed cavities, fewer seeds per fruit, and a heavier average seed weight. Multivariate analyses detected 3 geographic clusters of populations having similar fruit and seed morphology. In most cases, the population in which individual families are located could not be accurately determined based on fruit and seed morphology. However, the accuracy with which individual families could be identified as having come from one of these geographic regions was much higher. Implications for nursery procedures and reforestation programmes are discussed, together with possible explanations for the observed differences.

index.de: forest trees\fruits\genetic variation\quality\seed quality\seed size\seeds\size\temporal variation\trees\woody plants

bibl.et: Instruments for a new management policy for federal aid to Swiss forestry.
bibl.ft: Instrumente für eine neue forstliche Subventionspolitik des Bundes.
bibl.ms: in text
bibl.aa: BUWAL, Eidg. Forstdirektion, CH-3003 Bern, Switzerland.

ab.p: As a concrete example of the current trend in government reform, the new subsidy policy for Swiss forestry borrows and adapts tools from the field of public management science. In particular, it has developed the 'programme contract' as the key instrument. This has the advantage of regarding the federal government and the cantons as partners in the planning and monitoring of forestry measures. The respective roles are more precisely differentiated. The federal government places the emphasis on the national dimension and on strategic control, while the canton manages the local and operational levels. Classic forestry projects, which are essentially local in character, are entirely the cantons' responsibility. The federal government puts the accent on a larger entity: the programme as a whole. The understanding between the two partners will apply to the goals to be achieved rather than the action to be taken. The cantons will be given greater room for manoeuvre in both material and financial respects. An attempt will be made to pay for services by way of an (all-inclusive) price instead of reimbursing the cost. The latter will be the business of the forestry contractor. Effectiveness will be monitored through a system of project planning by objectives. Monitoring of efficiency will be ensured by systematising the cost-benefit analysis procedure. The 'beneficiary pays' principle will be developed.

index.de: administration\finance\forest administration\forest economics\forest management\forest policy\forests\government\management\subsidies

bibl.et: Structural analysis of four stands in transition to selection forest.
bibl.ft: Strukturanalyse in vier Plenterüberführungsbeständen.
bibl.aa: Institut für Forsteinrichtung und Ertragskunde der Universität Göttingen, Büsgenweg 5, D-37077 Göttingen, Germany.

ab.p: Stand characteristics are analysed for four stands in the La Joux Pélichet forest, Switzerland, which was established on pasture land in the 1900s. The stands were originally planted, as mixtures of conifers (60 to 70%) and broadleaves, with Picea abies, Abies alba, Fagus sylvatica the dominant species. Three of the stands have developed two- and three-stories, and are in an advanced transitional position with regards to selection forest criteria. The fourth stand type is predominantly P. abies, with no understorey.

bibl.do: Revista Brasileira de Ciência do Solo
bibl.et: Sampling standardisation for nutritional diagnosis and variations in nutrient concentrations of Pinus taeda L.: I. Macronutrients.
bibl.ft: Padronização de amostragem para diagnose nutricional e variações nas concentrações de nutrientes nas acículas de Pinus taeda L.: I. Macronutrientes.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Ciências Florestais, ESALQ/USP, Caixa Postal 9, CEP 13418-900 Piracicaba, SP, Brazil.

ab.p: Variations in N, P, K, Ca, Mg and S concentrations were determined in (1) current (6 months old), and (2) mature (12 months old) needles collected in upper (S), middle (M) and lower (I) thirds of the crown from 6- and 11-yr-old Pinus taeda trees, in the summer and winter seasons of 1992, in the county of Telêmaco Borba, Paraná, Brazil. The mean concentration ranges of nutrients in the needles were 15-21 g kg-1 for N, 0.9-1.4 g kg-1 for P, 3.4-6.8 g kg-1 for K, 1.1-4.4 g kg-1 for Ca, 0.6-1.2 g kg-1 for Mg, and 0.9-1.5 g kg-1 for S. The results indicated that in general, sampling for nutritional diagnosis of macronutrients in 6- or 11-yr-old P. taeda should be done on about 30 trees, selected in all diameter classes, on the following criteria: for N, P and K, in the position/needle age S 1, during the winter; for Ca, I 1, during the summer; for Mg, M 1, during the summer; and for S, S 2, during the winter. A practical compromise, that restricts sampling to one age of foliage, one position of the crown and one period of time, is to collect current needles from the upper crown (S 1) in 46 trees, during the winter season.

bibl.et: Feeding by vertebrate herbivores in a chemically heterogeneous environment.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Biología Animal y Ecología, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de Granada, E-18071 Granada, Spain.

ab.p: An investigation was conducted during February 1988 and March 1994 to study the constraints that food quality imposes on feeding decisions in 3 free-ranging herbivores feeding on winter twigs of the mountain birch (Betula pubescens ssp. tortuosa [Betula tortuosa]) in the Abisko Mountains, Sweden. Comparison was made between two sites, one at the treeline (600 m above sea level) and the other in a birch wood (380 m above sea level). The concentrations of secondary compounds (phenols) and N varied with respect to twig diameter, among individual trees and between sites, higher phenol and N concentrations being recorded at the treeline site and in thinner twigs. Faeces and urine of the mountain hare (Lepus timidus) and faeces of the willow grouse (Lagopus lagopus) showed the same site difference in phenol and N concentrations as found in the birch, with higher concentrations at the treeline. Faeces of the moose (Alces alces) did not exhibit the same pattern. These differences are discussed in relation to the size of eaten twigs, digestive strategies, and mobility of the species studied. It is suggested that spatial variation in quality may be of greater importance than variation in quantity for small herbivores such as the willow grouse and mountain hare, whereas larger animals may be less responsive to variation in quality.

bibl.et: Analyzing the urban-wildland interface with GIS: two case studies.
bibl.aa: College of Forest Resources, 1123 G Anderson Hall, University of Washington, Seattle 98195, USA.

ab.p: The application of geographic information systems (GIS) and remote sensing technology (Landsat imagery) to identify patterns of forest health and fragmentation at the urban-forest interface is discussed, with particular reference to 2 studies conducted in the Pacific NW region of the USA (one from downtown Seattle to the Cascade mountains and the other in Eugene, Oregon). Both studies involved environmental gradient analysis of the interface between urban area and forest using satellite imagery to assess vegetation cover and urban density variables. Results from the studies are analysed on a variety of scales, and the practical applications of such modelling is discussed.

bibl.et: The sensitivity of greater spotted woodpeckers (Dendrocopos major) to odours.
bibl.aa: Biologicheskii˘ Fakultet, MGU, Moscow, Russia.

ab.p: Ethological experiments were made in nature with 4 pairs of woodpeckers nesting in aspen [Populus tremula] and one pair nesting in an old oak [Quercus robur]. Two different odours were applied near the nest hole, viz. catmint leaves (Nepeta cataria) and cat's urine. Differences in the birds' responses to the two different odours were observed, and also behavioural differences by the individual birds.

bibl.et: Tree growth after trenching and compensatory crown pruning.
bibl.aa: The Morton Arboretum, 4100 Illinois Route 53, Lisle, IL 60532, USA.

ab.p: The roots of pin oak (Quercus palustris) trees were severed by trenching on 1, 2, or 3 sides the tree. The trees were 29 cm average diameter at breast height, growing at the Morton Arboretum, Illinois. The distance between the stem and the trenches was approximately equal to the stem girth. Half of the trees also received compensatory crown pruning. All trees survived and significant dieback was noted only on trees that were trenched on 3 sides. Generally, the more extensive the trenching, the greater the growth reduction and dieback, and the longer the reduction persisted. Compensatory pruning increased twig growth for all trenching treatments, but seemed to be most beneficial in reducing dieback after severe root loss from trenching. Under certain circumstances and in the absence of other damage on construction sites, vigorous trees may be able to tolerate and recover from trenching in the root zone.

bibl.et: Nutritional quality of glyphosate-injured browse for moose in Maine.
bibl.aa: Department of Wildlife Ecology, 5755 Nutting Hall, University of Maine, Orono, Maine 04469, USA.

ab.p: The nutritional quality of glyphosate-injured and uninjured twigs (current annual growth) from red maple (Acer rubrum) and white birch (Betula papyrifera), two abundant and commonly used winter foods of moose (Alces alces) in Maine, was compared 17 months after treatment of naturally regenerating clear-cuts. For red maple, neutral and acid detergent fibre (NDF and ADF) concentrations were 18% less, and lignin-cutin was 8% greater in injured than uninjured twigs. Predicted digestible dry matter (DDM) and digestible energy (DE) values were 7% greater in injured than uninjured twigs. Crude protein concentrations were low in red maple overall, but were greater in injured than uninjured twigs. In contrast, for birch, NDF and ADF concentrations were 6 and 8% greater and DDM and DE values were 8-11% less in injured than uninjured twigs. Lignin-cutin concentration was greater in injured than uninjured twigs. Crude protein content was not affected by injury in birch. Differences in the nature and magnitude of effects on nutritional quality for these two browse species demonstrates that there is not a generalized response to glyphosate injury. While measurable effects on nutritional quality of browse exist, absolute differences were generally small and may not represent important effects on diet quality of moose.

bibl.et: Feeding specialization of two species of bats and the fruit quality of Piper arboreum in a central Brazilian gallery forest.
bibl.aa: Departamento de Ecologia, Instituto de Biologia, Universidade de Brasília, Brasília, DF, 70910-900, Brazil.

ab.p: Two widespread bats (Carollia perspicillata and Glossophaga soricina) were the main consumers of P. arboreum fruits in a gallery forest near Brasilia. The success of their specialization relates to their high efficiency in locating ripe fruits, which occur at low densities. The relatively long fruiting season enabled the bats to specialize on the fruits for about one month. The nutritive value of the fruits is low but the nutritional content and volume consumed are enough to supply the metabolic requirements of C. perspicillata.

bibl.av: Ma, X. L.\Lu, G. M.\Xu, Z. L.\Song, Z. M.\Meng, P.\Zhang, J. S.
bibl.et: Distribution characteristic of the root system of forest belt and crop within the composite system of agriculture and forestry.
bibl.aa: College of Resources and Environment, China Agricultural University, China.

ab.p: The distribution of root systems of a poplar [Populus] forest belt and winter wheat in a composite system was investigated. The horizontal distribution of the root system of the forest belt stretched to 1.5H (where H is tree height). Within a distance of 0.5H, the root system of trees was prevalent. More than 90% was distributed in the soil layer at depths of 0-100 cm, mainly in the 20-60 cm range. The root system of wheat was reduced with increasing proximity to the forest belt. The root system was mainly situated in the soil layer at depths of 0-20 cm. Soil moisture and shade are also considered.

bibl.aa: Forstliche Versuchs- und Forschungsanstalt Baden-Württemberg, 79100 Freiburg, Germany.

ab.p: Details are given of the sampling and recording procedure devised for studying forest structure (including the spatial distribution of dead and living trees, and the spatial distribution of all the vegetation layers) in forest protection areas and reserves in Germany. Full instructions are presented for all the field-recording operations using the MICRONIC M900 data-recorder.

bibl.et: Natural regeneration of hardwood and softwood tree species following full-tree harvesting in northwestern Ontario.
bibl.pb: Natural Resources Canada, Canadian Forest Service, Ontario Region
bibl.aa: Earthworks Forest Consulting, P.O. Box 4, Paradise, Nova Scotia, B0S 1R0, Canada.

ab.p: Throughout north western Ontario (Canada) 71 clear-cut sites, which had been full-tree harvested between 1979 and 1986, were sampled in 1993 and 1994 for ingress of natural regeneration. Sampled sites were stratified by seedbed condition and the preharvest vegetation type that they supported, based on the north western Ontario Forest Ecosystem Classification. Seedbeds were classified as either intact/mixed forest floor or scalped/mineral soil exposed. Vegetation types were amalgamated into ecologically similar groups or treatment units, which included: jack pine (Pinus banksiana)/shrub rich, jack pine/feather moss, and black spruce (Picea mariana) jack pine/feather moss. The majority of the sites surveyed were classified as black spruce-jack pine/feather moss with intact/mixed forest floor seedbeds. Both the rate of natural ingress over the first 7 years of the stands development and the resultant stand structure and composition were examined. Large amounts of ingress were found on all site types. Average total stem densities ranged from 15&thin;000 to 20&thin;000 stems/ha 10 years after harvest, but were quite variable. Among treatment units jack pine always exhibited the highest average densities, although it was significantly more frequent than other tree species only on the jack pine/feather moss treatment unit. Black spruce was found at significantly higher densities on black spruce-jack pine/feather moss sites, whereas poplar (Populus spp.) was found at significantly higher densities on jack pine/shrub rich sites. Rate of ingress was based on the first 7 years after harvest for all sites. On average ingress of natural regeneration continued for 5.5 years following harvest and a minimum of 4 years elapsed before ingress was complete on any site. There were no significant differences in the rate of ingress for any treatment unit, species or seedbed combination.

bibl.et: Development of the Hessian forest planning after the war.
bibl.ft: Entwicklung der Hessischen Forsteinrichtung in der Nachkriegszeit.
bibl.aa: Hessische Landesanstalt für Forsteinrichtung, Waldforschung und Waldökologie, Abteilung Forsteinrichtung, Flächen, Karten, Giessen, Germany.

ab.p: The Hessische Forsteinrichtungs- und Versuchsanstalt [Hessian Agency of Forest Management Planning, Forest Research and Forest Ecology] has been responsible for forest planning in the state forest of Hesse and the communal forest in the district of Darmstadt, Germany, since 1949. Communal and community forests in other districts were included after 1970. Forest inventories and planning were concentrated on growth and yield, and maximizing profits. Ecological aspects, protection and recreation effects, success studies, the planning of capacity for work and finances, control of timber quota, regeneration, forest tending and protection were included later. The use of data processing led to rationalization and an increasing level of information.

bibl.et: LÖWE - a change for butterflies. The programme for long-term ecological forest development (LÖWE) in the State Forest Administration Office of Niedersachsen can save endangered butterfly species of forests.
bibl.ft: LÖWE - eine Change für Schmetterlinge. Das Programm zur langfristigen, ökologischen Waldentwicklung (LÖWE) in den niedersächsischen Landesforsten kann vom Aussterben bedrohte Schmetterlingsarten des Waldes retten.

ab.p: The long-term ecological forest development programme (LÖWE) of the State Forest Administration Office in Niedersachsen, Germany, is described. LÖWE defines types of forest development and supports the conservation of endangered fauna. The life history and necessary biotopes are described of endangered butterfly [Lepidoptera] species, including poplar admiral (Limenitis populi), purple emperor (Apatura iris), lesser purple emperor (Apatura ilia) and camberwell beauty (Nymphalis antiopa). Harmful silvicultural measures are revealed and appropriate measures for improving butterfly habitats are described. Large populations of deer, boar and ram hinder regional LÖWE targets and inhibit the regeneration of desired soft wood species.

bibl.et: Experiences of afforestation of farmland.
bibl.ft: Erfahrungen eines landwirtschaftlichen Betriebs bei der Aufforstung von Ackerflächen.
bibl.aa: Bayerische Fortsamts Griesbach, Rottal, Germany.

ab.p: The experiences of a young farmer by the afforestation of 70 ha of farmland in Germany are described. The decision to afforestation was influenced by EU subsidies and the difficult situation on the agricultural commodities market. The measures were greeted by nature and countryside preservation organisations and opposed by neighbouring farms and hunters. The afforestation was with broadleaf trees. Aspects of working techniques, organization, silviculture and business management and the development after 4 years are discussed.

bibl.do: Forest Research Report - Ontario Forest Research Institute
bibl.et: Promotion of cone production on field-grown grafts of eastern white pine by gibberellin A4/7 injection.
bibl.aa: Ontario Forest Research Institute, P.O. Box 969, 1235 Queen Street East Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, P6A 5N5, Canada.

ab.p: Six and 11 year old eastern pine (Pinus strobus L.) grafts growing in a breeding orchard were stem-injected once every 2 weeks with gibberellin A4/7 for a total of 4 times in each of 3 periods. Injection began from the period of rapid elongation of the first order lateral shoots (May) until a month and half after elongation ended (September). May-June treatments significantly increased pollen- and seed-cone production. June-August treatments did not affect pollen- and seed-cone production. August-September treatments inhibited seed-cone production but did not affect pollen-cone production. The results of 2 consecutive studies indicate that best pollen- and seed-cone production are achieved with gibberellin treatments in May and June, during the period of rapid lateral shoot elongation.

bibl.et: Macrofungi in Central German floodplain forests.
bibl.ct: Special issue. Floodplain forests: structure, functioning and management. Selected papers from a conference held at Leicester University in March 1995.
bibl.aa: Center for Environmental Reseach Leipzig-Halle Ltd, Department of Community Ecology, Hallesche Str. 44, D-06246 Bad Lauchstädt, Germany.

ab.p: Within ten floodplain forest fragments of the Alno-Ulmion complex situated near the rivers Weisse Elster and Saale in central Germany, the mycocoenosis was investigated from 1993 to 1995 on the basis of fruiting body phenology. The major part of the mycocoenosis was formed by saprophytic species, which are important for the fast degradation of organic material in the floodplain forests. In areas where forestry activities had left dead stems and branches of trees, lignicolous species formed the main feature of the fungal communities. Ectomycorrhizal fungi, which are important elements of the mycocoenosis of other temperate forest types, were represented in these systems by specialists, bound to typical ectotrophic plants within floodplains or to regular disturbance. Relatively few ectomycorrhizal species were found, and they were represented by species with mostly small ephemeral fruiting bodies which occurred with very low abundance within the floodplains.

index.de: bottomland forests\decay fungi\ectomycorrhizas\floodplains\forest ecology\forest fragmentation\forests\fragmentation\mycorrhizal fungi\wood destroying fungi

bibl.et: Biogeomorphology and diversity in multiple-channel river systems.
bibl.ct: Special issue. Floodplain forests: structure, functioning and management. Selected papers from a conference held at Leicester University in March 1995.
bibl.aa: Geography Department, University of Exeter, Exeter EX4 4RJ U.K.

ab.p: An examination is made of the causes of the high biodiversity of wooded alluvial floodplains in Europe. Multiple-channel floodplain forests have high ecotone/area ratios as a result of long stream lengths of channel banks and the presence of gravel/sand bars and palaeochannels. There is evidence that the multiple-channel state is a natural state for NW European floodplains prior to deforestation and channelization. One of the last semi-natural forested floodplains in Europe, the Gearagh in SW Ireland, illustrates the processes which maximize floodplain biodiversity. Of particular importance are structural factors including windthrow, which increases microtopographic variation and adds irregularity to river morphology. The complexity of the system allows the co-existence of organisms with rather different ecological requirements, an example being invertebrates characteristic of both lowland and upland rivers. The system is characterized by interactions between biological and geomorphological processes, with channel pattern and functioning being partially controlled by ecological processes which further increase the diversity of this relatively stable homeostatic system. It is argued that through the re-creation of multiple channels, floodplain diversity can be appreciably increased and maintained. This approach is compatible with the use of floodplains for flood storage and could, therefore, be a component of flood relief schemes.

index.de: aquatic communities\aquatic invertebrates\biodiversity\bottomland forests\channels\community ecology\flood control\floodplains\forests\geomorphology\hydrology\rivers\water management\wind damage

bibl.do: AFZ/Der Wald, Allgemeine Forst Zeitschrift fur Waldwirtschaft und Umweltvorsorge
bibl.et: Forest soil rehabilitation by activating ecosystem nutrient cycles.
bibl.ft: Waldbodenrestauration durch Aktivierung ökosystemarer Nährstoffkreislätfe.
bibl.aa: Forstliche Versuchsanstalt Rheinland-Pflaz, 67705 Trippstadt, Germany.

ab.p: On the basis of research in Germany, a set of principles is outlined for rehabilitating forest soils that have suffered acidification and loss of bases. These principles are based on biological processes, viz. creating a largely closed nutrient cycle involving the deeper mineral soil, creating a chemical environment throughout the whole mineral-soil rooting layer which avoids damage to fine roots, and ensuring adequate nutrient availability in the mineral soil. Examples are given of various silvicultural and chemical measures to rehabilitate forest soils by activating ecosystem nutrient cycles.

bibl.et: Genetical and physiological basis for forest operations in young oak stands of Quercus robur and Quercus petraea.
bibl.ft: Baze genetice s¸la;i fiziologice ale operat¸la;iumilor culturale în arborete tinere de stejar s¸la;i gorun.
bibl.aa: Universitatea "Transilvania", Bras¸la;ov.

ab.p: Studies were conducted in Romania between 1986-1991 to determine the type, intensity and periodicity of forestry practices required in 25-30 year old Quercus robur and Q. petraea stands. Data on phenotypical intraspecific variability, position in the stand, leaf flushing period, precocity or tardiness of leaf fall, tree diameter, transpiration, respiration, photosynthesis and water use are briefly discussed and tabulated for each species.

bibl.et: Location optimizing of transverse hydrotechnical works by a combined based on the graph theory.
bibl.ft: Optimizarea amplasa˘rii lucra˘rilor hidrotehnice transversale printr-un procedeu combinat, bazat pe teoria grafurilor.
bibl.aa: Universitatea Transilvania - Bras¸la;ov.

ab.p: Physical and economic constraints to the provision of appropriate flows from dams in Romania are briefly considered. The use of the 'graph theory' which includes topographical measurements of torrential watersheds, tracing of both longitudinal and transversal profiles, topography of the hydraulic characteristics of cross sections, and tracing the variation curves of cross section surfaces in relation to the measured depth up to the thalweg is described. After the identification of the limits and volume of alluvial deposits, and of vegetation 'knots', decision are made for the appropriate location and height of the dam. This computer method was tested with promising results on a torrential watershed near the city of Bras¸la;ov.

bibl.et: Ecological amplitudes of Ecuadorian palms.
bibl.aa: Institute of Biological Sciences, University of Aarhus, Department of Systematic Botany, Herbarium, Universitetsparken Building 137, DK-8000 Aarhus C, Denmark.

ab.p: A list of the 129 palm taxa presently recorded in Ecuador is presented, together with information on their ecological amplitude. The information was derived from a database containing details about more than 1900 herbarium specimens. The table includes, for each species, number of records, altitude, annual precipitation rate and temperature humidity index and tolerance of the dry season. Of the 29 palms, 98 (76%) require a mean annual temperature of ≥18°c and 58 (45%) more than 23°c. Only 39 taxa were able to tolerate a dry season, while 76 were restricted to areas where annual precipitation is at least twice as high as potential evapotranspiration.

bibl.aa: HC-33 Box 3208-L, Wasilla, Alaska 99654, USA.

ab.p: The use of palm nuts or seeds as a medium for arts and crafts is described, particularly when turned on a wood lathe. Anatomical and physical properties, and suitability for use is discussed for the following palm genera: Actinorhytis, Areca, Bismarckia, Hyphaene, Mauritia, Metroxylon, Normanbya, Oenocarpus, Orania, the subfamily Phytelephantoideae, Raphia, Veitchia, Verschaffeltia and Wodyetia. A practical guide to nut-turning is provided, including instructions for making a round box and turning a Tagua nut vase.

bibl.av: Hu, B. Z.\Li, J.\Gui, M. Z.\Li, G. Q.\Xu, L. J.
bibl.do: Journal of Northeast Agricultural University (English Edition)
bibl.et: Anatomical structure of root and root nodule of Alnus sibirica - host of Boschniakia rossica.
bibl.aa: Northeast Agricultural University, Harbin 150030, China.

ab.p: Boschniakia rossica is a parasitic rare medicinal herb which uses Alnus sibirica as a host. As part of a study of the host parasite relationship, this paper reports anatomical studies on the host root and root nodules. The root of Alnus sibirica is rich in tissue types. Phloem fibres are prominent and plasmodesmata are well developed. The number of primary xylem bunches is not stable - there are triarch, tetrarch and pentarch types. Vessel perforation plates are scalariform. The rays are radial in shape and unicellular in structure. In the root nodule (which is branched) the cortex is the best developed structure and the stele is small. Actinomycetes proliferate extensively in the root nodule tissues, and have different body shapes.

bibl.do: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological Sciences
bibl.et: Do fossil plants signal palaeoatmospheric CO2 concentration in the geological past?
bibl.aa: Department of Animal and Plant Sciences, University of Sheffield, Western Bank, Sheffield S10 2TN, UK.

ab.p: Fossil, subfossil, and herbarium leaves have been shown to provide a morphological signal of the atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) environment in which they developed by means of their stomatal density and index. An inverse relationship between stomatal density/index and atmospheric CO2 concentration has been documented for all the studies to date concerning fossil and subfossil material. Furthermore, this relationship has been demonstrated experimentally by growing plants under elevated and reduced CO2 concentrations. To date, the mechanism that controls the stomatal density response to atmospheric CO2 concentration remains unknown. However, stomatal parameters of fossil plants have been successfully used as a proxy indicator of palaeo-CO2 levels. This paper presents new estimates of palaeoatmospheric CO2 concentrations for the Middle Eocene (Lutetian), based on the stomatal ratios of fossil Lauraceae species from Bournemouth in England. Estimates of atmospheric CO2 concentrations derived from stomatal data from plants of the Early Devonian, Late Carboniferous, Early Permian and Middle Jurassic ages are reviewed in the light of new data. Semi-quantitative palaeo-CO2 estimates based on the stomatal ratio (a ratio of the stomatal index of a fossil plant to that of a selected nearest living equivalent) have in the past relied on the use of a Carboniferous standard. The application of a new standard based on the present-day CO2 level is reported here for comparison. The resultant ranges of palaeo-CO2 estimates made from standardized fossil stomatal ratio data are in good agreement with both carbon isotopic data from terrestrial and marine sources and long-term carbon cycle modelling estimates for all the time periods studied. These data indicate elevated atmospheric CO2 concentrations during the Early Devonian, Middle Jurassic and Middle Eocene, and reduced concentrations during the Late Carboniferous and Early Permian. Such data are important in demonstrating the long-term responses of plants to changing CO2 concentrations and in contributing to the database needed for general circulation model climatic analogues.

bibl.et: Environmental emissions from two wood-treating operations.
bibl.aa: Battelle Columbus Operations, Columbus, Ohio, U.S.A.

ab.p: This study compared environmental emissions from a wood-treating plant using ammoniacal copper/quaternary ammonium compound, Type B formulation (ACQ-B) as an alternative wood preservative to chromated copper arsenate (CCA). The most obvious change in environmental emissions was the elimination of arsenic (As) and chromium (Cr), which eliminated the generation of Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) wastes and the risk of contaminating the environment with these RCRA-regulated metals. ACQ-B, however, produced a greater amount of air emissions, mainly as ammonia (NH3). Wood products treated with either preservative demonstrated leachable characteristics. The amounts of active ingredients leached were estimated based on exposure of treated rough-cut timber to about 114 mm of artificial rainfall 4 days after treatment.

bibl.av: Li, X. C.\Huang, L. B.\Wang, W.
bibl.do: Journal of Jiangsu Forestry Science & Technology
bibl.et: Evaluation of the economics of different silvicultural systems for Chinese fir.
bibl.aa: Forestry Science Research Institute of Jiangsu, Nanjing 211153, China.

ab.p: An analysis was made of the production and economics of Chinese fir [Cunninghamia lanceolata] over short (12-15 yr) and longer (19-26 yr) rotations in a hilly area in south Jiangsu. The shorter rotation gave a higher production and returns than the longer one - production was 58.3% more at 15 than at 26 yr on a site index of 14 m height, and equivalent annual land value, internal rate of return and benefit cost ratio were 5.24×, 16.65% and 2.15× greater. For a a site index of 12 m height, and comparing 12 and 19 yr rotations, the respective production/economic values were 12.2%, 1.64×, 4.41% and 1.3× . The shorter rotations gave similar production/economic values to a stump sprout regeneration at 10 yr old.

bibl.do: Mokuzai Gakkaishi = Journal of the Japan Wood Research Society
bibl.et: Influence of frequency and decrement on psychological images of wood tapping sound. Investigation using computer synthesizing.
bibl.ms: English figures and tables.
bibl.aa: Graduate School of Agriculture, Kyoto University, Kyoto 606-01, Japan.

ab.p: To investigate why the sound of tapping on wood gives a 'natural' image, sounds with different frequencies and different decrements were synthesized with computers. Psychological images of the sounds were judged by subjects, using the paired comparison method. In the case of sine wave sounds consisting of one frequency and no decrement, subjects preferred lower frequency sounds for 'natural' images. However, in the case of sounds with one frequency and fast decrement, the nearer to 500 Hz the frequency was, the more 'natural' it was judged by subjects. This result is in good agreement with the frequency ranges and decrement rates of xylophones and marimbas. It also indicates that the influences of the frequency and decrement upon the psychological images are different from each other.

bibl.do: Proceedings of the Estonian Academy of Sciences, Biology
bibl.et: Air pollution deposition impact on the structure of bryophyte cover in Scots pine forests in Estonia.
bibl.aa: Rahvusvaheline Keskkonnabioloogia Keskus (International Centre for Environmental Biology), P.O. Box 676, EE-0026 Tallinn, Estonia.

ab.p: The distribution and structure of moss synusiae in Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris) forests (Vaccinium site type pine stands) along the environmental pollution gradient from NE (more polluted) to SW of Estonia was studied. The synusiae can be divided into two groups: (1) Synusiae whose distribution depends on the level of pollution. This group can be subdivided into 1a, the frequency is increasing on plots with higher pH values of the O horizon and 1b, the frequency is increasing on plots with lower pH values (typical of this type of forests); (2) Synusiae whose distribution is not directly affected by air pollution, the effect of phytocoenological, soil, and climatic factors being more important. The structure of the bryophyte cover depends on the level of air pollution stress. In Estonia the general tendency of the thickness of bryophyte cover is to increase from NE to SW in all the synusiae. The thickness of both living and dead parts of bryophytes is substantially lower in the polluted NE part of the air pollution deposition gradient. The thickness of the soil O horizon is notably lower in NE than in SW. The biomass of bryophytes by synusiae shows small differences along the air pollution deposition gradient. It has a tendency to decrease towards the polluted NE only in a few synusiae.

bibl.do: Proceedings of the Estonian Academy of Sciences, Biology
bibl.et: The impact of different factors on the increment of Vaccinium-type pine stands in Tallinn.
bibl.aa: Rahvusvaheline Keskkonnabioloogia Keskus (International Centre for Environmental Biology), P.O. Box 676, EE-0026 Tallinn, Estonia.

ab.p: The impact of climatic, edaphic, and anthropogenic factors and stand parameters on the additional volume increment (AVI) of Vaccinium-type pine (Pinus sylvestris) stands in Tallinn was studied. A significant negative impact of low current year winter temperatures on the radial increment and on AVI was detected. Among the soil parameters only the thickness of the forest litter horizon had a significant positive impact on the formation of AVI. Of anthropogenic factors, the recreational pressure, expressed as the relative size of trampled area, reduces the AVI of stands of all age classes. Besides this, in age class III the pH of snow water and in age class IV the sulfur content of needles proved to be factors substantially diminishing AVI. A significant impact of stand parameters on the formation of AVI was apparent only in the case of stands of age class IV. A negative effect of stand age and a favourable effect of a thick understorey were detected. An analysis of the co-effect of all the investigated factors showed recreational pressure to be the most essential factor.

bibl.do: Introduction to plant diseases: identification and management.
bibl.et: Introduction to plant diseases: identification and management.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Pathology, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC, USA.

ab.p: This elementary textbook first published in 1985, provides practical information on the management of diseases of food, fibre and landscape plants. Chapters are devoted to agriculture, plant diseases and human history; causes of plant diseases; history of plant pathology; development of plant diseases; integrated pest management; management of plant diseases; chemical management of plant diseases; biotechnology; nematodes; diseases caused by nematodes; fungi; diseases caused by soilborne fungi; diseases caused by airborne fungi; fungal diseases of shade and forest trees and decay in wood; bacteria; diseases caused by bacteria and mycoplasma; viruses; diseases caused by viruses; diseases caused by parasitic plants; and abiotic agents. New information is given on the precise identification of diseases and the pathogens that cause them, the development of epidemics of plant diseases, the application of biotechnology in plant pathology, the use of alternative methods of crop production and disease management that help protect the environment, and diseases that have become more important since the first edition was published. There is a glossary, a list of suggested readings and an index.

The remaining 8 chapters address plantation establishment, management and use: (6) Establishment and management - mostly sowing and planting stock production, with a small section on management; (7) Growth and development; (8) Biomass and yield; (9) Felling cycle and fertilizer application; (10) Introduction of social forestry - strip planting, community forestry, limitations, agroforestry, rehabilitation of degraded forest, afforestation, reclamation of waste land; (11) Need for raising bamboo plantation - with reference to use as raw material for the pulp and paper industry; (12) Problems and prospects of bamboo plantations - with regard to cultivation and socioeconomic aspects; and (13) Utilization - consumption pattern in India, and uses as parquet, laminates, in aircraft, concrete reinforcement, growing in artificial shapes, and as raw material for phytosterols.
