bibl.et: Factors influencing species composition in tropical lowland rain forest: does soil matter?
bibl.aa: Forest Science Department, Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR 97331, USA.

ab.p: The soil properties most likely to influence species composition in lowland tropical rain forests are, in decreasing order of importance: P availability, Al toxicity, drainage, water-holding capacity, and availability of K, Ca, and Mg. A total of 18 studies were examined in which species occurrence was studied in relation to such soil properties. Several of these demonstrated clear trends with soil physical properties, mainly drainage, as affected by topographic position. Only three studies provided evidence for correlations with soil chemical properties. In all three, the study area spanned soils of very widely differing age and soil fertility. Failure to find correlations with chemical properties may be due to: lack of range in soil fertility across the sites studied, failure of soil test methods to measure availability of nutrients to plants, or temporal and spatial variability in soil properties. Existing soil classification systems do not provide enough information on any particular soil to help establish relations between its chemical properties and plant distribution. Nonetheless, soils at ecological study sites must be classified if their nature and properties are to be made clear to others working worldwide. Traditional, largely subjective, soil-mapping techniques may reduce sampling needs by allowing stratification of soil and plant sampling by broad soil types. The mapping must be done, however, at a scale similar to the patchiness of the plant community (usually finer than 1:5000), something done in only 3 of the 18 studies examined. Correlative studies were considered only the first step in understanding causal relations between soil properties and plant species distribution. Next, nutritional, drainage, and water requirements may be established for individual species. Then field experiments may be set up to establish cause and effect.

index.de: botanical composition\drainage\forest soils\forest trees\forests\phosphorus\plant communities\rain forests\reviews\soil classification\soil fertility\soil properties\species diversity\synecology\trees\tropical forests\tropical rain forests\tropics\woody plants

bibl.et: Long-term dynamics of small-mammal populations in Ontario.
bibl.aa: University of Guelph, Guelph, Ontario, N1G 2W1, Canada.

ab.p: Forty-three years of live-trapping data for eight species of small mammals in Algonquin Provincial Park, Ontario, Canada, were analysed. The common tree species included Acer saccharum, Alnus rugosa, Acer rubrum, Populus tremuloides, Abies balsamea, Picea glauca and Picea mariana. The primary objective was to test whether complex non linear models are necessary to describe the dynamics of the Algonquin rodent populations. Variation in abundance among species was related to mean abundance by a simple power function with an exponent of 1.77, implying that population variability did not increase with mean density as much as one might expect for strictly statistical reasons. Time-series analyses of annual population densities indicated no significant autocorrelation functions for five species. Southern red-backed voles (Clethrionomys gapperi), red squirrels (Tamiasciurus hudsonicus), and northern flying squirrels (Glaucomys sabrinus) had significant autocorrelations, but only northern flying squirrels had an autocorrelation function suggestive of cyclic population dynamics. Per capita rates of population growth were density-dependent in all eight species, although in most cases there was substantial deviation around the fitted regression lines. Response surface models with one- and two-year lags significantly improved the statistical fit to data for three species, but only one of these response surface models was sustainable in the face of realistic stochastic variation in per capita growth. These results suggest that simple logistic models are adequate for predicting the long-term dynamics of the Algonquin small-mammal assemblage. All eight species showed evidence of synchronized population fluctuations over time, suggesting trophic linkages due to shared food resources, shared predators, or both.

bibl.et: Value of fruits and seeds from the floodplain forests of central Amazonia as food resource for fish.
bibl.aa: Botanisches Institut der Universität Kiel, D-24098 Kiel, Germany.

ab.p: The floodplain forests of Central Amazonia are heavily influenced by the periodic fluctuation of the water level. The regular change between the terrestrial and aquatic phase in the forests has an impact on fruit-shedding as well as on many fish species: during inundation, which lasts for months, fish migrate into flooded forests to feed on fruits and seeds shed by trees and bushes in an area more than 300&thin;000 km² in size. For the region near Manaus, Amazonia, Brazil, the nutritional value and chemical composition were determined of 19 fruits and seeds of those species used by fish as food, and of an additional 11 species which probably serve or could serve as fish food. The amount of fruits shed in one biota was determined for 4 species (Vitex cymosa, Psidium acutangulum, Ilex inundata and Pouteria glomerata), and the percentage of different fish catches with fruits as stomach content. Total annual production of the whole inundated forest was estimated to be 16-53 million tons of fruits, corresponding to a monetary value of the fish production from the floodplains in the range of US $ 320-530 million. The idea is discussed that since some of the fruits which are preferred by frugivorous fish are abundant in 3 different biotas, it may be possible to use them to feed farmed fish.

bibl.et: Indirect interactions mediated by changing plant chemistry: beaver browsing benefits beetles.
bibl.aa: Department of Biological Sciences, Northern Arizona University, Box 5640, Flagstaff, AZ 86011, USA.

ab.p: An indirect interaction between beavers (Castor canadensis) and leaf beetles (Chrysomela confluens), mediated by changing plant chemistry of their cottonwood hosts (Populus fremontii, P. angustifolia and their hybrid) on the Weber River, Utah, USA, was documented. Resprout growth arising from the stumps and roots of beaver-cut trees contained twice the level of defensive chemicals as normal juvenile growth. However, rather than being repelled by these defences, leaf beetles were attracted to resprout growth, resulting in a strong positive association between beavers and beetles. This was explained by the cottonwoods containing phenolic glycosides, chemicals that are defensive against mammalian herbivores, but are sequestered and used by the beetles for their own defence. Experiments showed that beetles fed resprout growth were better defended against their predators than those fed non-resprout growth. There also may have been a nutritional benefit, because the conversion of the plant's defence, salicin and other phenolic glycosides, to salicylaldehyde releases glucose. Also, resprout growth contained more total N than did non-resprout growth. Transfer experiments showed that, in apparent response to these increased nutritional benefits, beetles fed resprout growth developed faster and weighed more at maturity. Although indirect interactions are much less studied than direct interactions, it is suggested that the indirect interactions resulting from beaver cutting of cottonwoods have important consequences for other organisms and could represent an important component of community structure.

bibl.et: Perspectives of forest genetics and tree breeding in a changing world.
bibl.pb: IUFRO (International Union of Forestry Research Organizations) Secretariat

ab.p: This collection of 13 papers aims to present a current overview of some selected areas of forest tree genetics and tree breeding research, focusing on aspects of practical tree improvement. The papers are grouped into 3 sections: (1) aspects of tree breeding (5 papers); (2) new applications for provenance tests (5 papers); and (3) conservation of forest genetic resources (3 papers).

bibl.et: Effects of environmental change on the productivity of tree populations.
bibl.ct: Perspectives of forest genetics and tree breeding in a changing world
bibl.pb: IUFRO (International Union of Forestry Research Organizations) Secretariat
bibl.aa: University Sopron, Department of Environmental Sciences 9401 Sopron, Pf. 132., Hungary.

ab.p: Although much of climatic adaptation research has been initiated and studied on forest trees by provenance trials, results have failed to capture much attention outside the forestry community. The original goal of provenance experiments was to identify populations or areas of provenance which may provide reproduction material with the most desirable traits for a given region or country. Among other uses, provenance experiments also offer a direct opportunity to assess and forecast effects of environmental (climate) change. Instead of analysing genetic changes in subsequent generations in controlled environments, the observed variation in provenance tests may be interpreted as an adaptive response to changes in climate conditions. The necessary transfer of populations from the location of origin to the test site can be regarded as a simulation of environmental change and the response may be modelled. Spatial (geographic) variation patterns can therefore be interpreted as a simulation of responses to environmental change over time. When comparing the performance of populations across test locations, generalization of results is hindered by response changes modified by local site conditions. In order to enhance the flexibility of data evaluation and interpretation, the use of ecological distances (ecodistances) has been proposed. According to this concept, the quantitative response of populations at different test sites are related to environmental differences between the test site and the location of origin. This concept is examined using data on ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa) populations growing in the Sierra Nevada (California, USA). Results indicate that contrary to the general perception of physiological reaction to environmental change, the response of adapted, local populations is asymmetric due to the manifold constraints of biological regulation. As a consequence, a temperature increase leads to instant growth and productivity loss, and selective mortality.

bibl.et: Growth rate effects on temporal trajectories of ring width, wood density, and mean tracheid length in Norway spruce (Picea abies (L.) Karst.).
bibl.aa: Unité des eaux et forêts, Université catholique de Louvain, Place Croix du Sud 2, bte 9, B-1348 Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium.

ab.p: The study reported was conducted on 20 fast-grown and 20 slow-grown Norway spruce (Picea abies) trees from an even-aged, plantation-grown stand near Rendeux, Belgian Ardennes. The objective was to test whether increasing the growth rate of Norway spruce by heavy thinning had an effect on the temporal trajectories (i.e. fluctuations from year to year) of ring width, wood density, and mean tracheid length, all measured yearly from pith to bark. Since the data were chronologies (i.e. time series of yearly measurements), time had to be considered as a factor in the statistical analysis of the within-tree variation (repeated measures analysis of variance). While the effects of the growth category and its interaction with the year were highly significant after first thinning for ring width, a significant decrease in the wood density of fast-grown trees was observed in many years during that growing period; the decrease was small in magnitude, once averaged over years (-0.033 g/cm³). Tracheids were longer for the slow-grown trees after first thinning; although constant in sign and magnitude over several years, the difference in mean tracheid length between growth categories was not statistically significant. In summary, increasing the growth rate in circumference of Norway spruce from 1.7 to 2.7 cm/year by heavy thinning induced a limited decrease in wood density and mean tracheid length. These results support the statement that stand productivity might be improved without unacceptable loss of wood quality.

index.de: growth rate\growth rings\increment\thinning\tracheids\wood anatomy\wood density\wood properties

bibl.et: Evaluating the subject needs for wood science and forest products curricula.
bibl.aa: Center for Forest Products Marketing and Management, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, WA 24061-0503, USA.

ab.p: Wood Science and Forest Products programs across North America are re evaluating the needs of students and the forest products industry in order to provide the skills necessary to remain competitive in the changing marketplace. While some programs are losing students and even eliminating their wood science curricula, others are increasing enrolment and substantially altering their programs to meet the needs of industry. This research demonstrates how one Wood Science and Forest Products program evaluated and adjusted its curriculum to meet the changing needs of the forest products industry. Graduating seniors, alumni, and employers of alumni were surveyed to evaluate the Wood Science program at Virginia Tech. In this case study, it was found that all stakeholders rated traditional wood science classes as meeting the needs of students and employers, while improvements are needed in business and communication skills.

bibl.et: Habitat preference and food use by Metachirus nudicaudatus and Didelphis aurita (Didelphimorphia, Didelphidae) in a restinga forest at Rio de Janeiro.
bibl.aa: Laboratório de Vertebrados, Departmento de Ecologia, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, C. P. 68020 - 21941-590 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil.

ab.p: The microhabitat characteristics and the feeding habits of Didelphis aurita and Metachirus nudicaudatus were studied in a restinga forest area at Maricá, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in 1987. Thirty-seven microhabitat variables were measured on the 100 grid points set for the study, and analysed by multivariate analyses. The diet of the opossums was determined through the identification of food remains in faeces, which were compared for composition and diversity between the two species. For D. aurita the most important microhabitat variable was litter density. For M. nudicaudatus the most important variables were herbaceous stem density at 20 cm and horizontal estimated obstruction from 1 m to 1.5 m. Both species fed mainly on invertebrates, mostly insects. D. aurita used a wider spectrum of litter invertebrates than M. nudicaudatus, which had a more insectivorous and restricted diet consuming more ants [Formicidae], Isoptera, cockroaches [Blattellidae] and Coleoptera. It is noted that both species use the same available resources. The distribution of D. aurita was linked with the abundance of food resources, while the distribution of M. nudicaudatus was more associated with the structure of its microhabitat.

bibl.et: Shoot proliferation of curly birch (Betula pendula var. carelica) in vitro depends on the explant type.
bibl.aa: Department of Silviculture, Technical University, SK-96053 Zvolen, Slovakia.

ab.p: Three curly birch (Betula pendula var. carelica) explant types - whole plantlets developed in vitro, plantlets with removed apices, and plantlets with removed roots - were cultured on basal and multiplication media with or without 0.5 mg/litre benzyladenine. The best growth of lateral shoots occurred in the presence of exogenously added cytokinin on explants with removed apices. The presence of roots enhanced the number of lateral shoots regardless of the presence or absence of the apex. Root initiation on formed lateral shoots was significantly lower when the shoot length was less than 6 mm. Rooted shoots grew rapidly into vigorous plantlets which could be utilized again for the production of microcuttings with identical genotype in the same year.

ab.p: Factors conditioning the formation of the market with forest estates and forests in Slovakia are discussed. Information on the state and development of the market with these commodities in Austria are presented. Prices of forest estates and forests are illustrated by brief information from other countries. The development of main potential factors of the market with land in Slovakia and the expected development of forest estate prices is given. The possibility of the use of market prices in valuation practices is stressed.

bibl.et: A study of the ground beetles (Carabidae) of Corsican pine plantations in Thetford Forest, eastern England.
bibl.aa: School of Applied Sciences, Anglia Polytechnic University, East Road, Cambridge CB1 1PT, UK.

ab.p: A study of the carabid beetles of Pinus nigra plantations in Thetford Forest in the Breckland region, UK, was conducted. Each year ground beetles were pitfall-trapped for two, 1-week periods over a total of 7 years. 3 sites with plantations of different age were surveyed. Generally, catches were greatest from the 'pole-stage' plantation, representing the middle part of the 50-60 year rotation for Corsican pine. The catch at this site was dominated by one species, Pterostichus madidus. Species richness was generally low at all 3 sites. Only 20 species of ground beetles were recorded in the study. One species, P. angustatus was recorded for the first time in Breckland.

bibl.av: Jia, H. J.\Zheng, H. M.\Hua, X. M.\Li, J. N.\Wan, X. R.
bibl.et: Effects of steady-state mineral nutrition on Pt ectomycorrhizae formation and growth of container-grown seedlings of slash pine.
bibl.aa: Chinese Academy of Forestry Sciences, Beijing 100091, China.

ab.p: Container-grown seedlings of Pinus elliottii inoculated with Pt (Pisolithus tinctorius) ectomycorrhiza were given liquid fertilizer at a nutrient relative addition rate (NRAR) of 0, 5.3, 6.4 or 7.5%, with uninoculated seedlings as controls. Results showed that the seedlings with Pt in the 7.5% NRAR treatment had the greatest increases in plant height, radial growth and dry matter accumulation, which were 26.4, 52.5 and 140.2% higher than in the 0% treatment. Among the seedlings without Pt, those in the 6.4% treatment had greatest increases in plant height, radial growth and dry matter accumulation, which were 21, 16.7 and 54.1% higher than those in the 0% treatment, while those in the 7.5% treatment were lower. Pt ectomycorrhizae were formed in 97% of inoculated seedlings in the 7.5% treatment. The N use rate in inoculated seedlings was 2.7 times higher than that in seedlings without Pt.

bibl.et: Cell ultrastructure of needles from saplings of Norway spruce, Picea abies (L.) Karst., exposed to ozone and low phosphorus supply in open-top chambers.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Finnish Forest Research Institute, Suonenjoki Research Station, FIN-77600, Suonenjoki, Finland.

ab.p: Two-year-old saplings of one clone of Picea abies were exposed to ozone in open-top chambers near Göteborg, Sweden (as part of the Göteborg Ozone-Spruce project). The treatments were: charcoal filtered air (CF); non-filtered air + 1.5 times ambient ozone (NF+); charcoal filtered air and low phosphorus supply (CF/PD); and non-filtered air + ozone and low phosphorus supply (NF+/PD). Ozone exposure was started in 1992 and low phosphorus supply in 1993. Current (C) and 1-yr-old (C+1) needles were sampled on 27 July 1994 for structural studies. Electron microscopy showed that the structure of the mesophyll cells in C and C+1 needles from the CF treatment was intact. Statistically significant ozone-induced changes in ultrastructure were found only in the chloroplasts, all the other organelles were intact. In both ozone treatments the stroma was granulated. The granules were about 1.5 times the size of the chloroplast ribosomes. In the low phosphorus supply treatment changes were seen in the chloroplasts, in the mitochondria, and in the cytoplasm. The mean chloroplast and starch grain areas were significantly increased. In both age classes about 12% and 20% of the mitochondria were injured in the CF/PD and NF+/PD treatments, respectively. Furthermore, the cytoplasm in the C needles from low phosphorus supply treatments was partly disintegrated. The symptoms induced by ozone and low phosphorus supply were clearly distinguishable from each other, also in combined treatments, indicating their diagnostic value.

index.de: air pollution\cell ultrastructure\chloroplasts\cytoplasm\damage\foliage\forest trees\leaves\mesophyll\mitochondria\ozone\phosphorus\plant anatomy\plant composition\plant nutrition\starch\trees\woody plants

bibl.et: Effect of low pH and aluminium on growth of Pinus sylvestris L. seedlings mycorrhizal with Suillus luteus (L. ex Fr.) S.F. Gray.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Polish Academy of Sciences, Institute of Dendrology, Parkowa 5, 62-035 Kórnik, Poland.

ab.p: Pine seedlings were inoculated with Suillus luteus strain No 14 (which is characterized by a high tolerance to Al3+ ions) in semi-sterile culture in peat-perlite medium at pH 3.5 with or without added 4 m&smallcap;M Al3+. Three mycorrhizal morphotypes were distinguished on the pine roots: single, dichotomously branched and coralloid. The coralloid mycorrhizas were rare on plants treated with Al. Mycorrhizal abundance was similar in Al treated and untreated plants. However mycorrhizas from seedlings treated with Al had a thinner mantle and a lack of Hartig net compared with the untreated control. Seedling growth was not reduced by Al3+ treatment. Mycorrhizal formation with the selected S. luteus strain caused a lower Al3+ translocation to the upper part of the Al treated seedlings compared with the nonmycorrhizal control. It may be concluded that the Al3+ ion concentrations that appear in moderately polluted (acidified) fine-root layers of forest soil may under certain conditions negatively influence mycorrhizal formation in young Scots pines.

bibl.et: Relation between genetic structure and susceptibility to air pollution of European Pinus sylvestris populations from a IUFRO-1982 provenance experiment.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Adam Mickiewicz University, Department of Genetics, Mie&hook;dzychodzka 5, PL-60-371 Poznan´, Poland.

ab.p: The results are presented of a study of genetic variation and the relations between genetic parameters and growth, survival and needle necroses of 11 European Pinus sylvestris populations growing in a provenance experiment established in 1984 in western Poland. One site was near a phosphate fertilizer factory, and the other in an area free of acute air pollution. Significant differences were found between the sites in number of alleles per locus, expected and observed heterozygosity, genotype polymorphism indices and tree height. On average all genetic parameters were higher for the polluted site than for the control site. Differences in observed heterozygosity were related to height growth decline and plant mortality.

bibl.et: Biochemical responses to abiotic stress in beech (Fagus sylvatica L.) leaves.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Plant Physiology and Agricultural Chemistry, Univesity of Milan, 20133 Milano, Italy.

ab.p: A series of biochemical assays were carried out on beech leaves at two alpine forest sites (Val Masino and Val Gerola, Italy), characterized by a different degree of visible stress symptoms and by correspondingly different ambient ozone concentrations, in order to evaluate the response of cellular detoxifying systems toward oxidative stress produced by ozone. The tests were done on fully developed leaves before the beginning of autumnal yellowing and senescence [in 1995]. Besides ascorbic acid (AA) levels, the activity of 3 scavenger enzymes (ascorbate peroxidase, AAPOX; superoxide dismutase, SOD; and glutathione reductase, GR) was investigated. While SOD and GR did not exhibit a correlation with oxidative stress symptoms, both AA and AAPOX showed behaviour parallel to the injury symptoms and to the corresponding ozone exposure doses.

bibl.et: Sap-flow velocities and distribution of wet-wood in trunks of healthy and unhealthy Quercus robur, Quercus petraea and Quercus cerris oak trees in Hungary.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Institute of Nuclear Research of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, P.O.B. 51, H-4001 Debrecen, Hungary.

ab.p: As part of the Síkfökút research project, sap flow in these 3 oak species was studied using 43K radioisotope tracing, the heat pulse velocity technique and the Granier method. Numerous intense pulses were observed in healthy Quercus petraea superimposing onto the usual diurnal change pattern. Only a few pulses were observed in unhealthy Quercus petraea, in healthy Quercus cerris and healthy and unhealthy Quercus robur trees. The proportion of wet wood assessed by γ- and X-ray computer tomography and magnetic resonance imaging was significantly less in healthy Quercus petraea trees than in healthy Quercus cerris trees, and was higher in healthy trees than unhealthy trees of both species.

bibl.et: Effects of complex air pollution on tree species of the Atlantic rain forest near Cubatão, Brazil.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Universität Hohenheim, Inst. Landschafts- und Pflanzenökologie (320), D 70593 Stuttgart, Germany.

ab.p: The industrial complex of Cubatão, in São Paulo, SE Brazil, is presented as a typical example of the increasing environmental problems of developing and threshold countries. As a consequence of high air pollutant emissions the Atlantic Rain Forest in the region shows severe decline symptoms. Studies with native tree species, including field investigations in the stand and exposure experiments with young trees, revealed an accumulation of toxic elements such as fluoride and sulfur in the leaves, alterations in mineral nutrition, metabolic changes typical of stress situations and modifications of growth characteristics. These findings are discussed with respect to the risk to the vegetation from air pollution.

bibl.et: Forestry trees as invasive aliens.
bibl.aa: Institute for Plant Conservation, Botany Department, University of Cape Town, Rondebosch 7701, South Africa.

ab.p: Some alien tree species used in commercial forestry and agroforestry cause major problems as invaders of natural and seminatural ecosystems. The magnitude of the problem has increased significantly over the past few decades, with a rapid increase in afforestation and changes in land use. Trends can be explained by analysing natural experiments created by the widespread planting of a small number of species in different parts of the world. The species that cause the greatest problems are generally those that have been planted most widely and for the longest time. The most affected areas have the longest histories of intensive planting; Pinus spp. are especially problematic, and at least 19 species are invasive over large areas in the southern hemisphere, where some species cause major problems. The most invasive Pinus species have a predictable set of life-history attributes, including low seed mass, short juvenile period, and short interval between large seed crops. Pine invasions have severely impacted large areas of grassland and scrub-brushland in the southern hemisphere by causing shifts in life-form dominance, reduced structural diversity, increased biomass, disruption of prevailing vegetation dynamics, and changing nutrient cycling patterns. The (unavoidable) negative impacts of forestry with alien species are thus spilling over into areas set aside for conservation or water production. There is an urgent need to integrate the various means available for reducing the negative impacts of current invaders and to implement protocols to regulate the translocation of species that are known to be invasive.

bibl.et: Migration and seasonal range dynamics of deer using adjacent deeryards in Northern Michigan.
bibl.aa: Department of Fisheries and Wildlife, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, USA.

ab.p: In Michigan's Upper Peninsula (Thuja occidentalis forest), forest management that seeks to integrate wildlife, recreation, and silviculture goals is complicated by the seasonal movements of white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus) between summer and winter ranges. From January 1992 to January 1995, a radiotelemetry study was conducted of seasonal range use by deer that overwinter in 2 important deeryards in the central Upper Peninsula. Distance, direction, and timing of seasonal movements between summer and winter ranges were largely independent of age class or sex. Yearly overlap of seasonal ranges for individual deer suggested that spatial use was traditional. Overlap of composite ranges of deer that occupied study area deeryards suggested that herds specific to deeryards were isolated spatially during winter but not other seasons. These findings indicated a secondary level of social structure reflecting the location of suitable winter range in the surrounding landscape. It is suggested that managers use deeryard-summer range pairs that are connected by the migration tradition of discrete deer herds to design deer management units (DMUs) that are biologically meaningful. The surgical application of liberal hunting regulations in selected DMUs could then provide a landscape-level network of areas managed for the benefit of species and communities that are threatened by deer herbivory.

bibl.et: Effects of agricultural activities and hunting on home ranges of female white-tailed deer.
bibl.aa: Department of Forestry, Fisheries and Wildlife, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE 68583, USA.

ab.p: Insight into the effects of agricultural activities and hunting on deer could be used to facilitate management. Home range characteristics of female white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus) were measured in relation to corn [maize] development, corn harvesting, and the hunting seasons from 1991 to 1993. Among 30 radiomarked does, 53% (n = 16) remained residents of DeSoto National Wildlife Refuge, Nebraska, USA (DNWR, Populus deltoides bottomlands) throughout the study; 47% (n = 14) were transients. Among the transients, 30% (n = 9) permanently emigrated from DNWR and 17% (n = 5) migrated annually. Dispersal occurred in April and May. Annual home ranges of resident does averaged 170 ha (CI = 38, n = 14). Home range centres shifted an average of 174 m (CI = 74, n = 14) closer to cornfields when corn was in the tasselling-silking stage of development. After corn harvest, home range centres shifted 157 m (CI = 63, n = 12) away from crop fields and into areas of permanent cover. Home range sizes increased 32% (9-64% CI) after corn harvest because does were forced to find and use other sources of cover and food. Resident does that caused local crop damage during the growing season were available for hunting in the same areas where they caused damage. Migrators appeared especially vulnerable because they were exposed to state firearm and archery seasons and the DNWR 3-day muzzle loader hunt. Of all tagged deer, 20% of transients (3 of 15) were harvested legally, whereas 40% of residents (8 of 20) were harvested. Culling or removal to reduce crop damage around large areas of permanent cover should be conducted in early to mid-autumn, which can reduce deer densities in the immediate area but not impose additional hunting pressure on migratory deer.

bibl.do: Pépinières et plantations forestières en Afrique tropicale sèche.
bibl.et: Forest nurseries and forest plantations in dry tropical Africa.
bibl.ft: Pépinières et plantations forestières en Afrique tropicale sèche.
bibl.ms: many col. pl.
bibl.aa: Institut sénégalais de recherches agricoles (ISRA), Recherches sur les productions forestières, BP 2312, Dakar, Sénégal.

ab.p: This book is primarily aimed at foresters and those involved with afforestation programmes in the dry tropical zones of sub-Saharan Africa. The first part of the book comprises four introductory chapters, which outline (1) methods and techniques of forest nursery establishment (site, climatic conditions, irrigation, as well as labour and economics), (2) the collection, storage and germination of seeds, (3) the production and tending in the nursery of different types of planting stock, and (4) planting out and tending in young plantations. The second part of the book contains short information sheets for 65 tree species, detailing African vernacular names, silvicultural use and importance, nursery and plantation practises, and including one or more colour photographs, particularly of flowers and/or fruits. The species covered in the book include 15 Acacia spp., 3 Combretum spp., 2 Dalbergia spp., 2 Euphorbia spp., 2 Prosopis spp., and 2 Zizyphus [Ziziphus] spp., and includes multipurpose exotic species as well species traditionally used in the rural economy of Africa S. of the Sahara.

bibl.et: Environmental impact of forest roads.
bibl.ft: L'impatto ambientale delle strade forestale.
bibl.aa: Istituto di Assestamento e Tecnologia Forestale, Università di Firenze, Firenze, Italy.

ab.p: A literature survey is presented of the planning, building and maintenance of forest roads. It is emphasized that effective forest management - whether primarily for timber harvesting, game control, recreation activities, or for a combination of these - requires good forest access as provided by a suitable road network. Environmentally-sound roadbuilding requires precise knowledge on both potential impacts and preventive measures for minimizing damage. The bibliographic references are part of a collection on the environmental consequences of forest operations (2570 in total) compiled by the Istituto per la Ricerca sul Legno in Florence, Italy. All selected entries contained 10 descriptive fields for computer analysis, including the provenance of the studies (75% are from North America and Europe), type of the studies (74% were experimental), the kind of damage most often encountered (81% dealt with hydrogeological effects). The literature was mainly focused on: erosion, landslides, hydrogeological impacts, sediment production, effects on landscape and wildlife.

bibl.et: Perceptions and people's attitudes to forests and their social functions.
bibl.ft: Perceptions et attitudes de la population envers la forêt et ses prestations sociales.
bibl.ms: + 19 in text
bibl.aa: Departement Wald- und Holzforschung, ETH, Zürich, Switzerland.

ab.p: An analysis is made of selected opinion polls and articles published in the principal forestry periodicals of Germany, Austria and Switzerland between 1960 and 1995. The analysis shows that the number of publications on public opinion polls on forest condition and the image of forest services peaked in the 1970s and 1980s. The analysis also covered 63 publications showing how the forest sciences in Germany, Austria and Switzerland were increasingly confronted with social phenomena and expectations regarding forests and their role in providing inexpensive leisure opportunities. Forest services reacted by initiating social-science research on forest recreation. The analysis shows that the forestry sciences have recognized their role as mediators between the forests and the public, and accordingly have taken on a new professional responsibility.

bibl.et: Wood-inhabiting fungi as indicators of ecological continuity within spruce forests of southeastern Norway.
bibl.ft: Vedlevende sopp som indikatorarter på kontinuitet i <o>stnorske granskoger.
bibl.aa: Nils Bays vei 26, N-0876 Oslo, Norway.

ab.p: The ecology of some wood-inhabiting fungi in spruce forests in Norway was studied and their suitability as indicator species for dead and decaying wood was evaluated. All the studied species grew mainly on logs of Picea abies, having a relatively strong preference for thick logs as well as logs at certain stages of decay. Laurilia sulcata, Amylocystis lapponica, Phlebia centrifuga, Phellinus nifrolimitatus, Inonotus leporina and Fomitopsis rosea were mainly found in forests with little or no traces of management, while the other studied species also occurred in forests with cutting. This work supports other studies stating that these fungi prefer forests of long ecological continuity and that they thus may be used as indicator species. Nevertheless several of the studied species seem to have lower affinities to continuity in dead wood than expected.

index.de: biological indicators\dead wood\decay\ecology\forest ecology\forests\indicator species\logs\wood destroying fungi

bibl.et: The obsolete paradigm of professional forestry.
bibl.aa: Northern Arizona University, Flagstaff, AZ, USA.

ab.p: The linkage between environmental policy and forest planning in the USA is examined with reference to changes which have occurred since the National Forest Management Act 1976, which explicitly refers to and accommodates the National Environmental Policy Act. Features considered typical of forestry planning in the 20th century are outlined, including: an orientation towards scarcity avoidance strategies; a simple perception of sustainability; a tendency to separate components of the environment; and a heavy reliance on science, whilst ignoring political aspects of environmental issues. Ways in which these philosophies should be developed in the 21st century are discussed, in addition to a discussion of the role that ecosystem modelling will play in the future of forestry planning.

bibl.et: Role of diagnostic studies in forest monitoring programmes.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Swiss Federal Institute for Forest, Snow and Landscape Research, Zuercherstrasse 111, CH-8903 Birmensdorf, Switzerland.

ab.p: Within the European forest health monitoring system, assessments are currently made of defoliation and discoloration of individual trees, based on a systematic grid of sample plots. In addition, damage is ascribed to one of 8 classes: game and grazing, insects, fungi, abiotic agents, direct action of man, fire, known local or regional pollutants, and other causes. The results indicate that the majority of countries undertaking inventories do not attribute any damage to pollution injury. This may be because the injury is not observed (for example, it may occur on the upper sides of leaves in the upper crown), because it has been confused with other symptoms, or because it is absent. Considerable care needs to be taken with the interpretation of the results and the absence of a record should not be taken as meaning that a particular cause of injury was not present. Recent results from Switzerland suggest that ozone injury may be much more widespread than previously recognized, suggesting that the failure to observe the symptoms may be an important reason for their scarcity.

bibl.et: Biodiversity and stress level in four forests of the Italian alps.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Centro di Ecologia Alpina, I-38040 Viote del Monte Bondone, Trento, Italy.

ab.p: Diversity patterns of plants, fungi and arthropods were studied at 4 forest sites in the Provinces of Bolzano and Trento (Italian Alps). Two deciduous mixed forests at low altitude (560 and 680 m) dominated by Quercus spp., Fraxinus ornus and Ostrya carpinifolia, and two spruce forests close to the timber line (1750 and 1780 m) dominated by Picea abies, Pinus cembra and Larix decidua, were sampled, and some 2351 species were identified. Data on climate, land use and stress in the forests were correlated with species diversity. Species richness was higher in the deciduous lower altitude more stressed forests (the stress factors included tourism, grazing, clear felling, reforestation and drought). There was a very high turnover of species both between and within the 2 forest types. Similar patterns in some diversity parameters were recorded in the 2 forest types.

bibl.et: Ozone and air particulate measurements in mountain forest sites.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Lombardy Foundation for the Environment, Milan, Italy.

ab.p: Ozone and total suspended particulate (TSP) concentrations were measured for two consecutive summer seasons (1994-95) during a forest survey campaign carried out in two lateral valleys at Vahellina (Italian Alps) characterized by very different degrees of novel decline symptoms. Sampling methods and experimental data relative to ozone, measured by passive samplers and continuous monitors, and particulate pollutants, determined by multielemental analysis using EDXRF techniques, are described. While TSP levels were low and almost equal at the two sites, ozone concentration was much higher in the more damaged valley, where its values were above the toxicity threshold for many plant species.

bibl.et: Techniques for preserving and determining aluminium fractions in soil solution from podzolic forest soils.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Rovaniemi Research Station, Finnish For. Res. Inst., P.O. Box 16, FIN-96301 Rovaniemi, Finland.

ab.p: The purpose of the study was (1) to determine techniques for minimizing the effects of transportation and storage on the concentrations of different Al fractions in soil solution samples, and (2) to determine a suitable method for analysing monomeric Al concentrations in water samples from humus-rich podzolic forest soils. The test water samples were from 3 of the permanent monitoring plots established in Finland in 1995 as part of the European Programme for the Intensive Monitoring of Forest ecosystems (ICP Forests, level II); 2 were in Scots pine [Pinus sylvestris], and 1 in Norway spruce [Picea abies] forest. Aluminium fractionation was performed on a cation exchange column and the fractions were analysed by ICP/AES (inductively coupled plasma atomic emission) and FIA (flow injection analysis). A time lag of a few hours to two days between sampling and pretreatment appeared to have no effect on total Al concentrations, even though the samples were not preserved with acid. Freezing the samples was not an appropriate storage technique because it resulted in a strong decrease in total Al concentrations. Storage (+4°C) had a detrimental effect on the proportion of exchangeable monomeric Al, but this problem was overcome by fractionating the samples immediately on arrival at the laboratory. Adjustment of sample pH to <3.7 permitted storage of the fraction for at least 2 weeks before analysis by ICP/AES or FIA. Either of these two techniques can be used for determining exchangeable monomeric Al, but if the non-exchangeable reactive Al fraction (i.e. organically complexed Al) is required then analysis by FIA is necessary.

bibl.do: Proceedings of the ISTA Tree Seed Pathology Meeting, Opocno, Czech Republic, 9-11 October 1996.
bibl.et: Pitch canker of pines: A Southern African perspective.
bibl.ct: Proceedings of the ISTA Tree Seed Pathology Meeting, Opocno, Czech Republic, 9-11 October 1996.
bibl.aa: Tree Pathology Cooperative Programme, Department of Microbiology and Biochemistry, University of the Orange Free State, P.O. Box 339, Bloemfontein 9300, South Africa.

ab.p: The occurrence of Fusarium subglutinans f.sp. pini (FSP) in South Africa is used as an example of how quarantine measures might have failed to prevent the introduction of a serious pathogen. To date, FSP has only been found in South African pine nurseries where it causes a serious root disease. Research has shown that this fungus has a high degree of genetic diversity in South Africa. This implies that numerous genetic entities of FSP were introduced or that sexual crossings have taken place in nature. In the present studies, sexually fertile crosses between isolates from South Africa and the USA have been obtained. This is considered to represent strong evidence that the fungus was introduced into South Africa, probably on infected seed. The symptoms of pitch canker, the spread of FSP, pathogenesis, control and quarantine measures which should be imposed to prevent its further spread are reviewed.

bibl.et: Vegetation composition, structure, and chronological change in a decadent midwestern North American savanna remnant.
bibl.aa: The Morton Arboretum, Lisle, Illinois 60532, USA.

ab.p: Fire-maintained oak savannas on silt-loam soils essentially disappeared from midwestern North America soon after European settlement because of fire suppression and agriculture. The Wolf Road Prairie Nature Preserve, Cook County, Illinois, contains a 2-ha savanna remnant that persisted on mesic silt-loam soils because grazing was excluded and because it was frequently burned until about 1965. Tree increment cores were used to document temporal change in this savanna's tree density and canopy structure. The savanna has an open overstorey canopy of mature Quercus macrocarpa (bur oak) and a dense 30-year-old subcanopy of Q. macrocarpa and Q. ellipsoidalis (northern pin oak) that matured from oak grub sprouts after cessation of annual wildfires. Herb-layer sample plots were classified into four species groups corresponding to a measured light intensity gradient that correlated with canopy tree density. The ground layer was dominated by shade-tolerant species that presumably have spread into former savanna openings, while shade-intolerant species, such as prairie plants, were restricted to the few remaining light gaps. Plot species richness and number of prairie species were highest at highest light levels, while alien species richness was highest under canopy shade. Forbs were the most important species group (78.6 Importance Value); woody species were much less important (18.8 IV), and graminoid vegetation was only a minor component that was restricted to light gaps. Camassia scilloides was the most important forb and was distributed bimodally across the light gradient. Rubus allegheniensis was the most important woody species, and Carex pensylvanica was the most important graminoid species. The site retains important components of savanna vegetation and could be restored to former savanna composition and structure, helping provide elements of a savanna restoration model. Restoration would require a return to high fire frequencies and reduction of the subcanopy to its former grub layer, which should increase abundance of light- and fire-adapted species and reduce alien species. However, restoring former structure may be difficult, partly because of the fire resistance of maturing subcanopy oaks and because the absence of graminoid fuel species will reduce the effectiveness of fire. In addition, landscape-scale fire processes, which might be most effective, will be difficult to implement in this small fragmented natural area. As a result, experimental cutting or girdling of oaks should be used to supplement fire in opening canopy gaps.

bibl.et: Carbon dioxide recycling in two Amazonian tropical forests.
bibl.aa: Department of Biology, University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL 33124, USA.

ab.p: Recycling of respiratory CO2 was calculated with a previously developed model using stable isotope ratios and concentration values of ambient CO2. Measurements were taken in two different tropical forests in the Amazon basin during the dry season. One forest (Reserva Ducke, Amazonas, Brazil) was characterized by a closed canopy with lower wind speeds, while the other (Fazenda Vitoria, Para, Brazil) had a relatively open canopy and higher wind speeds. The closed canopy forest had up to 39% of its respiratory CO2 recycled at 18 m above the forest floor. Percentage recycling in this forest was related to wind speed at the date of collection. Calculations of recycling on the open canopy forest gave values ranging from 0 to negative. This forest may have ambient CO2 contamination from charcoal kilns in a nearby town, so calculations of recycling based on isotopic composition of ambient CO2 for this forest may be incorrect.

bibl.ct: Atmospheric ammonia: emission, deposition and environmental impacts. International conference, Culham, Oxford, UK, 2-4 October 1995.
bibl.aa: TNO Institute of Environmental Sciences, Energy Research and Process Innovation, Delft, Netherlands.

ab.p: Measurements of vertical gradients of ammonium nitrate aerosol and NH3 were used together with HNO3 concentrations to study the influence of gas-to-particle conversion (gtpc) on surface exchange processes above a forest. A numerical model of surface exchange, in which a description of gtpc was incorporated, was used to interpret the measurements. The model suggested that evaporation of particulate NH4NO3 during the day could lead to situations where upward fluxes of NH3 and HNO3 were observed above the forest, while both gases were deposited at the surface. At the same time, this mechanism provided an explanation for the observed aerosol deposition fluxes, which were larger than theoretically possible. Further support for this hypothesis was found in the analysis of a larger data set which showed that in many cases sub-equilibrium concentrations of NH3 and HNO3 (which may lead to evaporation of NH4NO3 aerosol) coincided with apparent emission fluxes of NH3.

bibl.et: The seed bank dynamics of Cornus controversa and their role in regeneration.
bibl.aa: Tohoku Research Center, Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, Morioka, Iwate 020-01, Japan.

ab.p: Seed-bank dynamics of C. controversa, a common tree in Japanese temperate forests, were investigated at Ogawa Forest Reserve by direct measurement of seed input, soil seed density, and seedling output (germination of soil seeds), together with two field experiments on postdispersal seed mortality. Soil seed density varied from 4 to 233 m-2 in the site near conspecific adults (<5 m horizontally from crown edge), and 0 to 18 m-2 in far sites (≥5 m) during the 1988-92 period. Seed input occurred only in 1988 and 1990: 190-740 m-2 at the sites near conspecific adults, and 4-20 m-2 at the far sites. Seedling output was observed every year and accounted for 0-15% of the loss from the seed bank, occasionally 30-60%. Seeds buried at 5-cm depth suffered moderate mortality (c. 0.2 year-1) by fungal pathogens. In contrast, seeds experimentally placed on the ground suffered higher mortality (0.5-1 year-1) through predation by ground mammals, probably wood mice. In the experiment, seeds whose mesocarp was removed survived much better. On the other hand, distance itself did not appear to affect post-dispersal mortality of seeds. Seeds in canopy gaps also tended to suffer higher mortality. Current spatial pattern and mode of seed dispersal should decrease the potential ability of the seed bank of this species to colonize safe sites. Rare and unpredictable events might increase the contribution of the seed-bank strategy to regeneration in this forest.

index.de: forests\mortality\natural regeneration\population dynamics\regeneration\seed banks\seed dispersal\seed predation\seeds

bibl.et: Leaf δ13C in Pinus resinosa trees and understory plants: variation associated with light and CO2 gradients.
bibl.aa: Department of Biology, Carleton University, 1125 Colonel By Drive, Ottawa, Ont. K1S 5B6, Canada.

ab.p: The relative importance of gradients in light intensity and the isotopic composition of atmospheric CO2 for variation in leaf carbon isotope ratios was evaluated within a Pinus resinosa forest. Photosynthetic gas exchange and leaf carbon isotope ratios were measured in understorey species (Dryopteris carthusiana, Epipactus helleborine [Epipactis helleborine], Hieracium floribundum and Rhamnus frangula), in order to estimate the consequence of the variation in the understorey light microclimate for carbon gain in these plants. During mid-day, CO2 concentration was relatively constant at vertical positions ranging from 15 m to 3 m above ground. Only at positions below 3 m was CO2 concentration significantly elevated above that measured at 15 m. Based on the strong linear relationship between changes in CO2 concentration and δ13C values for air samples collected during a diurnal cycle, the expected vertical profile for the carbon isotope ratio of atmospheric CO2 within the forest was calculated. These calculations indicated that leaves at 3 m height and above were exposed to CO2 of approximately the same isotopic composition during daylight periods. There was no significant difference between the daily mean δ13C values at 15 m (-7.77o/oo) and 3 m (-7.89o/oo), but atmospheric CO2 was significantly depleted in 13C closer to the ground surface, with daily average δ13C values of -8.85o/oo at 5 cm above ground. The light intensity gradient in the forest was substantial, with average photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) on the forest floor approximately 6% of that received at the top of the canopy. In contrast, there were only minor changes in air temperature, and so it is likely that the leaf-air vapour pressure difference was relatively constant from the top of the canopy to the forest floor. For P. resinosa and Ulmus americana samples, there was a significant correlation between leaf δ13C value and the height at which the leaf sample was collected. Leaf tissue sampled near the forest floor, on average, had lower δ13C values than samples collected near the top of the canopy. It is suggested that the average light intensity gradient through the canopy was the major factor influencing vertical changes in tree leaf δ13C values. In addition, there was a wide range of variation (greater than 4o/oo) among the four understorey plant species for average leaf δ13C values. Measurements of leaf gas exchange, under natural light conditions and with supplemental light, were used to estimate the influence of the light microclimate on the observed variation in leaf carbon isotope ratios in the understorey plants. The data indicated that one species, E. helleborine, gained a substantial fraction of carbon during sunflecks.

bibl.et: Survey and evaluation of comparative stands of Taxodium 'Zhongshansa' and T. ascendens, T. distichum and Metasequoia glyptostroboides.
bibl.aa: Institute of Botany, Jiangsu Province and Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing 210014, China.

ab.p: Taxodium 'Zhongshansa 302' ('Z. 302', T. distichum × T. mucronatum), T. 'Z. 401' (T. ascendens × T. mucronatum) and T. 'Z. 301' (T. distichum × T. mucronatum) were compared with T. ascendens [T. distichum var. imbricarium], T. distichum and Metasequoia glyptostroboides on saline soils of pH 8.0-9.5 at 7 sites in the northern part of Jiangsu Province, China. 'Z. 302' showed excellent growth, followed by 'Z. 401'; growth of 'Z. 301', T. distichum and M. glyptostroboides was average while that of T. ascendens was poor.

bibl.et: The ancient landscapes of the Gérardmer state forest, a contribution to planning reviews using long term historical data.
bibl.ft: Les paysages anciens de la forêt domaniale de Gérardmer, contribution patrimoniale à la révision d'aménagement.
bibl.aa: Département de Géographie, Faculté des Lettres, Université de Metz, Ile du Saulcy, F-57000 Metz, France.

ab.p: The use of historical documents for the analysis of forest history is discussed, and it is suggested that future forest management planning can benefit from such knowledge. The author illustrates this point of view with a case study of a state forest located on the western slopes of the Vosges, France. In AD 1865 the forest comprised 4800 ha of beech/silver fir/Norway spruce [Fagus sylvatica/Abies alba/Picea abies] forests, mainly on steep slopes facing N. or S., which are important protection forests. The challenge for modern forest management planning - the fulfilment of multiple functions of protection, production, recreation (both summer and winter), the maintenance of landscape aesthetics, and biodiversity - is discussed in the context of the information which the forest archives (dating from the late 17th century).

bibl.et: The forests of Lower Saxony in northern Germany: the difficulties of the past dictate a new management approach. Part 2: the 'Löwe' government programme embracing close-to-nature silviculture.
bibl.ft: Les forêts de Basse-Saxe en Allemagne du Nord: un passé difficile commande une gestion nouvelle. Deuxième partie: le programme gouvernemental 'Löwe' principes d'une sylviculture proche de la nature.
bibl.aa: École Nationale de Génie Rural, des Eaux et des Forêts, 14 Rue Girardet, CS 4216, F-54052 Nancy Cedex, France.

ab.p: The second part of this account of forest management in Lower Saxony outlines local government policy for future management of state forests. The 'Löwe' [lion] programme - so-called as it is an anagram for 'long-term ecological forest development' - has 13 objectives which are being pursued, for the purpose of improving and stabilizing wood production while increasing biodiversity. First results are described at the end of the article.

bibl.et: Interseeded legumes with loblolly pine. I. Effect of phosphorus and legume variety on pine seedling establishment and mortality.
bibl.aa: Agronomy Department, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, USA.

ab.p: A study was conducted at Overton, Texas, to determine the effects of legume companion crops and phosphorus (P) fertilizer on the growth and survival characteristics of newly established loblolly pine (Pinus taeda) seedlings. At 12 months post-establishment, there was no legume effect (P>0.05) on root lateral development or rooting depth for pine seedlings. Likewise, there was no legume effect (P>0.05) on aboveground biomass production of pine seedlings. Partridge pea (Cassia fasciculata) decreased (P<0.05) pine seedling total root biomass compared to other treatments. Pine seedlings grown with legumes allocated less resources to root development than pine seedlings grown alone. Pine seedlings grown alone or with cowpeas (Vigna unguiculata) were subject to less mortality (P<0.05) than seedlings grown with alyceclover (Alysicarpus vaginalis) or partridge pea. Phosphorus application enhanced dry matter (DM) yield of legumes but had no effect on rooting depth of pine seedlings during the first 12 months of growth. After 12 months post-establishment, the most pronounced effect of P application was that of increased nitrogen (N) content of leaf, stem, and roots of pine seedlings. Native, annual herbaceous grass biomass in the control plots (no legume) reduced the amount of soil N to below pre-planting levels, while soil N levels in all legume plots exceeded pre-trial levels. It is suggested that cowpeas have potential for growing with pine seedlings, with possible benefits for site stabilization, nitrogen cycling and pine growth.

bibl.et: Leaf litter decomposition along the Porsuk River, Eskisehir, Turkey.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Biology, Southern Illinois University at Carbondale, IL 62901, USA.

ab.p: The leaf litter decomposition of Typha latifolia, Phragmites australis, Acacia longifolia, Populus alba and Salix alba along the Porsuk River, Eskisehir, Turkey was studied using the fibreglass bag technique. After 180 days, soft-leaved species such as A. longifolia decomposed more quickly (0.52% loss day-1) than the tougher leaved species such as T. latifolia and P. australis (0.31 and 0.37% loss day-1, respectively). T. latifolia had the toughest while A. longifolia had the softest leaves among the five species as measured with a penetrometer (428.0 versus 128.2 g). Both leaf toughness and time were related to percent loss per day (F = 4.4, p < 0.01, and F = 37.0, p < 0.01, respectively). World trends in percent loss per day for T. latifolia do not fit predictions based solely on latitude.

bibl.et: The rebuilding of an isolated rain forest assemblage: how disharmonic is the flora of Krakatau?
bibl.aa: School of Geography, University of Oxford, Mansfield Road, Oxford, OX1 3TB, UK.

ab.p: The compositional balance of the flora of the Krakatau Islands, Indonesia, is examined in order to identify taxonomic and/or ecological groups which are under-represented in this recovering island ecosystem (which was arguably completely sterilized by volcanic eruptions in 1883), in relation to regional analogues and potential source areas in the Sunda Strait (Ujung Kulon and Sebesi Island). Interpretations are conditioned by the limited availability of comparative data, the uncertainty surrounding dispersal classifications, the problem of determining habitat suitability for missing elements, and thus the unsuitability of a formal statistical approach. Analysis by dispersal syndrome supports predictions that species with large, winged, wind-scattered propagules, or those with no particular dispersal potential, are under-sampled. However, some species with winged propagules have colonized, in most cases probably by thalassochory (sea-dispersal). Although zoochorous (animal-dispersed) trees and shrubs are well represented on Krakatau, those large-seeded species which are primarily dependent on dispersal by animals other than birds are under-represented. Large-seeded zoochores are probably highly dependent on two species of Ducula (large fruit-pigeons) for transport to Krakatau, and their colonization has been relatively slow. Comparison with Christmas and Jarak Islands yields differing degrees of overlap for thalassochorous, zoochorous, and anemochorous (wind-dispersed) spermatophytes and for pteridophytes, interpretable in terms of dispersability and size of the respective species pools. Particular families and genera can be identified which are seemingly under-sampled on Krakatau, as can some which are over-represented in relation to the principal comparative site, the Ujung Kulon peninsular, West Java. The latter are mostly very small-seeded wind-dispersed epiphytic herbs (especially orchids). Ferns are also very well represented in relation to the West Javan source pool. It is concluded that the flora of Krakatau remains disharmonic, in a predictable fashion, although it is certainly becoming less so. The data provide empirical evidence for the abilities of particular functional guilds of rain forest plants to disperse across significant barriers: the implications of these findings are discussed in relation to current concerns with forest fragmentation in the tropics.

bibl.et: Ultrastructure of exine of gymnospermous pollen grains from Jurassic and basal Cretaceous deposits in northwest Europe and implications for botanical relationships.
bibl.aa: Institute of Geography and Earth Sciences, University of Wales, Aberystwyth SY23 3DB, UK.

ab.p: Ultrathin sectioning and examination of gymnosperm pollen grains from various NW European, mid-Mesozoic successions has confirmed or added weight to previous suggestions of botanical relationships for some taxa, and indicated possible affinities for others. Sections of Araucariacites australis, Callialasporites dampieri, C. trilobatus and C. turbatus support a derivation from the coniferous family Araucariaceae. Although differing in gross morphology from pollen of both extant Ephedra and Welwitschia of the order Gnetales, Eucommiidites troedssonii has ultrastructural characters in common with these, and with Triassic Equisetosporites. Cerebropollenites macroverrucosus is widely accepted as not being closely comparable to pollen of modern Tsuga, but ultrastructural similarities suggest the possibility of an ancestral connection. The structure of the exine of Clavatipollenites hughesii sensu Schulz from Jurassic deposits is fundamentally different from that of Cretaceous grains referred to the same species, confirming observations made previously on the basis of analysis under the light microscope, and suggesting a possible derivation from cycadalean rather than angiospermous plants. Species of Chasmatosporites may also be linked to the Cycadales, or perhaps to the Ginkgoales. Pilasporites couperi is shown to be a gymnosperm pollen grain rather than a pteridophyte spore, but more precise (family) links have not been established. The protosaccate structure of Quadraeculina anellaeformis is clearly demonstrated but its botanical affinity remains enigmatic. Previously suggested relationships between Spheripollenites and members of the Araucariaceae, Cupressaceae and Taxaceae are not supported. They do not seem to lie with any modern gymnosperm family, nor with ancient angiosperms.

bibl.et: Architecture of the Wollemi pine (Wollemia nobilis, Araucariaceae), a unique combination of model and reiteration.
bibl.aa: National Herbarium of New South Wales, Royal Botanic Gardens, Mrs Macquaries Road, Sydney, NSW 2000, Australia.

ab.p: The Wollemi pine (Wollemia nobilis) is shown to possess a unique architecture. The model is not described by any of the 23 basic models previously described [see Bell, A. D. (1991) Plant Form Oxford University Press, Oxford, UK], but can be described by a modified Cook model whereby growth is rhythmic rather than continuous. This differs from all other extant members of Araucariacene, which conform to the models of either Rauh or Massart. The branching and coppicing habits can both be interpreted as adaptive reiterations. Both the architectural model and the two types of adaptive reiteration are shown to be advanced or autapomorphic conditions in the Wollemi pine.

bibl.do: Forest management in tribal areas: forest policy and peoples participation (Proceedings of the seminar, forest policy and tribal development during 15-16 February 1994 at Koraput).
bibl.et: Forest management in tribal areas: forest policy and peoples participation (Proceedings of the seminar, forest policy and tribal development during 15-16 February 1994 at Koraput).
bibl.ct: Forest management in tribal areas: forest policy and peoples participation (Proceedings of the seminar, forest policy and tribal development during 15-16 February 1994 at Koraput).
bibl.ms: refs at ends of chapters
bibl.aa: Council of Analytical Tribal Studies, D.N.K. Road, Koraput-764020, India.
bibl.ad: Patnaik, B. C.\Mahapatra, K. K.\Sahu, N. C.\Bas, B. N.\Nimai Bhai\Bhai, N.\Jagannath Shroff\Shroff, J.\Mohapatra, C. R.\Buchi, K. N.\Thakur, B. N.\Jagabandhu Samal\Samal, J.\Gantayat, S. P.\Achyut Das\Das, A.\Mishra, B. B.\Nilakantha Rath\Rath, N.\Pattanaik, D. K.\Mishra, M. K.\Dash, S. S.

ab.p: The book, which has 17 chapters, contains edited versions of 16 papers, 13 of which were presented at the seminar noted in the title, which was organized by the Council of Analytical Tribal Studies (COATS) at Koraput (Orissa), a body which carries out micro-level studies of the socioeconomic problems of tribal groups. The other 3 papers (the last 3 chapters) are one (by Neelakantha Rath) presented at a 1-day COATS seminar in January 1994, and 2 which were specially commissioned for the book. A number of important issues concerning the framing of a new forest policy suitable for the needs of tribal groups are discussed. After a foreword, the 16 papers included are: (1) Inaugural address (Patnaik, B. C.); (2) Parameters of forest policy and tribal development (Mahapatra, L. K.); (3) Forest policy in Orissa - a third visit (Sahu, N. C.; Das, B. N.); (4) Towards a new forest policy (Nimai Bhai); (5) Forest policy and tribal development (Jagannath Shroff); (6) Forest policy and tribal deprivation (Mohapatro, P. C.); (7) Podu [shifting cultivation]: an ecological hazard (Mohapatra, C. R.); (8) Shifting cultivation and its impact on forest ecosystem (Buchi, K. N.); (9) Impact of shifting cultivation on forest eco-system (Thakur, B. N.); (10) Role of forest in a poor resource base tribal economy: a micro analysis (Jagabandhu Samal); (11) A look at tribals and forest (Gantayat, S. P.); (12) Joint forest management in tribal areas: conflicts and resolutions (Achyut Das); (13) Tribal women and forest economy (Mishra, B. B.); (14) A note on approach to tribal area development (Neelakantha Rath); (15) Soil erosion and deforestation in Koraput district (undivided) (Pattanaik, D. K.); and (16) Medicinal plants used by tribals of Koraput District, Orissa (Mishra, M. K.; Dash, S. S.). The last chapter presents conclusions and recommendations.

bibl.et: Biological control of sapstain in New Zealand.
bibl.ct: Strategies for improving protection of logs and lumber: proceedings of a symposium at the Forest Research Institute, Rotorua, New Zealand, 21-22 November 1997.
bibl.aa: Natural Systems Group, Horticulture and Food Research Institute of New Zealand Ltd., Ruakura Research Centre, Ruakura Road, Private Bag 3123, Hamilton, New Zealand.

ab.p: Biological control offers an alternative approach for the control of sapstain in New Zealand. In two ongoing studies the ability of a micro-organism to inhibit the growth of sapstain species on Pinus radiata was demonstrated in both laboratory and field trials. In the first study, a total of 848 fungal and bacterial isolates were assessed for their suitability as potential biological control agents (BCA) of sapstain. On these, 116 isolates inhibited the growth of Ophiostoma piceae on small wood chips and/or wood blocks in laboratory-scale trials. Isolates of Epicoccum purpurascens, Gliocladium roseum, G. viride, Trichoderma hamatum, T. harzianum, Trichoderma sp., Trichothecium roseum, a member of Thelephoraceae, and an unidentified fungal isolate proved most inhibitory. Six of the most inhibitory isolates were tested for their efficacy to control sapstain on sawn timber and debarked logs. All treatments reduced the level of sapstain on either logs or timber. Trichoderma sp. and Trichothecium roseum provided the greatest level of control on sawn timber. These isolates gave control equivalent to the standard fungicide treatments. In the log trial, T. harzianum provided control superior to that of the commercial fungicide on the internal log tissue. In the second study, albino strains of four Ophiostoma species were developed. Isolates of O. floccosum and I. pluriannulatum successfully controlled the growth of Leptographium procerum and Sphaeropsis sapinea in laboratory trials. Field trials are currently in progress assessing the potential of the BCAs.

bibl.et: The use of coniferous seedlings as alternative food to protect red oak (Quercus rubra) from vole girdling.
bibl.aa: Groupe de Recherche en Écologie, Nutrition et Énergétique, Département de biologie, Faculté des sciences, Université de Sherbrooke, 2500 boulevard Université, Sherbrooke, Québec J1K 2R1, Canada.

ab.p: Seedlings of deciduous and coniferous species are easy prey for generalist mammalian herbivores such as meadow voles (Microtus pennsylvanicus). Among several protective measures available to reduce girdling of seedlings, the use of alternative food is thought to be one promising way of 'hiding' valuable seedling species from herbivory. The hypothesis was tested that bark use of red oak seedlings (Quercus rubra) would be lower when alternative food in terms of less valuable commercial coniferous seedlings was available to voles. Four groups of 10 voles each were tested to estimate bark use indices on red oak seedlings matched with white pine (Pinus strobus), Norway pine (Pinus resinosa) or white spruce (Picea glauca) - 3 coniferous species which are occasionally girdled by voles. Laboratory tests lasted 25 days under standardized rearing conditions of temperature (18-20°C), relative humidity (40-60%) and luminosity (16 h light: 8 h dark) with winterized seedlings. Use of red oak bark over the stem diameter due to voles was higher in mixtures with all the conifer seedlings (losses of 64-77%) than with red oak alone (56%). Coniferous seedlings did not lose more than 7% of their bark from the stem diameter when matched with red oak. The results indicate that conifers cannot be used as alternative food resources to protect red oak seedlings against vole damage.

bibl.et: An experimental test of interspecific competition for red-cockaded woodpecker cavities.
bibl.aa: USDA Forest Service, Southern Research Station, Department of Forest Resources, Clemson University, Clemson, SC 29634-1003, USA.

ab.p: To test whether the presence of nest boxes near red-cockaded woodpecker (RCW, Picoides borealis) cavity trees reduced cavity use by other species and improved RCW reproductive success on the Francis Mark National Forest in coastal South Carolina, 3 nest boxes were placed in each of 62 experimental clusters and designated 61 clusters as controls in Pinus taeda and Pinus palustris stands. Observations of nest box and cavity use showed that nest boxes were somewhat effective in reducing cavity use and that eastern bluebirds (Sialia sialis) and southern flying squirrels (Glaucomys volans) were the most frequent users of nest boxes and cavities. Bluebirds preferred nest boxes to cavities in both years and flying squirrels showed significant preference for nest boxes in 1992. Pretreatment monitoring (1990) of RCW reproductive performance showed no significant differences between control and experimental groups. However, posttreatment monitoring showed that in 1991 RCWs in experimental clusters were significantly more likely to nest than RCWs in control clusters; in 1991 and 1992, they were more likely to fledge ≥1 young. Further, RCWs were less likely to initiate a nest if ≥1 cavity was occupied by a non-RCW species than if no cavities in the cluster were occupied by a non-RCW species. These results indicate that RCW cavities were subject to interspecific competition and that nest boxes may be an effective means of reducing competition, particularly when the number of cavities is limited.

bibl.do: Social forestry in India: a study of economic aspects.
bibl.et: Social forestry in India: a study of economic aspects.
bibl.ms: + refs at ends of chapters
bibl.aa: Department of Economics, Ganjdundwara College, Etah, India.

ab.p: A comprehensive analysis is made of the social forestry programme in India in this book, particularly of its economic impact and of the extent to which it has lived up to its original objectives. Achievements are assessed, and reasons for success, and strengths and weaknesses, are evaluated. The analysis is presented in 7 chapters: (1) Introduction - an outline of the purpose of the study; (2) Background - history and objectives of the programme; (3) Programme achievements - farm forestry, village woodlots, strip plantations (canal, roadside, riverside and railside plantations), and reforestation/reclamation of degraded land; (4) Social forestry: income and employment - direct and indirect impacts on the standard of living of rural people; (5) Social forestry: cottage and small scale industries; (6) Social forestry: agriculture and environment; and (7) Conclusion. A subject index is included.

bibl.do: Greening at the grassroots: alternative forestry strategies in India.
bibl.et: Greening at the grassroots: alternative forestry strategies in India.
bibl.ms: Also available from Sage Publications, London, UK, and from Sage Publications, Thousand Oaks, California, USA (ISBN 0-7619-9218-9, hardback; ISBN 0-7619-9219-7, paperback)
bibl.aa: Social Planning and Research Council of B.C., Vancouver, BC, Canada.

ab.p: The reasons for the failure of social forestry programmes in India to meet their objectives are explored in this book, and possible alternative solutions investigated. The premise of the book is that afforestation efforts in India have consistently been directed towards urban and commercial requirements for construction wood, fuel and paper, while ignoring rural needs for fuel, fodder, fibre and food. This attitude is directly attributed to the replacement of the indigenous subsistence model of forest use by the extractive colonial model. The author maintains that the consequence of this is that India's official forestry programmes have become sites for confrontations between western and indigenous cultures and knowledge systems, exacerbated by the hierarchical, rigid and authoritarian approach of forestry officials. It is demonstrated that in contrast to official programmes, the voluntary sector in India is strategically placed to play a catalytic role in reclaiming indigenous concepts of indigenous forestry. Case studies are presented from 3 voluntary groups in Andhra Pradesh: KIPDOW - Kadiri Integrated and Participatory Development of Watersheds; RHGBMSS - Rayalaseema Harijana Girijana Backward and Minorities Seva Samajam; and GORD - Gandhian Organization for Rural Development. Factors identified for the success of these organizational cultures include the engendering of more participatory, interactive and empowering relationships with villagers so that forestry practices emerge from local knowledge. The book is arranged in 6 chapters : (1) The rhetoric of social forestry; (2) Anti-social forestry: bureaucracy in action; (3) Authority and power in forestry knowledge; (4) Voluntary organizations: myth or reality - the case studies; (5) Reversals of authority and knowledge in subsistence forestry; and (6) Conclusion. A subject index is included.

index.de: case studies\development projects\forest policy\indigenous knowledge\non-governmental organizations\participation\political attitudes\rural development\social forestry\subsistence\traditional technology

bibl.et: A note on the larval host plant and biology of Melobasis nervosa (Boisduval) (Coleoptera: Buprestidae) from Australia.
bibl.aa: P.O. Box 371, Penrith, New South Wales 2750, Australia.

ab.p: Acacia dealbata, is recorded for the first time as a larval food plant for Melobasis nervosa in Australia. Larval habits are briefly reported and aspects of the larvae/pupal chamber are described. Food plants recorded for other species of Melobasis are also considered. There are now 4 species of Melobasis known to develop in the wood of Acacia (M. cupriceps, M. nervosa, M. purpurascens and M. vertebralis).
