bibl.et: Predicting canopy closure for habitat modeling.
bibl.aa: 880 Lady Ellen Place, Suite 206 Ottawa, Ontario K1Z 5L9, Canada.

ab.p: The purpose of this project was to develop quantitative models that could be used to estimate crown cover density of forest stands from available data in the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources Forest Resource Inventory information system. Models were developed and tested on two areas: the Algonquin Provincial Park and the Shining Tree Crown Management Unit in the Gogama District. The testing included the potential role of the Forest Resource Inventory working group and stand variables such as stocking, height, volume, site class, and age. The possible influences of geographic location and the photo interpreter who carried out the original Forest Resource Inventory classification were also analysed. Stocking by working group provided the strongest estimates of crown cover density. Site class and age added slightly to the predictive power of some of the equations. Both geographic location and the original interpreter had an important bearing on the equation coefficients.

bibl.et: Ecotourism at the boreal edge.
bibl.aa: Laurentian University, Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.

ab.p: A model was constructed that can be used to determine which potential forest management educational sites best match the needs and interests of ecotourists. The research required two phases of work. First, an identification and assessment was conducted of the natural history of potential educational sites along the Deer Trial at Elliot Lake. Second, important site characteristics as defined by a survey of 750 potential tourists were determined. One important conclusion drawn in phase two was that the age of travellers and family complement had a relatively small impact on what was deemed the most important needs to be met. Based on the survey and natural history assessment, 5 major categories of site characteristics were identified: visual appeal, general site characteristics, recreational and fitness resources, natural history, and forest management characteristics. For each of these major categories, subcategories were delineated. This model was then used to rate six potential sites for future ecotourism development.

bibl.et: An interpretation of the present range of distribution and dispersal of Ochrosia oppositifolia (Lam.) K. Schum. (Apocynaceae) in the Philippine beach forest.
bibl.aa: Graduate School of Science and Technology, Institute of Biological Sciences, University of the Philippines at Los Baños, College, 4031 Laguna, Philippines.

ab.p: The Philippine populations of Ochrosia oppositifolia are restricted only to 3 localities in the western Philippines: Basilan Island, Zamboanga Peninsula and Lubang Island, Occidental Mindoro. This distribution pattern indicates that the Philippine populations may have originated from the Western Malesian region where the species is widely distributed. The fruit morphology suggests the possibility of hydrochorous (water) dispersal over a long distance. However, the limited range of distribution of O. oppositifolia in the Philippines implies that the species is possibly a late emigrant into the Philippine Islands with other species from Western Malesia such as Artocarpus superba [A. anisophyllus], Mallotus miquelianus, Mezoneurum sumatranum [Caesalpinia sumatrana]. The presence of the postulated Borneo-Palawan and Borneo-Sulu land bridges during the Pleistocene (1.6 million years BP) and the Recent (10 thousand years BP) may have greatly aided plant dispersal by serving as a corridor and temporary habitat of plants during the course of migration to the Philippine Archipelago.

bibl.et: Acclimation of Salix to metal stress.
bibl.aa: School of Biological & Earth Sciences, Liverpool John Moores University, Byrom Street, Liverpool L3 3AF, UK.

ab.p: Nine clones of 6 Salix species (S. cordata, S. fragilis, S. caprea, S. cinerea, S. burjatica and S. viminalis) and one hybrid (S. × calodendron) were exposed to heavy metals in solution culture in an attempt to increase innate metal resistance. Resistance was estimated using comparative root measurements and metal uptake was studied. The first experiment entailed pre-treatments with background nutrient solution, or 0.25 and 0.50 mg Cu/litre amendments, and re-exposure to each of the same concentrations. In a second experiment clones were exposed to sub-toxic concentrations of single metals (0.15 mg Cu, 0.15 mg Cd or 2.5 mg Zn/litre) and dual-combination treatments (0.075 mg Cu + 0.075 mg Cd, 0.075 mg Cu + 1.25 mg Zn or 0.075 mg Cd + 1.25 mg Zn/litre) with concentrations gradually raised 10-fold over 128 days. Plants tested in the first experiment, following pre-exposure to Cu, were no more resistant to subsequent exposure to this metal. In the second experiment, gradual cumulative doses resulted in reduced phytotoxicity and increased resistance, most notably to Cd. There appeared to be an inverse relationship between metal uptake and resistance. Cu uptake was restricted to the roots, whereas Cd and Zn were more evenly distributed throughout the plant. Exposure to dual combinations of metals resulted in several interaction effects on uptake: increased root-bound Cu in all combinations, and increase in uptake of both Cd and Zn into the root tissues when supplied with Cu. The implications of these results for the use of willows in phytoremediation programmes are discussed.

bibl.et: The influence of air pollution on the concentration of mineral elements, on the spectral reflectance response and on the production of stress-ethylene in the lichen Ramalina duriaei.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Sciences, George S. Wise Faculty of Life Sciences, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel.

ab.p: Two parameters were applied to estimate the degree of stress induced by exposure of Ramalina duriaei to air pollution in urban-industrial sites in Israel. Changes in the spectral reflectance response of the thallus and in the production of stress-ethylene were compared with the concentration of sulphate-S, V, Ni, K, Pb, P, Cu, Cr, Fe, Mn and Mg in either in situ or in transplanted thalli of the lichen. Concentrations of Cu, Mg, Fe, Ni, Pb, V, Cr, Mn and sulphate-S in in situ thalli collected in a nature reserve in an industrial town (Ashdod, SW Israel) were higher than those detected in in situ thalli collected in a forest (HaZorea Forest, NE Israel). The high concentrations of these mineral elements in R. duriaei from the nature reserve coincided with a high rate of production of stress-ethylene and with a low normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), indicating that changes in the spectral reflectance response relate to damage to chlorophyll. Lichens collected in the unpolluted forest in February 1994, either resuspended in the same site or transplanted in 9 sites in the Ashdod region, and retrieved in November of the same year, contained higher concentrations of sulphate-S, Pb, Cu, Ni, V and Cr in the urban-industrial sites than in most of the rural localities. Statistical analysis revealed a positive correlation between the amount of ethylene produced by R. duriaei and the concentration of V and Ni in the same thalli. To test the integrity of the ethylene-producing system, lichens were soaked in either 5 or 10 m&smallcap;M FeCl2 at pH 3.7. Thalli exposed to a very polluted environment produced less ethylene after this treatment. The NDVI correlated positively with the concentration of K in the thallus but negatively with the concentration of Mn, Ni, Pb and sulphate-S in the same material. It may be concluded that the in situ thalli of R. duriaei in the nature reserve are severely stressed and possibly endangered by the pollution produced by the combustion of heavy fuel oil in the local power plant and oil refineries, and by acid rain.

bibl.et: Effect of simulated acid rain on physiology, growth and foliar nutrient concentrations of sugar maple.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Stress factors and air pollution. Selected papers from the 17th International meeting for specialists in air pollution effects on forest ecosystems held in Florence, Italy, 14-19 September, 1996.
bibl.aa: Natural Resources Canada, Canadian Forest Service, Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario P6A 5M7, Canada.

ab.p: The effect of simulated acid rain (SAR) on sugar maple (Acer saccharum) seedling growth, morphology and physiology following exposure to 12 weeks of controlled SAR treatment in a greenhouse pot experiment was investigated. SAR induced visible foliar injury in treatments more acidic than pH 3.5. Growth and gas exchange parameters were not significantly altered by SAR treatment nor were foliar concentrations of K, Mg, Ca, Mn, P, Fe, or Al. Foliar levels of S were increased by treatment at pH 3.0. These results suggest that rainfall less acidic than pH 3.5 are unlikely to cause significant direct effects to sugar maple.

bibl.et: Ecological impact of compaction under teak plantation in the foothill of Darjeeling Himalaya.
bibl.aa: Environmental Research Station, Sukna, District Darjeeling, West Bengal, India.

ab.p: The effects were studied of compaction of the soil under a teak [Tectona grandis] plantation established in 1968 in the Darjeeling Himalayan foothills of West Bengal. Two areas were surveyed in October 1993: one near a village and subjected to compaction by livestock, vehicles, forestry operations (etc.), and the other an adjacent non-compacted (control) site. In the compacted area, decreases in height, diameter and basal area of teak were 8.3, 16.4 and 34.7%, respectively, probably because of the reduced porosity and increased density of the soil. Species density of the undergrowth was 121.93% more in the compacted than the control area, while species diversity was 68.30% less. Much of the density increase was due to the presence of the grasses Paspalum sanguinalle and Oplismenus burmannii (density 69.47 and 21.56/m², compared with 21.14 and 4.80%, respectively, in the control area). Undergrowth biomass production was 1.150 t/ha in the compacted area and 2.584 t/ha in the control area, but production of the fodder component of the undergrowth was less reduced in the compacted area than was the production of the other undergrowth components.

bibl.et: Distribution of VAM fungi in bauxite mine overburden plantation of Amarkantak (Madhya Pradesh).
bibl.aa: Forest Pathology Division, Tropical Forest Research Institute, Jabalpur, Madhya Pradesh, India.

ab.p: A study was made in 1994 of VAM (vesicular arbuscular mycorrhizal) fungi in the soil, tree root colonization and tree growth in plantations of 11 species (Pinus caribaea, P. roxburghii, P. kesiya, Shorea robusta, Eucalyptus hybrid [E. tereticornis], E. camaldulensis, Grevillea pteridifolia [G. banksii], G. robusta, Acacia auriculiformis, Pongamia pinnata, Tectona grandis) established in overburden in a bauxite mined area and in 1980 and 1984. Measurements of tree growth and soil VAM fungi and colonization were also made in plantations of the same tree species in a nearby degraded forest area, and of VAM fungi in adjacent barren bauxite overburden. The data collected are tabulated [but are incomplete]. Barren bauxite mine overburden soil was deficient in VAM fungi but the forest plantations enhanced the VAM population. VAM colonization and spore density (and tree growth) varied with species and with age for the same species. The population of VAM fungi was more in the plantation in the degraded forest area than in plantations on the overburden, and tree growth was also greater in the plantation in the degraded forest area than on the overburden site.

bibl.et: Contribution to the phytocoenological knowledge of Pyrenean forests.
bibl.aa: Departament de Biologia Vegetal and Centre de Recerca d'Alta Muntanya, Universitat de Barcelona, Av. Diagonal, 645, E-08-028 Barcelona, Spain.

ab.p: Phytocoenological descriptions of a number of communities are given for the Pyrenees. One new association, three new subassociations and five variants are newly described, and the others, though described previously, were poorly known until now. For each one, species composition, ecology and distribution are discussed, and a relevé table is provided. The list, in decreasing order of dryness of habitat, is: Quercetum rotundifoliae asplenietosum adiantinigri, subass. nova, holm oak forest growing on dry, rocky slopes, mainly of slate, in the basal (rarely sub-montane) belt of the inner, drier part of the Pyrenees; Pteridio-Quercetum pubescentis - in its typical form this is a meso-xerophilous deciduous oak forest, also found on non-calcareous substrata, in the sub-montane belt, preferring cooler slopes than the former association; it includes several variants and subassociations: pteridietosum (=typicum), betuletosum pendulae and pinetosum sylvestris, novae; Lathyro linifolii-Quercetum petraeae, deciduous oak or birch forest of the montane belt, growing on meso-xeric, acid slopes at the heads of valleys; Veronico-Betuletum pendulae, deciduous mixed woodland typical of poor, acid soils, on moister aspects at the heads of the valleys; and Roso pendulinae-Aceretum platanoidis, ass. nova, mixed, very diverse thicket confined to rock deposits in moist, snowy habitats, in the upper part of the montane belt of Val d'Aran which experiences a montane Atlantic climate.

bibl.et: Population structure, spatial pattern and seedling establishment of the grey mangrove, Avicennia marina var. australasica, in New Zealand.
bibl.aa: Leigh Marine Laboratory and School of Biological Sciences, University of Auckland, PO Box 349, Warkworth, New Zealand.

ab.p: Avicennia marina var. australasica occurs as monospecific stands in the North Island of New Zealand. Using 5 m wide strip transects, A. marina adult plants and seedlings were mapped out in eight distinctive mangrove forests. All forests showed reversed 'J' size distributions of adult plants. In most cases, seedling density increased with increasing distance from the seaward edge of the mangrove forests. Mean plant size and density with respect to tidal position showed no consistent pattern across forests. Plant size seemed correlated with latitudinal gradient, with taller trees in relatively warmer regions and shorter, stunted, dwarf-like types in colder areas. The survival and growth of (a) naturally occurring seedlings in and out of tree-fall gaps and at various distances from the seaward edge of the forest, and (b) transplanted seedlings of different sizes (small, medium and large propagules: ≤ 10 cm, 10-20 cm and 21-40 cm tall, respectively) and densities (2, 5 and 9 seedlings/m²) in three delineated (low, mid and high) intertidal positions were monitored over 18-month periods. Establishment of both natural and transplanted seedlings varied significantly between locations, canopy light conditions, intertidal levels and seedling sizes, but not with density. Generally, seedling survival and growth were better in gaps than under closed canopy, irrespective of tidal position. Intertidal level significantly affected survival of transplanted seedlings, but did so only marginally for the natural ones, with survival being greatest in the high intertidal zone. By contrast, increases in plant height and leaf production were best promoted in the low intertidal position of the forest floor. Survival of the transplanted seedlings was of the order: large > small ≥ medium-sized. However, the small seedlings grew best both in terms of height and accumulation of new leaves. These patterns of survival and growth were consistent across intertidal position and seedling density. The implication of these results for the conservation and possible restoration of mangrove forests, especially in New Zealand, are discussed.

bibl.et: Modelling transpiration in holm-oak savannah: scaling up from the leaf to the tree scale.
bibl.aa: Centre d'Ecologie Fonctionnelle et Evolutive - CNRS, B.P. 5051, 34033 Montpellier Cedex, France.

ab.p: The transpiration of oak-savannas in southern Spain was modelled by scaling-up from the leaf to the tree (Quercus ilex) during a drought period. Two characteristics of this ecosystem were found to facilitate the modelling procedure. The first was a near-zero decoupling coefficient between the surface and the surrounding bulk air, which simplifies the transpiration formulation. The second was that the surface conductance (g) is mainly related to the vapour pressure deficit of the air (Da). Based on both of these characteristics, the modelling procedure provides a general model of transpiration over the time scale appropriate for a drought period, from days to months. The response of g to Da was found to follow a negative exponential function, such that beyond a minimum value, g becomes independent of Da. This implies a feedback control on g by Da. The consequences of this control for transpiration were found at different levels of plant water status. This explains the plants' adaptation to long dry periods, even though there is also continuous water loss during these periods. Such an adaptation was corroborated by a seasonal hysteresis found in the relationship between transpiration and Da as a function of the plants' water status.

bibl.et: Description and biology of a new species of Virola (Myristicaceae) from French Guiana.
bibl.ft: Description et biologie d'une nouvelle espèce de Virola (Myristicaceae) de Guyane.
bibl.aa: ORSTOM, Laboratoire de Botanique, Institut de Botanique, 163 rue A. Broussonnet, 34000 Montpellier, France.

ab.p: Virola kwatae Sabatier, a new species of forest tree from French Guiana, is described. Its taxonomic affinities, and biological and ecological features are discussed. This species was previously confused with V. michelii. Its dispersal system is highly specialized for a few frugivores, the most efficient being the spider monkey (Ateles paniscus).

bibl.do: Mokuzai Gakkaishi = Journal of the Japan Wood Research Society
bibl.et: Prediction of maximum bending moment of glulam beam composed of arbitrary laminae and verification by experimental results.
bibl.ms: English figures and tables.
bibl.aa: Wood Research Institute, Kyoto University, Uji, Kyoto 611, Japan.

ab.p: An equation for predicting the modulus of rupture (MOR) of glued laminated beams (glulam) composed of laminae with an arbitrary grade and arbitrary arrangement of its cross section, was derived by making use of the concept for multi-layered beams with interlayer slips. The equation derived also could express the size effect on the MOR without using the so-called 'size-effect factor'. Applicability of the equation derived in this work was verified by using previous full-scale experimental results. Consequently, good agreements were obtained between theoretical maximum moments predicted and observed ones for both cases of pure wooden glulam beams tested and even in wood-steel hybrid glulam beams tested by other researchers.

bibl.et: An investigation into the tool wearing characteristics of rubberwood (Hevea brasiliensis) laminated veneer lumber.
bibl.aa: Department of Furniture, Buckinghamshire College, Queen Alexandra Road, High Wycombe, Buckinghamshire HP11 2JZ, UK.

ab.p: Peripheral machining of rubberwood (Hevea brasiliensis) laminated veneer lumber (LVL) and solid rubberwood were carried out on a computer numerical control router, using cemented tungsten carbide cutters. The cutter wear rate and power consumption showed similar patterns of increment. Rubberwood LVL was found to be four times as abrasive as solid rubberwood, and a combination of wear mechanisms were involved, in contrast to abrasion which was the predominant mechanism when machining solid rubberwood. The use of a simple wear model based on the Taylor's tool life equation has enabled the total tool wear to be quantified. This information can be expanded into useful production data for the rubberwood based high-volume furniture manufacturing industry in Malaysia.

bibl.do: Impact of diseases and insect pests in tropical forests. Proceedings of the IUFRO Symposium, Peechi, India, 23-26 November 1993.
bibl.et: Impact of diseases on the productivity of bamboo stands in Kerala.
bibl.ct: Impact of diseases and insect pests in tropical forests. Proceedings of the IUFRO Symposium, Peechi, India, 23-26 November 1993.
bibl.aa: Division of Plant Pathology, Kerala Forest Research Institute, Peechi 680 653, Kerala, India.

ab.p: Bamboo, a major non-wood forest produce, occupies a large tracts of forest land in Kerala. Bambusa bambos [? Bambusa arundinacea], Dendrocalamus strictus and Ochlandra spp. (reed bamboos) are the commercially exploited species in the State. Besides the biotic interference, diseases have been found to play major role in limiting the stand productivity. A systematic disease survey conducted during 1987-1992 in 22 representative areas of natural stands and plantations of bamboos, recorded a total of 27 diseases affecting different parts of bamboos. Although 32 fungi and one mycoplasma like organism (MLO) were recorded. Rot of emerging and growing culms, and little leaf disease were the potential diseases which have affected the stand productivity considerably. Rot of emerging culm caused by Fusarium moniliforme [Gibberella fujikuroi] var. intermedium occurred both in plantations and natural stands. In plantations, percent disease incidence varied from 5.50 to 25.50 depending upon the locality, the highest percent disease incidence (33.69) being in natural stands. Rot of growing culms caused by Fusarium equiseti, often predisposed by the injury made by a sap-sucking insect, Purohitha [Purohita] cervina. B. bambos, D. strictus and D. longispathus were the severely affected bamboos. Highest percent disease incidence in plantations (12.12) and in natural stands (14.65) was recorded during 1988 and 1989 respectively. D. strictus in the dry tracts was found affected severely with little leaf disease. The disease caused by MLO affected both new and old culms. Disease severity in all the areas was found medium and highest percent incidence (90) occurred during the year 1991. The impact of these major diseases on the productivity of bamboo stands is highlighted.

bibl.do: Impact of diseases and insect pests in tropical forests. Proceedings of the IUFRO Symposium, Peechi, India, 23-26 November 1993.
bibl.et: Potentials of microbe-activating technology for plantation health management.
bibl.ct: Impact of diseases and insect pests in tropical forests. Proceedings of the IUFRO Symposium, Peechi, India, 23-26 November 1993.
bibl.aa: Division of Environmental Sciences, Indian Agricultural Research Institute, New Delhi 110 012, India.

ab.p: A useful approach to enhancing the growth and multiplication of indigenous or introduced beneficial microorganisms could be through the application of microbe-activating technology (MAT). The MAT activates soil saprophytes through various agricultural biostimulant products available in the market. Tests carried out in various countries with such formulations have shown that a significant increase in yields of both annual and perennial plants over similarly fertilized controls can be achieved through this technology. MAT, the eco-friendly technology has potentials for enhancing the biocontrol efficacy of microbial pesticides and also alleviate abiotic stresses by modifying the soil-water oxygen relations in the rhizosphere. It is thought that MAT has potential for improving the health of forest plantations.

bibl.et: Interrelations between respiration and dormancy in buds of three hardwood species with different chilling requirements for dormancy release.
bibl.aa: Agricultural University of Norway, Department of Biology and Nature Conservation, P.O. Box 5014, N-1432 Ås, Norway.

ab.p: Respiration in vegetative buds of mature Betula pendula, Alnus glutinosa and Prunus padus trees was measured monthly at 15°C from mid-October 1996 to natural outdoor budburst in April 1997. In B. pendula the effect of bud water content on respiration was also estimated (December-April) by artificial imbibition of buds for 24 h prior to measurement of respiration. For estimation of corresponding bud dormancy status, batches of twigs were forced at identical monthly intervals at 15°C in long days (24 h), and budburst recorded. In all species dormancy was deepest when the leaves were shed in October, and dormancy was first alleviated in P. padus followed by B. pendula and A. glutinosa. However, bud respiration capacity was not related to dormancy release as it decreased in all species from October to November and displayed no notable increase until February in P. padus, March in B. pendula and April in A. glutinosa, after completion of dormancy release. Rather, increase in respiration coincided with growth resumption prior to budburst. Artificial imbibition of B. pendula buds increased the water content by approximately 10% (FW) and induced a doubling of the respiration rate (December-February). Moreover, the seasonal variation in bud water content (October-April) explained 94% of the variation in respiration in B. pendula and P. padus, and 84% in A. glutinosa. These observations suggest an important role of water content for respiration. During a cold period from mid-December to mid-January with mean temperature of -9.7°C dormancy release was arrested in P. padus, and to some degree in A. glutinosa, whereas dormancy release progressed normally in B. pendula. This indicates species differences in lower critical temperatures for dormancy release.

bibl.et: Effect of temperature on thermal stresses across the grain of wood. Preliminary study.
bibl.aa: Department of Wood Science, Agricultural University of Poznan´, Poland.

ab.p: The values of maximal thermal stress in oven dry beech wood (Fagus sylvatica) was determined by means of 'dumping' thermal linear deformations in the radial and tangential directions during heating samples from room temperature 20°C to a temperature of 40, 60, 80 and 100°C. Results showed that with a rise in heating temperature the value of thermal stresses increased. The maximal thermal stresses determined for beech wood heated at the given temperatures ranged from 0.39 MPa (at 40°C) to 1.40 MPa (at 100°C) for the radial direction, and from 0.30 MPa to 1.21 MPa for the tangential direction. The time required for the maximum thermal stress to develop was 5 to 6 minutes and did not depend on the anatomical direction of wood or heating temperature.

bibl.et: Are there species in the genus Clusia with obligate C3-photosynthesis?
bibl.aa: Institut für Botanik, Technische Hochschule Darmstadt, Schnittspahnstr. 3-5, D-64287 Darmstadt, Germany.

ab.p: Most of the species in the genus Clusia are very flexible in their photosynthetic pathway, and are C3-photosynthesis/Crassulacean acid metabolism (CAM) intermediate species; therefore, the identification and clear assignment of Clusia-species to C3- or CAM-pathways is difficult. An attempt was made to characterize obligate C3-photosynthesis species within the genus. Five species of the family Clusiaceae (four of the genus Clusia and one of the genus Oedematopus) were selected on the basis of their low leaf succulence as potential obligate C3-photosynthesis species. All of them showed a C3-photosynthesis pattern of gas exchange under well-watered conditions and their δ13C-values were also in the range of obligate C3-photosynthesis plants. Under drought stress C. articulata and C. cruiva were C3-photosynthesis/CAM intermediate species, while C. parviflora, C. multiflora and most likely O. mirandensis did not show any nocturnal CO2-fixation. However, in C. parviflora and O. mirandensis some night time accumulation of malate by internal CO2-recycling might occur. So far, C. multiflora seems to be the only known Clusia species with neither nocturnal net CO2-uptake nor malate accumulation.

bibl.et: Dormancy in seeds of Hibbertia cuneiformis and H. huegelii (Dilleniaceae).
bibl.aa: School of Environmental Biology, Curtin University of Technology, PO Box U 1987, Perth, WA 6001, Australia.

ab.p: Dormancy delays the germination of seeds in two species of the primitive angiosperm genus Hibbertia (H. cuneiformis and H. huegelii, family Dilleniaceae). After seed coat removal, germination increased in 18-month-old seeds of H. cuneiformis and 6- to 8-month-old seeds of H. huegelii. Hence, seeds of the two species exhibited seed coat dormancy. The removal of the seed coat may stimulate germination, as the result of increased water uptake, and/or the removal of mechanical and chemical inhibition. However, the occurrence of imbibitional injury and a reduced percentage of vigorous seedlings in decoated seeds suggested that embryo dormancy, as a second type of dormancy, impedes germination in H. cuneiformis. Embryo dormancy also delayed the germination of seeds of H. huegelii, since a high percentage of seeds did not germinate after removal of the seed coat. Embryo dormancy appeared to vary among individual seeds and between species. The germination experiments suggested a high percentage of non-dormant and weakly dormant embryos for 18-month-old seeds of H. cuneiformis. By contrast, many seeds of H. huegelii appear to contain deeply dormant embryos. In H. cuneiformis, the depth of the seed dormancy depended on seed age. Freshly harvested seeds did not germinate for 3 months. Treatment with 120 mg gibberellic acid (GA3)/litre significantly enhanced germination of freshly harvested and 18-month-old, intact seeds of H. cuneiformis and the germination of decoated 18-month-old seeds of H. huegelii. Kinetin and abscisic acid did not affect the final germination percentage in 18-month-old seeds of H. cuneiformis. For H. huegelii, germination was reduced in decoated seeds and seeds with cracked coats exposed to an 8 h day:16 h night diurnal cycle compared with complete darkness.

bibl.et: Early Tertiary macrofossils of Proteaceae from Tasmania.
bibl.aa: Department of Plant Science, University of Tasmania, GPO Box 252-55, Hobart, Tas. 7001, Australia.

ab.p: Proteaceous leaves from 2 Early Tertiary sites in Tasmania are described and discussed. Based on gross leaf morphological and cuticular characters, 15 species are recognized from Oligocene lacustrine sediments at Cethana. Some specimens were indistinguishable from extant Telopea truncata from Tasmania and Lomatia fraxinifolia from NE Queensland, and were assigned to these taxa. Specimens from the Leven River deposit, probably also of Oligocene age, are assigned to Orites, and are closely related to extant O. excelsa from rain forests in NE New South Wales and NE Queensland. The fossils demonstrate the past association of now geographically remote taxa, and the prevalence of sclero- and xeromorphy in the Proteaceae by the Oligocene.

bibl.et: Lignocellulolytic enzyme production on pretreated poplar wood by filamentous fungi.
bibl.aa: Department of Agricultural Chemical Technology, Technical University of Budapest, HU-1521, Hungary.

ab.p: Gliocladium sp. TUB F-498, a wild strain of a lignocellulolytic fungus with a fast growth rate and enzyme production rate, was selected as a potential in situ enzyme source for the bioprocessing of pretreated poplar [Populus sp.] wood (PPW) to ethanol in a simultaneous saccharification and fermentation process. TUB F-498 produced 77 filter paper units of cellulase activity and 246 IU of β-glucosidase activity per g dry weight of substrate utilized, as compared with the highly successful mutant reference strain Trichoderma reesei [Trichoderma longibrachiatum] Rut-C30, which produced 100 filter paper units and 92 IU per g dry weight substrate in a stirred-tank fermentation. TUB F-498 also produced more xylanase and endoglucanase activity than Rut-C30 on PPW in shake-flask fermentations.

bibl.et: Acoustic emission monitoring during bending moment test of round-end mortise and tenon joints.
bibl.aa: Dept. of Forest Products Technology, National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, Taiwan, China.

ab.p: An acoustic emission (AE) technique was employed to investigate the feasibility of quality evaluation of round-end mortise and tenon joints in T-shaped structure through measuring bending moment properties in this study. Kiln dried wood of red oak (Quercus falcata), rubber wood (Hevea brasiliensis), formosan ash (Fraxinus formosana) and chinese hemlock (Tsuga chinensis) were used as construction members. In bending moment test, parameters include types of adhesives and their spreading methods, and the rigidity was also measured. The total AE counts during the bending moment test decreased as the density of members increased, and was less when flexible adhesives such as PVAc emulsion was applied. The most AE counts were concentrated at the range beyond proportional limit during the bending moment test. The distribution of AE peak amplitudes showed the same trend for joints with various gluing approaches, i.e., the percentage of AE counts decreased with an increase in the peak amplitudes. AE counts were also affected by the species of the wood members, adhesive type, and glue spreading method.

bibl.et: Continuous-flow wood chip reactor for biodegradation of 2,4-DCP.
bibl.aa: Korea Environment Institute, 1049-1, Sadang, DongJak, Seoul, Korea Republic.

ab.p: This research investigates the ability and efficiency of continuous-flow wood chip reactors seeded with a white-rot fungus to degrade 2,4-dichlorophenol (2,4-DCP) using wood chips as a carbon source. When 2,4-DCP was the only substrate (nonglucose treatment conditions), the wood chip reactor system had a high degradation efficiency and operated continuously without excessive fungal biomass buildup on the wood chips. In the presence of added glucose, a clogging problem and an effluent contamination problem of fungal cells are found during the reactor operating period. In addition, 2,4-DCP is degraded effectively both under low-nitrogen (low-N) (0.012 g/litre of NH4Cl) as well as high-nitrogen (high-N) (0.12 g/litre of NH4Cl) treatment conditions. The 2,4-DCP is degraded to a greater extent with small-size wood chips (5&thin;×&thin;5 mm) and hardwood chips (birch as opposed to pine) as a carbon source. The results of this research demonstrate a potential application of wood chip reactor systems for the treatment of contaminated water while expanding the use of wasted forest products.

bibl.do: Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden
bibl.et: A revision of Styrax (Styracaceae) for western Texas, Mexico, and Mesoamerica.
bibl.aa: Department of Botany, Duke University, Durham, North Carolina 27708-0339, USA.

ab.p: Despite a recent taxonomic treatment of Styrax from North America and the Caribbean, the taxonomy of this genus has remained poorly understood. In an effort to clarify the taxonomy of Styrax from western Texas through Mesoamerica, morphological characteristics of over 2500 specimens from 29 herbaria were examined. The previous treatment emphasized vegetative characters for circumscription, whereas the present revision includes heretofore poorly characterized features of the androecium. This revision comprises 19 species and 24 taxa in the area considered, nearly three times as many species as recognized previously. It includes six new tree species (S. gentryi, S. incarnatus, S. nicaraguensis, S. radians, S. steyermarkii, S. tuxtlensis), two new subspecies (S. platanifolius subsp. mollis, S. nicaraguensis subsp. ellipsoidalis), three new combinations (S. platanifolius subsp. stellatus, S. platanifolius subsp. texanus, S. platanifolius subsp. youngiae), and two new species names (S. austromexicanus, S. lanceolatus, formerly S. argenteus var. grandiflorus and var. parvifolius). Two names (S. glabrescens var. pilosus and S. jaliscanus) are lectotypified. Nearly 70% of the species recognized in the revision are narrow endemics. This work has provided the basis for a taxonomic revision of all neotropical Styrax that is currently under way.

bibl.et: The restoration of replanted ancient woodland: A report for English Nature, contract No. FIN/CON/VTA9.
bibl.aa: MIEEM, 7 Maybank Close Chinley High Peak, SK23 6EN, UK.

ab.p: Temporary 5×5 m plots were used to assess the ground flora recovery and woody species regeneration in 4 (originally ancient woodland) sites in the UK recently restored after conifer planting (by thinning or felling the conifers, and some broadleaf planting). The sites were: Castor Hanglands NNR (National Nature Reserve); Cambridgeshire, Foxley Wood SSSI (Site of Special Scientific Interest), Norfolk; Mortimer Forest, Shropshire; and Eaton and Gamston Woods SSSI, Nottinghamshire. Comparisons were made with nearby original semi-natural stands and with remaining conifer stands. Ten plots were placed within each treatment, and a vascular plant list produced for the field layer (including regeneration less then 2 m high), the shrub layer and the canopy layer with dominance values assigned to each species. An estimate of percentage cover was also made for each layer. At most of the sites regeneration was occurring in the restored area, mainly from seedling establishment, with the mean number of regenerating species per plot 1.5-3.2. Regeneration was also occurring in the other treatments, although at one site, Eaton and Gamston Wood, it was a rather infrequent phenomenon in the original semi-natural stand (which had a closed canopy) and in the conifer stand (where there was a deep litter layer and which was very heavily shaded). It is concluded that a semi-natural tree cover would develop although some intervention may be required to remove undesirable species, particularly conifer seedlings, at some sites. Planting of conifers had suppressed the ground cover compared with that in the semi-natural stand, although the mean number of species per plot at each site remained similar. At two sites there was reasonable correlation between the species lists for the two stand types, including a similar number of ancient woodland indicator species. In the restored areas there had been considerable expansion of the ground layer, and at two sites in particular (Foxley Wood and Castor Hanglands) a significant increase in the number of species in the plots compared with the semi-natural stand. Generally the ground layer in the restored area included species characteristic of the semi-natural stand, including a similar number of ancient woodland indicators, although often at a low frequency. The new colonists, which usually contributed substantially to vegetation cover, were normally not woodland specialists and many would be classed as various types of competitors. The colonists are species which have developed regenerative strategies which allow them to take advantage of disturbance, such as felling, but they do not thrive in conditions where levels of stress are high and are thought unlikely to persist once a broadleaved canopy develops. From these findings it is concluded that a semi-natural ground layer would be restored successfully, at least at 3 sites. The exception was Mortimer Forest; reasons for this are discussed.

bibl.et: Silviculture. Volume 1. Forest studies.
bibl.ft: Silvicultura. Vol. 1. Studiul padurii.
bibl.ms: map in pocket

ab.p: This volume consists of 7 chapters. The first chapter provides general information on the tasks of silviculture, gives a short history of its development and discusses research methods and interactions between silviculture, agriculture, industry and human activity. Chapter 2 outlines the role and importance of forests, forest products and forest zoning in Romania; Chapter 3 discusses interactions between forest components and structure of forests and phytocoenoses; Chapter 4 focuses on interrelations between forests and climate, temperature, humidity, light, wind, air composition, topography, vegetation, fauna and human activity. Processes occurring in forest ecosystems such as regeneration, individual tree and stand growth, natural pruning and reduction of stand density, pure and mixed stands and succession of forest vegetation in Romania are described in chapter 5. A brief history of forest evolution is presented in Chapter 6. Chapter 7 adresses systems of classification, forest types, altitudinal and latitudinal zoning and interzone vegetation in Romania and principles and methods used in forest classification. A map detailing vegetation types in Romania is included.

bibl.et: A guide to the analysis of profitability of forest investments. A manual for rural development workers.
bibl.ft: Guide d'analyse de rentabilité des investissements forestiers. Manuel à l'usage des techniciens développement rural.
bibl.pb: Département des Eaux et Fore˘ts de l'ESSA
bibl.ms: Manuel forestier No. 3

ab.p: This technical guide is arranged in three chapters. Chapter 1 defines costs and receipts, categories, and how to assess productivity, and the various forestry activities which must be costed are detailed. Chapter 2 deals with the calculation of profitability, and the indicators which can be used, illustrated with hypothetical examples typical of Madagascar, e.g., the installation of a Eucalyptus sp. plantation on land unsuited to agriculture. Chapter 3 extends the analysis for use in agroforestry situations, illustrated with an example of a rice/Acacia mangium system, with details of costs and receipts for each year over a 13-year period.

bibl.et: Effects of in-forest sorting of Norway spruce (Picea abies) and Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris) on wood and fibre properties.
bibl.aa: Department of Forest Products, Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, P.O. Box 7008, S-750 07 Uppsala, Sweden.

ab.p: Logs from a mature stand of Picea abies and Pinus sylvestris were sorted into five pulpwood assortments to achieve better-defined raw material aimed at different fibre products. The sorting criteria were tree species, tree class, and log type (butt, middle and top). Differences in wood properties between species were moderate when equivalent log types were compared. Mean annual ring width and moisture content varied most between tree classes. Sorting based on log type resulted in the greatest differences in basic density, juvenile wood content, and heartwood content. Unbeaten kraft pulp from spruce assortments had weighted fibre length means of 3.1 down to 2.7 mm, while pine assortments had lengths between 2.7 and 2.5 mm. The largest percentage differences between the assortments were 6.3-14.8% for six strength indices. The differences in sheet densities and porosity were 5.0 and 50.4%, respectively. Differences in sheet properties were generally greater between log types than between species. Top logs exhibited the highest sheet densities, while middle logs showed slightly higher values for most strength properties. Spruce assortments tended to give better strength properties than pine, while middle logs of pine gave the highest porosity. By in-forest sorting, some concentration effects of fibres were achieved.

bibl.et: Is there a floral parasite mutualism in cycad pollination? The pollination biology of Encephalartos villosus (Zamiaceae).
bibl.aa: Ecology and Conservation, National Botanical Institute, P/Bag X7, Claremont 7735, South Africa.

ab.p: Observations and experiments were carried out in South Africa over 5 years to distinguish between wind and insect pollination in Encephalartos villosus. They were also designed to determine whether a pollination mutualism exists between E. villosus and Antliarhinus zamiae (Coleoptera: Brentidae), an obligate ovule parasite that routinely parasitizes a large proportion of the ovules. The percentage of fertilized ovules dropped slightly when wind was excluded from the megastrobilus. However, when insects were excluded by either net bags or insecticide, there was a substantial decrease in the proportion of fertilized ovules. Five beetle species belonging to 4 families were found on the strobili at the time of pollination. Using data on the effectiveness of pollen transfer to the receptive ovule, as well as data on abundance and pollen loads, a pollinator importance value (PIV) was determined for each beetle species and a pollinator importance index (PII) was determined for each population. PII values showed that an undescribed weevil (Porthetes sp., Curculionidae) was consistently the most important pollinator. A. zamiae and an undescribed beetle species within the Xenoscelinae (Languriidae) played a minor role in pollination, and their contributions varied from year to year and between populations. Two additional beetle species, one of Boganiidae and a second species of Xenoscelinae, had very low PII values and probably had little or no effect on pollination. Low PIV scores for A. zamiae were a result of its low numbers on the microstrobilus and the tendency of the beetles to remain on the outside of the megastrobilus. In the interaction between E. villosus and A. zamiae, the cycad did not appear to benefit significantly from a pollination service, indicating that the relationship is antagonistic rather than mutualistic. There is, however, a possible mutualism between Porthetes sp. and E. villosus.

bibl.et: Anti-herbivore defenses of young tropical leaves: physiological constraints and ecological trade-offs.
bibl.aa: Biology Department, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA.

ab.p: Defensive traits against herbivory of young leaves in tropical forests include rapid expansion, ant defence, secondary compounds, and synchronous leaf production to satiate the herbivores. Delayed chloroplast development postpones input of resources until the leaf is mature and better defended. This paper discusses the physiological processes and costs of these defences. Data from 250 species in lowland rain forests worldwide show that subsets of traits consistently co-occurred, but that they are not all present in a single species.

bibl.aa: Biology Department, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA.

ab.p: Epiphytic communities, which frequently occur on leaves in the humid tropics, are usually dominated by lichens and liverworts. A brief summary is given of the performance of lichens and liverworts. The effects of abiotic factors on the extent of epiphyte colonization and on competitive outcomes among different epiphytic species are examined. Evidence for both positive and negative effects of epiphytes on host leaves, and the effects of host leaf characteristics on rates of epiphyte colonization are discussed.

bibl.et: Freshwater and saltwater flooding response for woody species common to barrier island swales.
bibl.aa: Department of Biology, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, Virginia 23284, USA.

ab.p: Flood sensitivity of five woody species common to barrier island swale habitats was quantified in a glasshouse study to examine potential mechanisms affecting observed small-scale distribution patterns. Differential response to short-term (30 day duration) freshwater and saltwater flooding occurred among the five species. Only Baccharis halimifolia was sensitive to freshwater flooding. At both low (2 and 5 g litre-1) and mid-range (10 g litre-1) salinity, Myrica cerifera, Pinus taeda, and B. halimifolia were more sensitive than Juniperus virginiana or Iva frutescens. At low salinity, stomatal conductance was significantly reduced for M. cerifera, P. taeda, and B. halimifolia, although recovery occurred and there was no mortality. At midrange salinity, all five species showed reduced stomatal conductance, but recovery differed. Mortality was highest for M. cerifera and B. halimifolia (60%), followed by P. taeda (40%), I. frutescens (25%), and J. virginiana (20%). In contrast, 100% mortality occurred for all species in high salinity treatments of 20 and 30 g litre-1. It is suggested that interspecific differences in response to flooding may be a mechanism affecting small-scale distribution patterns of woody species in barrier island swales.

bibl.et: Secondary succession following catastrophic windthrow in a boreal forest in Hokkaido, Japan: the timing of tree establishment.
bibl.ct: Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute international workshop, Tsukuba, Japan, 7-9 September 1993. Part II.
bibl.aa: Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, Tsukuba 305, Japan.

ab.p: In 1954, Picea jezoensis or P. glehnii/Abies sachalinensis forests of central Hokkaido were levelled by a windstorm caused by a typhoon. Successional dynamics following disturbance on several forest habitats were monitored over 34 years. Differences in site conditions, such as soil, topography, and forest floor vegetation, influenced the direction of succession, but some patterns prevailing in this area were discernible. In the early stage of succession (up to year 10), all sites were immediately occupied by Rubus idaeus var. aculeatissimus which was an inconspicuous component of the stands before disturbance. Plants which dominated the understorey of stands before disturbance mostly disappeared during secondary succession except for Sasa senanensis. Residual conifers also survived except for those at a moss-floor site. Betula spp. and Salix spp. invaded within 6-8 years. At year 10-18, R. idaeus suddenly decreased in canopy cover and was replaced by S. senanensis as the dominant component. Trees, both residuals and invaders, were successful in growing over the shrub layer during this period and species diversity reached a peak. These observations suggest that the timing of tree establishment occurs during the transition from R. idaeus community to S. senanensis community in the shrub-layer, as a deterministic process founded in the life history traits of species.

bibl.et: Effects of season, weather and vertical position on the variation in light quantity and quality in a Japanese deciduous broadleaf forest.
bibl.ct: Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute international workshop, Tsukuba, Japan, 7-9 September 1993. Part I.
bibl.aa: Forest and Forest Products Research Institute (FFPRI), Hokkaido Research Center, Sapporo 062, Japan.

ab.p: Light measurements were taken under different sky conditions, seasons and spatial locations both vertically and along transects to provide a more detailed description of the forest light environment useful in interpreting the growth response of herbs and tree seedlings in the forest understorey. Measurements were made in a mature secondary forest in Sapporo, Japan. Cloudy skies reduced the heterogeneity in both PPFD (photosynthetically-active photon flux density) and R:FR (red to far red ratio, 656-664 nm/726-734 nm) in shade and forest gaps. Under cloudy conditions, R:FR was relatively stable across different PPFD. The mean light intensity in some forest sites was higher under cloudy skies than under clear skies because of increased penetration of diffuse light. In areas where overcast conditions are frequent, growth of understorey plants may show strong correspondence with the cloudy PPFD and R:FR conditions. Percent canopy opening was stable during the summer but daily sunfleck duration varied considerably because of the shifting solar track. Because of the presence of ground vegetation, light gradient above the forest floor is greatest from 0 to 1 m in the shade. Light environment may become dimmer with increasing heights beyond 1 m as shading from low tree branches imposes a greater influence. Across a forest transect, percent canopy opening showed marginal to five-fold increases from 0 to 1 m indicating higher PPFD on cloudy days. On clear days, plants at 1 m could experience more sunflecks of higher intensity and longer individual duration. Carbon balance of forest understorey plants may vary significantly with vertical location and weather conditions.

bibl.et: Stochastic resampling techniques for quantifying error propagations in forest field experiments.
bibl.aa: Canadian Forest Service, Pacific Forestry Centre, 506 West Burnside Road, Victoria, BC V8Z 1M5, Canada.

ab.p: Statistical analyses of forest field experiments often do not address uncertainties in model parameters and intermediate residuals and thus fail to account fully for the uncertainty inherent in the results. Stochastic resampling (bootstrap) provides a tool to integrate all known sources of variation into the final results. This paper demonstrates stochastic resampling of data from a red pine (Pinus resinosa) spacing trial with two spacings and four replications in Chalk River, Ontario. Stochastic resampling resulted in higher among-plot variances of tree size and volume, which consequently lowered the significance level of pairwise t-tests of no spacing effect. The reliability of a direct analysis (no resampling) averaged 0.84. Stochastic resampling lowered the t-test statistics by an average of 18% and their significance levels by about 75%. Resampling reversed the conclusion of 1 hypothesis out of 12 of no spacing effect, and changed the significance level of 2 tests from 0.06 to >0.09. Bootstrapped volume estimates were 1-6% higher than directly computed estimates because of nonlinear transformations of residuals in the volume equations. Resampling techniques with a complete account of all relevant sources of variation hold promise for data analyses in forestry.

bibl.et: Simulating the growth of a 160-year-old sugar maple (Acer saccharum) tree with and without ozone exposure using the TREGRO model.
bibl.aa: Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research, Tower Road, Ithaca, NY 14853-1801, USA.

ab.p: The simulation model TREGRO was parameterized from published phenology and allometry data to produce a 160-year-old sugar maple (Acer saccharum) tree following a 3-year model simulation. The simulated TREGRO sugar maple tree was calibrated so that (1) the modelled carbon (C) gain in each of the tree components (foliage, branch, stem, coarse and fine roots) and the total tree C gain was within 10% of the value projected from the literature-based allometric relationships and (2) the simulated tree maintained the proportion of total nonstructural carbohydrate (TNC) and the ratio of structure to wood in each of the tree components parameterized in the base tree. Using this parameter set, and the reported photosynthetic responses of sugar maple seedlings exposed to ozone (O3) in open-top chambers at Boyce Thompson Institute, Ithaca, New York, a series of model runs was conducted to assess the possible effects O3 exposure could have on mature sugar maple tree physiology. Atmospheric O3 concentrations at twice the ambient O3 concentration at Ithaca reduced the C gain of the 160-year-old simulated sugar maple tree. The reduction in tree C occurred only in the storage (TNC) portions of the C pools in the sugar maple tree following a 3-year simulation. Similar reductions of TNC pools have been observed in forest-grown sugar maple trees that exhibit symptoms of physiological stress. The reported simulations, although only an estimate of an individual tree's response in Ithaca, provide a basis for understanding the interactions between O3 stress and mature tree physiological responses heretofore unavailable due to cost and other constraints of field experimentation.

bibl.do: Environmental Science and Pollution Research International
bibl.et: Exposure to chlorinated acetic acids: responses of peroxidase and glutathione S-transferase activity in pine needles.
bibl.aa: GSF - Forschungszentrum für Umwelt und Gesundheit GmbH, Neuherberg, Institut für Biochemische Pflanzenpathologie, Ingolstädter Landstrasse 1, D-85764 Neuherberg, Germany.

ab.p: During long-term exposure of pine (Pinus sylvestris) seedlings to trichloro- and monochloroacetic acids via root uptake or acid mist treatments, both substances were removed from the plant tissues by metabolic activity. These compounds, which have been used as herbicides, are organic acids that have recently been detected in the environment, possibly originating from photodegradation reactions of volatile chlorinated hydrocarbons, which are anthropogenic atmospheric pollutants. None of the treated plants exhibited visible stress symptoms at the concentrations used. In addition, the exposure to both substances led to dramatic changes in the activity of xenobiotic detoxification enzymes (peroxidase and glutathione S-transferase) in the needles of the plants.

bibl.et: Planning conservation areas in Uganda's natural forests.
bibl.aa: Ghana Wildlife Department, PO Box M239, Ministry Post Office, Accra, Ghana.

ab.p: In the late 1980s the Ugandan Government decided to dedicate a fifth (3000 km²) of the country's 15&thin;000 km² forest estate to management as Strict Nature Reserves (SNRs) for the protection of biodiversity. The Forest Department subsequently undertook a 5-year programme of biological inventory and socio-economic evaluation to select appropriate areas for designation. Sixty-five of the country's principal forests (including five now designated as National Parks) were systematically evaluated for biodiversity, focusing on five 'indicator' taxa (woody plants, birds, small mammals, butterflies and large moths). A scoring system was developed to compare and rank sites according to their suitability for nature reserve establishment and 11 key sites were identified, which, when combined with the country's 10 national parks, account for more than 95 per cent of Uganda's species. In order to satisfy multiple-use management objectives, the Man and the Biosphere model of reserve design is being applied at each forest, by designating a centrally located core area as SNR, with increasingly intensive resource use permitted towards the periphery of each reserve and adjacent rural communities.

bibl.et: A taxonomic revision of the Eucalyptus striaticalyx group (Eucalyptus series Rufispermae: Myrtaceae).
bibl.aa: 156 Pimpala Road, Morphett Vale, South Australia 5162, Australia.

ab.p: A taxonomic revision of Eucalyptus striaticalyx W. Fitzg. sens. lat. has been undertaken based on morphological characteristics observed through field studies, herbarium research and seedling trials. E. striaticalyx W. Fitzg. subsp. striaticalyx, from the northern goldfields and E. clelandii F. Muell. from the central goldfields of Western Australia are treated and new taxa are described here as E. striaticalyx subsp. delicata Nicolle & P.J. Lang, restricted to a couple of lunette systems in the northern goldfields of Western Australia, E. gypsophila Nicolle, widespread in the Great Victoria Desert of Western Australia and South Australia, with remnant populations extending to the Gascoyne Region of Western Australia, E. repullulans Nicolle from the Pilbara area of Western Australia, and E. canescens Nicolle (with subsp. canescens and subsp. beadellii Nicolle), apparently endemic to the southern Great Victoria Desert of South Australia. Keys, maps and representative illustrations for all the described species are provided.

bibl.et: Aesthetic considerations in British Forestry.
bibl.ct: Special 70th year commemoration issue.
bibl.aa: Ash House, Bloxworth, Wareham, Dorset BH20 7EG, UK.

ab.p: The paper of the same name by Dallimore, W. in the inaugural issue of this journal in 1927, is reviewed from a current perspective. The subsequent lack of attention to the appearance of afforestation led to widespread criticism and the Forestry Commission responded by the appointment of Crowe, S. as landscape consultant. The development of a visual response to the landscape in forest design was adopted by some foresters but others found a functional and silvicultural approach easier and this resulted in continued visual problems of shape and, more frequently, scale. The ecological, hydrological, archaeological and social demands on forest planning and design have followed those of landscape and have become part of an integrated approach. Policy continues to be more clearly prescribed about such matters with the development of guidelines, indicative strategies and forestry standards. The need for other environmental demands to be integrated with landscape considerations and not to its detriment is stressed especially as good landscape design is capable of inspiring strong public support for forestry.

bibl.et: Participatory approach to relocate villages from protected area: a lesson from Chandaka-Dampara Wildlife Sanctuary.
bibl.ct: Special issue: Participatory forest management.
bibl.aa: Forest Department, Bhubaneswar, Orissa, India.

ab.p: The rehabilitation of villagers from protected areas is one of the major problems of forest and wildlife managers in India. The case study presented here involved the relocation of a part of village from Chandaka-Dampara Wildlife Sanctuary near Bhubaneswar, Orissa. The approach adopted was participatory, and had successful results. The methods used indicate that it may be possible to develop a methodology for relocating villagers from protected areas through promoting a sense of mutual trust and understanding of the problems which need to be addressed by foresters and villagers. The particular problems involved in the case of the Chandaka-Dampara Wildlife Sanctuary, and the characteristics of the sanctuary, are described. The same methodology could be applied to any community problem/rehabilitation proposal arising due to irrigation, mining, industrial or other project, and even for community development.

bibl.et: Vegetative propagation of Ricinodendron heudelotii, a West African fruit tree.
bibl.aa: Forestry Research Station, PMB 29 Kumba, S.W.P. Cameroon.

ab.p: Leafy stem cuttings of Ricinodendron heudelotii were collected as seedlings or coppice shoots from the Southern Bakundu Forest Reserve, Cameroon (seedlings were also collected from farm land), and inserted in a low-technology non-mist propagation system in a shade house. Three separate experiments were carried out using: (i) 6 propagation media - sawdust (SD), fine sand (FS), medium sand (MS), gravel (G), and 50:50 mixtures of G:SD and MS:SD; (ii) 4 IBA concentrations - 0, 8, 40 and 200 µg IBA/10 µl alcohol; and (iii) 4 leaf area treatments - 0, 25, 50 and 80 cm² (obtained using paper templates). The overall effect of propagation medium on final rooting percentage was highly significant, with the highest values being recorded in FS and SD. The number of roots per rooted cutting also differed markedly between treatments, mean values ranging from 3.8 to 7.3 in G and SD, respectively. Application of IBA had no significant effect on final rooting percentage, although root number was positively related to IBA concentration, with values ranging from 2.7 to 10.5 in 0 and 250 µg IBA, respectively. Leaf area had a highly significant effect on rooting percentage and root number, with the highest values recorded in the 80 cm² treatment. Defoliated cuttings completely failed to root. The maximum rooting of >80% obtained in all 3 experiments indicated that R. heudelotii is amenable to vegetative propagation using these techniques.

bibl.et: Avenue conservation and management: a case study.
bibl.aa: 1 Mona St, Beeston, Notts NG9 2BY, UK.

ab.p: Concerns for public safety led to the formulation of a management plan for Lime Tree Avenue, an important feature within the grounds of Wollaton Park, Nottingham, UK, which will ensure its conservation. The 899-m avenue has 404 lime trees (Tilia × vulgaris [T. europaea] with some T. platyphyllos) dating from the early 18th century, in a double-row pattern on either side of a grass ride, the whole extending over 4.4 ha, and aligned E.-W. on a gentle slope. A key feature of the plan is the reconciliation of three potentially conflicting objectives: public safety, nature conservation and landscape conservation. Avenue management is always problematic; satisfactory solutions cannot be prescriptive.

bibl.do: Applications of physiological ecology to forest management.
bibl.et: Applications of physiological ecology to forest management.
bibl.aa: Correspondence address: CSIRO Australia, Institute of Natural Resources and Environment, Canberra, ACT, Australia.

ab.p: This book is aimed at undergraduates in final courses for degrees in forestry and forest ecology, and postgraduate students in the same disciplines. It discusses the effects of the environment, humans and their interactions on the growth of forests, and the use of this knowledge in forest management decision making. There are 10 chapters covering a wide range of topics: Introduction; Forest biomes of the world; Canopy architecture and microclimate; Forest hydrology and tree-water relations; Carbon balance of forests; Soil organic matter and decomposition; Nutrient distribution and cycling; Changes in ecosystem structure and function during stand development; Ecosystem process models; and Applications of modern technology and ecophysiology to forest management.

bibl.do: Biodiversity conservation in transboundary protected areas. Proceedings of an international workshop, Bieszczady and Tatra National Parks, Poland, 15-25, May 1994.
bibl.et: Biodiversity conservation in transboundary protected areas. Proceedings of an international workshop, Bieszczady and Tatra National Parks, Poland, 15-25, May 1994.
bibl.ct: Biodiversity conservation in transboundary protected areas. Proceedings of an international workshop, Bieszczady and Tatra National Parks, Poland, 15-25, May 1994.
bibl.ms: refs at ends of papers. Issued by the Office for Central Europe and Eurasia, Office of International Affairs, National Research Council, National Academy of Sciences, Washington, DC, USA
bibl.aa: Department of Geoecology, Institute of Geography and Spatial Organization, Polish Academy of Sciences, Krakowskie Przedmiescie 30, 00-927 Warsaw, Poland

ab.p: An overview and 36 papers are presented from this workshop which was organized by the National Academy of Sciences of the USA (NAS) and the Polish Academy of Sciences (PAN), who began a bilateral cooperation on environmental issues in 1986. The workshop was held in 2 parts - the first at the Bieszczady Biosphere Reserve and the second at the Tatry Biosphere Reserve, and was attended by NAS representatives from various backgrounds from NAS, Poland, Belarus, the Czech Republic, Ukraine and Slovakia. The purpose of the workshop was to explore opportunities to integrate science and management in transboundary protected areas in Central Europe for the conservation of biodiversity. More specific goals were to: clarify current and future problems of wildlife management (particularly overgrazing), tourism and recreational use of protected areas; share current western theories and practices on forest management, including restoration ecology and landscape ecology; and develop a network of scientists and managers to cooperate in biodiversity conservation in transboundary protected areas. The 36 papers are arranged in 5 sections: I, General issues of conservation of protected areas (5 papers); II, Biodiversity conservation in the participating countries (7 papers); III, Biosphere reserves and natural conditions in Central European border regions (10 papers); IV, Wildlife and tourism management in transboundary protected areas (7 papers); and V, Monitoring and measuring the diversity of life in border areas (7 papers). Part VI has 3 appendices: Basic principles and research agenda; Workshop agenda; and List of participants. All the papers are noticed separately.

bibl.do: Air pollution: dimensions, trends and interactions with a forest ecosystem.
bibl.et: Air pollution: dimensions, trends and interactions with a forest ecosystem.
bibl.ms: refs. at end of each chapter; 115 figures and tables
bibl.aa: GKSS Research Centre Geesthacht, Max-Planck-Strasse, D-21502 Geesthacht, Germany.

ab.p: This book gives a final account of one aspect of a multi-disciplinary research project undertaken in Germany into the causes and symptoms of forest decline. The evaluation of air pollution - including status, inputs, temporal trends and fluxes, and interactions with forest ecosystems - was the focal point of research undertaken by the Institute of Physics of the GKSS Research Centre at Geesthacht. The research site, 'Postturm', is located 40 km NE of Hamburg, in a 90- to 120-year-old 1.4 km² forest predominantly of Norway spruce (Picea abies) with some Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris) and small amounts of beech (Fagus sylvatica) and oak (Quercus robur). The site, within a landscape of glacial end moraine topography, is on loamy sands, with weakly- or moderately-podzolic brown earth soils. The site is affected by air pollution from Hamburg. The book comprises eight main section, outlining experimental design and methodology, and presenting results from wet and dry deposition studies. After brief introductory sections which describe the site, the research concepts and coordination between the collaborating institutes, the chapters are: 5. Experimental procedures (23-43 pp.; 53 ref.) - sampling of rainwater, throughfall, particulates, gas measurements and trace elements, and analytical techniques employed; 6. Methodology for the determination of atmospheric deposition and of fluxes within the ecosystem compartments (45-55 pp.; 27 ref.); 7. Trace elements in rainwater: concentrations and wet deposition (57-72 pp.; 23 ref.); 8. Deposition of anions and cations via precipitation (73-80 pp.; 7 ref.); 9. Trace elements in size-fractionated particulates: concentrations and dry deposition into a forest ecosystem (81-91 pp.; 18 ref.); 10. Total deposition of trace elements (93-95 pp.; 3 ref.); 11. Element supply and element fluxes in the forest compartments (97-125 pp.; 5 pp. of ref.); 12. Concentration and deposition of gaseous pollutants: SO2, NO2, NO,NH3 and O3 (127-148 pp.; 26 ref.); and 13. Impact of gaseous pollutants on the forest ecosystem (149-166 pp.; 32 ref.). A fourteenth chapter summarizes the results and discusses conclusions.
